DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. AGRICULTURAL GROUP TO VISIT TAIWAN TO PROMOTE EXPOSITION

TEXT.P: A U.S. agricultural delegation is scheduled to visit Taiwan early next week to promote an international supermarket industry exposition to be held in Chicago next May, sources from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Friday.

The delegation of officials from the National Association of State Departments of Agriculture (NASDA) will visit Taiwan Monday and Tuesday to promote the 2001 International Supermarket Industry Convention and Educational Exposition, officials from the AIT's Agricultural Trade Office said.
The four-member delegation will be led by Leon C. Graves, NASDA president and commissioner of the Vermont State Department of Food and Agriculture, the AIT officials noted.
The exposition, being jointly sponsored by the NASDA and the U.S. Food Marketing Institute, will be held May 6-8 at McCormick Place in Chicago, Illinois, the officials said.
More than 1,400 exhibitors representing food products and consumer packaged goods, as well as retail equipment, merchandising systems, and services are expected to take part in the show.

Meanwhile, top food industry executives from around the world will gather in Chicago at the same time to take part in 30 seminars led by world-renowned experts in the food industry, the AIT officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Nov. 1, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: EU URGED TO BEEF UP POLITICAL TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By P. C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament (EP) passed an amendment to its resolution on the European Union's (EU's) diplomatic and security policy Thursday urging the 15-member bloc to strengthen political relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan.
The European Parliament, the EU's legislative arm, passed the pro-Taiwan amendment, which was jointly initiated by EP members Daniel Marc Cohn-Bendit and Monica Frassoni, with a vote of 482-5.

The amended resolution urges the Council of Ministers, the EU's decision-making body, to find feasible ways to forge closer political ties with Taiwan with a view to helping press for early resumption of dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China as well as supporting Taiwan's young democracy.
The revised resolution also once again pushes the European Commission, the EU's executive arm, to open a representative office in Taipei, the ROC's largest city.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 5,342.06.

Affected by a plunge in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,173.02 and began to go up following a rebound in both electrical shares and shipping stocks. The bourse fluctuated between 5,342.06 and 5,163.23 during trading.

A total of 1.52 billion shares worth NT$57.67 (US$1.75 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.67 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of US$57.39 billion (US$1.74 billion).

Only two of the eight major categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 0.9 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.2 percent. Plastics and chemical shares remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 2 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.7 percent, and construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 279 to 214, with 111 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMOTIONAL REMARKS NOT CONDUCIVE TO BETTERING CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: A ranking Mainland Affairs Council official said Friday that the sulky, emotional remarks uttered by one of Beijing's spokesmen Thursday toward Taiwan are by no means conducive to bettering cross-strait relations.

MAC Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said cross-strait discrepancies can only be resolved through patience and a rational approach, adding that Beijing's emotional terming of the latest consensus reached by the Republic of China President's Advisory Group on Cross-Strait Relations as a "grotesque word game" is not helpful to improving cross-strait relations.

He added that Taiwan has had a more realistic and practical approach toward the development of cross-strait relations, saying that Taipei's opening of direct trade, postal, and transportation links between the ROC-controlled outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese port cities and also its granting of permission to mainland Chinese media organizations to establish permanent offices in Taiwan are moves conducive to strengthening ties across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen again called for the Beijing authorities to return to the negotiating table without setting preconditions in order to resume an institutionalized negotiating mechanism across the strait so as to jointly address the differences between the two sides.

MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Thursday expressed regret over Beijing's response to the "three acknowledgments and four recommendations" that were reached by the inter-party President's Advisory Group on Cross Strait Relations.

Tsai urged the Beijing authorities to pay more attention to the proposals offered by the advisory group and exert a little more effort in trying to find "room for maneuver" that the proposals may have created in further developing cross-strait relations. "Ample room is needed to make good cross-strait interactions possible," she added.

Academic Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who leads the presidential advisory group on cross-strait relations, said Beijing made the regrettable remarks because policymakers there do not understand Taiwan.

Zhang Mingqing, spokesman of the Beijing State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, blasted the advisory group's proposals calling for a steady handling of relations with mainland China as "nothing but empty words that were grotesque."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIPEI CAB FARES ON THE ROAD

TEXT.P: New cab fares in the greater Taipei area, approximately 12.5 percent higher than before, went into effect Friday.

The first day of the implementation of the new taxi fare plan turned out to be chaos, as about one-third of the taxies in Taipei City did not follow the new tariff and still charged passengers at the old rate.

"Why bother to argue with passengers over the calculation of the new fares, which are as hard as the X-Files to solve, with new meters yet to be installed at a time when the economy is in bad shape," was the complaint of many of the city's taxi drivers.
Under the new plan, the flagfall has been formally increased to NT$70, with the flagfall travel distance shortened from the current 1.65 km to 1.5 km.

The plan, devised by the City Government Committee Supervising Rates of Public Utilities and Transportation, also sees the distance traveled for each meter click for each additional NT$5 shortened to 300 meters from the current 350 meters.
Another NT$5 is added every two minutes when the taxi is traveling at less than 5 km per hour, while an additional 20 percent surcharge is tacked on between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m.
City government officials called on taxi passengers to pay the cab fares based on a fee table posted in each taxi until such time as new meters can be installed, which will take about four months.
There are about 70,000 taxies in the greater Taipei area, which includes Taipei County, as well as Keelung City, which is located to the northeast of Taipei.

According to a survey conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in September, Taiwan taxi drivers made a gross average of NT$42,000 per month in 1999, for a net income of around NT$28,000 after expenses.

The gross average, however, has been considerably lower in recent months due to a variety of factors, including the plummeting stock market, the sagging economy and the increased number of taxi drivers in light of a higher unemployment rate in other sectors, according to taxi drivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHIPOWNERS COLD-SHOULDER 'MINI 3 LINKS'

TEXT.P: With only a month to go before the scheduled opening of direct "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait, most local shipping companies are adopting a "wait-and-see" attitude toward the new measure, shipping sources said Friday.

Shipping industry executives said even the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is not sure whether the planned direct trade, mail and shipping links between Taiwan's two frontline islands and select mainland Chinese ports, commonly known as "mini three links", would bring fat profits to local shipowners.

The opening of "mini three links" is being planned in accordance with the provisions of the Statute on Promoting Outlying Islands Development, which was passed early this year under the previous Kuomintang government.

The statute was designed to help boost economic development on Taiwan's major outlying islands of Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu. After the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government was inaugurated in May, it continued to promote the plan and even unilaterally announced to open the "mini three links" at the beginning of next year.

As Beijing has long closed its door to dialogue with Taiwan, the two sides have never met to discuss the Taiwan-planned opening of direct "mini three links" between its Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province.

Although Beijing reportedly has passively agreed to allow Fujian to open its Xiamen and Mawei ports for the Taiwan-proposed "mini three links," many Taiwan shipping companies still feel uncertain about the prospects of the new open-door measure.
Chang Chai-hsing, president of the Taiwan Provincial Federation of Shipping Industry Associations, said some local shipping firms truly have made preparations for operating the new shipping routes.

"Nevertheless, as far as I know, even these companies are still adopting a wait-and-see attitude toward the new services," Chang said, adding that the majority of local shipowners have shown lukewarm interest in getting into the new shipping market.

Chang said as Taiwan will only open Kinmen's Liaolo port and Matsu's Fuao port for direct shipping services with Fujian's Xiamen and Mawei ports, respectively, the ROC's large shipping companies, such as Yangming Marine Transport Corp. and Evergreen Marine Corp., have little interest in the new measure.

As for smaller-scale shipping firms, Chang went on, they are worried that they may be not competitive enough to vie for new shipping deals with their mainland counterparts following the opening of the new Liaolo-Xiamen and Fuao-Mawei shipping routes.
"Given mainland China's cheap labor, mainland shippers have an upperhand in price war with our shipping firms after the new shipping services open," Chang explained.

Moreover, Chang said, as the ROC's Coast Guard has stepped up inspections of ships sailing between Taiwan and its defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu in preparation for the opening of "mini three links," local shippers are complaining that the new security checks have increased their operational costs.

The intensified security checks are part of the ROC's efforts to ensure its national security and thwart any smuggling attempt after the opening of the "mini three links," MOTC Vice Minister Ho-Chen Tan said Friday.

Ho-Chen said the ministry is scheduled to finalize a package of measures governing the "mini three links" in the next few days and that the Cabinet is expected to formally unveil the package on Dec. 15.

Ho-Chen said once the package is promulgated, local shipping companies can formally file applications for operating regular, scheduled shipping services between Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, which lies opposite Taiwan.

Ho-Chen said the MOTC has also asked prospective operators to present their preliminary business blueprints for the ministry's reference from Friday. The blueprints should outline the ports and vessels to be used in their new shipping services as well as timetables and shipping charges.

According to Ho-Chen, MOTC Minister Yeh Chu-lan will make inspection tours of Kinmen and Matsu on Dec. 11 and Dec. 13, respectively, to review their preparations for the opening of direct shipping links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SURGEONS COMPLETE RARE HEART AUTOTRANSPLANT

TEXT.P: A female heart patient who received rare heart autotransplant surgery four months ago checked out of Cheng Hsin General Hospital Friday, going home with a strong "new" heart.

At a check-out press conference, the patient, a 60-year-old housewife surnamed Chen, said "to be alive is great" and that she is obliged to the Cheng Hsin heart surgery team led by Dr. Wei Jeng that enabled her to lead a healthy life again.

According to Wei, the director of Cheng Hsin's Heart Center, he and his team have previously completed two such heart autotransplants over the past two years, probably the only two cases in the world.

The team performed the first successful case in November 1998 on a 37-year-old man who suffered a ruptured left ventricle following mitral valve replacement. He has recovered satisfactorily with two years follow-up. The second such case was successfully completed in early August this year.

When performing autotransplant surgery, doctors first remove the defective heart from the patient's chest, "repair" it in an operation lasting no longer than six hours, and then put back the heart, according to Wei.

Wei began to explore the possibility of bench repair of left ventricular rupture by autotransplant several years ago. During the period, the two cases suffered left ventricle rupture following mitral valve replacement and both patients were saved by the autotransplant method.
After receiving the autotransplant surgery, the heart patient is fitted with a pacemaker to enable him or her to sustain a normal heart beat, Wei added.
According to Wei, Edinburgh surgeons reported the first such case in 1993, but the surgery was unsuccessful.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARTIFICIAL REEF CONSTRUCTED FOR FISHERY CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: An artificial reef made from 10-plus discarded utility poles was sunk in waters off the northern Taiwan port of Tamshui Friday as part of the government's fishery resources conservation efforts.
The reef was created under a cooperative program between the Council of Agriculture's (COA's) Fishery Administration and state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower).

Fishery Administration Director Hu Hsing-hua said that under the cooperative project, a total of 4,000 similar structures will be sunk in the waters around Taiwan's coast over the next few years to facilitate fishery resources conservation.

"The new structures are expected to provide a foundation that is colonized by coral polyps and in time becomes thickly encrusted with living coral, providing an ecosystem in which marine life can thrive," Hu explained.

In view of dwindling fishery resources in Taiwan's offshore areas, the COA has launched a campaign to use artificial reefs for marine life and ecology conservation purposes. In the past, old fishing vessels and cement frames have been sunk to form artificial reefs. Earlier this month, a decommissioned warship was sunk in the waters off the northeastern county of Ilan for the first time, to aid in conservation measures.
Hu said turning retired warships and waste cement utility poles into reefs is even more economical than previous practices and more meaningful in terms of waste recycling.
Hu and Taipower Vice President Lai Shih-chang boarded a ship to witness the sinking of the utility poles off Tamshui.
"We hope the new artificial reef program will contribute to our ambitious plans to rebuild marine resources in our offshore areas and develop an offshore recreational fishing industry," Hu explained.

According to Hu, Taipower has provided the COA with 20,000 waste utility poles that will all be remodeled as artificial reefs to be sunk in waters off Taoyuan County's Yungan, Taichung County's Wuchia, Changhua County's Wangkung and Hualien County's Yenliao for conservation of fishery resources and other marine life.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEK REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN TAIWAN SUSPENDS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Hellenic Organization for the Promotion of Exports in Taiwan suspended its operations Friday due to a new policy of the Greek government, officials of the Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.
The Greek government announced Nov. 24 that it was closing all its representative offices abroad because of a shift in policy.

The Greek representative office in Taipei will be officially closed Jan. 1, 2001, MOFA officials said, adding that those who want to apply for visas to visit Greece can go to the Spanish Chamber of Commerce for the necessary application forms.
As for other consular issues related to Greece, the officials said MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs will make a public announcement via the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSIONAL HEAVYWEIGHT BACKS CONTINUED ARMS SALES TO ROC

TEXT.P: Four U.S. congressmen, including Floyd D. Spence, chairman of the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives, reaffirmed Friday their firm support for continued U.S. arms sales to the Republic of China.
The visiting U.S. congressional heavyweights made their assurances during a meeting with ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, according to sources close to the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Spence (R-SC) told the local press after a lunch meeting with Wu that he and his House colleagues are visiting Taiwan to see for themselves the island's latest political situation and its defense requirements.
Spence said that as far as he knows, many U.S. House members, including himself, staunchly support the ROC and its sustainable construction and development in Taiwan.

He reportedly also assured Wu that he attaches great importance to Taiwan's security needs and supports Taiwan's acquisition of adequate defensive weapons to safeguard its national security and stability.

For his part, Wu said the MND briefed the congressmen on the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait. He said he also exchanged views with the American visitors on the sales of U.S.-made defensive weapons and military equipment to Taiwan. However, the minister would not elaborate on any details concerning the arms sales issues.

Spence, heading the 16-member delegation, arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit. Taiwan is the last leg of the group's current Southeast Asian tour aimed at getting a first-hand understanding the latest regional situation and developments. The delegation visited South Korea, Singapore and Thailand before coming to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PICVUE HEAD OPTIMISTIC ABOUT LCD MARKET POTENTIAL

TEXT.P: Picvue Electronics Corp. President Jacob W. B. Lin, a heavyweight in the local LCD (liquid crystal display) industry, is optimistic about the product's market prospects and has vowed to make his company one of Taiwan's leading high-tech firms.
In a recent interview with CNA, Lin not only talked enthusiastically about his panoramic plans for Picvue, but also expressed his full confidence in his LCD business.

According to Lin, Picvue has also invested in a spin-off business -- Picvue International Opto Electronics Ltd. (PIOE) -- which will set up three furnaces in five years to produce substrates as part of Picvue's efforts to expand its global market share of cellular phone panels and increase its business revenues.
Following is the text of Lin's exclusive interview with CNA:
Q: Can you tell us about the market share currently enjoyed by the Picvue-made LCDs in the world's personal digital assistant (PDA) sector and disclose the company's revenue target for 2001?

A: As the world's No. 1 maker of LCDs for PDA use, Picvue plans to lift its global market share from the current level of 38 percent to 42 percent. We have received a large order of 10 million LCDs for PDAs from the United States-based Palm this year.

Although Picvue can handle the order on its own, I don't think that over-reliance on each other is good. I prefer to go "slowly and stably" in upgrading production and increasing investment. Against this backdrop, I am planning to lift Picvue's market share in PDA to around 40 percent next year.

Picvue and Palm have maintained very close business relations, since orders from Palm contribute 55 percent of Picvue's total LCD output, while Picvue supplies 45 percent-55 percent of Palm's demand for LCDs.

At the same time, I am also trying to seek a second production source for Palm, such as Japan's Epson and South Korea's Samsung. I am not worried that there will be more competitors and I firmly believe that Picvue should grow together with its clients.

In addition to Palm, Handspring is also a major source of orders for Picvue. Currently, Picvue is the sole LCD supplier for Handspring's PDAs and I am also looking for a second manufacturing source for Handspring.

We estimate that Picvue's business revenue will reach NT$6 billion (US$182 million) this year, up 40 percent over the 1999 level. We forecast that the figure will rise to NT$10 billion (US$304 million) for 2001, 90 percent of which will be generated by PDA-used LCDs.
Q: What is Picvue's market potential for LCM (liquid display module) designed for cellar phones?

A: Picvue manufactured about 700,000 LCMs for cellar phones each month in the first half of this year, while its single-month production level has been doubled to 1.5 million units at present. We estimate that Picvue-made LCMs for mobile phones will grab 4.5 percent-5 percent of the global market in 2000 and that the percentage will grow to 10 percent in 2001.
Q: Will mainland China pose a threat to Taiwan's STN (super-twisted liquid crystal display) industry?

A: Japan is currently the world's strongest STN maker. As it is a fast-changing and highly customized industry, neither mainland Chinese nor South Korean manufacturers are able to meet the high international standards of fidelity, color and contrast.

Some South Korean firms, including Goldstar and Hyundai, have withdrawn from the industry. I think mainland Chinese companies may probably follow suit by jumping over the STN-LCD sector and directly shifting to the TFT-LCD (thin-film transistor liquid crystal display) sector.
Q: What do you think of the local TFT-LCD industry's future and the outlook of PIOE?

A: TFT-LCD is a very good invention, which can be widely applied in a wide range of new products, such as OLED and LCOS (liquid crystal on silicon). I think that TFT-LCD will be fully developed in the coming 20 or 30 years. Picvue has not yet started to manufacture the product because of market uncertainties, but the market demand for substrates remains quite clear.

Meanwhile, PIOE is scheduled to begin mass production of substrates in the second quarter of 2002 -- when construction of its first planned furnace is complete -- by using the overflow down-draw technology developed by the United States based Coring Corp.

PIOE has recruited many engineers from Japan, the United States, and Germany to join forces with its own researchers in the overflow down-draw manufacturing process. As long as the company's first furnace is able to begin operating as scheduled, PIOE will immediately invest in the second and the third furnaces.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR HALVING LEGISLATIVE SEATS GAINING MOMENTUM

TEXT.P: Support for a proposal to halve the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan was seen to be gathering momentum Friday, with support from across the political spectrum.

Kuo Su-chun of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), Feng Ting-kuo of the New Party (NP), and Chou Hsi-wei of the People First Party (PFP) said at a joint press conference that they are in favor of the proposal first initiated by Chang Hsueh-shun of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Chang said that he recently ran ads in the media for just one day proposing to half the present 225 legislative seats to 113 and was "inundated with support" from the public for the idea.
Chang said that most people have a negative impression of legislators and their poor performance and that the time is ripe for such a proposal.
Kuo noted that in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, the number of legislators who attend sessions regularly hovers at around 100.
Feng echoed her views and added that he is in support of the single-seat, two-votes parliamentary election system, which means casting one vote for the candidate and one for the political party.
Chou said that he will seek the consensus of the opposition parties on the halving of the number of legislative seats.

The widespread support came in the wake of a poll released by the prestigious monthly Common Wealth which shows that the public is pessimistic about the country's future and that up to 60 percent of the people believe that the Legislative Yuan is the source of the national chaos.
Meanwhile, Chang, who initiated the proposal, held a separate press conference with his DPP colleagues in the Legislative Yuan.

He said that after the scaling-down of the Taiwan provincial government, the number of legislators has ballooned, but the legislature has not become a cornerstone of political stability. Instead, he said, it has become the culprit that hinders national progress, adding that the people are beginning to detest the legislators for their low efficiency and shoddy performance.

Chang went on to say that according to his estimates, halving the number of legislators would save the nation up to NT$4.4 billion (US$133.33 million). This, together with the campaign expenditure saved would amount to NT$10 billion (US$303.03 million).

DPP Legislator Cho Jung-tai said that national reform has become a more urgent priority, noting that there is only one parliamentarian for every 250,000 people in Japan and one parliamentarian for every 150,000 people in South Korea. In comparison, there is one legislator for every 100,000 people in Taiwan, he said.
Cho claimed that if the number could be raised to one legislator for every 200,000 people, then the quality of the Legislative Yuan would improve.

However, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said cutting the number of legislators would not necessarily upgrade legislative performance, pointing out that in the previous first and second terms of legislators, the number of legislators only amounted to 100-plus, although the chaos was twice as bad.

Wang said that it is too early to talk about halving the number of lawmakers, although he also acknowledged that some legislators do sometimes give "outlandish performances" and fail to meet the expectations of the voters.
Wang also noted that the KMT, the largest opposition party that holds sway in the legislature, has yet to discuss the idea.
In addition, the proposal would involve revising the Constitution, which he said would not be easy.
DPP legislators led by Chang said they will launch a petition to support a constitutional revision to halve the number of legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL SERVANTS SAY THEY ARE 'DENIED RESPECT' BY NEW GOVERNMENT: POLL

TEXT.P: Some civil servants have complained that they have been denied respect under the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led administration, according to a qualitative study released Friday.

The report was prepared by the Sun Yun-suan Cultural Foundation, which examined the findings of two seminars held in November with the participation of 17 staff members of central and local administrative agencies.

According to the report, the biggest source of work stress for public functionaries currently lies in what they say is the failure of their politically appointed superiors to respect their professional expertise.

The report said since the new DPP administration took the helm in the Republic of China's first democratic transfer of power between different parties in May, the phenomenon of "laymen leading professionals" has become all too common in various government agencies.

Some civil servants were quoted as saying that several newly appointed Cabinet ministers or department chiefs have sacrificed professional dignity simply for short-lived partisan political gains in policy formulation and enforcement.
Many of those participating in the seminar also complained that their superiors' disrespect and distrust of existing systems or practices has seriously affected their morale.

Worse yet, the report said, some new political appointees have often derided them as "old bureaucrats ..." and rejected their opinions or suggestions simply because they joined government service before their superiors.

Meanwhile, civil servants working at local-level government agencies complained that some elected local government chiefs have often asked them to perform non-public affairs, increasing their workload. And elected representatives' failure to abide by the law in promoting individual people's rights or interests has made it even more difficult to perform their duties in accordance with law, they added.

Another plight facing local-level civil servants is that their pay scale, official duties and powers have not yet been clearly defined since many provincial government agencies were merged following the "marginalization" of the Taiwan Provincial Government.

In conclusion, the report said that as independence, neutrality and impartiality in the civil service is the aspiration of Taiwan's society, political appointees of the new ROC government should exercise more prudence and wisdom in carrying out their official duties and should avoid prioritizing partisan interests instead of professional requirements in policy formulation.

Meanwhile, a public opinion survey, also conducted by the foundation, found that the majority of the respondents feel that the overall performance of the country's civil servants has improved in recent years.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL BACKS ROC PRESIDENT'S PREDICTION ON TAIWAN STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's prediction that Taipei-Beijing relations are unlikely to deteriorate within the next year is "grounded on reasonable deductions," a top ROC official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs said Friday.

In response to Beijing's criticism that Chen's prediction "pretends that everything is going well without regard for the truth," Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung raised supporting claims to back the president's words.

Chen said that the president's assertion has merit because overall assessments point to three major stabilizing factors, namely that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are focusing on their impending accession to the World Trade Organization, that a new U.S. government is about to be established while the mainland leadership is also about to face a transfer of power, and that mainland China is vying to host the 2008 Olympic Games.

The global community hopes that cross-Taiwan Strait relations will continue to develop toward stability, Chen added. Therefore, he continued, abrupt changes in bilateral relations are unlikely to occur in the short term.

Meanwhile, responding to Beijing's doubts about Taiwan's sincerity in granting permission to mainland Chinese media organizations to report from Taiwan on a regular basis, Chen clarified that the rule requiring mainland Chinese journalists to apply one month in advance of arriving in Taiwan is not set in stone and may be handled with flexibility under "special circumstances."

He went on to say that mainland journalists may leave the city they applied to visit as long as they inform the relevant authorities in advance "in order to ensure their safety." He did not elaborate.
Along the same lines, Chen said that the journalists may change their predetermined coverage plans as long as they inform officials of the change in advance.
Currently, two journalists of the mainland's official Xinhua News Agency have already received ROC approval to report from Taiwan under the new guidelines. They are expected to arrive early December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. URGED TO ADDRESS IMBALANCE IN CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY MIGHT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged the United States Friday to address squarely the growing imbalance of military might on either side of the Taiwan Strait.
The premier made the remarks when he received Floyd D. Spencer, chairman of the Committee on Armed Services of the U.S. House of Representatives.

Chang said that mainland China has continued to modernize its armed forces in recent years and that there is an imbalance in the military might on either side of the Taiwan Strait, posing a threat to Taiwan's security.
He urged the United States to continue to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act and to step up cooperation and exchanges with Taiwan's military.

The premier said that economic development is the lifeline of the nation and that the premise of sustained economic development is a stable political situation. The nucleus of such political stability, he continued, lies in cross-strait stability.

The easing of tensions in the Taiwan Strait and the maintenance of cross-strait stability is the goal of the government, he went on, adding that the government is sincere in its desire to conduct dialogue and exchanges with the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

He also expressed the hope that the United States will support Taiwan's bids for observer status in international organizations, saying that if Taiwan can join more such organizations, it would be beneficial to regional balance and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO EUROPE LAGGING BEHIND COMPETITORS: GOV'T STATS

TEXT.P: Taiwan exports to Europe from January to June exhibited continued growth but lagged behind those of the island's major Asian competitors, the Economics Ministry's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) announced on Friday.

According to BOFT statistics, the European import market grew by 17.05 percent in the same period. Leading the growth, mainland Chinese imports soared by 25.44 percent, allowing the mainland's slice of the European market to grow to 6.31 percent.

South Korean exports to Europe went up by 18.1 percent to give the country a 2.36 percent share of the European import market. Hong Kong followed at 15.66 percent growth in exports to Europe, while Taiwan lagged behind at 13.53 percent growth, leading to a market share drop to 2.45 percent.

According to the BOFT, mainland China's export growth and market share increase in electrical machinery, machine tools, transportation equipment, and steel products outstripped those of Taiwan by a wide margin; while South Korea's automobile, semiconductor, steel, and computer products drove that country's growth in exports to Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS PESSIMISM PREVAILING AMONG HIGH-TECH EXECUTIVES

TEXT.P: More than half of local high-tech industry executives responding to a recent opinion poll have expressed pessimism about Taiwan's future, the Global View monthly magazine said Friday.

The magazine conducted a telephone survey of senior executives of the top 200 technology firms listed on the over-the-counter (OTC) stock market from Nov. 10-14 with a view to exploring their opinions about the new Democratic Progressive Party-led administration's overall performance. A total of 66 valid replies were collected.
Poll results show that 53 percent of the respondents are not optimistic about Taiwan's future prospects.
Asked whether their companies would continue to make investments in Taiwan, 55.4 percent gave a negative answer and only 18.2 percent said "Yes."

According to the poll, 56.9 percent said they are dissatisfied with President Chen Shui-bian's performance since his taking office in May; only 10.9 percent said they are content with Chen's performance; and 30.8 percent gave a "so-so" evaluation of his administrative record.

Nevertheless, only 15.2 percent threw support behind an opposition-initiated campaign to oust Chen over his administration's abrupt decision to abort a partially built nuclear power plant, while 59.1 percent gave a thumbs-down to the "recall" drive.

As much as 65.2 percent also voiced opposition to the opposition-dominated legislature's plan to boycott the DPP administration's budget plan for fiscal 2001, and only 12.1 percent backed such a move. The DPP controls barely one-third of seats in the 225-member parliament.

The poll also found that Taiwan indeed faces a threat of a possible exodus of high-tech firms as 56.1 percent of the respondents said their companies plan to increase overseas investments to cope with a lingering domestic economic slowdown, while 25.8 percent said they plan to cut domestic investments in the face of sluggish business activities.

Among those intending to make outbound investments, 69.7 percent said they plan to launch their new investment projects in mainland China; Southeast Asia and the United States tie at second place, with 15.2 percent choosing either of them as favorite investment destinations.

Nearly 90 percent want the DPP administration to articulate its policy on high-tech industry development because public policy uncertainty has made many local firms adopt a "wait-and-see" attitude, according to the survey.

The three top elements cited by the respondents as factors affecting their business expansion plans for the 2000-2001 period were dwindling market demand triggered by an economic slowdown, flip-flops in the new government's policy formulation and enforcement, and lower-than-expected profitability of global high-tech stocks, in descending order.

Among measures planned by the new government, the scheduled opening of direct "mini three links" between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Mawei ports received most praise, while the decision to abort the fourth nuclear power plant was the least unpopular.

While 42.4 percent support government invention in stock market operations to prop up stock prices, 25.7 percent said the government should adopt a hands-off policy so that the stock market can exactly reflects domestic economic fundamentals.

DOC.HEADLINE: 500 FERTILIZER FACTORY WORKERS STAGE DEMONSTRATION IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Some 500 Chinese workers of a state-run fertilizer factory in Funing county in eastern Jiangsu province have participated in a sit-in demonstration before the county government building for two days, a human rights group said here Friday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said the workers began to demonstrate Thursday, after the state-run enterprise had been unable to pay their salaries for 13 months because of corruption and mismanagement. The Chinese authorities have sent 80 anti-riot police to maintain order at the site of demonstration.
The information center said that China has trained more armed police in anticipation of more similar public protests after the country joins the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS HIT 600,000 AFTER RE-REGISTRATION DRIVE

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT), Taiwan's largest political party, has reported that three months into its re-registration drive, the party's membership has topped 600,000.
Chao Shou-po, director general of the KMT's Organizational Development Committee, said that the members who re-registered reached 550,000, while another 59,000 new members have joined the party.
Chao said he was elated to learn of the large amount of "new blood" that has joined the KMT, saying that half of them are youngsters and women, exactly the groups that the KMT is actively targeting.
He said that in the next two months, the KMT will focus on soliciting new party members, adding that it will print a pamphlet to recruit more people into its camp.

The KMT, which used to boast of two million members, began the re-registered campaign in September after suffering a humiliating defeat in the March presidential election, in which its candidate finished a distant third. KMT officials explained that the re-registration drive was an effort to consolidate the party's support.

On whether former Premier Tang Fei, former KMT Secretary General Huang Kun-huei, and Huang Hwei-chen, former KMT spokesman, have re-registered, Chao said that he believes that Tang, who had openly said that he would re-register, will honor his words, while the two Huangs have also said they would re-register.

Asked whether the 14 KMT members that have joined the Cabinet headed by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party have re-registered, Chao only said that quite a few have done so. He added that in order to shield them from possible trouble, he could not divulge their names.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN WINS PEACE AWARD

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin I-hsiung received the Peace Award Friday from the Taipei branch of Rotary International for his lifelong pursuit of peace and a better future for Taiwan.
Lin, who was chosen from among four other candidates, received the award from writer Liu Hsia, who praised him for his dedication to harmony among different ethnic groups in Taiwan.

Lin, who served as chairman of the DPP until the party took power in Taiwan in May, chose to step down when his political career was at its peak. At the time, Lin said he was choosing "the road less traveled by" and returning to social work with less of a halo.

The lawyer-turned-politician, who has pursued social justice as his lifelong goal, was once jailed for protesting against the Kuomintang government's oppression of an opposition magazine, and suffered great pain when his twin daughters and mother were murdered 20 years ago, a crime which has never been solved.
Lin was not defeated by all of his suffering, and continued to work hard for the future of Taiwan, Liu pointed out.
Lin said that the driving force that has kept him doing all these things for Taiwan was love, adding that he hopes his award will be an inspiration to all the people who pursue peace with love.
The judges said they gave the award to Lin because the majority of his life has been dedicated to cultivating the "values of love and forgiveness."

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY: MOST TAIWAN FIRMS DISAPPROVE OF ADMINISTRATION'S PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan technological firms disapprove of the performance of President Chen Shui-bian's six-month-old administration, according to a survey released on Friday.

The poll, conducted by the mass-circulated monthly "Global Views," also found that the slowdown of the island's economy and the uncertainty around the government's policies are the two major factors holding sway over local firms' investment plans for the next two years.

More than half of those interviewed said the government's policies influenced, often negatively, their operations. As a result, more than 60 percent said they were increasing their investments in mainland China.

Although more than half of them said they were "not optimistic" about the island's economic and political prospects, and 56 percent said they were displeased with Chen's on-the-job performance. However, more than 60 percent of those interviewed opposed the idea of removing Chen through a legislative recall.

More than half of the respondents said they do not see a bright future for their investments in Taiwan, and more than 90 percent favor the establishment of direct trade and shipping links with mainland China, as well as a clear-cut government policy of encouraging the development of high-tech industries.
As to the government's top tasks, most of them named the direct trade and shipping links with mainland China and providing ample sources of electricity and water as the nation's top priorities.

As expected, the government's abolishment of the island's nuclear plant was disapproved of by most of the respondents, because sufficient electricity is vital to their future development, according to the survey.
However, the respondents have no preference for nuclear power. Instead, 59 percent of the surveyed said they will settle for any kind of electricity, as long as it fulfills their needs.

The surveyed firms were split on whether the government should intervene to prop up the plummeting stock market, with 42.4 percent putting the market nose-dive down to non-economic factors that need government actions to reverse; while 25.7 percent of them were against government intervention, saying a hands-off approach is the best policy.
Noting that the stock market failed to respond to the government's all-out efforts to boost it, some respondents said the bungled attempt has backfired and compromised the government's credibility.

Although the government should not be held solely responsible for the island's receding industries, the blame for failing to better the island's infrastructure should be laid squarely on the government, said many interviewees.
One interviewee complained about the labor shortage resulting from the government's policy to reduce the number of foreign laborers in the wake of surging numbers of unemployed domestic workers.
Others criticized the government's decision to limit the kinds of high-tech industry that qualify for tax breaks from 450 to 150.
The survey was conducted between Nov. 10-14 among the top 200 high-tech firms on the island, with valid responses from 66 of them.

DOC.HEADLINE: CURRENT CROSS STRAIT SITUATION MAY CHANGE IN ONE YEAR: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew has said that the current cross strait situation will not continue for another year.
Lee said that if mainland China permits the present situation to continue, it would be giving Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian a chance to deny Beijing's "one China" policy.
Lee made the remarks last Saturday in an exclusive interview with the Hong Kong-based satellite TV channel.

Lee said he believes that President Chen Shui-bian will further promote Taiwan's position in the international community and offer economic assistance to poor countries so as to obtain their diplomatic recognition and support, but mainland China's growing economic power will eventually defeat Taiwan in the diplomatic arena.

Asked about whether Taiwan will relax its "no hurry, be patient" policy restricting investment in mainland China after Beijing gains entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Lee said that Taiwan is already prepared to abandon that policy, and is only awaiting an ease in cross-strait tensions.
All of the enterprises in Taiwan hope that the government will relax the policy as soon as possible, so as to enable them to make meaningful investments in mainland China, Lee said.

If the policy is not changed, Taiwan businessmen should invest in mainland China through third countries such as the United States, Hong Kong and Japan, Lee suggested. He added that investment in mainland China will have complementary benefits for economic entities across the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan investors have chosen mainland China of the familiar customs and language in that country, not to mention lower costs of labor, electricity and water, Lee noted.

Lee also forecasted that the economy of Taiwan will not crash, but still needs to be watched for a while. Although Taiwan's stock index and real estate prices have declined, and domestic banks are holding huge amounts of opverdue loans, the situation is not as bad as expected, Lee said. He added that the situation will make a turn for the better when cross-strait relations have settled.

Asked whether the new U.S. president will change U.S. policy on the Taiwan Strait issue, Lee said that no matter who becomes the next U.S. president, that nation's "China policy" will remain unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE TO OPEN-DOOR POLICY TO MAINLAND TOURIST: MAC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has never wavered in its decision to allow mainland Chinese people to make sightseeing tours of Taiwan starting in June 2001, a senior official in charge of mainland affairs said Friday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said the government decided to open doors to mainland Chinese tourists from mid-2001 when former Premier Tang Fei was still in office.

"And incumbent Premier Chang Chun-hsiung has announced guiding principles for relevant government agencies to work out detailed regulations to govern sightseeing visits by mainland people," Chen said, adding that the principles include "limited number" and "group in and group out."

Chen said the new opening measure needs many accompanying rules to ensure national security and social stability. As for the number of mainland tourists to be allowed in, Chen went on, the government will make a decision after completing a further review of various social and economic control measures.
Currently, mainland Chinese are restricted to visiting relatives on the island or for cultural and educational exchanges. Applications are scrutinized on a case-by-case basis.
As both Taiwan and mainland China are expected to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) early next year, Chen said the climate for cross-Taiwan Strait engagement will change by then.

Against this backdrop, Chen said, the MAC is scheduled to refer to the Cabinet early next year a blueprint for opening direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links, also known as "major three links."

Meanwhile, Han Kun, deputy director of the National Security Bureau (NSB), the government has completed all necessary preparations and security deployment in connection with the imminent opening of direct "mini three links" between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports.

Han said all security personnel and some large-scale security check facilities will be stationed or installed at Kinmen's Liaolo port and Matsu's Fuao port by Dec. 15 in preparations for opening the "mini three links" on Jan. 1 as scheduled.

Han said the NSB has also long been studying security measures in anticipation of the opening of direct cross-strait "mini three links" and "major three links" as well as the entry of mainland tourists and the posting of mainland journalists for news coverage. "We have completed all necessary preparations to ensure our national security," he added.
Official tallies show that mainland Chinese have made about 540,000 trips to Taiwan since rapprochement began in 1988.

The new liberalization measures are part of efforts by Taipei to assuage and reconcile Beijing, which is still deeply suspicious of ROC President Chen Shui-bian's pro-independence past and has threatened to invade if the island declared statehood.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT APPLAUDS ADVISORY BODY'S RECOMMENDATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that his new administration will use the "three acknowledgments and four recommendations" of an advisory body on Taipei-Beijing relations as reference for the formation of its mainland China policy.

Chen explained to four visiting U.S. congressmen that the Republic of China's mainland policy is based on his May 20 inauguration speech, but that he invited Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh to head the President's Advisory Group on Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations in order to fine-tune that policy.

He openly praised the advisory group for being able to reach a consensus Sunday after seven meetings and many compromises, and he thanked the efforts of the 20-some members, who come from diverse political and academic backgrounds. "It marked a good beginning," he added.

Taiwan's first democratic transfer of political power took place only this year, over 200 years later than the United States, where Chen said it is already "a part of life." Being a "brand new start" for Taiwan, he added that the new administration would "unavoidably" face many difficulties.

However, Chen told Floyd D. Spence (R-SC), chairman of the U.S. House of Representatives Committee on Armed Services, that he is confident that he can improve relations with Beijing and achieve a breakthrough so as to normalize cross-strait relations. He added that he is certain Taiwan can overcome the current political turmoil to focus on economic development.

Chen congratulated the four congressmen on their successful re-election to office and thanked them for their support of pro-ROC bills in the U.S. House of Representatives. He urged them to continue supporting the Republic of China, and added that the two countries share common interests in the Asia Pacific region and in maintaining security in the Taiwan Strait.

Spence, accompanied by U.S. Representatives Solomon Ortiz (D-TX), Richard M. Burr (R-NC), and Silvestre Reyes (D-TX), told Chen that no matter which candidate eventually wins the U.S. presidential election, the U.S. government will continue to give the Republic of China all the necessary support and assistance.

Heading a 16-member delegation, Spence arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit, his fifth to Taiwan. This is the last leg of his group's current Asian tour, aimed at gleaning first-hand understanding of the latest regional developments. The delegation visited South Korea, Singapore, and Thailand before coming to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE CONVENE GENERAL ASSEMBLY IN VIETNAM

TEXT.P: The Confederation of Asia-Pacific Chambers of Commerce and Industry kicked off its 18th general assembly in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on Friday, with the participation of some 200 representatives from 22 member countries.
The delegation from Taiwan is led by Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce and honorary chairman of the confederation itself.

The meeting, which will focus on the development of energy, food supplies and information technology, aims to promote cooperation among member countries and the development and prosperity of the Asian-Pacific region.
The confederation's members also include Japan, South Korea, Russia, India, Malaysia, and Pakistan. It covers 2.5 million enterprises across the Asia-Pacific region.
The confederation set up its permanent secretariat in Taipei in 1980, and it is the only international organization based in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SPIES INCREASINGLY THREATEN TAIWAN'S SECURITY: NSB OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China has stepped up espionage against Taiwan, posing increasing threats to the Republic of China's national security, a senior security officer said Friday.

Han Kun, deputy director of the National Security Bureau, told a seminar at the military-run Fushingkang College that mainland Chinese spies have been endeavoring to infiltrate Taiwan's businesses, government and armed forces.

Han said since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) took the ROC's presidency in the island's first democratic transfer of power in May, mainland China has worked out new measures to cope with Taiwan's new political circumstances.

For one thing, Han said, mainland China has changed its previous policy of "no contacts" with the DPP after the pro-independence party came to power. Beijing has since working to forge ties with influential DPP heavyweights.

In anticipation of possible frequent transfer of power between different political parties in democratic Taiwan, Han said, mainland China has decided to prioritize high-level contacts with ruling party heavyweights.
In addition, Han said, mainland China will also used every possible channel and means to cultivate pro-Beijing elements in all major opposition parties.

Han went on to say that every year, more than 3,000 mainland intelligence officers visit Taiwan under disguised identities. "During their visits, our security officers have consistently kept close monitoring of their activities here," he noted.
Nevertheless, Han said some 2,000 illegal mainland immigrants remain unaccountable, posing a potential threat to Taiwan's security.
Since Taiwan relaxed restrictions on travel by mainlanders to the island in 1988, mainland people have made 540,000 visits to Taiwan, Han said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO REFRAIN FROM FOREIGN EXCHANGE SPECULATION

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) urged the public Friday to have confidence in the New Taiwan dollar, amid widespread expectation that the currency may slide further.
Chou A-ting, director general of the CBC'c Foreign Exchange Department, said that the worst pressure on the NT dollar has passed.

He made the remarks to counter public expectations that the local currency will continue sliding. Fears about the NT dollar's stability have triggered frenzied buying of foreign currencies, which in turn have driven the Taiwan dollar down even further.

The New Taiwan dollar closed at 33.036 to the greenback on Taipei's foreign exchange market Friday, up NT$0.010 from Thursday. Dealers attributed the week's first day of NT dollar appreciation to general weakness in the U.S. dollar and CBC intervention.

Local media had reported that foreign exchange banks have predicted that outstanding foreign currency deposits in major financial institutions in Taiwan will prove to have hit NT$1.1 trillion as of the end of November, which would set a record high.
But Chou said that the media reports on foreign exchange deposits may be exaggerated.

He cautioned those who have U.S. dollar deposits to be careful about the risk of exchange rate fluctuations, so as to avoid losses. The media should also refrain from exaggerating the currency situation so as not to add fuel to the flames.

On the possible prospects for the U.S. dollar, he said that though the greenback is still strong, economic growth in the U.S. has eased, and whether the U.S. dollar can maintain its momentum is in question.
In addition, if the U.S. dollar loses steam, it will effect the flows of U.S. capital to Asia and Europe, he said, adding that this situation also needs further observation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-BORN CANADIAN CITIZEN SENT TO LABOR CAMP IN CHINA

TEXT.P: A 60-year-old Chinese-born Canadian citizen, who is a Falun Gong practitioner, has been sentenced to three years in an "education through labor" camp in mainland China without trial, a human rights group said here Friday.

The Falun Gong practitioner, Zhang Kunlun, emigrated to Canada in 1989, and became a citizen of that country in 1995. He went to China on Chinese passport in 1996 in order to teach sculpture in a university, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said.

The information center said Zhang's sentence is an indication that China is getting tough with Falun Gong practitioners living in foreign countries. Teng Chunyan, a Chinese-born American resident who is also a practitioner of Falun Gong, was put on trial in Beijing on Nov. 23.

The center also said Friday that two more Falun Gong practitioners died recently while in police custody. They were Meng Qingxi, 42, of Weifang county in eastern Shandong province, and Kung Qinghuang, 33, of Jiansui county in southern Yunan province.

Their deaths brought the number of Falun Gong practitioners who died in police custody in China to at least 72, it added. China outlawed Falun Gong and began to crack down on the spiritual sect in July, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE HEAD EMPHASIZES IMPORTANCE OF MILITARY'S SECURITY

TEXT.P: As exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China become closer, "security of troops" in Taiwan is increasing in importance, said Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen Friday.

Claiming that a "war without shooting" is already underway between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu warned attendees at a Taipei symposium on "security of troops" that Beijing is approaching Taiwan with a two-pronged policy -- disarming the public by making the gesture of reaching out, while reserving military force as the last resort to bring the island under its domination.
Wu said that the security of the military is the focus of any war, and should not be ignored either at the frontline or at the rear -- either in peacetime or war.

He stressed that the military is the cornerstone of national security amid Taiwan's power transition, which has been fraught with political and economic turmoil, as well as the presence of Beijing's persistent military threat.
Wu said Beijing has stepped up its pressure on Taiwan by giving military leaders a leading role in shaping its policy toward Taiwan.

Citing examples to support his claims, Wu said that Gen. Zhang Wannian, vice chairman of Beijing's Central Military Commission, now doubles as the deputy head of the Central Leading Group for Taiwan Affairs; and Major General Wang Zaixi has been appointed as deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the mainland's State Council.

Beijing has also warned through the mass media in Hong Kong that a war with Taiwan is inevitable within five years, said Wu, who reiterated the ROC armed forces' long-standing stance of "preparing for, but not provoking war."
The rapid economic and political changes on the island have also compromised the security of its troops by exposing soldiers to various political points of view, said the defense head.
He urged the symposium to raise the public's awareness about the security of the military, and the help promote the safety of the nation's soldiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
37 National Tsinghua University professors issue a joint statement blaming the scrapping of 4th nuclear power plant as 'distorting professionalism.'
The China Times:
Floyd D. Spence, chairman of U.S. House Committee on Armed Services, reaffirms U.S. commitment to Taiwan.
The United Daily News:
WTO entry will force 100,000 local farmers to leave farming industry.
The Liberty Times:
Mainland China adopts different strategies to deal with Taiwan's three major parties -- divide Kuomintang, attack the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and infiltrate People First Party.
The China Post:
PRC spies infiltrate ROC politics, military: NSB.
The Taiwan News:
'3 big links' planned for 2001 second half.
The Taipei Times:
Tourism opening to speed 'three links.'

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 64.71 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Saturday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 64.71 points to close at 5,277.35.
Market turnover amounted to NT$53.05 billion (US$1.61 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Saturday, Dec. 2, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SECURITY ESSENTIAL TO ASIA'S STABILITY: U.S. CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's security is essential to stability in Asia and is also in the national interest of the United States, said visiting U.S. Congressman Floyd D. Spencer (R-SC) Saturday.

Spencer, chairman of the House of Representatives Committee on Armed Services, said that after exchanging views with senior leaders in Taiwan over the past two days, he is now further convinced of the critical importance of maintaining peace and stability in East Asia and of moving toward a peaceful resolution of the future of Taiwan.

Spencer, heading a 16-member U.S. delegation including four congressmen, arrived in Taipei Thursday for a three-day visit. The group is here to see for themselves the latest situation in Taiwan politics, as well as the island's defense requirements.
In his departure statement, Spencer said he is pleased to see that democracy in Taiwan is continuing to develop and is becoming an increasingly powerful influence in the region.

"Now more than ever, supporting democracy in East Asia remains a priority for the United States. As such, any change in Taiwan's status should come only with the consent of the people of Taiwan," Spencer stressed.

He expressed his gratitude to the people of Taiwan for the extraordinary display of hospitality they extended to his delegation, and said he believes that the visit had strengthened the long-standing bonds of friendship between the United States and Taiwan.

During his stay in Taiwan, Spencer met with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, who took the opportunity to urge the United States to address squarely the growing imbalance of military might across the Taiwan Strait.

Chang urged Washington to continue providing Taiwan with defensive weapons, as mainland China has continued to modernize its armed forces in recent years. The premier stressed that the growing imbalance in military power across the strait poses an evident threat to Taiwan's security.
On another occasion, Spencer met with ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen. They exchanged views on the sales of U.S.-made defensive weapons and military equipment to Taiwan.

Spencer reportedly assured Wu that he attaches great importance to Taiwan's security needs and supports Taiwan's acquisition of adequate defensive weapons to safeguard its national security and stability.
This marked Spencer's fifth visit to Taiwan since 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR BANKER PITCHES FOR OPENING DOOR TO MAINLAND CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Chen Shih-meng proposed Saturday that Taiwan open its doors to mainland Chinese capital under appropriate regulations.
Chen said he is convinced that the "open-door" measure can help allay misgivings that ongoing mainland China-bound investment fever may hallow out Taiwan's economic clout.

The economics professor-turned-banker offered the recommendation after attending a seminar on how to help local industries secure adequate capital to finance their business operations and expansion. The seminar was jointly organized by the CBC and the Ministry of Finance.
Chen pointed out that the government can impose different ceilings for mainland investments in different local industries based on their distinctive features and requirements.

Taiwan currently still bans entry of mainland capital. But actually, some mainland China-based companies are believed to have remitted money into Taiwan for various investment projects via third places under disguised corporate identities.
Chen said if Taiwan legally opens doors to mainland capital under well-designed regulations, such "undercover" practices can be eradicated and some of local industries may also be given a boost.

As for the mainland-bound investment mania, Chen said relevant government agencies should endeavor to improve the general domestic business climate in addition to offering incentives to attract local companies to retain their business roots at home.
The outspoken former Taipei mayor further said Taiwanese investment in mainland China does not just involve issues of capital outflow.

"The most serious problem lies in mainland China's hostility toward Taiwan. With so many Taiwan-owned companies on the mainland, we fret that Beijing may one day pressure Taiwanese business people with interests on the mainland to force our government to yield to its negotiation terms," Chen noted.

The current Democratic Progressive Party-led government is facing pressure from local industry executives to scrap the "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy, adopted by the previous Kuomintang government, to allow them greater freedom to invest on the mainland to sharpen their competitive edge in the global market.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, is now reviewing the "no haste" policy and expected to announce further relaxed mainland investment regulations before the end of this year.

Under its "no haste" policy, Taiwan imposes an investment ceiling of US$50 million per project and bans businesses from investing in certain strategic industries there due to national security considerations.

Attracted by cheap land and labor as well as a common language and culture, Taiwan investors have poured an estimated US$40 billion into the mainland over the past decade. Funds were funneled into the mainland through Hong Kong or a third country.
