DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 64.71 points to close at 5,277.35.
The bourse opened at 5,346.93, and fell due to selling pressure on electronics shares. The index fluctuated between 5,379 and 5,260.97 during trading.

A total of 1.72 billion stocks worth NT$53.05 billion (US$1.61 billion) changed hands, compared with the previous trading session which saw 1.52 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$57.67 billion (US$1.75 billion).

Half of the eight major categories posted losses, with electronics shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.3 percent, and textile issues at 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.9 percent, construction stocks at 0.7 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 286 to 210, with 108 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Saturday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 179 points to close at 5,271, with 9,165 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 decreased 179 points to finish at 5,261, with 98 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 194 points to close at 5,374, with only one contract traded.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Saturday at 5,450 for December, 5,440 for next January, 5,568 for next March, 5,451 for next June, and 5,868 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 9.7 points to close at 268.3, with 2,206 contract transactions, while January TE futures decreased 9.7 points to finish at 268.2, with 36 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 TE futures fell 8.7 points to close at 268.2, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures lost 14.6 points to close at 649.2, with 916 contract transactions, while January 2001 TF futures moved down 20 points to finish at 645, with seven contracts changing hands.
March 2001 TF futures plunged 20.4 points to close at 651, with three contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG SEEKS TO BECOME GATEWAY TO TAIWAN FOR MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: With the Republic of China government talking about opening Taiwan to tourists from mainland China, the southern port city of Kaohsiung is actively seeking to become the gateway to Taiwan for such mainland visitors.
After years of discussion, the ROC government decided recently that tourists from mainland China will be allowed to enter Taiwan beginning next June for leisure and sightseeing trips.

The decision has prompted people in Kaohsiung's tourism industry to accelerate moves to grab as large a slice of the potentially lucrative tourism pie expected with the arrival of holiday makers from the mainland.

In a meeting with officials from the Kaohsiung City Government, local tourism industry representatives appealed for administrative assistance from the government to help them clench the opportunity to revive sagging tourism in the southern city.

The representatives said Kaohsiung should be made the gateway to Taiwan for mainland Chinese tourists, as the port city is the leading industrial and business city in southern Taiwan, as well as a transportation center with an international airport and a harbor that boasts the world's third largest container handling capacity.
In addition, they said, hotel accommodations and other expenses are much lower than the northern city of Taipei, the island's capital.
Lee Wen-liang, director of Kaohsiung City's Development Bureau, urged Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to render support to the city's tourism industry.

Meanwhile, meeting participants also suggested that Kaohsiung strive to become the key Taiwan seaport in conducting direct transportation links with mainland China once the so-called "Big three direct links" between Taiwan and mainland China are opened, which will likely happen in June next year at the earliest.
Concurring with the representatives, Hsieh said he will do his utmost to help realize their expectations and turn Kaohsiung into a gateway to Taiwan for mainland Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS TO VISIT TAIPEI OVER CURRENCY EXCHANGE RATE ISSUES

TEXT.P: U.S. Treasury Department officials in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs are scheduled to visit Taipei next week to gain a better understanding of the tendency of the New Taiwan (NT) dollar's exchange rate against the greenback.

Chou A-ting, director-general of the Central Bank of China's (CBC's) Foreign Exchange Department, said Saturday that the treasury officials' travel plan signifies U.S. concern about the recent depreciation streak of major Asian currencies against the U.S. dollar.

Because of an economic slowdown, the South Korean currency has depreciated to 1,208 won against one U.S. dollar, and the Japanese yen has remained weak in recent months due to economic woes and domestic political fray. Similar economic and political uncertainty has also driven down the NT dollar's exchange rate against the greenback to its four-year low this week.
Chou said all these developments have alarmed the U.S. Treasury Department and prompted it to decide to send its officials to Asia-Pacific countries for fact-finding visits.

When U.S. treasury officials arrive in Taiwan next week, Chou said he will brief them on Taiwan's hope that the central banks of all relevant Asia-Pacific countries cooperate closely to maintain regional currency and financial market stability.

Commenting on speculation that the recent depreciation of the Korean won could be attributed to the NT dollar's downward streak, Chou said some people might think that currency devaluation could help stimulate exports.

However, Chou stressed that the CBC has no intention of manipulating the currency exchange rate as a monetary policy tool to boost exports. He also reaffirmed the CBC's willingness to pool wisdom and expertise with its counterparts in other Asia-Pacific countries to help maintain currency market stability.
The NT dollar closed at 32.995 against the greenback Saturday, rising NT$0.041 from Friday's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR WARNS OF 'HOUSEHOLD FINANCIAL MELTDOWN'

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang legislator warned Saturday that a "household" financial meltdown may hit Taiwan's families before the arrival of the Lunar New Year, posing yet another threat to the country's sagging economy.
KMT Legislator Pan Wei-kang on Saturday urged the government to pay attention to factors that might contribute to a household financial crisis.

Pan said financial strain caused by the recent plummeting stock market has endangered all sectors of Taiwan society, including families. With the approach of the Lunar New Year, she added, company managers are obliged to have year-end bonuses ready, while borrowers are forced to clear their debts.

Quoting a recent online public opinion poll, Pan said two-thirds of those surveyed reported stock market losses over the past several months, 13.3 percent became debtors, and 6.5 percent said the slumping stock market had become a source of family quarrels and disputes.

In addition, she said, 22.6 percent of the respondents said they had lost all of their savings because of the plummeting stock market, while 31.3 percent said their fortunes had been substantially reduced.

According to results of the survey, the average wealth of each citizen dropped approximately NT$230,000 during the period, so the fortune meltdown for a four-member family would reach almost NT$1 million.
Average family savings were also dragged down by 22.64 percent over the past several months, Pan quoted the survey as indicating.
Pan warned that a household financial meltdown is threatening to undermine the nation's family morale and harmony, and is jeopardizing the careers and academic performances of family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP DEMANDS APOLOGY FROM LOCAL NEWSMAGAZINE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu's legal team announced Saturday that it will seek legal sanctions against a local magazine on her behalf if the magazine does not issue a public apology for accusing her of being a seditious rumormonger.

Lu herself was absent from the press conference, but she told reporters at the inauguration of a technology park in Taoyuan County that because she is the nation's deputy head of state, she does not wish to take legal actions unless absolutely necessary. However, she demanded a public apology from The Journalist newsmagazine.

Lu's six-member legal team and 13 legal advisers -- including her elder brother Lu Chuan-sheng, a practicing attorney -- declared that a careful examination of her residential telephone logs from Nov. 1-12 showed the vice president did not call up members of the media on Nov. 3 after 7 p.m. or at any other time to spread rumors about an alleged extramarital affair between President Chen Shui-bian and one of his female aides.
In its Nov. 16 issue, the magazine accused her of contacting a "senior media person" to spread such rumors.

Of the three phone calls Lu made after 7 p.m. during that period to members of the media, Lu's lawyers said that all three journalists have told them that none of the calls involved the alleged scandal.
President Chen had said in a Nov. 16 press release that he "has absolute faith in the vice president" and does not think that she is the source of the rumors.

Lu's legal team described The Journalist's reporting as "obviously false and malicious." Therefore, it continued, the magazine has until Dec. 10 to publish a half-spread front-page apology approved by Lu's lawyers in six newspapers, and also make public the full text of the apology via six television stations.

The lawyers added that The Journalist should also conduct a full investigation into the related "acts of negligence" by its reporters, writers, and editors and "deal out severe punishments" to show the news media's "sincerity in carrying out self-regulation and self-reflection."

The team accused the magazine of showing "actual malice" by claiming "without the slightest evidence" that Lu wanted to use the alleged presidential scandal to "finish off" the president and "flow with the momentum to scale new heights."

Furthermore, the lawyers continued, The Journalist's cover used a "libelous" headline without providing enough supporting proof to show that the claim was reasonable, thereby "seriously violating professional journalistic ethics" and again satisfying the definition of malice.
The headline read: "The one who stirred up the scandal and is secretly competing with the president unexpectedly turned out to be Annette Lu."

The team also alleged that a reporter from the magazine tried to encourage and induce the First Lady in a "pre-arranged trap" during an interview to articulate statements that would have been "unfavorable" to the vice president.

Despite repeated denials and clear warnings from the vice president's spokeswoman and a statement from the First Lady that she disagreed with the contents of the interview, The Journalist went ahead to publish and "exaggerate" the story in another "apparent manifestation" of malice, the lawyers said.
Regarding the litigation expenses that may be incurred, Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Eugene Chien said that they will be paid from various donations, and not from the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST OVERWEIGHT PEOPLE KEENLY HOPE TO LOSE WEIGHT FAST: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Most overweight people in Taiwan keenly hope for effective weight loss in just 15 days, and expect they can cut 5-7 kg of weight in just one month, according to the results of a recent poll.

The poll, conducted by Taipei Medical University (TMU), found that Taiwan citizens consider that the most effective ways of losing weight are regular exercise, eating only fruits and vegetables, and using weight-cutting equipment, in that order.

Although agreeing that exercise is the most effective way of losing weight, some 30 percent of the overweight respondents said they chose to take pills or traditional medicine to lose weight as a more convenient method, said pollsters from the university.

Some 24 percent of the respondents said they simply go to out-patient departments of general hospitals to seek medical help in losing weight, while some 30 percent said they opted for health foods and traditional medicines to cut down their weight.

The survey polled 1,031 overweight people who sought help in the TMU Family Medical Department and Weight-losing Department. It found that most of them became overweight because they could not resist the attraction of eating or because they did not know what made them fat.

According to Dr. Liao Chun-kai, chief physician at the TMU Family Medical Department, male patients are on average more satisfied and comfortable with their weight-loss results than female patients. He noted that men show greater confidence in themselves and in their physical prowess after losing weight.
Liao said effective weight-loss also helps improve the sex lives of married couples, adding that one-fourth of those surveyed said their marriage life is better now than before they lost weight.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES REPORTS THAT MADAGASCAR ASKED IT TO CLOSE REP. OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) denied Saturday news reports that the Republic of China Representative Office in Madagascar was closed down at the request of the Madagascar authorities.

MOFA announced last September that it was closing down the ROC office in that Indian Ocean island republic because the office had not worked well since its establishment in 1991, MOFA officials pointed out.

Recent local press stories have quoted foreign wire services as reporting that the Madagascar government asked the ROC to close down its office in Madagascar, thus indicating that relations between the ROC and Madagascar have been severed.
A MOFA spokesman said that the foreign wire reports were completely untrue.

The spokesman said that the Madagascar Foreign Ministry did not ask the ROC government to close down its representative office in Madagascar, and pointed out that Liu Shih, former ROC representative in Madagascar, has not been interviewed by the mass media.

The spokesman said that the ROC representative office in Madagascar had failed to accomplish its mission of efficiently promoting substantial relations with Madagascar. Additionally, the Madagascar authorities had failed to promote bilateral relations between the two countries in accordance with the ROC-Madagascar Special Agreement signed in 1991, the spokesman said.

After a series of consultations with the Madagascar authorities had no concrete results, the MOFA formally announced on Sept. 1 that the ROC office in Madagascar would be closed down on the same day, he said.
At present, a small group of staff members are still working in the office to handle business related to the closure.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FIRMLY OPPOSES TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: LIEN CHAN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan reiterated Saturday that the major opposition KMT will firmly oppose any move in the direction of Taiwan independence.

Lien also said that KMT is not a narrow-minded, biased, regional or racist political party, but is actually a party for all people of the nation. He added that the KMT should not be considered as only in support of the interests of ethnic mainland Chinese or those of ethnic Taiwanese, because he said it is supported by all the citizens of the Republic of China.
Lien made the remarks when he delivered a keynote speech at the closing ceremony of a meeting of the board of directors of the Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations.

Lien also briefed representatives of the overseas Chinese organizations on the ongoing KMT reforms. Because of the close relations between overseas Chinese and the Kuomintang, the party has decided to set up an overseas Chinese Affairs Commission to help it promote overseas Chinese affairs abroad, Lien said.

In a touch of criticism for the Democratic Progressive Party-led administration, Lien said that Taiwan's populace has been worried about the nation's future economic development since President Chen Shui-bian assumed power on May 20. The KMT will review itself and will arise again, Lien noted.
Lien also skirted the issue of cross strait relations, saying only that he hopes mainland China will transform into an open, peaceful, democratic and free country.
Meanwhile, Lien called on all ROC citizens to pool their efforts so as to build a harmonious and peaceful society in Taiwan.
Lien made the remarks when he addressed a seminar sponsored by National Normal University in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREEK PARLIAMENTARIANS ARRIVE FOR SIX-DAY VISIT TO ROC

TEXT.P: A group of four Greek Parliamentarians arrived in Taipei Saturday for a six-day visit to the Republic of China.
The Greek delegation is comprised of Dimitrios Georgakopoulos, Ioannis Thomopoulos, Parthena Foundouki-Theodoridou and Miltiadis Varvitsiotis.

While in Taipei, they will call on Council for Cultural Affairs Chairwoman Tchen Yu-chiou, Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Jong-nan, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong and other government officials.
They will also tour several cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan before departing for home on Dec. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER CALLS FOR 'LOYALTY CHECK' ON INTELLIGENCE OFFICERS

TEXT.P: Legislator Trong Tsai of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged military and intelligence authorities Saturday to launch a massive-scale "loyalty check" on serving and retired officers in order to maintain national security.

Tsai made the appeal in response to a report by National Security Bureau Deputy Director Han Kun on Friday that mainland China has managed to infiltrate Taiwan's government, political parties and military by bribing relevant officials.

Tsai said Han's report was "no news." In fact, he said, some U.S. officials told him in private during his trip to Washington, D.C. in September 1999 to lobby for the "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" that mainland China has deliberately "bought up" Taiwan officials under its "united front" tactics.
According to Tsai, mainland China has used "money" and "beautiful women" to bribe Taiwan officials and tempt them into providing Beijing with classified information.
Tsai claimed that many of Taiwan's military intelligence gathering channels in mainland China are now controlled by communist authorities.

As a result, Tsai said, Taiwan now has to spend large sums of money to obtain military intelligence reports on mainland China from the United States, Japan, Hong Kong, Australia, Russia and several European countries.

Tsai stressed that local security authorities must continue keeping track of retired intelligence officers to prevent them from building up a "second spring" in their career by "selling Taiwan's secret files."

Tsai further warned that if relevant government agencies -- and intelligence and military authorities in particular -- fail to tighten security measures and immediately conduct a large-scale "loyalty check" on serving and retired intelligence personnel, no foreign country will be willing to forge intelligence exchanges and cooperative ties with Taiwan in the future, and Taiwan's security would face even greater challenges.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL NEWSMAGAZINE STANDS BY ITS REPORT ON VP

TEXT.P: A local newsmagazine announced Saturday that it will stand by its Nov. 16 report on Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu, and will decide what legal steps to take after receiving an official letter demanding an apology from her lawyers.

Wang Chien-chuang, president of The Journalist, said at a press conference that his magazine did not cross any ethical boundaries by which all professional media organizations abide, and that the issue of apology is only a concern if it is proven that a news report does not correspond with the truth.

According to the evidence and data his magazine has in hand, Wang said that there is "sufficient reason" to believe in the accuracy of the report, and that the fact his magazine "went to great pains" to "reasonably" verify the facts shows it never intended any malice or sought to defame anyone.

Lu's legal team of 19 attorneys and advisers demanded in a press conference earlier in the day that The Journalist pay to publish an apology on the front page of six major newspapers by Dec. 10, and make public the full text of its apology -- to be approved by the team -- via six electronic news media outlets, including television stations.

Lu's lawyers claimed that the weekly showed "actual malice" in printing a "libelous" cover headline and story that accused the vice president of spreading rumors about an alleged extramarital affair between President Chen Shui-bian and one of his female aides. The team also accused the magazine of alleging that Lu wanted to use the presidential scandal to "finish off" the president.
The headline read: "The person who stirred up the scandal and is secretly competing with the president unexpectedly turned out to be Annette Lu."

On the issue of whether the magazine article actually overstepped the law, Wang said that Lu's behavior on various occasions led to "reasonable suspicions" that are legal topics for public discussion.

Wang said that Lu's public statements at a time when the president was facing a united opposition move to recall him were an attempt to draw a clear line between herself and Chen, and that she often discussed privately how to avoid being recalled along with Chen.
He added that even the greater public -- let alone professionally trained journalists -- would question the reasons behind Lu's alleged "surprising words and behavior."

Wang accused Lu's lawyers of providing an investigation report that "lacked all the requisites of exacting research" and questioned whether the telephone logs announced by her legal team were truly complete. Wang also questioned whether the vice president had any unlisted numbers unknown to others.

In its Nov. 16 issue, The Journalist accused her of contacting a "senior media person" on Nov. 3 after 7 p.m. to spread the rumors to smear the president, but Lu's legal team declared that a careful examination of her residential telephone logs from Nov. 1-12 showed the vice president did not call up members of the media that evening or at any other time to spread such rumors.
Of the three phone calls Lu made to the media after 7 p.m. during that period, Lu's lawyers said that all three journalists have told them that none of the calls involved the alleged scandal.
Lu's legal team added that the logs showed consecutive page numbers and time stamps, accounting for all the calls from her official residence within the period in question.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA PROFITABLE: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan-financed companies in mainland China have turned profits, the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) reported Saturday.

The CNFI, one of Taiwan's three largest business associations, distributed questionnaires earlier this year to 1,000 of the 18,000 local companies which have registered their mainland investment projects with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and collected 147 valid replies.

Quoting the survey results, the CNFI said 57 percent of the respondents said they have made money from their business operations on the mainland this year, while 17.2 percent said their mainland businesses have incurred debts.

Meanwhile, 71.6 percent said they believe that mainland China's economic prospects will become even rosier next year, and 70.5 percent predicted that their mainland businesses will post gains in the coming year.
Analyzing the findings, CNFI officials said the optimistic forecast by executives with interests on the mainland would further fuel the mainland-bound investment fever.

The survey also found that limited access to mainland bank loans is a common headache facing many Taiwanese investors on the mainland. Against this backdrop, Taiwanese business people have to turn to Taiwan for financial support for their mainland operations and this practice would in the long run result in huge capital flow from Taiwan to the mainland.

According to the survey, earlier opening of direct trade, mail and transport links across the Taiwan Strait is the most urgent task that local companies with interests on the mainland want the government to do. And the second priority cited by the respondents is allowing local banks to set up branches on the mainland to offer them easier access to bank loans.
Survey results further show that Taiwanese investors are not pessimistic about the prospects for cross-strait relations over the next two years, with 41.5 percent giving an optimistic forecast.

Asked whether the simmering cross-strait tension over sovereignty disputes would enhance risks in mainland-bound investment, 68 percent said "Yes" while only 14.3 percent said "No." The figures indicate that the continued cross-strait stalemate has upgrade Taiwanese investors' risk awareness or consciousness.

Nevertheless, the survey results show that the scale of local companies' mainland operations has become ever larger, with the number of single investment project worth more than US$10 million increasing steadily.

As much as 62 percent said they believe that a visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, would be helpful to future cross-strait trade and economic ties, and only 25 percent said they thing Wang's visit would have little effects on bilateral trade.
The majority of the respondents also said they think economic issues should take precedence over political topics in future cross-strait negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIZE-WINNING CHINESE SCIENTIST APPEALS FOR PEACE IN TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The only ethnic Chinese recipient of this year's U.S. National Medals of Science said Friday that he looks forward to seeing scientists on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait cooperate closely for their mutual benefit.
Yuan-Cheng B. Fung, a professor at the University of California, San Diego, added that he earnestly hopes no military conflict ever erupts in the narrow strait.
Fung made the remarks in a brief interview with CNA after receiving the award in a White House presentation ceremony presided over by U.S. President Bill Clinton.

Clinton received the 12 recipients of the accolade in the Oval Office. Fung is the sole laureate in the engineering field this year. The National Medals of Science are America's highest honors for achievement in relevant fields.
Clinton said the scientists and engineers receiving the medals "have transformed our world and enhanced our daily lives."
"Their imagination and ingenuity will continue to inspire future generations of American scientists to remain at the cutting edge of scientific discovery and technological innovation," he added.
Fung, 81, has made outstanding contributions to aerospace engineering, and is a pioneer in the application of engineering principles to solving biomedical problems.

Fung has long been famous in the three Chinese communities of Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong. He is now an academician of Taiwan's Academia Sinica, mainland China's Chinese Academy of Sciences and the U.S. National Academy of Sciences.
Fung traveled to Taiwan two weeks ago to chair the screening of a biotech research project sponsored by the Republic of China's National Health Research Institute.

Fung said he has maintained close contacts with ethnic Chinese scientists in the United States as well as their counterparts in mainland China and Taiwan. "I truly hope the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can strengthen cooperation in science-technology research," he added.

Created by the U.S. Congress in 1959, the award is administered by the U.S. National Science Foundation. Including this year's recipients, the honor has been awarded to 386 scientists. Previous Chinese recipients of the award included Chern Shiing-shen (mathematics and computer science) and Wu Chien-shiung (physical sciences) in 1975; Lee Yuan-tseh (chemistry) in 1986; Paul Chu (physical sciences) in 1988; and Yau Shing-tung (mathematics and computer science) in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLDEN HORSE AWARDS PRESENTED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Francis Ng and Maggie Cheung Saturday won the titles of the best leading actor and actress respectively of this year's Golden Horse Awards, while To Kei-Fung won the title of best director.

Established in 1962, the Golden Horse Awards is the Taiwan version of the Oscar. It honors Chinese films and filmmakers from Taiwan, Hong Kong, and mainland China. Su Tzen-ping, director general of the Government Information Office said at the awards presentation ceremony in Taipei that the Golden Horse Awards recognizes and supports the efforts of outstanding individuals in Chinese film, thus opening a new era for the film industry of the Republic of China.

Winners of major awards are: Best Picture-- Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon Best Short Film -- Travel Best Documentary -- Grandma's Hairpin Best Director -- To Kei-Fung (The Mission) Best Original Screenplay -- Fruit Chan (Little Cheung) Best Leading Actor -- Francis Ng (The Mission) Best Leading Actress -- Maggie Cheung (In the Mood for Love) Best Supporting Actor -- Cheung Ka-Nin (The Cabbie) Best Supporting Actress -- Chao Mei-Ling (Lament of the Sand River) Best Cinematography -- Li Ping-Bin and Christopher Doyle (In the Mood for Love) Best Original Film Score -- Tan Dun (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon) Best Original Film Song -- Zhang Yui-Wai (Bundled) Best Sound Effect -- Eugene Gearty (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon) Best Film Editing -- Tim Squyres (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon) Best Art Direction -- Lee Fu-Hsiung (Lament of the Sand River) Best Makeup & Costume Design -- Chang Suk-Pin (In the Mood for Love) Best Visual Effects-- Leo Lo and Rob Hodgson (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon) Best Action Choreography-- Yuen Wo-Ping (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon), and Best Screenplay Adaptation-- Ann Hu (Shadow Magic).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUCCESSFULLY DEVELOPS ADVANCED ANTI-SHIP MISSILE

TEXT.P: Taiwan has successfully developed advanced a supersonic anti-ship missile which is said to be superior to the Sunburn missiles that mainland China have acquired from Russia.

Researchers at the Chung Shan Institute of Science and Technology said Sunday that they have conducted several test fires of the Hsiungfeng-3 missiles, and mass production will begin as soon as the government gives the green light.

The Hsingfeng-3 anti-ship missile is yet another breakthrough for Taiwan in its development of missiles, which has also seen the development of the Tienkung (Sky Bow)-2 surface-to-air missile, the researchers said.
Beijing earlier this year purchased two Sovremenny-class destroyers to be equipped with the Russia-made Sunburn anti-ship missiles.

The turbine-propelled Sunburn missile, with its 300-kg. war head, has a maximum speed of Mach 2.34 and a range of up to 150 kms. With its high accuracy and speed, only 1.2 Sunburn missiles are capable of sinking a destroyer, while five missiles could totally destroy a 20,000-ton supply ship. The high-tech weapons pose a serious threat to Western nations' anti-missile defense.
The researchers said that the Hsingfeng-3 missile outperforms the Sunburn in terms of its speed and range, but they would not elaborate.
They said that additionally, the institute has made breakthroughs in missile guidance, control and propulsion.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF ROC CITIZENS SAY BEIJING LACKS SINCERITY TO SOLVE DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent Republic of China citizens believe that mainland China is not sincerely seeking to solve cross-strait problems in a peaceful manner, according to the results of a recent survey released Sunday.

The survey was jointly conducted by the Association for the Research of National Peace and Security in Taiwan and Trendgo Survey Research Center on 1,119 over 20-year-old islandwide between Dec.1 and 2. Its purpose was to learn the views of the public on cross-strait relations, and it carried a margin of error of 2.9 percent.

The survey showed that 69.7 percent of respondents think that the Republic of China "has the sincerity" necessary to solve cross-strait problems. The number of those who think that the ROC government is not sincere dropped sharply to just 20.2 percent, while 10.1 percent had no opinion or refused to answer.

But up to 67.9 percent said that the mainland has "no sincerity" in seeking to solve cross-strait problems peacefully, with just 20.2 percent saying Beijing "has the sincerity" to solve the disputes. Some 12.3 percent had no definite views or refused to answer the question.

Yen Chien-fa, director of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's Department of Chinese Affairs, said that the figures show that local people continue to be vigilant against Beijing's rhetoric, adding that Taiwan cannot let down its guard against the mainland.

On cross-strait relations, those who are in favor of maintaining the status quo and deciding later on the issue of unification or independence accounted for the most at 39.3 percent. They were followed by supporters of maintaining the status quo, and moving toward unification later, who accounted for 24.4 percent. Just 13.5 percent of the respondents favored maintaining the status quo permanently.
The lowest percentages fell to those in favor of early unification, at 3.8 percent, and supporters of an early declaration of independence, at 2.4 percent.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the opposition Kuomintang's Department of Mainalnd Affairs Research, said that the poll shows that those who are in favor of maintaining the status quo and moving toward unification later have increased sharply.
Meanwhile, Yen noted that the survey showed that those who are in some way in favor of the "status quo" are in the mainstream, as they account for 76.3 percent.

On ethnic identification, those who believe they are both Taiwanese and Chinese accounted the most, at 46.8 percent; followed by those who said that they are Taiwanese, at 38.4 percent; and those who said they are Chinese, at 12.6 percent.

Chang said that these results show that people who consider themselves both Taiwanese and Chinese are still the largest group, which falls in line with the conviction held by the late president Chiang Ching-kuo, former President Lee Teng-hui and KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
Yen also said that the majority of people said they are both Taiwanese and Chinese, which can be considered Taiwan's mainstream view.

Nearly 53 percent of the people were positive on the agreement on "three acknowledgments and four recommendations" reached by thePresidential Advisory Group on Cross-strait relations late last month, believing that it will help improve cross-strait relations.

Some 58 percent of the people are in favor of seeing President Chen Shui-bian handle cross-strait relations according to the ROC Constitution, which is thought to be a crucial point reached by the advisory group to accommodate to Beijing's hallowed "one China" principle.
The ROC's 1947 Constitution does not mention the "one China" issue, though it claims sovereignty over mainland China and Taiwan.

Up to 90.4 percent of the respondents said that they "agreed with" the advisory group's recommendation that the People's Republic of China should respect the international dignity and survival space of the ROC, as well as abandon military threats and work for a peaceful agreement.

The survey also showed that up to 86.4 percent of those polled agreed with the advisory group's view that the ROC has an established democratic system, and any change of the status quo must be agreed upon by the people through the democratic process.
Liao Fu-teh, researcher at Academia Sinica, the nation's highest academic institute, said that this shows that the public's paramount concern is peace, and then the democratic process.
Up to 70.4 percent of those polled also said that they are opposed to Beijing's rejection of the advisory group's "three acknowledgments and four understandings" as "empty talk, and a play on words."

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-FOURTH OF TAIWAN BUSINESS GROUPS LOST MONEY LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Nearly one fourth of business groups in Taiwan reported losses last year, a record high for the Republic of China, according to a newly-released survey.

The annual survey on Taiwan's business groups by China Credit Information Service also found that more than 20 percent of the island's firms were saddled with debts more than two times the value of their assets.

Given the fact that 1999 was the first year of recovery from the island's financial crisis, the survey warned that the huge losses bode ill for the island's economy, and could herald another financial storm unless the economic prospects and investment climate are improved in time.
The survey of Taiwan's 201 business groups, including six foreign conglomerates, show that 49 of them posted a pre-tax loss in 1999, the latest year for which such statistics are available.
Four groups have since gone bankrupt and vanished from the island's business map. They were excluded from the study, according to the survey.
Among the top 20 loss-making groups, 13 are counted in the island's top 100 business groups, and 10 of them are listed on the local stock exchange.

Leading the losing pact are Wei-Chuan Group, with a pre-tax loss of NT$5.55 billion (US$168.45 million), followed by Ruentex Group, with a loss of NT$4.56 billion (US$138.36 million), and Hung Tai Group, with a loss of NT$4.19 billion (US$127 million).
Bungled overseas ventures and the ailing local real estate market are the leading culprits for those business groups' plight, according to the survey's analysis.
Among the top-10 loss-makers, six were in the red for the second consecutive year, and three of them -- Ruentex, Hung Tai, and Ching Fon -- have ran up debts worth more than five times their assets.
Considering the political turmoil on the island and the slowdown of global economic expansion, the survey forecast an even worse performance for the business groups in 2000.

Cathay Life Insurance group ranked the biggest group on the island for the second year in a row, with combined assets of NT$1.1 trillion (US$33.48 billion). Following closely behind were Formosa Plastics Group, with assets of NT$1.05 trillion (US$32 billion), and Koo's Group, with NT$910.3 billion (US$27.57 billion).

All of the businesses controlled by the Kuomintang appeared for the first time on the list of the island's top-10 business groups compiled by China Credit Information Service. The combined Kuomintang assets were listed in eighth place, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS WARNS OF BREWING FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: In light of the dwindling profits and tremendous bad loans of Taiwan's financial institutions, a financial crisis in the Republic of China may be imminent, warned local experts on Sunday.

Huang Teh-yeh, professor of finance at National Taiwan University and a member of the Chinese Finance Association, said at a press conference Saturday morning that the profit-making capability of Taiwan financial institutions declined to among the lowest in the world in the third quarter this year.

Quoting the latest issue of Business Week, a U.S. magazine, Huang said that Taiwan's financial institutions are burdened by average overdue loans of 15 percent of their total outstanding loans. Huang said this figure has crossed what Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang has called the threshold of a finance crisis.

His view was shared by Huo Teh-ming, a professor at the Finance Institute of National Chengchi University. Huo said at the same press conference, which was called to release the Chinese Finance Association's rating of local banks, that the nation's financial institutions' overdue loans climbed while their returns declined as a whole during the third quarter.
The problem has been brought to a head by the intensifying competition among local financial institutions brought about by the emergence of a dozen new banks, said Huo.
He warned that the situation will only deteriorate after the island's entry into the World Trade Organization and the opening of its market to foreign competitors.

The banks ranked at the top of the association's list might be free from any financial trouble, but those further down the list could be ruined by their mounting liabilities unless they are merged with other, healthier banks, said Huo.

The association, which rates local banks by their size, financial health, liquidity, management and profit-making capability, named ChinaTrust Commercial Bank as the best among the island's 36 financial institutions which are either listed companies or have their stock traded on the unlisted securities market.
Rounding out the top five are United World Chinese Commercial Bank, Chiao Tung Bank, China Development Industrial Bank and International Commercial Bank of China.
The five banks on the opposite end of the list are Kaohsiung Business Bank, Taichung Commercial Bank, Chung Shing Bank, Taitung Business Bank and Tainan Business Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS SEEKING FOUR KIDD-CLASS DESTROYERS FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeking to obtain four U.S.-made Kidd-class missile destroyers to replace its aging fleet of destroyers, according to a local evening newspaper Sunday.

The China Times quoted the London-based Jane's Defense Weekly as saying that the deal, if agreed to by Washington, will boost the island's capability to counter Beijing's newly-acquired Sovremenny-class destroyers and Kilo-class submarines from Russia.
Under Taipei's proposal, it will lease the warships for five years, with ownership of the vessels transferred to Taiwan after it pays off the rent of about US$500 million.
Taiwan will use the four Kidds to take the place of its seven destroyers made before World War II.

Taipei has asked to purchase four U.S.-made Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis battle management system, but even if Washington agrees to the sale, the state-of-the-art warships are not expected to join the Republic of China Navy until 2010, according to the paper.
The Kidds, which could join the service within five years, might partially fill in the ten-year window, according the China Times.
The Kidd destroyer is armed with a SQS-53 sonar system similar to that used on the Arleigh Burke destroyer, which is very effective in detecting Kilo-class submarines, according to the China Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA TO OBTAIN FREE AIDS MEDICATION

TEXT.P: Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer will donate anti-AIDS drugs to the South African government free of charge for two years, in an attempt to reduce the country's AIDS epidemic.

Health Minister Manto Tshabalana-Msimang signed a Memorandum of Understanding with a Pfizer representative in Johannesburg on World Aids Day Friday. According to the agreement, Pfizer will provide the drug Diflucan, also known as fluconazole, at no charge to South African AIDS and HIV patients suffering from two types of Aids-related infections.

Pfizer expects to contribute about US$50 million worth of Diflucan over the course of the program. The drugs will be administrated by medical professionals in South African public hospitals and clinics.
The program will be regularly assessed to ensure that it meets patients' needs.
A Pfizer spokesman said it was an excellent example of the pharmaceutical industry providing innovative and often lifesaving medicines to those most in need.
He said the AIDS epidemic in Africa is one of the single greatest global health care challenges facing the world today.
He added that Pfizer is also committed to initiating discussions with other members of the Southern African Development Community with a view to expanding the program.
Southern Africa has the most serious AIDS epidemic in the world, and the governments in the region lack the resources to fight the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT 'MINI DIRECT LINKS' SAID TO HINGE ON BEIJING'S ATTITUDE

TEXT.P: There is still uncertainty surrounding the much-expected opening of the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait, Chen Shui-mu, speaker of Kinmen County Council, said Sunday.

Chen made the remarks after returning from a fact-finding visit to Xiamen in preparation for the "direct trade, postal and transport" links between the nation's two frontline islands -- Kinmen and Matsu -- and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei ports in Fujian province, which are scheduled to open Jan. 1, 2001.

Chen said that the uncertainty comes from the authorities in Beijing, adding that even if local governments in the mainland are enthusiastic about the "mini three links," the plan is not expected to go anywhere without clear instructions from the central government.

Chen noted that his 35-member delegation visited Xiamen, Guanzhou, where they toured the harbor facilities. Mainland officials, including Guo Anmin, said that they personally are in favor of "mini direct links," and that they were working on related matters some five years ago, but they have yet to received formal instructions on the matter from Beijing.
Chen said that the mainland believes that the "mini three links" should have been in place a long time ago, but that the Taiwan government has set up restrictions.

On Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai's plan for direct shipping to Xiamen Jan. 1, Chen Shui-mu said that it is still uncertain, and depends on whether or not Beijing gives the nod to the plan. "We cannot rashly inaugurate shipping without the invitation of our counterparts in Xiamen," he said, noting that the high expectations on Kinmen are absent in Xiamen.

On the return of many Kinmen residents stranded on the mainland during the civil war between the previous Nationalist government and the Communists, Chen expressed the hope that they will be allowed to return to their ancestral homelands in January on humanitarian grounds, in order to pay respect to their ancestors.
Chen stressed that port facilities in Xiamen will have no problem handling direct shipping, and that Kinmen also is expected to complete all the necessary preparations by Dec. 15.
Kinmen lies far closer to Xiamen than to Taiwan, but direct transport links between Kinmen and Xiamen have been banned for more than five decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 4, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to be Pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: General Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: With Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles, Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" is premiered on Broadway.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang Army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in the Sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng (concurrently vice president), and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which orbits the earth for a new record of 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han, and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a week's visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled in the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing all aboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1991: Terry Anderson, the last of a group of Americans held hostage by Shiite kidnappers since March 16, 1985, is released in Beirut, Lebanon.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise (ruler) lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 103.33 points to close at 5,174.02.
The bourse opened at 5,239.82 and continued to go down due to a lack of confidence on the part of investors. The index fluctuated between 5,243.05 and 5,168.91 during trading.

A total of 0.99 billion stocks worth NT$28.62 billion (US$0.87 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.72 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$53.05 billion (US$1.61 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues edging up 0.8 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, construction stocks at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.9 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NAVY TO BUILD 8TH PERRY-CLASS FRIGATE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Navy recently decided to build the eighth locally constructed Chengkung-class missile frigate to beef up its naval defense capability.
The ROC Navy recently struck an agreement with state-run China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) on the construction of the new frigate to be christened "Tien-dan," CSBC sources said Monday.

The navy began the "Kuang Hua No. 1 Project" in 1989, contracting the CSBC to build eight missile frigates modeled on the U.S. Perry-class warships. So far, the navy has taken delivery of seven of the frigates over the last 10 years.
Construction of the eighth, which was originally scheduled to be completed in December 1999, was suspended due to an insufficient budget.
In the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, naval authorities finally decided to revive the shipbuilding project.

CSBC officials said the construction cost for the "Tien-dan" must be re-evaluated because all stock building materials have been used up. Each of the seven Chengkung-class missile frigates, excluding installed weapon systems, costs about NT$7 billion (US$212 million).
With construction of the "Tien-dan" scheduled to kick off early next year, the eighth Chengkung-class frigate is expected to be delivered to the navy in March 2004, CSBC officials said.
They noted that all of the Tien-dan's specifications will be the same as those of the seven other Chengkung-class frigates now in service in the navy.

Naval authorities originally planned to install Aegis-class strategic weaponry systems on the Tien-dan frigate. However, they later scrapped the plan in consideration of the frigate's inadequate space, the navy's limited budget, and the possible difficulties in acquiring the new weaponry systems.

With a displacement of 4,200 tons, each Perry-class frigate is equipped with advanced radar, artillery, torpedoes, surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles, locally-developed anti-ship "Hsiungfeng II" missiles, as well as anti-submarine helicopters.
As part of its efforts to modernize its naval fleet and upgrade its defense capabilities, the ROC has gradually retired aging destroyers and replaced them with a second-generation of warships.

In addition to the Perry-class frigates, six Lafayette-class frigates have been purchased from France and six Knot-class frigates have been leased from the United States to form the backbone of the ROC's naval fleet.
