DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S R&D SPENDING LOWER THAN IBM'S: NSC DEPUTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China lags behind the international computer giant, IBM, in science and technology research investment, National Science Council (NSC) Vice Chairman Steve Hsieh said Monday.

Addressing the participants to an annual meeting of the Executive Yuan's Science and Technology Advisory Group, Hsieh said the ROC government's research and development (R&D) budget totaled NT$190 billion (about US$6 billion) in 1999.
"The amount was lower than the R&D spendings of many advanced countries and even less than that of IBM's," Hsieh noted.

According to Hsieh, IBM's overall business revenues amounted to US$87 billion in 1999. "As IBM's R&D budget usually accounts for 7 percent to 8 percent of its total business turnover, its 1999 R&D budget should exceed our government budget for science-technology development," he explained.
Hsieh pointed that Taiwan's R&D budget grew by an average of 10.7 percent annually between 1994 and 1999. The annual growth rate dropped to 8 percent last year due to an economic slowdown.
Private investment in R&D registered an average annual growth rate of 16 percent between 1997 and 1998, but the growth rate declined to 8.9 percent in 1999, Hsieh said.

Quoting a global competitiveness report released by the Swiss International Institute for Management and Development (IMD) earlier this year, Hsieh said Taiwan ranks 22nd in terms of its overall national competitiveness, but its sci-tech competitiveness is the world's 12th strongest.
A further analysis of the IMD report, Taiwan ranks ninth in terms of R&D manpower, but its R&D spending ranks far lower at 19th, Hsieh noted.

He said Taiwan indeed lags behind many advanced countries in R&D investment. For instance, Japan's R&D budget accounts for 2.98 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP), compared to South Korea's 2.89 percent and the United States' 2.84 percent.
In comparison, Hsieh said, Taiwan's R&D spending makes up only 2.05 percent of its GDP. "We are hopeful that the ratio can be raised to 3 percent in 10 years," he added.

Despite its limited R&D investment, Taiwan has made progress in sci-tech development in recent years, Hsieh said. In addition to its 12th ranking in the IMD global sci-tech competitiveness rating, Taiwan was the fourth largest recipient of the "new design" patents awarded by the U.S. patent authorities in 1999. Taiwan was also the sixth or seventh-largest recipient of "new invention" patents granted by the United States last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO RECALL WITHIN FIRST YEAR IN OFFICE,' SAYS INTERIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Chang Po-ya said Monday that an amendment should be included in the Presidential Election and Recall Law to prevent the possibility of a sitting president and vice president being ousted within the first year in office.

Fielding questions at a joint session of different committees at the Legislative Yuan, Chang said she believes that the National Assembly made an oversight years ago when it was drafting the law by not stipulating that a sitting president and vice president could not be recalled within the first year after their inauguration.

Legislator Tsao Er-chung from the opposition Kuomintang said the Ministry of Interior's decision to work toward including such an amendment in the Presidential Election and Recall Law is nothing more than licking the president's boots.

Lai Shyh-pao, party whip of the tiny opposition New Party in the Legislative Yuan, said the opposition coalition has now stopped pushing for a presidential recall vote in an attempt to give President Chen Shui-bian another chance to improve his service to the nation.
Lai pointed out however that the Ministry of Interior's move to push for the creation of a barrier to the recall of the president is suspicious and unjustifiable.
Chang answered the criticism by saying that the amendment move is still just on the drawing board and that she herself has not yet had a chance to review it.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PERSONNEL SAID SHOULD BE INCLUDED IN NAT'L HEALTH PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Military personnel should be covered by the National Health Insurance Program based on the principle of universal social justice, sources from the Legislative Yuan said Monday.

Democratic Progressive Party legislators Lai Ching-teh and Chen Chi-mai said they will move to push for an amendment to the National Health Insurance Law, mandating that military personnel, including career men and women in uniform, voluntary soldiers signed in on contract basis, military academy students, and all military dependents, should be covered under the national health insurance program.
Opposition legislators, including the New Party's Hao Lung-ping and the Kuomintang's Lee Chuan-chiao and Chang Tsai-mei, voiced their full support for the motion.

According to Legislator Chen Chi-mai, citizens from almost every walk of life in Taiwan have been included in the National Health Insurance Program since its inception in 1995, with only military personnel still being excluded, a situation which Chen said runs counter to the spirit of a universal plan.

Legislator Lai Ching-teh quoted a recent public opinion poll as indicating that some 68 percent of all military personnel said they would be pleased to join the national health insurance program if given the chance despite the fact that they are presently entitled to free medical care at military-run hospitals and clinics.

Lai added that the inclusion of military personnel in the national health insurance program is not only in line with the principle of social justice, but would also help generate approximately NT$1 billion in revenue for the National Health Insurance Bureau, significantly helping to ease the financial strain that the bureau has been experiencing over the past decade.

Lai suggested that career military officers and soldiers pay 30 percent of the monthly health insurance premium and the Ministry of National Defense pay 70 percent of the premium for dependents of these military personnel, and also that the ministry pay 100 percent of the premium for voluntary uniformed personnel and military school students.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY OPTIMISTIC ABOUT TIES WITH U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Despite uncertainty in the result of the cliffhanger U.S. presidential election, the Republic of China representative to the United States Sunday expressed optimism about future substantive relations between the two countries.

Chen Chien-jen, who flew to San Francisco from Washington, D.C. to deliver a speech on the future prospects of ROC-U.S. relations at the invitation of the Chinese-American Economic and Technological Development Association, said whoever wins the 2000 U.S. presidential election, Taipei-Washington relations will continue to grow and thrive.

Chen, a former ROC foreign minister, said the ROC government and its representative office in the United States have kept extensive contacts with chief foreign policy advisers of both Republican and Democratic camps.

"All of them adopt a smooth, friendly and unwavering attitude toward U.S. policy on Taiwan and have full understanding and sensible observation of Taipei-Washington and Taipei-Beijing relations," Chen noted.

The seasoned career diplomat further said optimistically that either Republican Party's George W. Bush or Democratic Party's Al Gore wins the presidency, the basic U.S. policy toward Taiwan and its stance on cross-Taiwan Strait relations will not undergo fundamental changes, unless the internal situations of Taiwan, mainland China and the United States see drastic changes.
Noting that Taiwan and the United States share enormous common interests, Chen said various U.S. social quarters highly recognize Taiwan's achievements in economic and democratic reforms.

Chen stressed that the key campaign strategists and foreign policy advisers of both Bush and Gore camps are friendly toward Taiwan and strongly support continued strengthening of ROC-U.S. exchanges and cooperation.

"One China," dialogue and peaceful means form the three pillars of the U.S. policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait, Chen said, adding that he has long pitched for the inclusion of the "assent of the people of Taiwan to the final solution of cross-strait issue" as the fourth element of the U.S. policy.

Chen said although it remains uncertain whether the future U.S. administration would enshrine the "Taiwan people's assent" as the "fourth pillar" of its policy on the Taiwan Strait issue, the concept has become a bipartisan consensus in the U.S. political arena.

Chen went on to say the U.S. government is not expected to pressure the ROC to negotiate with mainland China. "In fact, the ROC government has never resisted consultation or negotiation with the mainland on any topics of mutual concern, even political issues," he explained.

As for conflicting views on the "one China" principle inside Taiwan, Chen said it's only natural in a democratic society like Taiwan that the general public hold diverse views on major national issues. "Our U.S. friends fully understand it will take time for Taiwan people to forge a national consensus on the future development of cross-strait ties."

Chen also said he is convinced that there is still room for further improvement of ROC-U.S. relations. "And this is the common goal of our Ministry of Foreign Affairs and representative office in the U.S. proper," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT ISSUES WARNING ON PHARMACEUTICALS CONTAINING PPA

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that it will not immediately ban over-the-counter products containing an ingredient that could cause hemorrhagic strokes, but it will mandate that warnings against the ingredient should be carried in the usage instructions for drugs that contain the substance.

DOH officials said they presently have no plans for a domestic ban on sales of over-the-counter medicines, including appetite suppressants and cold remedies, that contain phenylpropanolamine (PPA). But they will explicitly require that medicine containing PPA come with instructions indicating that it contains the stroke-linked ingredient.

According to a survey conducted by the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, 39 appetite suppressants and 297 cold remedies currently being marketed in Taiwan contain PPA, which a Yale University research team recently determined to be stroke-linked, especially in young women.

DOH officials said the United States, Mexico and Canada have declare a ban on PPA in all medicine products; Sweden and Belgium are "assessing" the situation; while Australia, Japan, France, Germany and Switzerland have no plans to halt sales of products containing PPA.

According to Hu Yo-pu, director of the Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, the DOH previously realized the risk of using heavy doses of PPA, so the department banned the sale of cold medicines and weight-loss drugs containing over 75 ml of PPA some two years ago.

Under the new ruling, manufacturers of pharmaceuticals containing PPA are required to change the instructions they include with such medicine within half a year. Violators will face fines of between NT$20,000 and NT$100,000, Hu added.

The Yale study pointed to a higher risk of hemorrhagic strokes, or bleeding into the brain, for women aged under 50, but the U.S. Federal Food and Drug Administration cautioned that men also are at risk. The strokes reportedly occurred within three days after taking the products containing PPA. The Yale study reported that it is impossible to predict how any individual will react.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS ABOUT SERIOUSNESS OF DOMESTIC BANKS' BAD LOANS REJECTED

TEXT.P: The issue of domestic banks' bad loans is not as serious as what has been reported in the media, Vice Finance Minister Sean C. Chen said Monday.

Chen, making the remarks in the Legislative Yuan in response to reports that Salomon Smith Barney has put Taiwan bank's total bad loan figure at US$60 billion, said that a different basis of calculation will beget different results.

Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the New Party said that the so-called financial management policy of the ministry has been to request domestic banks to buy shares to bolster the struggling stock market and to allow the losses incurred in the stock market to be written off over a span of 10 years, which he said runs counter to the principles of accounting.

He added that it is no wonder that foreign institutions would say Taiwan's total bad loans figure could run as high as US$60 billion and that UBS Warburg says at least 13 commercial banks would have a negative net worth if they wrote off all their bad loans.

Chen rejected the reports as untrue, saying the stated figure of 5.36 percent nonperforming loans is based on a percentage of total bank lending, while the figure of 6.26 percent takes into account all financial institutions.

Chen said that using a different basis for calculation yields different results, pointing out that this is the reason why foreign institutions might have different figures from Taiwan's. He added that those loans that are overdue for three months and also the property taken over by the banks as collateral should not be taken into account.

Chen said that extending the period for loan payments is not tantamount to a bad loan, adding that the government adopted bailout measures for ailing enterprises two years ago and that up to 70 percent of those enterprises have been making regular payments, showing that if the enterprises are given a chance, they can restart again.
Chen therefore said that the ministry has no intention of "papering over the problem," adding that it is only a different basis of calculation that has resulted in the discrepancy.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chen also denied reports that the state-owned Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan, and Central Trust of China would soon merge following a recently passed revised financial bill which has cleared the path for bank mergers.
Chen also said that allowing domestic banks to set up branches in mainland China had better wait until Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO ADOPT MEASURES TO HELP TIDE OVER DIFFICULTIES

TEXT.P: Former Premier Vincent Siew said Monday that if the government adopts appropriate measures to deal with current financial problems, domestic enterprises will be able to tide over the tough economic times.
Siew made the remarks at a luncheon meeting with legislators from the opposition Kuomintang.

Siew said that every year, Chinese New Year presents a challenge to domestic enterprises, and though economic sentiment seems especially gloomy this year, the government can help firms weather the holiday, which falls in late January.

Siew noted that many economic indicators have been negative over the past six months, citing the slumping stock market, the slowdown in major investment projects, mounting bad debt among the nation's financial institutions, rising jobless rates, and the continued exodus of enterprises to the mainland. He predicted a bleak winter for domestic enterprises.

He said that many government officials have handled similar difficulties in the past, saying that if the government refers to their experience and adopts appropriate measures, then there is nothing that the private sector can not handle.

Siew noted that some foreign media organizations have painted a bleak picture of Taiwan's economic development, saying that the government should be on guard and address the economy as the paramount issue. He added that the nation would very likely tide over the current difficulties based on the solid foundations laid in the past.

On the Ministry of the Finance's decision to allow domestic banks to write off bad loads over a period of up to 10 years, he said that this goes against the rule of the market as well as international norms. He added that the move is not the proper way to address the problem, but will simply mislead the market.
Siew, himself a financial and economic expert, suggested that the government muster the determination and wisdom to deal with the problem.

He suggested that the government use the Constitution to stabilize the political situation and solve the controversy surrounding the construction of the nation's fourth nuclear plant and a reservoir in southern Taiwan. He said that this would improve investor sentiment and also help middle-aged and elderly workers find jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.076 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$33.071.
The local currency opened at NT$32.985 and was traded between NT$32.800 and NT$33.185.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$441 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY FORECAST TO GROW OVER 20% NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The global semiconductor industry is expected to grow by 20 percent next year while Taiwan's semiconductor industry is forecast to exceed 20 percent growth, said Secretary-General of Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association Jenda J. Hu on Monday.
He added however that growth in semiconductor production may slacken because of industry concerns about a production surplus.

As to talk of Taiwan experiencing a brain drain to mainland China beginning next July, Hu, who is also the vice president of research and development at the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, said he considers this impossible because the mainland's semiconductor industry has not yet reached the level where it is able to compete with Taiwan.
He said that Taiwan will always be able to maintain its competitiveness as long as it continues to invest in the industry.
In addition, Hu said she considers that attracting mainland China's high-tech skilled talent to Taiwan would certainly be beneficial to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HELP PARAGUAY BUILD POWER SUBSTATION

TEXT.P: A Paraguayan government official said Sunday that Taiwan has promised to provide US$1.5 million to help the South American nation build a power substation.

Leopoldo Ostertag, director of industrial parks under Paraguay's Trade and Industry Department, said that Taiwan made the promise at the 12th ROC-Paraguay economic conference held last month in Taipei.

In return, the ROC government requested that Paraguay officials make greater efforts to protect Taiwan investors in Paraguay, especially in the Ciudad del Este area by continuing to clamp down on mafia gangs operating there.
Ostertag noted that the ROC also agreed to help train Paraguay's small enterprise operators, with special emphasis on design.
In addition, Taiwan will help Paraguay set up an information technology research institute in order to develop the computer peripherals industry there.

Ostertag said Taiwan considers that the Southern Common Market has a large amount of demand for computers. With its experience as a world leader in computer production, Taiwan can make a large contribution to Paraguay's information technology research, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD TAIWANESE CONGRESS FORMED TO HELP UPGRADE ROC'S PROFILE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Senior executives of Taiwanese associations in North America have decided to form a World Taiwanese Congress (WTC) to help upgrade Taiwan's international profile in the face of mounting communist Chinese threats.
The decision was made during a meeting of some 60 representatives of major Taiwanese associations in North America held in Washington, D.C. over the weekend.

The representatives issued a joint statement pledging to invite Taiwanese associations in other parts of the world to join the WTC to help consolidate the strength of overseas Taiwan people in support of the new Republic of China government's domestic and diplomatic reforms and safeguarding Taiwan's democratic achievements and sovereign status.

The joint statement further said the WTC will sponsor the "Taiwanese culture week" program in various countries around the world in May every year to introduce to the world Taiwan's political democratization, technological development and economic prosperity.

Through efforts of pro-independence Taiwanese associations, a Taiwanese heritage week program has been held annually in May over the past two years. U.S. President Bill Clinton has consistently issued a congratulatory message praising the program's contributions to Taiwan-U.S. cultural exchanges.
The joint statement also vowed to actively support the ROC's bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.
Meanwhile, the statement said, the WTC is tentatively scheduled to hold its first conference in Taipei in March 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI KING DECORATES ROC ANTI-SMOKING ACTIVIST

TEXT.P: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, was granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei Monday for his contribution to the success of control of tobacco consumption in Thailand.

Yen, chairman of the John Tung Foundation, a local private organization dedicated to anti-smoking and public health causes, received the "Commander Third Class of the Most Noble Order of the Crown of Thailand" in a grand ceremony.

Juliapong Nonsrichai, executive director of the Thailand Trade and Economic Office, which represents Thai interests in the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, conferred the order to Yen on behalf of Thai King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

A message issued by the Thai king said Yen's foundation has not only dedicated to controlling cigarette consumption in Taiwan but has also extended its anti-smoking concern to the international community.

Back in 1989, when the United States pressured many Asian countries to open their markets to American cigarette makers, the statement said, Yen pushed for the establishment of the Asia-Pacific Association for the Control of Tobacco (APACT) in Taipei to resist the U.S. "open-door" pressure.

In 1993, the World Health Organization (WHO) presented an award to Yen in Tokyo in recognition of his efforts to promote the formation of APACT, which has since become the WHO's most important working partner in tobacco control in the Asia-Pacific region.

The citation from the Thai king also praised Yen for his efforts to help Thailand resist the U.S. demand based on U.S. "301" trade act that Thailand lift its ban on tobacco advertising and other promotional activities. At that time, Yen mobilized all APACT member countries to issue a joint statement appealing for U.S. Congress assistance to reject the demand. APACT's lobbying efforts caught international media attention and prompted the U.S. Senate and House of Representatives to call public hearings on the issue. At last, Thailand managed to maintain its all-out ban on tobacco ads.
Under Yen's strenuous efforts, the citation went on, the 16-year-old John Tung Foundation has had a strong impact on the anti-smoking campaign in Asia and other parts of the world.
Yen said he felt honored to receive the decoration. Nevertheless, he stressed that the decoration is a recognition of all of those who have contributed to anti-smoking drives, not just himself.
Noting that anti-smoking is a crusade to protect the health of all people around the world, Yen said the campaign will not end until tobacco products disappear from the planet.

Touching on Taiwan's tobacco control campaign, Yen said that although Taiwan has made progress in anti-smoking legislation, it still has a long way to go in educating its youth of the dangers of tobacco and in enforcing anti-smoking laws and regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY DEFENDS DROPPING OF NATIONAL EMBLEM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) defended Monday its decision to replace the Republic of China national emblem on its stationary with the national flag as "appropriate and justifiable."
Lo Chih-yuan, director of MOFA's Research and Planning Board, said the decision was made two weeks ago after far-ranging consultation and with the approval of Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao.

Contradicting news reports in Taipei, Lo said his ministry did not serve its overseas embassies and representative offices with a "classified notice" to drop the national emblem from all of its stationary, adding that the decision is not "controversial" at all.
Lo said his ministry decided to use the national flag in place of the national emblem because the national emblem bears a striking resemblance to the insignia of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

The KMT, which founded the Republic of China in 1912, made its party insignia the same as the "twelve-point white star on a blue background" device in the canton of the national flag. The party controlled the nation until it was ousted in the March 18 presidential election this year.
"In order to avoid misunderstanding," Lo said, the foreign ministry decided to drop the use of the national emblem and replace it with the country's flag.
As a symbol of the nation, Lo went on, the national flag is a more appropriate design for MOFA stationary such as invitation cards, banquet menus, name cards, etc.

In countries which do not have official ties with the ROC and thereby may frown on the display of the ROC national flag, Lo said, the ministry will use a plum flower design, which is widely considered as the national flower of the ROC, in the place of the flag.
Meanwhile, former Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who is the KMT spokesman, denounced the foreign ministry's decision as "making a fuss over nothing."

Noting that the national emblem, as well as the national flag, is enshrined in legislation enacted by the legislature in 1954, Hu said it is legal for the foreign ministry to use it and the decision to drop it is "extremely inappropriate."
He described as "unbelievable" the idea that any overseas ROC government agency might be mistaken for a KMT organization because of the display of the national emblem.

If the national emblem can be dropped because it looks like KMT insignia, "will the change of the national flag or even the nation's official name for the same reason be the (ruling party's) next step?" Hu asked.

Promoting the nation's stature on the international stage requires a great deal of work, he went on, but added that "dropping the use of the national emblem" will only invite controversy rather than do the country any good.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY SEMINAR OPENS IN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opened Monday in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.

Weng Cheng-I, chairman of the Republic of China's National Science Council (NSC), extended a written message on ROC policy toward the development of science and technology that was read to the assembled participants by NSC Vice Chairman Wu Mao-kun.

Barry Lam, board chairman of Quanta Computer Inc., gave a speech in which he said that due to the rapid development of the Internet, not only computers but also many other electronic products such as PDAs (personal digital assistants) can also have access to the Internet, making web security more and more important.
The annual seminar is co-sponsored by the Taiwan branch of the U.S.-funded Semi Corp. and the Taiwan-based Taiwan Semiconductor Industrial Association (TSIA).

Because Semi Corp. represents 2,400 semiconductor equipment and material suppliers around the world and TSIA stands for 130 local semiconductor design, wafer manufacturing, installation and testing businesses in the Taiwan area, the seminar is a discussion forum highly valued by the semiconductor sector.

Topics for discussion include ROC policy toward the sci-tech industry, the development of 12-inch wafers in Europe and Asia, strategies for the electronic equipment industry, semiconductor industrial trends in mainland China, electronic commerce strategies for the semiconductor sector, the key to the success of the sci-tech industry, as well as the requirements necessary to cope with the new economic era.
The seminar is scheduled to conclude on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPEN ONLY TWO AIRPORTS FOR MAINLAND CHINESE PLANES: AIR FORCE CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China should open only two airports to mainland Chinese commercial airliners once it finally decides to forge direct airlinks across the Taiwan Strait, Air Force Commander-in-Chief Chen Chao-min said Monday.

In view of safeguarding national security, Chen said, the air force will suggest that the government open only Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung International Airport in southern Taiwan to mainland Chinese civil planes after the inauguration of direct cross-strait airlinks.

Taiwan is scheduled to allow direct trade, mail and transport services between its frontline islands of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Mawei ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," from Jan. 1, 2001. It is also planning to expand these links to the "three links proper" after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year.

"Once the government makes a final decision on opening direct cross-strait airlinks, the air force will begin planning and security deployment to ensure national security and smooth defense operations," Chen said.

Noting that Israel once used a Boeing 747 jumbo jet to cover up a surprise attack by four F-16 fighter jets on a Libyan nuclear power plant, Chen said the ROC must make every possible effort to prevent similar activity by mainland China after the opening of direct cross-strait flight services. In the Israeli case, its Boeing jetliner helped paralyze the Libyan air force's radar system, which consequently failed to identify the Israeli F-16s.

To prevent mainland China from using a similar tactic against Taiwan after the opening of direct airlinks, Chen said mainland commercial airliners should be restricted to using only CKS and Kaohsiung airports.

Moreover, he added, mainland civilian planes should be banned from flying directly across the Taiwan Strait to Taiwan and should instead be asked to make a detour to avoid flying over the middle line of the strait to safeguard Taiwan's air space security and maintain safe skies for training flights by ROC military pilots.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THINK TANK REBUTS REASONS FOR SCRAPPING NUCLEAR PLANT (I)

TEXT.P: An opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank announced Monday a point-by-point rebuttal of the government's official justification for pulling the plug on the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project at the end of October.

P.K. Chiang, executive director of the pro-nuclear KMT's National Policy Foundation, said in a speech at a party function that the continued development of nuclear power is a choice that must be made in light of the Republic of China's national development.

Chiang disputed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration's explanations that nuclear power is unsafe, that advanced nations are scrapping new nuclear plant projects, that nuclear waste is an unresolvable issue, that concrete and feasible alternatives to the nuclear plant exist, and that the contract termination fines and other losses add up to less than the cost of continuing to build the plant, which is approximately 33 percent complete.

The former economics minister and top economic planner under the previous KMT administration said that in fact, the world currently has 431 operating nuclear plants, with 36 more in the process of being built and 36 others in the planning stages.

Furthermore, he went on, 16 countries have a higher ratio of nuclear to conventional power generation than Taiwan, whose six existing nuclear units are housed in three power plants producing 22.4 percent of the island's total electrical output in 1998, according to Government Information Office statistics.

Chiang added that developed nations such as the United States, Germany, Sweden, Switzerland, Russia, Finland, Japan, and South Korea still use nuclear power, and that the U.S. Congress even wrote laws to ensure that the U.S. Department of Energy will help the nuclear industry develop next-generation reactors over the next five to 10 years.
Therefore, Chiang said that the Cabinet's claim that the United States is doing away with nuclear energy is "incorrect."

The fourth nuclear power plant, Chiang continued, uses two light-water-cooled and moderated reactors that have never resulted in accidental deaths or injuries. Therefore, he claimed, the new design's safety is tenfold that of the existing three nuclear plants in Taiwan and there is "absolutely no possibility" of a recurrence of the Chernobyl accident of 1986.

In fact, there are only two identical units to the General Electric Advanced Boiling Water Reactor (ABWR) that were to be installed in the fourth nuclear power plant currently in commercial operation anywhere in the world. Both are in the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Station in Japan's western prefecture of Niigata and these units have only been operating for three and four years, respectively.

According to Chiang, "a book on radiation and health" published by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), which includes some of the world's largest economies, put the total number of deaths caused by the Chernobyl accident at "under 50 people."

Compared to what Chiang described as "the Cabinet's claim" that a total of 15,000 people died and 1.26 million children were contaminated by radiation from that accident, Chiang said that the government's numbers were "obviously incorrect" and were a "suspected attempt" at instilling fear into the public. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT THINK TANK REBUTS REASONS FOR SCRAPPING NUCLEAR PLANT (II)

TEXT.P: Chiang went on to claim that electricity generation via coal and natural gas is more dangerous than nuclear power, saying that the country's three existing nuclear plants have never caused any deaths, while at least 100 fatal accidents involving explosions occur annually at other power plants. Therefore, he added, scrapping the fourth nuclear power plant is actually an "irony" to the government's dream of turning Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

Regarding the disposal of nuclear waste material, Chiang said that the "techniques are mature," and that a site for nuclear waste will be selected in 2016 and will become operational in 2032. In addition, he went on, new natural gas power plants can be built on top of the land used by nuclear plants that have reached the end of their service life.

According to Chiang, the administration's promise that Taiwan will have sufficient electricity in the next seven years even without the fourth nuclear power plant is only a slogan, not a guarantee. If the construction progress on private power plants -- the government's proposed alternative to the nuclear plant -- are delayed by three to five years, Taiwan will see a recurring power shortage "nightmare" where electricity usage has to be limited, he added.

Chiang also criticized Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's claim that losses incurred by stopping the project will be less than continuing to build it, adding that Chang "forgot" that scrapping the project is tantamount to "throwing NT$82.7 billion (US$2.5 billion) into the ocean -- there's no coming back." On the other hand, finishing the plant would have been "an investment," Chiang said.

He also cited national security reasons for continuing to build the plant. In the event that the Taiwan Strait is blockaded, he continued, Taiwan would have to rely on hydroelectricity and nuclear power for the next one to three years because natural gas power plants stop operating on the 15th day of a blockade, oil plants stop on the 46th day, and coal plants stop on the 61st day due to the nation's limited gas, oil, and coal reserve levels.
Each of the two nuclear reactors at the fourth nuclear power plant would have been capable of generating 1,350 megawatts.

Meanwhile, an anti-nuclear alliance invited a city councilman from Niigata to testify that the ABWR units have been a source of constant problems since they became operational. In fact, twice as many problems have popped up than in traditional types of nuclear reactors, the councilman said. Therefore, he urged Taiwan to abolish the fourth nuclear plant and nuclear power altogether.

With increasing demand for electricity, especially for industrial use, the ROC government under the previous KMT administration began plans to construct the fourth nuclear power plant in 1980. Support for the project has been slowly undermined, however, by the general public's environmental concerns and increasingly vehement protests against nuclear power, which culminated in the anti-nuclear DPP government announcement to scrap the plant in late October.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDB CHIEF TO LEAVE FOR MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: With economic relations across the Taiwan Strait growing ever closer, Taiwan's industrial development chief will leave for mainland China for a six-day fact-finding tour, government sources said Monday.

Shih Yen-hsiang, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB), which administers Taiwan's industrial investment in mainland China as well as mainland Chinese industrial imports into the island, is scheduled to visit Shanghai and Guangdong, both of which have attracted large throngs of Taiwanese investors.

IDB sources said Shih will meet with mainland Chinese officials in charge of industrial development as well as explore Taiwan-owned companies' activities and demands as reference for policy formulation by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, of which the IDB is affiliated.

In addition, the sources said, Shih will take advantage of his mainland visit to study whether Taiwan should further ease restrictions on mainland China-bound investments by its information-technology and petrochemical companies.
Shih is also expected to collect information about incentives and measures adopted by mainland China to encourage and boost its industrial development.
Shih will be accompanied by several noted economists and scholars in relevant fields, including Wu Jung-yi, head of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, on his mainland visit.
Attracted by mainland China's cheap land and labor as well as a common culture and language, Taiwan companies have poured some US$40 billion into the mainland for various investment projects.

IDB tallies show that Taiwan investment in mainland China amounted to US$2.1 billion in the first 10 months of this year, up 98 percent from the same period of last year. Of the amount, investments by electronics firms accounted for 55 percent and marked a 158 percent increase from the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL EXPANDS ITS APPLICATION AND DESIGN CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The CPU giant Intel Corp. inaugurated Monday an expanded Asia Pacific Application Design Center Lab in Taiwan, in view of the island's information industry potential and the need to further serve its customers in the Asia Pacific region.
Many local computer industry heavyweights attended the inaugural ceremony, where they held up a card signifying the Pentium 4 chip to mark the opening of the center.

Wu Hui-yu, general manager of Intel's Taiwan branch, noted at the ceremony that Intel has only set up application and design centers in the United States and Taiwan. In the Taiwan center, she went on, Intel offers Taiwan companies the newest technology without the set-back of the time difference between the United States and Taiwan.

Huang I-sung, Intel's marketing chief responsible for Asian and Pacific regions, said that since Intel first established an application and design center in Taiwan in 1995, its has maintained close cooperative ties with Taiwan's manufacturing sector.

Because Taiwan is one of the world's most important information product design centers, he said, Intel decided to expand the scale of the Taiwan facility from five to some 60 engineers, investing a large sum of money in advanced equipment and training more talent to further serve its customers in Asian and Pacific regions.

Wu said Intel's expanded application and design center in Taiwan will offer the same technology supplies as it offers in the United States in terms of desk-top computers, notebooks, PDAs, wireless and fixed-line telecommunications and related products, to reduce the time Taiwan companies need to develop new products.
Intel also plans to place greater importance on the Taiwan design center, she added.

She said that the expanded center will focus its technology supply mainly on personal computers, which account for 80 percent of Intel's total operations, and on wireless, fixed-line telecommunications and Internet, which account for the remaining 20 percent.

Intel Senior Vice Chairman Sean Maloney said that the company's move toward expanding equipment and the scale of its application and design center in Taiwan reflects its confidence in Taiwan's information industry.

He pointed out that Intel purchased Taiwan products worth US$900 million this year, compared with US$450 million last year, representing 100 percent growth, and forecast that the sum will increase further next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE COMMANDER DENIES RUMORS OF LOW F-16 AVAILABILITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min denied a rumor Monday that the nation's F-16 jet fighters have an operational availability rate as low as 28 percent, describing the figure as "ridiculous."
Chen told reporters at a reception to welcome the air force's new political warfare director that "he might have found it acceptable" if the rumor claimed that the breakdown rate was 28 percent.

The fact is, he continued, jet fighters normally do not have high availability rates during peacetime, primarily because sustaining optimal availability takes full support in terms of both spare parts and supply and maintenance systems. During peacetime, he said, these systems are only kept under "normal conditions."

Chen added that only during wartime would the air force "throw in everything" to maintain availability rates higher than 90 percent. However, he said, the availability of the nation's fighters are above the standards set down by the Ministry of National Defense.
The F-16s are "very stable," and their availability rate is high, he said. However, he added, the exact numbers are a military secret and cannot be divulged publicly.
The recent activities of mainland Chinese jet fighters over the Taiwan Strait have been "very normal" and "stable," Chen continued.
Other military sources claimed that the current availability of F-16s can reach as high as 85 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PUSH FOR QUICK SHIPMENT OF AIM-120 MISSILES FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: With mainland China continuing to enhance its armed forces, the Republic of China Air Force plans to push for the shipment to Taiwan of AIM-120 air-to-air missiles it has already bought from the United States, according to ROC air force headquarters.

Speaking on condition of anonymity, a high-ranking air force official said Monday that mainland China will soon acquire from Russia SU-30 MK jet fighters and AA-12 medium-range air-to-air missiles, which will significantly upgrade its air force.

According to previous reports, the United States agreed to sell Taiwan the missiles on condition that they will only be shipped to the island when mainland China owns a missile of similar class -- namely the AA-12 -- or there is a crisis in the Taiwan Strait.

The official said that since Russia will ship SU-30 MK jet fighters and AA-12 missiles to mainland China before the end of this year, the ROC Air Force is planning to push for the shipment to and deployment of AIM-120s in Taiwan in order to upgrade its air defense capability and safeguard the security of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT HAVE 20,000 MORE UNEMPLOYED AFTER WTO ENTRY: CLA

TEXT.P: Taiwan may have 20,000 more people unemployed in the first year after its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to a forecast released Monday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

A report by National Chengchi University commissioned by the CLA indicates that there will be increasing demand for high-tech people with high educational levels after Taiwan's WTO entry, while middle-aged and older workers without high-tech experience will be left by the wayside.
The report estimates that the additional 20,000 unemployed will increase Taiwan's unemployment rate by 0.22 percent.

National Taiwan University professor of economics Wu Chung-chi said that he thinks that even many white-collar workers will lose their jobs after Taiwan's WTO entry, especially workers in the service industry, which has low competitiveness.
W.K. Kung, director of the CLA's Planning and Research Department, urged the government to form an interministerial group to find ways to handle this possible wave of unemployment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT: NATIONAL UNIFICATION COUNCIL IS NONFUNCTIONAL

TEXT.P: Branding the National Unification Council (NUC) an organization "existing only in name," President Chen Shui-bian said Monday he would rather base his policies toward mainland China on conclusions reached by his own non-partisan panel.

In a talk with presidential senior advisers, Chen was quoted as saying that the NUC exists only in name and that he is working on how to graft his non-partisan panel onto the NUC without causing an opposition outcry.
In any case, he went on, the non-partisan panel's decision will be the cornerstone of the government's policy.
Chen made the statement after being urged by some of his advisers to reconvene the NUC, which was put on ice after Chen was sworn in.
Instead of following the guidelines provided for national reunification in the NUC created in 1990, Chen formed the non-partisan panel to work out ways to deal with Beijing .

Other issues such as direct trade and shipping links with mainland China and the faltering stock market were also touched upon in Monday's talks, but Chen made no commitment on anything other than saying that his government will seriously consider the advisors' opinions while forming policies, according to sources who were at Monday's meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: `FRIENDLIER' CROSS-STRAIT TIES THROUGH `MINI 3 LINKS': PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday that he hoped both sides of the Taiwan Strait can enjoy a friendlier relationship through the "mini three direct links" scheduled to be implemented from Jan. 1, 2001.

Chang made the remark when meeting the press to brief reporters on the points reached during a Cabinet meeting held to discuss issues concerning the implementation of the direct links between the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu with the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei.

Chang expressed hope that the relevant government departments can complete the promulgation of regulations governing the "mini three direct links" as well as complete the installation of related software and hardware equipment between Dec. 15 and Dec. 20.
He issued the following five-point set of instructions during the Cabinet meeting:
-- The goal of implementing the "mini three direct links" on Jan. 1, 2001 will not change;

-- The Ministry of National Defense, the Coast Guard Administration, the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Justice should maintain social security in the Kinmen and Matsu areas set aside for direct trade activities with mainland China;
-- All departments concerned should map out their respective operation processes as soon as possible; and
-- The "mini three direct links" must pave the way for systemic dialogue and negotiation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which had outlawed the production, transportation, and sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang, as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens its branch office in Taipei.
1974: A five-member mission of the Central Committee of the Democratic Republican Party of the Republic of Korea led by Chang Kyung Soon arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.

Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TREASURY OFFICIAL TO VISIT ROC DEC. 11-12 ON FINANCIAL ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Richard Lung, a U.S. Treasury Department official in charges of Asia-Pacific affairs, will leave for an Asian tour this week, which will take him to Taiwan, Hong Kong and Thailand, sources said Monday.

Lung, a Chinese-American economist, is scheduled to visit Taipei Dec. 11-12 to gain first-hand information about the Republic of China's policies on stock market, currency exchange rate, financial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and merger of banking institutions.
Lung's upcoming Asian tour has attracted attention as it comes at a time when many Asian currencies have depreciated significantly against the U.S. greenback.
Nevertheless, Treasury Department sources stressed that Lung's visit is a routine and that he is not expected to negotiate with any Asian countries about any issues during his forthcoming visit.

As the Clinton administration will end its term of office in January, the sources said, Lung wants to take advantage of his visit to understand the latest monetary, financial and banking policy trends in various Asian countries.

During his stay in Taipei, Lung reportedly will look into the operations of Taiwan's National Stabilization Fund which was founded during the previous Kuomintang government with a view to stabilizing the island's volatile stock market.

Meanwhile, Lung will asses whether the ROC government has manipulated its currency exchange rate for unfair trade benefits as Taiwan's exports to the United States have set new record this year due to dramatic New Taiwan dollar depreciation against the greenback. Taiwan's Central Bank of China has denied speculation that it has ever manipulated in its currency market operations.

Lung will call at Taiwan's Ministry of Finance and the central bank and other relevant government agencies during his visit to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's current financial policy and further market-opening plans in preparation for the island accession to the World Trade Organization in the near future. Lung reportedly is also interested in understanding Taiwan's recent passage of a legislation allowing merger of financial institutions in order to upgrade its banking industry's competitiveness in the global financial market.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU THINK TANK HOLDS SEMINAR ON TAIPEI-BEIJING RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A ranking Republic of China official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs said here Monday that the ROC government has been actively promoting not only peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait, but also bilateral exchanges.

ROC Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Teng Cheng-chung said at a seminar on the roles of Taiwan, mainland China, and Europe regarding cross-strait issues that the new ROC government's mainland policy has been geared toward establishing stable bilateral relations, resuming dialogue, and promoting economic, cultural, and journalistic exchanges.
The two-day seminar, which began Monday, was jointly organized by the ROC representative office in Belgium and a research arm of the European Union that focuses on Asian affairs studies.

Teng said that "the final resolution of cross-strait political issues must be based on the gradual promotion of exchanges and dialogue to increase bilateral interaction and understanding in an environment of mutual stability and peace, thereby normalizing cross-strait relations and paving the way for a joint handling of the `future one China' issue in the future."

Teng told the scholars and experts from Taiwan, mainland China, England, Germany, Japan, and Hong Kong attending the seminar that the new ROC administration has not been avoiding "sensitive issues" since its inauguration in May and that the various "phenomena" which have been disrupting Taiwan's political situation are in fact part of an "important process" in the resolution of long-term issues.
He went on to say that a normalization of relations between Taipei and Beijing should begin with the normalization of bilateral trade and economic relations.

1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of ROC military service in order to muster the number of reservists.

1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislature revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FURTHER RELAX CURBS ON VISITS BY MAINLANDERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese citizens will soon be allowed to travel, trade, and teach in Taiwan following the passage by the Legislative Yuan of several amendments easing existing restrictions.

The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday passed four amendments to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area easing restrictions on mainland Chinese citizens visiting Taiwan for business, academic, or tourism purposes.

Under the new amendments, qualified mainland Chinese citizens who have formally registered in Taiwan for residence will be allowed to take up teaching posts at Taiwan's universities, research institutes, or social organizations.
Also under the amended regulations, mainland Chinese spouses of Taiwan nationals will be able to legally take up jobs in Taiwan.

The revisions will also solve the problem of the over 1,000 Republic of China nationals who have lived continuously in mainland China for over four years and are in danger of losing their ROC citizenship under the existing regulations because they are considered citizens of the People's Republic of China.
The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council expressed its support for the revisions, which will take effect after President Chen Shui-bian signs them into law.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU CITY OPENS FOREIGN LABORERS SERVICE CENTER

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu City Government opened a foreign laborers counseling service center Wednesday with a view to helping alien workers adapt themselves to new lives in Taiwan as soon as possible.
Hsinchu, a northern Taiwan city where the Republic of China's high-tech industry stronghold -- the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is located, has more than 12,000 foreign workers at present.

Municipal officials said the new center will offer publicity and counseling services concerning the ROC's foreign laborers regulations in order to protect the legitimate rights and interests of legally hired alien workers in Taiwan.

The new center will also provide foreign workers a proper channel for filing complaints and appeals as well as help resolve labor-management disputes between foreign employees and their local employers.
"The center is expected to help promote labor-management harmony and minimize various problems resulting from the introduction of foreign workers," said a Hsinchu city hall official.

According to city government tallies, the 12,000-plus foreign workers in Hsinchu include about 7,500 Filipinos, 2,300 Thai nationals, 1,600 Indonesians and 400 Vietnamese people. The remaining alien workers are from Malaysia.

With technology firms in the Hsinchu industrial park, Taiwan's version of the U.S. Silicon Valley, enjoying a continued export boom, the number of foreign workers in the Hsinchu area has increased steadily in recent years, causing many social problems in the otherwise peaceful city.

With the consent of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, the Hsinchu City Government managed to set up the new foreign laborers service center to handle relevant issues and help local employers improve management of foreign employees.

The center is staffed with three trained counselors and three inspectors who will be responsible for inspecting the employment situation of foreign workers to curb illegal hiring of foreign nationals, city government officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROBLEMS WITH PUBLIC SECTOR YEAR-END BONUS SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Wednesday called on members of the public sector to feel at ease regarding their year-end bonuses despite the evident financial strain the government is experiencing.

Addressing a cross-sectional meeting at the Executive Yuan, Chang promised that payments from the national government coffers will be delivered to local governments around the island before Jan. 14 next year to allow all the nation's public servants to receive their year-end bonuses before the arrival of the Lunar New Year, which begins on Jan. 22.
Chang said that there are "no problems with the bonuses" and called for the public functionaries to "enjoy a happy new year."
The premier made the promise amid widespread worries that the financial strain the government is facing will affect its payment plans for the public sector.

He added that a "salary and payment research ad hoc group" will be established under the Executive Yuan before Dec. 16 to probe the fabric of the government's financial structure in order to seal up any "cracks" that are causing the government to lose money.
There are presently about 1 million people working in the public sector in Taiwan, including government employees, military personnel, and teachers.
