DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO USE NEW THINKING TO BOOST OVERSEAS CHINESE UNITY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Wednesday that his administration will use new thinking and new strategy to boost solidarity of overseas Chinese communities around the world in the face of mainland China's intensified "courting" efforts.

Chen made the vow while meeting with 170-plus commissioners of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), who just concluded their first plenary meeting since Chen's administration was inaugurated in May this year.

Chen said mainland China has stepped drives to court allegiance of overseas Chinese by launching a series of "anti-Taiwan independence and pro-China unification" activities and driving wedges between the new Republic of China government and overseas Chinese communities.

To cope with mainland China's nationalistic and ideological publicity campaign, Chen said, the OCAC must use new thinking and innovative strategy in dealing with overseas Chinese affairs and consolidating overseas Chinese support for the ROC's national cause.

"We must continue improve services to overseas Chinese and forge even closer contacts with them so that overseas Chinese groups around the world will continue using their clout to help safeguard Taiwan's national security and interests in the international community.
Chen went on to say that his administration will continue exercising sincerity and patience in pursuing "goodwill reconciliation, constructive cooperation and lasting peace" with mainland China.

"We will continue seeking a breakthrough to the current cross-Taiwan Strait stalemate and pushing for an early resumption of bilateral dialogue to create a win-win scenario for both sides," Chen stressed.

Noting that the people of Taiwan used their ballots to complete the ROC's first democratic transfer of power from the Kuomintang to his Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election, Chen said the event marks a milestone in the global Chinese community.

"Taiwan has not only set a new model for democratic development in Asia but has also added a touching example to the world's ongoing Third Wave democratization," Che said, adding that all local residents and overseas Chinese the world over should treasure this hard-won achievement and work together to usher in a new era in Chinese history.

Chen vowed to establish a clean, efficient, forward-looking, energetic and competent new government with flexibility and expertise to cope with any emergencies and boost the well-being of people at home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD CONSIDER IMPORTING WATER FROM MAINLAND: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday that the Republic of China government should consider importing fresh water from mainland China to Taiwan's offshore islands to deal with the reality of water shortages there.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Lin said importing water is an economic issue that should be supervised by related agencies other than the Ministry of Economic Affairs, but he added that he personally believes the government should have an overall plan to help accelerate water imports.

Lin made the remarks in response to a question by People First Party Legislator Chiu Chuang-liang during an interpellation session as to whether the "water issue" has also been included in the government's plans to initiate the so-called "three mini links," referring to the direct trade, postal, and transportation links between the ROC-controlled offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese port cities scheduled to kick off early next year.

Chiu said that, as far as he knows, mainland Chinese authorities, in preparation for the implementation of the "mini three links" plan, have begun moves to "export" fresh water from the coastal province of Fujian to Taiwan's offshore island of Kinmen.

According to the information he has obtained, Chiu said that the Fujian port city of Xiamen recently began laying water pipelines and constructing related facilities and that a 6-inch-diameter pipeline from Xiamen to the city's offshore Dadeng Isle, located directly opposite Kinmen and less than 2.4 km away, has already been established.

Noting that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will consider assessing the issue, Lin said the issue may involve other non-economic problems, such as the safety and quality of the water to be channeled into Kinmen.

He added that even if the "water links" are opened soon, the related agencies should also come up with sound quarantine policies to control water safety for Kinmen residents, among which are some 10,000 military personnel.

Hsu Shiang-kueen, director of the Water Resources Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs who was also present at the interpellation session, said to Chiu and other legislators that the water resources plans for Kinmen and Matsu will take care of the two outlying islands' water needs until the year 2011.

Under the plans, Hsu added, the bureau will put up NT$200 million a year for the development and maintenance of Kinmen and Matsu's water resources. Among the other projects included in the plans is the Hsishan Reservoir construction project in Kinmen, which has already been completed. The new reservoir will be used to store rain water and to conduct desalination work, he noted.

Kinmen and Matsu, the ROC's key frontline posts responsible for safeguarding national security, have for long been plagued by water shortages. Soldiers, who used to make up the majority of the population on the islands until several years ago, were known to have practiced retaining water from the walls of tunnels, some of which are large enough to contain underground hospitals and command centers.

Hsu said that although the proposed water imports from mainland China may be a cost-efficient option for the bureau, the government still hopes that the offshore water resources development plans will eventually help the residents of Kinmen and Matsu secure adequate water supplies in the long run.
He disclosed that it costs an average of NT$50 for each water meter reading on Kinmen and Matsu, compared with an average of NT$9.53 on Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS FORMATION OF 'MINI 3 LINKS' GUIDING TASK FORCE

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung ordered the formation of a guiding committee under the Executive Yuan Wednesday to ensure smooth opening of the much-anticipated direct "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of 2001.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said the scheduled opening of direct trade, mail and shipping links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen/Matsu and select mainland Chinese ports is a major national policy.

"We must succeed in implementing this plan and cannot afford any failing in carrying out all relevant measures," Chang said, adding that he has directed Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen to organize a guiding committee to supervise all preparatory work.

As Beijing still refuses resumption of dialogue with Taiwan, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have not yet held any face-to-face talks on the Taiwan-initiated direct "mini three links" between Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Mawei ports.

President Chen Shui-bian has directed that the "mini three links" should be opened under three principles -- no adverse impact on national security and public order and no impact on the government's overall policy stability.

Based on these principles, the Cabinet has decided to carry out the "mini three links" measures step by step. In the first stage, the Republic of China government will unilaterally legalize the "small-amount" trade between fishermen in Kinmen/Matsu and Xiamen/Mawei. Such trading activities have been going on illegally for decades partly because of geographical proximity. Both Kinmen and Matsu lie far closer to the southeastern mainland coast than to Taiwan.

According to the Cabinet's plan, the ROC will allow its fishing boats to sail directly from Kinmen to Xiamen and from Matsu to Mawei to purchase products from Jan. 1. Nevertheless, mainland Chinese people and ships will still be banned from entering ports in Kinmen and Matsu because some technical problems must be resolved through bilateral negotiations.

The "mini three links" plan is designed under the outlying islands development bill passed by the legislature early this year with a view to boosting the economic development of those offshore islands, mainland Kinmen, Matsu and Penghu.

Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai said the "mini three links" plan is not expected to bring any concrete profits to the offshore county in the initial stage because mainland people and ships still cannot enter the territory.

"Nevertheless, we support the plan to be implemented as schedule. We must make a bold step to break the decades-old ban any direct trade and shipping links with the mainland," Chen said, adding that he hopes the plan can enter its second stage in one month or two to bring greater benefits to Kinmen residents.

Meanwhile, opposition Kuomintang spokesman Jason Hu expressed his doubt that the Democratic Progressive Party's plan to use the opening of the "mini three links" to "knock" open mainland China's long-closed door to dialogue with Taiwan. Hu said Beijing has shown little interest in the DPP government's "mini three links" plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN WETLANDS STILL BOAST WORLD'S LARGEST NUMBER OF RARE SPOONBILLS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is seeing a record number of black-faced spoonbills migrating to the island's southern wetlands this winter, with the number of arrivals reaching 469 as of Wednesday, a wildlife conservationist group said.

The number of arrivals is expected to increase to some 530 by early January when more of the endangered birds migrate from areas scattered across North Asia to the warm wetlands of southern Taiwan, said members of the private Tainan Black-faced Spoonbills Conservation Association.

According to an international bird survey, the total 1998-1999 global population of black-faced spoonbills was about 700 to 800, with the great majority of them consistently spending the winter in Taiwan to avoid their cold northern breeding grounds.
Most of the Taiwan-bound black-faced spoonbills have been seen in the Chiku and Tsengwenchi River mouth areas, including the scenic wetlands of Sitsao, in Tainan County.

According to bird conservationists from the Tainan association, sightings of black-faced spoonbills in Tainan County reached a record high of 463 in mid-December last year. The record was smashed this year on Nov. 24, when 468 of the visitors were seen. On Wednesday, the number of sightings was re-established at 469.

According to the Taipei-based Chinese Wild Birds Federation, which compiles data on Asia's wild birds in cooperation with other international wildlife groups, black-faced spoonbills also fly to Hong Kong, Japan, Vietnam and South Korea for the winter, but in much smaller numbers than those that come to Taiwan.

The conservationists added that unlike in previous winters, the spoonbills appear to be relatively more restless and jittery this year, probably because this has so far been a warm winter, coupled with a late harvest season for fishponds in the Tainan coastal area, which has affected the birds' feeding habits. The spoonbills normally feed on left-overs of the fishponds after they have been harvested.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.003 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 33.065.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 33.015 and was traded between 32.890 and 33.175.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$631.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60.3% DEFINE TAIWAN-MAINLAND TIES AS 'STATE-TO-STATE': POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of respondents to a recent public opinion poll think relations between Taiwan and mainland China are state-to-state in nature, the public opinion research center under National Sun Yat-sen University said Wednesday.
The center conducted the telephone poll of 1,085 randomly selected adult residents last week at the request of Huang Chao-hui, a former legislator.

Huang said the survey was aimed at exploring local people's view on the "one China" concept after the cross-party President's Advisory Group on Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations issued "three understandings and four recommendations" on the future development of cross-strait relations.

Survey results show that 60.3 percent of those interviewed said they think that Taiwan and mainland China are independent of each other and that their ties should be defined as "state-to-state" relations.
According to the poll, 46 percent said they regard Taiwan-mainland China relations as "fraternal relationship," while 14.9 percent said they think that Taiwan-mainland China ties are "hostile."
The same survey also found that 75 percent of the respondents would not accept mainland China' rule of Taiwan, but 10.8 percent said they are willing to accept the Chinese communist rule.
A further analysis of poll findings show that residents in northern Taiwan are more willing to accept the mainland rule than their southern Taiwan counterparts.

Meanwhile, 51.8 percent said they think that "one China" refers to the Republic of China, also Taiwan's current national title; 51.2 percent said they think "national unification" means that mainland China rules Taiwan.
Moreover, 52 percent said they think if Taiwan supports "unification" or Beijing's "one China" principle, the island would then fall under the rule of the "People's Republic of China."

Analyzing the poll findings, Huang said Taiwan people and the ROC government should remain highly cautious and exercise wisdom in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait issues now that the majority of local people still oppose mainland Chinese rule of the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PRICE HIKE FOR RICE WINE WITHOUT LEGISLATURE CONSENT: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan resolved Wednesday that the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) will not be allowed to raise the price of rice wine without the consent of the legislature.

The committee endorsed a proposal authored by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chu Hsing-yu to stem a quick price hike for rice wine, a staple ingredient in Chinese and Taiwanese cooking. The hike will be a result of a higher tax levy required if Taiwan is to be permitted to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), which upholds equal and free international trade.

People are already reported to be hoarding Red Label, the most popular rice wine manufactured by the TTWB, in anticipation of Taiwan's WTO entry, which could occur early next year, at which point the wine will be classified as a distillate, with a resulting high tax levy.
Shortages of Red Label rice wine as a result of hoarding actually began as early as November 1999, when talk about Taiwan's WTO accession was widespread.
The shortages prompted the TTWB to import rice wine from Singapore from January this year to overcome a shortfall in domestic production capacity.

At a meeting of the Legislative Yuan Finance Committee Wednesday, Vice Finance Minister Wang Teh-shan dismissed the legislature resolution, pointing out that if the tax on rice wine is not raised, it would run counter to the WTO agreement that Taiwan has committed to respect as a condition of entry into the world trade regulatory body.
The rice wine shortage has been exacerbated with the coming of winter, when local people traditionally use rice wine much more frequently to prepare warming soups and stews.

Currently, both the domestically produced Red Label rice wine and the imported variety are priced at NT$24 per bottle, but the price is expected to shoot up to NT$150 per bottle upon Taiwan's WTO accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SETS UP SECURITY COUNCIL: HONG KONG MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: The Beijing regime has established a national security council, or "small group," to respond rapidly to crises involving national security, reports the Dec. 14 issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review.
An advance copy of the report says that the move is apparently driven by the bombing of mainland China's embassy in Belgrade by NATO aircraft in May last year.

Quoting mainland Chinese officials, it reveals that the group is headed by President Jiang Zemin and coordinated by the director of the general office of the Central Foreign Affairs Leading Group, Liu Huaqiu.

"Some in the Chinese bureaucracy have questioned the need for such a body, arguing that its mission overlaps with the role of the politburo standing committee and the Central Military Commission in times of crisis. But pressure to respond to the embassy bombing with some concrete bureaucratic reform was great enough to ensure the group's creation," it says.
According to the report, the council has not yet had its first meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU HOSPITAL FETES 1ST 5-YEAR SURVIVOR OF LUNG TRANSPLANT

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital held a "thanksgiving" party Wednesday for Taiwan's, and also Asia's, first five-year survivor of a lung transplant.

Hsia Ming-ying, a patient with primary pulmonary hypertension who received a lung transplant at NTU Hospital in 1995 with a lung donated by a brain-dead recipient, was all smiles at the party, thanking the medical team which performed the transplant for helping her regain life and health.
"It's very nice to breathe fresh air normally," a grateful Hsia said emotionally, adding that she can now walk and do household chores.
Hsia represents NTU Hospital's first successful lung transplant and also Asia's first lung transplant recipient to have survived for more than five years.
The teaching hospital has so far performed 25 lung transplants on 21 patients, seven of whom have survived to date. Six of the survivors attended Hsia's party to celebrate her "rebirth."

Speaking on the occasion, Dr. Lee Yuan-chi, convener of the NTU Hospital's lung transplant surgical panel, said lung transplants are difficult because recipients are highly susceptible to post-operative infections, while the number of organ donors and patients who are suitable for transplants is limited.
Taipei Veterans General Hospital performed Taiwan's first lung transplant in the early 1990s, but the recipient died of a fungal infection six months after surgery.
Lee said lung transplants made headway only after the marketing of new anti-rejection drugs in the 1980s.
Noting that lung transplant recipients are very likely to die of chronic rejection, Lee said five-year survival is an important milestone for any recipient.
According to Lee, Taiwan has many patients suffering from various lung ailments who are awaiting transplants.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN ENVOY TO ROC PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: New Dominican Ambassador to the Republic of China Miguel Angel Hernandez Nunez presented his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao Wednesday.
Hernandez, a former journalist, arrived in Taipei Nov. 29 to assume his diplomatic duties. His wife came to Taipei Oct. 12 to serve as minister of the Dominican Embassy.
Hernandez has worked as a reporter, editor, columnist and television program producer in his home country.
Tien had just returned to Taipei from a trip to the United States and was scheduled to meet with reporters the following afternoon to report the results of his visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUPPORTS PROPOSAL TO HALVE NUMBER OF LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Central Standing Committee decided at its regular weekly meeting Wednesday to support a proposal to halve the number of seats in the Legislative Yuan.

During the meeting, Kao Chih-peng, one of the Central Standing Committee members, proposed cutting the number of legislative seats by half, which would give one seat for each of the country's constituencies, with an accompanying measure that would allow a system of "one seat, two votes," whereby each member of the electorate would be permitted to cast two votes -- one for the party and one for the candidate. His proposal won unanimous support from those attending the meeting.
It was also decided at the meeting that the proposal will be submitted to the party policy committee and DPP caucus at the Legislative Yuan for further study.
Other DPP legislators in recent days have proposed cutting the number of legislative seats and the DPP Central Standing Committee's proposal was an echo to the DPP legislators' proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NET USERS SPEND AROUND 15 HOURS PER WEEK ONLINE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan Internet users have spent an average 5.2 years surfing the web and spend an average of 15.6 hours per week on the Internet, according to the results of a recent survey.

According to the results of a survey of local Internet users conducted by Yam.com in 2000, information searches is the most frequent activity among local users, with 30.4 percent of Taiwan's total cyber population often doing so, up from the 1999 level of 25.5 percent.

Information in the Chinese language has become increasingly important for local net users, as 87.6 percent of them usually search for data in Chinese, spending an average 15.6 hours per week, up 4 percentage points and 3.1 hours, respectively, from the 1999 levels, the survey discovered. It also indicates that local web surfers are most troubled by slow connection speeds.
Providing Internet users with comprehensive, accurate and user-friendly services is of vital importance to any portal site seeking to triumph in the coming century, according to one Internet expert.

Sixty-one percent of Taiwan's net users claimed to be willing to shop on the Internet, with each transaction averaging NT$2,611 (about US$79), according to the survey, which revealed that net users aged over 25 form the bulk of online shoppers and that the older the surfer, the bigger the spender he or she is likely to be.
At the same time, around 10 percent of local users own wap phones, with which they usually play Internet games, as well as receive and send e-mails and obtain real-time news.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR COMMISSIONS 4 U.S.-DONATED RESCUE DOGS INTO SERVICE

TEXT.P: Four rescue dogs donated by a U.S. company to Taiwan were formally commissioned into service under the Taipei City Fire Department Wednesday.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou personally presided over a commissioning ceremony at the City Hall for the four highly trained sniffer dogs -- a Labrador and three German shepherds.

During the ceremony, the head of the canine team, named Raggie, was commissioned at the rank of "one-line-four-stars," while the three other dogs -- Sadie, Inga and Koda -- were all presented with ranks of "one-line-three-stars."
Before coming to Taiwan, the four dogs had undergone rigorous training in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, together with the Taipei City Fire Department personnel who will be their handlers.
As they have received full U.S. certification as qualified rescue dogs, they form the Republic of China's first canine team to meet international rescue standards.

Ma said the dogs, aged between 1.5 years and two-years-and-seven-months, will be used in rescue operations involving derailed trains, collapsed buildings, mudslides and other emergencies. "The team's entry into Taipei's rescue services will be a boon to rescue operations in our city," he added.
Ma said the municipal fire department plans to "localize" the rescue dogs through reproduction and training, including training them to understand instructions issued in Mandarin Chinese.

Taipei's Wanfang Fire Station has installed kennel space -- including areas for eating, sleeping and leisure -- on the third floor of its facility. Firefighters there said they were looking forward to working closely with their new canine pals.

Meanwhile, the fire department has asked schoolchildren at five Taipei elementary schools to select their favorite Chinese names for the canine team and each of its four members. The department has proposed five choices for the team and 18 entries for individual dog names. The final choices will be announced Jan. 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PARLIAMENTARIANS TO VISIT ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA): A 13-member Guatemalan parliamentary delegation led by Mario Israel Rivera Cabrera, chairman of the Guatemalan Congress Foreign Affairs Commission, will arrive in Taipei Thursday for an eight-day visit to the Republic of China.

While in Taipei, the Guatemalan parliamentarians will call on Control Yuan President Fredrick F. Chien, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Jong-nan and other government officials.
They will also visit the National Palace Museum, the World Trade Center, and other cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan before departing on Dec. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: STANDARD AND POOR'S LOWERS TAIWAN'S CREDITWORTHINESS PROSPECTS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Mandy Wang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: The economic survey institute Standard and Poor's Wednesday readjusted Taiwan's creditworthiness from stable to negative, citing political squabbling, lack of government direction and falling corporate earnings.
Standard and Poor's also attributed the decrease to a lack of consumer confidence and the large amount of bad loans.
However, the country's long-term credit standing was rated "AA+," while its short-term credit standing was rated "AI+."

Standard and Poor's pointed out that it readjusted Taiwan's credit rating because of concern over the administrative ability of Taiwan's government may increase pressure on the local financial, stock and real estate markets.

The agency further pointed out that although the Taiwan government is trying to carry out economic, public enterprise and banking system reforms, its failure to win support from the opposition might further cut market confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REMOVES RESTRICTIONS ON PHILIPPINE WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) removed restrictions on workers from the Philippines Wednesday, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.

CLA Vice Chairman Kuo Chi-jen said that because Philippine authorities have adopted measures to train Filipino laborers to prevent them from leaving their legal jobs after they get to Taiwan, both the ratio and the number of truant Filipino workers have fallen to second place among foreign laborers on the island.

Concerning the issue of excessively high brokerage fees that such workers are forced to pay, Kuo said that the Republic of China and the Philippines have already reached a consensus on the contents of the ROC-Philippine Direct Hiring Memorandum. The memorandum is expected to be jointly signed at an economic meeting next January.

The Philippine side has also agreed that the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) in Taipei will intermediate in disputes between employers and employees only with the consent of the employer, and only with the participation of a CLA agent. In cases where mediation fails to find a solution, CLA and MECO officials will form an ad hoc committee to resolve them.

The Philippines authorities have also agreed to stop using the term "violation of morality" concerning Taiwan's blacklisting of workers, and have rescinded their demand that employers should bear the burden of all legal expenses incurred by a Filipino employee who works beyond his or her initial two-year contract.

CLA's restriction on hiring workers from the Philippines for major investment projects and public construction projects had been in place since June 1 of this year. The agreement to remove the restriction came after senior Philippine officials, including the minister of labor, came to Taiwan to resolve the issue with CLA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES NEW U.S. GOVERNMENT NOT TO MENTION '3 NOES'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday called on the incoming U.S. government not to mention the outgoing Clinton administration's so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan any more.

Chen, the ROC's first head of state from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, made the appeal while meeting with a group of U.S. China hands organized by the National Committee on American Foreign Policy.

U.S. President Bill Clinton spelled out the "three noes" policy during a visit to mainland China in 1998, pledging that the United States would not support independence for Taiwan, membership for Taiwan in any organization in which statehood is a requirement and "two Chinas" or "one Taiwan, one China".

"I hope the new U.S. government can avoid mentioning the so-called 'three noes' policy," said President Chen, who was particularly critical of attempts to block Taiwan's entry to major international organizations.

If the United States really needs to have "three noes," President Chen suggested that it add a fourth "no" stating that it opposes mainland China using military force to resolve the Taiwan Strait issue.

Chen further told his guests -- many of them former U.S. officials -- that his administration is willing to discuss with Beijing any proposals for resolving bilateral sovereignty disputes, regardless forming a commonwealth, a confederation, a special "state-to-state" relationship or a European Union-style alliance.
Nevertheless, Chen stressed that any solution to the Taiwan Strait issue and any change to Taiwan's present status quo must have the assent of the 23 million people of Taiwan.

"With strong convictions for peace, democracy and prosperity, my administration will forge a new relationship with mainland China with patience and sincerity," Chen assured the visiting U.S. scholars.

He also urged the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a Washington-based think tank, to offer three other suggestions to the incoming U.S. government concerning its future policy toward Taiwan.

First of all, Chen said the United States should not sacrifice Taiwan's interest while dealing with Beijing. "We also expect equal and parallel engagements with the United States and look forward to seeing the United States play the role of 'balancer and stabilizer' in cross-strait relations and help promote peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region."

Second, Chen said he hopes that the unreasonable restrictions and treatment endured by senior ROC officials visiting or making stopovers in the United States can be eased and improved, and that U.S. officials responsible for foreign and security affairs don't have to wait until they retire to visit Taipei.

Third, Chen went on, the ROC hopes that the new U.S. government will reaffirm its commitment to abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act, the 1982 "six guarantees" to Taiwan, and the 1994 Taiwan policy review. "We also hope that the new U.S. administration will add a 'fourth pillar' to its China policy -- the solution to Taiwan Strait issues must win the consent of the people of Taiwan."

"One China," dialogue and peaceful means form the three pillars of the U.S. China policy. Chen said he hopes that the incoming U.S. government will add "no use of force against Taiwan" as the premise to its "one China" policy.

Chen further said he attaches great importance to the "three understandings and four recommendations" recently presented by a presidential advisory group on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, headed by Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh. "I feel regret that Beijing has flatly rejected all those proposals," he said, adding that as Taiwan is a pluralistic democratic society, it needs time to forge a national consensus on Taiwan's future relations with mainland China.
He also told the American visitors that mainland China basically does not recognize the so-called "1992 consensus on 'one China, separate interpretations."
"Against this background, I think it is very important that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sit down to work out a mutually acceptable definition of 'one China,'" Chen urged.
The visiting U.S. scholars included former U.S. assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord and President Bill Clinton's former top Asia adviser Kenneth Lieberthal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION TO PROBE LAFAYETTE PURCHASE SCANDAL IN FRANCE

TEXT.P: Opposition parties in the legislature have announced a plan to organize a delegation to fly to France to search for the truth behind a scandal linked to the sale to Taiwan of French-made Lafayette-class frigates.
Opposition lawmakers from the Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party (PFP) and New Party (NP) met at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday to discuss forming the delegation.
Chung Shao-ho, PFP legislative whip, said that because delegation is still being organized, the date on which it will fly to France has not yet been decided.

Members of the delegation said they hope to meet with key French parliamentarians, former French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, and a former broker for French defense company Thomson-CSF, who arranged the sale of the vessels.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH MEMBERS OF U.S. THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh said Wednesday that his party's cross-strait policy is heading in the direction of promoting mutual good will between Taiwan and mainland China.
Hsieh asserted that the DPP's cross-strait policy is more tolerant and flexible than that of the former Kuomintang administration.

Hsieh made the remarks at a meeting with a six-member delegation of the National Policy Committee on American Foreign Relations led by Winston Lord, former U.S. assistant secretary of state for the Asian-Pacific region. The meeting took place Wednesday evening at DPP Headquarters.
Hsieh briefed the American visitors on the ruling party's policy on cross-strait relations.
Hsieh said that the party supports safeguarding the Republic of China's sovereignty, and maintains that any change in the status quo is subject to the consent of the people of Taiwan.
Hsieh told local reporters after the meeting that the U.S. visitors expressed their concern over the DPP's cross-strait policy and its policy-making mechanism.
The U.S. think tank delegation arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a fact-finding tour of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CAUTIONS AGAINST PROSECUTION ABUSES IN FIGHTING CRIME

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan criticized the administration of the Democratic Progressive Party Wednesday for touting its efforts to crack down on crime while cutting legal corners in carrying out the campaign.
He lamented that the DPP government has damaged what he said is the rule-of-law foundation laid down by the Kuomintang during its five decades of government control.

According to Lien, the KMT's longtime support of a fair, just and efficient legal system has helped safeguard human rights and social security. He urged KMT lawmakers to ensure that legal due process is followed by the administration in fighting crime.

Lien made the comments at the weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee after listening to a report by the party's think tank on KMT calls for "safeguarding human rights, respect for freedom of the press, adherence to just procedures and opposition to selective investigation."
The report by Chen Hsin-min, a researcher at the Kuomintang National Policy Foundation, said the country's legal system is "deteriorating" with the new government in place for only six months.

Noting the search of a Kuomintang lawmaker's office and the prosecution raid on the office of the China Times Express, Chen asserted that these actions are taboo in democratic societies and are rarely seen in the West.

According to Chen, just six months into office, the DPP administration has already threatened to ruin two of the pillars of democracy -- an independent legislature and press freedom. He went on to quote the old adage that wherever there is power there is abuse.
He warned that such abuse of power will rapidly develop into a more common practice if it is not nipped in the bud.
Chen's report drew some veiled commentary from his fellow party members at the meeting.
Liu Chao-shiuan, vice chairman of the think tank, cautioned the party to distance itself from some of its prominent members, especially those who have suspicious reputations.

He said that to clean the party's tainted image, the Kuomintang should be prepared to "bite the bullet" and excise its criminal elements. He said that deeds, especially ones indicating the party's determination, "speak much louder than words," he said.

Liu's views were shared by Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who claimed that the party can never do too much to get its house in order, and Kuomintang Spokesman Jason Hu, who urged the party to spearhead the nation's campaign to weed criminals from the political system.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS SCORE HIGH IN GLOBAL SCIENCE, MATH TESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's junior high school students score first in science and third in mathematics in a global eighth graders' academic achievements study, according to the results released Tuesday.

Results from the Third International Mathematics and Science Study-Repeat (TIMSS-R) show that Taiwan students score an average of 569 points in science test, the highest among students in 38 countries studied.
Meanwhile, Taiwan students receive an average score of 585 points in mathematics test, next only to Singapore (604 points) and South Korea (587 points).
The TIMSS-R testing was conducted by the non-profit International Association of Educational Achievement (IEA) in 1999 with funds donated by various countries and the World Bank.
The math and science study scored students aged 12 to 14 on their abilities in mathematics, algebra, geometry, biology, physics and other related subjects.
This was the first time that Taiwan has participated in the TIMSS-R testing. A total of 5,772 students selected from 150 public junior high schools around the island took part in the testing.

The results show that 41 percent of participating Taiwan students scored over 616 points in mathematics and the top-10 percent ratio in science test also reached 31 percent. In terms of the top-10 percent ratios, Taiwan ranked second among all the 38 participating countries, lagging behind only Singapore.
According to the IEA report, East Asian students generally score far higher than their Western counterparts in the TIMSS-R testing.

Nevertheless, Chang Meng-lin, head of the cultural affairs division of the Republic of China's representative office in the United States, said Taiwan students generally perform better than their U.S. counterparts in the elementary and high school stages due to different educational methods in the two countries. Chang said the United States remains the best in advanced-level education.
The IEA report refers Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" instead of its national title "ROC."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS AIR VIEWS ON TAIWAN'S S&P RATINGS DOWNGRADE

TEXT.P: Republic of China government officials Wednesday indicated their concern about the latest report from U.S. ratings agency Standard & Poor's, which downgraded Taiwan's economic outlook from stable to negative.

Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan urged the people to maintain their confidence in the country's economy, saying that the island's general economic fundamentals remain sound and the rating for Taiwan's currency remains unchanged.
He said that the most important thing now is "to do what we should do, while paying attention to relevant developments."

Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih said that many people are worried about the political disputes between the ruling party and the opposition, but so far such disputes have not affected the operations of enterprises or public consumption.

He said that the most critical thing now is whether or not the national budget will be approved by the Legislative Yuan, where the ruling Democratic Progressive Party holds only one-third of the seats.
Chen said that his council will closely watch the island's changing economic situation, and urged the people to be confident of the country's ability to tide over the present economic difficulties.
Vice Finance Minister Chen Chung said that the Standard and Poor's downgrade constituted a "friendly reminder" about Taiwan's economic situation.
"It is indeed a good thing to remind Taiwan. Otherwise, the situation may turn worse in the future," he noted.

Chen admitted that the report on financial difficulty was justified. He said it was due to the fact that the budget for post-earthquake reconstruction projects has been increased by NT$200 billion, while tax revenues have decreased by NT$100 billion.
However, he said that the financial situation was not extremely bad when compared with those in other countries.
National Chengchi University Professor Yin Nai-ping said that the ratings downgrade might result in increased costs for local enterprises seeking foreign capital.
He added that it could also exacerbate the outflow of foreign investment, driving the value of Taiwan's currency down even further.

He noted that whenever a professional foreign ratings agency casts doubt about a government's financial management skills and a state's political stability, the nation's flow of foreign capital will be affected to some extent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG MEETS WITH U.S. EXPERTS ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong told visiting members of a U.S. think tank Wednesday that he is worried about what he called the administration's mistaken judgment on the cross-strait issue.

Meeting over lunch with a delegation from the National Policy Committee on American Foreign Relations, Soong said that although cross-strait relations seem to be heading toward improvement, this is only on the surface.

He said the expected entry of Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization next year, Beijing's desire to host the 2008 Olympiad, and the fact that the next Asian Pacific Economic Corporation Forum will be held in Shanghai all feed optimism that the cross-strait situation will improve.
However, the government should not misjudge the situation and become overly optimistic, Soong warned.
He also reminded the people of Taiwan that U.S. policy toward the two sides of the Strait will remain unchanged after the new U.S. administration is sworn in.
U.S. foreign relations experts lunching with Soong included Kenneth Lieberthal, U.S. President Bill Clinton's former top adviser on Asian affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER 'COMFORT WOMEN' GATHERING FOR PROTEST RALLY IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Former "Comfort women" from more than 10 countries are gathering in Tokyo for a demonstration beginning Friday to denounce Japan's Showa emperor and Imperial Army leaders for their war crimes.

Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, who will chair the gathering, told the media Wednesday that the main purpose of the event is to speak for the war-victimized women and to correct erroneous concepts about sexual violence.
Former "comfort women" from Taiwan, South Korea, North Korea, Indonesia and the Netherlands also met with the media at Wednesday's press conference.

One woman from North Korea said that she was forced to serve as a "comfort woman" -- one of thousands of women forced into prostitution by the Japanese Imperial Army in the 1930s and 1940s -- when she was 12 years old. She said that she wants the Japanese government to apologize for what happened to her and all the other women.
Four of the 12 attending former "comfort women" from Taiwan will appear on Saturday to tell their stories.
A spokeswoman for a Taiwan group supporting the former "comfort women" said that the Japanese government should extend an apology to the former sex slaves so as to reinstate their dignity.
Over 1,000 people have applied to attend the rally, according to its organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE IS COMMON LANGUAGE OF TAIWAN AND UNITED STATES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Peace -- especially peace across the Taiwan Strait -- is the common language of Taiwan and the United States, said Premier Chang Chun-hsiung Wednesday.

Noting that the balance of military might between Taiwan and mainland China is the groundwork for peace between the two former civil war rivals, Chang told a group of U.S. visitors that providing Taiwan with arms necessary for its defense is in the interests of Washington.
Citing a forecast by local military analysts, Chang warned that the cross-strait military balance so carefully maintained by Washington might tilt toward Beijing after 2005.
The premier said he hopes that Washington will address the problem by maintaining arms sales to Taiwan despite Beijing's fierce opposition.
He reiterated the government's stance that Beijing's claim to suzerainty over all of China -- including Taiwan -- is at variance with mainstream public opinion on the island.
Chang added that nonetheless, Taipei is willing to discuss with Beijing the meaning of the mainland's claims, and will do its utmost to maintain friendly relations with Beijing.

He said Taipei welcomes the improvement in ties between Washington and Beijing, and will not gloat about any regression in their relationship. Taiwan's only concern is that the interests of its people and peace across the Taiwan Strait are not compromised by changes in Washington-Beijing relations, he stressed.
Led by former U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Winston Lord, the delegates from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a two-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR OFFICIAL VISIT

TEXT.P: El Salvador President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrived in Taipei Wednesday night for an official visit.

Flores and his 26-member entourage were greeted by Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao at the airport, and a formal welcoming ceremony with full military honors is scheduled to be held in Taipei Thursday morning.
The Salvadoran president, who has already visited Taipei once during his presidency, will meet with President Chen Shui-bian as well as other government leaders during his four-day stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET PLUNGE NOT RELATED TO POLITICAL TRANSITION: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian claimed Wednesday that the plummeting Taiwan stock market has nothing to do with the Taiwan's recent transition of political power.

Pointing to simultaneous falls in other Asian stock markets, Chen told Robert Shiller, a Yale University economics professor, that the sharp plunge in Taiwan's stock market is in line with the global trend. The local bourse has seen the market value of its total listed stocks trimmed by nearly 40 percent since Chen was sworn in on May 20.

In addition to the NASDAQ, Japan, Indonesia, South Korea and Thailand have experienced a drop in stock prices, although no power shift is underway in any of those countries, Chen was quoted as telling Shiller.
Therefore, Chen said, it is evident that the cause of the Taiwan market's plunge is something other than the government handover.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TAIWAN STUDENTS STUDYING IN JAPAN RANKED THIRD
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: As of May 1 this year, Taiwan was sending the third most students to Japan, next only to mainland China and South Korea, according to statistics released Wednesday by Japan's Education Ministry.

The statistics indicate that the total number of foreign short- and long-term students at Japanese universities and junior colleges totaled 64,011 as of May 1 this year, a new record high and an increase of 8,200 from the same month in 1999.

According to the ministry, the number of mainland Chinese students ranked first, with 32,300, up 6,400 from the same period last year; the number of South Korean students was second, with 12,900, up 1,000 from the previous year; and the number of Taiwan's students ranked third, with 4,200, up an annual 100.
Asian students accounted for 90 percent of total foreign students studying in Japan at the time, the statistics show.
Deeper analysis found that the number of foreign students paying their own tuition had grown significantly, reaching 53,600, an increase of 8,200 from the same month last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 7, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts to achieve Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese rulers of three centuries leave the colony.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan cables independence day felicitations to Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Bishop H.H. Brookins, Dr. James G. Blake, and Bishop W. Hilliard, all members of a U.S. religious group visiting Taiwan.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY FOREIGN MINISTER SAID TO BE APPOINTED ROC'S FIRST REP IN EU

TEXT.P: Republic of China Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee is expected to be appointed the ROC's first representative at the headquarters of the European Union, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.

Lee, a member of the opposition Kuomintang, is being appointed by the Democratic Progressive Party-controlled government because of his seasoned diplomatic expertise and his sound people-to-people skills and experience, said the sources.
The appointment of Lee to be the first envoy at the EU headquarters also signals the importance that Taiwan is attaching to the development of relations with Europe, the sources said.

Lee may also be named concurrently as the ROC's representative in Belgium, replacing Huang Yen-chao, who will be re-assigned as the country's representative in Malaysia, said MOFA officials who preferred to remain anonymous.
According to the officials, Lee, who has been a stalwart KMT official and an astute diplomat, sought and received KMT Chairman Lien Chan's consent to accept the appointment.
Vice Administrative Foreign Affairs Minister Wu Tzu-dan is likely to be promoted to fill the vacancy to be left by Lee's departure as deputy foreign minister, they noted.
Lee, 51, obtained his doctorate in foreign affairs from the University of Virginia and conducted research at Harvard University's Fairbank Center for East Asian Research in 1993.

During his over 18-year career in public office, Lee has been chief of the ROC's representative office in Boston between 1993-96 and the ROC government spokesman between 1996-97 before becoming the deputy foreign minister in 1998.

Lee's appointment as the ROC representative at the EU headquarters is said to be only part of an ongoing personnel reshuffle taking place within the foreign ministry since the new DPP government took office in May of this year.

Other likely changes on the ROC's diplomatic front include the appointment of Prof. Chen Tung-pi from Tamkang University as the ROC's chief representative in Canada, replacing Fang Chin-yen, who will be re-assigned to another post, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEES KILL TMD BUDGET

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan's Defense and Budget and Final Accounts Committees Thursday decided to kill a budget proposal for helping finance a U.S.-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) system.

The opposition-dominated parliamentary committees deleted all of NT$1 billion (US$30.3 million) in budget for TMD-related projects included in the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) secret budget plan for fiscal 2001, which will begin Jan. 1.

Opposition New Party Legislator Elmer Feng said the Republic of China would have to spend at least NT$300 billion in the first 10 years of the TMD development if it indeed decides to join the costly U.S.-proposed joint defense system.
Moreover, Feng said, follow-up TMD development projects could cost an additional NT$300 billion in the long run, posing a great burden to the national coffers.
Since the United States has not yet made a final decision on whether to develop the controversial TMD program, Feng said he sees no reason for the MND to set aside budget for the plan in advance.
According to the MND-drafted plan, the NT$1 billion fund would be used for TMD-related land acquisition and long-range, early-warning missile system projects.

In his view, Feng said, Taiwan's participation in the TMD program could never generate benefits compatible with its required spending on the project. "Worse yet, the move would be very likely to further strain relations across the Taiwan Strait," noted the pro-unification lawmaker.
Senior mainland Chinese officials have on many occasions voiced strong opposition to the U.S. plan to include Taiwan into its TMD project.

Speaking at Thursday's budget screening meeting, another New Party lawmaker, Cheng Lung-shui, also questioned the MND's wisdom to set aside budget for a highly expensive project whose development prospects are still up in the air.

As most other opposition lawmakers present at the meeting echoed the two NP legislators' views, the MND-proposed NT$1 billion budget for TMD-related projects was totally erased from the military's secret budget plan for the coming fiscal year.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 70 points to close at 5,245, with 9,257 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 increased 79 points to finish at 5,249, with 163 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures gained 39 points to close at 5,304, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 42.11 points to close at 5,212.73.
Affected by a drop in U.S. stock prices, the bourse opened at 5,131.94 and began to go up following a small rebound in DRAM stocks. The index fluctuated between 5,216.22 and 5,131.94 during trading.

A total of 1.47 billion stocks worth NT$48.01 billion (US$1.46 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.23 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$77.03 billion (US$2.33 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted losses, with both construction stocks and pulp and paper issues moving down 1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.9 percent, and plastics and chemical shares, cement stocks, and electrical shares, all at 0.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 348 to 141, with 107 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. HOUSE REP. CALLS ON COLLEAGUES TO CONDEMN M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: U.S. Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va., has urged his colleagues to condemn Communist China because it has continued to repress its own citizens since it was granted permanent normal trade relations status with the United States.

In a Tuesday speech on the House floor citing recent human rights abuses by Beijing, Rep. Wolf, a long-time critic of Communist China's human rights record, told congressional supporters of granting Beijing PNTR that they must now speak out against the Beijing regime's actions against its own people.

During the PNTR debate, some supporters advanced the argument that PNTR would "bring change to China, open up the country, improve human rights, and reduce the national security threat that China poses to the U.S.," said Wolf.
However, he pointed out, people in mainland China "continue to be persecuted, imprisoned, and in some cases killed, because of their faith."

He added that many lawmakers said they voted in favor of PNTR "because they thought it would bring about a positive change to China's horrible human rights record and would ultimately increase U.S. national security," noting that Beijing's record has suggested otherwise.
"I urge all those members who voted for PNTR to challenge the regime in Beijing," he said.

"Speak out because the people who are suffering, who are imprisoned, or who are serving brutal sentences at labor camps need the concerted voice of Congress to bring about real and positive change in China," emphasized Wolf.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT YOUTH SUMMIT CANCELED OVER UNCERTAINTY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Thursday it has decided to cancel a plan to co-sponsor cross-Taiwan Strait youth summit meetings with a mainland Chinese research association due to uncertainties surrounding the program.

The DPP said the Beijing-based National Taiwan Research Association (NTRA) took the initiative to invite the party's Department of Youth Development and the Graduate Institute of Mainland Chinese Research of Taipei's Tamkang University to jointly organize youth meetings in mainland China and Taiwan.

The three parties originally agreed to co-host youth meetings in Beijing and Shanghai from Dec. 9-16, with the participation of students of mainland China's Peking University, Tsinghua University, Renmin University of China and Fudan University as well as Taiwan's college students who had previously attended the DPP-sponsored policy research camps.

However, the Beijing-based NTRA informed the DPP youth department earlier this week that senior mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs have pressured it not to receive any visitors from Taiwan for the time being.

The NTRA suggested that the planned cross-strait youth summits in Beijing and Shanghai be postponed for a few weeks. Wang Ming-yuan, director of the DPP youth department, said mainland authorities have not yet approved his application for extension of his mainland travel permit.
Wang, who originally planned to lead the Taiwan delegation to attend the Beijing-Shanghai youth summits, said as many uncertainties surrounded the events, the DPP has decided to cancel the program.

Wang pointed out that Beijing authorities disapproved of the "three understandings and four recommendations" recently presented to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian by Taiwan's cross-party presidential advisory group on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

As the cross-party advisory group didn't explicitly suggest that President Chen embrace Beijing's "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government under the PRC, Wang said, the Beijing leadership declined to open doors for contacts with the DPP and resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

Wang said since the pro-independence DPP took the helm in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, mainland China has adopted a "dual" attitude toward the ROC's new ruling party.
"While mainland leaders publicly reject any contacts or engagements with the DPP, they are eager in private to acquire a better understanding of Taiwan's home-grown political party," Wang explained.

Wang said he feels regret over the forced cancellation of the long-planned cross-strait youth summits. "I hope both sides of the Taiwan Strait can exercise reason and wisdom to resolve bilateral disputes and make continued efforts to forge rapprochement," he urged, adding that the DPP's youth department is willing to promote cross-strait exchanges of youth visits if opportunities present themselves in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ASKS FRANCE FOR COOP'N IN FRIGATE DEAL GRAFT INVESTIGATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appealed to the government of France Wednesday for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years ago.

Chen asked the French justice authorities to provide him with a name list of ROC military personnel and politicians who were allegedly involved in a graft scandal involving the US$2.8 billion 1991 Lafayette deal.

The number of ROC Navy officers and politicians allegedly involved in the graft case, in which US$500 million was said to have been paid by French shipbuilder Thomson-CSF and other related manufacturers to secure the sale of the Lafayette-class frigates to Taiwan is said to be around two dozen.
Chen made the appeal in separate interviews with leading French newspapers Le Monde and La Liberation, both of which carried the interviews in their dailies on Wednesday.

In the interviews, Chen also urged the French government and judicial authorities to show goodwill toward Taiwan by providing related information to ROC authorities to help solve the kickbacks scandal which also allegedly involved the murder of several people, including ROC Navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng.

Chen also asked Thomson-CSF to repay the ROC Navy the alleged kickbacks, which were reportedly flown to Taiwan, with a portion of them then being transferred to France, the United States, and mainland China as "grease money" for certain figures.
He said that if his appeal falls on deaf ears, the ROC Navy will sue Thomson-CSF for breaking the contract forged between the two sides before 1991.
Under the terms of the Lafayette purchase contract, Chen noted, Taiwan is entitled to seek compensation if the French suppliers are found to have paid bribes or commissions for the deal.

Chen told the two French newspapers that although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party government only has a minority in the Legislative Yuan, the government's determination in cracking down on crime is definite and unquestionable.

He admitted that solving the graft scandal has become increasingly difficult because so much time has elapsed since the deal, so many people were apparently involved in the scandal, so many human and technical barriers to the investigations exist, and so much important evidence has been destroyed over time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREX RESERVES PLUMMET TO 11-MONTH LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves fell to an 11-month low of US$108.23 billion at the end of November, the result of a recent surge in local foreign currency savings accounts, the Central Bank of China reported Thursday.

November's total, which was a decrease of US$825 million from that of October, remained the world's third largest national foreign exchange hoard, behind those of Japan and mainland China, according to CBC officials.

Despite five consecutive monthly reductions, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves in November were still some NU$4.69 billion higher than the year-earlier level of US$103.54 billion, CBC officials said.

CBC officials attributed the fall to the drastic increase of foreign currency deposits in domestic banks, continuing depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, and increased foreign currency purchases by importers in anticipation that the NT dollar will continue falling.

The CBC's foreign exchange holdings, which stood at an historic high of US$113.83 billion in June this year, have continuously fallen since September, and have shed some US$5.59 billion since the end of June, CBC officials said.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves plummeted to a record low of US$82.55 billion in March 1996, when Beijing conducted a series of missile firings and live-ammunition war games on Taiwan's doorstep.
With cross-strait relations easing and capital returning to Taiwan, the nation's foreign currency reserves had recovered steadily over the past several years.
