DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MAINLANDERS NABBED FOR CROSSING TO KINMEN

TEXT.P: With the so-called "mini three links" not yet officially established, two mainland Chinese men were found Thursday to have illegally crossed over to Kinmen to conduct "business talks," police sources from the offshore island reported.

Wang Junzhen, 29, and Wang Jianpuo, 28, both from mainland China's coastal province of Fujian, were caught red-handed in a restaurant in downtown Kinmen around 4 a.m. Thursday, where they were discussing "commercial exchanges" with three Kinmen business people, the police said.
According to the police, while the two Wangs were brought in for interrogation, the three Kinmen locals fled during the midnight crackdown.

Wang Junzhen told the police that he is an employee of a fishery production company in the Fujian port city of Xiamen. He said that his boss sent him to the ROC-controlled outlying island to scout the local market, particularly looking to set up potential sales of fish and seaweed. He added that his boss wanted to get a jump on the scheduled establishment of the "mini three links" early next year.

The so-called "mini three links" -- referring to direct trade, postal and transportation links between the ROC-control frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and select mainland Chinese port cities, including Xiamen -- are planned to be set up the ROC government in an attempt to facilitate exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China and help ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Wang confessed that he and the other Wang, a fisherman, departed Xiamen around midnight aboard a motored sampan and arrived around 1:30 a.m. on the shores of Kinmen, where they were picked up by several local people and driven away in a sedan.
Wang said they were originally scheduled to leave Kinmen for home around 5 a.m. the same day.

The pair will be sent to a detention center in Taiwan after their interrogations are completed, said the police, who added that they will continue trying to hunt down the three Kinmen residents who fled.

DOC.HEADLINE: '1992 CONSENSUS' SAID BEIJING'S BOTTOM LINE FOR 'ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung said Thursday he is convinced that the "1992 consensus" reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is Beijing's bottom line regarding its cherished "one China" principle.

Wu made the remarks while briefing members of a KMT Legislative Yuan subgroup on his recent visit to the mainland. Wu was the highest-ranking KMT official to visit there since the 106-year-old party was driven to Taiwan by the Chinese Communist Party in a civil war in 1949.
During his Nov. 17-28 visit, Wu met with senior mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs, including Vice Premier Qian Qichen and Wang Daohan, the top mainland negotiator with Taiwan.

After extensive talks with mainland officials, Wu said he has come to understand that the Beijing leadership is unlikely to accept any Taiwan retreat from the "1992 consensus" as far as cross-strait relations are concerned.
Wu said mainland leaders basically understand the previous KMT-led Republic of China government's stances on cross-strait ties.

"Mainland leaders understand our claims that China is now divided and separately ruled, that before the two sides are unified under democracy, each side can have its own interpretation of 'one China,' that the ROC is an equal entity to the PRC, and that the 'one country, two systems' Beijing used to take over Hong Kong and Macau is not applicable to Taiwan," Wu explained.
Nevertheless, Wu admitted that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait remain far divided over the content of "one China" or "unification."

Wu said he hopes the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government can return to the 1992 "one China, separate definitions" consensus, which allowed Taipei and Beijing to hold a historic high-level conference in Singapore in 1993, commonly known as the "Koo-Wang" meeting.

Noting that Taiwan's bargaining chips vis-a-vis mainland China are gradually fading away, Wu said the new ROC government should not drag its feet in play of words and should instead focus on forging a national consensus on future cross-strait ties to facilitate resumption of cross-strait dialogue.

The current DPP government has been reluctant to recognize the so-called 1992 "one China, separate definitions" consensus because the DPP's pro-independence diehards could not accept "one China" or "unification" as the sole option for Taiwan's future.

Wu said the new ROC government should give priority to the common interest of the 23 million Taiwan people and make strenuous efforts to forge a national consensus on the critical "one China" issue. According to Wu, mainland leaders remain highly suspicious of the DPP administration because of the party's pro-independence stance.

Wu said he had told his mainland hosts that their fears of Taiwan declaring independence were overblown because the majority of Taiwan people do not support such a move. "I advised mainland leaders not to overreact to the independence-unification debate in Taiwan as their hardline, bellicose rhetoric would only hurt Taiwan people's feelings and hinder bilateral rapprochement."

Wu went on to suggest that the DPP step up efforts to forge contacts with the Chinese Communist Party. "I hope to see more DPP heavyweights travel to the mainland to push for inter-party exchanges and facilitate formulation of the new ROC government's policy toward mainland China," he said, adding that more mainland visits would help DPP officials formulate more realistic, feasible policy and strategy on cross-strait affairs.
To his knowledge, some mainland scholars are studying various possible formulas, including "commonwealth" and "confederation," for future Taiwan-mainland China relations.

Asked whether the two sides can sign an agreement on mutual arms reduction, Wu said he does not think that the proposal is feasible. "As mainland China' military buildup plans are based on its global combat strategy, it is unlikely to suspend development of long-range strategic missiles and other relevant weaponry systems simply for Taiwan's demand," he explained.

Wu also reiterated his view that the time is still not ripe for KMT Chairman Lien Chan to visit the mainland. "Lien's visit must be conducive to cross-strait ties. Such a condition has not yet ripened," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EFFORTS TO UPGRADE TAIPEI'S LIVABILITY TO CONTINUE: MA

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that efforts to upgrade Taipei's status in the list of "most livable" Asian cities will continue.
Ma said the criteria of evaluating cities change slightly every year, but domestic changes in the Republic of China as a whole also can have an impact on the city's ranking.

According to a list published in the Dec. 8 issue of Asiaweek, Taipei is ranked as the fourth best Asian city in which to reside. The ranking was something of a disappointment after the city's second-place position on last year's list.
Tokyo and Fukuoka were tied for first this year, with Tokyo rising from fourth place on 1999's list. Fukuoka occupied the first place ranking by itself last year.
Singapore was ranked third this year, while Osaka and Taipei -- which tied for second last year -- slid into fourth in the latest rankings.

Noting that the city is at least still ranked among the top five in Asia, Ma attributed Taipei's high marks to the efforts of all of his predecessors. But he admitted that Taipei still has a room to improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOREIGN TRADE GROWING MORE SLOWLY THAN EXPECTED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export and import growth forecasts for 2000 will possibly be pared by one percentage point due to a slow global economy and continued depreciation of the local currency, the Finance Ministry announced Thursday.

Stressing that the nation's exports have seen 14 consecutive months of double-digit growth, the ministry said that the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) may have to adjust its annual export growth estimate from 23.1 percent to 22.1 percent, while its import growth forecast for the year may drop from 28.1 percent to 27.1 percent.
Additionally, the DGBAS forecast for this year's trade surplus may drop from US$7.9 billion to US$7.8 billion, the ministry announced.
However, Taiwan's external trade continues to expand steadily, the ministry noted.

According to Finance Ministry statistics, export volume for November reached US$12.72 billion, a 10.3 percent increase from the same period last year, mainly due to increased exports to the United States, Europe, Japan, South Korea, and the five members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Import volume reached US$11.95 billion during the month, an 18.2 percent increase from November 1999, due mainly to increased imports from the United States, Japan, and the ASEAN region; while the nation's monthly trade surplus reached US$770 million, US$650 million less than last year same period, according to the ministry.

Rapid growth in global trade volume and Taiwan's increasing competitiveness in high-tech exports drove the rapid growth figures, with electronics, information technology, and mechanical and optical equipment the leading sectors in exports, the ministry said.

It concluded that if the domestic economic and political situations can be stabilized, and if the degree of influence on the domestic economy by non-economic factors can be decreased, the economy will be able to maintain continued steady growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS STRONG TIES WITH EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a grand welcoming ceremony Thursday for Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez, who arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a four-day state visit.
Flores was accorded full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute, in the ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex near the Presidential Office.
In his welcoming remarks, Chen said the Republic of China highly treasures its 60-plus-year friendship with El Salvador.
Chen, who took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, also stressed the continuity of ROC foreign policy.

Chen said the ROC government will honor all bilateral promises and obligations under treaties and agreements with El Salvador. "We'll also continue upgrading relations and cooperation with El Salvador based on current foundations," he added.

He further said the ROC will consider favorably a request for agricultural technology assistance presented by Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt during a visit he made to Taiwan in October.

Chen also expressed his gratitude for the Salvadoran government and people's longtime support and assistance for the ROC's bids to join international activities and organizations, including the United Nations.

For his part, Flores said El Salvador appreciates the ROC's assistance in its economic and agricultural development over past decades. "We look forward to further strengthening our cooperation in various fields in the future," he added.
After the welcoming ceremony, the two heads of the state held talks on a range of issues at the ROC Presidential Office.

During their talks, Chen assured Flores that the ROC is more than willing to share its developmental experiences with El Salvador and promote bilateral cooperation in investment, trade, culture and science/technology development to cope with the challenges of the "new economy" era.

They also exchanged views on regional and global situations. Chen said the ROC wants to work together with all of its diplomatic allies under bilateral or multilateral cooperative frameworks for boosting economic, sci-tech and cultural development and jointly create a peaceful, free and stable new century.

This is Flores' second visit to Taiwan. During his stay, he will sign a joint communique with Chen and will meet with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and other senior ROC officials.

He will also deliver a speech to the ROC legislature Friday. Flores is accompanied by his wife, Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, Economics Minister Miguel Ernesto Lacayo and several other Salvadoran officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUDDHIST MASTER RECEIVES AWARD FOR CONTRIBUTION TO BUDDHISM

TEXT.P: Taiwanese Buddhist Master Hsing Yun on Thursday received an award from Thailand Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai for his invaluable contributions to Buddhism.

Speaking at a Buddhist rally in Bangkok to mark the friendship among the world's Buddhist followers, Master Hsing Yun urged the more than 600 Buddhists from 28 countries in attendance that Buddhism should be melded into daily life so that common Buddhist followers can obtain the real wisdom of life.
He said among the more than 130 countries in the world, only 28 sent representatives to attend the rally, so there are still many places in the world that need Buddha's light.

The founder of the Buddhist Fo Kuang Shan Temple indicated that Buddhism should exist not just in temples, but should extend into society and families so that everybody can enjoy the true joyfulness of life.
Master Hsing Yun emphasized the importance of the Five Precepts of Buddhism -- abstaining from killing, theft, illicit sexual relations, evil words and alcohol.
He also reminded Thai followers that drugs have become a serious threat that may destroy Thailand. He urged them to push for an anti-drug campaign in their country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOT FEDERATION APPEALS TO TAIWAN OVER SINGAPORE PILOTS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An international pilot's group appealed to Taipei authorities Wednesday to allow three pilots of a crashed Singapore Airlines (SIA) airplane to return home.

If the three pilots are not allowed to leave Taiwan before Christmas and the New Year, the England-based International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations might boycott flights to Taiwan, said its president, Ted Murphy.
However, Murphy went on, the boycott will be launched only as a last resort if all other efforts to persuade Taipei prosecutor's to allow the three pilots to leave have failed.

Murphy, who arrived in Singapore Thursday on his way from New Zealand to England accused Taipei in a statement of jeopardizing international flight safety by forbidding the three pilots from leaving the island, causing anxiety among other pilots and inevitably compromising their flying performance.

The three SIA pilots have been prohibited from leaving Taiwan ever since their Boeing 747 airplane crashed during takeoff on Oct. 31. Local prosecutors said they might charge all three with involuntary manslaughter for the 82 passengers among the 179 aboard killed when flight SQ006 tried to take off at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport from a runway closed for repair.

Murphy said in his statement that "even if they are to be the subject of legal proceedings in due course, there can be no justification for not allowing these individuals to return home pending those proceedings, so that they can continue their recovery from the trauma of the accident within their home environments."
He said the free flow of information between the operator and the pilots is vital to the safety of aviation and pointed out that Taiwan's action has put this trust in jeopardy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO RUSSIA DONATES 5 COMPUTERS TO LENIN LIBRARY
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to Russia on Wednesday donated five computers and a Russian-language copy of former ROC President Lee Teng-hui's book "The Road to Democracy -- Taiwan's Pursuit of Identity" to Moscow's Lenin Library.
The Lenin Library held a reception after the donation ceremony to thank the ROC representative office in Russia and representative Chang Wen-chung for the donation.
The Lenin Library is world's second-largest library, next only to the U.S. Library of Congress, but due to its limited budget, the library is old and shabby.
The library has finally received sufficient budget this year to proceed with a refurbishment for the first time in 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK `CONCERNED' ABOUT TAIWAN'S MAINLAND CHINA INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: Members of a U.S. think tank visited the Republic of China's Economics Ministry Thursday to find out about possible adjustments in Taiwan's economic policies following its accession into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

After meeting the six delegates, Economics Vice Minister Chen Ruey-lung described the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) as an "influential" think tank in the United States whose members may very well be invited to join the new U.S. administration.

The members include Winston Lord, former U.S. assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs; Kenneth Lieberthal, former head of the Asian affairs division of the U.S. National Security Council; Douglas Paal, head of the Asia Pacific Policy Center and a former member of the U.S. National Security Council; Robert A. Scalapino, professor of East Asian studies at University of California at Berkley; NCAFP Chairman George Schwab; and senior NCAFP member Donald Zagoria.

Chen told the delegates that Taiwan hopes the United States can support Taiwan's WTO accession into the WTO within the same timeframe as mainland China's membership. According to Chen, the delegates replied that many WTO member countries support this stance.

Chen quoted his visitors as saying that the whole world knows how difficult it is for a government to control capital flow where the aim is to seek profits. They then asked Chen how Taiwan feels about reports that US$70 billion of Taiwan's capital has gone to mainland China.

Chen replied that his ministry's statistics show that only approximately US$16.5 billion-worth of Taiwan capital has been invested in mainland China, while the mainland's official figures show that the amount of promissory investment totals US$45 billion along with US$35 billion in actual investment. Therefore, he added, his ministry believes that the actual figure is not as high as the US$70 billion claimed in the reports.

The vice minister said that the ministry is looking into adjusting the policy of "no haste, be patient" in terms of Taiwan investment in mainland China, and the policy of establishing direct trade, postal, and transportation links between the two sides. The ministry expects to see the adjustment proposals ready by the end of the month after further analysis with the Mainland Affairs Council and other related government agencies, he said.
The U.S. think tank delegation left Taiwan for mainland China later in the day, winding up a three-day fact-finding tour to Taiwan.
While in Taipei, they called on ROC President Chen Shui-bian and met with both ruling and opposition political heavyweights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS U.S. CHINA HANDS ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday Taiwan must avoid causing confrontation between the United States and mainland China for the sake of its own national interest.

Ma, the brightest political star in the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), made the remarks after meeting with a group of U.S. China hands organized by the influential Washington-based think tank -- the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP).

Ma said the visiting scholars, many of them former U.S. officials, had told him that they were afraid that Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's public call on the incoming American government to add a "fourth no" to the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan might have an adverse impact on the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing triangular relations.
"In their opinion, the U.S. scholars thought that President Chen should have made such an appeal in private, not in public," Ma said, adding that he himself agreed with the American visitors' view.

Ma, who holds a Ph.D. from Harvard University, said Taiwan should avoid pressuring the United States to make a choice between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "Otherwise, Taiwan itself will suffer a backlash," he noted.

During a meeting with the U.S. scholars Wednesday, President Chen said he hopes that the new American government will avoid mentioning the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan, or at least add a "fourth no" -- no Beijing use of force to resolve the Taiwan Strait issue.

U.S. President Bill Clinton spelled out the "three noes" policy during a visit to mainland China in 1998, pledging that the United States would not support independence for Taiwan, membership for Taiwan in any organization in which statehood is a requirement and "two Chinas" or "one Taiwan, one China."
Noting that the first two "noes" comply with the ROC's constitution, Ma said he thinks that the ROC government should focus its efforts to persuade the United States to soften its third "no."

Ma said one of major concerns of his guests was that if Presdient Chen, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), recognizes the previous KMT government's "one China, separate definitions" stance, also known as the "1992 consensus," will major Taiwan opposition parties accept Chen's views on mainland affairs?

"My observation was that since Taiwan's opposition parties all support the '1992 consensus,' Chen's recognition of the 'one China, separate interpretations' stance would greatly facilitate the formation of a national consensus on the ROC's cross-strait policy," Ma said.
Nevertheless, Ma said he had also reminded the American visitors that Taian people's top concerns are the ROC's national security and rights to participate in international activities.
"We certainly hope that Beijing can show goodwill on these two critical issues if we are going to negotiate sensitive political issues with it," Ma said.

Ma further explained that although Taiwan will not use the two demands as preconditions for resumption of cross-strait dialogue, Beijing should at least make it clear that it will deal with the two issues prudently and will not easily take hostile attitude toward Taiwan.
Ma said the United States does not want to see the current cross-strait deadlock continue in the years ahead and that most visiting American scholars support Taiwan's return to the "1992 consensus."

Judging from the current situation, Ma said whoever wins the cliffhanger U.S. presidential election will not have strong majority support in Congress. "Against this background, the new U.S. administration will very likely lean toward Beijing if it feels Taiwan does not show sufficient sincerity to improve cross-strait relations.

The members of the NCAFP delegation included Winston Lord, former U.S. assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs; Kenneth Lieberthal, former head of the Asian affairs division of the U.S. National Security Council; Douglas Paal, head of the Asia Pacific Policy Center and a former member of the U.S. National Security Council; Robert A. Scalapino, professor of East Asian studies at University of California at Berkley; NCAFP Chairman George Schwab; and senior NCAFP member Donald Zagoria.
Many members traveled to Beijing to continue their Asian tour after concluding their Taipei visit Thursday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH U.S. THINK TANK DELEGATION

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Vice Chairman Vincent Siew met with a group of visiting U.S. think tank members to discuss bilateral ties between Taiwan and the United States, as well as cross-strait relations.

Siew told the group of members of the National Policy Committee of American Foreign Relations that cross-strait relations will improve only when the Republic of China convenes the National Unification Council meeting in accordance with the National Reunification Guidelines.

He added that such a meeting could result in a national consensus on the issue, which would allow resumed talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. This would create a win-win result for both sides of the Strait, and would be in the interests of the United States in the Asia Pacific region, he said.

Siew made the comments to the six members of a U.S. think tank who called on KMT Headquarters. In addition to Siew, they also met with Stephen Chen, former ROC Representative in Washington D.C., and KMT Deputy Secretary General Shaw Yu-ming. KMT Chairman left Taiwan Wednesday for a visit to Britain and Italy.

During the meeting, Siew said the new ROC administration has failed to present effective measures to resolve the deadlocked cross strait relations since assuming power six months ago. The National Reunification Guidelines are the best way to resolve the currently deadlocked cross-strait relations, according to Siew.

Meanwhile, Shaw said the Chen administration wants to use the "three acknowledgments and four suggestions" of the Presidential Advisory Group on Cross Strait Relations to open the deadlocked cross-strait ties. He described this as "wishful thinking" and "playing games with words."
During the meeting, members of the U.S. think tank expressed their concern about the political situation in Taiwan after the island's first power transition on May 20.

In response to his U.S. visitors questions, Siew said that Taiwan has been set back both politically and economically during the past six months under President Chen Shui-bian's leadership, adding that this was mainly because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party-led administration has managed national affairs according to its own ideology.
The U.S. think tank delegation left here for mainland China later, after winding up a three-day fact-finding tour to the Republic of China.
While in Taipei, they called on President Chen Shui-bian and met with both ruling and opposition political leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REJECTS VISIT BY DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rejected Thursday a meeting between ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Frank Hsieh and KMT Chairman Lien Chan, saying it would be meaningless if Hsieh does not apologize for insulting the KMT.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng, who made the statement on behalf of the Republic of China's main opposition party, was referring to Hsieh's observation about corruption in the KMT when it was in power.
Lin also denied a report that the KMT has agreed to a visit by Hsieh after Lien returns from a visit to Europe.
Lien was defeated by the DPP's Chen Shui-bian in the ROC's March presidential election, ending more than 50 years of KMT rule in Taiwan.
According to Lin, Lien "showed his sincerity" by visiting Hsieh Oct. 2 and later attending a meeting called by Chen to discuss issues related to the interests of the country.

However, Lin went on, the DPP then announced its decision to scrap the partially constructed fourth nuclear power plant, also a product of KMT rule, only 30 minutes after the Chen-Lien meeting. The move provoked a political storm in Taiwan and led to an opposition move to oust the president.
In the ensuing squabble between the ruling and opposition parties, Hsieh blasted the KMT as corrupt.

Lin said the KMT members are furious about Hsieh's remarks, adding that they cannot imagine that such "irrational words" would be spoken with someone with any knowledge of the law. Hsieh majored in law.

In related issues, meanwhile, KMT sources said the DPP has inquired of them about their wish to convene a national affairs conference to amend the Constitution, to which they responded that the most important thing at present is to respect the Constitution.

The KMT sources said that Chen does not respect the Constitution and has failed to respond to the opposition's call for a "dual head" system, under which the president must appoint a premier from the majority party in the legislature, or a premier who has the approval of the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. THINK TANK RECOMMENDS TAIPEI-BEIJING ARMS RESTRAINT AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Members of a U.S. think tank recommended that Taipei and Beijing sign an "arms restraint agreement," but a spokesman for the Republic of China Defense Ministry said Thursday that the development of a mutual trust mechanism should come first.

According to the Ministry of National Defense (MND) official, the visiting members of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) brought up their suggestion twice during their three-day fact-finding trip.

The NCAFP members include Winston Lord, former U.S. assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs; Kenneth Lieberthal, former head of the Asian affairs division of the U.S. National Security Council; Douglas Paal, head of the Asia Pacific Policy Center and a former member of the U.S. National Security Council; Robert A. Scalapino, professor of East Asian studies at University of California at Berkley; NCAFP Chairman George Schwab; and senior NCAFP member Donald Zagoria.
However, he continued, only through a foundation of cross-Taiwan Strait military confidence-building measures can the two sides begin to talk further about the possibility of arms restraint.
Furthermore, the official said, mainland China has not yet responded to the numerous overtures made by ROC Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen on the establishment of a mutual trust mechanism.
According to the MND, Taiwan has always been positive about the idea of such a mechanism, but there are currently no concrete developments in cross-strait military issues.

The MND added that the ROC National Defense University even publicly proposed at a seminar last week the concept of establishing a telephone hotline between Taipei and Beijing, complete with various evaluations and timetables for the establishment of such a hotline.

Although signing an agreement to restrict arms buildups may be able to resolve the crisis of accidentally sparking off a conflict in the strait, the MND official said that there would still be "a long way to go" if the foundation of military mutual trust is not there.

The U.S. think tank delegation left Taiwan for mainland China later in the day. While in Taipei, they called on ROC President Chen Shui-bian and met with both ruling and opposition political heavyweights.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER PROMISES TO ASSIST IN EL SALVADOR'S NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said while paying a call to visiting Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez Thursday that the Republic of China will "do all it can" to assist El Salvador in its national development plans.

Chang added that the ROC government will also encourage local companies and entrepreneurs to value the investment possibilities in El Salvador and jointly participate in the country's national development.

Flores arrived in Taipei a day earlier for a four-day state visit, his second to Taiwan. He visited ROC President Chen Shui-bian earlier in the day, who thanked the Salvadoran government and people for their long-term support for the ROC's bid to join international events and organizations, including the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC ANNOUNCES 5% RESERVE DEPOSIT FOR FOREIGN CURRENCY DEPOSITS

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Thursday a five percent reserve for every deposit in foreign currency as part of an attempt to stop the slide of the new Taiwan dollar against the greenback.

Under the new regulation, which the bank said was set in line with the practices of financial centers in the European Union, Japan and Singapore, local banks are required to deposit with the CBC reserves of five percent of the foreign currency savings they receive from customers.
In a press conference called to announce the new regulation, CBC officials said the decision was reached in a meeting of the CBC councilors Thursday evening.

Chou A-ting, director-general of the Foreign Exchange Department under the CBC, said the measure was imposed briefly between June and November of 1990, and between September 1993 and March 1994, and achieved the desired results.

Chou also allayed fears that local banks will bear heavier interest since Standard & Poor's downgraded its outlook on Taiwan's sovereign ratings Wednesday, saying that the CBC is willing to lend foreign currency to local banks at the usual market rates.

A local analyst said the CBC's move was designed to prop up the local currency against the greenback while meeting the seasonally surging demands for N.T. dollars around Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 24.
Meanwhile, the Taipei branch office of Netherlands-based ABN AMRO Bank scaled down its interest rates on deposits in foreign currency in anticipation a drop in rates in the United States.
Local analysts predicted that the move is the harbinger of a similar drop in rates on foreign currency deposits.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPATRIATED GANG LEADER INTERROGATED

TEXT.P: "Four Seas Gang" leader Yang Kuang-nan, who was repatriated back to Taiwan from mainland China via Macau Wednesday, was interrogated Thursday by prosecutors of the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office.

Information from the Criminal Investigation Bureau indicated that Yang is an important figure in the 1998 murder of Yuanta Securities Vice President Huang Nai-hsuan, but Yang claimed to know nothing about the background of the murder or of the 1996 slaying of gang leader Chen Yung-ho.
He also denied the report that the influence of the "Four Seas Gang" extends as far as the mainland Chinese city of Shanghai.

Yang fled Taiwan to the mainland several years ago. He was pronounced "persona non grata" by Shanghai law enforcement authorities last March and expelled to Macau, where he was to be handed over to Taiwan police.
However, with the help of local gangsters, Yang eluded Taiwan police at Macau Airport and fled to Singapore, from where he re-entered the mainland on a fake passport.
Last month, Shanghai law enforcement authorities apprehended Yang again and again expelled him to Macau, where Taiwan police were waiting for him.
National Police Administration Director-General Wang Chin-wang told legislators Thursday that Yang's capture was realized with the cooperation of mainland Chinese authorities.
He also stated that some 20 to 30 other wanted leading members of Taiwan organized crime groups are still hiding in mainland China and other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOCK TRIBUNAL ON WAR CRIMES AGAINST WOMEN OPENS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The "Women's International War Crimes Tribunal" opened in Tokyo Thursday to accuse Japan's imperial army of forcing foreign women to serve as sex slaves during World War Two.
About 1,000 people from 30 countries and areas attended the opening ceremony at the Kudan Kaikan Hotel near the Imperial Palace.
Some 80 "comfort women" from South Korea, North Korea, mainland China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Malaysia, the Netherlands and Indonesia have come to attend the six-day event.
The mock tribunal will be conducted Dec. 8-10 and three "comfort women" from Taiwan will testify before the court Dec. 9.
The tribunal will hand down a verdict Dec. 12. Although non-binding, it is expected to heighten the publicity of the "comfort women" issue in Japan and the international community.
Participants at the tribunal will also stage a demonstration and meet with Japanese parliamentarians Dec. 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DELEGATION CALLS FOR PEACEFUL CROSS-STRAIT RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: There is no question that Washington would like to see the dispute between Taiwan and mainland China solved peacefully, a delegation from a U.S. private think tank said Thursday.

Kenneth Lieberthal, a China expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. and a member of the delegation of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, told a press conference at the end of a three-day visit to Taiwan that dialogue between Taipei and Beijing and the peaceful resolution of their disputes are what Washington has pressed for all along.

He appealed for a stop to the arms race between Taiwan and mainland China, which he said would ease the strains across the Taiwan Strait, but denied that his delegation has tried to broker a sort of cross-strait arms limitation agreement.

The former U.S. national security official echoed President Chen Shui-bian's calls for Washington to include in its "three noes" China policy that mainland China should not use force against Taiwan, saying it serves the interest of Washington.

Two other members of the delegation -- Douglas Paal and George Schwab -- expressed concern about what they see as the deterioration of Taiwan's economic situation over the past few months, adding that Washington would prefer to see a stable, democratic and prosperous Taiwan.
Winston Lord, another of the delegates, said the delegation will present its findings on Taiwan to the incoming U.S. government as a policy-making reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT DECORATES ROC PRESIDENT, OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Visiting El Salvador President Francisco Guillermo Flores decorated Thursday his Republic of China counterpart, President Chen Shui-bian with the Jose Martias Delgado Cross gold order in recognition of Chen's contribution to promoting bilateral relations between the two nations.

The decoration ceremony took place during a banquet that Chen hosted in Flores' honor at the Presidential Office. Flores also conferred Jose Martias Delgado Cross silver orders on both Premier Chang Chun-hsiung and Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao.

Chen thanked Flores, saying that the medals -- El Salvador's highest civil honor for foreigners, is not only a great honor for him but also a symbol of the solid relations between the ROC and the Central American country.
Flores and his entourage of 26 arrived in Taipei Wednesday at the start of a four-day state visit to the ROC.
Chen spoke highly of Flores' able leadership, saying that this is the reason behind El Salvador's progress.

He told his guests that the ROC, after achieving economic prosperity and implementing a democratic system, is now seeking to join international organizations so as to make a greater contribution as a member of the international community. He added that he hopes El Salvador will continue rendering its firm support to the ROC in this regard.
While presiding over a military ceremony to greet Flores earlier in the day, Chen said that the ROC treasures its 60-plus-year friendship with El Salvador.
Chen, who took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, also stressed the continuity of ROC foreign policy.

He said the ROC government will honor all bilateral promises and obligations under treaties and agreements with El Salvador. "We'll also continue upgrading relations and cooperation with El Salvador based on current foundations," he added.

He further said the ROC will consider favorably a request for agricultural technology assistance presented by Salvadoran Vice President Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt during a visit he made to Taiwan in October.

For his part, Flores said El Salvador appreciates the ROC's assistance in its economic and agricultural development over past decades. "We look forward to further strengthening our cooperation in various fields in the future," he added.
After the welcoming ceremony, the two heads of the state held talks on a range of issues at the ROC Presidential Office.

During their talks, Chen assured Flores that the ROC is more than willing to share its developmental experiences with El Salvador and promote bilateral cooperation in investment, trade, culture and science/technology development to cope with the challenges of the "new economy" era.

They also exchanged views on regional and global situations. Chen said the ROC wants to work together with all of its diplomatic allies under bilateral or multilateral cooperative frameworks for boosting economic, sci-tech and cultural development and jointly create a peaceful, free and stable new century.

President earlier in the day met Premier Chang Chun-hsiung to exchange views on matters of mutual concerns. Before leaving Saturday, he will sign a joint communique with Chen and will meet with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao and other senior ROC officials. He will also deliver a speech to the ROC legislature Friday.

This is Flores' second visit to Taiwan. He is accompanied by his wife, Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, Economics Minister Miguel Ernesto Lacayo and several other Salvadoran officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1ST AMC TO BE ESTABLISHED WITHIN TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first assets management company (AMC) will be established within "one to two months," Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Thursday.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will also push for the establishment of financial assets service companies to act as the fair third parties to help remold the reputation of local banks for bad loans, appraise the worth of assets and carry out auctions of assets, Yen said after an MOF meeting that was also attended by representatives of nine renowned international investment banks.
The Legislative Yuan recently passed a law governing the merger of financial institutions, paving the way for these institutions to liquidate their bad debts.

Yen noted that foreign-funded companies have shown high interest in Taiwan's assets management market, with one firm in particular saying that it is prepared to submit an application "at any time." He said Taiwan will have more than two AMCs in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 8, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: The United States Labor Union is established.
1914: Britain's Royal Navy destroys a German naval squadron off the Falkland Islands.
1938: "The Count of Chaplin," the first German aircraft-carrier, is launched at the port of Kiel.
1941: Japan invades Thailand.
1941: The United States, Britain, and Australia declare war on Japan.
1944: U.S. forces attack Iwo Jima, 750 miles south of Tokyo, to begin the longest and fiercest battle in the Pacific War.
1949: The United Nations National Assembly asks world powers to recognize the political independence of China, as the ROC government moves to Taiwan.
1953: The United States proposes the international control of atomic energy in the United Nations General Assembly.
1958: The first African People's Convention opens in Accra, the capital of the Republic of Ghana.
1959: The ROC Legislative Yuan amends Article 12 of the Organization Law of the National Assembly to enable the president to appoint an acting secretary-general of the National Assembly when it is not in session.
1962: Rebellion in Brunei fails after British intervention.
1974: Greece votes to become a republic, abolishing a 142-year-old monarchy.
1975: Yu Chi Chien, South Korean education minister, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Hsieh Min-nan and Kuo Chi-hsiung return from Bangkok after taking second place in the 23rd World Cup Golf Championship.
1976: Abdullah B.H. Mohammed, a member of the Asian Amateur Athletic Association, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles R. Anderson, professor emeritus of American literature at John Hopkins University, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1978: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Foreign Exchange Management Regulations under which the new Taiwan dollar is no longer pegged to the U.S. dollar.
1978: Golda Meir, who resigned as Israel's first woman prime minister in April 1974, dies at the age of 80.
1980: Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Leonid Brezhnev visits India.
1986: The ROC and the United States reach agreement on tobacco and wine tariffs. The ROC's Ministry of Finance announces that from January 1987, U.S. cigarettes and alcohol are free to enter the Taiwan market.
1990: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan resigns but is re-appointed within 24 hours.
1991: Russia, Belarus, and the Ukraine form the "Commonwealth of Independent States" with its capital in Minsk.
1993: Kao Chun, a young mainland Chinese citizen, hijacks a Northern Airlines flight to Taiwan.
1995: Communist China enthrones a new six-year-old Panchen Lama, pressing Tibetans to accept its controversial choice for Tibetan Buddhism's second-ranking monk over the one named by the Dalai Lama, the exiled religious leader.
1995: The World Health Organization announces that a new outbreak of the Ebola virus, which killed 250 people in Zaire earlier in the year, has been confirmed in the Ivory Coast.
1995: Flight services between Taiwan and Macau begin.
1997: U.S. President Bill Clinton welcomes Wei Jingsheng, mainland China's noted democracy activist, to the White House.
1998: Japanese scientists report that they have cloned eight calves from the same dead cow.
1999: On behalf of the victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake, Master Cheng Yen expresses her appreciation to the international community and to individuals who have extended a helping hand to the victims.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 40.1 points to close at 5,252.83.
The bourse opened at 5,216.36 and fluctuated between 5,269.62 and 5,186.35 during trading.

A total of 1.66 billion stocks worth NT$49.97 billion (US$1.51 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.43 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$48.01 billion (US$1.48 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted losses, with both construction stocks and electrical shares edging down by 0.1 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 2.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.3 percent, textile issues at 2.1 percent, cement stocks at 2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 271 to 211, with 119 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS FAVORITE TOURISM DESTINATION FOR MAINLANDERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is the most popular holiday destination for mainland Chinese citizens who have the opportunity to travel abroad, a Beijing survey showed.

According to sources from the mainland Chinese State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, which quoted a survey recently conducted by related agencies, Taiwan is the place that most mainland Chinese people most want to visit abroad.

Another survey conducted even more recently by the Beijing-based Straits Travel Agency showed that some 25 million mainlanders will register to travel to Taiwan if the Republic of China government officially opens its tourism market to citizens of mainland China next June.

Members of China's tourism industry have already begun jostling for position in attaining a share of the Taiwan-bound tourist market since the ROC Legislative Yuan amended related statutes on Dec. 5 easing existing restrictions and allowing mainland Chinese citizens to travel, trade, and teach legally in Taiwan, hopefully beginning in June next year.

A Straits Travel official said that although the opening of Taiwan to mainland tourists seems promising and highly attractive to mainland tourism operators, he is not that optimistic Taiwan will actually implement the plans any time soon. He said his view is based on his observations of Taiwan's opening itself up to allow mainland Chinese journalists to be permanently stationed in Taiwan.
Members of the Taiwan-based tourism industry have also expressed welcome for the plan to open the island up to mainland tourists, with some calling it "the last spring" for the sagging industry.

According to Tseng Sheng-hai, chairman of the Taipei Association of Travel Agents, if Taiwan received 1 million mainland Chinese tourists a year, it would help generate NT$100 billion (US$3 billion) in revenue for Taiwan. His calculation is based on the assumption that each visitor from the mainland would spend an average of NT$100,000 during the course of an average 10-day visit.

Tseng suggested that the ROC government repeal the existing regulation mandating that each mainland visitor coming to Taiwan have a guarantor formally guarantees that the visitor will return to the mainland as scheduled and not attempt to remain in Taiwan. He suggested that the government instead collect a cash deposit from each tourist to guarantee their return to mainland China.

In related news, a Taiwan tourism promotion group, to be led by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Tuo and two other DPP lawmakers, may cancel their scheduled trip to Beijing set to begin Dec. 30 as the Beijing authorities have still not granted visas for the DPP legislators.

Wang said he and the other members of the group, which also includes several legislators from the opposition parties and some 300 members from Taiwan's tourism industry, are planning to visit the mainland to gain a better understanding of how receptive Beijing authorities have become regarding Taiwan opening itself up to mainland Chinese tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, FRANCE TO STRENGTHEN COOPERATION IN IPR PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and France pledged Friday to further strengthen cooperation in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, particularly claims on patent/trademark priority rights.

The ROC's Intellectual Property Office (IPO) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and France's national institute of intellectual property INPI made the vow in a joint press statement issued at the end of a seminar on IPR protection.
IPO Director Chen Ming-pang and INPI Director Daniel Hangard co-chaired the seminar in Taipei, which was attended by judges, prosecutors, and officials in charge of IPR affairs in the two countries.

Chen said the IPO and the INPI have strengthened bilateral relationship through regular exchanges of information and annual meetings, which take place alternatively in France and in Taiwan, since the two sides signed an agreement in 1996 on mutual granting of a priority right with regards to patents, designs and trademarks.
Chen said the two offices agreed to further improve protection of their nationals' claims on patent/trademark priority rights during their last meeting held in Cognac, France on Oct. 23, 2000.

According to Chen, the two sides further agreed at Friday's seminar to amend their original agreement, pending the completion of the domestic procedures of each side, so as to permit the following applications:

-- The INPI will accept that ROC nationals who have filed patent/trademark applications in third countries maintaining reciprocal arrangements with the IPO will be able to claim patent/trademark priority rights in France, and vice versa.
-- The IPO and the INPI recognize that both ROC and French national's applications filing based on the international treaties, such as the Hague Treaty, can claim priority in each territory.

Meanwhile, the two sides also agreed that the mechanism on exchange of information between the IPO and the INPI will be further strengthened. Both sides agreed to discuss relevant details subsequently.

During the seminar, the French delegates also introduced France's and other European countries' IPR protection frameworks and shared their experience in anti-counterfeiting and trademark disputes handling.

The French delegation was headed by Ambroise Auge, INPI deputy director in charge of legal and public affairs. LVMH Group's senior executives in charge of Asia-Pacific anti-counterfeiting operations also attended the seminar.
The two sides also agreed that the next IPO-INPI annual meeting will be held in Taiwan in late 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES PILOTS TO BE RELEASED NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office announced Friday that the three pilots of the Singapore Airlines passenger jetliner that crashed in October while taking off from the wrong runway at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport will be released on Dec. 15.

Whether the three SIA pilots will be prosecuted for the crash that killed 83 of the 179 people aboard the jumbo jet that took off in stormy weather will be decided after investigations into the accident are completed, the prosecutors said in a formal statement.

The prosecutors pointed out that reports by several foreign wire service agencies saying that the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office has decided to prosecute the trio were apparently due to a misunderstanding.

The prosecutors also denied that they decided to release the SIA pilots because of pressure from abroad, which includes threats from a spokesman for the Singapore Chapter of the International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations that the group will consider an unprecedented boycott of Taiwan's airspace if the pilots are not freed soon.

The pilots -- flight commander Capt. Foong Chee Kong, 41, a Malaysian, and Singaporean co-pilots Latif Cyrano, 36, and Ng Kheng Leng, 38 -- were taken into custody by Taoyuan police the day of the crash. CKS International Airport is located in Taoyuan County in northern Taiwan.

The prosecutors said the pilots will be handed over to Singapore's representative office in Taiwan on Dec. 15. It has also been learned that Singapore Airlines will arrange for the trio to return to Singapore the same day.
They noted, however, that the Singapore representative office is obliged to make sure the pilots return to Taipei when they are again needed for investigations.

The prosecutors added that the Republic of China is a sovereign state and judicial rights are part of its sovereignty. "The prosecutors' judicial rights are by no means to be interfered with by any other force," they stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SIGNS AMNESTY FOR 21 PRISON INMATES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian signed papers Friday granting amnesty to 21 prisoners in a move supposed to uphold human rights, according to sources from the Presidential Office.
The amnesty, the first of its kind since Chen took office May 20, is scheduled to take effect Dec. 10, World Human Rights Day, the sources said.

The president decided to grant the amnesty in accordance with a joint assessment contributed by the Executive Yuan, the Ministry of Justice and the Ministry of National Defense and in consideration of human rights protection, said Presidential Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun.

The 21 inmates include 19 men jailed for refusing to engage in military service for religious reasons, one jailed for leading a labor union demonstration, and one imprisoned for attempted robbery and homicide.

Members of the legislative caucus of the opposition Kuomintang said they respect Chen's decision to grant the amnesty, a presidential right empowered by the Constitution, but they added that the president should pay more attention to Taiwan's deteriorating social order and spearhead moves to bolster security and restore order to society.
Ting Shou-chung, a KMT heavyweight at the Legislative Yuan, said Chen's amnesty is no more than a political public relations ploy that fails to address the real needs of society.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, EGYPT TO EXCHANGE REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Egypt have agreed to exchange representative offices, which the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) described Friday as a breakthrough in Taiwan's diplomatic offensive.
The ministry said in a press release that the move was designed to cope with growing trade and cultural exchanges between the two countries.
This is the first time that the ROC and Egypt have managed to forge official ties since Cairo switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1956.

Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Egypt's consent to exchange representative offices with Taiwan marks an important step forward in the ROC's diplomatic work in view of Cairo's pivotal role in Africa and the Arab world.
"Despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations, the exchange of representative offices between our two countries is of great significance," Tien stressed.
He said the ROC has sent officials to Cairo to prepare for the opening of its representative office, which will be officially named the "Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Egypt."

Saying that Egypt is "no ordinary country," Tien said MOFA will dispatch a competent senior official familiar with African and Arab affairs to serve as the ROC's first de facto ambassador in that country.

Meanwhile, Tien went on, Egypt is also expected to send an ambassadorial-level official to head its representative office in the ROC, to be named the "Egyptian Office for Trade and Culture in Taipei."
If all goes smoothly, Tien said, the two countries will be able to complete the establishment of representative offices in each other's territory before the end of this year.
Tien noted that Egypt is an old country with a long history and a marvelous cultural heritage. In 1999, more than 10,000 ROC nationals made sightseeing tours of Egypt.

Moreover, Tien continued, bilateral commercial exchanges have grown steadily since Egypt began privatization and other economic reforms in 1991. Two-way trade between Taiwan and Egypt exceeded US$200 million last year.
Up until now, the two countries have not opened any offices to handle visa and relevant affairs, causing inconvenience and trouble to business people and tourists.
"Therefore, we have been seeking to forge substantive ties with Egypt to facilitate bilateral trade, economic and cultural exchanges," Tien said.

The minister further said that as Egypt understands that the ROC is widely recognized as one of the world's trade, investment and economic powerhouses and that its people have strong purchasing power and like to go abroad for sightseeing, it is willing to develop closer ties with the ROC.

Egypt has traditionally maintained friendly relations with mainland China. Tien said the ROC will not interfere with Egypt's engagements with Beijing nor will it pay special concern to Beijing's possible reaction to Cairo's decision to exchange representative offices with Taipei.
Tien said he is convinced that Egypt has evaluated all relevant political issues in its decision-making process concerning the exchange of representative offices with the ROC.

He said Egypt's move is by no means an indication that it is unfriendly toward Beijing. "Relations among countries around the world hinge on reciprocity and mutual benefit, not on a zero-sum game," he noted.
Diplomatic sources said Tao Wen-lung, director of the MOFA's African Affairs Department, is likely to be the ROC's first representative to Egypt.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER: GOVERNMENT WILL TRY TO EASE CROSS-STRAIT POLICY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the government will consider easing its cross-Taiwan Strait policy, as long as national security can be assured.

He made the remarks to reporters in response to a suggestion by the Science and Technology Advisory Group of the Executive Yuan at its 21st meeting that ended Friday that the government should adopt a strategy of economic globalization and readjust its "go slow, be patient" policy in dealing with investment in mainland China.

Chang said that within the scope of national security, the government will consider adjusting the "go slow, be patient" policy and the "three direct links" -- direct trade, postal and transportation links.
Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, chief advisor of the group, also pointed out the need for easing the "go slow, be patient" policy under the present trend of economic globalization.
This year, the Science and Technology Advisory Group carried out its projects with the theme of "developing Taiwan into a green silicon island."
Priority has also been given to environmental protection, development of intellectual economy and improvement of social justice.

The group called on the government to continue promoting the use of broad-band Internet, the re-training of unemployed workers and enhanced development of potential industries such as software design, bio-tech information, information technology and communications, and semiconductors.

DOC.HEADLINE: EL SALVADOR PRESIDENT ADDRESSES ROC LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez of El Salvador urged all countries around the world Friday to resolve their disputes through peaceful negotiations in line with international law.
Flores, who is currently on a four-day state visit to the Republic of China, made the appeal in an address to the ROC's Legislative Yuan.
In his speech, Flores also said El Salvador attaches great importance to its diplomatic relations and cooperative programs with the ROC.

Flores said the ROC-Central America Mixed Committee provides a useful dialogue mechanism and has thus helped boost bilateral and multilateral exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and its Central American diplomatic allies.
ROC lawmakers from both ruling and opposition parties, as well as Legislative Yuan staff members, turned out to welcome Flores and listen to his speech, which was delivered in Spanish.
Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Flores' visit was an honor for the ROC legislators and marked a further step forward in Taiwan-El Salvador relations.

The ROC forged diplomatic ties with El Salvador nearly 70 years ago and the two countries now maintain trade, agricultural, technological and cultural cooperative programs. The legislative bodies of the two countries forged cooperative ties in 1992.

Later in the day, Flores paid a visit to Talin Hospital in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County in the company of ROC President Chen Shui-bian. The newly opened hospital is operated by Master Cheng Yen's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.

Master Cheng Yen led a group of Tzu Chi volunteers in welcoming the Salvadoran leader. Flores expressed his gratitude for Tzu Chi's donation of relief goods to El Salvador more than two years when the country was hit by a devastating hurricane.
This is Flores' second visit to Taiwan. He will co-sign a joint communique with Chen Saturday to reaffirm the countries' commitment to furthering bilateral relations and cooperation.
Flores is accompanied by his wife, Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, Economics Minister Miguel Ernesto Lacayo and several other Salvadoran officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HUMAN RIGHTS STILL NEED IMPROVEMENT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's human rights index shows signs of decline in almost all sectors of society this year, except for the judicial sector, the Chinese Association for Human Rights (CAHR) reported Friday.
According to the CAHR annual report released Friday, Taiwan has made little progress in improving its human rights in 2000.
The report shows that women's rights have not made any significant progress this year, while children's right flunk for the fourth consecutive year.

There were no adequate nursing facilities or government policy for the elderly in Taiwan, with public care for the elderly in southern and eastern Taiwan falling behind the levels given to old people in northern and central Taiwan, according to the report.

Meanwhile, the report indicates, the overall political rights index dropped to below the three-point approval rate this year when more than 200 scholars and experts surveyed for the report found that people had less inclination to fight government officials for their rights and met more difficulties when applying for licenses.

The respondents said the media's justice and respect for the people involved in news events were increasingly doubtful and they found that concerns about the existence of vested-interest groups in society and unjustifiably poor performances of lawmakers dropped to the worst-ever levels.

In terms of the lowered index for economic rights, the respondents noted that public power has invaded the private economic arena, with government intervention to prop up the stock market and the opposition parties' boycott moves against the government for "unjustifiable reasons" cited as major causes dragging down the economic rights index.

On the condition of social rights, which dropped to the second-lowest level in nine years, the respondents said that despite a peaceful power transition in Taiwan when the Democratic Progressive Party took control the government, social order has continued to deteriorate, while natural disasters, unemployment and labor-management disputes have all increased.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE PITCHES FOR END TO POLITICAL WRANGLING

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh pitched for an end to domestic political wrangling Friday, saying Taiwan cannot afford a continued war of attrition.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, made the appeal in a news conference held at the conclusion of a five-day meeting of the Science and Technology Advisory Group of the Executive Yuan, or Cabinet. Lee is the top adviser of the group.

Noting that the current Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government should take the greatest share of blame for a crisis of confidence now simmering in the country, Lee said other domestic political parties and all ordinary people should work together with the government to overcome various challenges and obstacles to Taiwan's pursuit of economic globalization.

In fact, Lee said, Taiwan is not alone in suffering an economic slowdown which he said is almost a worldwide phenomenon. According to Lee, the global economy is undergoing significant changes. "Taiwan has not yet fully readied itself for all new developments. We should make an overall review and step up reforms to cope with new challenges," he noted.

During the five-day meeting of sci-tech advisers, Lee said, globalization was a hot topic. "As globalization is key to the development of knowledge-based 'new economy,' local industries should be given full freedom to chart their global production, investment and marketing plans," Lee explained, adding that Taiwan itself should also keep its door open to foreign investors.
Lee said most of sci-tech advisers support the proposal that Taiwan ease its restrictions on investment in mainland China under its "no haste, be patient" policy.

In his view, Lee said, the exodus of Taiwan industries may not necessarily be a detriment to the island. "So long as outbound investment can help expand a company's global market share and enhance competitiveness, the trend can be a boon to Taiwan."
Under a global development strategy, Lee said, continued upgrading of research and development (R&D) capabilities hold the key to Taiwan's survival and sustainable growth.

Lee said the focus of sci-tech advisory meeting was not the "exodus of Taiwan industries. "The advisers focused discussion on whether Taiwan can foster a better investment climate to enable its companies to produce even higher value-added products and further upgrade R&D capabilities," he added.

According to Lee, although many Taiwan technology companies relocate to mainland China, most of them have just moved production lines to the mainland while retaining their R&D and design centers in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULING, OPPOSITION LEGISLATORS RESUME DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: Ruling and opposition legislative caucuses reopened unofficial channels Friday in order to begin the monumental task of amending a series of complicated laws on which certain executive powers are based.

A portion of the amendments to the Administrative Procedural Law giving a temporary one-year extension for those powers passed a third reading earlier in the day. Two identical versions were voted on -- one from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and another from the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP) -- due to the fact that the two camps are not speaking to each other.

The DPP and the opposition parties have broken off all official communication channels since Premier Chang Chun-hsiung of the DPP made a sudden announcement at the end of October that a decision had been made to scrap the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.

Presently, a backlog of over 30 related amendments is awaiting review by the legislature, but the Administrative Procedural Law is set to be promulgated into law Jan. 1, 2001. If the related amendments are not completed in time, over 100 executive order powers will lose their legal basis, thus making it urgent for a compromise to define a grace period for those powers to retain their legality.

Due to the enormity of working out the amendments, the separate camps in the legislature agreed to the Cabinet's urgings and decided to allow the grace period while the lawmakers define the various kinds of executive orders, in particular the "authority of office" subtypes.

According to reports, however, neither the Cabinet nor the legislature are optimistic about being able to complete all the amendments within one year. Therefore, a corollary to the amendment passed Friday allows the Cabinet to extend the grace period -- with the legislature's consent -- one month before the time limit is up.
However, KMT Legislator Liu Kuang-hua and NP Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta criticized the amendment for giving too much power to the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR GROUP TO INVEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Criticizing the Republic of China government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China, a local semiconductor group has announced that it will establish a plant in Shanghai to gain a better foothold in this giant market.

Jason Chang, board chairman of Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Group, said Friday in a radio interview that the "no haste, be patient" policy is an anachronism, adding that Taiwan should take the initiative in dissolving cross-strait hostilities by allowing local enterprises to invest in the mainland so as to maintain their competitiveness.

He said that mainland China has actively promoted its economy in recent years and now offers preferential conditions for semiconductor manufacturers, thereby attracting numerous firms, including Motorola and Philips, to invest there.

Chang went on that Taiwan's lifeline is in high-tech industries, but because of its limited market, almost 90 percent of its electronics must be exported. "However, whoever wants to be the No. 1 enterprise in the world has to take on the mainland China market," Chang said.
He indicated that the government should abandon ideological arguments and let local companies decide their own future.

Although mainland China is still some three to five years behind Taiwan in semiconductor and wafer manufacturing, other international firms are actively positioning themselves in the market, Chang said. He warned that Taiwan may lose its advantage soon.

Trying to ease government misgivings about Taiwanese investment in mainland China, Chang noted that after leading firms such as IBM and Philips invested in Taiwan, their partners here did not attempt to co-opt their market positions. On the contrary, their relations have been mutually beneficial, he said.
Chang added that it is already late to invest in some sectors of mainland China's market, but opportunities still exist.

He cited the activities of Winston Wang, son of Taiwan tycoon Wang Yung-ching, who recently announced that he was setting up a large-scale wafer plant in mainland China in cooperation with the son of President Jiang Zemin.

Chang noted that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd. did not establish factories in mainland China because of the ROC government's policy, which let other firms seize the opportunity. He said that such firms would likely become major rivals for the semiconductor giant.
Chang said he does not want to ever see his company miss out on such an opportunity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROFESSOR SELECTED FELLOW OF THIRD WORLD ACADEMY OF SCIENCES

TEXT.P: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University has been selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies, local academic sources said Friday.

Hwu, also a professor with the Institute of Chemistry of Academia Sinica, the Republic of China's highest research body, is a noted synthetic chemist. He has won international recognition with innovative contributions to organosilicon chemistry.

His research areas also cover natural product synthesis, new reactions and new reagent, synthetic methods and concepts, mechanistic studies, drug design and synthesis, molecular genomics and polymer science.

Hwu, 46, said he felt honored to become a TWAS fellow. Noting that the TWAS is an important international non-governmental organization, with participants from the United States, Europe, Asia, Africa and other parts of the world, Hwu said TWAS operations have not encountered too much political interference.
Hwu said the ROC should forge closer contacts with the TWAS to break bottlenecks in its science-technology exchanges with other countries.
According to Hwu, the TWAS once helped the ROC break mainland China's diplomatic embargo and resolve some problems with the United Nations concerning the U.N. ban on chemical weapons.
Hwu was one of the 35 new TWAS fellows selected at the organization's latest biennial meeting held in Tehran, Iran last week.

The Italy-based TWAS was broached by a group of renowned scholars from around the world in 1983 and formally inaugurated in 1985 with the support of the United Nations. It maintains close ties with UNESCO.
The TWAS now has 543 fellows from 75 countries, including many Nobel Prize laureates. Its fellows include outstanding Third World scientists and Third World immigrants to advanced countries.

In addition to Hwu, several other ROC scholars were already selected TWAS fellows in the past few years, including Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who was also a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, and Chou Chang-hung, president of National Sun Yat-sen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ON TAIWAN PATIENT RIGHTS RELEASED

TEXT.P: Opposition New Party (NP) legislator Hau Lung-bin released a report Friday on the rights of Taiwan medical patients, and urged for the passage of a Basic Medical Rights Law to clearly define such rights.

Hau, the NP's national convener, said that the patient rights issue should be addressed through the system by establishing equal doctor-patient relations and passing a law to ensure that neither patients nor medical personnel ignore their respective rights and duties.

According to the report, which was compiled by the Republic of China Association for the Advancement of Patient Rights, Taiwan has always been found to be lacking in terms of medical rights. The association noted that although the Department of Health is working on a law to resolve medical disputes, controversy still exists regarding its limitations and its proposed complaint channels.

In regards to medical education and professional self-discipline, the association noted that no Taiwan medical school has set up a full-scale curriculum on either patient rights or medical ethics. What's more, the association continued, professional organizations have never taken any active measures on the issue and have not applied internal discipline to cases in which doctors invaded the privacy of patients.

The association criticized the media for creating too much publicity for certain doctors, which it claimed gave patients "excessive expectations." It urged the media to provide more reporting aimed at balancing out "unequal" doctor-patient relations.
According to the association, the report was based on a set of evaluation guidelines established by the World Health Organization in 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC NOT TO INVEST IN MAINLAND CHINA FOR 5 YEARS

TEXT.P: The boss of Taiwan's Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC), the world's largest foundry semiconductor maker, said Friday that his firm will not invest in mainland China during the next five years.

TSMC head Morris Chang made the remark in reaction to speculation that his firm intends to march into mainland China in light of Chang's recent call for loosening the government's "no hurry, be patient" trade policy toward the mainland and his mainland China visit planned for next Tuesday.
Chang said he actually just wants to attend an international bridge tournament in Beijing, and does not intend to meet with mainland Chinese authorities on investment affairs.

Specifically, he denied a rumor that he intends to meet with Zhang Qi, director of the Department of Economic and Information Products Management under mainland China's Ministry of Information Technology and Telecom Industries. Zhang is now visiting Taiwan at the head of a 10-member mainland Chinese delegation.

Although he said TSMC will not enter mainland China for the next five years, Chang stressed that Taiwan high-tech manufacturers investing and setting up factories in the mainland will be an unavoidable trend in the future. He urged the government to come to grips with the trend as early as possible, and remove the ban on making major investments in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMANDER OF US 7TH FLEET HOPES CROSS STRAIT DIALOGUE TO BE RESUMED
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Vice Adm. James Metzger, commander of the U.S. Seventh Fleet, has said he hopes that the dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China will be resumed soon.
He made the remarks in an interview at the Foreign Press Club in Hong Kong Friday, in which he touched on issues related to cross-strait relations, the Spratly Islands and the Korean peninsula.

Metzger said that the stance of the United States government is to encourage the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume their dialogue. He spoke highly of the Republic of China's presidential election and described it as "positive."

Although U.S. forces under his command are capable of reaching the Taiwan Strait very quickly, he said he does not expect that it will be necessary. Metzger added that U.S. relations with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will remain unchanged.
He said that the U.S. will not forget its responsibility to the Taiwan Strait region, and to encourage a resumed dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China is its main responsibility, Metzger said.
He added that he believes such a dialogue is the only effective way to improve cross-strait relations.
He did not respond to a question about whether Beijing threatens Taiwan militarily, but reiterated that only a dialogue can resolve the cross-strait issue.

Metzger also said that containing mainland China is impossible, so communication with Beijing is necessary to resolve disputes. He noted that the Seventh Fleet is conducting exchanges with mainland's navy.

Mentioning the Spratly Islands issue, he said the U.S. position toward the isles remains unchanged.
