The U.S. government will not support any particular country's claim to sovereignty over the islands, he said, adding that the United States is mainly concerned about maintaining navigational freedom in the area.
On the Korean Peninsula issue, Metzger said that the U.S. will continue to promote talks between South and North Korea, which are already underway.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRICKS-MORTAR, ONLINE COMBINATION KEY TO DOTCOM SURVIVAL (I)

TEXT.P: Amid a sweeping wave of increased acquisitions and mergers among worldwide online firms, local Internet experts contend that a combination between bricks and virtual operations represents the key to continued survival for all dotcoms.

Despite the surprising acquisition last month by Yahoo! of the local portal Kimo, many local dotcom operators are of the opinion that setting up a bricks-mortar revenue model, rather than a virtual-virtual combination like the Yahoo-Kimo case, is pivotal to their existence.

The most well-known bricks-mortar combinations in recent years have been the mergers between America Online and Time Warner and between Pacific Century Cyberworks and Hongkong Telecommunications Ltd., according to local Internet experts.

Although such large-scale combinations between virtual and traditional businesses have not yet occurred in Taiwan, the experts say mergers between small- and medium-sized online businesses are increasingly frequent, pointing to the recent cooperation between inforian.com and Hewlett Packard, which through coolbid.com -- a site run by inforian -- launched an HP fleet website.

Institute for Information Industry Chairman H.M. Huang, who is a former head of Hewlett Packard Taiwan Ltd., said in a ceremony marking the formation of the joint venture that companies with real distribution networks, if incorporated with Internet channels, should be able to create revenue models for profit under a labor division pattern.

eAuto.com -- a website on car information -- also acquired two car magazines -- Auto Driver and Auto Express -- in October. eAuto owner C.N. Chou said that such a "bricks-mortar" consolidation will help his website move a big step toward becoming the leading brand among similar local sites and offer an opportunity for his business group to embark on diversification.

According to Chou, eAuto.com provides quick and efficient information to its viewers, while the newly purchased magazines are available for making detailed and extensive reports to their readers. A combination of the two different types of businesses will produce a profound cross-media platform effect, he added.

At the same time, certain traditional businesses, such as Ford Lio Ho Motor Company Ltd., have also noticed the importance of such consolidation. The carmaker has been actively promoting a campaign dubbed "e-order," boasting that delivering a car on the Internet takes only 15 days.

Meanwhile, another major local carmaker -- Yulon Motor Co., Ltd. -- has joined forces with cmc.taiwanet.com to create a real distribution network to pave the way for expanding into the area of B2C commerce.

Another example is Netvista Information Corp. and Topology Research Inc., both of which have successfully coped with a recent shape-up among online businesses by transforming into B2B software developers from pure B2C websites. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: BRICKS-MORTAR, ONLINE COMBINATION KEY TO DOTCOM SURVIVAL (II)

TEXT.P: Starting from a B2C website -- auctions.com -- Netvista has transformed into a B2B application service provider by launching e-commerce software products for local small enterprises.

In a move to set up a distribution network to promote its physical products, Netvista has signed contracts with islandwide distributors to market a package of e-commerce software products -- esafe -- which provides local businesses with comprehensive enterprise resource planning.

"I believe that a bricks-mortar combination represents the key solution to all e-commerce websites. It is not easy to make money by only running online businesses and an e-commerce website should play only a supportive role for a real distribution system," says Netvista Vice President Howard Yu.
According to Yu, Netvista has acquired many orders from downstream distributors, a situation which is expected to chalk up an income on the company's balance sheet by the end of this year.

Chief Executive Officer Charles Chen of Topology Research -- a pioneer Internet technology service provider in Taiwan -- told CNA that Internet software and platform systems will be his company's mainstream products in the future.

Aiming at the Internet's future trends, Topology set up an Internet system division last year to develop a series of Internet software products to provide its corporate customers with across-the-board Internet, Intranet and Extranet solutions, Chen said.

In addition, Topology has also devised a much faster third-generation search engine -- Web Genie -- to search for data and information on the Internet, Chen noted, adding that his company has applied for patent rights for the product's key technology -- the first-ever in the world -- in Taiwan, the United States, Japan and South Korea.

According to Chen, Topology has also reached agreement with the Beijing-based ACE Group, in the hope of promoting Internet software products in mainland China, which he said is set to emerge as the world's largest market for Internet businesses.

"With the approach of the knowledge-based `new economy,' software programs on information management are set to play a significant role in the future. The search engine with better technology and more value-added functions to help users upgrade their productivity will enjoy a larger slice of the market," he explained.

At a time when more and more dotcom operators are realizing the vital importance of a bricks-mortar/virtual combination as a way of making profits, Internet experts say only those online businesses that know how to forge profitable business alliances or conduct acquisitions will be able to continue to move on.
Only the fittest will survive, they warn.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRAISES E.U. PARLIAMENTARY RESOLUTION IN ROC'S FAVOR

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) praised the European Parliament Friday for passing a resolution in the ROC's favor.

A MOFA official said the resolution was yet another indication of the support of Taiwan's democratization from the world community, and added that it will be significant for the future bilateral relations between the ROC and the European Union.

The European Parliament passed the resolution on Nov. 30. Referring to relations between mainland China and the European Union, the European Parliament expressed its regret over the deterioration of the human rights dialogue between the European Union and China.

The European Parliament called on the E.U. Council of Ministers and its executive committee to advise Beijing clearly that future relations between China and the European Union will depend mainly on human rights in the mainland.

A group of parliamentarians from the Green Party proposed an amendment to the resolution on E.U.-China relations. The amendment included a demand that the E. U. council of ministers attempt to strengthen political relations with Taiwan, which they said would promote a dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China as well as support Taiwan's democratization. It also called on the E.U. Executive Committee to set up an office in Taiwan.

The proposal was backed by the European People's Party, the Socialist Party and the Liberal Party. The E.U. parliament adopted the resolution with 482 votes in favor, five objections and 38 abstentions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH NATIONAL POLICY ADVISORS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian met Friday with seven of his national policy advisors to hear their opinions on the government's policies on important matters.
It was the fifth group of national advisors Chen had invited to present their suggestions.
An advisor who was present at the meeting told reporters afterward that during the two-hour meeting, Chen spent most of the time listening to suggestions and issued no instructions.
The topics, he said, centered on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, diplomatic affairs, and financial and economic issues.
One of the advisors, Tseng Yung-hsien, reportedly stated at the meeting that the government should refrain from taking an over-hasty attitude in implementing its mainland policy.
He said that the government should first work out a set of complementary measures before allowing mainland tourists and reporters to visit Taiwan.

The six other national policy advisors invited to meet with Chen were Lin Kun-chung, Lin Chung-hsiung, Chen Lung-chih, Ni Po-chiu, Lee Tsai-fang and Tsai Chao-yang. Presidential Secretary-General You Shi-kun was also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINES EYEING PROSPECT OF TAIPEI-BEIJING ROUTE
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Chen Huang-szu and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taipei and Beijing may still be mired in disagreement over the "one China" issue, but Taiwan's airlines are already poised to cash in on the undoubtedly lucrative Taipei-Beijing flight route that would follow a breakthrough in bilateral talks.

According to industry sources, Taiwan's China Airlines, EVA Airways, Far East Air Transport, and TransAsia Airways have already established regional offices in Beijing in anticipation of the possible profits.
Despite the fact that the bilateral dialogue has stalled and neither side seems willing to budge on more sensitive political issues, planning and preparation continue at the airlines.

Although direct air links between the two capital cities may still be a pie in the sky at this stage, Hsieh Ching-lung, EVA's Beijing office planning director, said that initial estimates put the potential market to be in the range of tens of billions or perhaps even hundreds of billions of New Taiwan dollars, which is equivalent to approximately US$3 billion to US$30 billion.

Hsieh said that the number of travelers to mainland China from Taiwan this year -- all of whom must transit in either Hong Kong or Macau -- will exceed three million, while the number of mainlanders who travel to Taiwan is approximately 100,000.

If mainland China further opens air routes over its territory to Taiwan carriers, the so-called "Silk Road in the Sky" will save about two hours in flight time from Taiwan to Europe, Hsieh said. Currently, flights from Taipei to European cities require transits in Bangkok or other cities, driving up costs and adding to travelers' inconvenience.
According to Hsieh, the time saved by flying a direct route over continental Asia would allow an airline to fly an additional flight to Hong Kong.

The Republic of China government has held out olive branches to Beijing by first announcing that direct trade, postal, and transportation links between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and designated ports in mainland China will be established in January, then later announcing that direct links between Taiwan-proper and mainland Chinese cities are in the works.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN'S MOVE TO GRANT AMNESTY TO 21 PRISONERS LAUDED
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung County, southern Taiwan, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Participants of an international seminar on human rights Friday praised Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's move to sign a decree granting amnesty to 21 prisoners, to be effective on World Human Rights Day, which falls on Sunday.
In a statement, they also urged the ROC government to actively complete judicial reforms with an ultimate goal of minimizing the number of cases of human rights infringements.

Seminar participants said that although human rights conditions in Taiwan have improved significantly, there are still some problems. They urged the ROC government to set up a Cabinet-level human rights committee to promote the protection of human rights in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, seminar participants strongly condemned the ROC Legislative Yuan for slashing National Huwei Institute of Technology's budget by NT$1 million because of Vice President Annette Lu's "inappropriate" words in a speech at the institute Wednesday.
They indicated that the Legislative Yuan's move infringed upon academic freedoms and the freedom of speech. They urged the people of Taiwan to protest the action.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZATION FOR SUFFERERS OF RARE DISEASES TO BE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: After a year of preparation, an organization to benefit disadvantaged sufferers of rare diseases will be formally set up on Sunday in Taipei, group organizers said Friday.

The association will promote the rights and benefits of underprivileged patients in Taiwan, and will be an umbrella organization covering two dozen groups of sufferers of rare disorders on the island, they said.

Some 220 sufferers of 34 rare diseases, their physicians and families, as well as officials from the Interior Ministry's Department of Health will attended Sunday's inauguration ceremony, said the organizers.
Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Department of Health officials have promised to attend the ceremony in person to show their support.

Noting that the patients are disadvantaged because of their small numbers and society's ignorance of their need, the organizers said the new group will promote public awareness of the patients' misery and their families' lonely struggle to care for them, as well as encourage the health care system to address the sufferers' needs more properly.
The organization will also bring together the patients and their families to support each other by sharing their experiences, said the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'COMFORT WOMEN' TRIAL OPENS IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A mock "world court" trial of Japan's former Imperial leadership opened its first session Friday, with prosecutors accusing the Japanese of violence against women during the Second World War.

The event, which is being held to draw attention to the continuing plight of former "comfort women" -- women forced into sexual slavery by the Imperial Army of Japan before and during World War II -- drew an unprecedented crowd of observers.
The prosecutors formally filed an indictment against 11 World War II era officials, including the late Emperor Hirohito and late Prime Minister Hideki Tojo.

More than 80 former "comfort women" from Taiwan, mainland China, the Philippines, Indonesia, East Timor, Holland, and North and South Korea attended the trial's opening session, which also drew journalists and more than 1,000 representatives of organizations from all over the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE AIRLINES HEAD SAID UNSATISFIED WITH TAIWAN AIR PACT

TEXT.P: Philippine Airlines Chairman Lucio Tan has expressed his discontent over the air agreement that the Philippine government signed with the Republic of China in September, according to ROC Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) officials.

In a recent interview with Hong Kong-based AsiaWeek magazine, Tan said the new air agreement was signed by the Philippine government under economic pressure from the Taiwan side, and added that the deal will result in annual losses of some US$800 million for Philippine Airlines.

Officials of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) of MOTC responded Friday by saying that all international air pacts are signed under the principles of equality and the respective needs of the signatories.

There is no such thing as one side having an advantage over another, said the officials, citing the example of Thai Airways International, which operates fewer flights to Taiwan than those of Taiwan airlines to Thailand.
However, Thai Airways has never asked Taiwan to reduce its flights to Thailand, because of the strong ticket sales brought on by Thailand's healthy tourism industry, the officials added.

Referring to the possible annual losses for Philippine Airlines, the CAA officials said that customers are free to choose which airline they wish to fly, and suggested that Philippine Airlines improve its service to attract more customers instead of casting blame for its losses elsewhere.

With respect to the Tan's suggestion that Taiwanese airlines will try to merge with Philippine Airlines after it goes bankrupt, the officials said that several airlines, including Cathay Pacific, Lufthansa and Taiwan's EVA Airways have all looked into acquiring a piece of Philippine Airlines, but have felt that the airline does not merit their investment.

The Philippines unilaterally severed air links with Taiwan last October because of a dispute over the division of passenger loads. Air services between the two countries briefly resumed in January, only to be cut by Manila a few days later over the issue of how passenger load ratios should be calculated.
After tedious negotiations, the Philippines and Taiwan resumed air links again in October this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT VISITS FOUNDER OF BUDDHIST TZUCHI FOUNDATION
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: El Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez visited Venerable Master Cheng Yen in Chiayi Friday to extend his gratitude for her group's timely relief efforts for victims of the 1998 hurricanes in his country.

Accompanied by Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, Flores and his wife went to the Buddhist Tzuchi Talin General Hospital in Chiayi to meet with Cheng Yen, the founder of the Buddhist Tzuchi Foundation.
The visitors were greeted by Cheng Chen and a large group of Tzuchi volunteers. They were briefed on the operation of the hospital, which was constructed with donations collected by the foundation.
After touring the hospital facilities, Flores praised the benevolent spirit of Tzuchi.
Chen also affirmed the contributions of the foundation, saying that Tzuchi volunteers always emerge wherever urgent help is required.
He said that he will employ the spirit of Tzuchi in ruling the country.

After El Salvador and several other neighboring countries were struck by devastating hurricanes in September and October of 1998, Tzuchi launched a large-scale campaign at home and abroad to collect relief funds and materials.
The foundation collected more than 3 million pieces of clothing in nine days, and dispatched relief teams to provide medical aid and food to the stricken regions.
Flores arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a four-day official visit at the invitation of the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY: U.S. MISSILES BEST MATCH FOR PERRY-CLASS FRIGATES

TEXT.P: The Navy's fleet of Chengkung-class frigates will be one of the service's key weapons if they are armed with U.S.-made Harpoon missiles, the Navy said Friday.

In an attempt to defend its decision to replace the locally-made Hsiung-II missiles on its Chengkung frigates with Harpoons, the Navy said in a news briefing Friday that Harpoons are standard equipment aboard the U.S. Perry-class frigate, on which the Chengkung vessel is patterned.
With a range of 110 miles and the capability of skimming over the sea at supersonic speed, the Harpoon is a more powerful weapon than the Hsiung-II for the 3000-ton Perry frigate, said the Navy.
The Hsiung-II missile will instead be used by the Navy's Chinchiang-class gunboat, which has a displacement of 500 tons, said the Navy.
The Navy is trying to seek the legislature's support for the NT$600 million (US$18.18 million) budget earmarked for the purchase of the Harpoons from the United States.
Revelations of the formerly secret budget caused an outcry at the Legislative Yuan Thursday, because the General Staff Headquarters (GSH) had not yet approved the purchase of the Harpoons.
Angry legislators accused the Navy of trying to muddle through with an unauthorized arms purchase.

The Navy's Vice General Staff Lei Kuan-shui explained at a press briefing Friday that Washington had refused to sell Harpoons to Taipei when it agreed to allow Taiwan to build eight frigates based on the model of the Perry-class vessel in the early 1990s.
As a consequence, Taiwan was forced to make do by installing its home-made Hsiung-II missile on the frigates, of which seven are now in service.

However, Washington reversed its decision and granted Taipei's request for Harpoon purchases in September, after Beijing took delivery of its second Russia-made Sovremenny-class destroyer -- which could tilt the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.

Grasping at the long-awaited chance, the Navy cut normal procurement procedures and added the down payment of NT$600 million for the NT$1.1 billion deal to its budget. But the proposal was rejected by the General Staff Headquarters on the grounds that standard procedures were not followed.

Lei admitted that the NT$600 million set aside for the purchase was not stricken from the Navy's budget, which was compiled before the GSH rejection. He added that the funds would not be available for use even if the request passed through the legislature without being detected.
He apologized for the negligence, but vociferously defended the Navy's decision to buy Harpoon missiles.

Given the fact that it would take 18 months to deploy the missile, Lei appealed for the legislature's support for the purchase, which will be added to the Navy's revised 2000 budget according to established procedures and resubmitted for approval later.
Any delay acquiring the missiles would compromise the Navy's capability to counter Beijing's naval might after 2004, warned Lei.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER NAVY HEAD QUESTIONED IN CONNECTION WITH LAFAYETTE SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Retired Admiral Yeh Chang-tung, former Navy commander-in-chief, was questioned by investigators in connection with Taiwan's purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates in 1993.
Yeh was questioned by officials of the Investigation Bureau in Taipei, and left with his lawyer after the interrogation.
Yeh was the Navy chief from 1988 to 1992 and presided over the purchase of the six frigates, which are now at the center of a kickback scandal.
He is the second admiral to have been questioned in the case, after Deputy General Chief of Staff Hsia Tien.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The alliance of three opposition parties vow to closely screen the budget plan for fiscal 2001.
The China Times:
The ROC will exchange representative offices with Egypt in the near future.
The United Daily News:
At least 11 senior military officers will be indicted over the Lafayette frigate kickback scandal.
The Liberty Times:
National policy advisers urge President Chen not to take radical steps toward mainland policy.
The China Post:
ROC, Egypt in representative office exchange.
The Taiwan News:
Banks cut interest on U.S. dollar deposits.
The Taipei Times:
President Chen grants 21 convicts amnesties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 9, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-Communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany, and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The UN General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun, and his wife.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents, Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross, at the Presidential Office.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FINANCE MINISTER EXPLAINS POLICIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said in a recent interview with U.S.-based BusinessWeek Online that the ROC government is working to improve the asset quality of its banking sector and is encouraging consolidation.

According to the Dec. 11 online issue of the prestigious business weekly, there are signs that Taiwan may be on the brink of a financial crisis despite its strong electronics sector and other positive economic indicators.

The New York Times and The Economist have recently published similar reports, drawing defensive responses from Taiwan's Central Bank of China and Ministry of Finance, whose official figures put the nation's non-performing loans (NPLs) at about 5.6 percent of the Gross Domestic Product. Foreign analysts have estimated that the NPL ratio may be as high as 15 percent.

Yen told BusinessWeek Online that Taiwan has a healthy trade surplus, foreign reserves of more than US$110 billion and low government debt. However, he admitted that the average NPL ratio has grown from 3.7 percent at the end of 1997 to 5.35 percent at the end of September for commercial banks. "I don't think we've hit the peak yet," he added.

Other than passing a new bank merger law on Nov. 25 that will also make it easier for banks to dispose of bad loans, Yen said that the government is reducing the gross revenue tax from 5 percent to 2 percent in a gradual process that will lead to its final elimination, which he said will allow banks to use the money saved on taxes to write off bad loans.

To create an alternative channel for banks to dispose of NPLs other than going to the courts, which can take three to five years, Yen said that he is "pushing very hard" for the creation of a domestic asset-management company (AMC) within three months to buy and sell problem loans. He added that he has been approached by a number of foreign companies, including Goldman Sachs and GE Capital, in this regard.

Former U.S. Vice President Dan Quayle, who works for Cerberus Capital Management, the world's largest investor in distressed debt, also visited Taiwan in late November to help Cerberus find local partners to set up an AMC.

With 53 banks and nearly 360 non-bank financial institutions such as farmers credit cooperatives in Taiwan, Yen said that the three biggest banks have a comparatively low market share of 26 percent. "We need to encourage consolidation," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF EXECUTIVES VISIT KINMEN AMID PREPARATIONS FOR `MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: A group of Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) executives visited the Republic of China's frontline island of Kinmen Saturday amid the ROC's intensified preparations for the scheduled opening of direct "mini three links" with mainland China.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin, head of the group, said upon his arrival at the defense outpost that opening direct trade, postal and shipping links between the ROC-held outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian Province on Jan. 1, 2001 is the government's established policy.
"Even if the Beijing authorities continue resisting talks with us on the `mini three links' issue, the policy will be implemented as scheduled," Yen stressed.
Authorized by the ROC government, Yen went on, the SEF is ready to talk with Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on the "mini three links" issue.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies mandated by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

"We have not yet given up hope of holding face-to-face discussions with ARATS officials on `mini three links' issues before the end of this year," Yen said, adding that the SEF will also be willing to negotiate with ARATS even after the direct "mini three links" are opened at the beginning of the new year.

Touching on the Kinmen County Government's hope that both the SEF and ARATS will post officials on Kinmen to help deal with commercial disputes, travel services and criminal activities that may arise after the opening of direct links with Xiamen, Yen said the SEF has already finalized a plan to set up a branch office in Kinmen to facilitate services for Kinmen and Xiamen residents.
"Once the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which oversees SEF operations, approves the plan, the SEF will dispatch staff members to operate its Kinmen branch office," Yen said.

During their Saturday meeting, Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai told Yen that he plans to head a delegation of Kinmen officials and civic representatives on a direct maiden voyage to Xiamen aboard two county government ferries on Jan. 1.

"We hope the SEF can send staff members to join us on the planned four-day ice-breaking visit," Chen said, adding that his mission also plans to bring back a number of elderly Xiamen residents to their Kinmen homeland so that they can pay their respects to their ancestors. The old people have been stranded in the Xiamen area for more than 50 years since the Chinese civil war in the 1940s.

In response, Yen said Chen's "two-way" traffic links plan still involves many technical problems that must be resolved through SEF-ARATS discussions. "We have prepared a detailed agenda for bilateral negotiations, but we cannot reveal it at this moment," he added.

Yen further said that if Beijing remains reluctant to return to the negotiating table, Taiwan will be forced to implement one-way trade and shipping links with the mainland in the initial stage, including legalizing "small-amount" trading between Kinmen and Xiamen fishermen, which in fact has been going on illegally for years. Kinmen lies far closer to Xiamen than to Taiwan.
The SEF delegation also paid a visit to the Kinmen Defense Headquarters to discuss measures for ensuring national security following the opening of the "mini three links."

On Sunday, the group is scheduled to inspect Liaolo Port, which will be used for the direct Kinmen-Xiamen shipping services, and the Hsinhu fishing port, which will be used as a cross-strait fishing trade center in the second stage of the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRY LEADER PROMOTES ESTABLISHMENT OF SPECIAL TRADING ZONE
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin County, Taiwan, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: A local industry leader said Saturday that he will make recommendations to the Economics Ministry to promote the establishment of a special trade and economics zone to be located next to a new industrial zone in central Taiwan.

Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) Chairman K.C. Lin said during a tour of Formosa Plastics Group's sixth naphtha cracking plant in Yunlin County that the establishment of the special trading zone will allow the government to reach its goal of persuading industries to stay in Taiwan.

He said that tariff exemptions or reductions within the special zone will be an added incentive for industry investment. Furthermore, he added, if the proposed 1,000 hectare zone can escape minimum wage requirements set forth by the nation's Labor Standards Law, industries will not have to move out to find low-cost land and labor in another country.

Lin pointed out that Yunlin is the closest county in Taiwan proper to mainland China in terms of distance and that if the government opens up direct trade, postal, and transportation links between Taiwan and mainland China in the future, the special trading zone will be a prime location for industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO MAKE ROC `HUMAN RIGHTS MODEL' FOR NEW CENTURY
DOC.DATELINE: Green Island, Taiwan, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: On the eve of International Human Rights Day, President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Saturday his commitment to making the Republic of China a new "human rights model" for the 21st century.

Chen made the pledge while attending activities to mark the anniversary of the establishment of Asia's first monument to human rights, situated on Green Island, off Taiwan's southeastern coast. The scenic offshore island is the site of the ROC's most tightly guarded prison, which was used to jail political prisoners during Taiwan's martial law era.
Chen laid a wreath and bowed three times before the monument to pay his respects to Taiwan's prisoners of conscience, human rights and democracy activists.

The artist-designed monument was inaugurated Dec. 10, 1999 in celebration of Human Rights Day. However, the monument and an adjoining wall on which the names of more than 500 political refugees are inscribed were damaged by typhoon Bilis that hit the Taiwan area this summer.

With the support of the Presidential Office and the private Human Rights Education Foundation, the monument and the adjoining wall have now been repaired and refurbished and Chen personally presided over the structures' re-inauguration.
Chen said Green Island used to be burdened with the "darkest chapter" of Taiwan's political history.

"By erecting the Human Rights Monument, we have managed to transcend the sad, grim past and courageously face our previous misfortunes and mistakes," Chen said, taking advantage of the occasion to apologize once again to former political prisoners and their families on behalf of the government.

Chen, who took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of political power between different parties, said his administration will continue to push for the legislation of a human rights law to offer better human rights protection for ROC nationals and he declared his determination to set up a national human rights commission.
Chen also said he had approved an amnesty for 21 prisoners, effective Sunday -- International Human Rights Day -- which he said shows the new ROC government's respect for human rights.

After ending his speech, Chen walked around the monument, reading the inscribed eulogy to the political prisoners and examining the names engraved on the adjoining wall -- including those of Vice President Annette Lu and President Chen's senior advisors Peng Ming-min and Yao Chia-wen, all of whom served time as prisoners of conscience under the Kuomintang, which ruled Taiwan for more than 50 years until being ousted this May.

Some former political prisoners and their families flew to Green Island to attend the anniversary activities. The human rights wall originally carried the names of more than 500 political prisoners. This year, 180 more names of newly confirmed former political prisoners were added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL SEMINAR ON TAIWAN-MACAU RELATIONS OPENS
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Adam Lee and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Sixth Annual Taiwan-Macau Relations Seminar opened here Saturday to explore the role of Macau in promoting Taipei-Beijing interaction.

Approximately 40 scholars and experts from both Taiwan and Macau are attending the two-day seminar, including Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung, who stressed that he is attending in his personal capacity as a professor at National Taiwan University.

Chen is the highest-ranking Republic of China government official to visit the former Portuguese colony since it was returned to mainland Chinese rule on Dec. 20, 1999 as a special administrative region.
Maintaining a low profile, Chen refused to give official ROC government opinions regarding Hong Kong and Macau.
The seminar is held in Taipei and Macau alternately. The first, third, and fifth meetings were convened in Taipei.

The discussion topics at this year's meeting include how to strengthen Taiwan-Macau relations through cultural, economic, trading, and tourism exchanges and how to develop an unique role for Macau in Taipei-Beijing relations.

Other issues such as a comparative study of bilateral relations before and after Macau's handover to mainland China and the effects of Taiwan's and Beijing's impending World Trade Organization accession on Taiwan-Macau trade are also expected to be discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PRODIGIES SET WORLD RECORDS FOR MENTAL CALCULATION

TEXT.P: Three child prodigies in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung set new world records for mental arithmetic Saturday amid the cheers of a large crowd of spectators.
Wang Chia-lu, 13, set new records for multiplying two eight-digit numbers as well as two 13-digit numbers in a mental arithmetic contest sponsored by the Guinness World Asian Witness Center.
It took Chia-lu only 26.51 seconds to come up with the 26-digit answer for multiplying two 13-digit numbers, breaking the 28 seconds Guinness world record set by Shakuntala Devi of India in 1980.
Chia-lu, a first-grade student at Lingya Junior High School in downtown Kaohsiung, has long been famous for his incredible ability to add, multiply and divide large numbers in his head.
Meanwhile, Chia-lu's two sisters -- Wang Yi-hui, 12, and Wang Hui-yin, 8 -- also broke Guinness world records in the same contest held at Yencheng Elementary School, also in downtown Kaohsiung.
Yi-hui set a new record by coming up with an answer for adding 100 single-digit numbers in 18.98 seconds, breaking the original Guinness record of 19.23 seconds.

The youngest Wang child, Hui-yin, also claimed a slot in the Guinness Book of World Records Saturday by solving square root of a six-digit number in 10.48 seconds, faster than the previous Guinness record by more than 50 seconds.
Steve Day, chairman of the Guinness World Asian Witness Center, presided over Saturday's contest. Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh also put in an appearance to cheer on the Wang children.

The three prodigies' father, who is also their trainer, said he decided to nurture Chia-lu's mental calculation skills when the child was five years old because Chia-lu was so full of energy that he found it difficult to concentrate. Chia-lu's two sisters followed the same training programs, as they also demonstrated an interest in mental calculation in their early childhood.
So far, Chia-lu has participated in many international mental arithmetic contests and has been invited to demonstrate his incredible capability in many countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD CRITICIZES ROC PRESIDENT FOR WANTING TO AMEND CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian is attempting to amend the Constitution to gain more power, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) chairman said Saturday via a written address read out in his absence at a KMT-organized seminar.
Lien Chan, who is currently in Europe, criticized Chen and his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for "trampling" the ROC Constitution for his own benefit.
KMT Deputy Secretary-General Shao Yu-ming read out Lien's address at a seminar on the developments in constitutional government, which was sponsored by a KMT think tank.

However, after the seminar, DPP Policy Executive Director Shen Fu-hsiung denied Lien's charges and said that Chen has not violated the Constitution. Shen added that the KMT, as the legislative majority, should have toppled the Cabinet when Chen failed to allow the KMT to form the Cabinet -- and thereby a coalition government.
Therefore, he went on, Chen has the right not to let the parliamentary majority head the Cabinet, although he admitted that both sides deserve "50 thrashings."

Citing France as example, Shen noted that of the six occasions when France's president and parliamentary majority hailed from different parties, three times the problem was resolved by establishing a coalition government, twice the president ended up dissolving the parliament, and once led to the parliamentary majority toppling the Cabinet.

As to whether a new constitutional amendment will bring the country toward a presidential system of government, a parliamentary system, or a dual-leadership system, Shen said that it will require "everyone's opinions."

Chen had first tried to form a so-called "government of the people" by putting Tang Fei, a KMT stalwart, at the head of the largely DPP-led Cabinet in May, and then replacing him with the current Premier Chang Chun-hsiung in October, officially signaling the start of his minority government.

The KMT and the opposition alliance it formed with the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP) have been advocating that the government return to the "modified" dual-leadership system they say is stipulated in the Constitution.

Chou Yu-jen, a professor of policy administration at National Taipei University, said that the ROC constitutional system is similar to that of France, wherein if the elected president belongs to a different party than the parliamentary majority party, then the president's powers are limited, and the majority party has the right to form a Cabinet.
Chou criticized Chen for attempting to use his "subjective willpower" to override the system.

Another scholar at the seminar, Shih Cheng-feng, a professor of public administration at Tamkang University, put forward a different view, saying that the last constitutional amendment in 1997 adjusted the constitutional system to a presidential-based structure wherein the key is that the president's selection of a premier no longer requires the approval of the legislature.

Therefore, said Shih, who stressed that he was not a DPP member, the Constitution does not lean toward a parliament-based system when the president and the legislative majority are from different parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang, says the opposition party will not tolerate President Chen Shui-bian's attempt to expand power.
The China Times:
The president pays respects to the victims and their families on the eve of International Human Rights Day.
The United Daily News:
Gore stays in race after Florida Supreme Court ordered an immediate hand count of disputed ballots.
The Liberty Times:
The president hopes to pass a law for human rights protection.
The China Post:
Chen rebated over expansion of powers.
The Taiwan News:
Florida's top court revives Gore hope.
The Taipei Times:
Court puts Gore back in the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GRANTS AMNESTY TO 21 PRISONERS

TEXT.P: Twenty-one prisoners, including 19 prisoners of conscience and a trade union leader, were released Sunday, International Human Rights Day, under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian.
Those released under the amnesty decree included 19 Jehovah's Witnesses convicted of refusing to accept military conscription for religious reasons.
Chen also gave special pardons to Tseng Mao-hsing, a long-time fighter for workers' rights, and Su Ping-kun, jailed on insufficient evidence for robbery.
Tseng was jailed for leading a strike in which protesters lay across railway lines to protest a decision to close a textile plant without offering employees severance and retirement pay.

Yu Shyi-kun, secretary-general to the president, said after announcing the amnesty decree that Chen has ordered an all-out review of the nation's human rights policy with an ultimate goal of making the island "a new indicator for human rights in the 21st century."

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES AIRLINES COMPLAINS ABOUT TAIWAN CARRIERS' COMPETITION

TEXT.P: Cut-throat competition from Taiwan airline companies has wrought havoc on Philippine Airlines (PAL), its chairman, Lucio Tan, complained Sunday.

Tan complained that China Airlines and EVA Airways -- the two Taiwan carriers which have flown the Taipei-Manila route since it was reopened in October -- have bitten into PAL's customer base by wooing passengers from Manila to the United States via Taipei.

Ticket prices offered by the Taiwan carriers to the United States is almost half of that charged by PAL, adding to the woes of the Filipino carrier which is already struggling to keep afloat under the surging international fuel price.
Claiming that the Taiwan carriers' practice is "a sort of dumping," Tan appealed them to compete "fairly" with PAL and give his cash-strapped airline a chance to survive.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 70 PERCENT OF POPULATION IN FAVOR OF HALVING LEGISLATIVE SEATS

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of the people of Taiwan are in favor of cutting the number of legislators by half, according to the results of a poll released Sunday.
The poll, conducted by the Coalition to Cut the Number of Legislators by Half, surveyed 1,068 people from Dec. 5-7 and had a margin of error of 3 percent.

Up to 68.48 percent of the respondents said they are in favor of cutting the 220-seat legislature, compared with 9.78 percent who said that are against the idea. Some 21.74 percent expressed no opinion.

The number of Taiwan's legislators ballooned in the wake of the streamlining of Taiwan provincial government. Legislator Chang Hsueh-shun recently launched a drive to half the number of legislative seats, saying that the low performance of the legislators has long been a point of contention on the part of the public.

Some 48.91 percent of those polled said they are also in favor of the proposed single-seat system, meaning one seat for one constituency, compared with 32.61 percent who are against the proposal, with 18.48 percent expressing no opinion.

Fifty percent of the respondents said they are also in favor of the proposed two-vote system -- one vote for the candidate and one vote for the party -- compared with 30.43 percent who are against the idea, with 19.57 percent expressing no opinion.

Legislator Chuang Sheng-jung, a member of the opposition coalition, said that the proposal to halve the number of legislators has won support across the party spectrum and he urged speedy action to revise the Constitution.

Chuang expressed the hope that constitutional revision can be completed by June next year so as to implement the goal to reform the legislature, which was cited as the source of national chaos in a recent poll by the prestigious monthly magazine Common Wealth.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OVERSEES GROUP WEDDING TO MARK HUMAN RIGHTS DAY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian oversaw a group wedding ceremony in Taipei Sunday to mark International Human Rights Day.

Describing their marriage as "Marriages for Human Rights" Chen urged the brides and bridegrooms to make "respect, tolerance, sense and sensibility" the four pillars of their marriage and to live out human rights in their new families.

The president, known for his tenderness and thoughtfulness toward his paralyzed wife, encouraged the new couples to instill the idea of human rights in the minds of their future children and to develop their children into "human rights seeds."

During the ceremony staged at the Taipei Guest House, Chen read the wedding pledge for the 36 new couples that they vow to love one another until the end of their lives and not to be separated by anything other than death.
The pledge also said that the couples agree to refer their disputes, if any, over the question of having children to "experts" for resolution rather than trying to sort it out themselves.
The wedding pledge also includes the clause that they will never force their children to fulfill their own desires or make the children the parents' showpiece.

Saying that "a spacious heart is worth more than a spacious house," Chen urged the new couples to be tolerant toward their spouses and never forget the admiration they have toward their other halves which led to their trip up the aisle.

Among the witnesses of the wedding ceremony was writer Po Yang, who put forward the idea of the group wedding. As a former political prisoner, Po now serves as a human rights adviser to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SAID NOT AFFECTED BY BUSINESS EXODUS

TEXT.P: The former head of the nation's top economic planner said Sunday that the exodus of domestic industries to Southeast Asia and mainland China has not affected the nation's economy.

P.K. Chiang, former chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks in a seminar titled "Economic Globalization -- Economic Cooperation Between the Two Sides of the Taiwan Strait" sponsored by Tamkang University.

Chiang, who currently serves as president of the main opposition Kuomintang think tank the National Policy Foundation, noted that since the appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar in 1986 and 1987, domestic businesses have begun to invest in Southeast Asia and mainland China.

Though a large amount of capital has flowed out, it has not resulted in the hollowing-out of domestic industry, Chiang said. Exports this year have boomed, showing that the fundamentals of the nation's economy are still good and that the industrial sector has continued to upgrade, he added.
Chiang said Taiwan must maintain its competitive edge, which he said is the government's paramount task.
He suggested that the government think in three directions, citing first the example of Taiwan's large trade deficit with Japan.

Chiang said that Taiwan has long wanted to improve the trade deficit with Japan and has introduced technology, capital and research and development from Japan, hoping to make up for the large number of imports from Japan. However, he went on, the trade deficit has not decreased, showing that Japan has maintained its edge by pumping large amounts of money and effort into R&D.
He said that what the government should therefore do is maintain a technological edge over mainland China.

He also said that there should be no borders for the movement of capital and urged the government to improve the domestic investment environment so that local businesses will keep their faith and roots in Taiwan.

Third, he continued, the government should try to keep the profits of those companies investing overseas, including Southeast Asia and mainland China, in Taiwan, by keeping their orders, negotiating, R&D, and marketing operations in Taiwan, which he said will help realize the nation's goals of becoming an Asia and Pacific operations center and an Asia and Pacific logistic planning center.
On whether to permit the nation's high-tech industries to invest in the mainland, Chiang said that those high-tech industries that have a competitive edge should stay in Taiwan.
He added, however, that the competitive edge will not remain static and said the government should periodically review the situation.
But he also said that the government should still ban Taiwan investment in large-scale mainland investment projects such as power plants and public construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: `1992 CONSENSUS' SAID BEST OPTION TO BREAK CROSS-STRAIT STALEMATE

TEXT.P: A consensus between Taiwan and mainland China reached in 1992 would serve as the best option to break the cross-Taiwan Strait stalemate, former Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head Su Chi said Sunday.

Su, who currently serves in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) think tank the National Policy Foundation, made the remarks in a seminar titled "Economic Globalization: Economic Cooperation Between the Two Sides of the Taiwan Strait" sponsored by Tamkang University.

Su said that the 1992 consensus is the only political compromise reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and paved the way for a historic high-level meeting across the Taiwan Strait the following year.

Su noted that the cross-strait standoff is rooted in the "one China" issue, and that the previous KMT government advocated an agreement that it says was reached in 1992 on "one China, different interpretations." The mainland, however, has denied since 1995 that such an agreement was ever reached.

Beijing espouses "one China," which is anathema to the new government of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party. This is why, Su said, he promoted in May this year a vague term of "1992 consensus," hoping to defuse the cross-strait tension.
Su noted that as far back as 1991, the KMT held to the concept that Taiwan is part of China and the mainland is part of China, while Beijing said only that Taiwan is part of China.

Su said he regretted that it is only now that Beijing has come around to the KMT stance, referring to a recent statement by Beijing Vice Premier Qian Qichen that Taiwan and the mainland are both part of China.
Su said that he believes cross-strait relations are complicated and require careful consideration of political and economic factors.

In addition, he went on, with the changing times and environment, the government should also make adjustments to the "go slow, be patient" policy and the current ban on direct cross-strait trade, postal and transport links.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO IMPORT NATURAL GAS FROM SIBERIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan should consider importing natural gas from Siberia and the Kurile Islands, or should invest in those regions, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

In an analysis of the international economic situation in its weekly publication, the CEPD noted that Japan, South and North Korea and Russia have cooperated to develop oil and natural gas in the region.

The article said that taking part in the energy development in Northeast Asia will not only benefit Taiwan's industrial development, but will also help ensure a steady supply of energy. In addition, it will help promote substantive relations between Taiwan and Russia.
The article noted that the nation's energy supply relies almost entirely on imports, mainly from the Middle East.

But with the world trend toward a balanced development of energy, environmental protection and the economy, nations such as mainland China, South Korea and Japan have signed cooperation agreements with Russia to develop energy sources.

The article suggests that the nation should follow this lead and consider importing natural gas from Siberia, the Far East or Kurile Islands, especially now that the government has announced the halting of construction of the island's fourth nuclear power plant and increased the ratio of natural gas in the nation's energy sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT BUDGET FACES UPHILL WAR IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The government budget which has already been cut by NT$21.5 billion (US$651.51 million) in the review of committees faces a continued uphill fight at the joint session of the Legislative Yuan that will begin from Dec. 18.
Legislator Chu Li-lung, a convenor of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) budget reviewing panel at the Legislative Yuan has threatened to cut the budget by another NT$75.5 billion at the joint session.

Chu played down the size of the cut to date -- NT$663.1 billion out of government projected revenues of NT$1.45 trillion, and NT$21.5 billion out of projected outlays of NT$1.6 trillion -- which accounts for a 4.33 percent cut of the government's income and 1.34 percent of the government's expenditure.
Both figures are less than the average of the last decade, said Chu.

Fellow KMT legislator Ho Chih-hui criticized the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) which, he said, although it vowed to rein in the government's "swollen budget" before taking power, has reneged on its promise by expanding the budget by 7.3 percent, leading to a projected deficit of NT$600 billion (US$18.18 billion).
The KMT legislator's view struck a chord with the two other main opposition parties.

New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao predicted that the government's budget will undergo another round of cuts during the joint session because the committee members -- who are often closely related to the government agencies monitored by the committee -- are usually unwilling to slash the budget too much.
The joint session that brings together all Taiwan's lawmakers is usually more sensible in its review and is likely to rid the budget of more redundant expenditure, said Lai.
He said a cut of 5 percent, or NT$80 billion, is reasonable and will not seriously threaten the government's agenda.
The People First Party (PFP) also supports the claims for more budget cuts.
Legislator Lee Ching-an, a spokeswoman for the PFP, did not say how much more her party believes should be slashed from the budget, but promised the figure would be appropriate.
The three parties command a comfortable majority in the legislature, and are capable of scuttling any budget they believe to be unnecessary.

Among the items that have already fallen victim to the ax are NT$1.5 billion for waterworks intended to plug the water supply gap created by the government's plan to scrap the construction of the Meinung Reservoir in southern Taiwan.

The budget of Academia Sinica, whose president, Lee Yuan-tseh, is a enthusiastic supporter of President Chen Shui-bian, has been considerably pared, while the budget for the Executive Yuan's Science and Technology Commission of which Lee doubles as head has been cut off entirely.
Even the budget for the Presidential Office has not been spared the ax and has been trimmed by NT$180 million, while the budget for rental of a house for Vice President Annette Lu was cut by half.
The DPP criticized the opposition for what it said was venting anger over its defeat in the presidential election by mauling the government budget with the design of paralyzing the administration.
DPP Legislator Hsu Tien-tsai said the oppositions is holding the nation hostage by tampering with the government budget in an "insensitive" manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY HALL MARKS ANNIVERSARY OF FORMOSA INCIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung City Hall sponsored a concert Sunday to commemorate the 21st anniversary of the Formosa Incident, which occurred in the southern port city.

Many people jailed for years after the incident were invited by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to attend the event, among them Tsai Ching-wen, a seller of Formosa magazine at the time of the incident. He was sentenced to nine years in jail for his part in the incident.

The incident is generally thought to have been a turning point in Taiwan's political history and an event that led eventually to the lifting of martial law, as well as the ending of a ban on new political parties and newspapers.
The opposition camp formed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in 1986. Fourteen years after its founding, the party finally took power, ending the Kuomintang's 55 year-rule on the island.

The Formosa Incident occurred on the night of Dec. 10, 1979, when a group of opposition activists clashed with police during a torchlight parade to observe International Human Rights Day. Sixteen people were injured during the clash.

Two days later, many of the people who took part in the parade were arrested, tried by a military court and jailed. Among them were Annette Lu, who became the nation's vice president on May 20 this year, Chen Chu, who became chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, and former DPP chairmen Lin Yi-hsiung and Shih Ming-teh.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 ARRESTED IN CONNECTION WITH ARMS SMUGGLING

TEXT.P: Some 12 suspects in an arms smuggling ring were arrested and a large haul of arms were seized during an extensive raid, police said Sunday.

Police said that they were tipped off more than one month ago that gangster Chu Chung-shun, 39, was planning along with several accomplices to smuggle arms to Taiwan from Thailand, and began a large-scale stakeout operation.

Police said that after Chu boarded a plane from Bangkok to Taiwan Saturday afternoon, they began simultaneous raids in Taichung, Taoyuan and Taipei, arresting a total of 11 people. Chu himself was arrested upon landing at Taiwan's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.

Police seized a bill of lading from Chu, which they traced to a crate of arms in the cargo section of the airplane. The arms, including 17 pistols, one shotgun and more than 1,500 rounds of ammunition, were hidden in generators that had had their insides removed.

An initial investigation found that Chu, who had been posing as an importer of generators for use in quake-affected areas in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake last year, had worked the ruse on at least five previous occasions.
Police estimate that he has brought more than 70 guns and thousands of rounds ammunition into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR UNION STAGES HUMAN RIGHTS DEMONSTRATION

TEXT.P: More than 8,000 members of an alliance of labor unions held a demonstration in Taipei Sunday to urge the government to maintain the 84 working hours every two weeks passed by the Legislative Yuan and promulgated by President Chen Shui-bian.

The alliance was comprised of the Chinese Federation of Labor, the National Labor Federation of Manufacturing Industries, the Workers Legislative Action Committee, and the Labor Union Human Rights Association.

The demonstrators paraded from Ta An Park along Hsinsheng South Road and Jenai Road, where they called on the opposition People First Party and Kuomintang to uphold the 84 working hours every two weeks so as to protect the "human rights" of laborers.

The demonstration ended at the plaza in front of the Presidential Office where they asked President Chen Shui-bian to keep the promises he made during his presidential election campaign to maintain the 84 working hour deal.
A party was scheduled to be held Sunday night at the plaza and the labor union alliance said it will stage another demonstration on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOBER TRANSACTIONS AVERAGE US$ 4.85 B DAILY ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: Daily transactions averaged US$4.85 billion on the Taipei foreign exchange (FOREX) market in October, a Central Bank of China (CBC) official said Sunday.
The official said that the transactions had accumulated to US$101.87 billion for October alone.

In terms of transaction types, transactions between banks and customers accounted for 45.2 percent of the total transaction volume, while bank to bank trading accounted for 54.8 percent. Transactions between local banking institutes occupied for 25.6 percent, while transactions between local banks and foreign banks accounted for 29.2 percent.

In terms of the monetary unit, transactions between new Taiwan dollars and foreign currencies accounted for 66 percent of the total transactions, of which transactions between NT dollars and U.S. greenbacks represented 62 percent of the total in October.
Transactions of monetary units accounted for 34 percent of the total transactions, of which transactions between Japanese yen and the U.S. dollar accounted for 14.8 percent.
Spot transactions accounted for 64.2 percent of the total transactions, while spot exchanges made up 16.2 percent. Futures transaction accounted for 9.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAKE CREDIT CARDS COST LOCAL BANKS NT$ 1.1 B IN FIRST NINE MONTHS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has earned many world "No. 1's" and another was added to the list Sunday.

According to statistics released by the Taiwan Bankers Association, fake credit cards have cost local banking institutes losses of NT$1.16 billion (US$37.6 million) in the first nine months of this year, surpassing Japan as the No. 1 country in the world in terms of credit card fraud.
The association said that last year's figure was just NT$200 million and that the new figure represents a ratio increase of 578 percent over the year-earlier level.
An association official said that Taiwan has become a production center for fake credit cards, meaning that fake cards from Taiwan are exported abroad.
Malaysia ranked third as a source of fake credit cards, followed by Australia, Hong Kong, Indonesia, mainland China, the Philippines and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MACAU RELATIONS EXPECTED TO IMPROVE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The relations between Taiwan and Macau are expected to improve steadily, Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan, said Sunday upon his return to Taipei from the former Portuguese colony.

Chen, who attended the Sixth Annual Seminar on Taiwan-Macau Relations on Dec. 9-10 in Macau in his capacity as a professor of the National Taiwan University, said most participants in the seminar believed Taiwan-Macau relations would improve steadily.

Approximately 40 scholars and experts from Taiwan and Macau attended the seminar. The topics of their discussion included how to strengthen Taiwan-Macau relations through cultural, economic, trading, and tourism exchanges and how Macau can serve as a bridge for promotion of relations between Taiwan and mainland China. Macau became a special administrative region of China in last December.
The MAC official told the press upon his return to Taipei that during his visit he did not meet with Macau leaders, but he did feel an atmosphere of goodwill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DIRECTOR WINS AWARD AT ASIAN PACIFIC FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan director Chang Chih-yung Sunday won the Best Director Award at the 2000 Asia Pacific Film Festival for his film "Lament of the Sand River."

The film festival, which is the Asian version of the Oscars, was held Dec. 6-10 in Hanoi. Thirty-eight feature films, 14 short films, and five animation films were entered for competition in the festival.
Taiwan film "Hidden Whisper," directed by Vivian Chang, was given the Special Jury Award. Wong Ching-Hsi of Taiwan won the Best Original Film Score Award.

Winners of other major awards are: Best Film -- Sand Life (Vietnam) Best Actor -- Choi Min Sic (South Korea) Best Cinematography -- "In the Mood for Love" (Hong Kong) Best Original Screenplay-- "Virgin Stripped Bare by Her Bachelors" (South Korea) Best Art Designing -- "Nagasaki Bura-Bura" (Japan) Best Editing -- "In the Mood for Love" (Hong Kong) Best Sound Effect -- "Lieutenant Adnan" (Malaysia) Best Short Film -- "Mrs. Nam" (Vietnam) Best Animation -- "The Boy Who Saw the Wind" (Japan)

Market turnover amounted to NT$44.42 billion (US$1.35 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE WINE PRICES TO INCREASE ANNUALLY AFTER TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: The price of rice wine will still be adjusted upward each year after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization despite an earlier decision by the Legislature, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long said Monday.

Amid public concerns about rising rice wine prices, the Finance Committee of the Legislative Yuan decided last week that the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Board (TTWB) would not be allowed to raise the price of rice wine without the consent of the legislature.

Chen, speaking at a seminar in Kaohsiung on the new business opportunities to be created by Taiwan's entry into the WTO, said that after Taiwan joins the world trade body, rice wine will be classified as a distillate, resulting in a high tax levy of NT$185 (US$5.58) per liter.
A standard 0.6-liter bottle of rice wine will therefore be priced at more than NT$100 (US$3.02), with the price being adjusted upward each year thereafter, Chen said.

But Chen also said that Taiwan has stepped up its communications with other nations during its negotiations to enter the WTO, explaining to them that rice wine is a staple ingredient in Chinese cooking and soliciting their understanding for more time in making the adjustment.
The TTWB has also launched a cooking wine onto the market in order to meet the needs of consumers. The cooking wine has a tax levy of only NT$22 per liter.
People are reportedly already hoarding Red Label, the most popular rice wine manufactured by the TTWB, in anticipation of Taiwan's entry into the WTO, which could take place early next year.
Shortages of Red Label rice wine as a result of hoarding actually began as early as November 1999 when talk of Taiwan's WTO accession was widespread.
The shortage prompted the TTWB to import rice wine from Singapore to overcome the shortfall in domestic production capacity.
Currently, both the domestically produced Red Label rice wine and the imported variety are priced at NT$24 per bottle.
