DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.58 points to close at 5,284.41.
The bourse opened at 5,283.81 and fluctuated between 5,300.3 and 5,237.19 during trading.

A total of 1.54 billion shares worth NT$44.42 billion (US$1.35 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.66 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$49.97 billion (US$1.51 billion).
All of the eight major categories gained ground, except for foodstuff shares, which remained unchanged.

Pulp and paper issues moved up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.9 percent, construction shares and cement stocks, both at 1.4 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.2 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 325 to 158, with 115 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO UNVEIL RELAXED MAINLAND INVESTMENT POLICY IN 20 DAYS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will unveil an eased "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy before the end of this year, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, Lin said the modified policy on mainland China-bound investment will give local companies greater freedom to invest on the mainland while requiring them to adopt capital risk management measures.
Under pressure from local entrepreneurs, legislators and economists, the MOEA has been reviewing the "no haste" mainland investment policy implemented by the previous Kuomintang (KMT) government.

Lin told members of the Legislature's economic and budgetary affairs committees that the policy review in entering the final stage and that the MOEA will come up with a revised version of the policy in 20 days.

In an attempt to cool a continued mainland investment fever amid Beijing's persistent hostility toward Taiwan, the former KMT government implemented a "no haste, be patient" policy in 1996. As the mainland economy continues thriving, local companies have been pressuring the government to ease the policy to allow them greater freedom to relocate production lines there to help maintain their market niches.

Under the "no haste" policy, Taiwan companies are banned from investing in mainland China's infrastructure construction and certain strategic industries. Moreover, the maximum amount for each investment project should not exceed US$50 million.
Lin said the adjusted policy will offer Taiwan companies greater freedom in deciding the fields or industries in which they will invest on the mainland.
Attracted by cheap land and labor as well as a common language and culture, Taiwan enterprises have poured some US$40 billion into the mainland for various investment projects over the past decade.

Asked how the MOEA evaluate the possible impact on cross-Taiwan Strait economic relations of Taiwan's and mainland China's anticipated accession to the World Trade Organization in the coming spring, Lin said WTO entry is indeed a "variable" to Taiwan's domestic economic situation and its trade with the mainland.
Nevertheless, Lin said he is convinced that the MOEA will be able to cope with any new challenges, including improving the domestic investment climate.
Lin further said he hopes the domestic political situation will remain stable next year and that the local economy will bottom out of its current slowdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 20 points to close at 5,330, with 6,389 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 increased 28 points to finish at 5,328, with 120 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures gained 26 points to close at 5,303, with three contract transactions.
June 2001 futures rose 56 points to finish at 5,303, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for September 2001 futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,310 for December, 5,300 for next January, 5,277 for next March, 5,247 for next June, and 5,728 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 0.4 points to close at 263.1, with 1,686 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures increased 1.15 points to finish at 262.15, with 71 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures rose 2.8 points to finish at 686, with 954 contracts changing hands, while January 2001 TF futures gained 6.6 points to close at 685, with 10 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 11, or the 16th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton), resulting in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: A South Korean naval training flotilla with 618 crewmen aboard leaves Kaohsiung after a three-day visit.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Col. Ernesto P. Goles, secretary of the Philippine chapter of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League, and Dr. Fethi Tevetoqlu, secretary-general of the Middle East Solidarity Council of Turkey, arrive in Taipei to attend the 23rd APACL pre-conference executive meeting.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the poll that selects Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S LEGAL TEAM TO DECIDE NEXT MOVE WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The legal team of Vice President Annette Lu will meet Wednesday to discuss its next move after the deadline set for a local magazine to apologize for what the team calls "libelous reports" about the vice president expired, a spokeswoman for Lu said Monday.
But Tsai Ming-hua said Monday that she has received no instructions that indicate the plans to take legal action against the Journalist will change.
In its Nov. 16 issue, the Journalist alleged that Lu was the source of the rumor about an extramarital affair between President Chen Shui-bian and one of his female aides.

Lu's legal team, calling the Journalist's report "obviously false and malicious," demanded that the magazine publish a half-spread front-page apology approved by Lu's lawyers in six newspapers and also make public the full text of the apology via six electronic media outlets before Dec. 10.

The legal team also demanded that the magazine conduct a full investigation into related "acts of negligence" by its reporters, writers, and editors and "dish out severe punishment" to show the news organization's "sincerity in carrying out self-regulation and self-reflection," or else face legal action.
But the Journalist did not apologize by the deadline set by the legal team and only sent a letter to the vice presidential office last Friday to explain its reports, Tsai said.

As two members of Lu's six-member legal team are currently out of the country and as the vice presidential office does not want to create the impression that it is "wicked and cruel," the office has decided not to immediately press charges against the Journalist and to leave the decision up to the legal team, Tsai said.
Tsai said that the maximum period for filing defamation charges is six months, adding that there is no hurry to come to any decisions in the next couple of days.

The legal team recently discussed follow-up actions and concluded that should it decide to press charges against the magazine for painting Lu as a rumormonger, it will demand that the Journalist take legal responsibility for its reports and will ask for NT$100 million (US$3.02 million) in compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DIRECTLY ELECT NEW CHAIR NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will hold the first-ever direct election of its chairman between March and April next year, a senior party official said Monday.

Chao Shou-po, director of the KMT Organization and Development Department, said the party is also planning to hold intraparty primary elections next May to select its candidates for the elections of local government chiefs and legislators slated for late 2001.

Chao said the KMT's membership re-registration will be closed at the end of this month. "But the party will offer a one-month grace period for those who for various reasons fail to complete re-registration before the deadline," he added.

According to Chao, more than 600,000 previously-registered KMT members had re-registered as of Dec. 9. In addition, Chao said, the party has so far managed to attract more than 70,000 newcomers to join its roster. "Altogether, our membership is approaching the 700,000-mark," he added.
After wrapping up the membership re-registration, Chao said the party's next key tasks are electing a new party chairman and holding primaries for the coming mayoral and parliamentary elections.

Chao said the 106-year-old KMT, which ruled Taiwan without interruption for 55 years until May 20, will allow its members to directly elect their new chairman for the first time next year, either in March or April. Chao said the KMT is still mulling whether to hold elections of party congress delegates at the same time as the chairmanship election.
In preparation for the elections of local government chiefs and legislators late next year, Chao said the KMT will hold primaries for the two critical elections separately in May 2001.

As the two elections are seen crucial to gauge whether the KMT, which now still controls a comfortable majority in the legislature, can stage a comeback in the 2004 presidential election, the party reportedly will make all-out efforts to win as many seats as possible.
Chao said the party will begin accepting registrations for primary elections for local government chiefs and parliamentary contests after the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 24.

To ensure fair competition and prevent hopefuls from changing their minds, Chao said the KMT will require prospective candidates to register for party primaries in just one election -- either for the applicable mayoral and county magistrate race or for the legislative contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC CHAIR SAYS M'LAND CHINA CANNOT SURPASS TAIWAN IN MICROCHIP OEM

TEXT.P: The Chairman of the world's largest microchip foundry said Monday that mainland China absolutely cannot surpass Taiwan in computer microchip original equipment manufacturing.

Morris Chang, president of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., said during a forum held at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan that he has confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects.

He pointed out that TSMC will not set up plants or make investments in mainland China in the near future and will instead focus its development in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE QUAKES ROCK SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three earthquakes with magnitudes of 5.3, 4.6, and 4.8 respectively on the Ritcher scale shook southern Taiwan Monday between 3:30 a.m. to 5:34 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau said.
A CWB official said, the first earthquake struck at 3:30 a.m., with its epicenter located 6.3 kilometers northwest of Yungkang, Tainan County and 16.5 kilometers below the surface.
The second quake struck at 4:00 a.m., with its epicenter 7.5 kilometers west of Yungkang and 19.1 kilometers below the surface.
A third temblor rocked the island at 5:34 a.m. The epicenter of the last earthquake was seven kilometers west of Yungkang and 19.1 kilometers below the surface.
Prior to the three successive temblors that hit Monday morning, no major quakes had occurred in the area for 30 years.

The CWB deputy-director, Lu Pei-ling, told the public not to panic because this phenomenon does not appear to be the signal for another major earthquake, although she added that minor quakes may occur over the next two to three days.

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.015 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$33.035.
The local currency opened at NT$32.990 and was traded between NT$32.988 and NT$33.075.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE PILOT SHORTAGE IS TEMPORARY: AIR FORCE BRASS

TEXT.P: The current shortage of pilots in the Republic of China Air Force is just a transitional and temporary phenomenon, a senior Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) officer said Monday.

AFGH Chief of Staff Chou Wen-chung made the remarks in response to an inquiry by opposition People First Party (PFP) Legislator Chung Shao-ho at a Legislative Yuan budget screening meeting on whether the current pilot shortage threatens Taiwan's security.

Chou pointed out that the manpower shortage has mainly been caused by the fact that a number of new pilots of the ranks of first and second lieutenant are now being trained to operate F5 jet fighters and AT-3 trainers in order to accumulate the minimum number of flight hours required for flying a new generation of warplanes.
According to present air force regulations, a military pilot must have a minimum of 400 hours of flight time to qualify for operating a new-generation jet fighter.

"As new graduates of the Chinese Air Force Academy only have 200 flight hours on their records, they must accumulate additional flight hours and experience by flying F5 fighters and AT-3 trainers," Chou explained, adding that the air force cannot compromise on this requirement, with a view to maintaining the quality of its pilots.

Chou noted that Taiwan lags behind mainland China in terms of the number of its military aircraft. "Against this background, we must endeavor to achieve qualitative superiority in order to maintain air supremacy in the Taiwan Strait," he said, adding: "This goal can be attained only by providing ROC pilots with a good training environment and well-designed courses to perfect their flight skills and combat tactics."

Chou said that with an eye on ensuring qualitative superiority, many air force pilots with more than 400 hours of flight time on their records now are also receiving "replacement" flight training on the new-generation fighters.
Therefore, Chou said, the present pilot shortage is just a temporary phenomenon during this transitional period.

As part of its military modernization plan, the ROC air force has purchased 130 locally developed Ching-kuo indigenous defense (IDFs), 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 fighters and 150 U.S.-made F-16 fighters. With a number of these advanced warplanes commissioned into service in the past few years, an unpublished Control Yuan report said that the nation's air force is suffering a serious pilot shortfall.

According to the report by the Control Yuan, the country's highest watchdog body, the number of first- and second-lieutenant pilots stationed at the air force's five major bases who are qualified to operate its second-generation warplanes reaches just 55 percent of current needs.

Meanwhile, press reports said two "seed" flight instructors who had been trained to operate F-16 and Mirage planes in the United States and France, respectively, have recently applied for retirement from the military service. Air force sources said their retirement will be a great loss to the country at this time of transition in its military arsenal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 'SILICON VALLEY' CELEBRATES 20TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Monday that his administration will join forces with the private sector to ensure sufficient water and electricity supplies for companies in Taiwan's premier high-technology industrial park.

Chen made the vow in a speech delivered at the opening of a global high-tech industry forum held in celebration of the 20th anniversary of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Taiwan's version of the U.S. Silicon Valley.
Chen said the government will also continue improving Taiwan's investment climate by cultivating qualified manpower, offering fine-quality infrastructure and world-standard legal system.

The president also said he is convinced that so long as Taiwan can successfully foster new competitive edge, the rapidly increasing outbound investment by Taiwan firms in recent years, mostly to mainland China, will not mean an "industrial hollowing out" for Taiwan.
"In such a case, an exodus of companies will instead mark an extension of Taiwan's industrial strength," Chen said optimistically.

Chen also pitched for his ambitious goal of building Taiwan into a "green silicon island," saying the plan is not aimed at protecting any specific industry or enterprise, but aimed at cultivating a new generation of business executives and enterprises that can use innovative technologies and open new business frontiers to accelerate upgrading of industry and overall economy.
In his speech, President Chen also hailed the achievements of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, 70 kilometers (42 miles) south of Taipei.

"It has become one of the most successful industrial parks in the world. With the park, the Republic of China has emerged as a key high-tech product producer," Chen said, adding: "Its rich experience has emerged as a textbook for many countries, including mainland China, in formulating their own science and technology development policies."

Speaking on the same occasion, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said the government is determined to forge partnership with private industries to create a favorable environment for sustainable economic development. He also expressed his hope that local technology firms can help those in traditional industries to transform and upgrade their production and management in order to survive increasingly intense global competition.

Sixteen information-technology industry heavyweights from eight countries and 20-plus local high-tech industry executives are attending the two-day forum to draw up a new blueprint for Taiwan's high-tech industry development.
Occupying a land of 600 hectares, the industrial park houses 390 companies, notably microchip makers, integrated circuit design houses, computer and computer peripheral companies.
With a combined total of 100,000 employees, the industrial park's output is forecast to surge to NT$900 billion (US$27.26 billion) in 2000, up from NT$300 billion in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTE IS ABOUT POLITICAL SYSTEMS: MAC VICE HEAD

TEXT.P: Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tung said here Monday that the current dispute between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is an argument over political systems, and not over national reunification or independence.

He said that actually, the dispute over national reunification or independence falls under the main issue of political systems, since the choice of Taiwan's national identification will eventually be decided through its political system, he said.
He said that he did not regard a supporter of Taiwan independence as someone who has "forgotten his own origins" -- despite criticism to that effect from the authorities in Beijing.

Chen made the remarks in a keynote speech on cross-strait relations at a seminar for the Chinese-language Teachers of Malaysia sponsored by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, which is under the control of the Executive Yuan.

Chen pointed out that the "three direct links" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would benefit both sides, as long as they cooperate with each other. If both sides operate on the basis of economic cooperation and shared interests, the links would help to improve peaceful political relations across the Taiwan Strait, he said.

"If both sides could cooperate, it would create an everlasting peace," he said, going on to quote a Chinese proverb that any place that a merchant cannot reach must be at war. He also called on leaders in mainland China to strengthen economic cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait after both sides are admitted into the World Trade Organization.
Asked why President Chen Shui-bian has only identified himself as Taiwanese and has not said that he is also Chinese, Chen Ming-tung noted that the president has never said that he is not Chinese.
Chen also expressed the hope that mainland China will enter into negotiations with Taiwan over the "mini three links" scheduled to be opened next January.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR INVESTMENT CASES DECREASED BY NEARLY 50 PERCENT IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Apparently affected by domestic political unrest, the number of major investments of more than NT$200 million decreased by nearly 50 percent annually in November, the Ministry of Economics Affairs reported Monday.
The decline was more than 50 percent in terms of capital volume, the MOEA added.

Just four new major investment projects, worth a total of NT$3 billion, were registered in November, the MOEA said. It added that there were seven new major investment projects worth a cumulative NT$8.8 billion were registered last November. MOEA officials attributed the decrease to domestic political unrest and the worsening investment climate in Taiwan.
A total of 185 new major investment projects were registered during the January-November period this year, worth a total of NT$615.2 billion.

About 50 percent of that total was invested in electronic machinery and electronics. Among the standouts, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. invested NT$149.5 billion to build a factory to produce 12-inch wafers, and Formosa Plastics Group invested NT$130 billion to establish the sixth Naphtha Cracker Plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-CENTRAL AMERICAN FM COMMITTEE MEETING SLATED FOR WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The ninth meeting of the Mixed Foreign Ministers Cooperative Committee between the Republic of China and Central America is scheduled to be held Wednesday in Taipei.
Topics for discussion will be centered on regional cooperation and relations between the ROC and its allies in Central America.

In addition to ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hong-mao, Guatemalan Foreign Minister Gabriel Orellana, El Salvador Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, Honduras Foreign Minister Roberto Flores Aguirre Sacasa, Costa Rican Vice Foreign Minister Elayne Whyte Gomez, Panamanian Vice Foreign Minister Harmodio Arias, Belize Member of Parliament Vildo Marin will be present at the meeting, with Dominican Republic Vice Foreign Minister Miguel Anibal Pichardo Olivier attending as an observer. A delegate from Central American Integrated Systems (SICA) will also attend.
President Chen Shui-bian will receive all the participants on Thursday and they will also call on Tien, as well as visiting local cultural and economic establishments before leaving for home Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRMS TO HAVE MORE CHANCE IN MAINLAND CHINA AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan enterprises will have more trade opportunities in mainland China after both sides of the Taiwan Strait enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), said a high-ranking Republic of China policy planner Monday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said in a symposium on trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is also evaluating whether to revise the country's "no haste, be patient" policy toward Taiwan investment in mainland China.
Chen added that the ministry will come up with an initial conclusion before the end of the year.

Under the "no haste" policy, Taiwan companies are banned from investing in infrastructure construction projects in mainland China, as well as certain strategic industries. Moreover, the maximum amount for each investment project is not supposed to exceed US$50 million.

Chen declined to comment on the call to ease the "no haste" policy from many ROC industrial leaders, including Formosa Plastics Group President Wang Yung-ching. Chen only said that the MOEA has been evaluating the request.

Noting that many Taiwanese traditional industries have already invested in mainland China, Chen said that Taiwan firms will have more space to develop their share of the mainland market after the entry of both sides of the Taiwan Strait into the WTO. He warned that WTO entry will also result in fierce competition.
He urged industries in Taiwan and mainland China to cooperate and integrate for their mutual benefit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NT$ 500 NOTES TO BE ISSUED DEC. 15

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will issue a redesigned NT$500 note Dec. 15 as part of a series of moves to revamp the local currency, a CBC official said Monday.
Wu Shaw-chi, director-general of the CBC's Issue Department, said the existing NT$500 notes will remain in circulation until June 30, 2002, after which people will be able to exchange them.

The new notes will be 155 mm by 70mm and will be brown in color. The obverse side of the new bills will carry a "sports pattern" and the Chinese characters for "The Republic of China," "The Central Bank of China," and "Five Hundred Dollars." It will also carry the digit "500," while the reverse side will carry a design based on the sika deer, a mountain view and bamboo.

A redesigned NT$1,000 note was introduced in July and the CBC also plans to put into circulation next July a new NT$100 note, to be followed in January 2002 with a NT$200 note and in July of that year with a NT$2,000 note.
All the new notes will be manufactured with more advanced technology to make them more difficult to counterfeit, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO GERMAN PARLIAMENTARIANS ARRIVE FOR WEEK-LONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Rainer Eppelmann, former East Germany's last defense minister and now a parliamentarian, arrived Monday in Taipei with his colleague W. Link for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

While in Taipei, they will call on MOFA, the Government Information Office, the Mainland Affairs Council, Kaohsiung Port and a military training center in Pingtung County before departing for home Dec. 17.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAVID C.Y. HU CONFIRMED NEW ROC ENVOY TO PANAMA

TEXT.P: David C.Y. Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affair Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) was confirmed Monday by MOFA to be new the Republic of China Ambassdor to Panama.
MOFA also confirmed that the vacancy created by Hu's appointment will be filled in by Robert M.T. Chen, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Miami.

The current ROC ambassador to Panama, Lan Chi-min, will be ordered home to take over as MOFA secretary-general, filling the vacancy left by Yang Chien-tien, who has been named ROC representative to Australia.
Hu is an expert in Central American affairs and his upcoming mission will undoubtedly help strengthen the formal diplomatic relations between the ROC and Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU INDUSTRIAL PARK FOUNDER PLEASED WITH ITS 20-YEAR HISTORY

TEXT.P: Irving T. Ho, one of the founders of Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, said Monday that establishing the park proved to be the correct policy, considering the facility's contribution to Taiwan's economy in the past 20 years.

Ho, who also served as the first director general of what has often been hailed as the world's No. 1 high-tech complex, said at the park's 20th anniversary celebration that a total of US$600 million has been invested throughout the years to develop the facility, but that the total cumulative returns have exceeded US$100 billion. This 160-fold investment return is "very worthwhile," he added.

Aggregate sales of the more than 200 technology-based firms in the park will reach NT$900 billion (US$27.2 billion) this year, which is equivalent to approximately 10 percent of Taiwan's Gross National Product, Ho noted. He went on to say that the Hsinchu site takes up only six square kilometers, making the park's accomplishments all the more remarkable.

Ho urged Taiwan's high-tech industries to set their sights on network, communication, software, and biotechnology development while continuing to innovate. He added that Taiwan and mainland China should cooperate with each other instead of looking at their respective high-tech development efforts as a zero-sum game.

Regarding fears that Taiwan may lose its competitiveness if industries continue to set up their manufacturing centers in mainland China, Ho said that as long as better products can be developed to replace the ones that left, Taiwan should be able to retain its edge.

Ho worked for IBM in the United States for 16 years prior to returning to Taiwan at the invitation of then-Premier Sun Yun-suan, who was also present at Monday's celebrations in his current capacity as a senior presidential adviser.

Upon returning to Taiwan, Ho took up the post of vice chairman of Taiwan's National Science Council (NSC) and concurrently served as the head of a division of the NSC called the Science-based Industrial Park Administration, which oversees the Hsinchu site.

He later served as the president of Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry, a quasi-governmental organization that promotes Taiwan's information industry and is charged with accelerating the country's national computerization program.

Ho is currently an adviser to several industrial parks in mainland China and the chairman of EiC Corp., a U.S.-based integrated circuit company specializing in the development of wireless handset components.

As a successful example of a government-university-industry initiative, the park is home to such prominent names as Acer and Mitec, leading manufacturers of personal computers; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., a pioneer in the semiconductor foundry business; United Micro-Electronics Corp. and TI-Acer, both leaders in the microprocessor and DRAM/SRAM business; and Umax, a leading producer of optical scanners and multimedia products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN INDUSTRIAL PARK ESCAPES EARTHQUAKE LOSSES
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan escaped damage from three earthquakes which hit southern Taiwan Monday, thanks to their efficient safety measures.
The three quakes, with magnitudes of 5.3, 4.6 and 4.8 respectively, occurred between 3:30 a.m. and 5:34 a.m.

The preparatory center of the industrial park said that the strong earthquake that caused tremendous loss to manufactorers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park on Sept. 21 last year have prompted most high-tech companies to strengthen measures to counter quake damage. Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is often called the Silicon Valley of Taiwan.

For example, the center added, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd. and Chi Mei Corp. purchased their own seismometers in order to receive related information and take emergency measures as quickly as possible.
The Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park, which is expected to be completed in 2005, will be able to accommodate some 200 companies and employ more than 70,000 workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S KG, JAPAN'S NTT DOCOMO TO EXPLORE MAINLAND CHINESE MARKET

TEXT.P: Jeffrey Koo, vice chairman of the Koo's Group (KG), expressed Monday his group's intention to join hands with Japan's NTT DoCoMo to explore the mainland Chinese telecommunication market.
At a cocktail party held to mark the cooperation of two groups, Koo said the opening of the mainland market is expected to trigger a new wave of investment there.

He noted that NTT DoCoMo's recent investment in KG Telecommunications Co. is a significant move for the two companies to work out a global strategy and to explore the mainland and other Chinese markets.
Last month, NTT DoCoMo acquired a 20 percent share of KG Telecommunications at a cost of over NT$17 billion.
DoCoMo President Keiji Tachikawa noted that mainland China has a population of 1.3 billion and is an attractive market and described the cooperation with KG as "happy event."
The cocktail party was jointly chaired by Koo, Tachikawa and KG Telecommunications Chairman Koo Cheng-yun.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO CATCH UP ADVANCED COUNTRY IN 10 YEARS: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chung-hsiung said Monday that the Republic of China government will put maximum efforts into promoting some strategic industries and try to reach the level of an advanced country within ten years.
He made the remarks during a meeting with visiting Tennessee State Governor Don Sundquist.

Chang, who earlier the same day had attended a celebration of the 20th anniversary of the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, known locally as "Taiwan's Silicon Valley," told Sundquist that it is expected that production at the industrial park can one day reach NT$3,000 billion (US$90 billion) and that the development of high-tech industries is the crucial factor in the park's success.

The premier went on to say that the 21st century will see fierce competition in various industries. The United States is expected to lead other countries in the areas of biotechnology and information technology, thanks to their gigantic investment in research and development, Chang said, adding that the U.S. model is worth emulation by other countries.

As Tennessee has sisterhood ties with Taiwan Province, Chang said, he will improve the local investment environment to attract more American entrepreneurs to invest in Taiwan, adding his hope that Sundquist will also promote bilateral investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL ATTENDS MEETING OF CARIBBEAN, LATIN AMERICAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu returned to Taipei Monday after attending the Dec. 5-8 annual meeting of Caribbean and Latin American countries in Miami.
Lin told reporters that the ROC mission held a cocktail party Dec. 6 to introduce the latest economic and trade developments in Taiwan, attended by over 500 delegates to the meeting.
Topics discussed at the four-day meeting, according to Lin, included energy, tourism, transport, intellectual property, telecommunications, textiles and free trade zones.
Of the participating countries, 13 maintain diplomatic relations with the ROC.
Lin also took advantage of the meeting to hold talks with Guatemalan President Alfonso Portillo and Grenadian Prime Minister Keith Mitchell.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENNESSEE GOVERNOR CALLS ON ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian told visiting Tennessee Governor Don Sundquist Monday that safeguarding the peace and stability of the Asia Pacific region conforms with both ROC and U.S. interests.

Chen went on to say that American democracy serves as a model for the Republic of China. Taking this year's shambolic U.S. presidential election as an example, Chen said that although the results are not yet known, the American people have "retained their rationality" out of respect for the system and the constitution and are "quietly waiting" for the outcome. "That is democracy," he added.

Chen went on to say that although he himself won the ROC presidential election in March by only a slim 2.5 percent margin, or 310,000 votes, the people fully accepted the election results with no legal contentions and no "unfortunate casualties" afterward. This, he continued, is what is so noteworthy about Taiwan's democratic maturity.

In reply, Sundquist quoted former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who once quipped that "democracy is the worst form of government, except for all the others that have been tried from time to time." Sundquist went on to say that the current situation in the United States where the election results are still up in the air is indeed a first in U.S. history and a difficult challenge to the country.
He added that the situation should end soon so as to allow the country's affairs to go on.

Sundquist said that he has been a long-time friend of Taiwan and that his supportive stance will not change. He praised the Republic of China's economic accomplishments under its democratic system and expressed his hope that the two countries will continue to strengthen cooperative and exchange efforts under a liberalized trading environment.
Sundquist's delegation of four arrived in Taipei last Thursday and is scheduled to depart Tuesday. This is his fifth visit to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR PREDICTS STABLE TAIPEI-BEIJING RELATIONS FOR THREE YEARS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 10 (CNA) (By Eric C.Y. Tseng and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taipei-Beijing relations will remain stable for the next three years because mainland China is "secretly happy" about the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation, Chou Yang-sun, a former Republic of China legislator, said here Sunday.

Chou, who is currently a visiting professor at Columbia University, said at a seminar organized by opposition New Party supporters in New York that Beijing is also pleased that the new U.S. president -- whoever it may be -- will probably not change the existing U.S. policy toward mainland China because he will be a "minority president."

According to Chou, the U.S. electoral college system was designed to protect the rights of smaller states, and that if Texas Governor George W. Bush were to eventually win the election, then it would signify the failure of popular democracy and the victory of the constitutional system.

Regardless, Chou continued, making changes to an existing constitutional system is not something that should be spoken of lightly. He cited Taiwan's six constitutional amendment efforts as examples of this, saying that the fifth attempt actually violated the Constitution itself.

As to whoever becomes the next U.S. president, Chou said that the split in various levels of government caused by the ongoing political and legal contentions will leave the new leader as a "minority" leader who is likely to tread a careful line.

From the mainland Chinese perspective, Chou said that Beijing has been maintaining a watchful attitude toward Taiwan's political development since the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party took the reins of power in March.

Chou said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian's repeated pledges not to declare independence during his four-year term, the numerous other olive branches he has held out toward Beijing, and the domestic political instability in Taiwan, have all pleased Beijing. On the surface, however, mainland China continues to "sound tough" toward Taiwan.

Chou claimed that because Beijing was able to achieve its objectives without using a single soldier or bullet, he believes that no matter how tough Beijing may seem over the next three years, cross-strait relations should remain stable.

However, ha also said that in the second half of 2003, Chen will be facing another election battle and may give way to some extent in bilateral relations, thereby bringing about possible changes in cross-strait development.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAST RESTRICTION ON FOREIGN HOLDINGS IN LOCAL FIRMS TO BE LIFTED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan authorities will lift the last restriction on foreign investors' stakes in any individual listed firm at the beginning of next year, Vice Finance Minister Chen Chung said Monday.
Chen told the Legislative Yuan that Taiwan will open its market fully to foreign investors from Jan. 1, 2001, as promised in its protocol for entry into the World Trade Organization.
Current regulations limit foreign ownership in any listed firm to 75 percent of its shares.
Since Jan. 1 is a bank holiday, the new regulation will take effect Jan.2, Chen added.

Chen made the comment in response to legislators' concerns that the Morgan Stanley Capital International Inc. (MSCI) has reneged on its promise to hike Taiwan stock's weighting in its various indices from 80 percent to 100 percent in May because of the island's restriction on foreign investment.
Meanwhile, an official at the Securities and Futures Commission under the Ministry of Finance played down the MSCI's decision as having more of a psychological than a physical effect.
So far, the maximum foreign stake in any firm is no more than 30 percent, despite the fact that they can hold up to 75 percent, said the official, who refused to be named.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING LIKELY TO ENTER WTO BETWEEN APRIL AND JUNE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taipei and Beijing will probably enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) between April and June next year, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said Monday.

Lin said that according to WTO administrative procedures, if Beijing completes its WTO working group meetings in January next year, the General Council -- the WTO's highest decision-making body -- is expected to hold a meeting to finalize the case in March or April.

At present, Taipei has completed all bilateral and multilateral negotiation procedures with all WTO member economies. It is Beijing's insistence that it join WTO prior to Taipei that has delayed Taipei's progress in entering the world trade regulatory body as Beijing has lagged behind in its own entry process.

Beijing had its last WTO working group meeting in early December and the final such meeting is scheduled to be held in January. If everything goes smoothly, it is expected that the meeting of the WTO General Council will be held in March or April to pass Beijing's WTO application and Taipei is expected to be admitted into the WTO shortly afterward.
Once Taipei's and Beijing's respective legislatures have approved their own WTO entries, both sides will formally become WTO members.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS STRIKE OFF BUDGET FOR LAFAYETTES' LOGISTIC SUPPLIES

TEXT.P: A NT$330 million (US$10 million) budget allocation for logistic supplies for the country's six Lafayette-class missile frigates was axed Monday by the opposition-held National Defense Committee at the Legislative Yuan.

The budget for spare parts for the island's six French-made Lafayettes, which are already in service, was cut entirely by opposition lawmakers on the grounds that the authorities have failed to come clean on allegations that huge kickbacks were involved in the purchase of the six warships.

New Party Legislator Cheng Long-shui said the government should not give more money to French company Thomson, which is reputed to have paid huge kickbacks to officials in Paris, Taipei and even Beijing in return for a green light for the sale of the warships in 1990s.
The navy is contemplating a lawsuit against Thomson before a French court for inflating the price of the Lafayettes with brokers' commissions, which was forbidden under the contract.

In an attempt to keep the budget intact, Navy Chief of Staff Vice Admiral Chang Wen-ping told the legislators that the deal for the spare parts was signed with the French government rather than Thomson, and that any breach of the contract could invite claims for compensation from Paris.

The only opposition legislator who spoke out for the budget was Chou Cheng-chih of the Kuomintang, who claimed the deal should not be canceled to the prejudice of Taiwan's contacts with France, as this could strengthen Washington's hand in terms of arms sales to the island.
However, his arguments failed to cut any ice with his legislative colleagues.
Also excised by the committee was a budget of NT$600 million (US$18.18 million) earmarked for spare parts for the navy's 26 S-2T anti-submarine aircraft and an unspecified number of helicopters.
Answering questions from the legislators, Vice Adm. Chang admitted that only one of the 26 S-2Ts is in fact operational, as all have engine problems.

However, the committee did approve a budget for a NT$50,000 (US$1,515) hike in salary for each air force pilot in an attempt to stop the exodus of jet fighter pilots from military to the civil aviation industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTERS OF GUATEMALA AND HONDURAS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The foreign ministers of Guatemala and Honduras arrived in Taipei Monday night.

Guatemalan Foreign Minister Gabriel Orellana and Honduras Foreign Minister Flores Bermudez, traveling at the heads of their respective delegations, will attend the ninth meeting of the Mixed Foreign Ministers Cooperative Committee between the Republic of China and Central America which is slated to be held Wednesday in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 95.68 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 95.68 points to close at 5,380.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$67.31 billion (US$2.04 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 95.68 points to close at 5,380.09.
Encouraged by a rebound in U.S. hi-tech stocks, the bourse opened at 5,320.61 and continued to go up. The index fluctuated between 5,403.14 and 5,320.61 during trading.

A total of 2.08 billion shares worth NT$67.31 billion (US$2.04 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.54 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$44.42 billion (US$1.35 billion).

All the eight major categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 3.3 percent, followed by electrical shares at 2.2 percent, textile issues and bank and insurance shares, both at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, foodstuff shares and pulp and paper issues, both at 0.8 percent, and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbers losers 442 to 88, with 73 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 60 points to close at 5,390, with 8,519 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 increased 77 points to finish at 5,405, with 298 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures were set Tuesday at 5,330 for December, 5,328 for next January, 5,335 for next March, 5,305 for next June and 5,748 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
December TE futures moved up 4.1 points to close at 267.2, with 2,261 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures increased 3.85 points to finish at 266, with 73 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 TE futures gained 5.35 points to close at 265, with two contracts traded. No transactions were reported for other months.
December TF futures rose 9 points to finish at 695, with 1,021 contract transactions, while January 2001 TF futures gained 15.8 points to close at 697, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 12, or the 17th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: German aeronautical engineer Hugo Junkers conducts a test flight of his all-metal plane, the world's first.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a US warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking, and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revised Factory Law.
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others, and a special prize at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian legislature for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: Chi Ta-chuan, a mainland Chinese national, hijacks a Xiamen Airlines plane to Taiwan.
1994: The Lien Chan cabinet is re-organized and new cabinet members are sworn in on Dec. 15.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning, in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS NOT IN FAVOR OF PAY RAISE FOR CIVIL SERVANTS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the Cabinet's support for a pay raise for the nation's public servants remains unchanged despite the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) legislative caucus proposal to delay the move for one year.

Chang, who heads the DPP administration, said that the 3 percent salary boost for the Republic of China's government employees, military personnel, and teachers was included in the budget proposal for the fiscal year 2001 precisely because it is the Cabinet's "set policy."

He added that because the Cabinet's proposed budget must be reviewed and approved by the Legislative Yuan, where the DPP is a minority party, the Cabinet will strive to win over legislative support on this and other items.

Chu Wu-hsien, director general of the Cabinet's Central Personnel Administration, pointed out that one-and-a-half years have passed since the last salary adjustment for public functionaries. He noted that the consumer price index increased 0.18 percent in 1999 and 1.8 percent for 2000, adding that it is projected to rise 2.01 percent for 2001, thereby outstripping the proposed 3 percent pay raise.
He therefore noted that the proposed salary hike is really only meant to help civil servants cope with the rise in prices and does not actually represent an increase in their income in real terms.

DPP legislators Chou Po-lun and Tsai Huang-liang spoke out against the supposedly "unanimous" passage of the motion to strike out the NT$21 billion (US$636 million) budget item at the DPP legislative caucus meeting earlier in the day. The caucus is scheduled to make its actual proposal to strike out the budget at a Legislative Yuan meeting next Monday.
Tsai said he will introduce another proposal to reverse the caucus decision, and Chou remarked that the factionalism within the party means "opposition parties aren't even necessary."
Meanwhile, the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang, the People First Party (PFP), and the New Party (NP) announced its support for the pay raise and criticized the policy about-face.
PFP spokeswoman Lee Ching-an said the new DPP legislative caucus decision "came as a surprise" as the Legislature's Organic Committee had only made a decision days earlier to accept the budget item.

NP spokesman Lai Shyh-bao said that a pay raise would help boost morale and would be helpful to the nation's development. He added that the DPP is the ruling party and yet its own legislative caucus ended up unilaterally going against the ROC president and Cabinet's promise for such a salary raise.

DPP legislative whip Hsu Tien-tsai said that although his caucus finds it "heartrending" to slash the budget item, public servants, unlike many laborers, are not in danger of losing their jobs even at a time when the domestic economy is doing poorly. He therefore claimed that the public servants should be able to understand the caucus's "responsible move."
