DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR SMOOTH WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he hopes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) simultaneously in the first half of next year.
Chen made the appeal while meeting with visiting U.S. Senator Max Baucus for wide-ranging talks.
President Chen told the Democratic senator from Montana that he looks forward to seeing Taipei's and Beijing's smooth WTO entry next spring without any political interference.
Chen also expressed his hope that the United States continues to play an even more active role in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Baucus joined 14 other U.S. senators in 1992 to push then-U.S. President George Bush to support the Republic of China's bid to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which was superseded by the WTO in 1995. "We are grateful for your support for our national cause," Chen told Baucus.
Baucus has been concerned about Taiwan's security and supports continued U.S. supply of defensive weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.
President Chen requested Baucus to continue joining forces with his congressional colleagues to back security, peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region.
Touching on cross-strait relations, Chen told Baucus said he will abide by the ROC constitution to maintain national sovereignty and dignity while engaging mainland China.

Chen also pledged his determination to improve cross-strait relations with wisdom and vision. "My administration is now working hard to forge a national consensus on how to respond to Beijing's 'one China' principle and to forge a new framework for bilateral engagement," he explained.

Chen told Baucus that a cross-party presidential advisory group has recently come up with "three understandings and four recommendations" on the future development of cross-strait ties, including that any changes to Taiwan's present "status quo" must have the assent of the people of Taiwan.

As the ROC's national leader, Chen said he fully understands that he is obligated to maintain peace and security in the Taiwan Strait for the well-being of Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

For his part, Baucus said he is impressed by Taiwan's remarkable progress in democratic reform since his first visit to the island in 1992. He particularly lauded Taiwan for its peaceful democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May.

Baucus also told President Chen that he is convinced whoever wins the cliffhanger U.S. 2000 presidential election, the incoming U.S. administration will continue supporting the ROC and the current cross-strait status quo. He also suggested that Taiwan strengthen trade and economic exchanges with the mainland to facilitate resumption of cross-strait dialogue.
Baucus concluded his three-day visit to Taiwan Tuesday at the head of a 22-member Montana trade delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.053 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 33.088.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 33.006 and was traded between 33.004 and 33.130.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$362 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED MICROELECTRONICS TO INVEST IN 12-INCH WAFER PLANT IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Robert H.C. Tsao, chairman of microprocessor and DRAM/SRAM business leader United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), announced Tuesday that his company will invest over US$2 billion to build a 12-inch wafer plant in Singapore.
However, he would not divulge who will be the company's partner in the joint venture, saying only that UMC will retain full control over the investment.

Tsao said that the reason his company chose to build the plant in Singapore is that the Singaporean government understands the semiconductor industry more than Taiwan's government does and provides many investment incentives.

Furthermore, the Singaporean government allows companies that invest there to hire talented people from around the world, creates an open and global environment, and helps workers at these companies obtain permanent residence, he added.

Tsao said that the Singaporean government, unlike Taiwan's, understands that the semiconductor industry uses less water and electricity than other industries with similar turnover. The Singaporean government also knows that the semiconductor industry has no pollution problems, while the government in Taiwan treats the industry as a high-polluting industry, he said.
As for the decision to build a 12-inch wafer plant instead of an 8-inch plant, Tsao said that UMC believes a 12-inch plant would be more competitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: '3 MINI LINKS' AIMED AT LEGALIZING CURRENT SMALL-SCALE TRADE

TEXT.P: The primary reason to open the "three mini links" is to legalize the existing small-scale trade between two offshore islands and mainland China, the nation's top planner on mainland policy said Tuesday.
Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks when she called on the opposition New Party caucus in the Legislative Yuan to exchange views on cross-strait policy.

On the partial trade, postal and transport links between Kinmen and Matsu and designated ports in mainland China, commonly known as the "three mini links," Tsai said the MAC will follow the Legislative Yuan resolution to consider legalizing the already rampant practice of small-scale trade between the people of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China.

Tsai said that the MAC would take into account the convenience of the residents of Kinmen and Matsu, who live closer to mainland China than to Taiwan proper and who have traded goods with mainland residents for years. She noted that they could be penalized because current law still bans such trade, but it would be better to simply legalize the commerce.
Tsai said that residents in Kinmen and Matsu who travel to the mainland and bring back goods should not be considered as smugglers, which is a factor in considering the legalization of the practice.
The first stage of the "three mini links" will be to legalize the current small-scale trade, after which larger-scale commercial trade can be considered, Tsai said.

Lai Hsyh-bao, NP legislative whip, said that the three mini links will be put into practice as scheduled on Jan. 1, 2001, but there is no timetable for the implementation of the full direct links between Taiwan proper and the mainland.
Lai also said that Tsai will consider the introduction of mainland China laborers to Taiwan and also allow more distant mainland relatives of Taiwan residents to travel to Taiwan.
Tsai said that it is expected that the first batch of mainland tourists will come to Taiwan in June next year.

She also said the crucial part of the current "go slow, be patient" policy will be adjusted to keep industrial roots in Taiwan. She also said that a system must be put into place by which capital would also flow back to Taiwan, rather than simply remaining in the mainland.
She stressed that this would entail creating a good economic environment so that capital would return to the island naturally, rather than in a compulsory fashion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAIL CORP. SIGNS DEAL WITH JAPANESE FIRM

TEXT.P: Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC) signed a formal agreement with Japan's Taiwan Shinkansen Consortium (TSC) in Tokyo on Tuesday to purchase the core equipment and power system for the island's first high-speed railway.
According to a THSRC news release, the NT$95 billion (US$2.9 billion) deal was sealed by THSRC Chairwoman Nita Ing and TSC Chairman Kazuo Sato.

The contract came six months after a memorandum of understanding on the deal was signed, instead of the "four to six weeks" that Ing had promised at the time. THSRC said that the delay was caused by the company's desire to ensure that all documents were complete and carefully handled.

According to the news release, the Japanese consortium will obtain a 10 percent stake in THSRC for about NT$13.5 billion (US$409 million) in cash, with TSC's first installment of about NT$2.4 billion (US$73 million) expected by the end of this year.
TSC will supply "bullet train" locomotives and carriages as well as signaling, communication, and electrification systems for the high-speed rail line.
Construction on the railway started last year, and all systems are scheduled to be completed before August 2005, with commercial operation set to begin in October of that year.

The new system is designed to shorten the travel time between Taiwan's major northern and southern cities, Taipei and Kaohsiung. With a maximum speed of 300 kilometers per hour, a trip from Taipei to Kaohsiung with only a single stop at Taichung will take approximately 90 minutes, according to THSRC.
The company noted that a specially designed system will detect earthquakes and landslides so that trains will automatically slow down or stop completely.
The electrification system to be used will be an upgraded version of the system being used to power Japan's Shinkansen bullet trains.
TSC's partners include Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Marubeni Corp., Mitsui Corp., Sumitomo Corp., Kawasaki Heavy Industries, and Toshiba Electric.
TSC unexpectedly defeated the Alstom-Siemens Eurotrain consortium last December to win exclusive negotiating rights for the THSRC's core system and equipment contract.

The European consortium, which was named THSRC's "preferred bidder" in 1997 in a preliminary deal for the equipment and systems, filed an injunction with Taipei District Court in January to bar THSRC from signing the contract with the Japanese consortium.
The legal action was dropped after the judge said Eurotrain failed to provide sufficient evidence for an injunction against THSRC.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG FOUNDER LI HONGZHI NOMINATED FOR NOBEL PEACE PRIZE

TEXT.P: Li Hongzhi, founder of Falun Gong, has been nominated for 2001 Nobel Peace Prize, the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Tuesday.
The information center said more than 30 lawmakers and professors from the United States, the United Kingdom, and some other countries have jointly nominated Li for the prize.

They based their decision to nominate him on the grounds that his theory of Falun Gong has helped enhance peace of human beings, that his followers have enriched the idea of peace by showing strong confidence in peace during the harsh government crackdown on the Falun Gong sect, and that Li and his followers have become a strong buttress for protection of basic human rights on the Chinese mainland, it added.
Founded by Li in 1992, Falun Gong promotes a kind of traditional Chinese "qi gong". It is a combination of meditation, breathing techniques, and the idea of "truth, compassion, and forbearance."

Falun Gong soon became an enormous spiritual movement with millions of followers in mainland China. The Chinese government outlawed Falun Gong as an "evil cult" in July last year, and has sent hundreds of its practitioners to prison and labor camps since then.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, HONDURAS NATIONAL PARKS FORGE SISTERLY TIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Yushan National Park forged a sisterly relationship with La Tigra National Park of Honduras Tuesday to strengthen cooperation in the conservation of natural ecology and biological diversity.

Interior Minister Chang Po-ya and visiting Honduran Foreign Minister Roberto Flores Bermudez signed a memorandum of understanding on the Yushan-La Tigra tie-up on behalf of their respective governments.

Minister Chang said both the Yushan and La Tigra national parks were established for ecological preservation and natural resource protection. While Yushan is the ROC's oldest national park, La Tigra, rich in flora and fauna resources, is widely recognized as one of the world's largest natural reserves.
Chang said the Yushan-La Tigra ties will facilitate cooperation in environmental protection and education as well as research of biological studies.
"We hope the new cooperative program will open a new chapter in ROC-Honduras relations," Chang added.
Honduran Foreign Minister Flores arrived in Taipei Monday to attend a meeting of foreign ministers of the ROC and its Central American diplomatic allies, scheduled to open Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO HASTE' POLICY AIMED AT RETAINING BUSINESS ROOTS IN TAIWAN: MAC

TEXT.P: The government's "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment is mainly aimed at encouraging Taiwan enterprises to retain their business roots at home, a senior mainland policy planner said Tuesday.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the remarks after briefing the legislative caucus of the tiny opposition New Party.
"The most important spirit of the `no haste' policy is to make our entrepreneurs keep their business roots in Taiwan," Tsai stressed.

She went on to say that the Republic of China government is reviewing the policy with the aim of giving local businesses greater freedom in deciding whether to launch investment projects on the mainland.

According to Tsai, the mainland investment policy will be eased step by step. "Local entrepreneurs need not feel disappointed if the initial relaxation of restrictions on mainland investment is not very large," she noted, adding that there will be follow-up adjustment measures announced later.

While easing restrictions on the lines of business to be allowed for Taiwanese investment on the mainland, Tsai said, the government hopes to simultaneously develop a system that will allow Taiwanese capital to flow home, to protect Taiwan from a capital drain.

"To reach this goal, we must create a favorable economic climate that will make it attractive for Taiwanese investors on the mainland to willingly remit their capital gains back to Taiwan, " Tsai explained.

The "no haste, be patient" policy was first adopted by the previous Kuomintang government in 1996 to cool a prevailing mainland investment fever. Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Monday the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will unveil a relaxed version of the policy in 20 days.
Tsai said an inter-ministerial task force composed of officials from the MAC, MOEA and other relevant government agencies, has almost completed its review of the "no haste" policy.
"What we are mulling is the speed and scope of the liberalization of mainland China-bound investment," Tsai said.

Meanwhile, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said six kinds of technology products, including semiconductors, wireless communications products and high-end personal computers, will be opened for Taiwanese investment in mainland China under the adjusted policy. The six items are currently on an off-limit list.

Chen said the revised policy will basically offer greater freedom for local companies to decide the items they plan to produce on the mainland, while imposing harsher restrictions on capital management. "We hope local companies can develop capital risk management systems while launching investment projects across the Taiwan Strait," he added.

MOEA sources said that investment in production of 189 high-tech products, including DRAM (dynamic random access memory chips) and SRAM (static random access memory chips), will still be banned under the revised policy.

In related news, Robert H.C. Tsao, chairman of microprocessor and DRAM/SRAM business giant United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC), said he personally opposes restrictions on mainland investment because Taiwan must promote economic and industrial globalization to maintain its competitiveness.

Nevertheless, Tsao said he also disagrees with the remarks that if a Taiwan company fails to jump the bandwagon of mainland investment, it will lose its competitive edge in the global market. "The remarks are exaggerated," he opined.

Meanwhile, Tsao announced Tuesday that his company will invest over US$2 billion to build a 12-inch wafer plant in Singapore. However, he would not divulge who will be the company's partner in the joint venture, saying only that UMC will retain full control over the investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ISSUES WARNING OVER TOXIC `CHRISTMAS PLANTS'

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) warned local residents Tuesday to beware of the toxic nature of poinsettia, those festive scarlet-leaved pot plants ubiquitous in Taiwan at Christmas time.

According to a survey by a research and breeding center under the COA, there are 748 species of toxic plants in the Taiwan area, many of which are very common, including oleander, lantana, digitalis, castor-oil plant and lochnera rosea.

Because cases of mistakenly touching or eating toxic plants are fairly common, the center is to publish a series of video tapes introducing toxic botany to the public and cautioning them to be on their guard around such plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: TERRA COTTA WARRIORS AND HORSES ON DISPLAY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A group 120 terra cotta warriors and horses from the tomb city of China's first emperor, Qin Shi Huang, who died more than 2,000 years ago, are arriving in Taipei for a public exhibition scheduled to kick off Friday.

Of the 124 terra cotta warriors and horses to be displayed at the National Museum of History on Nanhai Road, 120 pieces, including 17 that are life-size, have been loaned from six museums in mainland China's northwestern province of Shaanxi, where the Qin Dynasty emperors made their capitals and ruled their vassal states.

The priceless exhibits also include two replicas of bronze chariots loaned from the National Museum of Natural Science and a private collector, in addition to two stone tablets, completing the fullest-ever introduction of Qin culture to Taiwan.
Founded in northern China with both Han people and northern tribes as its population before the 3rd century BC, the Qin Kingdom conquered its neighboring kingdoms to become a unified China in 221 BC.
King Qin Ying Zheng regarded himself as superior to the three kings and five emperors who were considered the founders of China, and appointed himself the First Emperor -- "Shi Huang."

He built the first empire in China at the age of 13 and named it the Qin Dynasty. In order to strengthen the empire, Qin carried out centralization and integrated a diverse writing system, the metrology systems and currencies.

Believing in the afterlife, Qin ordered the establishment of the "Underground Palace of Shi Huang," "Pits of Terra Cotta Warriors and Horses," "Pits of Stables," and "Pits of Bronze Chariots and Horses," as well as the surrounding architecture of his tomb.

According to mainland Chinese archaeologists, Qin ordered the planning of his tomb in the first year of his coronation. Although development and building of his tomb was carried out throughout his tenure of 37 years, the "tomb city" was not completed by the year he died at the age of 50 in 211 BC.

Shi Huang's son, who succeeded him, continued the construction of the "tomb city" and ordered imperial concubines and skilled craftsmen who made the terra cotta warriors and horses buried alive as sacrifice to the dead.

In 1976, northern China was hit by drought and a farmer accidentally discovered the "Pit of Terra Cotta Warriors and Horses" while digging a well, opening the passage to the Qin Empire of 2000 years ago.

The vivid life-sized terra cotta warriors astonished the whole world, as it had been commonly believed that the Chinese had rarely produced human sculpture. The discovery of the warriors also helped piece together the short yet disturbing era of the Qin Dynasty.
According to archaeologists and historical artifacts experts, the terra cotta warriors and horses are considered masterpieces for their sheer size, scale, refined quality, design and beauty.
The exhibition, the largest of its kind to be mounted outside mainland China, will last until March 11, according to National Museum of History officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-DPP CHAIR HEADS LAWMAKERS ASSOCIATION TO BOOST ROC-U.S. TIES

TEXT.P: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), took the helm Tuesday of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.

Shih, who renounced his DPP membership last month, succeeded Liu Sung-pan, a former Legislative Yuan speaker and now a member of the opposition People First Party (PFP) parliamentary caucus, as president of the association.

The changeover ceremony was attended by many prominent political figures, including Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh and PFP Chairman James Soong.

Visiting U.S. Senator Max Baucus (D-Mont) and several staff members of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, also attended the ceremony.
Speaking on the occasion, Lu said that despite the absence of diplomatic ties, substantive ROC-U.S. relations have grown steadily.
"Taiwan people now make 1 million visits to the United States annually, while Americans make 300,000 visits to Taiwan. Two-way trade has also increased substantially," Lu said.
In the past, she went on, U.S. congressional members have often played the "role of a lever" to prevent U.S. policy toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait from leaning too heavily toward Beijing.
Lu called on the incoming U.S. administration to further strengthen exchanges of high-level visits and expand bilateral cooperation.

The ROC-U.S. lawmakers association was founded after a trade dispute between the two countries in 1986, when ROC legislators organized a delegation to visit the United States and work out a solution to the squabbles with their American counterparts. The association was formally inaugurated in Taipei in 1988.
Shih said the association is an effective conduit for ROC-U.S. parliamentary exchanges and for the people of the two countries to share friendship and goodwill.

Noting that the ROC and the United States have a long tradition of close cooperation and have made great contributions to world peace, human rights and democracy, Shih said he will devote his full energy to the association's operations and boost further cooperation between the lawmaking bodies of the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HELP LOCAL ENTERPRISES GLOBALIZE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Tuesday that the government will help local enterprises to globalize so as to help upgrade their international competitiveness prior to the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Chang, who made the remarks when he exchanged views with textile industrialists at a symposium held at the Executive Yuan, said the moves will include the setting up of overseas sales locations and bonded warehouses abroad.

Deputy Premier Lai Ing-chaw, Secretary-General to the Executive Yuan Chiou Yi-jen, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Governor of the Central Bank of China Perng Fai-nan and Chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs Chen Chu also attended the symposium.
Chang went on to describe the textile industry as a "basic industry of livelihood." He praised the contribution to the nation's economic development made by the textile industry over the years.
He pointed out that in order to cope with WTO entry, the local textile industry must "speed up its development into a high-tech industry."
He also said that the government has already proposed development incentives for traditional industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL DENIES ENTRY OF ANIMAL MEDICINE FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Tuesday gave the green light to imports of 27 additional categories of agricultural and industrial products from mainland China, but denied the entry of 188 other items, including animal medicine.
One hundred and forty of the banned 188 items were animal medicine products, related raw materials and additives for animal feed, BOFT officials said.

Of the 27 categories that were approved to be imported were powdered pumpkin -- the only agricultural product approved in the latest round of government approval on this concern -- and lacquer-free earthenware, cast-iron nuts and bolts, ceramic capacitors, ball-point pens, colored pens, auto pencils, and other industrial products.

BOFT Deputy Director-General Wei Ke-ming said Taiwan's screening system for mainland product imports will be retained even after the country is admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), hopefully early next year.
Currently, the government has no plans to have the screening system repealed at the present juncture of WTO accession, Wei noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PATIENT RECEIVES NEW HEART 4 YEARS AFTER LIVER TRANSPLANT

TEXT.P: Chen Ching-ling, a carrier of hepatitis-B, has become Taiwan's first patient to receive liver transplant four years after undergoing an operation to replace her heart with that of another donor.

Dr. Cheng Lung-ping of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital said that Chen had a heart transplant operation four years ago after she gave birth. A month ago, she contracted acute hepatitis, which necessitated the liver transplant.

Dr. Cheng said that Chen had ingested anti-resistance medicine to retard her immune system after her heart transplant, which was necessary to enable her body to accept the new heart. Unfortunately, the same drugs allowed the hepatitis virus already existing in her body to revive, the doctor added.
Cheng quoted statistics showing that four to five out of every 500 kidney-transplant patients are later killed by acute hepatitis.

He said that Chen's case was a rare case in the medical world, because the patient received both a heart and liver transplant operation over a period of four years, and with organs from different donors.

DOC.HEADLINE: EU TO ESTABLISH TAIPEI OFFICE AFTER ROC'S WTO ACCESSION

TEXT.P: The European Union (EU) will establish a liaison office in Taiwan soon after the island is admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the head of the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT) said Tuesday.

Paul Scholten, chairman of the Taipei-based grouping of European businessmen said that pushing for the establishment of a EU liaison office in Taiwan to help bolster bilateral business and trade relations between Europe and Taiwan has been one of the major goals of the council over the past few years.

An ECCT delegation visited the European Commission, the Executive body of the 15-member European Union, in Brussels Nov. 28-29, marking the sixth such visit in six consecutive years, to promote bilateral ties between Taiwan and Europe, Scholten said.

Scholten said the delegation expressed strongly the will of the ECCT to the European Parliament and the European Commission that the EU should establish a liaison office in Taiwan "at the earliest possible date" to help strengthen ties.
The ECCT members also asked the EU to support Taiwan's admission into the WTO and the World Health Organization, he went on.

Scholten added that as far as he knows, the European Parliament has already asked the European Commission to accelerate exchanges with Taiwan so as to facilitate the resumption of dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO RECLASSIFY ITEMS BANNED FROM MANUFACTURE IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is mulling whether to allow six new categories of Taiwan products to be manufactured in mainland China by local companies.
Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi made the remark as part of MOEA plans to review its existing classification for Taiwan products that are subject to screening for manufacture in mainland China.

The MOEA plans to reclassify the six items, none of which are currently permitted to be manufactured in the mainland by local companies, into categories subject to screening on a case-by-case basis. The six items are semiconductors, wireless telecommunication products, high-performance personal computers, digital consumer electronic products, LCD upstream products and plasma displays.
However, Lin continued, there will still remain 189 banned items, including SRAM and DRAM chips, CPUs and TEL-LCDs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOCK `WORLD COURT' CONVICTS LATE JAPANESE EMPEROR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: A mock "world court" known as "The 2000 Tokyo Grand Jury Trial" of Japan's former imperial leadership Tuesday convicted Japan's late Emperor Hirohito.

The court also said the government of Japan should bear the responsibility of apologizing and compensating the women forced into sexual slavery by the Imperial Army during and before the Second World War.
The court was officiated over by four internationally renowned judges led by Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, former president of the court that tried former Yugoslavia war criminals.

The judges read their decision before a group of 80 former "comfort women" from eight countries in the Asia and Pacific region and more than 1,000 mass media representatives and civic organization representatives who supported former comfort women in condemning the barbaric practices of the former Japanese army.

The verdicts read in part as follows: "After a three-day trial, the Japanese late Emperor Hirohito is found guilty for his failure to stop the former Japanese Imperial Army's sexual slavery system and violation of humanity."

The judges went on that the evidence indicates that Hirohito was not a puppet but the nation's highest administrative decision maker. Hirohito must have been in a position to know about the Japanese Imperial Army's cold-blooded behavior during the rape of Nanjing in 1937. Hirohito not only failed to stop the Japanese cruelty but also agreed to set up "comfort stations" -- euphemisms for army brothels in which more than 200,000 women were enslaved and raped repeatedly.
The judges cited testimonies of several former comfort women, including that of Kao Bao-chu and Lu Man-mei of Taiwan, to prove the cruel behavior the Japanese.

The judges also criticized the Japanese government's move to use a civic foundation to pay reparation, to avoid admitting official responsibility. The judges also dismissed Japan's assertion that post-war treaties signed by Japan made it unnecessary to pay individual compensation.
The judges called on the Japanese government to assume its responsibility and apologize to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN BANKS TO BE ALLOWED TO MERGE WITH LOCAL COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Foreign banks will be allowed to merge completely with local banks after the scheduled enactment of the Banking Law early next year, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Tuesday.

Yen made the remarks while meeting with the heads of the local branches of foreign banks, including Citibank, N.A., ABN AMRO Bank, The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, and Banque National de Paris, as well as chiefs of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and the European Council of Commerce and Trade (ECCT).

Yen said that the proposed Banking Law will give foreign-invested banks national treatment by allowing them to merge 100 percent with local banks, turning the local banks into branches of the foreign banks that own them.

ECCT Chairman Paul Scholten, who is also president of the Taipei branch of ABN AMRO bank, pointed out that Taiwan will see large-scale banks which might have a local market share of between 15 percent to 20 percent after mergers are allowed.
He also said that the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization on local banks will be minimal, since they already experience stiff competition.
