DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 4.27 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 4.27 points to close at 5,384.36.
Market turnover amounted to NT$45.73 billion (US$1.39 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 13, or the 18th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France, and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the United Nations Security Council, China vetoes admission of Outer Mongolia to the U.N.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1976: Gen. Lee Hon Kon, the South Korean council chairman of the APACL, arrives in Taiwan for an executive board meeting.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 4.27 points to close at 5,384.36.
Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,380.34 and fluctuated between 5,397.29 and 5,332.52 during trading.

A total of 1.71 billion shares worth NT$45.73 billion (US$1.39 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.08 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$67.31 billion (US$2.04 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories posted losses, with electrical stocks edging down 0.4 percent. Foodstuff shares meanwhile remained unchanged.

The other major categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 341 to 172, with 91 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved up 40 points to close at 5,430, with 6,673 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 increased 21 points to finish at 5,426, with 310 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures gained 34 points to close at 5,429, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,390 for December, 5,405 for next January, 5,395 for next March, 5,365 for next June, and 5,809 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were generally higher.
December TE futures moved up 1.3 points to close at 268.5, with 1,684 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures increased 2 points to finish at 268, with 81 contract transactions.
June 2001 TE futures edged up 0.1 points to close at 265.1, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures rose 5 points to finish at 700, with 1,389 contracts changing hands, while January 2001 TF futures lost 1 point to close at 696, with 57 contract transactions.
March 2001 TF futures fell 13.6 points to finish at 695.2, with only one contract traded. No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT TO BE HONORED BY JAPANESE UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Japan's Takushoku University President Shiro Odamura will travel to Taiwan Friday to bestow an honorary doctoral degree on former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, a Taiwan Research Institute official said Wednesday.

Su Chi-cheng, the vice president of the institute, said that the university will honor Lee for his contributions to the democratic development of Taiwan and to the promotion of relations between the ROC and Japan.
Lee, who stepped down as president this May after leading the nation for the past 12 years, currently serves as the honorable chairman of the Taiwan Research Institute.

Su said that Takushoku University bestows honorary doctoral degrees each year on world figures renowned in their special fields and that the awarding ceremonies usually take place at the end of the year.
Odamura will bestow the honorary doctoral degree on Lee at the Taiwan Research Institute where Taiwan alumni of the Japanese university in Tokyo will gather to witness the ceremony Friday.
Former first lady Tseng Wen-hui will also be present at the ceremony to share the honor with her husband.
Odamura, who has visited Taiwan in the past, has had close relations with the former president.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND AWARE OF MAINLAND CHINA'S ICBM TESTING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Wednesday it has been fully aware of mainland China's military activities.
The ministry was responding to a U.S. Pentagon report that mainland China tested a new mobile intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) in early November.

The ministry would not make any comment on the report, but said instead that mainland China's military activities, including troop movements and missile testing, have consistently been under the MND's close monitoring.

Unless mainland China's military activities are targeted at Taiwan or its armed forces undergo abnormal deployment, the MND said, it usually does not take the initiative to divulge details of mainland military operations to avoid endangering its intelligence sources.

According to the Pentagon report, mainland China test-fired its Dongfeng-31 missile over its territory on Nov. 4 when Gen. Henry Shelton, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, was visiting the mainland as part of an effort to improve bilateral military relations.

It was the third flight test of the new missile since August 1999, the Pentagon report said, adding that two of the tests took place this year. U.S. intelligence sources said that mainland China's latest DF-31 missile test incorporated U.S. nuclear design information allegedly obtained through espionage.
U.S. Defense Department spokesman Kenneth Bacon said the DF-31 missile has a range of 8,000 kilometers, but the missile fired in the latest testing didn't reach its maximum range.

Bacon said mainland China began to develop the DF-31 missile in the late 1980s. According to Bacon, the United States has consistently paid close attention to mainland China's weaponry development. He said mainland China's long-range ballistic missile development plan cannot compete with similar projects in the United States, Russia, Britain and France in terms of scale.
Bacon didn't answer whether the DF-31 missile tested in the November firing carried multi-warheads.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU VISITS RESTING PLACES OF CHIANGS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu paid her respects to the late Republic of China presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo Wednesday by visiting their temporary mausoleums located in the northern county of Taoyuan.

Lu's unexpected visit to the mausoleum of the Generalissimo located in Tzuhu and to the temporary resting place of the late Chiang Ching-kuo in Touliao, only a few kilometers away, makes her the highest-ranking official from the new government to visit the two places, considered sacred sites by followers of the Kuomintang, which lost power to the Democratic Progressive Party in this March's presidential election.

The vice president's visit to Tzuhu and Touliao also took the staff members of the two establishments by surprise because she never visited the two sites during her tenure as county head of Taoyuan. Lu was Taoyuan County's magistrate before being elected the vice president of the Republic of China this year.

According to Lu's spokeswoman Tsai Ming-hua, the main purpose of her visit to the two mausoleum establishments in Taoyuan County was to probe the areas' tourism potential as the government is planning to open Taiwan's doors to mainland Chinese tourists beginning next June.

Tzuhu is the third most popular choice in Taiwan in terms of locations that mainland Chinese tourists would like to visit most, after only Mt. Ali in southern Taiwan and Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan, according to a recent survey compiled by related agencies in Beijing.

Lu suggested that mainland Chinese tourists who visit Taiwan could enter via Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan and exit the island from Hsiaokang International Airport in the southern city of Kaohsiung, or vice versa, thereby directly helping gear up tourism development in the northern county of Taoyuan.

Later in the day, Lu attended a seminar hosted by the Taoyuan County government's Tourism Bureau on the topic of how Taoyuan can grasp the opportunities to be created by the opening of Taiwan to tourists from mainland China.

Quoting a recent report which said that presently some 8 million mainland Chinese citizens go abroad annually for tourism and that some 28 million mainlanders would make Taiwan their top choice if given the opportunity to visit abroad, Lu said the tourism potential is immense when one considers that the second number is actually greater than Taiwan's entire population of 23 million.

During the seminar, Lu urged members of Taoyuan's tourism industry, including travel agents and restaurant and hotel owners, to establish a tourism promotion committee so as to grab the golden business opportunities to be brought on by the government's policy of opening Taiwan to mainland tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST MISSING CHILDREN CASES ARE RUNAWAYS

TEXT.P: Most of the reported cases of missing children in recent years are the result of children running away from home rather than because of their being abducted as was the case in the past, a children's right group announced Wednesday.
The Child Welfare Legal Foundation made the remarks when announcing a report on the missing children situation in Taiwan this year.

Foundation official Chen Chu-yeh said that among all the youngsters who went missing between September 1992 and October 2000, those aged between 12 and 18 accounted for the largest percentage, with females outnumbering males. He added that most of the missing children did not suffer from any sort of mental disabilities.
In terms of the reported missing locations, Chen said that most children who went missing did so from home or nearby locations, accounting for 60 percent of the total.
In terms of the ways of missing children who were found, a quarter of the total were found due to a tip off or because the children voluntarily returned home.

He Hsiung-hua, who found his grandson through the assistance of the foundation, also took part in the reunion party sponsored by the foundation. He said that he lost six kilograms during the four months when his grandson was missing.

A father surnamed Chang, who said that his daughter Chang Ching-ya has been missing for two years, and a Mrs. Chen, whose daughter Chen Yi-tien has been missing for 12 years, said that they still harbor the hope that their children will return to the family fold someday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was up NT$0.007 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 33.081.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 33.030 and was traded between 32.990 and 33.130.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$535.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA GROUP PROMOTING EXPORT TRADE IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan trade promotion group visiting Australia has reaped an enviable harvest over the past two days, receiving orders that could reach US$10 million, sources from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Wednesday.

The CETRA trade promotion group, comprised of officials from the Board of Foreign Trade and representatives from trade associations and some 40 local export-oriented companies, met businessmen in Sydney and Brisbane in separate workshops.

In the Sydney workshop, the Taiwan group attracted executives and representatives from some 240 Australian companies, resulting in US$120,000-worth of orders placed on the spot, with follow-up business opportunities expected to reach US$6 million in the coming year, CETRA officials said.

In Brisbane, the Taiwan group met delegates from 203 Australian companies and received on-the-spot orders worth US$700,000, with follow-up business estimated to reach US$3.4 million in the year to come.

The CETRA officials said the Taiwan trade promotion group was organized in an attempt to redress the trade imbalance between Taiwan and Australia, with Taiwan suffering a deficit of some US$1.2 billion last year.

Taiwan companies represented in the group include those producing stationery, gifts, sporting goods, hardware, machinery, houseware, gloves, socks, medical equipment, auto parts, computers and telecommunications products.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Australia reached US$4.8 billion in 1999, with Taiwan importing US$3 billion-worth of products from Australia while exporting US$1.8 billion-worth of commodities down under, leaving the island with a deficit of US$1.2 billion, according to CETRA tallies.

Taiwan and Australia have been complementary trade partners over the years, with Taiwan exporting mainly industrial products to Australia and Australia delivering mainly agricultural and industrial raw materials, CETRA officials said.
Between 1991 and 1998, bilateral trade grew 10.25 percent, with Australia's exports to Taiwan surging 11.8 percent and Taiwan's exports to Australia soaring 8.3 percent.
After wrapping up their Australia trip, the CETRA group will proceed to New Zealand to continue with its promotion of Taiwan exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET STANDS BY ITS STANCE ON PAY RAISES FOR CIVIL SERVANTS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reaffirmed Wednesday that the Executive Yuan supports a pay raise for the nation's civil servants.

Chang made the remarks after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus in the Legislative Yuan proposed that a 3 percent pay raise for government employees, military personnel and teachers be suspended for a year in view of "the difficult financial situation."
Chang said that the Cabinet under his predecessor Tang Fei had already begun to plan for the pay raise and that the proposal had been carefully reviewed by the Legislative Yuan.
Hsu Tien-tsai, DPP party whip in the Legislative Yuan, denied Wednesday that the proposed suspension was aimed at "sounding out the reaction" of the public.
Hsu stressed that there is no political consideration in proposing the suspended pay raise, saying that the DPP caucus did not notify the executive branch.
In view of the dire domestic financial situation, he said, the proposal to ax the budget of NT$21 billion earmarked for the pay raise would go ahead Monday as scheduled.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said that there are advantages and disadvantages of the pay raise, but as the government has made the raise its set policy, it is "odd" that the DPP legislative caucus would have a different opinion.
The main opposition Kuomintang blasted the DPP caucus for attempting to suspend the pay raise, saying that it shows that the DPP government's right hand does not know what its left is doing.
Vice KMT Chairman Vincent Siew, presiding over a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday, did not say clearly whether or not his party supports or opposes the DPP's idea.

But he demanded that the DPP government adopt a clear and consistent stance on various issues, saying that the ruling party has been "rash in its policy making and has wavered along the way," on various issues, resulting in loss of public confidence in the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK INKS TIES WITH SPANISH COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park entered into sisterhood relations Wednesday with Spain's Andalucia Technology Park.

Huang Wen-hsiung, director of the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park Administration, and Felipe Romero, director of the Andalucia Technology Park, inked the memorandum on cooperation on behalf of their respective parties.

Under the terms of the agreement, the two parties will strengthen the interchange of information and personnel. The information interchange will include high-tech industrial technology exchanges and will further promote the interchange of high-tech companies' personnel between the two parks.
The two parks will also exchange information on semiconductors, computers and related equipment, telecommunications, precision machinery and biotechnology.

Romero, visiting at the head of a 20-member delegation, said that Andalucia, which is located in the southern part of the country between the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea, is the biggest autonomous area in Spain with a population of seven million.
The Andalucia park becomes the tenth foreign industrial park to have entered into sisterhood ties with the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP PITCHES FOR UNION OF ASIAN STATES

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu pitched Wednesday for the formation of a union of Asian states to ensure regional prosperity and peace.

Lu made the appeal in a speech delivered at the opening of the 2000 Asia-Europe Cooperation Forum, which brought together scores of local and foreign scholars and experts to discuss regional security issues and Asia-Pacific cooperation.
Lu said she looks forward to seeing Asian states learn from the 15-member European Union and make issues of national and territorial sovereignty secondary to achieving regional prosperity and peace.
The vice president then reiterated her idea of forming a "union of Asian states," which she said could serve to integrate the region and give Asian nations a more effective role in world affairs.
"It would also increase economic efficiency, enhance social openness and promote peace in the region," Lu explained.

Noting that the 21st century will dawn in just 19 days, Lu said this is a moment for mankind to reflect on both the remarkable achievements that have allowed humanity to enjoy unparalleled progress and prosperity, and those appalling human errors that have inflicted needless pain and loss on so many over the past century.

Lu said that while the 20th century has been plagued by violence, war, poverty, human rights abuses and gender inequality, at a heavy cost to human dignity, equality, justice and peace, it has also had many encouraging developments of common humanity and values.
"The wave of democratization, the end of the Cold War and the development of information technology have all contributed tremendously to the advent of a global society," Lu said.

She went on to predict that the world in the 21st century will be an "open globe," where resource-sharing and cooperation are stressed. "Thus, the United Nations, a half-century-old world body, should catch up to this new reality," she said.
For one thing, Lu said, the United Nations should stop practicing the "politics of exclusion and discrimination" and should instead embrace the "politics of inclusion, diversity, peace and love."

Stressing that Taiwan is an open society and a true democracy, although it is recognized by only 29 out of 189 U.N. member states, Lu said: "In the new century's `open world,' it is absolutely absurd for the United Nations to remain deaf and blind to Taiwan's existence."
Lu recalled that former South African President Nelson Mandela once said: "You don't make peace by talking to your friends, you have to make peace with your enemies."
"But it is surely just as important to maintain peace with your friends and neighbors. I think the ultimate aim of the current forum is both to make peace and maintain it," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCUMENTARY ON TAIWAN BIRDS NOMINATED AT NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: A documentary on Taiwan's wild birds has made the short list for a nature and wildlife award in the New York Festival 2000.
The film, titled "Feathered Glory: Wild Birds on Taiwan," was chosen from among more than 3,000 entries to make the short list. The film follows the lives of more than 40 wild birds in Taiwan.
Chung Jung-feng, the maker of the film, said the work is the culmination of his 13-year career as a wildlife cameraman and took him more than a year to shoot and edit.
Perhaps most noticeable among the 40-odds birds featured in the work are the migratory gray-faced vultures, black-faced spoonbills and terns.

With an area of 36,000 square kilometers, Taiwan is home to about 500 species of birds, giving the island the distinction of being the world's second-densest bird habitat in terms of species per square kilometer, according to Chung.
The New York Festival, set up in 1957, has this year attracted 3,732 entries from 38 countries. The winners will be announced Jan. 19, 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES DRAFT RULES FOR TRANSPORT LINKS WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved Wednesday a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
According to government spokesman Su Cheng-ping, only an outline of the rules is provided at this time because the Legislative Yuan has yet to evaluate and vote on the draft.

The actual rules will be divided into 36 guidelines on the application procedures for ships wishing to travel between the two areas, the designated routes, vessel identification and communication, and port authority affairs, according to a Cabinet press release.

Entry and departure application procedures, permissible intent, duration of stay, trading methods, commodity imports and exports, quarantine inspections and port safety restrictions are also addressed by the rules, the release notes.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Teng Chen-chung revealed at a press conference later in the day that all ships entering or leaving the outlying islands will need to submit applications for either regularly or irregularly scheduled routes.

Teng said that those on the islands who wish to travel directly to mainland China must show that they have already resided on the islands for a certain period of time. He added that all business transactions must be carried out in new Taiwan dollars.

Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said at a Cabinet meeting where he approved the implementation measures that the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal, and transport links between the two outlying islands and designated ports in mainland China -- are a major national policy.
He went on to say that the links are also a major measure involving "a big step forward" that will allow the nation to attain stable and harmonious cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
This measure must be implemented under "sound principles," he said, adding that "it must not fail."

Chang said that the issues eliciting the most concern during the implementation of the "mini three links" will be national security and public security in Kinmen and Matsu, which lie much closer to mainland China than Taiwan. The shortest distance from the main Kinmen island to communist-held territory is only 2.3 kilometers.

With only around 200 police officers on Kinmen and Matsu combined, he added, the Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior, and the Coast Guard Administration will "spare no effort" to assist in maintaining the islands' security.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT ON LATEST CENSUS OF TAIWAN AREA TO BE PUBLISHED IN JUNE 2001

TEXT.P: A written report on the latest census of Taiwan and the offshore islands under its control is scheduled to be published in June next year, the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) announced Wednesday.

The DGBAS has began conducting the census in mid-December. Subject to the census are Taipei and Kaohsiung, the special municipalities under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan; the 23 counties and cities under the Taiwan Provincial Government, including the offshore islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.
Data collected through the census will be provided to the government for reference in carrying out administrative affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER: GOVERNMENT NEEDS MORE TIME TO RESOLVE ECONOMIC PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Wednesday that the new government, which was inaugurated in May this year, needs more time to resolve Taiwan's economic problems.
He made the remarks while answering questions raised by members of the Legislative Yuan's Economic Affairs and Energy Committee.

Huang Yi-chiao, a People First Party lawmaker, asked Lin to comment on Formosa Group founder Wang Yung-ching's statement that "the new government is inferior to the old government, and the new generation of the Democratic Progressive Party is inferior to the old generation of the party."
Lin acknowledged that he was not sure whether Wang had made such a statement, but pointed out that the new government had inherited everything from the old government without any complaint.
He stressed that the new government should be given more time to resolve the nation's pressing economic problems.
Wang has been urging the new government to start full-scale direct postal, trade and transport links with mainland China and relax the "go slow, be patient" policy.
Lee Ching-hsiung of the Taiwan Independence Party asked Lin about his view on United Microelectronics Corp.'s plan to invest US$2.5-3 billion in a semiconductor wafer fabrication plant in Singapore.
Lin said that UMC has its own global strategy, and noted that Singapore provides tax incentives for foreign investors.
Lee said that the Taiwan government should work to improve its investment environment so as to keep domestic enterprises from moving elsewhere.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOE MISSION TO VISIT MAINLAND IN PREPARATION FOR ACCREDITATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will organize a delegation to conduct a fact-finding visit to mainland China in preparation for recognizing its academic qualifications, Education Minister Ovid Tzeng said Wednesday.
Tzeng said as recognizing mainland China's academic accreditation involves many complicated problems, the MOE has decided to form a special task force to carefully study all relevant issues.

Tzeng said Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-lin will head the new study team to be composed of scholars, experts and educators. In the past, the MOE once proposed a list of 73 mainland colleges and universities whose academic accreditation might be recognized by the Republic of China government.

The list was later shelved due to opposition from some social quarters. With the number of Taiwan students traveling to the mainland to receive college education increasing rapidly in recent years, the appeal for the government to recognize mainland academic accreditation has risen loudly again.
Against this background, Tzeng said the MOE is seriously mulling the accreditation issue.
Initially, Tzeng said, the new MOE task force will review the current situations of the 73 mainland colleges or universities included in the previous list.

Tzeng said many mainland colleges and universities have been undergoing merger in recent years. "The task force will look into how these schools have been merged or re-organized as well as their curricula, teaching facilities and student performance evaluation systems," he explained.
The minister stressed that the MOE will play a leading role in deciding which mainland school's academic accreditation will be recognized.

As for the timing of recognition, Tzeng said the MOE will discuss with the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, and the National Security Council before deciding when to begin recognizing mainland China's academic qualifications.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND LEADER CALLS FOR INCREASED DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Mainland China's leading liberal voice, Li Rui-huan, has set off fresh speculation about high-level factional disputes in Beijing over the pace and direction of political reform with a bold appeal for more popular democracy, according to the December 21 issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review.

An advance copy of the report reveals that Li, speaking at the end of a three-day conference with non-communist political groups in Beijing on December 6, said that economic reform has created a diversity of interests in the mainland.
"It is very hard for a single measure that is promulgated to benefit everybody equally, as there are invariably those who are for it and those who are against it," he was quoted as saying.
"Such a complex and changeable state of society is bound to have a profound impact on the social foundation of our regime."

The solution, he reportedly said, was for the ruling Chinese Communist Party (CCP) to "open up and unclog the democratic channels through which the masses from all walks of life can express their views."
That meant the need to "expand the citizens' orderly participation in political affairs," he was further quoted as saying.

According to the Review, Li's remarks contrasted sharply with the hardline comments of CCP chief Jiang Zemin, who reportedly said at the conference's opening session that the growing social diversity calls for officials to actively "defuse friction and straighten out people's feelings" in order to maintain social stability and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATOR SUGGESTS TRIAL VOYAGE BETWEEN KINMEN, MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Chen Ching-pao said Wednesday that a trial voyage between Kinmen and mainland China should be undertaken before the "mini three links" are officially established in order to avoid cold treatment by mainland China.

Chen pointed out that Taipei and Beijing have yet to begin negotiations on the issue of opening direct trade, postal, and transport links between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China, raising concerns that a maiden voyage scheduled for Jan. 1, 2001 may encounter difficult political waters.

He added that the problem is especially evident after Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen said that until bilateral negotiations are held, mainland ships will not be allowed to enter Kinmen or Matsu, and that mainland Chinese residents will only be allowed to travel to the islands on Taiwan-registered vessels.
Chen, who represents the Kinmen constituency, said that the "mini three links" should be a new beginning in the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and not a point of resurgent conflict.

The trial voyage could take place between Dec. 25 and Dec. 27, he said, adding that Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen has told him that she agrees with the concept in principle, but that coming up with a concrete course of action will require further discussion.
Meanwhile, KMT legislator Chang Chin-fang urged Taipei and Beijing to return to the negotiating table to work out the many concrete measures needed for the establishment of the "mini three links."

However, Chen and Chang recommended that before bilateral negotiations resume, the government should concentrate on ironing out issues of entry into and departure from Kinmen and Matsu, as well as restrictions, possible social problems and tariffs.

They suggested that mainland Chinese residents who wish to enter Kinmen or Matsu be made to apply for entry through Taiwan travel agencies or through their relatives in Taiwan. They added that visitors should be required to hold round-trip tickets to ensure their compliance with the limitations on their duration of stay, with violators of such limitations subject to forced repatriation.

They urged the government to remove the restriction in its draft of the implementation rules that limits visitation rights to residents of mainland China's Fujian province. Chen and Chang said that removing the restriction would bring about more trade and tourism, and that enforcing the original rule would add to the difficulties by crossing into mainland China's jurisdiction.

Regarding possible social problems that may surface after the "mini three links" are established, they suggested that the police force on the offshore islands be increased, and that the activities and movements of the mainland visitors be carefully monitored to prevent any illegal activities.

They also urged the government to establish a tariff-free zone in Kinmen and Matsu, allow the islands to use raw materials from mainland China to develop their industries, and improve the tourism and service industries on the islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: DHL TAIWAN COMPLETES TWO MORE LARGE-SCALE SERVICE CENTERS

TEXT.P: Lu Li-hsing, president of DHL Taiwan Corp., said Wednesday that his company has recently completed two more large-scale service centers which will speed up its island-wide transport of commodities.
Under the NT$1 billion investment plan, five large-scale service centers have been in operation since early this year, Lu noted.

This indicates that DHL Taiwan will not change its plan to extend its roots in Taiwan, said Lu, although the firm's air cargo and express section has complained about discriminatory treatment by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
A DHL Taiwan official in charge of the air cargo and express section claimed that the MOTC has been providing better treatment to two U.S. firms -- FedEx and UPS.

Owing to the discriminatory treatment, he said, DHL Taiwan will give up its plan to establish a trans-shipping operations center in Taiwan, and will consider setting up the center in Hong Kong -- a move that will cost Taiwan some 500 jobs and tens of millions of U.S. dollars in investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WAFER FOUNDRY MANUFACTURING AHEAD OF MAINLAND: TSMC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan has the edge over mainland China in wafer foundry manufacturing, according to Morris Chang, founder of the world's largest semiconductor foundry manufacturer, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC).

The scale of the wafer foundry industry in mainland China pales in comparison with that of Taiwan, which enjoys an advantage over mainland China because of its abundant manpower resources, Chang said.

Chang said that he had traveled to mainland China only to attend an international bridge tournament. He said that although mainland China has greatly improved its level of technology in recent years by offering attractive incentives to woo Chinese experts from Silicon Valley, he is optimistic about Taiwan's investment environment.

Chang said that instead of venturing into mainland China as many Taiwan firms have, TSMC will concentrate its expansion on southern Taiwan's Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, at least for the next three or four years.

He said he wouldn't rule out meeting with Beijing officials during his stay, if asked by them. However, he stressed that his main reason for traveling to Beijing was to attend the bridge game, and given the tight schedule at the tournament, any such meeting could only take place over breakfast.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CENTRAL AMERICAN ALLIES VOW TO STRENGTHEN TIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and its Central American allies pledged to strengthen cooperation in various fields at the end of a meeting of the Mixed Commission on Cooperation between the ROC and Central American Countries Wednesday.

A joint communique issued at the conclusion of the one-day conference said foreign ministers of member countries of the Mixed Commission have agreed to expand cooperation in political, economic, trade, investment, agricultural, fishery, educational, cultural, health, sports, technological, human rights, environmental and other related fields.

Foreign ministers from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and the host Republic of China as well as representatives of foreign ministers of Costa Rica, Panama and Belize attended the ninth meeting of the Mixed Commission. The Dominican Republic also sent its vice foreign minister to attend the conference as an observer.
The communique said all the participants have exchanged views on matters of mutual concern, particularly international cooperation and development-related issues, in an amicable atmosphere.

"All the participating foreign ministers or representatives recognize the importance of various cooperative programs reached in the meeting and promise to fully implement all of them," the communique said, adding that the participants also agree to jointly promote transformation and modernization of Central American countries.

During the meeting, ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao lauded the ROC's Central American allies for their achievements in promoting regional integration, democratization, economic growth and sustainable development.

Tien also expressed the ROC's gratitude for its Central American allies' staunch support for its bid to join international organizations. Tien further reaffirmed the ROC's commitment to helping promote Central American regional integration.
Meanwhile, Central American delegates thanked the ROC for its financial assistance to their economic development, particularly the development of their small and medium-sized enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES BETWEEN ROC AND CENTRAL AMERICA TO BE FURTHER CEMENTED: ROC FM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Wednesday that the recent Ninth Meeting of Foreign Ministers of the Republic of China and Central America has further strengthened economic and political cooperation between the ROC and its diplomatic allies in Central America.
Tien said that the participants reached a high-level of consensus on political and economic issues, as well as small- and medium-sized enterprises and human rights.
Guatemalan Foreign Minister Gabriel Orellana, who presided over this year's meeting, reaffirmed that the Central American nations' friendly relations with the ROC will remain unchanged.
ROC Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao at first extended a warm welcome to Panamanian Vice Foreign Minister Harmodio Arias, who took part in the meeting after a three-year interruption.
Tien stressed that the ROC attaches a great deal of importance to friendly relations with the Central American countries, and added that the annual meeting has strengthened those relations.

Touching on the outcome of the meeting, Tien said that all the attendants expressed their satisfaction with all the cooperative projects between the ROC and Central American countries during the past year. The projects were related to politics, economics, trade, investment, livestock, small- and medium-sized enterprises, education, culture, technology and environmental protection cooperation.

Speaking on educational cooperation, Tien said that the ROC will offer more scholarships for Central American students and will increase the number of student exchanges that it sponsors so as to help its Central American allies' development.

On the ROC's trade surplus with its allies in the region, Guatemalan Foreign Minister Orellana said that the Central American countries will narrow their trade deficit with the ROC by expanding the scope of mutual cooperation.
The participants will be received by ROC President Chen Shui-bian Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRANSPORTERS CRAVING DIRECT CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT TRAFFIC (I)

TEXT.P: Aiming at the huge profits to be gained by the establishment of direct transport ties across the Taiwan Strait, local aviation firms have been gearing up to set up strongholds in mainland China, according to industry sources.

Although the government is planning to first open the so-called direct "mini three links" between Taiwan-controlled Kinmen and Matsu islands and certain mainland Chinese ports, the sources said Taiwan-based airlines are keenly engaged in preparations for the full opening of direct transport links between the two sides by setting up representative offices in the mainland.

As direct cross-strait traffic will noticeably reduce operation costs and travel time for Taiwan-based carriers such as China Airlines (CAL), EVA Airways Corp. (EVA AIR), and Far East Air Transport Corp. (FEAT), share prices of all rose by about 10 percent late November on the Taiwan stock market.

According to a FEAT executive, the aviation company, which only operates domestic routes at present, has decided to increase its daily flights between Taipei and Kinmen from four to five, amid the expectation that the implementation of the "mini three links" will also significantly boost cargo and passenger traffic volume between the offshore islands and Taiwan proper.

The FEAT executive said that his company has already readied itself for full direct links between Taiwan and the mainland and added that its current fleet of Boeing 757 airplanes used on domestic flight routes is also suitable to fly cross-strait routes.

The much-anticipated opening of full transport links between the two sides of the strait are expected to generate at least NT$30-NT$40 billion-worth of business opportunities, providing a major fillip for local carriers, he added.

Lagging behind only CAL, FEAT is the second Taiwan-based aviation company to have obtained approval from mainland China's civil aeronautics authorities for repair and maintenance of mainland Chinese airplanes, and has already opened an office in the mainland.

In a recent meeting of shareholders, FEAT, which has long been preparing to make inroads into the mainland, also made a decision to invest NT$35 million (US$1.1 million) in the mainland's air cargo and passenger transport industry and related businesses, in the hope of gaining an upper hand in the lucrative market.

Although the implementation of the "mini three links" slated for the beginning of next year will be of limited help to CAL and EVA Air, both of which ply mainly international routes, industry experts said the Taiwan's two largest carriers will benefit from the full direct transport ties across the Taiwan Strait.
Both CAL and EVA Air maintain representative offices in mainland China. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRANSPORTERS CRAVING DIRECT CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT TRAFFIC (II)

TEXT.P: According to industry sources, the first freedom, which Taiwan-based aviation firms will enjoy after the opening of direct cross-strait airlinks, will markedly help reduce fuel costs and flying time for local carriers on their routes to European destinations.

In addition, the granting of the third, fourth and fifth freedoms will allow local carriers to fly directly to their destinations in the mainland without having to pass through Hong Kong, helping realize a reduction in operation costs of 75 percent and 62.5 percent for the Taipei-Fuzhou and Taipei-Xiamen routes, respectively, and a 40 percent slash for the Taipei-Beijing route.

At the same time, the local shipping industry is also strongly urging the government to ease its current "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy by allowing direct full transport ties between the two sides.

Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan) Ltd., which operates the world's largest container fleet, has repeatedly called on the government to permit full transport links between Taiwan and the mainland, rather than just setting up partial relations between certain ports across the strait.

According to industry sources, local shipping companies all harbor similar hopes, which it is believed will enable them to work out more adequate and efficient shipping schedules, substantially reducing transshipment costs and allowing them to chalk up greater profits.

At present, Hong Kong is the transshipment center for exports from and imports to mainland China's central and southern provinces, while South Korea is the hub for outbound shipments from and inbound shipments to the mainland's central and northern regions. Japan, Europe, the United States and Southeast Asian countries are the leading outlets for mainland Chinese products, the sources noted.
The mainland's shipping market, which deals with at least 10 million TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units) annually, is growing at a double-digit rate each year, the sources added.

Taking as an example Yangming Marine Transport Corp., which has set up eight offices in the mainland in the last seven years, it is only able to handle 250,000-300,000 TEUs annually, accounting for just 0.25 percent or 0.3 percent of the total, the sources said.

Given the fact that Taiwan businessmen in the mainland generate most business opportunities for Taiwan-headquartered shipping companies there, a Yangming executive was cited as saying that his company will head for wherever there are Taiwan businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES EXTENSION OF ROC-GUATEMALA COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Cabinet approved a five-year extension of the Republic of China-Guatemala Agricultural Technical Cooperation Agreement at its weekly meeting Wednesday, with the aim of strengthening friendship and agricultural cooperation between the two countries.
A Ministry of Foreign Affairs official noted that the agreement was first signed between the two countries in 1985. The pact expired on Nov. 14, 2000, having already been extended twice in the past.

The Guatemalan side had affirmed that the ROC technical mission stationed in Guatemala has effectively promoted the Central American nation's economic and agricultural development over the past year. Guatemala also expressed the hope that the agreement would be extended an additional five years.
ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Wu Jen-hsiu and Guatemalan Vice Foreign Minister A. Carlos had exchanged notes on the extention on Nov. 15 in Guatemala City, on behalf of their respective governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OKs TWO-YEAR EXTENTION OF ROC-PANAMA FISHERY PACT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a two-year extention of the Republic of China-Panama Fishery Cooperation Agreement at its weekly meeting Wednesday.
A spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said that the extention was granted at the request of the Panamanian government.
The ROC agreed to extend the agreement for another two years, meaning that it will expire on Aug. 25, 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS US$ 1.4 BILLION TRADE SURPLUS IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports in November totaled US$13.892 billion, up 17.8 percent on those of October, announced the Foreign Exchange Department of the Central Bank of China (CBC) Wednesday.
Imports during November rose 17.7 percent to reach US$12.400 billion, resulting in a monthly trade surplus of US$1.492 billion.

According to CBC statistics, the island's exports during the first 11 months reached US$146.846 billion, while imports amounted to US$134.633 billion, creating a surplus of US$12.213 billion during the period.
Officials attributed the rise in foreign trade mainly to continued growth in exports of electronics and imports of related accessories and capital equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELIGIOUS LEADER, MAINLAND CHINESE RELIGION OFFICIAL MEET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's renowned Buddhist leader Master Hsing Yun and mainland China's top official in charge of religion Ye Xiaowen reached four points of consensus when they met on Tuesday, according to Hsing Yun's Fokuangshan Temple in Taiwan.

Ye, who is director of mainland China's State Bureau of Religious Affairs, was quoted as saying in the meeting that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are going to establish direct trade, postal, and transport links in the future, then the religious sector might as well spearhead the initiative -- as long as everything is done under the principle of "one China."

Responding to Ye, Hsing Yun urged mainland China to "peacefully co-exist" with Taiwan in a "rational and gentle" manner and insisted that Beijing should never resort to the use of force against Taiwan. "Chinese do not fight Chinese," he stressed.

The consensus included a promise from Ye to help bring a treasured mainland Chinese religious artifact to Taiwan for exhibition. The artifact, said to be a finger salvaged from the Buddha's ashes after his cremation 2,000 years ago, has never been displayed outside mainland China since its archeological discovery 12 years ago.

Mainland China also owns one of the three legendary Sacred Teeth of Buddha. In 1998, a Tibetan monk in exile in India donated another to Hsing Yun, whose Buddha's Light International Association is the world's largest Buddhist organization.
Ye also promised that his bureau would be willing to help Fokuangshan set up a university in mainland China. The Buddhist organization has already established Fokuang University in Taiwan.
Hsing Yun and Ye also agreed to continue to promote the mainland's bid to hold the next World Buddhist Friendship Convention in Beijing.
Lastly, Ye said that he hopes a volume on academic research into Chinese Buddhism currently being compiled by Fokuangshan will be allowed to be published in Beijing.

At the invitation of Fukuang University, five officials of Ye's bureau had visited Taiwan in 1998, when they toured various religious centers, temples, and churches for the purpose of cross-Taiwan Strait religious exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER SEEKS CENTRAL AMERICAN STATES' SUPPORT FOR ROC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will continue to attempt to join international organizations, Deputy Premier Lai In-jaw said Wednesday.

In a meeting with a visiting group of Guatemalan parliamentarians, Lai made a plea for the support of Taiwan's Central American allies in its efforts to widen its presence in the international community.

The vice premier also rebutted foreign media reports about Taiwan's deteriorating financial situation. He said that with an average national income of US$14,000, Taiwan's economic outlook outshines that of nations of similar income levels, with national economic growth of 6 percent and a jobless rate of just 3.1 percent.
Western states post an average unemployment of 4 percent, Lai noted.
The capitalization of Taiwan's stock market was ranked fourth in the world last year, next only to the stock exchanges in New York, London and Tokyo, he added.
Although Taiwan stock prices have plummeted by nearly 40 percent since May, Lai said he believes that the island will still be listed among the top five this year.
Noting that the volume of foreign investment in Taiwan is currently twice that of last year, Lai said that the economy of the island is very healthy.
The 13-member group of Guatemalan parliamentarians was in Taiwan for a visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. TO PROBE DUMPING OF HOT-ROLLED STEEL FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) has decided to conduct an investigation in the near future into the alleged dumping of hot-rolled steel exported to the United States from 11 countries, including Taiwan, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.
The BOFT noted that 11 U.S. steel manufacturers had lodged dumping charges against Taiwan manufacturers of hot-rolled steel sheeting, hot-rolled steel alloys, and electromagnetic steel sheeting.

U.S. steel manufacturers charged Taiwan manufacturers with dumping their hot-rolled steel products on the U.S. market at prices some 16 percent to 50 percent cheaper than those of the same products made by U.S. manufacturers.
Other countries also charged with dumping hot-rolled steel by the U.S. side include Argentina, mainland China, India, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Holland, Romania, South Africa, Thailand and the Ukraine.
The BOFT indicated that the sharp increase of U.S. imports of Taiwan steel products had aroused the U.S. side's concerns.

In addition to hot-rolled steel products, the U.S. side has warned Taiwan's steel manufacturers to take care not to dump other types of steel on the U.S. market, or risk having these products targeted during the next wave of anti-dumping investigations in the United States.

According to U.S. Commerce of Department's statistics, from 1998 to the first eight months of 2000, exports of Taiwan's hot-rolled steel to the United States grew by 76.4 percent to 366 percent, with sales volumes increasing from US$50 million to US$170 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
After Supreme Court rules, Bush is certain to win the 2000 U.S. presidential election.
The China Times:
Top court ruling clears the way for Bush to become next U.S. president.
The United Daily News:
Al Gore has decided to concede the protracted U.S. election, clearing the way for Bush to win the presidency.
The Liberty Times:
Gore mulls concession after court ruling.
The China Post:
Gore drops out of election race, will address nation.
The Taiwan News:
Gore bowing out in wake of court ruling.
The Taipei Times:
'Small three links' set to take effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 14, or the 19th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1799: George Washington, the first president of the United States, dies at the age of 67.
1819: Alabama becomes the 22nd state of the United States.
1895: George VI, English monarch, is born. He succeeded to the throne when his brother, Edward VIII, abdicated to marry the twice-divorced Mrs. Wallis Simpson.
1906: Germany's first submarine, the U1, is launched in the military port of Kiel in northern Germany.
1907: In St. Petersburg, 38 Russian soldiers are sentenced to life imprisonment for surrendering to the Japanese at Port Arthur.
1910: Scottish-born US steel industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie establishes the Carnegie Peace Foundation.
1911: Roald Amundsen, a Norwegian explorer, becomes the first person to reach the South Pole.
1916: The people of Denmark vote to sell the Danish West Indies to the United States for US$25 million.
1918: Six million British women cast their votes for the first time in general elections in Britain.
1927: Chinese government forces put down an attempted communist coup in Canton.
1927: The Republic of China breaks off relations with the Soviet Union.
1937: Japan sets up a puppet Chinese government in Peiping (Beijing).
1939: The Soviet Union is expelled from the League of Nations for invading Finland.
1959: Archbishop Makarios is elected the first president of Cyprus.
1967: Scientists at Stanford University isolate nuclear DNA from a virus in a test tube.
1972: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: After three days of exploration on the lunar surface, US Apollo 17 astronauts blast off from the moon.
1975: Nam Duck Woo, deputy prime minister of South Korea, arrives in Taipei to take part in the 10th Sino-Korean Economic Cooperation Conference.
1975: Agustin Martines Varela, El Salvador interior minister, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: A two-day pre-conference executive committee meeting for the 23rd Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives a six-member delegation from Japan led by Yoshiko Nakano, president of the Organization for Industrial, Spiritual and Cultural Advancement International.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives some 20 delegates to the pre-conference executive committee meeting for the 23rd conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League.
1978: The ROC armed forces manufacture missile-carrying vessels capable of traveling speeds up to 40 knots.
1981: Israel annexes the Golan Heights, which was captured from Syria in 1967.
1990: Ten Vietnamese boat people set fire to themselves in Hong Kong to protest a screening policy that could prevent them from settling in the West.
1990: Chang Chun, senior adviser to the president, dies in Taipei at the age of 102.
1992: The United States allows its companies to sign contracts with Vietnam, easing a 17-year trade embargo.
1999: The 11th World Soft Tennis Championship conclude in Taoyuan County, with Taiwan emerging the biggest winner with four gold, three silver and three bronze medals.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The purpose of the magnanimous is to be found in procuring benefits for the world and eliminating its calamities."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 64.2 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 64.2 points to close at 5,320.16.
Market turnover amounted to NT$36.28 billion (US$1.1 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 64.2 points to close at 5,320.16.

Affected by the continued plunge in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,350.26 and continued to go down due to profit-taking selling pressure. The bourse fluctuated between 5,350.26 and 5,274.15 during trading.

A total of 1.49 billion shares worth NT$36.28 billion (US$1.1 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.71 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$45.73 billion (US$1.39 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 0.7 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.5 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares, bank and insurance stocks, and textile issues all moving down the most at 1.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1 percent, and foodstuff shares and plastics and chemical stocks, both at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 223, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 105 points to close at 5,325, with 6,133 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 decreased 101 points to finish at 5,325, with 300 contract transactions, while June 2001 futures lost 65 points to close at 5,340, with five contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,430 for December, 5,426 for next January, 5,429 for next March, 5,405 for next June, and 5,848 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 6.7 points to close at 261.8, with 1,540 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures decreased 7 points to finish at 261, with 109 contracts changing hands.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures fell 11.2 points to finish at 688.8, with 837 contract transactions, while January 2001 TF futures lost 9 points to close at 687, with 71 contracts traded.
June 2001 TF futures plunged 25.4 points to finish at 705.4, with two contract transactions, while September TF futures decreased 17.2 points to close at 720.2, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CONGRATULATES BUSH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian offered sincere congratulations to U.S. President-elect George W. Bush Thursday, saying he hopes that relations between Taiwan and the United States will be further strengthened under the Bush presidency.
"I sincerely congratulate you on your election as the next U.S. president," President Chen said in his congratulatory message to Bush.

Chen went on to pointed out that the Republic of China and the United States share a longtime cordial relationship and have common principles in pursuing democracy and human rights. "I look forward to seeing our two countries strengthen cooperation on the basis of mutual trust and friendly spirit in the future," he added.

Noting that the Taiwan Strait stability is critical to Asia-Pacific regional peace and security and accords with the interests of both countries, Chen said the ROC government is willing to make joint efforts with the incoming Bush administration to maintain stability and promote prosperity and development in the Asia-Pacific region and the whole world.

Chen further said the peoples of the two countries have elected their new national leaders through democratic procedures this year. "I believe that future ROC-U.S. relations will become even stronger on the basis of democracy," he noted.

Chen also expressed his hope that the new U.S. government will reinforce engagements and substantive cooperation with the ROC based on the Taiwan Relations Act and the "six U.S. guarantees" to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, a Presidential Office press release said Vice President Annette Lu has also cabled warm felicitations to U.S. President-elect Bush and his running mate Dick Cheney.
