DOC.HEADLINE: ALUMNUS DONATES CHIP CENTER TO CHUNGSHING UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: An exceptional alumnus of National Chungshing University and the founder of a U.S.-based high technology company donated a chip center to his Alma Mater Wednesday, marking what he called his "tiny" contribution to the most prestigious university in central Taiwan.

Gerald Hsu, chairman, CEO, and president of the Fremont, Calif.-based Avant! Hi-Tech Corp., handed the key to the US$23 million Meng Yao Chip Center to the president of NCU, Peng Tso-kwei, in a ceremony held at the newly-founded chip center located on the university's campus.

The Meng Yao Chip Center, expected to serve as a cradle for the IC industry and specialists in central Taiwan, marks the biggest donation ever made by any individual to their Alma Mater in Taiwan's history.

Making an address at the donation ceremony, Hsu, who owns and runs one of the leading EDA (electronic design automation) companies in the world, said the chip center should serve only as a starter that will induce more alumnae to offer feedback to Chungshing University so as to help in the development of the institute.
"We will starve to death if we only rely on subsidies from the government," he added.

Expressing his appreciation to Hsu for the donation, Peng said the establishment of the chip center promises to turn Taichung into Taiwan's third science-based industrial park, after the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan and the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

The Meng Yao Chip Center, which is named after Hsu's father, comes equipped with a laboratory using Avant!'s design facilities and know-how, two operation centers containing two high-speed servers and 30 Sun operation stations, and an Internet video conference center.
Avant! Hi-Tech Corp., a leading EDA firm, which maintains 60 affiliates and offshoot companies in 17 countries around the world, established its first affiliate in Asia in Shanghai this past October.
Although the company sees mainalnd China's market potential as immense, Hsu said he chose to help Taiwan to gear up further, adding that "Taiwan is where I'm from."
Hard-work is Hsu's motto for success and the only advice that he gave to his young alumnae, pointing out that his enterprise kingdom has been built with tears and sweat.
Graduating from Chungshing University's Applied Mathematics Department in 1968, Hsu left for the United States in 1970 to study after finishing two years of mandatory military service in Taiwan.

With only US$700 to his name, he went on to study hydromechanics at Iowa University and obtained a bachelor's degree two years later. He graduated at a time when America was experiencing an oil crisis and economic depression. In this setting, none of the 290 job applications his wife typed up and sent out received a response, like "stones falling into the ocean."
Despite the financial strains he and his wife were experiencing, they moved to the East Coast and still aimed to fulfill his dream of entering the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Ten years later, after earning stature in the business world with a master's degree from MIT, his graduate school director told Hsu that he had been accepted into MIT's Institute of Structural Engineering program because the director had been moved by Hsu's "super strong ambition and salesman characteristics."
As a poor foreign student, Hsu said he did any humble job he could, such as washing over 1,000 toilets in nine months or working for as little as US$2 per hour, just to make ends meet.
Hsu said that he retains his work ethic to this day, adding that it's normal for him these days to work 80 to 100 hours per week without taking a break on weekends.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER HAILS BUSH'S VICTORY

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao said Thursday he is pleased to see Republican candidate George W. Bush win the cliffhanger 2000 U.S. presidential election.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee, Tien said although he failed to meet Bush in person during his U.S. visit in November, he managed to meet with Bush's senior advisers in private.
Tien told lawmakers that he had taken advantage of those meetings to gain a better understanding of the major directions of possible future U.S. policies toward the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"Of course, I had also clearly informed Bush's advisers of our government's views and stances on cross-Taiwan Strait relations," Tien explained.

Meanwhile, Tien said he got an impression during his U.S. visit that the United States attaches great importance to the "three acknowledgments and four recommendations" presented recently by the Republic of China's cross-party presidential advisory group on the development of cross-strait relations.
"Even though not all Americans I met agreed with those proposals, some of them threw explicit support behind the advisory group's 'acknowledgments and recommendations,'" Tien said.
The minister further said he is convinced that U.S. President-elect Bush will deal with cross-Taiwan Strait issues with a positive attitude.
Tien also said he thinks that the views of Bush's advisers on Taiwan are quite positive.

Responding to opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Shei-saint's claim that Vice President Annette Lu's recent remarks on cross-strait issues have caused Beijing's unhappy reaction, Tien said the ROC should avoid taking any provocative action as local people want peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Tien added that peace and stability are also in the U.S. interest in the Asia-Pacific region.
In related news, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs cabled warm congratulations Thursday to U.S. President-elect Bush and his running mate Dick Cheney.
The ministry said in its messages that substantive ROC-U.S. relations have grown steadily on the basis of mutual trust and reciprocity in recent years.
The ministry went on to point out that U.S. President Bill Clinton's 1994 Taiwan policy review has brought about some improvements in bilateral engagements.

It also recalled Washington's "firm action" during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis when mainland China conducted missile tests and live-fire military exercises ahead of Taiwan's first presidential election. At the height of the crisis, the ministry said, the U.S. government had demonstrated its determination to maintain peace and security in the area by dispatching two aircraft carrier battle groups to waters near the Taiwan Strait.

"We believe that there should be ample room for our two countries to further expand cooperation on the basis of traditional friendship, mutual trust and reciprocity since we have common ideals of pursuing democracy and human rights and share common interests in peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region," the ministry added in its messages.
Bush won the U.S. presidency after Democratic rival Al Gore conceded defeat following a Supreme Court decision halting vote recounts in the key state of Florida.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT TO FILE CIVIL SUIT AGAINST LOCAL MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu will file a civil suit against a local magazine over its reports implicating her in a scandal, Lu's legal team announced on Thursday.

Lu's six-member legal team and 13 legal advisers -- including her elder brother Lu Chuan-sheng -- also said that it will not rule out pressing a criminal case against The Journalist and asking for compensation of NT$100 million (US$3.02 million).
However, the legal team stressed that the attitude of the weekly will be a major factor in their decision on whether to press criminal charges against it later.

On Dec. 4, the team demanded that the magazine openly apologize by Dec. 10 over what it claimed to be "obviously false and malicious" reporting on Lu. But The Journalist only responded with a Dec. 8 letter in which the legal team found the weekly was trying to "distort the definition of press freedom," and "mislead the general public" without any kind of reflection on the ethical code of professional journalists, the team said.
Therefore, the legal team made the announcement to pursue the legal action after a discussion Wednesday night.

The team said in Thursday's statement that Lu had originally wanted to avoid a laborious legal battle and forgive the magazine -- following its open apology -- because she is "always kind to others." But there is no other choice now but to go to court to solicit legal justice and clear the damaged names of the vice president, the legal experts said.

The team claimed that the weekly printed a "libelous" cover headline and story that accused the vice president of spreading rumors about an alleged extramarital affair between President Chen Shui-bian and a female aide. The team also accused the magazine of alleging that Lu wanted to use the presidential scandal to "finish off" the president.
The headline reads: "The person who stirred up the scandal and is secretly competing with the president unexpectedly turned out to be Annette Lu."
President Chen said in a Nov. 16 news release that he "has absolute faith in the vice president" and does not think that she is the source of the rumors.
Meanwhile, The Journalist, which had earlier stood by it reports, showed no sign of budging and responded by saying that it is ready to face the legal procedure.

Wang Chien-chuang, president of The Journalist, said that over the past six weeks, the magazine has mostly been concerned about press freedom, professional journalism, and journalistic ethics. He added that its credo is now on the line in the legal battle.
Wang also said in a press conference that a national leader filing charges against a magazine sets a "bad example" for the democratic and constitutional history of the nation.
Wang said that no political figure, especially a national leader, should try to cover up their mistakes, which he said would only lead to a dead end, examples of which abound in other countries.

Wang claimed that The Journalist's articles on the vice president's alleged spreading of rumors are accurate, adding that more and more evidence has surfaced over the past month that proves the authenticity of its reports.

He stressed that the magazine has remained passive over the past month, despite what he called the emotional and insulting remarks by the vice president and her legal team. He added that it will now adopt a more aggressive attitude toward the legal procedure.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S VICTORY SHOULD BE A PLUS FOR TAIPEI STOCK MARKET: MANAGERS

TEXT.P: Convinced that George W. Bush's election as the next president of the United States will have little impact on Taiwan's economy, some foreign securities consulting firms operating in Taipei believe that the Bush victory will nevertheless be a plus for the local stock market.

Taiwan stands to benefit more from a Bush victory, as the U.S. president-elect has touted a more powerful tax cut than his rival Al Gore -- over US$1 trillion against some US$40 million. Bush's victory will benefit the U.S. stock market temporarily at least, helping to fuel the American economy, which will eventually be beneficial for Taiwan's bourse, said Andrew Lin, vice president of Jardine Fleming Taiwan Securities.

Bush's election is expected to result in little change to overall U.S.-China relations and cross-Taiwan Strait ties, but its impact on Taiwan will be more positive than negative, Lin noted. In addition, Republicans have been traditionally been friendlier to Taiwan than Democrats, he pointed out.
He said it is still too early to speculate on whether foreign capital will flow from Taiwan to mainland China in the wake of the victory of the Texas governor.
Meanwhile, Wu Yi-hsun, president of UBS Warburg Securities' Taipei branch, said the results of the U.S. presidential election will have little influence on the Taipei stock market.

Although Washington's Taiwan Strait policy has a direct influence on Taiwan, little change has been seen in the policy so far, Wu said. Since the United States' foreign policy has to have continuity and is primarily controlled by Congress, whoever is in the White House office actually makes little difference to it, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.004 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 33.077.
The local currency opened Thursday at 32.994 and was traded between 32.994 and 33.130.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$467 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SILICON VALLEY DIRECT AIR LINK TO OPENS NEXT APRIL

TEXT.P: U.S. air carrier American Airlines (AA) has announced that it will open a direct air link between Taiwan and San Jose, California. The move is expected to strengthen the interchange of information and personnel between Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and Silicon Valley.
A spokesman for AA said that the maiden voyage will take place on April 1, 2001.

Currently, if a visitor wants to visit Silicon Valley, the U.S. high-technology industrial center, he must first fly to either San Franciso or Tokyo before transferring to a flight bound for San Jose.

The spokesman said that some 300 high tech companies in Silicon Valley have close relations with firms in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which was the deciding factor behind the airline's decision to open a direct air link between Taiwan and San Jose. Flights will occur on a daily basis, meaning that the first plane will fly from San Jose to Taipei on April 1 and return to San Jose on April 2.
The Taipei-San Jose route will expand AA's direct air services to Silicon Valley. The firm already maintains direct flights between Tokyo and San Jose.

The new route is seen as an indication that the tremendous interchange of high-tech industrial personnel between Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and Silicon Valley has attracted the attention of the air transport industry.
AA will use Boeing 777 with a capacity of 235 seats to fly the Taipei-San Jose route, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MAGISTRATE SPEAKS ON 'THREE MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-tsai, magistrate of the outpost island of Kinmen, said Thursday that the government's proposed "three mini links" has focused more on plugging up loopholes than seeking benefits for Kinmen people.

Chen criticized the regulation mandating that only people who have been registered as residents of Kinmen and Matsu for more than six months will be allowed to engage in direct transport with the mainland, saying that it should be eased.
Direct transport refers to one of the three "mini links," the other two being direct trade and postal links across the Taiwan Strait.

He said that the roughly 200,000 people originally from Kinmen who now reside on Taiwan proper, as well as the 300,000-odd Kinmen natives who live overseas, should also be able to enjoy the same rights.
He said that he will continue to discuss the issue with the central government.

He noted that the first stage of implementing the "three mini links" between the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland ports will be to legalize the existing small-scale trade with the mainland, and the second stage will be to allow larger-scale commercial trade.
Noting that the central government has yet to set a timetable for the second-stage works, he urged it to step up its preparations.

Chen also suggested that the number of mainland tourists allowed to travel to Kinmen every day be increased to 1,500 from 700 during the second stage of the links, which he said would stimulate Kinmen's tourism industry.

Chen also said that the government should encourage Taiwan businessmen to set up plants in Kinmen and make use of cheap raw materials from the mainland for reprocessing and re-exporting, and even introducing mainland laborers so as to upgrade the competitive edge of Taiwan businesses.

Chen also said that in the long term, the government should consider declaring Kinmen a special peace zone between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, so that the outlying island would enjoy the benefits of peace and cross-strait trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN INSPECTS CHIASHAN AIR BASE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian made an inspection tour of the Chiashan Air Base in eastern Taiwan Thursday to gain a better understanding of the Republic of China Air Force's "command, control, communications and intelligence" operations.
This was the first time that Chen has inspected the maximum-security Chiashan air base since he took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May.
Chen was accompanied on the inspection tour by Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yao-ming and Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min.

Air force sources said that President Chen, also the commander-in-chief of the ROC's armed forces, monitored mainland Chinese military aircraft's real-time movements through the Sky Net System, and inspected the ROC air force's precautionary measures and combat preparedness in the face of the potential mainland military threat.

Chiashan is one of Taiwan's most important air bases for counterattacking after a "first strike" by mainland China. It can withstand a direct hit by a traditional missile and a 6-plus-magnitude earthquake.

The air base is also equipped with facilities to protect itself from attacks by nuclear, biological and chemical weapons. With an immense interior, the base can accommodate hundreds of warplanes of various types.
Air Force Commander-in-Chief Gen. Chen Chao-min told President Chen that the Chiashan Air Base's main function is to preserve "combat power" for launching counterattacks on enemy forces.

"Once our air bases in western Taiwan were struck by the enemy's first-wave attack, some warplanes deployed at those bases would be flown to Chiashan upon receiving orders from the air force operations command," Gen. Chen explained.
Construction on the Chiashan air base began in January 1985 and was completed in December 1993, with a price tag of NT$27.29 billion (US$826.97 million).

The air base has an anti-flood system as well as comprehensive power generation, water, fire, communication, medical, air conditioning, security and emergency power supply systems. Each of its exits is equipped with a protective steel door.

To demonstrate the Chiashan Air Base's emergency combat capabilities, the air force arranged for a squadron of jet fighters to fly to the air base from other military bases. Several warplanes stationed at Chiashan scrambled to escort fighters to safely land at the base.
After watching the emergency flight demonstration, President Chen had lunch with officers and men stationed at the Chiashan Air Base to boost their morale.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUPPORTERS OF BUSH-CHENEY CAMP TO HOLD CELEBRATORY PARTIES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Association of Friends of Bush and Cheney Thursday expressed joy upon learning the news that Republican George Bush had won the U.S. presidential election.
Chiu Yung-jen, president of Kaohsiung's Yung Jen Hospital and the convenor of the Taiwan association, said that the association will hold celebratory parties to mark the Republican victory.
The association of over 200 members was established in mid-September to solicit support for the Republican ticket, mainly by telephone and mail.
Chiu said that the association plans to convene a meeting of ranking cadres to prepare for the celebrations, probably to be held in Kaohsiung and Taipei simultaneously.

Meanwhile, following the election of Bush as the new U.S. president, former Taiwan Provincial Assembly member Su Shun-kuo was named as Taiwan co-chairman of the National Asian-American Republican Coalition.
Su moved to the United States after quitting active politics in Taiwan several years ago. During the election period, Su campaigned for the Bush-Cheney camp in the United States and Taiwan.
He said that he is scheduled to leave for the United States at the end of this month to attend Bush's presidential inauguration Jan. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAY RAISE FOR CIVIL SERVANTS NEXT YEAR TO BE HONORED, SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung reiterated Thursday that the three percent pay raise for civil servants next year will be honored, despite a proposal by the lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to freeze the salary increase.
Chang made the remarks to reporters after attending a meeting on post-earthquake reconstruction work in Taichung.

He said that the three-percent pay raise is the fixed policy of the Executive Yuan, and added that the budget for the pay raise is being reviewed by the Legislative Yuan after it was approved by a legislative committee.
A few days ago, the DPP legislative caucus proposed a freeze on the pay raise, citing the central government's financial difficulties.
Chang said that the Executive Yuan will try to communicate with the DPP legislative caucus and to urge them to support the government's pay raise plan.
Regarding the possible shortage of money for year-end use by several local governments, the premier said that the Executive Yuan will shoulder full responsibility of meeting their needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING NOT EXPECTED TO ENTER WTO NEXT SPRING: U.S. OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The chances of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait entering the World Trade Organization (WTO) next spring have become slim, a senior U.S. trade official said Wednesday.

Assistant United States Trade Representative Donald M. Phillip made the remarks while briefing the Republic of China's representative office in the United States on the just-concluded 14th screening meeting of the WTO working party in charge of mainland China's membership bid.
Phillip told ROC representative office staff that the working party is scheduled to meet again in Geneva from Jan. 10-17, 2001.
"And that meeting is not expected to be the last one," Phillip said, adding that the working party will have to meet one more time or two to finalize negotiations with mainland China.

Against this backdrop, Phillip said, Taiwan's WTO entry will be delayed due to the slow progress in the world trade regulatory body's multilateral negotiations concerning mainland China's accession terms. It is a WTO consensus that Taiwan and mainland China will be admitted to the body simultaneously, so although Taiwan has long finalized bilateral and multilateral negotiations, it must wait for mainland China to complete all necessary procedures.

According to Phillip, mainland China made important concessions in intellectual property rights protection and service market opening and transparency during the working party's 14th meeting, which wrapped up Dec. 8.
Nevertheless, he went on, the mainland still failed to reach agreement with major WTO members on many sensitive issues, including farm produce subsidies, service trade and anti-dumping measures.

According to WTO working procedures, entry will take one or two more months even after mainland China completes its multilateral talks with major WTO contracting parties. As a result, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are not expected to obtain WTO memberships by the end of March next year.

With Republican candidate George W. Bush's victory in the U.S. presidential election, the U.S. trade representative will have a brand new negotiating team after the Jan. 20 presidential inauguration to handle Taipei- and Beijing-related trade affairs.
Taipei applied to join the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1990, while mainland China filed its application with GATT in 1986. The GATT was superseded by the WTO in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CONGRATULATES U.S. PRESIDENT-ELECT BUSH
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Tony Feng & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, who is in Rome on a private trip, cabled his congratulations to U.S. President-elect George W. Bush on Thursday.
Bush will be sworn into office on Jan. 20, 2001, becoming the next President of the United States of America.
Lien also congratulated U.S. Vice President-elect Richard Cheney.

Lien said that this year's U.S. presidential election was the most fiercely competitive race since the United States of America was founded 224 years ago. Despite the election's outcome being undecided over the past five weeks, the result was decided by trusting and respecting the spirit of the U.S. Constitution, Lien said.

He said he believes that this constitutional spirit played a key role in maintaining U.S. national stability during the political uncertainty of recent weeks. "By upholding the Constitution, difficult issues can be easily resolved," Lien said.

Lien also cabled his congratulations to the chairman of the Republican National Committee, expressing his hope that the Republicans will continue to focus on maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait and to help develop cross-strait relations.
Lien also reminded the U.S. new administration to pay attention to economic situation in the Asia-Pacific region, which he said is worsening every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER UPBEAT ON FINANCIAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said Thursday that he believes 2001 will be a year of "thorough changes" for the country's financial sector because there will be a legal environment conducive to financial reforms.

Yen said at an informal meeting with a legislative subgroup that the domestic asset management company (AMC) he hopes to introduce into the industry to buy and sell problem loans is already moving from the drawing board to its preliminary formative stages.

He went on to say that a government asset management agency similar to the U.S. Resolution Trust Corporation (RTC), which from 1989 to 1996 administered federal savings and loan institutions that were insolvent between 1989 and 1992 by either bailing them out or merging them, is also in the works.
Following the passage of a bank merger law, Yen said that a financial holding company law will also be sent to the Legislative Yuan during its next session for deliberation.

He reiterated that Taiwan is not in danger of a financial crisis, adding that the 12 major banks with government share backing lend out over 70 percent of the loans in the market, and saying that the problematic farmers credit cooperatives account for only 1 percent of the loans extended.

However, he said that consolidation must take place because the three largest banks in Taiwan account for only 24 percent of the market, whereas elsewhere in the world, the three largest banks in a country usually account for between 40 percent and 80 percent. He added that the mergers will not be restricted to small banks, but will also involve the 12 largest banks.
Taiwan has 53 banks and nearly 360 non-bank financial institutions such as farmers credit cooperatives.

Paul Chiu, who had previously proposed setting up an RTC when he was finance minister under the previous Kuomintang administration, said at the same meeting that the Central Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, can raise its interest rate to bring in an additional NT$3 billion (US $91 million) in premiums that can be used in turn to raise NT$30 billion (US$907 million) in government bonds to serve as capital for the formation of an RTC.

Taiwan's financial health has been under criticism since The Economist magazine recently published a report that said Taiwan may suffer its own belated version of the Asian crisis -- perhaps even before the Chinese New Year in January. The New York Times and BusinessWeek magazine followed with similar reports that quoted foreign analysts as saying Taiwan's actual rate of non-performing loans is higher than the government admits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA CONFERS MEDAL ON OUTGOING ROC AMBASSADOR
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Panamanian Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman conferred a medal Thursday on outgoing Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-ming, in recognition of Lan's contributions to bilateral cooperation and friendship.

Aleman said while conferring the Vasco Nunez de Balboa en Grado de Gran Cruz that the two countries have grown closer since establishing formal diplomatic ties in 1922, and that ethnic Chinese immigrants to Panama, which now stand at 5 percent of the country's total population, have played a noticeable role in all sectors of Panama's development.

He went on to praise Lan's decades of service in Central and South America, adding that he is certain Lan will continue to promote friendly bilateral ties upon returning to Taiwan to take up the post of secretary-general of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
The vacancy created by Lan's appointment will be filled by David C.Y. Hu, currently the director-general of MOFA's South and Central American Affairs Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SOVEREIGN RATING REMAINS STABLE AT AA3: MOODY'S
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior executive with Moody's Investors Service said Wednesday that the credit rating agency still ranks Taiwan's sovereign rating as "stable" at AA3.

Moody's Vice Chairman Thomas Byrne made the remarks in an interview with CNA after delivering a speech on mainland China's sovereign rating and investment risks. The lecture was sponsored by the China Institute, a private think tank.
Byrne said that although many Taiwan banks have been troubled by a high non-performing debt rate, it will not affect the island's AA3 sovereign rating.
Nevertheless, he pointed out that political instability could become a potential threat to Taiwan's sovereign risk rating.

In his view, Byrne continued, continued squabbles between the Democratic Progressive Party-led government and the opposition-dominated legislature, coupled with slow progress in parliamentary screening of the government's budget plan for the new fiscal year, will undermine Taiwan investor confidence.
Equally noteworthy is that inbound investment in Taiwan is declining due to foreign businessmen's misgivings about the island's political prospects, Byrne noted.

Two Moody's banking industry analysts are currently in Taiwan to study its banks' credit status and are expected to unveil their latest credit rating report after wrapping up their visit and returning to the United States next week.

Among Asia-Pacific countries, Byrne said, Singapore boasts the healthiest banking system, followed by Australia, Hong Kong and Taiwan, in that order. Mainland China ranks eighth, lagging behind even Malaysia and the Philippines.
According to the latest Moody's assessment, Taiwan receives a stable "AA3" rating in terms of its foreign exchange reserves and high bank deposits.

But the report also cited several elements that might affect Taiwan's sovereign rating in the future. First of all, political tension between to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait has not shown signs of easing. Moreover, mainland China's insistence on the "one China" policy and its refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan might eventually affect the already close cross-strait trade ties and even destabilize the Taiwan economy.

Taiwan's financial authorities have said non-performing debts account for about 6 percent of total bank loans, but Moody's said the actual rate might be higher. Some U.S. securities firms have estimated that Taiwan banks' non-performing debt rate is as high as 15 percent.

Byrne said that although the increase in non-performing loans could affect the health of the overall banking system, its impact on a country's sovereign rating is limited. Nor will a high bad debt rate cause an immediate threat to the downgrading of a country's sovereign rating, he added.

The Moody's assessment report also said Taiwan's long-term economic performance has qualified the island to join the ranks of "middle per capita income" countries in terms of standards set by the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

The report further said Taiwan banks should merge and enhance transparency to survive ever-increasing competition, as a banking glut has led to cut-throat competition and has threatened the stability of Taiwan's banking sector.

Meanwhile, Moody's ranks both Taiwan's and mainland China's sovereign rating prospects as "stable." But Taiwan outshines mainland China in terms of its long-term bank deposits, state bonds and long-term government performance.
Singapore led the 14 Asia-Pacific economies in the Moody's sovereign rating report, followed by Japan, Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT RE-EVALUATING POLICIES ON INVESTING IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Senior government officials from various ministries convened their first meeting Thursday on the re-evaluation of government policies regarding investment in mainland China.

The cross-ministerial meeting was presided over by Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and attended by Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, Council of Labor Affairs Vice Chairman Kuo Chih-jen and Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Lee Chien-chuan.

A special task force headed by Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-lung to re-evaluate the former Kuomintang administration's "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy submitted a report and suggestions, which the officials discussed before reaching a six-point consensus.
The participants at the meeting agreed that:
-- All new local investment projects in the mainland should follow the concepts of "keeping the roots in Taiwan" and "risk management;"
-- the projects should not be detrimental to the employment opportunities of Taiwan laborers;
-- corporate sector needs and globalization must be taken into account;
-- an improved service system for Taiwan businessmen and industries in mainland China should be established;
-- the capital to be invested in mainland China should come from "various sources;" and
-- an "active adjustment" mechanism should be established for all investment projects in mainland China.

MAC Vice Chairman Teng Cheng-chung said after the meeting that the current US$50 million maximum on individual investment projects in mainland China still exists, but that amounts over that limit may in the future be allowed on a case-by-case basis depending on "various factors."

He added that the meeting did not decide on the task force's suggestion that local petrochemicals, wafer fabrication and personal computer manufacturing be allowed to invest in mainland China because such a decision would depend on the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SAID FORMING `MINI THREE LINKS' GROUP

TEXT.P: Mainland China, which has decried the "mini three links" that Taiwan will soon launch between the two sides, has actually established a task force to deal with the matter, Taiwan's top mainland affairs official was quoted as saying Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen was quoted by Legislator Lai Shih-pao as saying at a closed-door legislative meeting that the government is now "cautiously optimistic" about the "mini three links" -- transportation, postal and trade -- between the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and designated mainland ports.

Mainland China, which insists on the "one China" principle as the basis for any cross-strait "three direct links," has on the face of it been throwing cold water on the move which Taiwan is set to begin at the beginning of next year.
Tsai was invited to brief the first meeting of the Legislative Yuan's cross-strait panel on the "mini three links" issue.
Lawmaker Chen Ching-pao, who is elected from Kinmen, suggested that a direct voyage between Kinmen and the mainland port of Xiamen be allowed as early as Dec. 25 on a test basis.
Tsai first said the move would violate regulations, but later promised a decision on the issue will be available next Monday after discussion with Premier Chen Chun-hsiung.
She said that the government is willing "to do anything that is beneficial to improved cross-strait ties," including allowing proposed visits to the mainland by opposition lawmakers.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who presided over the meeting, said that whether the legislative panel will pay a scheduled visit to the mainland has yet to be considered and approved by the legislature.
Tsai reportedly told the meeting that far from being against "mini three links," the mainland side in fact has "great expectations" of the links and has set up a group to handle related affairs.

Tsai was described by the meeting participants as "keeping a low profile" over the issue. "What we care about most is to realize the mini links. There is no need for us to show off," she is reported to have said. She was also reported to have later changed her previous remarks, amending the phrase "cautiously optimistic" on the links to "cautious."

DOC.HEADLINE: TENNIS STAR TO SERVE AS INSTRUCTOR AT TAIWAN TENNIS CAMP

TEXT.P: Chinese-American tennis star Michael Chang has been invited to serve as instructor at a youth tennis camp in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, between Jan. 30 and Feb. 3.
This will be the first time Chang will have trained Taiwan tennis players. Chang's elder brother, a tennis coach, will also teach at the camp.
The event, jointly sponsored by the Westin Ta Shee Resort and the Chang Foundation, will be open to over 100 tennis players aged between 10 and 18.
Chang, 28, became a tennis star after he won the French Open when he was 17.
A spokesman for the Chang Foundation said that the tennis camp is designed to promote tennis exchanges between the youth of Taiwan and North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAINTING TO COMMEMORATE 2ND SUMMIT BETWEEN ROC AND C.A. UNVEILED

TEXT.P: A painting to commemorate the Second Summit between the Republic of China and Central American countries was formally unveiled Thursday at Tamkang University in Tamshui.
The painting, which measures one meter by 1.5 meters, is the joint work of Central American and local artists.
Vice Foreign Minister Chiou Jong-nan and visiting Guatemalan Foreign Minister Gabriel Orellana were among 60 foreign and Chinese dignitaries who witnessed the unveiling.
Both Chiou and Orellana expressed the hope that friendly relations between the ROC and Central American countries will be long-lasting.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs decided to make the painting in appreciation of the efforts made by Tamkang University's Spanish Language and Literature Department and Institute of Latin Affairs, which have contributed very much to Taiwan's diplomatic and economic staff.

Tamkang University has also entered into sisterhood ties with the University of Costa Rica and the University of Chile, which has helped the government enhance relations between the ROC and Latin American countries.
According to Chiou, the summit meeting was the first large-scale international meeting held in the ROC and demonstrated that relations between the ROC and Central American countries are very cordial.

Guatemalan Foreign Minister Gabriel Orellana said that the ROC is not only a friend of Central American countries, but that relations between the ROC and Central American countries have been further consolidated after Panama, Belize and the Dominican Republic joined the five-nation summit.

El Salvador Foreign Minister Maria Eugenia Brizuela de Avila, Honduras Foreign Minister Roberto Flores Bermudez, Nicaragua Foreign Minister Francisco Xavier Aguirre Sacasa, Costa Rican Vice Foreign Minister Elayne Whyte Gomez, Panamanian Vice Foreign Minister Harmodio Arias, Belize Parliamentarian Vildo Marin and the Dominican Republic Vice Foreign Minister Miguel Anibal Pichardo Olivier also witnessed the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SATISFIED WITH ROC-JAPAN RELATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian received Japanese House of Representatives members Shyoichi Nakagawa and Keiji Furuya at the Presidential Office Thursday.
Chen extended a warm welcome to the Japanese parliamentarians and stressed that although the Republic of China maintains no diplomatic relations with Japan, unofficial relations are very cordial.
He also expressed his gratitude to Nakagawa and his father for their staunch support for the ROC over the years.
Chen noted that both Taiwan and Japan have enjoyed brisk economic development stemming from the mutual concern and gratitude existing between the people of the two countries.

The ROC head of state pointed out that democracy, freedom, human rights and justice are a universal value which is a common language between the ROC and Japan. He expressed the hope that Taiwan and Japan will further strengthen economic and trade relations as well as cultural ties based on this foundation.

Nakagawa for his part described ROC-Japan relations as "the largest alliance without writing a treaty." After both Taiwan and Japan experienced devastating earthquakes, mutual assistance consolidated substantive relations between the two countries, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN TO REVIEW 45-YEAR-OLD MUTINY CASE

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan is to review a mutiny case involving a well-known general 45 years ago after a scholar found a report favorable to the general.
Gen. Sun Li-jen was a famous general during the Sino-Japanese war and commander-in-chief of the army from 1950-1954.
In 1955, one of his former subordinates and confidants, Kuo Ting-liang, was arrested for plotting a mutiny on the eve of a military inspection by then-President Chiang Kai-shek.
A total of 34 military officers, all of them Sun's former subordinates, were implicated in the plot by Kuo and sentenced to various jail terms.
Sun was sacked from his post as personal chief of staff to the president in 1955 and remained under house arrest in Taichung until 1988.

He died in 1990 at the age of 92, and his son Sun An-ping has long sought his name to be cleared after the 1988 death of President Chiang Kai-shek's son Chiang Chiang Ching-kuo, who succeeded his father as president of the Republic of China.

In a plea to the Control Yuan Thursday, Sun called for the disclosure of the full text of a 1955 report by the Control Yuan's five-member panel, and the related letters of the panel members to Chiang.

The report claimed that Sun was "framed," contradicting a government investigation by a nine-member panel chaired by then-Vice President Chen Cheng, said Chu Hung-yuan, a researcher at the Institute of Modern History under Academia Sinica, who was asked by the Control Yuan to look into the case.
The five Control Yuan members concluded in their report that Sun could not have intended to mutiny in light of his intelligence and a confession by alleged Beijing spy Kuo.
Letters written separately by the panel members to Chiang pointed out unanimously that there was no evidence Sun had any knowledge of his former subordinate's plot, according to Chu.
What is more, Chu said, Kuo's fatal fall from a moving train in 1991 is also dubious.

Kuo was initially sentenced to death, later commuted to life imprisonment. He was released on parole in 1975 and had tried to clear his name by persistently filing pleas with various law enforcing authorities.

He was found dead on Nov. 16, 1991, apparently having fallen from a moving train. However, Chu said a post-mortem conducted by six surgeons from National Taiwan University Hospital showed that there were four to five injuries to his head which suggested that he was murdered.

Calling for a new probe into Kuo's death, Chu said that the Political Warfare Department under the Ministry of National Defense, the Military Intelligence Bureau and the former Taiwan Garrison Command, which were charged with catching spies when the island was ruled by martial law, should explain if they played any role in Kuo's death.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO PUSH HARD FOR CENTRAL AMERICAN DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Thursday to boost ties with Central America and press for the region's peace, freedom and development.

Receiving Central American delegations to a foreign ministerial-level conference between the Republic of China and several Central American countries that took place Wednesday, Chen said the conference has further cemented the island's ties with Central America.

As a member of the international community, he went on, Taiwan shares the values prevailing in all democratic and free states and is more than willing to pull its weight in the struggle for world peace.
Although the island is shut out of most international organizations, its commitment to fulfilling its international liability is undiminished, Chen said.

He expressed thanks to Central American states for admitting the island as an observer of the System of Central American Integration and pledged to cooperate with them to improve peace, freedom and democracy in the region.
The delegations from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, the Dominican Republic and Costa Rica were accompanied by ROC Foreign Minster Tien Hung-mao at the reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN VISITS JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 14 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Government Information Office Director Su Cheng-ping said here Thursday that Texas Gov. George W. Bush's victory in the U.S. presidential election will not bring about big changes in U.S. policy toward Taiwan.

Su, who arrived in Japan the day before for a week-long visit, told foreign journalists at an informal gathering at Tokyo's Foreign Correspondents Club that American policy toward Taiwan has a sense of continuity and that the United States believes in the peaceful resolution of cross-Taiwan Strait issues. He added that this is line with both ROC and U.S. interests.

Touching on Taiwan's domestic political situation, Su, who also serves as ROC government spokesman, said that ROC President Chen Shui-bian's Democratic Progressive Party administration is a minority government. Therefore, he went on, the new administration might face some difficulties in promoting certain policies, but Chen will soon gain the experience needed to overcome these difficulties.

Su pointed out that the Republic of China is a completely democratic country, and that the resolution of all cross-strait issues requires the consensus of the people. Taiwan looks forward to dialogue with mainland China, he continued, but mainland China has so far been unwilling to re-engage in dialogue, citing as the reason Taiwan's unwillingness to first accept Beijing's "one China" principle.

Su said that Taiwan does not rule out discussions on the "one China" issue, including its content and definition. However, he added that Beijing's "one China" -- the People's Republic of China -- is not acceptable to Taiwan.

Regarding foreign media reports on Taiwan being on the brink of a financial crisis, Su denied the charges and said that although Taiwan may be facing "certain problems" with its financial system, the fundamentals are sound and the government has already taken measures to respond to the issues. He added that the effects that may be caused by the problems are limited and will not bring about a so-called financial crisis.

Su also said that the "one country, two systems" method being used to govern Hong Kong is not acceptable to the people of Taiwan. Hong Kong was a colony, unlike Taiwan, he said, adding that the two cannot be compared.

On the issue of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project that was scrapped by the Chen's government, Su said the issue involves political and economic factors and that the outcome will depend on a decision by Taiwan's Grand Justices. He added that it is incorrect to say that Taiwan will run short of electricity if the plant is not built.

Su also claimed that 70 percent of the Taiwan public are against the opposition alliance's intention to recall the president, which came about in the wake of the announcement of the scrapping of the nuclear plant. He added that he is confident the recall issue will be overcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Bush wins the U.S. presidency, emphasizes wish to build unity across party lines.
The China Times:
Restrictions on mainland investment to be eased; high-tech ventures, cases above US$50 million to be on agenda.
The United Daily News:
Relaxed mainland investment policy will encourage entrepreneurs to keep business roots at home.
The Liberty Times:
President-elect Bush promises to be 'uniter, not divider.'
The China Post:
Bush finally heading to White House.
The Taiwan News:
President-elect Bush vows reconciliation.
The Taipei Times:
Bush urges unity and an end to rancor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 95.42 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Friday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 95.42 points to close at 5,224.74.
Market turnover amounted to NT$31.16 billion (US$0.94 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 15, or the 20th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1711: The plague breaks out in Copenhagen, Denmark.
1891: The Bill of Rights, the first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution, goes into effect.
1915: Noted Taiwan folklore writer Chung Li-ho is born.
1920: China and Austria are admitted to the League of Nations.
1927: The ROC government orders the closure of the Soviet consulate in Shanghai and begins rounding up communists following the attempted communist coup in Canton the day before.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman and premier of the Nationalist government, retires, citing the interests of party unity.
1938: The United States agrees to lend US$25 million to China under a Sino-American oil loan agreement.
1944: Chinese expeditionary forces capture Bhamo in northern Burma.
1946: The United Nations General Assembly decides to set up its permanent headquarters in New York.
1948: France completes the construction of its first nuclear reactor.
1949: The ROC Executive Yuan names Wu Kuo-chen governor of Taiwan.
1952: Beijing rejects India's plan for a Korean armistice.
1961: The United Nations General Assembly votes against a Soviet proposal to admit communist China as a member.
1965: The U.S. Mariner spacecraft flies past Venus and relays data about the planet to scientists on Earth.
1966: Walter Elias Disney -- the U.S. animator, showman and film producer known as "Walt" -- dies at the age of 65.
1970: The first Sino-American Conference on Mainland China is opened in Taipei.
1971: The state-run Bank of China becomes a private bank and changes its name to The International Commercial Bank of China.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1972: The Japanese embassies in Taipei and Kaohsiung are closed.
1973: Tachien Dam, which had been under construction in central Taiwan for four years, becomes operational.
1977: A newly built integrated steel plant of the state-run China Steel Corp. starts operating in Kaohsiung.
1978: President Jimmy Carter announces he will establish diplomatic relations with communist China from January 1, 1979, and break off relations with the Republic of China at the same time.
1978: The "Chang Sheng," the first Taiwan-built 20,000-ton container vessel, is launched in Keelung.
1980: The ROC's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park is inaugurated.
1988: The United Nations General Assembly overwhelmingly calls for the convening of an international Middle East peace conference.
1993: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves a revision of the University Law, which gives more autonomy to colleges and allows students to participate in meetings related to school affairs.
1995: Beijing sentences Wei Jingsheng, a noted dissident, to 14 years in jail for "conspiring to subvert the government," a move that arouses international condemnation.
1999: The U.S. State Department clarifies its stance on the ROC's bid to join the World Health Organization, saying the U.S. supports Taiwan's "meaningful participation," not its membership, in the body.
Confucius: "Think how anxious your parents are when you are sick, and you will know your duty toward them. The duty of a good son nowadays means only to be able to support his parents. But you also keep your dogs and horses alive. If there is no feeling of love and respect, where is the difference?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 95.42 points to close at 5,224.74.

Affected by a drop in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,256.09 and continued to go down due to a prevailing wait-and-see attitude on the part of investors. The bourse fluctuated between 5,264.18 and 5,202.04 during trading.

A total of 1.19 billion stocks worth NT$31.16 billion (US$0.94 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.49 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$36.28 billion (US$1.1 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.4 percent, bank and insurance stocks and textile issues, both at 2.3 percent, construction shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, electrical shares at 1.5 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 1.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 428 to 87, with 78 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 124 points to close at 5,201, with 5,532 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 decreased 115 points to finish at 5,210, with 577 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 104 points to close at 5,220, with five contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,325 for December, 5,325 for next January, 5,324 for next March, 5,340 for next June, and 5,743 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 6.75 points to close at 255.05, with 1,446 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures decreased 6 points to finish at 255, with 152 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 TE futures fell 8.4 points to close at 250, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures moved down 18.4 points to finish at 670.4, with 865 contract transactions, while January 2001 TF futures lost 20.2 points to close at 666.8, with 79 contract transactions.
March 2001 TF futures declined 3 points to finish at 681, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING UNDERTAKING "POLICY OF DISTRACTION": THINK TANK

TEXT.P: To delay or avoid a potential confrontation with the United States, Communist China is undertaking a "policy of distraction," actively seeking to drive a wedge between Washington and its Asian allies, a Texas-based private think tank wrote in a recent analysis.

Stratfor, Inc., pointed out in its Dec. 13 Global Intelligence Update that Communist Chinese Premier Li Peng recently told opposition Japanese politicians in Beijing that Japan must have its own voice in politics and on security issues, adding that Peng also said Japanese forces are sufficient to defend Japan and U.S. forces stationed there are nothing but "a symbol of U.S. hegemony."

Li's comments are part of "an emerging Chinese policy of distraction aimed at the United States," noted the analysis. Beijing is increasingly concerned that its own interests and those of Washington will inevitably clash but is not prepared to confront the United States right now, it noted.
Instead, Stratfor said, Beijing "is seeking ways to undermine the close coordination between Washington and its Asian allies, particularly South Korea and Japan."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA TO HOST AFRICA-ASIA BUSINESS FORUM

TEXT.P: South Africa is set to host the second Africa-Asia Business forum, aimed at bringing companies from the two continents together to set up partnerships and achieve trade deals, in July of next year.

United Nations Development Program Representative John Ohiohenuan said that the forum will help bring African and Asian companies together in order to foster economic growth in sub-Saharan Africa through technology transfers, joint ventures, and financial investments.

Ohiohenuan said the forum will focus primarily on building links through Asian direct investment in Africa, adding that one of the major challenges will be the fact that Asian companies are generally more interested in establishing trade links.
The first Africa-Asia business forum was held in Malaysia in October, 1999 and brought together 230 companies from the two continents.

Asian companies set to participate in the forum include those from India, Pakistan, mainland China, Japan, and South Korea. African private enterprises with enough potential to participate include those from Togo, South Africa, Nigeria, Senegal, Mozambique, Mauritius, Uganda, and Zambia.

Executives attending the forum will also participate in capacity building workshops, aimed at developing their ability to negotiate deals, form strategies and plans, utilize commerce, and understand foreign business, accounting, and legal issues.
Ohiohenuan also said special attempts are being made to identify women entrepreneurs and invite them to attend the forum and capacity building workshops.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHOES TO BE AUCTIONED OFF TO RAISE FUNDS FOR CAMBODIAN ORPHANS

TEXT.P: A total of 5,000 pairs of shoes will be auctioned off this weekend at a charity bazaar in downtown Taipei to raise funds for orphans and homeless children in Cambodia.

The charity bazaar, scheduled to be held at No. 34, Lane 198, Siwei Road between Dec. 17 and Jan. 20, will also have jewelry, Chinese paintings and calligraphy works, T-shirts, cards, CDs, and books on sale, all for the purpose of raising more money for poor children in remote rural areas in Cambodia who lead deprived lives with little chance for an education.

According to Yang Wei-lin, founder and head of the charity Field Relief Agency, which has been working for years to help homeless children in deserted border areas in Cambodia, Laos, Thailand, and Vietnam, bazaar goers will also be able see pictures and videotapes depicting the hardships that these children face.

Also during the bazaar, people will be briefed on an education plan currently being implemented in a mountainous region of Cambodia under the supervision of the Field Relief Agency and also on a women and children rescue plan soon to be initiated in the remote Cambodian-Laos border region, said Yang.

Yang, formerly a flight attendant, said helping these unfortunate children requires manpower and materials, adding that while relief efforts can easily die with a suspension in contributions, her care and compassion for these poor children has never diminished.

Yang said she hopes that, through the bazaar, the well-off citizens of Taiwan will gain a better understanding of the poverty and hopelessness that innocent people in that part of the world face, some of whom are of Chinese origin, and will offer some tiny part of their possessions to the needy.

She retold the heart-rending story of seeing a little girl begging in a market in a border village years ago. The fatherless child, whose mother had also just died, was carrying her six-day old baby brother in a swaddling cloth on her chest. The infant was too weak to cry out in hunger and only lay there with its mouth open and eyes closed.
Yang said that after the little girl left after receiving some money for food, the image of the infant's wide-open mouth and dying face lingered in her mind for a long time.

She thought to herself that money alone won't help these poor souls. "What they need is education," Yang concluded. From that day, she decided to work to help people in these poor areas gain an education and a better chance in life. So she established the Field Relief Agency and began looking for volunteers and donations.

In four years, Yang has helped establish 15 make-shift schools in mountainous areas of Cambodia, has sponsored some 700 children, and has managed to recruit 27 volunteer teachers from Taiwan to teach in those schools.
At Kuang Hua School in Yunshai Village, where 95 percent of the villagers are Hakka people or their descendants, Yang accepted 67 children who had never attended school for even a single day.
The children who attend the schools established by Yang divide their time equally between studying and making a living by farming or making pottery.

Yang also mentioned the touching story of the children at the school offering all the cash they could and asking Yang to send it to Taiwan to help the victims of the deadly earthquake that struck the island on Sept. 21, 1999.

Yang said she could not turn down the compassionate gesture and accepted the money, in tattered and stained small-denomination Cambodian and U.S. bills, valued at about US$75, from the poor and struggling families who sometimes go a whole day without a meal.

After returning to Taiwan, she said, she and her aids tried to change the cash into New Taiwan dollars at the Bank of Taiwan. The bank clerks said the bills were too old and worn and refused to accept them.

Yang then packed the money into a bag and sent it to the county government of Nantou, one of the hardest-hit areas in central Taiwan, with a note on the bag saying "Love from Cambodia. Value: about US$75."

Although only a tiny fraction of the amount of money that poured into Taiwan from around the world after the devastating earthquake struck, the US$75 from the Cambodian village was one of the most touching contributions that Taiwan has ever received, Yang asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER STRESSES CORDIAL TIES WITH PALAU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Tien Hung-mao Friday denied speculation that the Republic of China's diplomatic relations with its West Pacific ally of Palau may be shaky, stressing that relations between the two countries have been cordial.
"We have consistently enjoyed a warm relationship with Palau, and speculation about a possible 'about-face' in the Pacific island nation's foreign policy is unfounded," Tien noted.

The minister was responding to opposition New Party Legislator Elmer Feng's claim that Palau President-elect Tommy E. Remengesau is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Saturday to express his country's dissatisfaction with the ROC's attitude toward Palau.
Feng said at a Legislative Yuan plenary session that as the ROC bet on a "wrong choice" in Palau's Nov. 8 presidential election, Remengesau will voice a protest during his visit.

Moreover, Feng said, the Palau president-elect will also his country's displeasure with the ROC's failure to open an embassy on its territory since the two countries forged diplomatic ties late last year.

Because of all these factors, Feng cautioned the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) that Palau is likely to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. According to Feng, Remengesau may travel to Beijing via Hong Kong after his Taipei visit.
Commenting on Feng's remarks, Tien said Feng might have been misinformed about the purposes of Remengesau's upcoming visit.
Tien said Remengesau is now Palau's vice president who has had outgoing Palau President Kuniwo Nakamura's full support to be his successor.
Noting that Remengesau is no stranger to Taiwan, Tien said, ROC-Palau relations are in good shape and Remengesau's visit has nothing to do with any possible diplomatic "about-face."
Tien would not elaborate on Remengesau's itinerary or agenda here as Remengesau has informed the MOFA of his desire to keep his Taipei visit low profile.
Tien went on to say that he will arrange for Remengesau to meet with ROC lawmakers to brief them on the current state of ROC-Palau relations.

Emphasizing that ROC-Palau relations have been close, Tien said the ROC is scheduled to open its embassy in Palau in January 2001 to facilitate bilateral exchanges and further boost mutual cooperation.

Tien also took advantage of his meeting with Feng on Friday to urge the opposition-dominated legislature to recover a MOFA budget plan for offering a US$30 million loan to Palau to help finance its economic development projects. At a budget screening meeting last week, lawmakers deleted the lending proposal from the government's budgetary plan for the new fiscal year, which begins Jan. 1, 2001.
