DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SUPPORTS PROPOSED LEGISLATIVE YUAN PRESIDENT'S VISIT TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: The major opposition Kuomintang supports a proposed visit to Beijing by a high-profile delegation to be led by Legislative Yuan President and KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT official said Friday.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng said the party fully supports Wang's Beijing visit, which will hopefully take place soon after the Lunar New Year.

Describing Wang as one of the most appropriate choices for the mission, Lin at the same time said he hopes that Beijing will demonstrate an equal degree of enthusiasm and hospitality to Wang and the Legislative Yuan delegation.

Wang's proposed Beijing trip is widely seen as an effective way of redressing the new deadlock between Beijing and Taipei since President Chen Shui-bian took office in May this year, and also as a key to helping resume talks between chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and the head of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

It was learned that Wang had previously not been too enthusiastic about the Beijing trip, only recently changing his attitude after learning that Beijing had demonstrated a plausible degree of sincere enthusiasm for the plan amidst evident support from the Chen administration.

Still somewhat hesitant about the proposed visit, Wang stressed that the Beijing trip, if it indeed occurs, will have to be based on four principles: national needs, popular support, legislative resolution, and equality and dignity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEMICONDUCTOR FIRM TO ESTABLISH FOUNDRY IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's United Microelectronics (UMC) announced plans Friday to establish the world's most advanced 300-mm wafer foundry company in Singapore's Pasir Ris Wafer Fab Park.

UMC and German firm Infineon Technologies AG signed a memorandum of understanding under which the German company will take a minority stake in the company that will operate as a subsidiary of UMC with a planned investment of US$3.6 billion.

The 300-mm plant will be built in two phases, with a total planned production capacity of 40,000 wafers per month. The company will focus on System-on-Chip (SOC) products utilizing advanced World-logic 0.13-um and 0.10 10-um copper/low k process technologies jointly developed by UMC, Infineon and IBM. Groundbreaking for the plant is scheduled for early 2001 with equipment move-in for the first phase scheduled for mid-2002.

UMC and Infineon are both pioneers in the implementation of 300-mm wafer production. Infineon was the first company to ship products from a 300-mm facility, and UMC's joint venture with Hitachi and Trecenti Technologies, was the first pure-play foundry to achieve working silicon for 300-mm wafers, and operates the world's first 300-mm production plant to manufacture functional ICs.

The decision to locate the joint venture in Singapore demonstrates the growing importance of the country as a center for high value-added manufacturing. Singapore is home to numerous advanced wafer foundries and test and assembly facilities. This is the first announcement for a state-of-the-art 300-mm fab on the island and represents the largest investment in the history of its semiconductor industry.
UMC, a world leader in semiconductors, operates seven wafer foundries in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park.

Infineon Technologies AG offers semiconductor and system solutions for applications in the wired and wireless communications markets, for security systems and smart cards, for the automotive and industrial sectors, as well as memory products.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOTS ABSENT FROM FLIGHT SIMULATION

TEXT.P: The three pilots involved in the crash of Singapore Airlines (SIA) flight SQ006 did not show up at a flight simulation Thursday designed to help determine the cause of the accident, sources from the Taoyuan District Prosecutor's Office said Friday.

Soong Kuo-yeh, assistant chief prosecutor at the Taoyuan District Prosecutor's Office, said that the office decided to add a requirement that SIA should also be responsible for the return of the three pilots to Taipei when they are needed for the crash investigation.
The crash killed 83 of the 179 people aboard the jumbo jet that took off at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in stormy weather on the evening of Oct. 31.

The Taoyuan office bowed to international pressure last week and agreed to allow the three pilots to leave Taiwan on condition that the Singapore representative office in Taiwan is obliged to make sure the pilots return to Taipei when they are needed for the investigation.

The pilots -- flight commander Capt. Foong Chee Kong, 41, a Malaysian, and Singaporean co-pilots Latif Cyrano, 36, and Ng Kheng Leng, 38 -- had been prevented from leaving the island by the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office since the day of the crash. Pilots from some foreign airlines threatened to boycott Taiwan airports unless the three pilots were treated according to international precedent.

The new requirements were expected to take another three to four days because additional paperwork is needed. The prosecutors said related papers should be signed by SIA officials of president or general manager levels or higher to enable the pilots to go home.
Soong declined to say whether the prosecutors' decision to impose additional conditions was related to the pilots' absence from the flight simulation sponsored by SIA on Thursday.
At the request of prosecutors, SIA arranged for a cargo plane similar to the ill-fated Boeing 747 passenger plane that crashed to conduct a simulated flight to retrace the path of SQ006.

Prosecutors hoped to gain better understanding of the crash via the simulation in order to determine whether the accident was caused by pilot error, misleading control tower instructions, bad weather or other reasons.
They said they will decide whether the three SIA pilots will be prosecuted for the crash after the investigation into the accident is complete.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-JAPANESE JOINT-VENTURE SYNCHROTRON BEAM LINE INAUGURATED
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A high-energy synchrotron radiation beam line jointly created by the Republic of China and Japan was inaugurated in Hyogo Prefecture Friday to facilitate cutting-edge life science and material research.

The new beam line, believed to be the world's strongest and most powerful synchrotron radiation light source, was co-produced by the ROC's Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (SRRC) and the Spring-8 Light Source under the Japan Synchrotron Radiation Research Institute (JSRRI).
The facility also marks the first time that the ROC has managed to break mainland China's diplomatic embargo to forge a joint venture with Japan in the high-technology field.

ROC National Science Council Chairman Weng Cheng-i, SRRC Director Chen Chien-teh, JSRRI Chairman Yashinori Ihara and Spring-8 Director Hiromichi Kamitsubo jointly presided over the inauguration of the research facility.
Speaking on the occasion, Chen said the new beam line will allow ROC scientists to perform exclusive research in biological structure and state-of-the-art material science from next year.

According to Chen, many Taiwan research teams are planning to travel to Hyogo to use the new synchrotron radiation beam line for experiments in environmental engineering and earth science, as well as research into protein crystalgraphy, high-temperature superconductivity and cutting-edge materials such as magnetic and optical materials.
Chen said the inauguration of the new facility is expected to lead Taiwan into brand new research frontiers in life science and cutting-edge materials development.

Taiwan installed a synchrotron radiation accelerator in October 1993. It can produce third-generation beam line for soft X-ray-related scientific research. The accelerator, however, cannot provide beam line for hard X-ray-related scientific experiments.

The ROC then proposed at the 1996 ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum that all APEC member economies open their synchrotron radiation research facilities for joint research.

The JSRRI's Spring-8 Light Source, inaugurated in October 1997, can produce the world's strongest hard X-rays for research purposes. As Taiwan's SRRC has reached world standards in cutting-edge scientific research, Spring-8 agreed in late 1998 to cooperate with it in building a beam line for biological structure and material science research. The cooperative program also made the SRRC the first foreign research institute to host an exclusive facility at Spring-8.

In addition to cooperation in research hardware construction, Chen said the SRRC will also cooperate with the Japanese research institute in various scientific studies, including protein crystalgraphy, structural biology, cutting-edge materials and non-condensed physics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN YOUNG LAWMAKERS TO FORM EXCHANGE ORGANIZATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Two groups of young lawmakers from Taiwan and Japan have tentatively agreed to form parliamentary organizations to strengthen exchanges between the younger parliamentarians of the two countries, it was announced here Friday.

A group of four legislators from Taiwan led by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Chung-mo met with a group of members of Japan's Lower House led by Koki Kobayashi Thursday at the Headquarters of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) to discuss how to strengthen exchanges and friendship between the younger parliamentarians of the two countries.

Kobayashi said at a press conference jointly sponsored by Kobayashi and Lin at LDP headquarters that the Japanese side will be temporarily named the "Japan-Taiwan Younger Parliamentarians Association." Taiwan has already organized a supra partisan "Taiwan-Japan Parliamentarians Anti-Hegemonic Alliance."
Lin said that the alliance under his leadership comprises 22 members in the Legislative Yuan and is aimed at promoting exchanges between the younger parliamentarians of the two countries.
However, he went on, because the Japanese side expressed a negative opinion about the word "anti-hegemonic" at the meeting, his alliance may consider changing the name.

Both Lin and Kobayashi said that the new parliamentary organization will not become an obstacle for the "Japan-ROC Dietmen Council," which was established to promote unofficial relations between Taiwan and Japan.

Lin also expressed the hope that Republic of China former President Lee Teng-hui can visit Japan soon, and said that Japan should follow the U.S. example by passing legislation similar to the Taiwan Relations Act. Japan should also play a more positive role in helping maintain the security in the Taiwan Strait, he said.
Other members of the ROC delegation included Parris Chang (DPP), Legislator Hsu Jung-su (DPP) and Legislator Chen Chen-hsiung of the main opposition Kuomintang. They arrived in Tokyo Thursday.
They left for home Friday after calling on Japanese civic leaders including Speaker of the House of Representatives Tamisuke Wataneki.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISCUSSION ON ATTENDING APEC MEETING IN MAINLAND CHINA GOES SMOOTHLY

TEXT.P: A discussion on matters concerning the Asia Pacific Economic and Cooperation (APEC) forum meeting scheduled to be held next year in mainland China has gone smoothly, a Republic of China official who is currently visiting the mainland said Friday.

Andrew Hsia, director-general of the Department of International Organizations of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, made the remarks after a meeting with Wu Hailong, Beijing's deputy director of the Department of International Organization and Conferences under the mainland's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Hsia, one of the representatives of 21 APEC members who arrived in Beijing over the past few days for the meeting, exchanged views on the related details of the APEC meeting scheduled to be held in Shanghai.
Hsia said that the communication process has been progressing smoothly so far, and that Taiwan will continue to use the name "Chinese Taipei" as it has in the past for APEC events.

He noted that as the ROC does not have an organization to handle related matters, it has to communicate and exchange views with the mainland at an early date on such procedures as entry and exit to the mainland by ROC delegates.
Hsia departed for Beijing Tuesday via Hong Kong. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.002 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 33.075.
The local currency opened Friday at 33.017 and was traded between 33.017 and 33.090.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$242 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SURVIVAL LIES IN SECURITY, DEMOCRACY, ECONOMY: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A group of scholars attending an international seminar in Taipei agreed Friday that Taiwan's security is closely related to regional developments and that its survival lies in security, democracy and economy.

The one-day seminar, organized by the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank headed by former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, focused discussion on Taiwan security in the year 2000.

Michael Y.M. Kau, a senior advisor of the ROC's National Security Council and a political science professor at U.S. Brown University, said Taiwan should not be isolated in the international community in view of its marvelous achievements in economic development and political democratization.

Torkel Patterson, a senior researcher with the U.S. Center for Strategic and International Studies, said the United States wants to continue constructive engagements with mainland China and would not have any conflicts with its.

On the other hand, Patterson said, the United States also fully respects Taiwan people's choice of democratic lifestyle and values. Moreover, he said, the United States hopes to see Taiwan enjoy a continued economic boom because of Taiwan's crucial strategic location, close bilateral trade ties and Taiwan's clout to Asia-Pacific regional development.

Lin Cheng-yi, director of Academia Sinica's Institute of European and American Studies, said Taiwan's security environment sees significant changes in 2000 which reflect in a sharp increase in the number of papers discussing the possibilities of military conflicts erupting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lin said either side can unilaterally adopt goodwill measures and then ask the other side to make reciprocal response in order to gradually reduce cross-strait tension.

He pointed out that the United States can play a more active role in cross-strait confidence-building process. "The United States can act as a balancer, guarantor and supervisor, and it should remain impartial and ask both Taipei and Beijing to compromise on their disputes," he explained.

Kenneth Boutin, a research fellow with Singapore's Nanyang Technological University, said in the eyes of policymakers of Southeast Asian countries, Taiwan's importance lies in its role in regional economic development as Taiwan has provided the region with financial and technological assistance.

In the political arena, Boutin said, Taiwan's status in Southeast Asia has been affected by mainland China's role in the region. For Southeast Asian countries, Boutin said, they can neither ignore mainland China's political clout nor Taiwan's economic strength. Therefore, he said, promoting improvements in Taiwan-mainland China ties is in the common interest of Southeast Asian countries.

Meanwhile, Hidenori Ijiri, a professor with Tokyo University of Foreign Studies, said Japan attaches great importance to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and that peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes has been a major field of Japan's preventive diplomacy.

Ijiri further said Japanese scholars and politicians have begun to use new thinking to deal with the Taiwan Strait issue. In the past, he said, the Japanese tended to mull cross-strait disputes from either "pro-Taiwan" or "pro-China" viewpoints. Nowadays, he said, the Japanese have begun to separate Taiwan-Japan engagements from Japan-(mainland) China relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Lin Li-ming and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong research institute has invited Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou to visit Hong Kong in February to attend a dinner to celebrate the institute's fifth founding anniversary, its chairman said Friday.
Hong Kong Policy Research Institute Chairman Paul Yip said Ma will give a speech on "the outlook for exchanges among cities of mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong."

The institute will also invite local and international experts in business, political and financial circles, as well as scholars from colleges and universities to exchange views on the relationship between Hong Kong and Taipei.
Yip last arranged for Ma to visit Hong Kong in March, 1999, setting off an upsurge in exchanges between the two cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PITCHES FOR BEIJING'S POSITIVE INTERACTION TO EXPAND 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: The Republic of China looks forward to seeing mainland China adopt positive measures in connection with its planned opening of direct "mini three links" across the narrow Taiwan Strait, a senior mainland affairs official said Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) told a news conference that the planned direct trade, mail and shipping links between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Mawei, commonly known as "mini three links," can be expanded only when mainland China is willing to adopt complementary measures.
According to the MAC-drafted plan, Taiwan will unilaterally implement its direct "mini three links" opening measures from the beginning of next year.

As mainland China still refuses to resume dialogue with Taiwan, Lin said, the enforcement will initially focus on "legalizing" small-amount trade between fishermen on both sides of the Taiwan Strait that has been going on illegally for years.

"The enforcement will also include measures that we can unilaterally implemented," Lin explained, adding that mainland China's positive interaction is needed to expand the scope of "mini three links."

Asked about the possible currency exchange issues following the opening of "mini three links," Lin said in the initial stage, only the ROC's currency -- the New Taiwan dollar -- can be used in the ROC territory.
In the Kinmen-Matsu area, Lin said, traders can convert their foreign currencies into the New Taiwan dollar. But he stressed that the foreign currencies mainly refer to the U.S. dollar.

In the later stage, Lin said, the ROC government will consider allowing the circulation of the mainland currency -- renminbi -- in the Kinmen-Matsu area under two premises -- mainland China is willing to accept the New Taiwan dollar and the sides develop a currency settlement mechanism. "No timetable is set for the beginning of this measure," he added.

As for the government's plan to ease its "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland China-bound investment, Lin said the relaxed policy will offer local entrepreneurs greater freedom in deciding the items they want to invest on the mainland while highlighting the spirit of "keeping their business roots" in Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Lin said the ROC hopes that the new U.S. government under President-elect George W. Bush will play a more active role in balancing and stabilizing relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Lin said he believes that the United States can help bridge cross-strait negotiations while refraining from involvement in substantive talks.
Lin further said he does not expect that the incoming Bush administration would make any fundamental changes to the current U.S. policy on cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

Noting that the ROC and the United States have common interest in upholding democracy, human rights and economic prosperity as well as maintaining Asia-Pacific regional peace and stability, Lin said the ROC hopes to further strengthen cooperation with the new U.S. administration. (BY Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FOUNDING CHAIRMAN DIES

TEXT.P: Chiang Peng-chien, a member of the Control Yuan and founding chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), died Friday of pancreatic cancer at the age of 61.

National Taiwan University Hospital said Chiang was diagnosed as suffering from a pancreatic tumor last year. He maintained a stable condition after chemotherapy, but a regular checkup in June this year found that the tumor had relapsed.

President Chen Shui-bian said he was saddened to learn of Chiang's death and lauded him as a selfless man who contributed greatly to Taiwan's democratic development. He also eulogized Chiang's "lifelong pursuit of his ideals."
The president said that Chiang never sought the limelight, but quietly pursued his ideals, making him a paradigm of the Taiwan people.

Ever since his early days as a lawyer, Chiang dedicated himself to the promotion of human rights and was a member of the legal team that also included now-Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian, which acted as the defense during the 1979 Formosa Incident trial.
He also campaigned on a "one-term legislator and lifelong non-partisan people" slogan and won election as a legislator in 1983. He honored his words by not seeking reelection three years later.

But he was most credited for spearheading the formation of the opposition DPP in 1986 and serving as its inaugural chairman. During the grim atmosphere of the martial law era, he led the DPP through its initial difficulties and great adversity.

The Formosa Incident occurred on the night of Dec. 10, 1979, when a group of opposition activists clashed with police during a torchlight parade to observe International Human Rights Day. Sixteen people were injured during the clash.

Two days later, many of the people who took part in the parade were arrested, tried by a military court and jailed. Among them were Annette Lu, who became the nation's vice president this year, Chen Chu, who is currently chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs and former DPP chairmen Lin Yi-hsiung and Shih Ming-teh.

The incident, which took place in the Kuomintang-instigated "white terror" atmosphere, is generally thought to have been a turning point in Taiwan's political history and an event that eventually led to the lifting of martial law, as well as the ending of a ban on new political parties and newspapers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW-DESIGN NT$ 500 NOTES HIT STREET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new-style NT$500 notes went into circulation Friday at financial institutions islandwide, somewhat earlier than originally scheduled.
The Central Bank of China (CBC) had intended to issue the new reddish-brown notes in January, in time for Chinese New Year.
As there was no limit to the number of notes each customer could withdraw, there was no stampede for the new notes and little fanfare.
The current NT$500 bill versions, designed in 1976 and 1981, will continue in circulation until June 30, 2002.
As well as a new graphic design, the new bills also have a host of anti-counterfeiting features.
The CBC issued a new-design NT$1,000 note in July and is scheduled to issue a new-design NT$100 note next July and a completely new NT$200 bill in January 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWYERS URGE VICE PRESIDENT, LOCAL MAGAZINE TO SET ASIDE DIFFERENCES

TEXT.P: Taiwan Bar Association Executive Director Chu Sheng-chun Friday urged Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu and local newsmagazine The Journalist to set aside their legal differences "for the greater good of the nation."

Chu and a group of attorneys held a news conference to announce their common desire to see the dust settled so that the vice president can concentrate on affairs of the state while the weekly can focus on its duty to provide impartial news coverage.
He urged Lu to be magnanimous and the magazine to respond with good will so that the "workings of the country and society can get back on track."

Lu and The Journalist have been engrossed in a legal battle over the magazine's Nov. 16 report that Lu "tried to finish off the president" by calling the magazine with a story that President Chen Shui-bian was having an affair with one of his young female staffers. On Dec. 4, Lu's legal team demanded that the magazine openly apologize by Dec. 10 over what it claimed to be "obviously false and malicious" reporting on Lu.

However, The Journalist claims to have proof that the voice on the phone was Lu's, and only responded with a Dec. 8 letter that Lu's legal team described as an attempt to "distort the definition of press freedom" and "mislead the general public" without any kind of reflection on the ethical code of professional journalists.

Lu's six-member legal team and 13 legal advisers -- including her elder brother Lu Chuan-sheng -- announced Thursday that she will file a civil suit against the magazine, seeking NT$100 million (US$3 million) in compensation, and does not rule out the possibility of pressing criminal charges.

Chu said that he had already tried to persuade Lu's brother not to press the case. However, he added that it appeared no single "outsider" can control the events, which led him and others in the legal profession to try to appeal to both sides openly as a group and to serve as a moderating force if necessary.
Chu declared on behalf of the other lawyers that they fully respect the vice president's litigation rights but also respect journalistic freedom.

He went on to say that the lawyers understand that Lu is pursuing legal action to protect her reputation and that The Journalist is firmly holding its ground in an attempt to preserve the freedom of the press.

However, he said that political bickering in Taiwan has continued non-stop, adding to the social unrest and economic woes. Out of a "sense of responsibility," he added, the lawyers believe any action that may lead to further social disorder should be avoided.
Chu said that the lawyers are willing to be moderators and help bring the whole affair to an end as quickly as possible while heeding the principles of human rights and journalistic freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister David Lee has met with the leaders of Macedonia's ruling alliance to reaffirm bilateral ties during his four-day trip to the former Yugoslavian republic. Lee's trip began on Tuesday.

According to an ROC Foreign Ministry press release, Lee's visit came in the wake of recent changes in the make up of Macedonia's coalition government. Macedonia is one of two European diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, with the other being the Holy See.

According to the press release, Lee met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubcho Georgievski of the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (VMRO), Democratic Party of Albanians (DPA) leader Arben Xaferi, and Risto Gusterov, head of the Liberal Party (LP) of Macedonia, which has replaced the Democratic Alternative (DA) party as the third member of the ruling coalition.

Lee also called on Deputy Prime Minister Zoran Krstevski, Defense Minister Ljuben Paunoski, Economics Minister Besnik Fetai, and Parliament Speaker Stojan Andov. He later met with acting Foreign Minister Viktor Gaber to exchange opinions on the progress of various cooperative projects between Taiwan and Macedonia.

The press release added that because Macedonian products are scheduled to begin receiving tariff-free export benefits in the 22 countries of the European Union and the European Free Trade Association on Jan. 1, 2001, the ROC-invested Skopje Export Processing Zone will be a "perfect springboard" for Taiwan's industries to dive into the European market.

According to the Macedonian Information Agency (MIA), Lee said at a press conference Thursday that cooperation between Macedonia and Taiwan is "good" and that there is no reason to disrupt diplomatic ties.

Questioned on Macedonian President Boris Trajkovski's statement that "only economic cooperation is possible between Macedonia and Taiwan," Lee said that the remark had been "misinterpreted," according to the MIA report.

According to MIA, Lee later commented on a recent statement by Macedonian Foreign Minister Srdjan Kerim about the settling of relations between Macedonia and mainland China. "I have never heard of any country which has established relations with both the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China," Lee reportedly said.

MIA also quoted Lee as reporting that Taiwan has provided credit, financial assistance for hospitals, scholarships, computer equipment, education and investment in Macedonia's "Bunardjik" free trade zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENSUS OF TAIWAN AREA TO BE TAKEN SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The government will conduct a census of the Taiwan area Saturday, with the survey to include all of the offshore islands under its control, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Friday.
Ninety thousand public servants and volunteers will jointly take the census, which the government sponsors every 10 years.

Subject to the census are Taipei and Kaohsiung, which are special municipalities under the direct jurisdiction of the Executive Yuan, and the 23 counties and cities under the Taiwan Provincial Government, including the offshore islands of Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

People who have lived in the Taiwan area for longer than three months, including foreign residents and laborers, will be included in the census, the DGBAS said. It added that the area's houses will also be targeted.
The DGBAS pledged that it will keep the data collected through the census confidential, and provide it to the government for reference in carrying out administrative affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 ELECTED OFFICIALS PROSECUTED IN CRACKDOWN ON 'BLACK GOLD'

TEXT.P: Some 30 elected representatives and officials were prosecuted in a crackdown on "black gold" between June 1 and December 10, the Ministry of Justice announced Friday.

The ministry made the figures public following an inspection of its operations by Premier Chang Chun-hsiung. The new government has made the crackdown on "black gold" -- government links to organized crime -- one of its top priorities since its inauguration May 20.

Justice officials said they've achieved substantive results during the past few months. They said their investigations have been indiscriminate, adding that they have acted in cases in which they find evidence of illegal activities. They stressed that they have implemented the crackdown without regard for any suspect's rank or party affiliation.
They also urged all investigators to follow proper legal procedures and operate under the principle of human rights protection, so as to maintain public support for the crackdown on "black gold."

DOC.HEADLINE: VOLUNTEERS SHARE EXPERIENCES

TEXT.P: An ambassador's wife and Springfield, Illinois' Citizen of the Year shared their experiences as longtime volunteers Friday, a day before the scheduled opening of the government-sponsored Millennium Cultural Volunteering Seminar.

Celestina Diaz de Valdez, wife of the Paraguayan ambassador to the Republic of China, is currently a volunteer at the Taipei Municipal Zoo, while Guerry L. Suggs, who was invited to speak at the seminar organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs, has been a volunteer for over 25 years and is currently an Illinois State Museum trustee.

Suggs said that volunteering in what is now the United States can be traced back to 1641, adding that a 1995 Gallup poll showed that over half of American adults have done volunteer work at one time or another.
Suggs went on to say that volunteering is also a good way to meet new people when one moves to a new community.
"Volunteering can be considered as second nature to Americans," Suggs said, adding that it is a "way of life" and a kind of social responsibility.

Valdez, who has been in Taiwan for three years and recently volunteered to donate her time and knowledge of animal care to the city, said that being a volunteer is the most direct and meaningful way to promote exchanges between people.

Explaining simply that she likes animals, Valdez said she began to devote her time to the zoo two months ago. Before that, she had also volunteered to provide guidance in English courses at a local elementary school attended by one of her three children.

Her children do not attend private foreign schools, but rather local ones. She explained that local public schools give them the chance to mix with Taiwanese students, which will give them a better understanding of Taiwan's culture.
Despite a lack of monetary or material rewards, she said that a volunteer can garner a sense of satisfaction from cultural exchanges and learning about different languages, lifestyles, and customs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INT'L ANALYSTS: POL. INSTABILITY TO SLOW TAIWAN GDP GROWTH IN 2001

TEXT.P: Political instability in Taiwan will dampen the nation's annual economic growth to 5.2 percent in 2001 following growth of 6.4 percent in 2000, according to a report published by The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU), an international economic analysis firm.

In its "2001: country by country" report, EIU also forecast that Taiwan consumer prices will rise by an average of 1.7 percent in 2001. The local currency will weaken and the current account surplus will fall to only $US2.1 billion in 2001 from US$3 billion this year, it added.
The report noted that an "unprecedented degree" of political instability will also disrupt Taiwan's relations with mainland China.

Weak share prices will reduce the scope for companies to raise equity finance, creating pressure for weaker firms, which may find that banks are restricting credit because of their high levels of non-performing loans, it said.

But the report also pointed out that the high sales and export growth achieved by many of Taiwan's electronics firms in 2000 will prompt continued capacity-increasing investment in the sector. Private-sector investment growth is expected to increase further, as high-tech companies upgrade their production facilities to supply higher-specification products.

It also forecast that government projects will play a part in this robust investment growth, and predicted that the new administration will honor the wide-ranging market-opening commitments made by the previous government in its attempt to secure membership in the World Trade Organization.

The report said Taiwan's political instability in 2001 stems from Mr. Chen Shui-bian's victory in the March 2000 presidential election and his Democratic Progressive Party's failure to gain a majority in the Legislative Yuan, which is still dominated by the Kuomintang.

The report said that Chen's hand will be strengthened if the Democratic Progressive Party improves its position following the legislative elections in late 2001. An increase in the number of DPP legislators in the poll would allow the president to introduce more of the party's members into the Cabinet, and calm tensions between the Legislative and Executive Yuans. (by Mark Ou)

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS FOR BUILDING CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY MUTUAL-TRUST MECHANISM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian called for the establishment of a military mutual-trust mechanism Friday so as to avoid misunderstandings and misjudgment on both sides.

Chen made the call while meeting a group of foreign scholars who were taking part in a one-day forum titled "Taiwan Security in the Year 2000: Retrospect and Prospects," which was sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute.
Chen said that peace in the Taiwan Strait is the pillar of security for the Asian-Pacific region and therefore in the interests of the United States.
The President stressed that ever since his inauguration on May. 20, he has done his best to improve cross-strait relations.
By exercising self-restraint and not provoking or challenging mainland China, he has successfully prevented the cross-trait ties from deteriorating, he said.

Chen added that his next step will be to begin handling the cross-strait ties in accordance with the consensus of the "three understandings and four suggestions" -- the conclusion reached recently by the Presidential Advisory Group on Cross-strait Relations.

Chen noted that the body's consensus includes that any change to Taiwan's status quo must be agreed upon by the people of Taiwan in accordance with democratic procedures, and that an official response to mainland China's "one China" principle should be determined in line with the Republic of China Constitution.
The president emphasized that Taiwan-mainland relations should not be characterized by "one side trying to destroy the other," but rather by both sides coming up with a "win-win" situation.

In answering questions raised by the visitors, Chen said that the leaders of both Taiwan and the mainland should sit down now and jointly seek to come up with a mutually-acceptable definition of "one China."
He also urged the United States to play a more active role in promoting peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Forum participants included Dr. Desmond J. Ball, professor of Strategic and Defense Studies Centre at National Australian University; professor Michael B. Yahuda, convenor of the International Relations Department at The London School of Economics and Political Science; and Dr. Hidenori Ijiri, professor at Tokyo University of Foreign Studies.

DOC.HEADLINE: '3 DIRECT LINKS' IMPERATIVE AFTER TAIPEI, BEIJING JOIN WTO

TEXT.P: The "three direct links" across the Taiwan Strait will be imperative and cross-strait trade will expand quickly following the entry of Taipei and Beijing into the World Trade Organization (WTO), said several participants at a seminar Friday.
The mainland China-based web firm Sina.com held a seminar Friday on ways to take advantage of the mainland Chinese market through e-commerce.

P.K. Chiang, executive officer at the National Policy Research Foundation, stressed that Taiwan businessmen can enjoy a superior position in the future only by creating high value-added products through the use of the "knowledge-based economy."

Schive Chi, an adviser to the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, noted that "regional economies" have gradually come to play a major role in the world's macro-economy. The "three direct links" with mainland China and further Taiwan investment in mainland China will be conducive to Taiwan's economic development and the improvement of the island's industries, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 16, or the 21st day of the 11th of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Boston residents dump 342 chests of tea worth 9,000 British pounds aboard a British ship overboard in Boston harbor in the so-called "The Boston Tea Party" incident.
1809: Napoleon Bonaparte divorces Josephine Beauharnais because she is not able to provide him with an heir.
1902: An earthquake racks Turkestan in Central Asia, killing 4,000 people.
1920: An earthquake estimated at over 8 points on the Richter scale devastates Kansu Province in China, killing 180,000 people and becoming one of the worse natural disasters of all time.
1922: Tu Chung-ming graduates from Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to earn a doctorate during the Japanese occupation of Taiwan.
1944: German troops begin the "Battle of the Bulge" in the Ardennes area of Belgium during World War II.
1949: Chinese Communist Party Chairman Mao Tse-tung visits the Soviet Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite, the first satellite purely for the purpose of meteoric research.
1963: Yen Chia-kan, new premier of the Republic of China, assumes office.
1971: After a war against rebels and their Indian allies, Pakistani forces surrender East Pakistan, which soon becomes the independent nation of Bangladesh.
1971: Foreign Minister S. K. Chow and Bolivian Foreign Minister Dr. Mario R. Gutierrez sign the Sino-Bolivian Scientific Technical Cooperation Agreement and the Sino-Bolivian Scientific Agriculture Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1975: Kang Sheng, deputy chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1976: The 16-member Korean Pacific Cosmetics Company women's basketball team arrives in Taipei for an 11-day tour.
1976: A nine-member team headed by Hsieh Ching-chung, president of the Republic of China Cycling Association, leaves for Costa Rica to take part in an international race.
1976: Everett Drumright, former U.S. ambassador to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei for a brief visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo strongly condemns the U.S. decision to sever diplomatic relations with the Republic of China in favor of the Beijing regime.
1986: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revised provisions to laws governing medical doctors to establish a system of full time doctors.
1988: The United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization hold their first meeting in Tunis.
1989: A hijacked Air China plane is forced to land in Japan's Fukuoka airport. Hijacker Chang Chen-hai, who was injured after being pushed off the plane, is arrested by Japanese police.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan presides over the inauguration ceremony of the Southern Link Railway.
1991: The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits is set up in Beijing, with Wang Daohan as its chairman.
1992: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl announces 17.6 billion marks (US$11.2 billion) worth of debt relief for Russia.
1995: The presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia sign a peace treaty in Paris, ending years of civil war in the Bosnian region.
1995: British geologists say they have pinpointed the location of the biblical cities of Sodom and Gomorrah on a Dead Sea peninsula.
1996: A South Korean court of appeal reduces the sentences for former President Chun Doo Hwan to life in prison and former President Roh Tae Woo to 17 years in prison on the grounds that they had contributed to the democratic development in South Korea.
1999: The seventh ROC-New Zealand trade consultation conference opens in Taipei, with the two sides agreeing to ink accords in several fields.
Confucius: "You look at how a man acts; consider his motives; find out his tastes. How can a man hide himself; how can he hide himself from you? If a man will constantly go over what he has acquired and keep continually adding to it new acquirements, he may become a teacher of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 90.64 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Saturday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 90.64 points to close at 5,134.1.
Market turnover amounted to NT$28.2 billion (US$0.86 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES DEVELOPING BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense on Saturday denied reports that Taiwan may be developing nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons of mass destruction.

Vice Defense Minister Sun Tao-yu denied an analysis report released recently by Canada's national security and intelligence bureau that identifies some 10 nations, including Taiwan, as being suspected of developing chemical or biological weapons.
The Canadian intelligence report even pointed out that Taiwan has so far developed 36 types of bacteria to be used for biological warfare.

Calling the report "absolutely wrong," Sun reiterated the Republic of China's set policy of not developing nor owning nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons, stressing that this position will not change.

Sun added, however, that although Taiwan will never develop nor own nuclear, chemical or biological weapons, it has researched and developed anti-chemical and anti-biological warfare equipment and related know-how.

Meanwhile, Sun said, the long-planned Military Procurement Bureau, which will combine the existing Military Procurement Bureau, the military Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology, and the General Headquarters into one agency, is expected to be formally established in one year.

A preparatory department responsible for the planning of the establishment of the cross-sectional bureau, which is expected to have a staff of some 8,000 people, is scheduled to become operational on Feb. 1, Sun added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 90.64 points to close at 5,134.1.
Affected by a downward streak in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 5,179.46 and fluctuated between 5,205.51 and 5,131.21 during trading.

A total of 0.98 billion stocks worth NT$28.2 billion (US$0.86 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.19 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$31.16 billion (US$0.94 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.9 percent, textile issues at 2.5 percent, construction stocks at 2.4 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.2 percent, cement stocks at 1.7 percent, electrical shares at 1.5 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.7 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 480 to 45, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Saturday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for December moved down 65 points to close at 5,136, with 4,951 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for January 2001 decreased 95 points to finish at 5,115, with 966 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 80 points to close at 5,140, with three contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Saturday at 5,201 for December, 5,210 for next January, 5,220 for next March, 5,216 for next June, and 5,619 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
December TE futures moved down 4.3 points to close at 250.75, with 1,318 contract transactions, while January 2001 TE futures decreased 5 points to finish at 250, with 344 contracts changing hands.
June 2001 TE futures edged up 0.1 points to close at 250.1, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
December TF futures moved down 6.4 points to finish at 664, with 734 contract transactions, while January 2001 TF futures lost 6.0 points to close at 660, with 178 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC FACTORY OPENS IN PANAMA'S FORT DAVID EPZ
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 15 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Colon's provincial governor and the mayor of Colon City jointly presided over a Taiwan businessman's recent factory-opening ceremony in an export processing zone (EPZ) that was established in cooperation with the Republic of China.

Governor Luciana de Policani and Mayor Jorge Boedanea congratulated Tu Chien-chung for launching his second plastic factory in Panama's Fort David EPZ and urged other ROC businessmen to follow suit to help promote Panama's economic development.

The Panamanian officials called on Taiwan businessmen to make their own investments and establish their own factories within the EPZ in order to create more employment opportunities for Panamanian citizens in the region.
In addition to the ROC-Panama EPZ joint venture, Colon is also home to a free trade zone where over 300 companies enjoy tariff-free import and export benefits.

Tu told the Panamanian officials and the 30-some ROC diplomatic officials and businessmen at the ribbon-cutting ceremony that the plastic mold injection system in his new factory was imported from Taiwan and that it is the most advanced system of its kind in the central American and Caribbean region, capable of producing 2,000 plastic chairs a day.

Although the almost fully automated factory does not require a lot of manpower, expanded production in the future will provide 50 to 70 employment opportunities for Panama's third largest city, where the unemployment rate runs as high as 30 percent, Tu said.

A former ROC military attache to Chile and Argentina, Tu is fluent in Spanish and was first persuaded by former ROC Economics Minister P.K. Chiang to head up Fort David's administrative office when the EPZ was established in 1996. He later started his own manufacturing business in a region mostly dominated by import and export-centered companies.

He urged the ROC government to provide more assistance to Taiwan businessmen who invest in nations with which the Republic of China has formal diplomatic ties because, in his view, hiring local workers is also a kind of diplomatic investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VICE CHAIRMAN DENIES ORGANIZING ECONOMICS SOCIETY

TEXT.P: The number two man in the major opposition Kuomintang denied Saturday that he is organizing a finance and economics society that will offer tips to help redress the existing financial and economic problems that the new government is facing.
KMT Vice Chairman Vincent Siew disclosed, however, that he is actively involved in research work pushing for the establishment of a common market across the Taiwan Strait.

Siew, who had served as the head of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Mainland Affairs Council before serving as the premier from September 1997 to May 2000, has in recent months advocated the idea that trade should be the axis of cross-strait relations and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should establish a common market.

Siew, a seasoned expert in economic affairs, said that when the time is ripe, he and his friends will announce the establishment of a foundation that will jointly promote the idea of a cross-strait common market.
Siew categorically denied that he has met with former President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui in recent days to discuss ways to help the new government solve Taiwan's financial and economic problems.
He also dismissed allegations that he is organizing his own society because of his walking "on a different path" from KMT Chairman Lien Chan.
He said that he is content with his current life of teaching, writing, and researching.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPEAKER RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF EX-PRESIDENT FORMING NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng Saturday ruled out the possibility of former President Lee Teng-hui and his supporters forming a new political party.
Wang, also a vice chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), said he has "100%" or even "10,000%" not heard of such kind of information.
Wang, who is widely known to have maintained close ties with Lee, also a former KMT chairman, said he doesn't believe that Lee's supporters would form a new political party.
"If that is true, the move would certainly hurt the KMT's unity and strength," Wang said, adding he is convinced that such a scenario is unlikely to become reality.

Speculation that Lee's supporters might split away from the KMT to form a new party arose after Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank, suggested that current ruling and opposition parties merge among themselves to become a mainstream party that can command a comfortable majority in the legislature to maintain domestic political stability.

Liu, a Lee protege who once served as the KMT's top financial manager, said he believes that no domestic political party would be able to win more than half of seats in the legislature after the next parliamentary election slated for late 2001.
In his view, Liu said, the existence of a number of small parties would hinder domestic political stability and smooth government operation.

Noting that Taiwan cannot afford a war of attrition among rivaling political parties, Liu said Taiwan needs a major political party that can represent mainstream public opinion and control majority seats in the legislature to maintain political stability and facilitate domestic economic development.

Liu said Taiwan should learn from Japanese experience in party restructuring. According to Liu, Japan's current Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) was formed through merger of two parties more than 30 years ago. The LDP then managed to take the helm of the Japanese government for three decades and transform Japan into a global economic powerhouse.

Since President Chen Shui-bian took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, Taiwan has been plagued by political wrangling between Chen's minority government and the opposition-dominated legislature.
The KMT still controls a firm majority in the 220-seat legislature after losing the presidency to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which holds hardly one-third of the legislative seats.

Judging from the current domestic political situation, Liu said he does not think that any local party, including the KMT, the DPP and two other opposition parties -- the People First Party and the New Party -- would be able to win more than half of the parliamentary seats in next year's election.

Therefore, Liu said he hopes that existing political parties can merge into a large new party to help ensure political stability and fast economic development following next year's parliamentary election.

Liu, a trained economist, said he himself has no interest in organizing a new party. "Former President Lee is also unlikely to assume such a mission. He would at most agree to serve as a spiritual leader of the proposed new party," Liu said, adding that he hopes to see younger politicians, such as President Chen, push for the formation a mainstream party to maintain domestic political stability and ensure smooth economic development which is Taiwan's lifeline.
