Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$67 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BEEFING UP SECURITY ON OFFSHORE KINMEN AND MATSU

TEXT.P: The Republic of China National Police Administration (NPA) is moving to increase its preparedness in maintaining national security and social order on the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu as Taiwan prepares to open the "mini three links" with mainland China in the near future, NPA sources said Saturday.

In the face Taiwan's imminent implementation of direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's port cities of Xiamen and Mawei, the NPA has mapped out plans aimed at reinforcing national security and social order on the islands, NPA officials said.

In a briefing to Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, NPA officials said initial attention will be focused on Kinmen's Liaoluo Bay and Matsu's Fuao Bay where a public safety mechanism responsible for reacting to emergencies or any sudden unexpected situations will be set up.

Meanwhile, to prevent mainland Chinese citizens from conducting illicit activities that threaten to undermine the security and social order on Kinmen and Matsu, a notification system connecting local governments, law enforcement authorities, and local citizen's boroughs will also be established before long.

To prevent mainlanders from sneaking into Taiwan proper after legally landing on Kinmen or Matsu, the officials said that all entries of mainland citizens visiting the offshore counties will come with identified entry and exit date.

For her part, Interior Minister Chang said she fully understands the pressure that Kinmen and Matsu security and customs authorities are facing at a time when the "mini three links" are set to be implemented.

She said she will press the Executive Yuan to pay more attention to the real and urgent needs of Kinmen and Matsu, stressing that extra funds and manpower are definitely required at the present time in order to ensure a smooth implementation of the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD LEAGUE FOR FREEDOM AND DEMOCRACY HOLDS ROC CHAPTER ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday in a written statement to the ROC chapter of the World League for Freedom and Democracy that the league should continue to share Taiwan's democratic experiences with the rest of the world.

Chen said in the congratulatory statement, which was delivered at the chapter's general assembly, that to rule by democracy is a global trend that is the most suitable way of life for mankind at the moment. Freedom and human rights are universal values that should be given attention and guarantees by all governments, he added.

The president said that the Republic of China on Taiwan has experienced countless difficulties and obstacles over the past 50 years of promoting democracy and developing economic prosperity. Today's law and order, he continued, is the fruit of every citizen's labor and as such should be cherished.
Creating a stable, peaceful, secure, and dignified living environment is the new government's primary goal, he said.
Chen urged the league's ROC chapter to reach out to all the freedom-loving people in the world and strive together for mankind's common welfare and peace.

ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh also attended the general assembly, which was presided over by the chapter's president Yao Eng-chi, who concurrently serves as the vice president of the Legislative Yuan.

Yao is currently embroiled in a dispute with former Tamkang University President Clement C.P. Chang over who is the rightful president of the league -- formerly an anti-communist branch of the government. Both claim to be the legally elected league president because two separate elections were held by their respective camps' supporters at the same time in November.

Yao said that he is willing to invite Chang to be the league's honorary chairman who is in charge of all league affairs excluding those of the local chapters, adding that the two of them can split the government-allotted budget. However, Chang has not agreed to such an arrangement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR-GENERAL ACCUSED OF ILLEGALLY DETAINING RETIRED OFFICER

TEXT.P: The son and daughter of retired Vice Adm. Lei Hsueh-ming pressed charges Saturday against the state public prosecutor general for "illegally detaining" Lei since Sept. 24 to question his alleged role in a naval procurement graft case.

Lei Chun and Ms. Lei Chien first submitted a plea at the Taipei District Court urging the judge to immediately release their father because of a Taiwan High Court ruling the previous day that denied a district prosecutor's request to continue holding the aging Lei, 73, incommunicado.

To avoid encroaching on the elder Lei's human rights, Lei Chun said that there should be no delay in releasing his father as the high court ruling effectively rescinded a previous court order allowing the prosecutors to hold him in custody.

Furthermore, Lei said that detaining his father was originally intended as a way to assist in solving the graft case. However, the elder Lei has not been interviewed once by the special task force assigned to investigate the case during his two months spent in isolation, Lei added.

Later in the day, Lei turned to the district prosecutor's office to lay charges against Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa, Taiwan High Court prosecutor Hung Wei-hua, and Taipei district prosecutor Hsueh Chung-hsing for what he alleges is their illegal detention of the elder Lei and their violation of his rights.

The retired vice admiral has been accused by the special task force of first concealing the price quoted by a French shipyard that built the Lafayette missile frigates that the Republic of China Navy purchased, giving a fabricated higher quote and then reporting a false final procurement price from which he received kickbacks.

Although he was directly involved in the entire ship purchasing evaluation process as a former director of the ROC Navy's weapon acquisition programs, Lei has denied masterminding or covering up any plans to fabricate the purchase price.

The special investigation task force was ordered by President Chen Shui-bian on July 31 to look into the case after press reports in France said that huge kickbacks were paid to Taiwan officials involved in the frigate purchase.

The controversial procurement scandal first received public attention after the 1994 death of ROC Navy Capt. Yin Ching-feng, who was the executive secretary of the navy's weapons acquisition programs at the time of his death.

He is widely believed to have been murdered because he was about to blow the whistle on corrupt officers, but a six-year investigation into his death by a joint military and police task force turned up little evidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL RESIDENCE OPENED FOR VISIT BY MENTALLY CHALLENGED KIDS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's official residential compound in downtown Taipei was opened for visits by journalists and a group of mentally challenged children Saturday.

This was the first time that the local news media was offered a glimpse into the Republic of China president's tightly guarded official residence at the intersection of Chungching S. Road and Aikuo W. Road near the Presidential Office.

President Chen and First Lady Wu Shu-chen showed up at the main entrance to greet the visitors. Chen then served as a guide, leading the visitors to tour the complex's main building where the first family will live for the rest of the president's four-year tenure.
Chen and his family have actually been living in their own home on Taipei's Mingsheng E. Road since he took office in May because the presidential residence has been undergoing renovations.
Chen said the main building of the compound has not undergone any major changes besides the addition of certain facilities, including an elevator, for the convenience of his wheelchair-confined wife.

The president's aides said that renovations to the two-story main building have been completed and that the first family will be able to move into its new home once refurbishments of the security guards' dormitory adjacent to the main building are finalized.
According to Chen's aides, the first family will move into the official residence sometime between Christmas and the Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 24.

The compound of the presidential residence covers a land area of about 18,000 square feet. It has a spacious courtyard and garden where a number of wood carvings and stone sculptures created by noted artist Ju Ming are on display. Chen's aides said all the exhibits in the garden were lent by their creator for a one-year exhibition.

The first floor of the main building includes a drawing room and a dining room. On the main wall of the drawing room hangs a landscape oil painting featuring Mt. Kuanyin (the Chinese goddess of mercy) located in northern Taiwan. The painting was created by Lee Tze-fan, the father of Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist.

President Chen jokingly described the drawing room as a "hall of Taiwan images" because all of the paintings and other decorations on display were created by Taiwanese artists and feature local scenes and themes.

Chen said all the paintings in the drawing room were borrowed from his friends for a one-year display. As all of the works are considered invaluable, they have been insured for NT$150 million (US$4.55 million).
The second floor of the main building is comprised mainly of bedrooms, which were not open to the media during this visit.

After giving a guided tour of the main building, President Chen and his wife proceeded to the courtyard to watch dance performances put on by a group of mentally challenged children. Chen said he was moved by the children's performances as they had obviously put a lot of time and effort into rehearsing and practicing their dance skills.
At the conclusion of the performances, the president presented stamp albums and wrist watches to the children as gifts.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETIRED WARSHIP SUNK IN WATERS OFF PENGHU AS ARTIFICIAL REEF

TEXT.P: A retired warship was intentionally sunk in waters off Taiwan's offshore county of Penghu Saturday to form an artificial reef and facilitate conservation of the island's offshore fishery resources.

The supply ship "Ling-Yun" was sunk in waters off Chimei, a small islet of the Penghu archipelago early in the morning under the supervision of officials from the Fishery Administration of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).

It was the second retired naval vessel to be remodeled into an artificial reef. The first warship-turned-reef was sunk in waters off northeastern Taiwan's Ilan County in mid-November. The Republic of China's naval authority donated the two retired supply ships to the COA last year for fishery resources conservation purposes.
COA officials said many traditional fishing countries have used artificial reefs -- places to rest and breed for fish -- in recent years to conserve fishing resources.
COA sources said the council sent officials to attend a seminar in the United States in July this year to learn from foreign expertise and experience in transforming warships into artificial reefs.

As part of its efforts to improve the environment of Taiwan's major fishing grounds, the COA has launched a program to create artificial reefs to preserve fishery resources. In addition to warships, the COA has used other waste materials, including waste facility poles donated by state-run Taiwan Power Co., to form artificial reefs.
Fishery officials urged local fishermen to cherish all those new facilities and work together with the government to conserve fishing resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
U. S. president-elect George W. Bush names retired General Colin Powell his secretary of state.
The China Times:
More than 120 countries sign a U.N. treaty against organized crime.
The United Daily News:
The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) registers 28 nominees to run in mayoral and county magistrate party primaries in 16 cities and counties, but it postpones registering nominees in seven others to leave open the possibility for coorperation with other parties.
The Liberty Times:
The DPP registers 28 nominees to run in mayoral and county magistrate party primaries in 16 cities and counties.
The China Post:
Bush Cabinet choice has star power, wide support.
The Taiwan News:
Opposition whacks more out of budget.
The Taipei Times:
Report pans handling of SQ006 crash.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU PRESIDENT-ELECT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR PRIVATE VISIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of Palau President-elect Tommy Esang Remen Gesau arrived in Taipei Saturday night for a private visit amid warnings that Taipei's diplomatic ties with the Western Pacific island state are in danger.

Remen Gesau, who is presently the vice president of Palau, and his 10-member entourage are expected to call on President Chen Shui-bian and Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The ministry didn't release the details of Remen Gesau's itinerary while in Taiwan, calling his visit a private one since he has not yet been sworn in as president.

Legislator Elmer Fung of the opposition New Party said Saturday that the Palauan president-elect has concerns about Taiwan's financial aid to his country and could visit mainland China after leaving Taiwan to explore the possibility of establishing diplomatic ties with Beijing.
Fung warned Friday that Taipei jeopardized its ties with Palau by supporting Remen Gesau's rival during the Palauan presidential election.
The foreign ministry refuted Fung's claims, dismissing them as allegations set afloat by some diplomatic brokers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO PANAMA HEADS TO TAIPEI TO TAKE UP NEW POST
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 16 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-min left Panama for Taipei on Saturday to take up his new post as secretary-general of the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Those seeing Lan off at the airport included the Panamanian second vice president, Dominador Kaiser Bazan, and also many overseas Chinese, Taiwan businessmen, and ROC civil servants stationed abroad.

David C.Y. Hu, director of the Department of Central and South American Affairs under the ROC's MOFA, will succeed Lan as the ROC's ambassador to Panama. He is scheduled to arrive in Panama on Dec. 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEN KING PENGUINS FROM U.S. ARRIVE AT TAIPEI ZOO

TEXT.P: Ten king penguins from the United States arrived in Taipei on Saturday and will meet with visitors to the Taipei Zoo during the Chinese New Year holidays, head of the Taipei Zoo said Sunday.
Yang Sheng-hsiung said the 10 penguins were in good health and spirits after being cleaned upon their arrival at the Taipei Zoo late Saturday night.

The beautiful creatures will be given time to get accustomed to their new surroundings and will have to undergo quarantine procedures before meeting the Taiwan public during the Chinese New Year holidays in late January, administrative personnel at the Taipei Zoo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TECH INDUSTRY'S M'LAND INVEST'T EXPECTED TO PEAK BY 2003: POLL

TEXT.P: Business executives said Taiwan's technology industry's investments in mainland China will peak between 2002 and 2003, a poll released Sunday showed.

The poll, conducted by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party, Wintel and other market survey centers, found that 41 percent of respondents in Taiwan's technology industry said the industry's investments in the mainland will peak in 2002, while some 37 percent said they will peak in 2003.

The poll also found that 85 percent of respondents said Taiwan's technology industry is presently ahead of mainland China's and that 51 percent said that Taiwan's Internet industry is presently ahead of the mainland's.

Some 51 percent said that Taiwan's technology industry will still be ahead of mainland China's in three to five years, while 49 percent said that the mainland's will move ahead of Taiwan's within three to five years.

With respect to the Internet industry, 46 percent of those surveyed said that Taiwan will still be ahead of mainland China in three to five years, but 54 percent said that the mainland will surpass Taiwan in this period of time.

Asked about which science-based industrial parks in Taiwan or mainland China have the most potential, some 92 percent of respondents mentioned Shanghai's, 87 percent referred to Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan, 56 percent mentioned Beijing's, and 55 percent mentioned Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

On the topic of the greatest concerns towards Taiwan's economy, 43 percent of those surveyed mentioned political risks, 27 percent mentioned the island's talent pool, 18 percent referred to Taiwan's high costs, and 12 percent mentioned the need for infrastructure upgrading.

On the question of the advantages of investing in the mainland, 35 percent pointed to the incentives offered to investors, 24 percent noted the easy access to land for plant construction, 21 percent mentioned the cheap cost of labor, and 20 percent pointed to mainland China's better infrastructure.
A total of 518 questionnaires were sent out for the survey, with 187 valid responses being received.
The poll was released against a background of mainland China actively wooing those in Taiwan's technology industry to invest in the mainland.

Zhang Qi, director of Beijing's Department of Economic and Information Products Management under the Ministry of Information Technology and Telecom Industries, is currently visiting Taiwan to seek exchanges and cooperation between the information technology and telecommunication industries on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA HOPES TO STRENGTHEN LABOR, ECONOMIC PARTNERSHIP WITH TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Manila hopes to strengthen its labor and economic partnership with Taipei now that the issues of the bilateral dispute over direct flights between the two countries and Taiwan's ban on hiring Philippine workers have been solved, a Philippine official said Sunday.

Taipei lifted the ban on the hiring of Philippine laborers for the domestic construction sector and other industries on Dec. 5, and flights between Manila and Taipei were resumed in early October after a nearly yearlong suspension due to the dispute over flight rights.

Philippine Labor Minister Bienvenido Laguesma said he hopes that with the lifting of the ban on the hiring of Philippine labor in early December, Manila and Taipei can strengthen bilateral ties and prevent the recurrence of disputes that could result in strained relations between the two sides.
Laguesma said that after Taipei announced the suspension on the hiring of Philippine laborers, the number of Philippine laborers coming to Taiwan to work decreased by 30 percent.
He said the Philippines hopes the new Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Lo Chih-yuan can further strengthen relations between Manila and Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT DENIES KNOWLEDGE OF FORMATION OF NEW POLITICAL MOVEMENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui denied Sunday any knowledge that his political supporters are mulling the possibility of forming a new political movement to represent "mainstream political thought".
Emerging from a church in Tahsi, Taoyuan County after worship services, Lee brushed aside questions shouted by waiting reporters about the formation of a new political movement.
Before entering his car and leaving, Lee only said "I have never heard anything about it before and have no idea."

Rumors were rife in Taipei political circles after one of Lee's former confidants, the former chief of the Kuomintang's Business Management Committee, proposed the formation by Lee's political supporters of a new political movement to represent "mainstream political thought" and to help the country weather the current political turmoil.

Lee quit politics after the candidate of the Kuomintang under Lee's leadership was defeated in March's presidential election. His followers within the party were displeased with the Kuomintang's policy of reaching out to members who had deserted the party prior to the presidential election because of their disapproval of Lee's policies of so-called "Taiwanization".

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER HEAD OF ARMED FORCES DENIES INVOLVEMENT IN SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Former Chief of the General Staff Adm. Liu Ho-chien on Saturday vehemently denied any involvement in the scandal surrounding the Republic of China Navy's purchase of six French-made frigates in 1991.
"I should be put to death by being chopped to pieces if I had any role in it," Liu was quoted by Legislator Lee Ching-hwa as saying.

Liu, who was the head of the ROC Navy between 1983-1988 and executed the purchase of the controversial Lafayette-class frigates while serving as the Chief of General Staff between 1992-1995, also denied that he had anything to do with the death of naval Capt. Yin Ching-feng in 1993, Lee said.

Yin, the executive director of the navy's arms acquisition programs at the time, was apparently murdered Dec.9, 1993. He had been accused of wrongdoing in a letter to then-President Lee Teng-hui and was reportedly threatening to defend himself by going public with the alleged improprieties surrounding the ROC Navy's acquisition programs before his body was found drifting in the naval harbor in Ilan.
It was the discovery of Yin's body and allegations that kickbacks were involved in the frigate deal that prompted the Taipei authorities to look into the circumstances surrounding the sale.

Lee quoted Liu as confiding in him during a six-hour conversation on Saturday that Yin had reported to him what Yin suspected were irregularities surrounding the Lafayette deal after a trip to France in 1993.
Liu said that Yin was probably murdered for threatening to reveal the alleged wrongdoings surrounding the US$2.8 billion deal.

Lee said that Liu expressed regret over the fact that Yin's family accused him of being the mastermind behind Yin's death and that he was one of the ROC Navy leaders who most aggressively pursued the case.
Liu said he once even instructed the navy investigators to contact an alleged conjurer in a desperate effort to gain clues into the causes of Yin's death.

In a related development, a retired navy vice admiral who was detained for investigation in connection with the death of Yin was released Saturday night after his detention order was vacated by a court.
Vice Admiral Lei Hsueh-ming was freed by the Taipei Detention Center late Saturday after being detained by prosecutors for 84 days.

The 72-year-old Lei was questioned Sept. 24 in connection with Yin's death after authorities reopened the probe into the unsolved case. He was then detained for "inflating the price of the Lafayettes" to benefit the manufacturers, an allegation which he denied.

His two-month detention was extended for another two months at the request of the prosecutors on Nov. 24. But the extension request, after being approved by the lower court, was revoked by the high court Wednesday after Lei's appeal.
Lei, who is the highest-ranking officer to have been detained in the case, returned to his Taipei home Saturday night and attended a church service with his family Sunday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP TO BE PEOPLE'S `THIRD OPTION': SOONG

TEXT.P: James Soong, chairman of the opposition People First Party, said Sunday that his party will become the "third option" of the people.
Soong made the remarks at the inauguration of the federation of the associations of James Soong's friends at the Lai Lai Sheraton Hotel in Taipei.

Pointing out that the public was not satisfied with the previous government of the Kuomintang and is also not at ease with the present government under the Democratic Progressive Party, he said that his party wants to be the "third option" of the people.
He said that his party wants to forge the mainstream views of society, stressing that the PFP aims to find the causes of Taiwan's woes and bring back dynamism to the island.
Not hiding his worries about the future of Taiwan, he said that Taiwan faces problems with respect to cross-strait relations, the economy, ethnic relations, and political reforms.

He said that "Taiwan is ill," and "in serious condition," adding that surveys have shown that more than 70 percent of the people believe that Taiwan's economy will turn for the worse next year and that more than 40 percent are afraid of losing their jobs.
He cited the example of the fact that when he first learned to speak Taiwanese, the island was awash with money, but less than a decade later, the island has become plagued with debt.
He also criticized the current "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland, noting the mainland is stepping up efforts to woo Taiwan investors.
On Taiwan's economic problems, he urged the government to deal with the situation as both sides of the Taiwan Strait prepare to enter the World Trade Organization, likely some time next year.
Soong also said clearly that his party will not merge with any other parties, but will instead seek cooperation across party lines.

He said that the PFP will work with two former chairman of the now ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Hsu Hsin-liang and Shih Ming-teh, and with Sisy Chen, former director of the DPP's Publicity Department, and also reformers in the opposition Kuomintang and New Party.

But Soong also said that the PFP will not compromise its principles and ideals and will serve as the backbone of society. He added that his party will do its best in the elections of legislators and city and county chiefs at the end of next year.

Soong, a former heavyweight of the KMT, quit the party to run on his own in the March presidential election. He finished a close second in the race, trailing the DPP's candidate Chen Shui-bian by about 300,000 votes.

The associations of James Soong's friends played a key role in Soong's showing in the presidential race, and the inauguration of the federation aims to translate his personal popularity into support for the party, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FOUNDATION FOR HEALTH REFORM HOLDS FIRST PREPARATORY CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A foundation aiming to improve Taiwan's health care system called its first preparatory conference Sunday and disclosed the results of the first polls it conducted revealing many people's disapproval with the medical care they have received under the current system.

Chang Li-yung, one of the organizers of the Taiwan Foundation for Health Reform, said he was inspired to form the foundation because of the miserable treatment he and his family have received in Taiwan's health care system.
He criticized the fact that the current profit-oriented health care system has reduced medical workers to "slave laborers" who are more concerned about efficiency than about the patients.
Patients, especially the elderly, women, and children, often do not receive appropriate medical treatment, said Chang.

Citing a poll commissioned by the foundation, Chang said more than half of those surveyed said that they were not informed of their disease after the diagnosis and that they were unaware of what medication their doctors had prescribed to them.

The poll of 1,077 people who had seen a doctor at least once within the previous three months also found that nearly 50 percent of respondents said their doctors took less than five minutes to diagnose them. Eight percent said their doctors finished their diagnosis in less than two minutes, although the average time for a visit to the doctor is one hour.
The poll also found that the more education one receives, the more they are displeased with the treatment they receive in the present health care system.
In order to improve the medical care system in Taiwan, Chang sought 500 sponsors, with each donating NT$1,000 per month, to finance the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, M'LAND CHINA SHOULD SET UP FINANCIAL COOP'N AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Central Bank of China suggested Sunday that the two sides of Taiwan Strait set up a mechanism to promote East Asian financial cooperation after they are admitted into the World Trade Organization.

Lee Sheng-yen, director of the Banking Department of the CBC, said that as Taiwan and mainland China are set to enter the WTO soon, it is necessary to set up a financial cooperation mechanism so as to prevent a financial crisis from happening.

Lee, making the remarks during a keynote speech at the first Taiwan-Japan International Seminar, said Taiwan and mainland China will not only have to face the effects of opening their local markets to more international competition, but will also have to deal with the shock to local financial markets brought by the easing of controls on capital inflows.

Lee said that although the banking institute has imposed adequate controls when implementing capital liberalization measures, this mechanism will not be sufficient to prevent a financial crisis from unfolding.

Therefore, in order to prevent such a crisis from occurring, both Taiwan and mainland China should set up a cooperation mechanism to promote financial cooperation in East Asia after both are admitted into the WTO, he said, adding that this will also help improve cross strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MOST FARMERS NOT WELL AWARE OF IMPACT OF TAIWAN'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Results of a public opinion survey showed that a great majority of farmers are not well aware of what the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization will be.

A spokesman for the survey organizing committee said this indicates that the relevant government agencies should put more effort into explaining the positive and negative impacts of Taiwan's admittance into the WTO.
The Public Administration Society of the Republic of China randomly interviewed 1,071 farmers across the island between Dec. 3 to Dec. 9.

Of those interviewed, 85.3 percent said they knew that the ROC will soon be admitted into the WTO, and 69.1 percent said they were aware that the government will have to open the local agricultural and livestock market and lift a lot of import bans on agricultural products from other countries.
The same poll showed that 51.7 percent of respondents do not know that the government will have to cancel all the current agricultural subsidies after Taiwan is formally admitted into the WTO.

Meanwhile, 73.8 percent of respondents said they believe that WTO admission will bring more negative impacts than benefits, and 54.9 percent said they believe Taiwan's agriculture sector is not competitive enough to deal with the shock to be brought by the island's WTO entry.

In the same survey, 84.5 percent of respondents said that they will continue to work in the farm industry after Taiwan is admitted into WTO, and 56.2 percent said they are worried they may lose their job after Taiwan's WTO entry.

Legislator Hsiao Wan-yu of the Kuomintang said the survey results indicate that both farmers and the government agencies concerned have a different perspective on what Taiwan's WTO admission will bring.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO PROMOTE INT'L EDUCATIONAL COOPERATION: OVID TZENG
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Dec. 17 (CNA) (By Hsin Yi-ping & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Education Minister Ovid T.L. Tzeng said in Kuala Lumpur Sunday that Taiwan will work to promote international cooperation on education with foreign academic institutes.
Minister Tzeng said that Taiwan would like to promote cooperation in the fields of teacher training and book publishing with Chinese language schools abroad.
Tzeng made the remarks when exchanging views with Chinese language educators in Malaysia.

"The Republic of China has made achievements in basic science and technology and has also won international praise for its DNA research. Taiwan is willing to share its achievements in these areas with friendly countries, Tzeng said.
He said that the variety of cultures and societies around the world will play an important role in the process of globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DISCUSS WITH M'LAND USE OF RENMINBI AFTER "THREE MINI LINKS"

TEXT.P: After the implementation of the "mini three links" between the two outlying Republic of China islands Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China, Taiwan will have to discuss with the mainland the issue of the use of the renminbi before the currency can be used on the two islands, an official in charge of mainland policy said Sunday.

Chen Ming-tung, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that direct trade, postal, and transport links are scheduled to be inaugurated on January 1, 2001 and that the renminbi will not be used in Kinmen and Matsu during the initial stage.

Chen said that this is because Taiwan is not a member of the International Monetary Fund, adding that Taiwan will have to discuss with the mainland the issue of the currency settlement basis and make sure that the mainland will buy back the renminbi before it allows the use of the currency on the islands.

In addition to the concerns about the currency, he also stressed that the government will have to make plans to ensure the maintenance of social order on Kinmen and Matsu, adding that the Coast Guard Administration, the Ministry of National Defense, and the National Police Administration will join forces to work out the plan to ensure an effective trade environment.

Chen made the remarks while appearing on a program on a Taiwan television station concerning the "mini three links" and plans for the establishment of direct links between Taiwan proper and the mainland.

Legislator Chen Ching-pao of the opposition Kuomintang, speaking on the same program, said Taiwan has unilaterally decided to implement the "mini three links" without communication and consultation with the mainland.
Chen again suggested that the government first begin trial shipping to the mainland in order to gain a better understanding of the difficulties it may encounter in the future.

Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director of the Department of Chinese Affairs of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, said that in consideration of the citizens, national security, and social order, the DPP has adopted a gradual opening of links between Taiwan and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 41% NOT SATISFIED WITH GOVERNMENT'S ECONOMIC POLICY

TEXT.P: Some 41 percent of Taiwan citizens are not satisfied with the financial and economic policies of President Chen Shui-bian, the latest poll released Sunday by a think tank of the opposition Kuomintang showed.

The National Policy Foundation conducted the survey between November 26 and December 2 on people over 20 years of age. Some 1,072 valid samples were collected, and the poll is said to have a margin of error of 2.99 percent.

The survey found that 58 percent of respondents said they believe the government should make the economy its number one priority, and only 12 percent said that the top priority should be social welfare.

The poll found that if President Chen Shui-bian were unable to deliver on his campaign promises, around 38 percent of the respondents said they would not support him, and 17 percent said they would continue to stand by him.
Meanwhile, the poll also indicated that 63 percent are worried that they or one of their family members will lose their job, while around 30 percent said that they have no such worries.

Some 35 percent of those polled also said they want the government to be more open regarding cross-strait trade policy, 17 percent said the government should be more conservative, and some 26 percent said it should maintain the status quo, while 23 percent said they have no comment on this question.

On the issue of the slumping stock market, 19 percent said that it has been the result of the proposed recall motion by the opposition coalition, 12 percent attributed it to the unstable financial policy of the new administration, and nine percent said bad economic fundamentals were the cause.
The survey also found that around 47 percent of respondents said they think that the financial and economic policies of President Chen are erratic and chaotic.

National Chengchi University Professor Lin Chu-Chia, commenting on the poll, said the government's economic policy should be consistent and stable, adding that the new administration's policy has instead been erratic, which he said is evidenced by the controversies surrounding a pay raise for civil servants and the imposition of a national security tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Poll finds local people dissatisfied with the DPP government's financial and economic policies.
The China Times:
Private enterprises will be first allowed to produce alcoholic beverages and then tobacco after Taiwan is admitted to the WTO.
The United Daily News:

Powell: China isn't a U.S. strategic partner yet.

Time names Bush Person of the Year 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 78.9 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 78.9 points to close at 5,055.2.
Market turnover amounted to NT$25.79 billion (US$0.78 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOL PRODUCTION TO BE GRADUALLY OPENED TO PRIVATE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The government's monopoly on tobacco and alcoholic drink production is expected to become a thing of the past after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year, Ministry of Finance sources said Monday.
Alcoholic drink production will likely be gradually opened to the private sector over the first three years after Taiwan's WTO accession, MOF officials said.

According to an MOF proposal submitted to the Executive Yuan for approval, the liberalization of alcoholic drink production will be carried out in four stages during the three years, leading to the complete privatization of the long-monopolized wine and liquor industry.

In the first year after Taiwan's WTO accession, the production of fruit wines of all varieties will be opened to private companies to invest in or operate. In the second year, all kinds of fermented wine, including rice wine but excluding beer, will be opened to the private sector, according to the proposal.

In the third year, production of liquors of all varieties will be opened to private production and investment. The production of beer products will only be opened to the private sector three years after Taiwan has joined the WTO.

In the proposal, the MOF does not suggest that the production of tobacco and cigarette products be privatized in the first three years after Taiwan's WTO accession, but it does say it will consider such an opening under certain special circumstances, MOF officials said.
Taiwan is expected to become a formal member of the WTO sometime after next April, immediately following mainland China's accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 78.9 points to close at 5,055.2.
The bourse opened at 5,116.07 and continued to go down despite purchases made by government funds. The index fluctuated between 5,127.73 and 5,022.34 during trading.

A total of 0.9 billion stocks worth NT$25.79 billion (US$0.78 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 0.98 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$28.2 billion (US$0.86 billion).

Of the eight major categories, bank and insurance shares remained unchanged, while all the others lost ground, with electrical shares and pulp and paper issues moving down the most, both at 2.1 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.9 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical shares, both at 1.5 percent, construction stocks at 1.4 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 441 to 69, with 81 stocks remaining unchanged.
