DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 18, or the 23rd day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan(Hankow), which had been proclaimed capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan, and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Tae Woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a ten-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young Sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DIPLOMATS EXPECT CLOSER TIES WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: U.S. President-elect George W. Bush's nomination of retired General Colin Powell as his future secretary of state is expected to facilitate further improvement of Taipei-Washington relations, a senior diplomat said Monday.

Liu Chih-kung, director of the North American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), made the remarks in response to a press inquiry about his views on Bush's first cabinet appointment.

Noting that Powell has been very friendly toward Taiwan, Liu said he is convinced that Powell's appointment will contribute to constructive development of substantive ties between the Republic of China and the United Sates.

"Given Powell's wide appeal to Americans and a reputation as a man of honor aloof from the political fray, Powell is believed to win the U.S. congressional assent to serving as secretary of state under the incoming Bush administration," Liu said.
Powell, a Gulf War hero, once visited Taiwan in 1997. Liu said that visit has enabled Powell to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's democratic development and economic liberalization.

Liu said he believes that Powell's first-hand look at Taiwan's development and his personal experience in observing relations across the Taiwan Strait during that visit will help make it easier for the ROC to communicate with the Bush administration concerning cross-strait issues.
And against this backdrop, Liu said he is optimistic about the prospects for further improving ROC-U.S. relations.

Many other MOFA officials, who preferred anonymity, echoed Liu's views, saying they believe that substantive cooperation between Taipei and Washington will become even closer after Bush and Powell take their new posts.

For one thing, the officials said optimistically that the new U.S. administration will more fully consider Taiwan's stance and America's own interests, not just mainland China's reaction, while dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait issues.
As for the current cross-strait deadlock, MOFA officials said, the ball is now in Beijing's court since the ROC government has on many occasions held out olive branches to mainland China.

If mainland China continues to resist resumption of cross-strait dialogue or refuse any compromise on its certain stances, MOFA officials said cross-strait relations will remain almost same as their current state when the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum holds its annual informal summit meeting next November. APEC groups 21 economies, including Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.
Meanwhile, Vice Defense Minister Chen Pi-chao said he foresees no major changes in the U.S. policy on arms sales to Taiwan.

Noting that the United States has consistently adopted a "balance of power" principle in formulating its policies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the new U.S. administration will continue placing the top priority on its national interest in mulling arms deals with Taiwan.

Against this background, Chen said, the incoming Bush administration will follow the past formula in selling defensive weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, a U.S. law that governs U.S. relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties and requires the United States to provide Taiwan with sufficient defensive arms to help ensure Taiwan's security.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN OFFICIATES AT GROUNDBREAKING FOR NEW SOFTWARE PARK

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian on Monday welcomed the marriage between Taiwan's cutting-edge information technological industry and the traditional manufacturing industry, a development he said will help usher the country into the era of the new knowledge-led economy.

Addressing a ceremony marking the groundbreaking for the Kaohsiung Software Technology and Industrial Park, Chen said the park will be a new source of pride for southern Taiwan and a point of embarkation for business and industrial transition in southern Taiwan.

The software park, to be jointly sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Kaohsiung City Government, will showcase the cooperation between the central and local governments, not only serving local needs, but also helping to bolster national reconstruction, Chen noted.
The proposed software park, a NT$13 billion investment, will also serve as a milestone project pushing Taiwan closer toward its goal of becoming a "green silicon island," the president added.

Despite concerns about the fact that many Taiwan companies have begun considering relocating their manufacturing operations to mainland China to take advantage of China's cheap labor and production costs and to skirt Taiwan's deteriorating economic situation, the projected software park has already successfully solicited investors to a tune of about 70 percent of its target, said park administration officials.

Investors which have already forged agreements with the park administration include Chunghua Telecom, National Sun Yat-sen University, and the Institute of Information Industry, which aims to develop wide-band and optic-fiber telecommunications products, park officials said.

Park administration officials said that in order to attract and retain investment in the software park, investors will be entitled to certain privileges, including long-term low-interest loans and more convenient land acquisition.

The park, the first of its kind in southern Taiwan, is expected to include a 19-story main building and a four-story operations center. It is expected to become fully operational in April 2002, creating some 5,000 job opportunities for people in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO IMPROVE HUMAN RIGHTS PROTECTION FOR FOREIGN LABORERS

TEXT.P: Labor groups in Taiwan on Monday urged the government to improve conditions for foreign laborers during their unveiling of a list of human rights violations that foreign laborers in Taiwan have experienced.

On the day declared "International Migrant's Day" by the United Nations, the groups called on the government to actively improve conditions, set up a system of shelters and mid-way homes, and establish a channel for complaints by foreign laborers.

Labor Front and Rerum Novarum Labor Center invited the fathers and sisters who have direct contact with foreign laborers to report 12 types of rights violations that foreign laborers have encountered in Taiwan.

The violations listed were the stripping of personal and religious freedom, long working hours and no holidays, different wages for the same work, the stripping of solidarity, astronomical brokerage fees, unequal judicial protection, restrictions on movement and change of employment, a lack of marriage and birth rights, sexual harassment, contracts that are not drawn on parity, lack of privacy in place of residence, and racial discrimination.

Father Edwin Corros of St. Christopher's Church, who has served foreign laborers in Taiwan for the last seven years, said that the most serious problem these workers face is high brokerage fees, pointing out that the fee has risen to more than NT$100,000 (US$3,019). He said that the Republic of China government should work with foreign laborer exporting countries to set reasonable brokerage fees.
Father Corros said that issue of runaway foreign laborers is another problem, which he said is mostly the result of exorbitant brokerage fees or the mistreatment of employees.
He said that although the government has regulations in place to punish employers who abuse foreign workers, these regulations are not the proper remedy for addressing the situation.

Sister Stephana Wei, director of Rerum Novarum Labor Center, said that residence privacy for domestic helpers and care takers is especially lacking because they live under the same roof as their employers.

Wei said that some domestic helpers and care takers living with their employers have no privacy at all, pointing out that some rooms are fitted with transparent glass walls and that some employers change the locks on doors at random so that they can monitor their employees at all times.
Wei also pointed out that current regulations state that foreign laborers who get pregnant should be repatriated immediately, which she said ignores the human needs of the foreign laborers.

She also said that it is not sufficient for the Council of Labor Affairs to set up a complaint hot line, as employers are able to almost immediately, within 24 hours, repatriate laborers who file complaints.

She suggested that the government provide complaint centers with the authority to mediate disputes between foreign laborers and their employers, adding that it should also set up a mid-way home so that the laborers involved in disputes with their employers have a temporary residence and are not in danger of being repatriated by their employer at will.

The International Labor Organization and World Bank estimates that there are 150 million migrants in the world, with 97 million of that total being foreign laborers and their families. Foreign laborers remit a total of US$73 billion to their home country each year, according to the estimates.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN TRADE BOARD WEBSITE HACKED INTO

TEXT.P: The Internet website of the Republic of China's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) was broken into on Sunday and Monday by a hacker suspected of being from mainland China.

The break-in by the hacker, calling himself the "Old Cat from Chaozhou" on the BOFT website's homepage, brought back memories of the wave of computer hacker break-ins into official Republic of China websites that occurred in 1999 from across the Taiwan Strait, sources from the BOFT said.
Fortunately, a firewall -- a device that protects data from outside intruders -- protected most of the BOFT's database from the hacker, who was only able to replace the homepage.

Suspecting that there may have been political motives behind the intrusion, which occurred between 6 p.m. on Sunday and 9 a.m. on Monday, related BOFT officials and Internet experts are looking into the case, hoping to trace back to the source of the break-in.

Although the hacker's self-proclaimed name suggested that he was from a mainland Chinese city, BOFT officials do not rule out the possibility that he is from Taiwan and was just having some malicious fun.

Last year, hackers across the Taiwan Strait engaged in a series of dog-fight style Internet battles with Taiwan authorities after the mainland Chinese hackers broke into important ROC government agency websites, including those of the Control Yuan, which is the top watchdog agency in Taiwan, the National Assembly, and the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau.

One "Chinese hacker" broke into the Control Yuan website on Aug. 7, 1999, claiming that "there is only one China in the world, and the world needs only one China." The message was believed to be clearly aimed at then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of the Taipei-Beijing relationship as a "special state-to-state" one.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, U.S. TO ENTER 'STRATEGIC COOPERATION'

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will formally enter "strategic cooperation" with the United States when its military builds up the "net assessment" capability next year, Ministry of National Defense (MND) sources said Monday.

According to MND sources, the U.S. military began to assist the ROC in building up "net assessment" capability after the 1995-96 Taiwan Strait crisis during which time mainland China lobbed missiles and conducted live-fire military exercises at Taiwan's doorstep in an attempt to affect the result of the ROC's first direct presidential election.

At present, the sources said, several teams of ROC military officers are receiving relevant training in the United States. "Our armed forces are expected to acquire full 'net assessment' capability next year," said an MND official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The official explained that "net assessment" refers to a quantitative research system comprising a set of calculating software programs and highly efficient hardware facilities.

"The U.S.-developed 'net assessment' system will enable us to evaluate all possible scenarios through simulated warfare on the basis of quantitative data and information," the official said, adding that with the assistance of this highly sophisticated assessment system, the ROC military will be able to shed subjective, arbitrary elements in traditional military strength evaluation.

With the return of ROC military officers from the United States sometime next year, the official went on, Taiwan's armed forces will establish their own data banks and use the U.S.-developed software and hardware facilities to work out defense guidelines and strategy in line with the ROC's basic defense policy and more efficiently distribute the country's defense resources.

In fact, the official said, the ROC military already employed the "net assessment" system and spirit in this year's "Hunching No. 16" combined services military exercise to evaluate its capability to launch a counterattack in case mainland China uses M-class missiles to attack Taiwan.

The official said as the ROC will formally unify its military command and administrative systems from February 2001, it badly needs an objective military strength assessment system to enable is civilian defense minister to conduct a comprehensive analysis of the country's overall defense resources and armed forces structure.
According to the new defense law scheduled to take effect next February, the General Staff Headquarters will come under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of National Defense.

In preparation for the overhaul of the ROC's defense system, the official said the MND's strategic planning department will open a new "net assessment" office to handle integrated strategic environment evaluation.
"The inauguration of the new office will offer our defense minister more accurate, objective and unbiased counsel in formulating defense policy and resources distribution plans," the official noted.

According to the official, ROC-U.S. military exchanges have expanded and upgraded after the 1995-96 Taiwan Strait crisis. By 2001, he said, the ROC will become the third country to have the "net assessment" capability, after the United States and Israel.
The official further said the MND looks forward to seeing further breakthroughs in ROC-U.S. military exchanges after the Bush administration is inaugurated next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN-CHINESE COOP'N POSES THREATS TO U.S. AND TAIWAN: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Russian-Communist Chinese cooperation is a clear demonstration of the adversarial nature of the basic security policies of these two nations toward American interests and allies and poses serious threats to both Taiwan and the United States, an American national security expert said Sunday.

Stephen Blank, professor of national security studies at the Strategic Studies Institute of the U.S. Army War College, wrote in the Washington Times that Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov announced in Beijing last month his government's open support for an axis consisting of Russia, Communist China, and India if and when these states decided they wanted one.

Mr. Kasyanov has also apparently negotiated the sale of an AWACS-like system to Beijing, thus confirming that Moscow-Beijing relations have immense significance for Asia and the world and that the United States is increasingly seen as the main threat to Communist China, pointed out Blank.

He noted that the main threat to U.S. interests consists of Russian arms sales to Communist China that comprise technologies, weapons, regular staff exchanges on scenarios in the Taiwan Straits and presumably elsewhere, and intelligence sharing.

As the Pentagon recently admitted, "a cross-strait conflict between China and Taiwan involving the United States has emerged as the dominant scenario guiding People's Liberation Army force planning, military training, and war preparedness," wrote Blank.
He added that these weapons transfers are therefore "deliberately aimed at American forces, allies, partners, and interests."

The overall pattern of Communist Chinese acquisitions -- and not just from Russia -- strongly suggests that intimidating or capturing Taiwan and deterring the United States and its armed forces from coming to Taiwan's defense is a military priority for Beijing's leaders and planners, wrote Blank.

However, he stressed, Moscow-Beijing cooperation against the United States does not end with threats to Taiwan and the United States. This intimate relationship has impeded progress toward Russian-Japanese rapprochement and a formal Russian-Japanese peace treaty.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.003 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 33.076.
The local currency opened Monday at 33.036 and was traded between 33.036 and 33.098.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$248 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CIVIL AVIATION OFFICIALS ARRIVE FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: A delegation of mainland Chinese civil aviation administrators arrived in Taiwan Monday for a 10-day fact-finding visit in preparation for opening direct airlinks across the Taiwan Strait in the future.
The 12-member mainland delegation was headed by Yeh Igan, director of the Huadong (eastern China) Civil Aviation Bureau under the Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC).
Yeh said although this is his first trip to Taiwan, he has many friends in Taiwan's civil aviation community.

Asked whether the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to forge direct trade, mail and transport links, commonly known as the "major three links," next year, Yeh said mainland China's civil aviation community has long been ready for operating direct cross-strait flight services.
"As for when direct cross-strait airlinks will become a reality, it's not a matter that our civil aviation authority can unilaterally decide," he added.

Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council is scheduled to unveil a blueprint for opening direct cross-strait "major three links" in the first half of next year. As mainland China still refuse to resume dialogue with Taiwan, it remains uncertain when the much-anticipated direct cross-strait "major three links," including flight services, can formally kick off.

As the opening of direct cross-strait airlinks is expected to bring about lucrative business opportunities, major Taiwan carriers have opened liaison offices on the mainland and forged close ties with their mainland counterparts.

Members of the mainland delegation include Wang Cunhao, director of the CAAC's Xinan (southwestern China) Civil Aviation Bureau; Zhang Shih-hung, deputy director of the Economic Affairs Bureau of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council; Wu Li, deputy director of the CAAC's Taiwan-Hong Kong-Macau Affairs Office; and chief managers of Beijing, Shanghai, Xiamen and Guangzhou airports.
Some Taiwan civil aviation officials, legislators and airline executives showed up at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the main gateway to Taiwan, to greet the mainland civil aviation visitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO SET UP 'MINI THREE LINKS' COORDINATION CENTER IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will open a coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen to ensure smooth opening of direct "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait at the beginning of next year, a cross-strait negotiator said Monday.

Yen Wan-chin, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), a quasi-official intermediary body authorized by the Republic of China government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties, made the remarks after arriving here to inspect preparations for the "mini three links" opening.

Accompanied by Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai, Yen made an inspection tour of the Chukuang Villa, a Kinmen County Government estate to accommodate the planned administrative coordination center.
Yen said the Executive Yuan, or Cabinet, will unveil a package of regulations Wednesday to govern the operations of the coordination center, which is scheduled to become operational on Dec. 25.

According to the Cabinet's plan, relevant ministries or government agencies will take turn in assigning a deputy head to lead the coordination center. In addition, a senior civil servant will be named to handle the coordination center's day-to-day affairs.

Yen said the coordination center will be authorized to integrate and coordinate operations of various central and local government agencies in handling passenger and cargo transport issues and legal problems that may arise after the opening of direct "mini three links" between Kinmen and the southeastern mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen.

In line with an offshore islands development bill passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the ROC government has decided to open direct "trade, mail and shipping links" between its defense outposts of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Mawei in Fujian province, popularly known as "mini three links," on Jan. 1, 2001.

Noting that the government cannot afford any failing concerning the opening of "mini three links," Yen said there will be three mechanisms to ensure smooth operations of direct Kinmen-Xiamen trade and shipping services.

In addition to the new coordination center, Yen said, such central government agencies as customs, quarantine, immigration and coast guard authorities as well as the Kinmen County Government will jointly form an administrative and inspection center at the Liaolo port, the only Kinmen harbor to be opened for "mini three links" in the initial stage.
Meanwhile, Yen said, the military's Kinmen Defense Headquarters will be responsible for security-related affairs.

As mainland China still declines to resume dialogue with Taiwan, Yen said, the enforcement of "mini three links" in the initial stage will focus on legalizing "small-amount trade" between fishermen on both sides of the Taiwan Strait that has been going on illegally for years, as well as on matters that Taiwan can unilaterally handled.

Yen said so long as mainland China makes goodwill response to Taiwan's efforts to improve cross-strait ties, the "mini three links" will be expanded in the second stage to more effectively help boost Kinmen's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SETS GOAL OF CREATING 270,000 JOB OPPORTUNITIES

TEXT.P: In order to alleviate the escalating social pressure caused by the rising unemployment rate in Taiwan, the Cabinet has decided to implement policies toward the goal of creating 270,000 job opportunities.

Chang Ping-nan, deputy director-general of the Government Information Office, said the government will accomplish the set goal by implementing a series of incentive measures, including the expansion of vocational training programs and the offering of subsidies and services for job hunters.

Chang, who said the government has decided to adopt these measures after in-depth Cabinet-level task force discussions on the issue, pointed out that these moves are designed to relieve the pressures caused by unemployment in the short-term and should not be considered as thorough solutions to the problem of rising unemployment.

Meanwhile, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung urged all the nation's public functionaries to make adequate preparations in order to face any challenges arising at home or abroad. He also exhorted them to play a more positive role in stabilizing Taiwan's political situation.
Chang said that the existence of opposition political parties will absolutely not be accepted as an excuse for local political unrest or economic recession.
The premier made the remarks while attending an award presentation ceremony honoring outstanding public works during the year 2000.

He also categorically denied recent criticism that the Republic of China was headed for political crisis, saying that he is confident in the government's ability to maintain a stable democracy on Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SEND MEDICAL TEAM TO NEPAL

TEXT.P: A medical team will depart for Nepal next week to provide humanitarian medical assistance in that country, Legislator Chen Hsei-saint of the opposition Kuomintang said Monday.
Legislator Chen, who helped inspire the formation of the team, said the 18-member medical team, headed by Chang Kung Memorial Hospital doctor Hung Kai-feng, will depart for Nepal Dec. 25.

Chen noted that each winter, hundreds of Tibetans climb through high mountains to flee into Nepal. These Tibetans, however, are unable to receive proper care and suffer from malnutrition when they arrive in Nepal because of the lack of medical materials and the poor quality of life there. They sometimes even suffer from frostbite and have to have limbs amputated, he added.

Chen said that although the medical team, which has received government and private assistance for the humanitarian mission, will stay for only a week, it will serve as a forerunner for follow-up medial activities.

He said that cooperation with local medical schools, the establishment of more permanent medical footholds, and the providing of better medical services for the Tibetans and local people have not been ruled out as possibilities.

The establishment of a medical assistance mechanism in Nepal has also been considered so as to create favorable conditions for Taiwan's bid to enter the World Health Organization and to gain international support for its bid, he said.

Chueh Sn Tsering, member of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission, expressed his appreciation for the medical team, saying that many Tibetans have fled each year to Nepal for the sake of freedom and human rights.

He said that those who have applied for Nepalese citizenship number in the hundreds of thousands, while the number of those who have yet to apply amounts to more than 30,000, adding that the visit by the Taiwan medical team will have a positive effect on bilateral exchanges between the Republic of China and Nepal.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RULES OUT POSSIBILITY OF COOPERATING WITH DPP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) ruled out Monday the possibility of political cooperation with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), according to a senior KMT official.
KMT Secretary-General Lin Feng-cheng categorically denied that such cooperation will take place, describing the idea as "impossible."
Legislator Chou Po-lun (DPP-Taipei County) had called on the DPP to cooperate with the KMT to form a ruling political alliance so as to stabilize the local political situation.
Chou also claimed that the current KMT force in the Legislative Yuan is a false phenomenon and that the power of KMT Chairman Lien Chan will end with next year's legislators' election.
The theme of reorganization of local political parties is a hot topic in political circles after Liu Tai-ying, a former KMT financial planner and controller, mentioned the idea.
Ho Chi-hui, KMT's legislative whip, claimed that Chou's remarks were personal opinions that did not represent the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13 SHIPPING FIRMS INTERESTED IN PLYING KINMEN-XIAMEN ROUTE

TEXT.P: With the opening of direct "mini three links" entering a final countdown, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Monday it will soon unveil regulations governing scheduled shipping services to selected mainland ports.

As part of its efforts to help boost economic development in the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, the Republic of China government has decided to allow direct trade, mail and shipping links between the two offshore islands and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian Province, commonly known as the "direct mini three links," from Jan. 1, 2001.
MOTC officials said the ministry will formally unveil regulations governing applications for operating scheduled Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Fuzhou shipping services on Tuesday or Wednesday.
Interested companies can file applications with relevant harbor authorities once the package of regulations has been promulgated, the officials said.

MOTC sources said 13 shipping firms in the Kinmen area have expressed interest in operating scheduled shipping services between Kinmen and Xiamen. Among them, eight companies intend to operate passenger transport services, four want to operate cargo services and the remaining one plans to operate both passenger and cargo services.
To their knowledge, MOTC officials said, there will certainly be maiden voyages on both the newly opened Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Fuzhou shipping routes on New Year's Day.
Shipping firms in Matsu are mainly interested in transporting pilgrims to mainland China's Fuzhou and Meizhou to pay tribute to the Chinese goddess of sea, MOTC officials said.
According to the MOTC regulations, scheduled shipping services can be offered only between Kinmen's Liaolo port and Fujian's Xiamen port or between Matsu's Fuao port and Fujian's Mawei port.

As for chartered shipping services, the MOTC will not impose any restrictions on mainland destinations. Therefore, local shipping firms will be able to operate chartered shipping services from either Kinmen or Matsu to any mainland ports with Beijing's assent.

MOTC officials said they believe local shippers will focus on operating chartered direct shipping services from Kinmen/Matsu to mainland ports in the initial stage because market prospects for scheduled shipping services remain uncertain.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK CHAIRMAN REITERATES NEED FOR UNITED `MAINSTREAM' PARTY

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Taiwan Research Institute, a private think tank, reiterated Monday that the country needs someone to consolidate "mainstream opinion" and form a political party to effectively promote national development.

Liu Tai-ying, a former Kuomintang (KMT) top financial manager and a protege of former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, recently brought up the idea of "unifying the current political spectrum" in order to create a legislative majority power that can maintain domestic stability.
In his view, Liu said two days earlier, the existence of a number of small parties hinders domestic political stability and smooth government operation.

Liu, a trained economist, said that he has no interest in organizing a new party. "Former President Lee is also unlikely to assume such a mission. He would at most agree to serve as a spiritual leader of a proposed new party," Liu said.

He added that he hopes to see younger politicians, such as President Chen Shui-bian, push for the formation of a "mainstream party" to maintain domestic political stability and ensure the smooth economic development that he described as Taiwan's lifeline.

At a Monday press conference on Taiwan's economic prospects for 2001, Liu said that next year's year-end legislative, county, and municipal elections might still leave the political landscape dotted with numerous parties, none of which has a majority mandate, especially in the legislature.

According to Japanese, Italian, and French experience, a minority ruling party is usually unstable, with frequent no-confidence votes against the Cabinet that have an immense impact on a country's economy, he said.

He again cited Japan's party restructuring as an example of how the merger of two parties into the Liberal Democratic Party was able to bring about decades of economic prosperity for Japan, and how that prosperity was lost when the party split and unity was shattered.
Taiwan may not be able to withstand a 10-year depression, he said, which is why he came up with the idea of having someone establish a party that can bring the "mainstream" together, Liu said.

When questioned whether the opposition alliance of the KMT, the People First Party (PFP), and the New Party (NP) might be able to play the role of this "mainstream party," Liu said that his observations indicate that the alliance has been opposing the ruling party for the sake of opposition.
He added that the various parties have different political opinions and would have "a limited effect," even if united under one flag.

Meanwhile, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Wu Nai-jen said that it is too early to speak of cooperating with other parties because there is still one year between now and the elections.

However, he brushed aside reports that PFP Chairman James Soong is willing to link up with former DPP chairmen Shih Ming-teh and Hsu Hsin-liang for the elections, saying that the effects of such a move on how well the DPP will do at the polls would be "not too big."
Shih said later in the day that he does not rule out the possibility of running in the legislative election with over 10 others as independent candidates.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng agreed with Wu that it is still too early to speak of joining forces with the PFP and the NP for the elections. However, he added that he does not rule out the possibility and that the three parties are "doing well together" at the moment.

The KMT is currently concentrating on internal reforms to bring it closer to the "mainstream" public, he said, adding that Lee, the former president and former KMT chairman, has also made it very clear that he is not about to establish a new party.

Chen Hung-chi, head of a KMT legislative subgroup, said that he does not sense the kind of atmosphere that would allow for the formation of such a party. On the other hand, he added that the KMT and the PFP are "certain" to work together in next year's elections when nominating candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OPENS MARKET TO USED CARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will lift a long-standing ban on imports of used cars beginning Jan.1, 2001, the Board of Foreign Trade announced Monday.
The present regulations that allow only overseas Chinese and Taiwanese studying abroad to bring their own used cars when they return to Taiwan will be abandoned.
The imported second-hand cars will be subject to the same rules as apply to new cars entering the island.

Although used caterpillar track vehicles, tractors, golf carts, and steam turbines will also be allowed to be imported, the market for used cars will bear the brunt of the new rules, which are designed to prepare the island for its accession to the World Trade Organization.
It is expected that local importers will introduce used Japan-made cars from the United States to sidestep the quota on the import of Japanese cars.
Used Japanese sport cars, which are usually brought in under the names of local students who studied in the United States, are hot items on the local market.

Under the new rules, business or non-business importers will have to get permission before importing second-hand cars just as they did before importing new cars, and the used cars will be subject to the same regulations concerning safety, pollution and energy efficiency as the new cars.
However, the new measures do not cover vintage cars more than 20 years old, import of which will require special permission.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUPS BLAST PRESIDENT CHEN OVER ECONOMIC RECESSION

TEXT.P: Scores of women's group representatives filed a petition with the main opposition Kuomintang's legislative caucus Monday, urging it to push the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government to revitalize the sluggish domestic economy.

The representatives also issued an open letter to President Chen Shui-bian in front of the Legislative Yuan, reminding him to stop "ruling with his mouth" and begin "ruling with his mind and heart" in order to upgrade government efficiency, accelerate reconstruction of earthquake-stricken areas and improve the investment climate.
The KMT legislative caucus agreed to transfer the letter to President Chen on behalf of the representatives. Several female KMT legislators also showed up to throw their support behind the appeal.

The representatives claimed that women's four basic human rights -- to survival, freedom, property and work -- have been undermined or faced unprecedented challenges since Chen took office in Taiwan's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May.

Since Chen has often presented himself as a "human rights" president, the delegates went on, he should shed his personal ideology and adopt more realistic policies to revamp Taiwan's slumping economy and regain public confidence in the country's future prospects.

The representatives further complained that since the inauguration of Chen's administration, the suicide rate among women and the number of domestic violence cases have risen substantially due to the deteriorating local economic situation and surging unemployment rates.

Noting that local women's daily lives have been affected over the past half-year, the delegates said if the Chen administration fails to stop its "empty talks" and adopt effective measures to improve the economic climate, they will stage a massive-scale demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY NEXT YEAR WILL LAG BEHIND THIS YEAR: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The public's lack of confidence in the government's economic and financial policies and a possible recession of the U.S. economy next year will cause Taiwan's economy to lag far behind this year, the head of a research institute said Monday.
Liu Tai-ying, president of the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI), made the remarks at a press conference on the outlook for Taiwan's economy in 2001.
He predicted Taiwan's economic growth rate in 2001 to be 5.53 percent, much lower than the 6.03 percent forecast earlier by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

Liu said that due to six consecutive hikes in interest rates, the U.S. economy has slowed down. Some people have estimated that the U.S. economic growth rate this year will drop sharply to 3.2 percent from 5.3 percent, while others have predicted it will slip even further to below 3 percent.
No matter what figure is proved to be true, it will surely have an adverse effect on Taiwan and other Asian nations, Liu said.

Liu forecast that the growth rate of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter of next year will be 5.92 percent, declining to 4.91 percent in the second quarter. However, he went on, the growth rate in the third and fourth quarters will probably rally to 5.40 percent and 5.89 percent, respectively, pushed by major domestic investment projects.
He further forecast that the growth rate of Taiwan's private investments next year will fall to 5.12 percent, down significantly from this year's 16.16 percent.

He also predicted that the export growth rate next year will be only 6.34 percent and that the import growth rate will be just 5.29 percent, while the private consumption growth rate will fall to 5.62 percent.
Liu stressed that unless the government can take definite and effective financial and economic measures, the outlook of Taiwan's economy next year is not promising.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TIES WITH MACEDONIA SECURE: ROC VICE FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said Monday that his trip to Macedonia last week allowed him to secure a "new understanding" of bilateral ties from the new Cabinet members of the former Yugoslavian republic.

Lee said that the few members of the Liberal Party (LP) who were originally against the establishment of bilateral diplomatic ties because of a "misunderstanding" on the depth and breadth of bilateral relations now have a "completely new perspective" on the issue after he explained to them that bilateral ties are built on more than just an export-processing zone cooperative project.

The Macedonian Cabinet underwent a reshuffle Nov. 30, with LP stalwarts taking on the posts of deputy prime minister and foreign minister. The LP replaced the Democratic Alternative (DA) party as the third member of the Macedonian ruling coalition, which also includes the Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization (VMRO) and the Democratic Party of Albanians (DPA).
Lee said that the establishment of ties between the two countries was decided by the two governments, not merely with the agreement of "a few Macedonian parties." There is "no problem," he added.

Describing ties between the two countries as undergoing a honeymoon stage, Lee said that the two would not likely be speaking so soon of a "divorce." However, he added that newlyweds inevitably have "small quarrels."
Macedonia is one of two European diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, the other being the Holy See.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ PREDICTED TO DECLINE AGAINST U.S. DOLLAR NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Chunghwa Institute for Economic Research forecast Monday that next year's parity between the new Taiwan dollar and the U.S. dollar will be NT$34.10 and might drop to NT$34.5 at its lowest point.

Chen Yuan-pao, the institute's director of the forecast center for economic prospects, said that the institute based its forecast on the premise that the deficit of Taiwan's international balance of payments will continue to expand and the inbound foreign capital inflow will be unable to maintain the level of this year.

Taiwan will be unable to maintain its favorable export situation after both Taiwan and mainland China are admitted into the World Trade Organization (WTO), further narrowing the trade surplus, he went on.

He forecast that the new Taiwan dollar will depreciate by 3 to 5 percentage points, a rate that the Central Bank of China would find tolerable so long as the local stock market does not drop further, capital and assets do not shrink further and a monetary crisis does not occur next year.
The local currency closed Monday at NT$33.076 against the U.S. dollar on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange Market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING BOAT CAPTAIN KILLED
DOC.DATELINE: Pintung, southern Taiwan, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A crewman from mainland China has stabbed and killed Tseng Min-lai, captain of a Pingtung-based trawler, and injured other two Taiwanese officers in waters off Malaysia, according to a Monday report.
Tseng's family urged the relevant government agencies to help them resolve the incident, which occurred at midnight on Dec. 16.

According to a foreign wire report, the suspect sneaked into the skipper's cabin and stabbed Tseng in the neck, killing him instantly, before going to the cabin of first officer Lin Hui-kuo and his roommate Wang Chih-wen, who put up a fight. The suspect fled by jumping into the sea.
The Long Wan Chern No. 47, with 10 crew members, including five mainland Chinese and two Indonesians, sailed for Malaysia Nov. 9.

One of the Indonesian crewmen informed ship's agent of the incident and the agent then informed the Malaysian authorities, who sent two patrol boats to escort the trawler into the port Penang for further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S FIRST COMMERCIAL BANK TO OPEN BRANCH IN EL SALVADOR

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based First Commercial Bank is scheduled to officially open its El Salvadoran branch Tuesday, bringing to 21 the total number of branches and offices operated by the bank overseas.

The bank has established branches throughout Asia, Europe and the Americas in cities including Hong Kong, Singapore, Tokyo, London, Frankfurt, New York, and Los Angeles. The El Salvadoran branch will handle savings, loans, import and export, and currency exchange services.

According to bank officials, El Salvador has a well-established transportation industry, its currency is relatively stable, and capital does not face government restrictions. With the second highest Gross National Product in Central America, it is a major regional commercial center.
Bank statistics show that Taiwan investment in El Salvador as of July totaled US$39 million, with textile export processing investment accounting for US$25 million.

A U.S. initiative begun under the Reagan administration has allowed El Salvador to become a Caribbean Basin Incentives (CBI) beneficiary country, whereby selected products manufactured in CBI countries can be exported duty-free to the United States. This has given an added boost to the country's competitiveness in textile manufacturing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMICONDUCTOR MAKERS DELIVER FIRST BATCH OF 12-INCH WAFERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, set a record Monday by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer, according to a company spokesman in Tainan County, southern Taiwan.
The 12-inch wafers, turned out by a production line at the company's 6th plant in the Tainan Science-Based Industrial Park, have already been received by the customer, the official added.

Touting the successful production of the wafer as a milestone in the island's semiconductor industry, which is the world's third-largest manufacturer of 6-inch and 8-inch wafers, the official said 12-inch wafers will be the backbone of wafer production in the early 21st century.
He went on to say that two 12-inch wafer plants, one in Hsinchu and one in Tainan, are still under construction, with targeted production dates of 2001 and 2002, respectively.
A third 12-inch wafer plant is on the cards and is also expected to be built in 2001, said the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OFFICIAL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ROC-U.S. TIES

TEXT.P: A high-ranking Ministry of Foreign Affairs official (MOFA) said Monday that he is optimistic about ROC-U.S. ties after U.S. President-elect George W. Bush takes office in January, 2001.
Vice Foreign Minister David Lee made the remarks while meeting the press after returning to Taipei from a visit to the Balkan state of Macedonia.

He termed Bush's nomination of Gen. Colin Powell as U.S. secretary of state as the "right choice" and praised Powell for his merits in the Persian Gulf War, when he served as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He also lauded Powell's rich experience in administrative affairs.
He expressed optimism about the development of bilateral ties after the Bush administration takes office.

Lee said that over the past eight years, many "U.S. friends" who served in former administrations have visited the ROC, some of whom have actively contacted with and exchanged views with ROC officials when those ROC officials visited the United States.
He refused to disclose the names of these U.S. officials, but said that the bilateral communication channel is very smooth.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLAYER WINS ASIAN CHINESE CHESS CHAMPIONSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Dec. 18 (CNA) (By Hsin Yi-ping and Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Chinese chess player Wu Yi-ping of the Republic of China captured Monday the title of the women's division of the 11th Asian Chinese Chess Championships being held in the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur.
Wu edged out Huang Wei of mainland China in a sudden death playoff to win the title.
Third place went to a Vietnamese player and a player from Malaysia was ranked fourth.
In the men's division, mainland China is vying for the title with Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 19, or the 24th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae Jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black money" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 14.95 points to close at 5,040.25.
The bourse opened at 5,004.6 and fluctuated between 5,044.07 and 4,957.27 during trading.

A total of 1.18 billion stocks worth NT$31.32 billion (US$0.95 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.9 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$25.79 billion (US$0.78 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted losses, with cement stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.4 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent, and construction stocks at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 311 to 196, with 87 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND `TORCH PROGRAM' DIRECTOR PROMOTES COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The director of mainland China's "Torch Program" said here Tuesday that jointly developing new products and technology with Taiwan will ensure a "win-win situation."

Zhang Jingan, director of the China Torch High Tech Development Center under the mainland Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST), is currently in Taipei for a two-day seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait industrial technology cooperation and development.

The seminar is being jointly organized by Taiwan's Chinese National Federation of Industries and a division of the mainland's MOST International Cooperation Department that handles cooperation and exchanges with Taiwan in the field of science and technology.

Zhang told the press that the two sides of the Strait have "a lot of space" for industrial cooperation. In the case of high tech industrial development, he said that Taiwan has the technology, while mainland China has the human talent and the market. Therefore, he added, the two should work together to develop new products and technology.

Zhang's "torch center" is the brainchild of mainland China's Minister of Science and Technology Zhu Lilan. The center is in charge of establishing and supervising the 40-some high and new technology industry development zones around the country and aims to nurture the mainland's domestic technology research capabilities.

After the two-day conference, Zhang's 39-member delegation of government officials, industry representatives, and academic experts is scheduled to visit the Institute for Information Industry, a quasi-governmental organization that promotes Taiwan's information industry and is charged with accelerating the country's national computerization program.

The delegation is also set to tour the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), the largest of Taiwan's non-profit research institutes. The ITRI serves primarily to develop industrial technologies and transfer them to domestic private enterprises to sharpen the competitive edge of Taiwan industry in the international market.

Zhang said that he is especially interested in seeing the software and hardware development environment at Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, a successful example of a government-university-industry initiative that is home to such prominent names as Acer and Mitec, both leading manufacturers of personal computers.

The park is also home to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., a pioneer in the semiconductor foundry business; United Micro-Electronics Corp. and TI-Acer, both leaders in the microprocessor and DRAM/SRAM business; and Umax, a leading producer of optical scanners and multimedia products.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA CAUGHT BETWEEN U.S. AND RUSSIA OVER MISSILE DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Canada on Monday found itself caught in the middle of growing tension between Russia and the United States over the issue of American plans to build a National Missile Defense system.

Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien and visiting Russian President Vladimir Putin spent over five hours meeting behind closed doors over the past two days, talking about issues regarding nuclear weapons, trade, and the Arctic.
At the end of their meeting, the two leaders signed an agreement on nuclear stability, with both questioning a plan by U.S. President-elect George W. Bush to create an NMD system.
Putin argued that the American plan to set up the missile defense shield would "damage international security," and he asked Canada to join with other nations to oppose the project.

Though both Putin and Chretien reaffirmed their support for the long-standing anti-ballistic missile treaty, Chretien said it was premature to discuss the NMD plan since it's still in the concept stage.

Any American system would need Canada's cooperation, and Chretien admitted that being between the U.S. and Russia on this issue is not a very comfortable position, telling Putin that "questions will be raised by the Canadian government."

"We're in a bit of geographical bind in a way because Russia is on one side, and on the other side is the Americans. So we want to consider all the consequences this program could have for Canada," Chretien told the media.

Russia said if the U.S. goes ahead with the program, it will destabilize world security. Now that it is no longer a world superpower, Russia seems to be looking to Canada for a little leverage with Washington, D.C.
Canada could act as a mediator, Putin said at a joint press meeting with Chretien.
Putin appeared to have gained Chretien's cautious support in his fight against Bush's plan for a nuclear defense system.
It's uncertain how the new administration in Washington will react to the new cooperation between Canada and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELLING MORE ARMS TO TAIWAN IN AMERICA'S BEST INTEREST: EXPERT

TEXT.P: An American expert on defense and foreign policy on Monday urged the new Bush administration to sell more arms to Taiwan, stressing that "an effective Taiwanese deterrent makes it less likely that the United States will ever be called on to rescue Taiwan and therefore is definitely in America's best interest."

Ted Galen Carpenter, vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the Washington-based Cato Institute, wrote in an Op-Ed article that as tensions continue to simmer between Communist China and Taiwan, the Bush administration will come under increasing pressure to provide Taiwan with a firm security guarantee.
"That could be dangerous and put the United States directly at risk. Instead, the United States should increase arms sales to Taiwan and encourage other countries to do the same," noted the expert.

Carpenter also called the Clinton administration's decision this year on arms sales to Taiwan "timid," saying that it "plays into Beijing's strategy to isolate, weaken, and ultimately strangle Taiwan."

He was referring to Washington's decision not to sell Taiwan the centerpiece of its purchase request, the Arleigh Burke-class Aegis destroyers, nor the diesel submarines and P-3 Orion patrol aircraft the island asked to buy. The administration also decided to keep the advanced AMRAAM medium-range air-to-air missiles in the United States unless Taiwan needed them in response to an emergency.
"If Taipei is to deter mainland China from using coercion on the issue of reunification, Taiwan must be able to purchase modern armaments, now and in the future," pointed out Carpenter.

He did add that this does not mean that Washington should approve every request, pointing out that Taipei's desire for diesel submarines, for example, seems ill advised and a waste of money. He said he is convinced that Taiwan's military would be better off increasing the number of its P-3 aircraft for anti-submarine missions in its next request order.

Carpenter stressed, however, that U.S. officials should approve most weapons systems Taiwan seeks and stop worrying about whether such actions will annoy Beijing because, as far as mainland China is concerned, any arms sale to Taiwan is unacceptable.

"In its self interest, Washington should be more open to Taiwan's arms requests. A well-armed Taiwan is better able to deter Beijing from contemplating the use of force to achieve reunification. Conversely, a Taiwan armed only with obsolete weaponry may prove an irresistible temptation to hardliners in Beijing," concluded Carpenter.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

The local currency opened Tuesday at 33.041 and was traded between 33.041 and 33.099.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, MATSU RESIDENTS START TO APPLY FOR TRAVEL TO M'LAND

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Immigration started to accept applications from residents of Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu for travel to mainland China Tuesday in anticipation of the opening of the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait.

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the ROC government has decided to open direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Mawei in Fujian province, the so-called "mini three links," effective Jan. 1, 2001.
Under the regulations, those who have had their residence on Kinmen or Matsu registered for more than six months can apply to enter the mainland anytime after Jan. 1 by ship.

The average citizen will be able to receive a multiple entry and exit permit valid for one year, while government employees, teachers, military servicemen, and police officers will be able to receive a single entry and exit permit valid for six months.

Mainland Chinese citizens who have a registered residence on the mainland, and not necessarily only in Fujian province, can apply to enter Kinmen or Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan proper.

But regulations state that mainland citizens who want to enter Kinmen or Matsu for business or academic activities, to visit relatives, or to attend the funerals of family members must have someone with residence status on Kinmen or Matsu apply on their behalf.

For individuals, the number of mainland Chinese citizens that will be allowed to enter Kinmen per day will be between 17 and 100, while the number allowed to enter Matsu per day will be between 3 and 20, depending on how many mainlanders are already present on the islands on any given day. The mainlanders will be able to stay on the outlying islands for a maximum of seven days per visit.

According to group tour regulations, each group must have between 10 and 25 people. Those visiting Kinmen as part of a tour group will be able to stay for a maximum of one night and two days, with the daily maximum number of mainland Chinese group tourists set at 600. Mainlanders visiting Matsu as part of a tour group will be able to stay on the island for two nights and three days, with the daily maximum number of mainland tour group visitors set at 40.

While the Bureau of Immigration and its service branches in Taichung, Kaohsiung, and Hualien have started to accept applications, those on Kinmen and Matsu have only started to hand out application forms and will begin processing applications from Thursday.
Lee Tzeng-shou, who was the first person to receive an application form, said that he has been waiting for this moment for more than five decades.
Lee said he obtained application forms for himself and his family members and also some for his relatives who were unable to leave the mainland over 50 years ago.
He said that he plans to take the first ship, which is scheduled to depart Jan. 1, to visit his relatives on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP FAILS TO PUSH THROUGH 44-HOUR WORKWEEK AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party legislators on Tuesday failed to push through a 44-hour workweek amendment to the new Labor Standards Law that is set to go into effect at the start of January.

Following the DPP administration's decision to increase the number of labor work hours from 84 hours per two-week period to 44 hours per week, the DPP legislators were unable to pick up enough votes against the opposition alliance among the Kuomintang, the People First Party, and the New Party, which together hold a majority in the Legislative Yuan.
The motion to amend the law failed by a vote of 77-61 with two abstentions during the first reading and by a vote of 80-60 with two abstentions during the second reading.

DPP Legislative Whip Hsu Tien-tsai said after the votes were tallied that his caucus will initiate a third attempt Friday. He urged labor organizations to understand the necessity of increasing the number of work hours due to the country's current economic plight, adding that he is certain there are more lawmakers who are supportive of the proposed amendment.
Premier Chang Chun-hsiung told reporters while inspecting the foreign ministry that the 44-hour workweek plan is the "best policy" that will create a win-win situation for both management and labor.

He went on to say that the Cabinet will not only continue to promote the amendment, but that it will also strive to persuade all sectors -- including the opposition-majority in the Legislative Yuan -- to support it because "there is no other way to go."

Chang said that the industry might "pay an immense price" once the law, which was passed in June, goes into effect on Jan. 1, adding that the Cabinet does not wish to see Taiwan industry face the "painful consequences."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN SUPPORTIVE OF UMC'S INVESTMENT PROJECT IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday after touring United Microelectronics Corp.'s plant in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park that he supports the major Taiwan computer chip maker's investment project in Singapore.

The president said that as long as domestic enterprises' outbound investment strengthens the continued growth and extention of domestic industry, the government will view it from a positive perspective and support it.

Chen said UMC's investment in the building of a US$3.6 billion wafer plant, the largest single Taiwan investment in Singapore, will serve as a reference for Taiwan on how Singapore attracts investors.

UMC's announcement last week that it will form a new company with German chip maker Infineon Technologies AG to build a 12-inch wafer foundry plant has aroused heated debate in Taiwan on whether this represents the beginning of the exodus of Taiwan's high-tech industry or the natural expansion of a mature technology company.

But UMC Chairman Robert H. C. Tsao, in a briefing to the president, said that UMC will definitely keep its roots in Taiwan and that its investment in Singapore will only be for the purpose of gaining experience.

The president lauded UMC's investment as representative of domestic enterprises' ability to go multi-national, meaning that they do not only have to invest in third world countries to make use of cheap labor there.

Chen stressed that through the UMC's investment in Singapore, Taiwan will be able to learn how the Singaporean government has used attractive offers and its high efficiency to introduce high-tech industry, how it has solved water and electricity supply problems, and how it has set environmental standards and implemented environmental measures, all of which will serve as a useful reference for the improvement of Taiwan's domestic investment environment.
Chen continued by saying that a modern government should not try to apply a too rigid approach to its top enterprises and turn them into second or third rate enterprises by tying them down too much.

The president said that he was gratified to see that UMC has continued in recent years to pursue the upgrading of its technology and the forming of international strategic alliances to expand its business scale.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 20, or the 25th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young Sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae Jung pardons Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 'POLITICAL REFORM MIRACLE' GIVES ISLAND ANOTHER EDGE: PM

TEXT.P: Besides Taiwan's well-known economic miracle, the miracle of its political reform is another element giving the island a competitive edge in the international arena, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday.
Unlike mainland China's political system, Taiwan's has legal opposition parties -- a result of decades of struggle for political reform, Chang said during a meeting at the Executive Yuan.
"We are still in the up-grading process and we, the government, are bracing ourselves for all varieties of challenges," Chang stressed.

Chang said he disagreed with recent allegations that while mainland China is now focusing its efforts on economic development, Taiwan is engaging in political struggle -- a situation opposite that during the era of President Chiang Ching-kuo when Taiwan was in full-gear developing its economy and mainland China was mired in disastrous domestic political strife.

He said the allegations are untrue as Taiwan has not only already achieved an economic miracle, it is also creating a miracle in the field of political reform, giving the island another major competitive advantage in the international community.

Meanwhile, commenting on the Democratic Progressive Party legislators' failure Tuesday to push through a 44-hour work-week amendment to the New Labor Standards Law that is set to go into effect Jan. 1, Chang insisted that a 44-hour work-week is the only approach that is beneficial to both management and labor.

Calling for support from members of the Legislative Yuan and from the labor sector for the 44-hour work-week amendment, Chang noted that the 84-hour per two-week work plan initiated by the opposition Kuomintang will only have the effect of pushing more domestic industries to relocate their operations abroad to avoid the inhospitable investment climate at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

Affected by a plunge in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 4,966.8 and continued to go down due to lack of purchasing willingness. The bourse fluctuated between 4,998.35 and 4,919.2 during trading.

Losers outnumbered gainers 444 to 67, with 77 stocks remaining unchanged.
