DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TROOPS CAPABLE OF DEFENDING NATIONAL SECURITY: MILITARY CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China armed forces are capable of defending national security, Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming said confidently Wednesday.

Tang was responding to a U.S. Defense Department report that conceded the existence of several "gaps" in its understanding of Taiwan's and mainland China's military capacities and needs which could affect the U.S. ability to comply with the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Tang said the ROC military is certainly capable of safeguarding Taiwan's security. "It's a matter beyond any doubt," he stressed after reviewing an army training exercise, code-named the "Brave Lions" drill, held at an army base in northern Taiwan.

The senior military officer further pointed out that as the Taiwan Strait stability holds the key to Northeast Asian peace and security, relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have been a common concern of the United States and Northeast Asian countries.

In his view, Tang said maintaining cross-strait military balance is crucial to safeguarding Northeast Asian regional peace and stability. "If any side of the Taiwan Strait does not have enough defense capability, regional peace and security would be threatened," he noted.

Tang was originally scheduled to fly to the ROC-held frontline island of Matsu to inspect its security measures in preparation for the imminent opening of direct "mini three links" with mainland China's Mawei port. As Matsu's Peikan airport was closed Wednesday morning due to poor weather conditions, Tang canceled his inspection tour and instead traveled to the Hukou military base where an infantry battalion of the motorized brigade was conducting an urban warfare training exercise.
The U.S. Defense Department said Monday there were three key "gaps" in Washington's ability to assess the potential for any future conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The Pentagon made the statements in an unclassified version of a report to Congress on continuing U.S. implementation of the TRA, the 1979 law that requires the United States to supply Taiwan with sufficient defensive weaponry.

"The Department of Defense has dedicated significant resources over the past two decades to monitoring the situation in the Taiwan Strait," said the report, which noted that tension between mainland China and Taiwan appeared to be low at the present time.

It further said that Washington continued to press Beijing and Taiwan to settle their differences peacefully. But the report cautioned that while much was known about airplanes, warships and other weaponry on both sides, "in general, three kinds of gaps stand out" in information needed by Washington to more accurately assess the situation:
-- Details on how authorities in Beijing and Taiwan view their military and political situations;
-- Information to predict how each side's military capabilities will develop in the key areas of missiles and information warfare.

"In some cases, we are unlikely ever to obtain exactly the information we would want," the six-page report said. "If some knowledge gaps cannot be corrected, it is at least advantageous to be aware that they exist."
In spelling out U.S. goals for the cross-strait issue, the report stopped short of committing the U.S. to come to Taiwan's defense if attacked.

"The overarching U.S. goal is to avoid any use or threat of force to resolve differences in the Taiwan Strait," it noted, adding that mainland China must be persuaded against or deterred from attacking or threatening attack, and if the attack comes, it must be "unsuccessful."
Finally, the report said, the Pentagon seeks to avoid in peacetime the erosion of its capacity to assist Taiwan in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS' PLANNED `TRIAL SAILING' TO MAINLAND ABORTED

TEXT.P: The planned trial sailing by a group of Taiwan legislators to the mainland Chinese port city of Xiamen prior to the implementation of the so-called "mini three links" has been aborted, sources from the Legislative Yuan said Wednesday.

The trial sailing plan was aborted because a notification by the legislators to Beijing's intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), through Taipei's counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), was actually not sent as planned on Tuesday as a result of Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen "saying no" to sending the message, said Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ken-teh.

Chen, convenor of the Legislative Yuan's Transportation Committee, said the notification was not sent out Tuesday because Tsai ordered a stop to the move, consequently delaying the preparatory period for the trial sailing and prompting the committee to call a halt to the plan.
Chen said Tsai will be invited to the Legislative Yuan soon to make a special report on this concern as "she owes us an explanation."

Chen planned to lead a delegation from the Legislative Yuan Transportation Committee and members of Taiwan's media on a sailing from the ROC-controlled frontline island of Kinmen across the Taiwan Strait to Xiamen on Dec. 28 to explore all varieties of possibilities prior to the kicking-off of the "mini three links."

As part of its efforts to help boost economic development on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, the ROC government has decided to allow direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the two offshore islands and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou in Fujian province, commonly known as the "mini three links," from Jan. 1, 2001.

Meanwhile, another similar Taiwan delegation, being sponsored by Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao, a lawmaker from Kinmen, is reportedly set to carry out its own trial sailing, also from Kinmen to Xiamen, as scheduled on Dec. 28.
It remains unclear whether the second group has already applied for such a trial sailing through the ordinary process for such matters, which includes an application to the ARATS via the SEF.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC TAKES OVER OIL BUSINESS ON KINMEN

TEXT.P: The soon-to-be privatized Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) has received authorization to take over the oil service industry on the frontline island of Kinmen, ending five decades of control by the Kinmen County Government.

The transfer will mark another of the positive results of the Republic of China's efforts to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait, which includes the impending kick-off of the "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail and shipping links between ROC-controlled outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou, scheduled for Jan. 1, said Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai.

Presiding over a ceremony marking the hand-over, Chen said owing to the unique cross-strait circumstances, the Kinmen County Government had been authorized to take charge of the oil industry and services for nearly five decades on Kinmen, a frontline anti-Communist China defense garrison until recently.
With the kicking-off of the "mini three links" on Jan. 1, 2001, Chen said demand for oil and petroleum products is expected to increase by leaps and bounds in the Kinmen area.

Also addressing the ceremony, Huang Chung-chuan, a CPC official from Kaohsiung who will be in charge of the new CPC business on Kinmen, said that although operations in the offshore area will be much more difficult and complicated than those on Taiwan proper, the company vows to provide the best possible services to consumers on Kinmen, which still has some 10,000 military personnel.
To ensure steady and sufficient supplies of oil and related products, Huang said the CPC is planning to build an oil terminal in Kinmen's Hsinhu District.
Construction of the new oil terminal, a complex of six oil depots and related facilities carrying a price tag of NT$200 million, is expected to begin later in 2001 if all goes smoothly, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGLE-DIGIT FIGURES EXPECTED FOR ROC'S DECEMBER EXPORT, IMPORT GROWTH

TEXT.P: The growth in the value of Taiwan's exports and imports for the month of December is only expected to be 7.5 percent and 2.0 percent respectively, the Ministry of Finance said Wednesday.
MOF officials said the estimated figures represent the first time that both exports and imports will only register single-digit monthly growth since October 1999.

The officials made the remarks after announcing that statistics showed exports for the period Dec. 1 to Dec. 16 totaled US$6.73 billion and imports totaled US$5.99 billion, up 7.1 percent and 0.5 percent respectively.
Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$740 million for the first half of December, up 1.3 times over the figure for the same period the previous year, they added.

The officials said that during the first half of December, the rate of increase in integrated circuit exports was relatively large, but exports of automatic data processors and component parts and industrial textiles experienced a relatively large rate of decrease.

The rate of increase in crude oil and sophisticated instrument imports was relatively large for the same period, and imports of electronic products and machinery experienced a relatively large rate of decrease, the officials added.
Affected by a global slowdown, Taiwan's economic development has also slowed, and demand for its electronics and information products has gradually shrunk.
Meanwhile, a domestic economic slowdown and the depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar has increased the cost of imports, leading to a decrease to single-digit growth in imports in December.
The officials also predicted that export growth for the whole year will be 21.8 percent, while import growth will be 26.7 percent.

Total exports for the year to Dec. 16 totaled US$142.12 billion, while imports for the same period amounted to US$134.7 billion, up 22.5 percent and 27.7 percent respectively over those of the same period the previous year.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's trade surplus for the year to Dec. 16 totaled US$7.36 billion, down 29.8 percent over the figure for the same period the year before.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR UPGRADING OF ROC-THAI RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian pitched for the upgrading of relations with Thailand Wednesday while meeting with a Thai senatorial delegation.

President Chen said the visit of the Thai senatorial mission symbolizes the cordiality of relationship between the two countries. Nevertheless, Chen said there is still ample room for the ROC and Thailand to upgrade their exchanges and cooperation.

Chen said he is hopeful that the Thai parliament can help push its government to throw support behind the ROC's bids to become a dialogue partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and a full member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the World Health Organization (WHO).

In view of ever-growing civilian and commercial exchanges between the two countries, Chen went on, Thailand should also upgrade the level of official contacts with the ROC and resume the annual ministerial-level economic conference.
"It is a must to enhance bilateral engagements, particularly exchanges of visits by high-ranking government officials," Chen said.
Thailand has been reluctant to maintain official contacts with the ROC since it switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1975.

President Chen said two-way trade between Taiwan and Thailand has grown steadily and reached US$4.5 billion last year. In addition, Chen said Taiwan is the largest employer of expatriate Thai workers and the third largest foreign investor in Thailand.

Against this backdrop, Chen said, Thailand should forge closer official contacts with the ROC for mutual benefits. "For one thing, the two countries should resume the annual ministerial-level economic conference which has bee suspended since 1991," he added.

Chen further suggested that the existing bilateral labor meeting be upgraded to the ministerial level to facilitate settlement of certain migrant workers-related issues and improve services for legal Thai workers in Taiwan.

More than 141,000 Thai people are now working in Taiwan, accounting for about 50 percent of total expatriate Thai laborers. Chen said he is grateful for the contribution of migrant Thai workers have made to Taiwan's infrastructure construction over past years. Chen told the visiting Thai senators that local employers are generally satisfied with Thai workers' diligence and law-abiding spirit.
The 10-member Thai delegation was headed by Sawai Prammanee, chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Labor and Welfare.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA ANNOUNCES MORATORIUM ON DEBT OWED BY POOREST COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Canada announced a moratorium Tuesday on the repayment of about C$700 million (US$455 million) in loans by some of the world's poorest countries.
Finance Minister Paul Martin's announcement puts Canada on the leading edge of an international initiative to forgive all debt owed by severely impoverished nations.

The moratorium lets most of Canada's poorest debtors off the hook on principal and interest payments. The debts will be forgiven when the countries fulfill promised democratic and human-rights reforms.
"Crippling debt burdens represent a formidable obstacle to the poorest countries of the world," Martin said.
"These nations must be given a sustainable path to enable them to provide basic services such as health care and education to their populations," he added.

About 17 countries are on Canada's list of poor debtors. Eleven of them will benefit from the moratorium, namely Benin, Bolivia, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Ghana, Guyana, Honduras, Madagascar, Senegal, Tanzania, and Zambia.

Countries such as the Democratic Republic of Congo, Liberia, Sudan, and the Ivory Coast still have too many human-rights problems to enjoy Canada's "humanitarian generosity," said Martin. The combined amount these countries owe Canada is about C$370 million (US$243 million).
"The countries that will be receiving the benefits of this moratorium are countries that have indicated unequivocally that they are prepared to put the money into health and education," said Martin.

He noted that the moratorium will be extended to the six excluded countries when Canada becomes satisfied that they are prepared to provide good government and spend the money on health and education.

Canada's plan, which goes into effect Jan. 1, 2001, won't cost the government much in terms of revenue as many of the world's poorest countries have not been servicing their bilateral debts anyway. Canada only collected about C$20 million in principal and interest payments in 1999 from these countries, or about 68 percent of what it was owed for that year.
The initiative won praise from aid groups, with even the conservative Canadian Taxpayers Federation voicing its support for the policy, saying the financial impact on Canada will be negligible.

"As an affluent country, we have a role to play in the community of nations," said federation president Walter Robinson. The challenge lies in ensuring the money is not invested in arms or "corporate welfare," he added.
Ensuring that recipients promote free-market reforms, property rights, and democratic governance is the best way of offering a hand up and breaking the cycle of welfare dependency, Robinson said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS URGE BUSH TO WORK TO MAINTAIN PEACE IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Two American China experts urged the new Bush administration to work to maintain peace in the Taiwan Straits and to make it clear to Beijing that continued deployment of increasing numbers of short- and medium-range missiles across from Taiwan make an American Theater Missile Defense response in the area almost inevitable.

David M. Lampton, director of the Nixon Center, and his assistant director, Gregory May, wrote in a recently published report that the United States, by maintaining a modest contingent of around 100,000 forward deployed troops, has managed to contribute to a stable balance of power and peace in the Asia-Pacific region's powder kegs, namely the Taiwan Straits and the Korean Peninsula.

"This should continue to be the focus of U.S. government policy in the region, though Washington needs to think creatively about how to best maintain a stable balance in the years ahead," said the report.

Currently, the two experts pointed out, cross-strait tensions "represent an unacceptably high risk of spiraling out of control. Policy assessment is needed in Washington, and this should be among the new administration's highest foreign policy priorities," they wrote.

They noted that mainland China's preoccupation with, and "deterrence" posture toward, Taiwan is hampering its ability to reassure neighbors in the Asia-Pacific of its peaceful intent. Beijing's military buildup will undoubtedly shape the policies of other Asia-Pacific actors, including the United States, "a fact Beijing does not acknowledge."

Beijing generally sees itself as reacting to the initiatives of others, rather than others reacting to its moves. "China's gradual buildup of short-range missiles to `deter' secessionist tendencies on Taiwan is a classic example of how Beijing's self-conception of reacting is feeding responses in Taiwan, in the United States, and more broadly in East Asia," they wrote.

While other countries in the region worry that Communist China will become less respectful of the interests of others as its overall economic and military strength continues to grow, Beijing worries about what it views as the "hegemony" of the United States, they noted.

With this in mind, the two experts recommended that the new Bush administration should do its best to involve Beijing in bilateral and multilateral arms control efforts and that it must give important weight to Communist China's reactions when it debates the issue of a national missile defense system.
"A missile defense deal with Russia that excludes China would be damaging to stability," they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.048 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 33.129.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 33.040 and was traded between 33.040 and 33.150.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$380 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LEGISLATOR CRITICIZES LAVISH SPENDING ON EX-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Legislator Elmer Feng of the opposition New Party Wednesday criticized the government for lavishly spending money to cover the expenses of previous President Lee Teng-hui.
Saying the exorbitant price tag of NT$80 million (US$2.4 million) a year set aside for Lee's expenses sets a "bad precedent in the world," Feng stressed that he would do his best to cut related fees.

Feng noted that the government has appropriated NT$30.16 million to care for the previous president in its budget for 2001, including NT$13.85 million for personnel expenses and 16.31 million for overhead.

Feng noted that the personnel expenses figure covers the retired president's annual pay of NT$4.93 million, which works out to NT$411,000 per month and not much less than the monthly salary of NT$440,000 for current President Chen Shui-bian, saying that "this is obviously not reasonable."

In addition to the ex-president's annual salary, the personnel fees figure also covers the pay for 12 staff members, totaling NT$8.92 million. Feng said there are "obviously too many" staff members for Lee, adding that most of them are government employees, which he said sets "a bad example."

Pointing out that the NT$16.31 million for overhead includes the rent of NT$12.25 million per year for the ex-president's residence and the monthly rent of NT$400,000 for Lee's office at the Taiwan Research Institute, Feng vowed to do his best to cut the government's spending on Lee's office rent at the think tank.

Of the NT$30.16 million appropriated this year, the government has already spent NT$20 million on decorating Lee's residence. Feng noted that this amount and the salary and bonuses for Lee's 22 security guards will bring the total for the year to NT$70 million, adding that if the NT$10 million expense for Lee's two limousines is tacked on, government spending on the ex-president will be about NT$80 million for the year.

Feng questioned if it is reasonable to spend such a large amount on a retired president when the general public is suffering from the economic slump and people living in areas affected by the major earthquake that struck Sep. 21 last year are still reeling from the disastrous temblor.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR CLOSER ROC-U.S.-JAPAN COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has called for closer cooperation among the United States, Japan and Taiwan in order to protect Asia from being dominated by a hegemonic mainland China.
Lee made the appeal in a recent interview in Taiwan with Japanese cartoonist Yoshinori Kobayashi, which was printed in the latest issue of SAPIO, a Japanese bi-weekly political magazine.
In his talks with Kobayashi, Lee said he does not think that a NATO-style security cooperation organization is likely to come into being in Asia.

"Therefore, it is important for individual Asian countries to form separate cooperative ties to ensure their own national security," Lee said, adding that Japan should be more confident of playing a leading role in handling regional security affairs.
Lee told Kobayashi, who has published a popular comic book on Taiwan, that he foresees drastic changes in mainland China's internal situation in the next eight years.

"My observation is that mainland China will be plagued by internal power struggles or a host of serious social and economic problems in the next eight years or so and will thus undergo significant changes from within," Lee noted.

In his view, Lee went on, it is crucial for Taiwan to persevere and withstand this transitional period. Lee said he has on many occasions reminded incumbent ROC President Chen Shui-bian of this issue.

Lee, an outspoken critic of mainland China's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, further pointed out that the fundamental dispute between Taipei and Beijing lies in their sovereign claims over Taiwan. Against this backdrop, Lee said he thinks that Taiwan should not co-host the 2008 Olympic Games with mainland China.

Asked about his views on enthusiastic Taiwanese investment in the mainland, Lee described such activities as "suicidal." According to Lee, mainland China-bound Taiwanese investors, lured by its vast market and cheap labor, are only seeking short-term profits.
Lee said he is convinced that Taiwan-financed companies on the mainland will certainly face many headaches soon, ranging from rising labor costs and water/power shortages to environmental problems.

Lee, who has a Ph.D. in agricultural economy from Cornell University, said Taiwan companies must upgrade production technology and management expertise if they are to survive global competition. He suggested that Taiwan businesses strengthen cooperation with their Japanese counterparts to maintain their market niches.

Although Lee stepped down from the ROC presidency in May, the Japanese government still refuses to allow Lee to visit as a private citizen due mainly to Beijing's strong opposition. In his interview with Kobayashi, Lee said he is confident that he will be able to visit Japan in the not-too-distant future. He once studied at Japan's Kyoto University.

Kobayashi's comic book on Taiwan has sold more than 240,000 copies, mostly to women in their 20s. Publishing industry sources said the comic book has helped attract many young Japanese women to make sightseeing trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: `MINI THREE LINKS' GESTURE OF GOOD FAITH TO MAINLAND CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Wednesday that the scheduled opening of direct "mini three links" Jan. 1, 2001 is an important move designed to express the Republic of China's sincerity and goodwill toward mainland China.

Speaking at a weekly Cabinet meeting, Chang said that although mainland China has so far given a lukewarm response to the imminent opening of direct trade, transport and postal links between the ROC-controlled islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected mainland Chinese ports -- the so-called "mini three links" -- it will mark a very important step forward in relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"Therefore, all relevant government agencies should cooperate closely to ensure the success of the measure," Chang said, adding that relevant government agencies should also step up a publicity campaign to help local people understand the true ramifications of the move.

After several months of preparations, the ROC government formally announced last week that it would allow a limited number of mainland people to visit Kinmen and Matsu from mainland China's southeastern province of Fujian on a trial basis for one year from the beginning of the new year.

The "open-door" decision also includes the easing of a decades-old ban on direct trade, shipping and postal links between Kinmen/Matsu and selected mainland ports -- Xiamen and Fuzhou in the initial stage.

Chang said the upcoming opening of the links is a prelude to Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the opening of full-fledged direct cross-strait trade, transport and mail links, also known as "the three direct links."

By opening the "mini three links," Chang said, the ROC wants to demonstrate to mainland China and the whole world that its commitment to forging rapprochement with Beijing is not just lip service. "We are always willing to take concrete steps to improve cross-strait relations," he pledged.

It remains unclear whether mainland China, which has not held any talks with Taiwan on the planned opening, will go along with the plan. According to press reports from the mainland, Beijing will neither respond to nor block the opening of the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: PALAU PRESIDENT-ELECT HOPES ROC WILL STRENGTHEN TOURISM INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of Palau President-elect Tommy Esang Remen Gesau expressed the hope Wednesday that the Republic of China and Palau will strengthen their economic relations, especially in terms of the tourism industry.
He made the remarks after holding a 30-minute meeting with ROC Economics Minister Lin Shin-yee.

Remen Gesau expressed hope after the meeting that the two countries will strengthen their economic and trade relations and cooperation on a mutually beneficial basis and said he discussed several potential cooperation projects, including the tourism industry, with Lin.

Lin said that he and Remen Gesau discussed several cooperation projects, including small- and medium-sized enterprises and the tourism industry. He added that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will evaluate all the proposals and will select some prospective projects to cooperate with Palau.
The ROC and Palau established diplomatic relations on Dec. 30, 1999. Taiwan has already invested US$55 million in Palau to build two golf courses and a hotel.
Two-way trade during the first 11 months of the year totaled US$5.46 million, with US$5.24 million trade surplus in the ROC's favor.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT: CROSS-STRAIT PEACE COMMON INTEREST OF ROC, JAPAN, U.S.

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.

Chen made the remarks as he received a a seven-member Japanese parliamentary delegation and added that the Beijing regime expansion of its military buildup and deployment of missiles affects not only Taiwan but also Japan and the United States.
He also claimed that Beijing accepts Japanese economic assistance to pay for these missile deployments and the military expansion.

Chen noted that Japanese parliamentary delegation was comprised of younger members of the Lower House from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), the Conservative Party, the Kuomei Party and opposition Democratic Party and expressed the hope that younger parliamentarians of both Japan and Taiwan will strengthen exchanges of visits so as to further cement relations.

He went on to say that among the 18 Cabinet members reshuffled by Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, 11 ministers belong to the pro-Taipei non-partisan "Japan-ROC Dietmens Council," while three others are very friendly toward Taiwan, adding that the Cabinet reshuffle was of very great significance to Taiwan.

Chen said that when the Japanese government reviews its foreign aid program, attention should be paid to the Beijing government. Although Japanese economic assistance to Beijing will certainly help maintain the peace and stability of the Asian-Pacific region and Beijing's efforts to develop its economy, which will help it carry out its democratization and liberalization, the Beijing regime is also using the aid to expand its military and deploy missiles.

Lower House member Yuriko Koike, on behalf of the visiting delegation, expressed gratitude to Chen for receiving them and also expressed the hope that younger parliamentarians on both sides will strengthen their exchanges to strengthen bilateral relations.

Touching on cross-strait issues and economic development in Taiwan, Chen said that Taiwan's economy is its lifeline and the government under his leadership will try its best to meet any challenge at home and abroad to carry out the established economic development policy.

He also said that the government will try to normalize economic and trade relations with mainland China and is reviewing the "no haste be patient" policy and the "three direct links" policy, as both Taiwan and mainland China will soon be admitted into the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET OKS ROC-PARAGUAY INTELLECTUAL ASSETS RIGHTS PROTECTION PACT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Cabinet approved Wednesday the ROC-Paraguay Intellectual Assets Rights Protection Agreement proposed earlier by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
The agreement will help upgrade industrial, high-tech and economic development between the ROC and Paraguay, an official of MOEA said.
ROC Economics Minister Lin Shin-yee and Paraguayan Minister of Commerce and Industry V. Acevedo inked the pact on behalf of their respective parties Nov. 23 in Taipei.

Under the agreement, each side will have a priority right to approve applications for patent rights on an invention, brand mark and service of a new invention presented by the other party. Each side can obtain information and systems from the other and can exchange published documentation, information and personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIST URGES LIMITATIONS ON TRADE TIES WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: A locally well-known economist told President Chen Shui-bian Wednesday that the government should curb Taiwan's commercial ties with mainland China for the sake of the island's security.

Contrary to local businessmen clamoring for a relaxation of the government's long-standing limitations on Taiwan's trade links with mainland China, Wu Rong-i, president of the non-profit Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, urged President Chen Shui-bian to impose "necessary" limitations on trade as well as on movement of capital and personnel across the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that the government has earmarked NT$250 billion (US$7.57 billion) for next year's defense budget because of Beijing's refusal to renounce the threat of force against Taiwan, Wu said it is "evident" that Taiwan should refrain from boosting Beijing's national strength by helping its economic development.

The present "no haste, be patient" policy which allows businessmen to invest in mainland China as long as the funds do not come directly from Taiwan and do not jeopardize the island's financial stability and national security, is the last resort of the government, Wu argued.

He conceded, however, that some non-technology industries on the island will perish without relocating to mainland China because of Taiwan's high labor costs, but argued that huge investment in mainland China, or some "special industry" that would erode the island's competitiveness against the mainland, should be prohibited.

Wu's views run counter to the calls from the island's low-tech sector, which has difficulty raising money because of the plummeting of its stock prices and is eager to relocate to the mainland to tap the cheap labor market there.
Wu said his institute has three recommendations for the president, namely:
-- revamping or scrapping the outdated regulations and speeding up the development of the service industry;
-- pushing ahead with knowledge-based economy in an innovative way and supporting young businessmen's ventures with a healthy capital market and tax breaks; and
-- improving the country's infrastructure and developing islandwide broad-brand and fixed-line networks.

Citing the deregulation of the telecommunication in 1996 as an example, Wu said Taiwan now has more than 15 million mobile subscribers, among the highest concentration in the world in light of its population, thanks to the opening of the telecommunication market to private operators in 1998.
The economist refused to comment on Wednesday's plummet of the Taipei stock market, which saw its benchmark index sink below the psychological mark of 5,000 points.
"As a member of the national stabilization fund" set up to boost the sapping stock prices, Wu said he is not in a position to make any public comment on the matter.
He also defended Chen's detachment from the tumbling stock market, saying that the up and down of stock prices is none of the president's business.
As to the value of the new Taiwan dollar, Wu said he thinks the local currency's decline against the greenback will turn around soon, given the slowdown in the U.S. economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ANTI-TANK MISSILES COMMISSIONED INTO ARMY SERVICE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army's newly acquired anti-tank weapon -- TOW-2A missiles -- came into the limelight for the first time Wednesday when they were used on the second day of a two-day military training exercise.

Military sources said the U.S.-made TOW-2A missiles have high mobility, as they can either be installed on mobile missile launchers or in static positions. Equipped with an infrared tracking device, TOW-2A missiles, which are now mounted on the Army's mobile M113 missile launchers, have an extremely high accuracy rate.

Army officers said the deployment of the new missiles is part of the grass-roots army units' current campaign to upgrade their equipment and beef up their firepower in line with the ROC's military build-up goal of establishing an elite deterrent force in the face of mainland China's persistent military threat.
The TOW-2A missiles have replaced the aging 106 mm and 75 mm howitzers previously used by the anti-tank army units, military sources said.

Army officials said the TOW-2A missiles have been assigned to the anti-armored vehicle battalions under the army's motorized brigades. Each battalion now has 12 M113 TOW missile launchers, each of which can accommodate 10 missiles at a time.

Meanwhile, army officers said the army is also seeking to purchase French-made APILAS short-range TOW anti-tank missiles. "The new procurement plan is approaching maturity," said an army official, who preferred anonymity.
In an effort to demonstrate the combat capability of its newly formed combined services brigades, the army launched a two-day training exercise Tuesday at an army base in northern Taiwan.

The "Brave Lions" training drill was carried out by the 269 motorized brigade, one of the toughest of its kind in the army. The exercise was based on a scenario that Taiwan was under attack by mainland China.

The second day of the training drill involved a simulation of nighttime and pre-dawn urban warfare. The "Brave Lions" exercise also marked the first time that a regular training exercise of this kind was open to the press.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS WORTH US$ 13 BILLION RECEIVED IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Export orders worth US$13 billion were received in November by Taiwan firms, representing a 10 percent increase over the same period of a year ago, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Wednesday.

The official said that the semiconductor industry topped the growth list with a rate of 45 percent over the previous year, while the information technology and communications industries, which topped the growth list last year, posted a zero growth rate this year.
The official also forecast that export orders for the whole year will grow 20 percent over that of last year.
Taiwan enjoyed record export orders totaling US$13.9 billion in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA PLANS TO PRODUCE NT$ 200 B.-WORTH OF WIRELESS COMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: A "wireless communications program" being implemented by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is expected to produce NT$200 billion-worth of wireless communications items by the year 2005.

An IDB official said Wednesday that in addition to achieving the production goal, the project will also help Taiwan become a major global supplier of cellular phones as well as a major exporting country of wireless communications devices.
The program will also help Taiwan become the world No.1 in wireless modems for telecommunications products.

The program is expected to produce worth N$100 billion-worth of wireless communications items by 2002, during which period, the MOEA hopes Taiwan will become one of the important production bases of low-priced cellular phones and the main supplier of wireless modem systems in the Asia-Pacific region.

Wong Pu-shan, board chairman of the Wireless Communications Federation, said that the development of the wireless communications industry is a world trend and that the cellular phone business will become one of the world's most important communications services in the 21st century.
The IDB hopes that the wireless communication industry will become a locomotive industry for the semiconductor, information and software industries, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER TAIPEI LANDMARK TO BE TORN DOWN

TEXT.P: The 42-year old Taipei City Baseball Stadium is to be torn down, with the result of bidding in open tender for the project to be announced Friday by Taipei City Hall's Division of New Construction Projects, a division source said Wednesday.
So far, the facilities and equipment of the stadium have been removed. If everything goes smoothly, demolition is expected to start at the end of this year, according to the source.
It was learned that after the demolition, a new sports stadium will be built on the original site of the baseball stadium.
Meanwhile, the repair project of the sports stadium of Taipei Physical Education College is now under way with the invitations to bid in open tender completed Monday.
It is expected that the repair work on this stadium will start in January and be completed in March next year, according to a college source.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO COMPLETE REPORT ON SIA AIR CRASH BY MID-FEBRUARY
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aviation Safety Council (ASC) plans to make public in mid-February its investigation report on the Oct. 31 crash of a Singapore Airlines (SIA) plane in Taiwan, according to a Singapore news report Wednesday.

An ASC official was quoted as saying that the accounts of the three Singaporean pilots of the jumbo jet and those of officials at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, site of the crash, will be included in the report.
The official said that investigators will begin analyzing relevant data to determine the cause of the crash after the report is completed.
The Los Angeles-bound jet crashed and burst into flames while trying to take off amid strong winds and heavy rain. Eighty-two of the 179 people aboard were killed.
Pilot error was blamed for the accident because the pilot took the plane onto a runway that had been closed for repair since September.
Investigators expect that the reason for the error will be determined in about one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE-LANGUAGE WEBSITE ON TAIWAN PRODUCTS TO BE INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A Japanese-language website on Taiwan-made products will be formally inaugurated Thursday, a Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) official said Wednesday.
The website will showcase Taiwan-made electrical and electronic items, machinery and computers and Japanese buyers will also be able to directly search for Taiwan suppliers, the official said.
The website, which will be called www.taiwantrade.gr.jp, will be formally inaugurated by Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long at the Taipei International Conference Center.

Under the co-sponsorship of BOFT, the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, the Taiwan Association of Machinery Industry and the Taipei Computer Association, the website will help local producers promote sales to Japan so as to narrow the huge trade deficit suffered by the ROC.
Taiwan suffered a US$18.7 billion trade deficit with Japan last year. The trade deficit this year is expected to reach US$22 billion.
A total of 8,700 manufacturers and traders and over 3,000 catalogs of products, as well as some 23,000 main Japanese buyers, will be listed on the website.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES URGED TO TRANSFORM FOR SURVIVAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that traditional industries must transform and upgrade if they want continued development and survival.
He made the remarks while receiving outstanding businessmen from the machinery industry.
Chen noted that Taiwan will become an important member of the global trading system after it joins the World Trade Organization in the near future.

Facing the severe challenge of complete trade liberalization and internationalization, he said that Taiwan's industries, both in the high-tech and traditional sectors, must speed up their pace of renovation and improvement.

Chen said that the government will play a more positive role in improving the domestic investment environment by removing non-economic obstacles so as to provide the private sector with a better stage for pursuing development.
Regarding the upgrading of traditional industries, he said that efforts must be placed on the improvement of management and concepts.
He urged these industries to support the government and follow the government's policy on improvement of the island's industrial level.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ENACT WTO-RELATED LAWS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said Wednesday that nine laws will hopefully be enacted by the Legislative Yuan by next spring to pave the way for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
He told reporters that Vice Premier Lai In-jaw instructed administrative units at a Tuesday meeting to enhance communications with legislators over the issue.
The meeting was attended by the chiefs of the Mainland Affairs Council, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, the Economics Ministry and the Council of Agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 750,000 KMT REAFFIRM PARTY MEMBERSHIP

TEXT.P: With the deadline for opposition Kuomintang (KMT) members to reconfirm their party memberships only ten days away, some 750,000 members have so far re-registered with the party across the island, party officials said Wednesday.

Calling it "a shot in the arm" for the party which handed over political power earlier this year after being defeated in the presidential election, the party sources said that KMT leaders had taken heart from the higher-than-expected number of party members reconfirming their loyalty to the party.
Taking a lesson from past failures, the sources said, the KMT will beef up the communication between the party apparatus and party members and form a strong links between them.
The party had urged its members to reconfirm their affiliation by re-registering their membership between September and December.

The party, which once boasted a membership of 4 million, was embarrassed and humiliated to see its candidate, former Vice President Lien Chan, come in a remote third in the presidential election in March.
Stimulated by the defeat, the party launched the registration campaign with the aim of reaffirming its membership and laying the ground for choosing party leaders and candidates through primaries.

KMT Deputy Secretary-General Shaw Yu-ming said the election of the party chairman directly by party members early next year is a warm-up for party primaries for the selection of party candidates for the legislative elections at the end of 2001.

The KMT used to pick party candidates through a panel of party leaders, and those who failed to be nominated often thumbed their noses at the party bosses by entering the race as independents -- and often spliting the party voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC OFFICIAL URGES POPULACE TO BE CONFIDENT IN EXCHANGE RATE

TEXT.P: A Central Bank of China (CBC) official urged the Taiwan populace Wednesday to be confident in the new Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the US dollar and not to be "misled" by future forecasts on exchange rate trends.
Chou A-ting, director-general of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, made the call at a press conference.

The exchange rate, he said, depends on the supply and demand for US currency on the Taipei foreign exchange market. He added that the factors affecting the supply and demand for US dollars are as follows:
-- Exports;
-- Capital trading, including direct investments, securities investments and other investments;
-- Effects caused by "third nations;" and
-- The psychology of anticipation.

He said it is very difficult to predict foreign exchange rate trends in view of the fact that many of these factors are affected by influences abroad and are thus hard for local institutions to control.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
KMT Chairman Lien Chan questions the legal basis for the proposed joint bidding center for all public construction projects.
The China Times:
Four banks are targeted for probes on suspected irregularities.
The United Daily News:
Fed warns of further slowdown of the U.S. economy.
The Liberty Times:
Former President Lee Teng-hui says Taiwanese investments in mainland China are suicidal moves.
The China Post:
'Mini three links' a goodwill gesture, says Premier Chang.
The Taiwan News:
Taiwan stock index dives below 5,000 points.
The Taipei Times:
DPP upbeat on working hours plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPORTS TO U.S. HIT SINGLE-MONTH RECORD HIGH IN OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 20 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to the United States amounted to US$3.78 billion in October, marking the sixth single-month record high in a row, sources from the U.S. Department of Commerce reported Wednesday.

The October figure represented a whopping 26.2 percent increase over that of the same month the previous year and was mainly the result of the considerable depreciation in the value of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback, according to foreign trade experts in Washington.
Taiwan exported US$33.95 billion worth of products to the United States in the first 10 months of this year, registering an annual growth rate of 17.95 percent, according to the DOC tallies.

Based on the Jan.-Oct. performance, Taiwan's exports to the United States are expected to exceed the mark of US$40 billion for the first time ever this year, the foreign trade experts said. Taiwan's exports to the United States totaled US$35.19 billion in 1999.

According to the DOC tallies, Taiwan is currently the seventh largest source of imports to the United States. It is also the United States' seventh largest export market and its sixth largest source of trade deficit.

Cumulatively, two-way trade between Taiwan and the United States was US$54.66 billion in the first 10 months of 2000, up an impressive 23.2 percent over the figure for the same period in the previous year.
Taiwan is presently the United States' eighth largest trading partner, behind Canada, Mexico, Japan, mainland China, Germany, Britain, and South Korea, in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 130.67 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 130.67 points to close at 4,817.22.
Market turnover amounted to NT$14.79 billion (US$0.45 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 21, or the 26th day of the 11th month in Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to Earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 130.67 points to close at 4,817.22.
Affected by a plunge in the NASDAQ index, the bourse opened at 4,834.76 and continued to go down due to pessimism among investors. The bourse fluctuated between 4,834.76 and 4,797.27 during trading.

A total of 0.64 billion stocks worth NT$14.79 billion (US$0.45 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.08 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$26.23 billion (US$0.79 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 2.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.4 percent, textile issues at 2.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 2 percent, cement stocks at 1.3 percent, constructions shares at 1.2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 462 to 61, with 57 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved down 169 points to close at 4,687, with 4,357 contracts changing hands.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI DEVELOPS WORLD'S FASTEST DNA SEARCH AND COMPARISON SOFTWARE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announced Thursday the development of a commercial software package allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.

The software, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), is being boasted as the fastest of its kind in the world. It consists of a series of bioinformatics software packages which all employ the novel algorithm allowing very rapid paired local alignment, said Lee Chung-hsi, director of ITRI's Biomedical Engineering Center.

Noting that the ultimate goal of genetic research is to find the connections between genes and diseases and to research and develop new medicines and cures for the diseases, Lee said FLAG, using bioinformatics techniques, offers a helpful commercially-applicable software package making quick genomic DNA comparison and searches easy.

According to Adam Yao, FLAG project manager, l-FLAG and s-FLAG are two software packages that allow for long sequence comparisons at a rapid speed, requiring only 21 minutes to compare C. elegans chromosomes 1 and 3 on a PC workstation.

Yao said FLAG may run faster than BLAST, a similar version developed earlier in the United States, when a query sequence is over 2000 bases. FLAG also tends to find more matches with medium similarity (50-75 percent) than BLAST, Yao said.

Yao said he and his 15-member project team are preparing FLAG for beta testing. "We welcome all interested users, particularly those who tend to perform large-scale sequence alignments, to try out this software," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD INVEST MORE FOR FUTURE: NOBEL LAUREATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should invest more for future and should carve out a way and a direction for itself instead of just following in the footsteps of Western countries, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh urged Thursday.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, made the remarks while attending a ground-breaking ceremony for a new production facility of Silicon Integrated Systems Corp. in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

Noting that continued investment is key to sustain a country's development, Lee said Taiwan must spend more on scientific/technological development, education and manpower cultivation, in addition to investing in traditional and high-tech industries.

In his view, Lee went on, research and development (R&D) will determine a country's competitiveness in the 21st century, particularly in biotechnology and genetic study which will become a main battlefield.' "Taiwan must brace itself for ever more intensive competition in the biotech field in the new century," he noted.
Through strenuous efforts over past five decades, Lee said, Taiwan has managed to lay a solid foundation for future development.

"We should not forget our own strength while reviewing our past developments. We should also avoid blindly following the path of Western countries and should find out our own way and direction to maintain our market niches," the respected scholar said.

Silicon Integrated Systems Corp. (SISC), headquartered in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan, became the 27th company to build a factory in the Tainan industrial park. It will invest an estimated NT$50 billion for building the new wafer production facility. The government has so far approved applications by 50 firms for establishing plants in the Tainan high-tech park.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT FILES LIBEL SUIT AGAINST MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu filed a libel suit against a local magazine Thursday after mediation efforts to end a dispute between the two sides failed.
Tsai Ming-hua, spokeswoman of the vice presidential office, said Lu is seeking to clear her name and gain a public apology from The Journalist by filing the civil lawsuit against the magazine.
Tsai made the remarks after a legal team, comprised of eight lawyers from the Taiwan Bar Association, announced that its mission had failed after days of mediation efforts.

Tsai said that what Lu wants is clear, namely to have the entire truth be revealed before she considers talking about reconciliation. In other words, the vice president wants the magazine to present the alleged tape of her spreading the rumor of an alleged extramarital affair between President Chen Shui-bian and one of his female aides or else publish a public apology to clear Lu's name.

Lu's own legal team had earlier said that a careful examination of the vice president's residential telephone logs from Nov. 1-12 shows she did not call up any members of the media on Nov. 3 after 7 p.m. or at any other time to initiate the rumor.
In its Nov. 18 issue, the magazine accused Lu of contacting a "senior media person" to inform them of the alleged affair.

The vice president's legal team accused the magazine of showing "real malice" by claiming "without the slightest evidence" that Lu wanted to use the alleged presidential scandal to "finish off" the president and "flow with the momentum to scale new heights."
Tsai stressed that the magazine's position of not apologizing to the vice president and only offering to run a statement by Lu on the matter in the magazine is unacceptable.
Meanwhile, The Journalist issued a statement that it regretted the breakdown in mediation efforts, saying that it would now actively prepare for all legal proceedings.

Chu Sheng-chun, president of the Taiwan Bar Association, said Thursday on behalf of the mediation team that it tried to mediate between the two sides between Dec. 15 and Dec. 20 based on the principles of "sincerity, efficiency, and privacy."
Chu said that the team hoped that the whole thing would end peacefully and that both human rights and press freedom would be preserved unharmed.
But as the two sides continued to insist on their respective positions, the team had to announce with regret that the mediation mission had failed.

Lu had earlier set a dateline of Dec. 10 for the magazine to publish a public apology or face legal action, but she delayed the action to give the mediation team a chance to step in and try to resolve the dispute.

Wang Chien-chuang, president of The Journalist, has said that the magazine will stand by its report, noting that there is "sufficient reason" to believe in the accuracy of the report and that the fact that his magazine "went to great pains to reasonably verify the facts" shows there was never any malicious intent to defame anyone.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE AIRLINES PILOTS FREED

TEXT.P: The three Singapore Airlines (SIA) pilots who have been detained since the crash of SIA Flight SQ006 that killed 83 of the 179 people aboard on the evening of Oct. 31 were freed Thursday by the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office.

Prosecutor Huang Mo-hsin said the detention of the three pilots of the SIA jumbo jet that crashed during take-off at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in stormy weather has been suspended and the restriction on their leaving Taiwan has been lifted.

The pilots -- flight commander Capt. Foong Chee Kong, 41, a Malaysian, and Singaporean co-pilots Latif Cyrano, 36, and Ng Kheng Leng, 38 -- are expected to return to Singapore later on Thursday or Friday.

They were freed after officials from SIA and the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei who were given joint custody of the trio last week by Taoyuan prosecutors gave bonds obligating them to produce the three men at any time that they are summoned.

The pilots were originally expected to go home last week after officials from the Singapore Trade Office in Taipei signed court documents guaranteeing they would return to Taipei when they are needed for the crash investigation.
However, the Taoyuan prosecutors added a requirement last Friday that Singapore Airlines should also be responsible for the return of the three pilots when they are summoned.

The prosecutors declined to say whether their decision to impose additional conditions for the release was related to the pilots' absence from a flight simulation designed to help determine the cause of the accident.

At the request of prosecutors, Singapore Airlines arranged last Thursday for a cargo plane similar to the ill-fated Boeing 747 passenger plane that crashed to conduct a simulated flight to retrace the path of SIA Flight SQ006.

Prosecutors said they hoped to gain a better understanding of the crash via the simulation in order to determine whether the accident was caused by pilot error, misleading control tower instructions, bad weather, or other reasons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRIC-POWERED BUSES TO BEGIN TEST RUN IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Two electric-powered buses were handed over to the Taichung city government Thursday in a bid to cut air pollution in the city.
Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying said that the electric-powered buses have low chassis, which means that they will be more convenient for elders and the disabled to board and get off.
Chang said that most of the passengers were satisfied with the performance and comfort of the new buses, which have an average speed of 60 kilometers per hour and can accommodate 30 passengers.
The Environmental Protection Administration, which subsidizes the program, said that the advantage of using electric-powered buses is a reduction in pollution caused by diesel emissions.
The EPA said that during the six-month test run of the new buses in Taichung, careful assessments regarding the weather, roads, and passenger reactions will be conducted.

DOC.HEADLINE: `MINI THREE LINKS' MARKS GOODWILL GESTURE TOWARD MAINLAND: PM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's initiation of the "mini three links" is meant to show goodwill toward mainland China and eventually help bolster friendliness across the Taiwan Strait, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday.

In an annual briefing to members of the Control Yuan, the nation's top watchdog authority on major administrative policies, Chang said the government has already completed impact assessments and planning for the "mini three links" in an effort to improve cross-strait relations.

The "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the Republic of China's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou, both in the southern province of Fujian, are scheduled to kick off on Jan. 1, Chang noted.
Chang added that the implementation of the "mini three links" will not only serve as a peace initiative toward Beijing, but will also help promote economic development in the ROC's offshore counties.

Chang noted, however, that after the opening of the links, related ROC agencies will be highly vigilant against irregularities, such as prohibited shipping between mainland Chinese ports and Taiwan proper.

Meanwhile, he said, the Executive Yuan is also working on plans paving the way for the implementation of the more significant direct trade, post, and transportation links between Taiwan proper and mainland China, better known as the "big three direct links," in order to cope with Taiwan and mainland China's expected entry into the World Trade Organization and the eventual reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S BATTLE AGAINST CORRUPTION FAR FROM OVER: VOA

TEXT.P: Despite some official declarations of success in Communist China's iron fist crackdown on graft, the battle against corruption is far from over, with some believing that corruption could threaten the very survival of the Communist Party, reported the Voice of America radio station Thursday.

The VOA, which expresses U.S. government policies, pointed out that with Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization just around the corner and with the resulting faster pace of growth in the mainland's economy, Communist Chinese officials will have even more opportunities to misuse public funds.

In September, the VOA said, hundreds of thousands of mainland Chinese viewers watched Cheng Kejie, a former vice chairman of the nation's parliament, being sentenced to death for taking millions of dollars in bribes. He became the highest level Communist Chinese official ever put to death for corruption.

Jean-Pierre Cabestan, director of the Hong Kong-based French Center for Research on Contemporary China, noted that Communist Chinese leaders fear corruption is eating away at popular support for Communist rule and are therefore anxious to show the public that they are serious about wiping it out.

In the first eight months of this year alone, Communist China prosecuted more than 23,000 criminal corruption cases. And in November, it sentenced to death 14 people, including some senior officials, for their role in the biggest smuggling and payoff scandal in Communist Chinese history.

More officials are expected to be ensnared in the Fujian smuggling scandal, but Cabestan said Communist Chinese leaders are debating who to sacrifice and who to save. For example, Beijing's Communist Party chief Jia Qingling is said to have been involved in the scandal when he was the top leader in Fujian province at the time when most of the smuggling occurred. Jia, however, remains in power, with many feeling it is due to the fact that he is a close ally of President Jiang Zemin.

The VOA said that because so many senior officials have been linked to graft scandals, the Beijing leadership's crackdown on corruption is a double-edged sword. The more senior officials that are publicly prosecuted, the more people begin to question the legitimacy of the Communist Party itself, it pointed out.

Many mainland Chinese citizens now believe that those most responsible for corruption have remained unscathed by the crackdown, saying the Beijing regime is only going after minor figures and sparing people at the top, reported the VOA.

Ms. He Qinglian, an economist and outspoken critic of corruption, told the VOA that the government's crackdown fails to attack the root of the problem. She was demoted from her position as newspaper editor because of her vocal stance on corruption, she said, adding that the question is not who in mainland China is corrupt, but who is not corrupt.

She stressed that many countries do not need to resort to executions to cure graft and that the one-party system leads naturally to corruption because those in power are not subject to any independent supervision. She said she believes the only way to cure the problem is to allow for the formation of political parties besides the Communist Party. She also said the news media requires more freedom to expose wrongdoing.

But the VOA said Communist China's leaders are deeply concerned that any loosening of their tight grip on power would lead to a disintegration of the Communist Party and even of the state, just as the Soviet Union collapsed ten years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 22, or the 27th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1895: Using his newly discovered X-ray technology, German physicist Wilhelm Konrad Roentgen photographs his wife's hand to reveal the bones beneath the skin.
1905: The Ching court signs a treaty with Japan in Peking regarding Manchurian affairs, following Japan's victory over Russia in the Russo-Japanese War.
1907: The Ching government sets up the Directorate General of Railways and appoints Liang Shih-yu as the director-general.
1909: Korean Prime Minister Yi Wanyong, who agreed to a merger of Korea with Japan, is badly injured by assassins. Japan took complete control of Korea less than a year later.
1915: China's Ministry of Education sets up a training center to teach the phonetic annotation of the Chinese alphabet.
1936: Noted Chinese writer Yu Ta-fu visits Taiwan
1936: Madame Chiang Kai-shek, accompanied by W. H. Donald and T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), fly to Xian.
1938: Japanese Prime Minister Prince Konoye lays down a three-point guiding principle for the settlement of the Sino-Japanese conflict and the establishment of a "New Order in East Asia."
1942: U.S. heavy bomber planes bomb Japanese-occupied Rangoon, Burma.
1945: General George Marshall arrives in Chungking as U.S. President Truman's special envoy.
1945: The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union hold a meeting in Moscow.
1961: James Davis becomes the first American soldier to die in Vietnam since America's involvement began in the Southeast Asian country.
1965: President Chiang Kai-shek issues a decree convoking an extraordinary session of the National Assembly in Taipei on Feb. 1, 1966.
1968: North Korea releases 82 crewmen of the U.S. intelligence ship Pueblo at the truce village of Panmunjom, 11 months after their capture off the North Korean coast.
1971: Austrian envoy Kurt Waldheim becomes the secretary-general of the United Nations.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Australia and New Zealand.
1976: Adm. Soong Chang-chih, chief of the general staff, presents citations to outstanding cadres and political warfare personnel.
1989: Civil war in Romania ends the 24-year-long reign of terror by Nicolae Ceausescu, who flees Bucharest with his wife Elena. Both were later executed.
1990: Lech Walesa becomes Poland's first popularly elected president.
1991: Dissident mainland Chinese astrophysicist Fang Li-chih visits Taipei.
1996: Chiang Hsiao-yung, the third son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo, dies of cancer in Taipei at the age of 49.
1997: Hong Kong authorities decide to destroy all chickens imported from mainland China after three people die of what is thought to be a strain of flu carried by poultry.
1999: Nasir Ahmed Sooro, listed as the world's tallest (236.2 cm) person by the Guinness Book of World Records, meets with the local press as he starts his four-month visit to Taiwan.
Confucius lesson for the day: "Treat people with seriousness and they will respect you. Let them see that you honor your parents and your prince, and are considerate of the welfare of those under you, and the people will be loyal to you. Advance those who excel in anything and educate the ignorant, and the people will exert themselves."
