DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN, OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN POST RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The total value of fresh investments made in Taiwan by foreign nationals and overseas Chinese between January and November of this year hit a record high of US$6.853 billion, up a whopping 92.66 percent over the year-earlier level, the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Friday.

Officials from the MOEA's Investment Commission attributed the remarkable increase mainly to surging overseas investments in Taiwan's telecommunications industry, including its mobile phone industry, after the government liberalized the up-and-coming industry early this year.

In November alone, foreign nationals and overseas Chinese channeled US$794.24 million into Taiwan for 69 investment projects, marking a noticeable growth of 69 percent over the total for the same month in 1999.

Of the total amount of fresh foreign and overseas Chinese investment from January to November, 30.29 percent went into Taiwan's financial and insurance industries and 17.29 percent was put into the telecommunications and related services industry, the officials said.

Meanwhile, Taiwan companies remitted some US$2.3 billion to mainland China in the first 11 months of this year for various investment projects, mainly electronics and electrical appliance manufacturing.
The Jan.-Nov. mainland-bound investment marked a staggering increase of 93 percent over that of the corresponding period the previous year, the officials noted.

They said they believe the whopping increase in Taiwan's mainland-bound investment is the result of mainland China's expected entry into the World Trade Organization and the resulting jostling for position by Taiwan and foreign companies in attaining a share of the promising mainland markets.

Meanwhile, the officials noted, Taiwan's out-bound investment to overseas areas beyond mainland China grew by a relatively slower pace of 23 percent to total US$3.765 billion for the Jan.-Nov. period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CHANG TO VISIT KINMEN TUESDAY FOR 'MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will visit the frontline island of Kinmen Tuesday to inspect preparations for the impending opening of the direct "mini three links" with selected mainland Chinese ports, Cabinet sources said Friday.

According to the sources, Premier Chang will attend a seminar on issues related to the "mini three links" to be held at the Kinmen Defense Headquarters and officiate at the inaugural ceremony for a Cabinet-level "mini three links" coordination center during his inspection tour.

Chang will also inspect new facilities at the Liaolo port, which will be opened for direct shipping links with mainland China's port city of Xiamen as part of the much-anticipated opening of "mini three links" on Jan. 1, 2001.

The "mini three links" refer to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the Republic of China's defense outposts of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou, both in the southeastern province of Fujian which lies opposite Taiwan.

In a briefing to a group of members of the watchdog Control Yuan, Premier Chan said the opening of the "mini three links" is part of the government efforts to show sincerity and goodwill toward mainland China.

Chang said he is hopeful that the "mini three links" kick off smoothly as scheduled to help forge rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait and to help boost economic development in the ROC's two offshore islands, which lie far closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

In preparation for the opening of "mini three links," the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) conducted a rehearsal of immigration and customs clearance services at the newly refurbished passenger service center at Kinmen's Liaolo port Friday morning.

Wu Rong-quey, director of the MOTC's Navigation and Aviation Department, presided over the rehearsal, which was participated by staff members from the MOTC and many other relevant government agencies, including the Kinmen county Government's harbor division, the Bureau of Immigration under the Ministry of the Interior, the Kaohsiung Customs Office under the Ministry of Finance, the National Coast Guard Administration, the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health, the Plant and Animal Inspection and Quarantine Bureau and the National Bureau of Standards.

The rehearsal involved a simulation of 200 passengers proceeding with immigration and luggage inspection under the guidance of government staff members in preparation for a direct voyage from Kinmen to Xiamen. Many Kinmen residents participating in the rehearsal as "passengers" said they have long expected direct links with the mainland. "It's a dream come true," said a resident.

Pao Cheng-kang, the chief secretary of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, and opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chen Ching-pao, who represents the Kinmen constituency, showed up to observe the rehearsal.

Legislator Chen said he has applied for a trial sail from Kinmen directly to Xiamen on Dec. 28 to test whether the new shipping route is safe. "If mainland authority approves the plan, we'll set sail from Liaolo port as scheduled," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICES TO MAKE DECISION ON NUCLEAR PLANT BEFORE LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: The Council of Grand Justices is expected to provide an explanation before the Lunar New Year, after completing review of the legality of the Executive Yuan's decision to scrap the island's fourth nuclear power plant.
At the request of the Executive Yuan, which holds an anti-nuclear position, the Council of Grand justices began a closed-door review of the case Thursday.

The Executive Yuan, which on Oct. 25 decided to halt the construction of the fourth nuclear plant, a project started by the former Kuomintang government in 1994 and already 30 percent finished, turned to the Council of Grand Justices for endorsement of its stance after a bitter quarrel with the opposition parties.

On Friday, members of the Council of Grand Justices said they will convene no more debating sessions on the issue and decided to close the case before the Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 23 this year.
Both the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan, which opposes the abolishment, sent representatives to make their cases before the 14 grand justices who presided over Thursday's review.

In addition, officials from the National Audit Office under the Control Yuan, the supreme watchdog of the government's execution of budget, and Shi Shih-chi, chairman of Taiwan Power Company, builder and operator of the fourth nuclear plant, were also present at the review held at the Judicial Yuan.

Although the review is designed to convince the grand justices that the dispute is a legal rather than a political issue and falls within their authority, both the Executive Yuan and the Legislative Yuan voiced their reasons behind their cases and blamed the other side for sparking the controversy by misinterpreting the law.

Enraged by the administration's decision to scrap the project, legislators from the opposition Kuomintang, New Party and People First Party (PFP) asked the Control Yuan Nov. 7 to initiate an investigation into Premier Chang Chun-hsiung for possible impeachment, and even threatened to force a vote to recall President Chen Shui-bian.

On Friday, PFP Legislator Chou Shi-wei said the Executive Yuan's unilateral decision to scrap the nuclear power plant is unconstitutional because the budget for the plant was passed by the Legislative Yuan before 1994.
New Party Legislator Ying Chih-hung said the legislators have the better chance of winning the battle because the Executive Yuan's points of views are "full of holes."

Nevertheless, representatives of the Executive Yuan at Thursday's review argued that even though the budget cleared the legislative floor, it is not a binding bill and the government is free to opt out of carrying out a budget which it considers no longer appropriate.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN, MATSU TIGHTEN SECURITY AHEAD OF OPENING OF `MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Friday it has asked the National Police Administration (NPA) to tighten security on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu in preparation for the imminent opening of direct "mini three links."

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the government has decided to open direct trade, mail, and shipping links -- better known as the "mini three links" -- between the islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, effective Jan. 1, 2001.

Speaking at a seminar on the "mini three links," MAC Vice Chairman John C.C. Teng said security issues are the Republic of China government's top concern in opening direct commercial, civilian and transport links with the mainland.

Amid reports that some mainland people had sneaked onto Kinmen to steal a large amount of jewels in recent days, Teng said the MAC has pushed the NPA to deploy more police officers on Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

In addition to increasing the police force in the ROC's two defense outposts, Teng went on, the NPA has also been instructed to install advanced security facilities and hone an effective coordination mechanism to ensure safety and good public order in Kinmen and Matsu after the opening of the "mini three links."

According to the MAC-drafted "mini three links" regulations, those who have had their residence on Kinmen or Matsu registered for more than six months can apply to enter the mainland directly after Jan. 1 by ship. Meanwhile, a limited number of mainland Chinese citizens who have a registered residence on the mainland, and not necessarily only in Fujian Province, can apply to enter Kinmen or Matsu brief visits.

As mainland China has refused to resume dialogue with Taiwan, Teng said the initial enforcement of the "mini three links" plan will focus on legalizing the small-time trade between fishermen on both sides of the Taiwan Strait that has been going on illegally for decades, and on activities that Taiwan can unilaterally carry out.

Against this backdrop, Teng said, transshipment services are not included in the first-stage enforcement of the "mini three links." "This means that without prior government assent, mainland merchandise imported into Kinmen and Matsu is banned from transshipment to Taiwan proper, while Taiwan goods should also not be shipped directly to the mainland via Kinmen and Matsu," Teng explained.

To avert such illegal transshipments and smuggling, Teng said, the government has set up checkpoints at Kinmen's and Matsu's airports, harbors and post offices. Moreover, he added, the National Coast Guard Administration will intensify patrols in all the surrounding areas to safeguard security in the two offshore islands and thwart any attempts to smuggle goods and humans into Taiwan proper.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC)-drafted regulations governing direct Kinmen-Xiamen and Matsu-Fuzhou shipping services will take effect Dec. 25, when the MOTC will start to accept applications from local and mainalnd shipping firms to operate cargo/passenger transport services on the two new routes. Maiden voyages on the two new routes will kick off Jan. 1.

The MOTC conducted a rehearsal of immigration and customs clearance services at Kinmen's Liaolo Port Friday, while Premier Chang Chun-hsiung is scheduled to visit Kinmen to see for himself the preparations for the opening of the much-anticipated "mini three links."

In related news, Chang Ching-sen, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that if the "mini three links" proceed smoothly, the government will consider expanding the scope of enforcement to help cultivate a better investment climate in the two offshore islands, which currently lag behind Taiwan in terms of economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ALLIANCE COMPLETES FILING OF PRESIDENTIAL RECALL BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition alliance submitted a presidential recall bill to the Legislative Yuan Friday but stressed that the move marked only a completion of the filing process and that the actual motion for its passage will not be brought up at present.

Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Ting Shou-chung said that sending the bill into the official legislative process is meant to put pressure on President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Ting went on to say that if Chen still cannot come up with the appropriate solutions to the nation's problems and ends up triggering a wave of unemployment and bankruptcies, then the bill will be introduced to the legislative floor to be voted on.
He added that although the People First Party (PFP) did not send a representative to submit the bill together with the KMT and the New Party (NP), the PFP nevertheless supports the move.

Ting, who authored the bill to oust both Chen and ROC Vice President Annette Lu, began a drive to collect endorsement signatures from other legislators Oct. 30 after the DPP administration abruptly announced Oct. 27 its decision to scrap the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project.

The bill has the endorsement of 147 legislators, a two-thirds majority in the 220-member legislature, which is required before the bill can be approved, after which a nationwide referendum would decide the outcome of the recall attempt. The opposition alliance of the KMT, PFP, and NP jointly controls 141 seats, while the DPP holds only 67 seats. The remaining seats are held by independents.

According to a statement by the opposition alliance, although the recall bill already has the endorsement of the required number of legislators, the alliance "still holds a ray of hope" that the ruling administration will "reflect upon itself."

The statement went on to say that the root of the crisis facing the nation is not the system itself, but rather the mentality and actions of the Chen administration. "As the one in power only shouts empty slogans and has no real solutions to the problems, Taiwan is rapidly losing its economic advantages," it added.

The statement also pointed to the "deepening degree of misery" experienced by the people since the new administration took power in May, citing stock market losses and frozen Taipei-Beijing relations as reasons that the opposition alliance has the "responsibility to warn those in power" in order to prevent the "Taiwan miracle" from being "destroyed overnight."

DOC.HEADLINE: CCB ESTABLISHES STRONGHOLDS IN PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Huang Ming-hsing and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Chinatrust Commercial Bank (CCB) opened its second South American branch office in Asuncion, Paraguay on Thursday, a CCB source said Friday.
The CCB branch office is located in Pettirossi, Asuncion's main commercial district.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Liu Ting-tsu said the CCB has built a firm foundation in Paraguay and has provided customers, especially overseas Chinese, with a lot of services.

He went on to say that CCB's decision to strengthen its presence in Paraguay, especially at a time when Paraguay's economy is not performing very well, demonstrates that the ROC supports Paraguay's economic development, which he said is conducive to the promotion of ties between the two nations.

The CCB plans to set up its third South American branch office in Paraguay's Eastern City in February, 2001, the source said, adding that the bank will also begin credit card services in the South American nation once the number of its customers has grown significantly.
The CCB set up its first South American branch office in Asuncion in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL STABILITY, SOUND POLICY KEY TO REVITALIZING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: The government must maintain domestic political stability and craft sound financial and economic policies if it wants to revitalize the sagging Taiwan economy, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh warned Friday.
Quoting a report released by Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics (IOE), Lee said the Republic of China economy will apparently take a turn for the worse next year.

"At this crucial moment, the government should do its utmost to maintain domestic political stability and work out the right economic and financial policies to regain public confidence in its competence," Lee said, adding: "If the local public loses confidence, it will be very difficult for us to resume our previous economic boom."

The IOE report forecast that Taiwan's economic growth rate would decline from this year's estimated 6.23 percent to a mere 5.21 percent in 2001 and that the private consumption growth rate would also drop to 4.63 percent from this year's estimated 5.76 percent.

Despite the IOE's pessimistic forecast, Lee said he remains confident in Taiwan's information-technology industry, citing that 15 new 12" wafer production facilities are being constructed in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park in southern Taiwan, which would jointly increase Taiwan's integrated circuit (IC) production capacity by more than 10 percent.

Lee, a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry, further said as the Taiwan economy has shown apparent signs of a slowdown in recent months, now is not the right time to push for a drastic cut in work hours.
He was commenting on the opposition parties' insistence on implementing a bi-weekly 84-hour workweek scheme from the beginning of next year.

Noting that shortening of work hours will affect productivity, Lee said the opposition-proposed new workweek system would aggravate Taiwan's economic woes as local labor productivity cannot quickly upgrade to offset the decrease in work hours. In his view, Lee said it is more reasonable to implement a 44-hour workweek system proposed by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-led government.

Lee further said he thinks that Taiwan need not worry too much about mainland China-bound investments by its companies. "So long as our government and individual local companies work out effective management systems, mainland-bound investments will not necessarily lead to Taiwan's industrial hollowing out," he said.
With economic globalization becoming a prevailing trend, Lee went on, Taiwan companies should catch up with it to stay competitive in the global market.

Since President Chen Shui-bian, a DPP stalwart, assumed office in May, Taiwan's stock market has plunged drastically while the unemployment rate skyrocketing. Chen's approval rating has also dropped to a new low in recent weeks.
Commenting on the phenomenon, Lee said Chen's minority administration has not operated smoothly partly because of continued inter-party political wrangling.
In fact, Lee said, the new DPP government has endeavored to shed the bad practices left by the previous government over the past seven months.

Nevertheless, Lee said, there is still ample room for the Chen administration to improve, particularly its inexperience in handling many politically sensitive issues. "And it takes time for the new government to reform systems and improve its operational efficiency," he said, adding that the public and private sectors should make concerted efforts to create a better living and business climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEE MAY VISIT JAPAN NEXT SPRING
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Japan Lo Fu-chen said in Tokyo Friday that he was delighted to hear that former ROC President Lee Teng-hui may visit Japan next spring.

Lo also expressed the hope that parliamentarians in Taiwan and Japan will strengthen their constructive interchanges and visits so as to further promote mutual understanding and friendly relations between the two countries.

Lo made the remarks at a yearend press conference where he briefed Taiwan media stationed in Tokyo on the operations and working achievements of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tokyo during the year.
He said that the younger parliamentarians in the two countries have decided to strengthen their relationships with each other through more interchanges and visits.
He also expressed the hope that Taiwan's younger parliamentarians will spend more time studying about Japan so as to better grasp the political changes and movements occurring in that country.
Speaking on the issue of former President Lee Teng-hui's proposed visit to Japan which has not yet been confirmed, Lo suggested that next spring might be a good time for the visit.
He added that the former president probably should have a physical examination prior to the visit as he has recently undergone surgery.

Meanwhile, Lo noted that statistics compiled by the Taiwan Visitors Association reveal that a total of 835,000 Japanese citizens visited Taiwan in the first 11 months of the year, adding that the number may top the 900,000 mark for the year.

At the same time, the statistics show that a total of 762,000 Taiwan citizens visited Japan during the same period this year, with that number also having the potential to break the 900,000 mark for the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS FAIL TO HAVE 84-HOUR PER TWO-WEEK WORK PLAN AMENDED

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus failed Friday in its attempt to amend the 84-hour per two-week work plan, which is scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1, 2001.

The DPP's attempt to have its alternative proposal of a 44-hour workweek put on the agenda failed when 90 of the 162 legislators present in the Legislative Yuan voted against the proposal. There were seven abstentions.

After the attempt failed, DPP party whip Hsu Tien-tsai said the party, which only has a minority in the legislature, will continue to work with the other political parties, adding that next Tuesday's floor session will be the last opportunity to seek an amendment.

The vote was held amid loud protests from management and labor representatives outside the Legislative Yuan, with the managers saying they cannot afford such a shortened workweek and the laborers saying that their rights should be protected.

Although the DPP's attempt failed, there were already signs that the opposition alliance made up of the Kuomintang, the New Party, and the People First Party might come around and not stick to the 84-hour per two-week work plan in view of Taiwan's sluggish economic situation, which could add fuel to fire if the workweek is put into practice in a few days.

The coalition, after intensive consultations, has come up with the proposal that the overtime pay rate for laborers be cut so as to cushion the dramatic effect of an 84-hour bi-weekly workweek, which could cost employers a large amount in overtime salary costs.

Lai Shyh-bao, party whip of the opposition New Party, said that management has said reducing the workweek from 44 hours to an average of 42 hours would cost them about NT$80 billion and so the opposition has discussed cutting insurance premiums for laborers by 1 percent, which they said would save them about NT$10 billion, to make up part of the losses.
Lai had therefore proposed that the 84-hour bi-weekly workweek could stand and that employers, after getting the consent of the labor unions and half of the laborers, could adopt a 44-hour workweek.
Management said that it could accept such a proposal while labor said that they would want the proposal to be discussed more, said Lai.

He Chi-huei, KMT party whip, said that the compromise will be turned over to the management and the workers so that they can forge a consensus and that the coalition would respect such a consensus during the Legislative Yuan's floor session next Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LOW-KEY ON RESPONSE TO RECALL BILL

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Friday remained low-key in its response to the opposition alliance's filing of a presidential recall bill in the Legislative Yuan earlier in the day, saying only that Taiwan cannot afford to be divided at the moment.

A presidential aide said that the Presidential Office hopes the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang (KMT), the People First Party (PFP), and the New Party (NP) can abandon its differences with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) administration and re-open the doors of negotiation.

Although the opposition alliance formally completed the process of submitting the bill, which aims to recall both Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the alliance assured the public that the actual motion to put the bill to a vote will not come immediately.

The alliance said that the bill is meant to put pressure on Chen and to urge him to "observe the spirit of the ROC Constitution" and not "arbitrarily twist the national system simply because of his gains in personal power."

In a statement made before submitting the bill, the alliance also urged Chen to return to the Guidelines of National Unification in order to re-open the doors to negotiation with Beijing on the basis on the "1992 consensus." The government should also propose concrete and effective measures to boost the economy and resolve the problem of unemployment, the alliance added.

According to an aide to KMT Chairman Lien Chan, Lien pointed out at a traditional winter solstice dinner with KMT legislators the previous evening that introducing the bill is meant to "leave a record in history" and to "buy insurance for the people" before the legislative session -- as well as the 20th century -- ends after this month.

PFP spokesman Sun Ta-chien, whose party's absence while submitting the bill earlier in the day raised questions as to whether the PFP truly supports the move, said that "the timing lacks consideration," but that "there is currently no indication of the possibility of going against the opposition alliance."

However, he went on to say that there is still room for discussion before the bill is actually introduced on the floor for a vote and that if the developments are not congruent with "public expectations," then the PFP "will carefully reconsider its options" and "will not always follow the KMT's lead."

Sun pointed out that the opposition alliance has wanted all along to give Chen another chance to first resolve the country's financial and economic problems, which he said is why the recall bill has not yet been put into motion.
Meanwhile, DPP legislative whip Hsu Tien-tsai said that he believes the move to make the recall bill official is meant to lead the way for "a larger political move" in the future.

Hsu said that the "political intent" of the move, coming on the heels of a recent KMT subgroup internal proposal to oust Premier Chang Chun-hsiung of the DPP and replace him with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT vice chairman, is "obvious." The series of moves seems to be aimed at forcing the Presidential Office to make a "certain degree of compromise," Hsu added.
Although the formalization of the recall bill is most likely "a feint," the DPP legislative caucus will keep a close eye on the KMT, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA FORECASTS ROC'S 2001 GROWTH RATE AT 5.21%

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's gross domestic product (GDP) growth rate would drop to 5.21 percent in 2001 from this year's estimated 6.23 percent, the Institute of Economics of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research body, predicted Friday.

The institute said in a report on the overall outlook for the ROC economy in 2001 that Taiwan's GDP growth reached a high of 7.93 percent in the first quarter of this year due to a continued export boom and a rebound in the domestic demand.

However, the report said, this strong upward swing reversed itself following the island's first democratic transfer of power from the Kuomintang (KMT) to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in May.

The report said the domestic economy has since taken a turn for the worse due to a host of factors, including a standoff between the DPP minority government and the opposition-dominated legislature, an about-face in major government economic and financial policies, poor policy coordination among various government agencies and a slowdown in the global economy.
As a result, the report said the real GDP growth rate for 2000 is estimated at 6.23 percent, lower than originally expected.

As for the next year, the report said the GDP growth rate would further shrink to 5.23 percent due to a global economic slowdown and weak domestic demand resulting from the fact that many local banks have been plagued by high nonperforming debt rates.

The report also predicted that the domestic private consumption would rise a mere 4.63 percent next year, down from this year's estimated growth of 5.76 percent, and that the 2001 growth rate for private investment would be about 3.41 percent, far lower than this year's 15.69 percent.
According to the report, government consumption would register a negative growth of 1.83 percent and government investment would increase a marginal 0.98 percent next year.

In addition, Taiwan's merchandise and service export growth rate would shrink to 6.42 percent in the coming year and the import growth rate would also plummet to 4.37 percent from this year's 15.67 percent.

Wu Chung-shu, an Academia Sinica research fellow, said several economic and non-economic factors would certainly affect Taiwan's actual economic performance next year, including relations between the DPP government and the opposition parties, the development of cross-Taiwan Strait ties and the U.S. economic situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CURRENCY EXCHANGES TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN STAGES: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top planner on mainland policy said Friday that the matter of currency exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must be implemented in stages.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks while attending a seminar sponsored by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition New Party on the topic of how to set up a capital return mechanism for Taiwan businessmen operating across the Taiwan Strait.

Lai said that the Ministry of Finance thinks that it can complete the planning of cross-strait currency exchanges in four months so that domestic banks can establish representative offices on the mainland.

Tsai said the MAC will basically follow the timetable of the Ministry of Finance and that cross-strait currency exchanges will have to take many things into consideration as Taiwan's overall mainland policy and also the cross-strait trade and economic structure will be involved.

Legislator Lai made several suggestions, including that the government improve the local investment environment, adjust its "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland, and take the initiative in conducting tax negotiations with the mainland and planning a cross-strait currency exchange mechanism.

Tsai said that the issue of taxes is a thorny one, noting that the mainland imposes heavier taxes than Taiwan does and that after mainland taxes, Taiwan will have no room for taxation and will lose tax revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T MUST SPEED UP IMPLEMENTATION OF THREE DIRECT LINKS: SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: A group of scholars Friday suggested to President Chen Shui-bian that the government must speed up the implementation of "three direct links" across the Taiwan Strait which will benefit both Taiwan and mainland China.

The group headed by Chi Schive, former vice chairman of the Economic Planning and Development, also recommended that the government should spend more effort on developing the economy and less on talk about politics.
Furthermore, they suggested that efforts be made to speed up financial reform so as to reactivate the market and labor market.

In order to deal with the worsening economic situation in Taiwan, they said the government should moderately expand its investment in the public sector and strongly improve the domestic investment climate in order to restore consumer confidence.

Touching on the cross-strait issue, they suggested the government speed up implementation of the "three direct links" between Taiwan and mainland China as both will benefit from the move and as it is in line with the trend of globalization.

Speaking on financial reform, they recommended that the government work out a series of accompanying measures to deal with the aftermath of financial reform and that it improve the investment climate so as to lure more high-tech investment to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP 10 ROC DOMESTIC NEWS STORIES OF 2000

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top news story in 2000 was the election to office of Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian and vice presidential candidate Annette Lu, according to a poll by local media editors.

Together with the Central News Agency, a panel of domestic editors-in-chief and news directors jointly selected the following as the top ten domestic headlines for the year 2000, listed according to the order of importance determined by the panel:
1. The first political transfer of power from the Kuomintang (KMT) to the DPP took place as Chen and Lu were elected to the posts of the 10th ROC president and vice president, respectively.

2. The new DPP administration announced a stop to the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project, drawing strong criticism from the opposition parties for the timing of the announcement and inadvertently triggering the formation of the opposition alliance among the KMT, the People First Party (PFP), and the New Party (NP), which sought to recall Chen and Lu from office.

3. The unstable domestic political situation, compounded by a lack of breakthroughs in Taipei-Beijing relations and a lackluster year in the global economic environment, led to a sharp year-long 40 percent plunge in the local stock market and a continual depreciation of the local currency to 33 New Taiwan dollars against the greenback.

4. KMT stalwart and former defense minister Tang Fei was appointed premier in the new administration during the transition from the KMT government to the DPP government in order to stabilize the political situation, only to be replaced by Chang Chung-hsiung of the DPP after four months in office for what was widely held to be differences of opinion with the DPP over the nuclear power plant issue.

5. The death of four workers who were trapped in rising waters during a flash flood while waiting for a rescue that never came -- because of opposing claims by the helicopter arm of the police force and that of the air force that the area was the other's responsibility. The fiasco focused attention on the new government's ineffective crisis-response mechanism and led to the punishment of related officials.

6. The new government announced the implementation of the "mini three links" -- direct trade, transportation, and postal links between the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and designated ports in mainland China's Fujian province -- at the end of the year and the trial opening of Taiwan-proper to mainland Chinese tourists and capital in June 2001.

7. Then-KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui resigned to take responsibility for the party's defeat in the presidential election, after which the KMT began a series of reforms under the leadership of the new chairman, Lien Chan.

8. A Singapore Airlines 747 attempting to take off from a runway under repair at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in typhoon conditions crashed into heavy construction equipment, killing 82 people onboard and injuring 49.
9. Typhoons Kai-tak, Bilis, and Xangsane wreaked havoc across the island, particularly Xangsane, which caused immense flood damage to the greater Taipei area.

10. The National Assembly was stripped of most of its constitutional powers after amendments worked out by both the KMT and the DPP were passed to limit its functions, transferring the rest to the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTION OF TAIWAN'S FIRST SALT INDUSTRY MUSEUM STARTS
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The ground-breaking ceremony for the construction of Taiwan's first Salt Industry Museum and Salt Research and Development Experimental Center was held in Tainan County Friday.
The ceremony was presided over by Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi.
The museum is being constructed on two hectares of land provided by the government-run Taiwan Salt Industrial Corp. to display the rise and decline of the island's salt industry.
The museum is scheduled to be completed in 2001, and the cost for the first-phase of construction work is estimated at NT$100 million.
In addition to the exhibition of the data and instruments related to the development of the salt industry, an experimental center will be constructed to demonstrate how salt is produced.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAIN SUSPECT IN TAOYUAN AIR BASE WEAPONS ROBBERY GETS LIFE SENTENCE

TEXT.P: The judge of Taoyuan District Court Friday sentenced nine suspects in the Taoyuan Air Base weapons and ammunitions robbery case to prison terms ranging from 14 months to life.

The weapons and ammunition station at Taoyuan Air Base was robbed twice, on Oct. 3 and Oct. 11. A total of 8,960 rounds of ammunition, 24 packages of dynamite, 32 grenades, and 17 practice grenades and other objects were taken during the robberies, which caused a national stir.

The verdict said that Chang Yung-tao, the main suspect, who had huge debts, asked his companions in the military, namely Chen Kuo-chen, Feng Chi-cheng, Lo Chang-ping, Su Huang-ping, and Wang Chih-wei, and his friends Hsu Yun-nan, Chang Pai-lung, and Wu Chia-hsing to help him rob the weapons and ammunitions station.
The suspects also successfully looted a pistol from a sentry at the Taoyuan base of the Coast Guard Administration on Feb. 2, 2000.

Chang Yung-tao was sentenced to life imprrisonment and civil death, and Chen Kuo-chen was sentenced to 15 years in prison. The sentences for the others convicted in the case were 12 years for Wu Chia-hsing; 13 years and six months for Hsu Yun-nan; eight years for Liu Yen-ting; five years for Chang Pei-lung and also Feng Chih-cheng; one year and two months for Chen Meng-hao; and six years and two months for Lin Wen-yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO FULLY OPEN LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS MARKET IN 2005

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will fully open its livestock products market in 2005, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday.

In order to adapt ROC's livestock products industry to a new environment after the nation joins the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2001, the COA has mapped out a six-year plan on the adaption of the livestock products industry.

Cheng Chung-chiang, director of the Animal Industry Department under the COA, said that according to the ROC's WTO entry promise, the import quota for livestock products must be canceled on an all-out basis in 2005. No application for quota on the importation of pork, chicken, and chopped entrails will be required from that time, he said.
Cheng said the six-year adaption plan's ultimate goal is to let domestically produced livestock products and imported livestock products reach a balance through a control in total quantity.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH'S VICTORY TOP INT'L NEWS STORY: TAIWAN NEWS MEDIA

TEXT.P: Republican candidate George Bush's victory in the U.S. presidential election was selected Friday by Taiwan's news media as the top international news story of the year 2000.
The top ten international news stories selected were as follows:
1) Bush was elected the 43rd president of the United States after a long drawn out process to determine the winner of the election.
2) Sequencing of the human genome is completed.
3) The leaders of South Korea and North Korea held a historic summit in Pyongyang and issued a declaration to seek unification.
4) All 118 men aboard the Russian nuclear-powered submarine Krusk died after days of being trapped deep below the surface of the ocean.
5) The sharp decline in share prices on Wall Street affected the world's stock markets.
6) South Korean President was named the winner of the 2000 Nobel Prize for Peace, and exiled mainland Chinese writer Gao Xingqian won the Nobel Prize for Literature.
7) No major crisis occurred as a result of the Y2K computer bug.
8) The 2000 Summer Olympic Games were held in Sydney, with the top three medal-winning countries being the United States, Russia, and mainland China.
9) U.S. President Bill Clinton signs permanent normal trade relations status for mainland China into law.
10) The risks posed by genetically modified foods caused world-wide concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP 10 MAINLAND CHINA NEWS STORIES OF 2000: TAIWAN NEWS MEDIA

TEXT.P: The large-scale military exercises held by mainland China's military in August was the top mainland China news story of 2000, as selected by editor-in-chiefs and news executives of the Central News Agency and other news media in Taiwan.
The list of top stories in order is as follows:

-- The Nanjing military region held the largest sea drill in recent years in early August in the Yellow Sea and the East China Sea, with as many as 110,000 military personnel taking part in the drill conducted from Lianyun Harbor, Jiangzu to the north and Shaoan, Fujian to the south;

-- Mainland China issued a white paper on the "one China principle and Taiwan issue" to explain the basic stance and policy, hoping to influence the outcome of Taiwan's presidential election held in March and to sway international opinion to its side;

-- Mainland China issued a statement through the Xinhua News Agency that it will "listen to the words and observe the deeds" of Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party after he was elected President of the Republic of China;

-- Mainland China reiterated the "three ifs" in its white paper on national defense for 2000, saying it will do everything possible to win peaceful unification. The "three ifs" refer to the use of force against Taiwan if the island declares independence or if there is an intervention of foreign forces or if the island drags its feet on negotiations indefinitely;

-- Beijing authorities arrested thousands of Falung Gong members on mainland China's National Day on Oct. 1 when they held their largest protest since being listed as an evil cult by mainland China in July 1999;

-- The Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the State Council issued a statement in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech that as long as Taiwan clearly promises it will not define cross-strait relations as "state-to-state" and insist that Taiwan's Association for Relation Across the Taiwan Strait and mainland China's Straits Exchange Foundation, two semi-official intermediary bodies, reached a consensus in 1992 on the "one China" principle, then Beijing would authorize the ARATS to contact and hold dialogue with the groups or individuals authorized by Taiwan;

-- Mainland China President Jiang Zemin said during a meeting with a business delegation from Taiwan that Beijing has insisted on peaceful unification and that he does not hope to see a cross-strait war, but added that Beijing will not renounce the option of the use of force against Taiwan if necessary;
-- Taipei announces the opening of Taiwan to mainland China's media, but Beijing criticizes the related regulations as not reasonable; and
-- Beijing convicted the first batch of suspects in mid-November in the crackdown on a smuggling ring which has implicated as many as 800 mainland officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
DPP fails to get workweek bill passed.
The China Times:
The 44-hour workweek system to be implemented under some conditions.
The United Daily News:
Both the driver and front-seat passenger must fasten safety belts from now on.
The Liberty Times:
President Chen will visit Southeast Asia in January.
The China Post:
Opposition files recall proposal against the president.
The Taiwan News:
44-hour workweek barely alive.
The Taipei Times:
Workweek row takes new turn.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 23, or the 28th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1814: U.S. Gen. Andrew Jackson, who would later served as president from 1820 to 1837, halts British forces at New Orleans.
1832: French troops take Antwerp, forcing Holland to recognize the independence of Belgium.
1888: Vincent van Gogh, Dutch post-impressionist painter whose works included "The Potato Eaters" and "Starry Night," cuts off his earlobe in a fit of madness. His long struggle with depression ended in suicide.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen meets in Kweilin, Kwangsi province, with Marin, a representative of the Comintern (Communist International), to discuss such issues as cooperation with Russia. The Comintern, which was established in 1919 by V.I. Lenin, founder of the Communist Party in Russia, helped Outer Mongolia set up a Communist government in the early 1920s.
1922: German statesman Helmut Schmidt, former chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, is born.
1933, Akihito, emperor of Japan, is born.
1934: Chen Sao-pai, one of an early supporters of Dr. Sun Yat-sen in the Chinese revolution, dies in Peiping (Beijing) at the age of 66.
1941: US forces on Wake Island in Pacific surrender to Japan in World War II.
1948: Japanese Prime Minister Hideki Tojo and six other Japanese leaders are hanged in Tokyo for war crimes committed during World War II.
1957: The Control Yuan impeaches Premier Yu Hung-chun for transgressions and negligence of duty.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter-high Tokyo Tower is completed.
1972: An earthquake strikes Managua, Nicaragua, killing 10,000.
1972: Elections for members to the National Assembly, the Legislative Yuan and the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, as well as elections for mayors and country magistrates, are held in Taiwan, Kinmen, and Matsu.
1974: The first test-flight of the United States' B-1 bomber is successful.
1974: Dr. Ruben Alfonso Rodriguez, president of the Legislative Assembly of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Wu Chu-tsai as ambassador to El Salvador and Shih Chi-yang as vice minister of education.
1976: During celebrations of the U.S. Bicentennial, Ambassador Leonard Unger presents 60 historical paintings to Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang.
1979: Lin Yu-chu is cited for patriotism by Kung Ling-cheng, director general of the National Police Administration. The middle-aged woman kneeled and begged rioters not to attack policemen during the Kaohsiung incident December 10.
1986: The US aircraft Voyager lands in the Mojave desert in California after becoming the first aircraft to circumnavigate the globe nonstop without refueling.
1986: Dr. Andrei Sakarov, the Soviet dissident and physicist who was released on Dec. 19 from the closed city of Gorka, returns to Moscow with his wife Yelena Bonner.
1989: The Romanian army announces the capture of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife Elena, both of whom fled Bucharest on Dec. 22.
1996: The five-day National Development Conference begins. Discussion focuses on three major topics: enhancing constitutional systems of government and multiparty politics; economic development; and cross-strait relations.
1998: South Korean police use water cannons and tear gas to disperse a group of monks from Chogye temple after the monks cast firebombs and rocks at them. The clash ends a 40-day standoff between rival monks.
1999: Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, takes over the post of presidential secretary-general, replacing John Chang.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not know how men get along without good faith. A cart without a yoke and a carriage without a harness, how could they go?"

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. FRUSTRATED IN PRESSING PRC TO IMPROVE HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS

TEXT.P: The U.S. assistant secretary of state for human rights affairs admitted Friday that there are frustrations in pressing Communist China to improve its human rights records and that certain congressional sanctions ought to be imposed on a country "engaged in such unusually severe violations."

In an interview with the Voice of America radio station, Harold Koh pointed out that expectations were raised in the summer of 1998 when China's President Jiang Zemin made statements during U.S. President Bill Clinton's visit about opening dialogue on the issues of human rights and Tibet with the United States. Mainland China also signaled at the time that it intended to sign and ratify the two major covenants on international human rights, Koh added.

Since then, he said, "we have had disappointing trends across the board with regard to suppression of democracy activists, issues of religious freedom, Internet restrictions, and restrictions on free labor."
"One of the reasons the Chinese government finds these movements -- Christian, Uighurs, Tibetans -- worrisome is that they think they are 'splitists,'" he added.

In other words, Koh explained, these movements "may bring about the separation of political entities and may lead to the breakup of China, something the leaders in Beijing seem to be very worried about. So they associate religious freedom with some sort of breakaway movement."

Secondly, he noted, for a Communist system to have people who believe in something more fervently than communism is very threatening to the system itself. The Falun Gong, which is a group of individuals with a certain set of beliefs that are not particularly political, poses that kind of threat, he said.

The Communist Chinese have therefore pursued a really severe and enhanced crackdown policy against the extremely well-organized Falun Gong movement. And in response, Koh said, the Falun Gong has only become more organized and has started to make better use of the Internet to publicize its concerns.

Meanwhile, the ranking U.S. official confirmed, at least five churches and two Buddhist temples in the Wenzhou area have been destroyed by mainland Chinese authorities in the last few weeks. "This is completely appalling, particularly at Christmas time. Frankly, it's extraordinarily counterproductive," he said.
Koh said it is for these three reasons, among others, that "we have focused so much on human rights conditions in China in our daily statements, in our human rights reports."
"And for the last two years, I have designated China as a country of `particular concern' for the International Religious Freedom Act," he added.

In response to the VOA reporter's question as to what his definition of a country of `particular concern' is, Koh replied that it is one "that is engaged in unusually severe violations on which certain sets of congressional sanctions ought to be visited."

Koh did add however that "there have been astonishing changes in China -- much greater economic freedom, expansion of commerce, the development of markets. All of these have given the Chinese people a much greater interest and lust for freedom and a greater capacity to communicate with one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR RECEIVES PASSING MARKS FROM CONSTITUENTS: POLL

TEXT.P: Taipei citizens gave their mayor Ma Ying-jeou a passing grade of 69.43 out of 100 for his administrative performance, according to a public opinion poll conducted by Shih Hsin University and released at a press conference Saturday.
The survey also showed that 60.3 percent of the respondents are satisfied with Ma's performance since becoming mayor in 1998, 22.2 percent are not satisfied, while 17.6 percent did not comment.
The respondents said they are most satisfied with the mayor's performance in the areas of environmental protection, transportation, and public construction works.

Meanwhile, the university also polled Taipei County residents, who gave their county magistrate Su Tseng-chang an average score of 64.17 out of 100. Only 46.3 percent of the respondents said that they are satisfied with Su's administrative performance, while 23.9 percent said they were unsatisfied, and 29.9 percent said they had no comment.
The respondents gave the highest marks to Su's accomplishments in the areas of public construction works, transportation, and education and culture.

The survey also revealed that 12.8 percent of the respondents residing in the northern section of Taipei City are most satisfied with the performance of New Party (NP) legislator Hau Lung-bin, while 11.2 percent chose Kuomintang (KMT) legislator Ting Shou-chung, and 6.6 percent gave the honor to Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Wang Hsueh-fung.

In southern Taipei, 17.2 percent of the respondents heaped praise on the performance of DPP legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, 15.2 percent said they are most satisfied with People First Party (PFP) legislator Lee Ching-an, and 7.2 percent chose NP legislator Lai Shyh-bao.

In Taipei County's first election precinct, PFP legislator Chou Hsi-wei received votes of confidence from 14.4 percent of the survey respondents hailing from that region, while DPP legislator Chang Ching-fang received 7.5 percent, and DPP legislator Lee Wen-chung received 6.2 percent.

In the county's second election precinct, KMT legislator Lin Jih-jia was named by 10.3 percent of the poll respondents in his constituency to be the most satisfactory, while DPP legislator Chen Ching-chun was chosen by 6.9 percent of the respondents, and 6.2 percent picked KMT legislator Kuo Su-chun.

Meanwhile, 16.7 percent of the respondents from the third election precinct said they are most satisfied with PFP legislator Lee Ching-hua, 15.8 percent chose KMT legislator Jao Yung-ching, and 6.2 percent chose DPP legislator Chou Ya-shu.

The telephone poll was conducted Dec. 5-9, with 1,232 valid samples collected from Taipei city residents above the age of 20 and 1,835 samples collected from Taipei county residents also over 20 years of age. The margin of error for the Taipei city random sampling is plus or minus 3 percent, while that for the county sampling is plus or minus 2.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN TO VISIT JAPAN, U.S.

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will attend a national breakfast prayer service to be chaired by new U.S. President George W. Bush in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 1, a Kaohsiung City Government official said Saturday.

"Hsieh will attend the annual U.S. national prayer service on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)," said Chiu Ying-tsai, director of the city government's public affairs division.
According to Chiu, President Chen has appointed Hsieh to represent him at the U.S. prayer service. Chen, a DPP stalwart, has maintained close friendship with Hsieh.

Chiu further said that U.S. President-elect Bush's transition team has also invited Hsieh to attend Bush's inaugural ceremony scheduled for Jan. 20. "However, Hsieh has decided to turn down the invitation because he is scheduled to visit Japan during that period," Chiu noted, adding that Hsieh's alma mater, Kyoto University of Japan, has long invited Hsieh to return to the school for a visit.

Chiu said Hsieh is scheduled to leave for Japan for a 10-day visit around Chinese New Year's Day, which falls on Jan. 24. Hsieh will visit Osaka, Kyoto, Tokyo and Yokohama. "The mayor's detailed itinerary is still under planning," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTER-RELIGIOUS AND INT'L FEDERATION CONVENES MEETING IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Inter-Religious and International Federation for World Peace (IIFWP) and other world organizations convened a meeting in Taipei Saturday for leaders of the new age aimed at promoting world peace and prosperity.

Some 200 Republic of China leaders in various sectors of society participated in the meeting jointly organized by the U.S.-based IIFWP, the World Association of Non-Governmental Organizations, and several local organizations.

Participants in the meeting discussed issues related to the world's religions, the reconstruction of the United Nations, world peace, culture, environmental protection, family ethics, character education, and measures taken by Taiwan to resolve problems in these fields.
Kuo Ting-huan, chairman of the IIFWP, also urged the participants to offer their ideas and suggestions about the future of the United Nations.

Kuo said that they have pushed more than 100 countries to organize such meetings before the end of this year with an attempt to bring together global leaders in all walks of life for the pursuit of a new world order based on the principles of liberty, peace, and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NPA PITCHES FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION IN FIGHTING CRIME

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) said Saturday it plans to send criminal investigators to mainland China to push for bilateral cooperation in fighting crime across the Taiwan Strait.

The NPA said it has come up with the initiative after its Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) received information that mainland China's public security authorities have launched a series of anti-organized crime campaigns since October in the southeastern coastal areas, including Guangdong Province and cosmopolitan Shanghai.

NPA officials said the current mainland anti-organized crime operations are mainly designed to eradicate "bad elements" from Hong Kong and Macau, many of whom have reportedly colluded with Guangdong- and Shanghai-based criminal rings in conducting criminal activities.

According to CIB sources, at least 100-plus wanted Taiwan fugitives have fled to the mainland. However, the sources said, many of wanted Taiwan criminal ringleaders have managed to travel to rural or inland mainland provinces for hiding amid the current mainland crackdowns on organized crime in the coastal regions.

Senior police officers said the NPA plans to send CIB staff members to the mainland to get first-hand information about mainland China's ongoing anti-crime campaign and to discuss cross-strait cooperation in fighting major crimes, including smuggling of firearms and other contraband goods, drug trafficking and robbery.

CIB officials said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait now can exchange information about criminal investigations through their Red Cross Societies or Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- in line with the Kinmen Agreement signed by the Taiwan and mainland China Red Cross Societies in the early 1990s.

"Such indirect communication mechanisms, however, have often undermined efficiency in anti-crime operations," a CIB official said, adding that he hopes criminal investigators on both sides can cooperate directly and more closely in fighting crime.

As mainland China still declines to resume dialogue with Taiwan for political reasons, the official said the CIB may send staff members to visit Beijing to push mainland authorities to pay attention to the need for cross-strait cooperation in thwarting cross-border criminal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 TYPES OF FISH SOLD ON MARKET FOUND TO CONTAIN TOXIC POLLUTANTS

TEXT.P: A recent study of freshwater and saltwater fish being sold on the market in Taiwan revealed excessive amounts of persistent organic pollutants (POPs), synthetic chemicals that are linked to cancer, birth defects, and developmental problems.

The Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF), which funded the research, announced Saturday the disturbing results of the National Tsinghua University (NTHU) study, which was conducted on 30 types of fish purchased in September from supermarkets and traditional markets in the greater Hsingchu area in northern Taiwan.

EQPF Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung said that although numerous types of POPs have long been banned in the country, 14 out of the 30 fish types studied -- including such local dinner table favorites as milkfish, hairtail, salmon, goldenthreads, and threestripe tigerfish -- showed residues of the toxic chemicals. Furthermore, four of the 14 types of fish showed traces of organochlorine pesticides exceeding international standards, he added.

POPs break down in the environment extremely slowly, travel thousands of miles in the air and water, and are extremely toxic to wildlife and humans. Due to the persistency of these compounds and the quantity used years ago -- ironically, for the purpose of controlling disease, increasing food production, and improving the standard of living -- they are still prevalent in different environmental matrices such as soil, sediment, and biota.

NTHU chemistry professor Ling Yung-chien, who conducted the study, said that six out of the seven fish types with the greatest concentration of POP residues are either saltwater fish or come from mainland China. Therefore, he stressed the necessity of setting down relevant government control measures as soon as possible.

Concurring, Liu said that inevitably closer exchanges with mainland China in the future makes it all the more important for the government to establish POP control measures because mainland China currently has no laws prohibiting the POPs under question.

Ling said that POPs are usually concentrated under the skin, in fats, and in the internal organs of the fish. Therefore, he suggested that the public can refrain from ingesting these parts of the fish. Smaller or less mature fish may also contain less POP build-up, he added.

POPs are not soluble in water, but they dissolve readily in fats and oils. Because of their resistance to degradation and their affinity for fat, POPs accumulate in the body fat of living organisms and become more concentrated as they move from one creature to another onward and upward through the food web.

In this way, extremely small levels of such contaminants in water or soil can magnify into a significant hazard to predators who feed at the top of the food web, such as dolphins, polar bears, herring gulls, and humans.

The Tsinghua study comes on the heels of a recent breakthrough in global POP control efforts. On Dec. 10, diplomats from 122 countries completed their fifth and final negotiating session on a treaty for POPs and finalized the text of the legally binding document.

The treaty is expected to be formally adopted and signed by plenipotentiaries at a diplomatic conference in Stockholm on May 22, 2001. Ratification by at least 50 countries will be required before the treaty enters into force, a process likely to take three to four years.

The 12 chemicals targeted under the POPs Treaty are hexachlorobenzene (listed in two forms: as a fungicide and as an industrial chemical), endrin, mirex, toxaphene, chlordane, heptachlor, DDT, aldrin, dieldrin, polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), dioxins, and furans.

The treaty calls for the elimination of eight of the 12 toxic chemicals while adopting severe restrictions on the use of DDT and creating a "roadmap" toward the elimination of PCBs and the two unintentional byproducts, dioxins and furans. It also seeks to provide technical and financial assistance to developing nations to help them move toward safer alternatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES SUPPORT FOR 44-HOUR WORKWEEK

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung emphasized Saturday that the 44-hour workweek policy is beneficial to both management and labor and urged all sides to support it.

Chang made the remarks after the Democratic Progressive Party legislative caucus failed Friday in its attempt to force an amendment to a revised Labor Standards Law that sets the standard of 84 work hours per two-week period.
Chang indicated that as Taiwan's unemployment rate is climbing, the government has presented the 44-hour workweek plan to create a "win-win" situation for both management and labor.

He added that the reduction in the number of workweek hours under the Labor Standards Law will definitely cost employers a large amount in overtime salary costs, saying that when management cannot handle the surging costs, they will have to shut down plants, thereby leading to an increase in Taiwan's unemployment rate.

The premier said he would like to see the 44-hour workweek policy approved by the Legislative Yuan after discussions and negotiations between the government, opposition parties, management, and labor.
He stressed that the Cabinet has no other alternative plan to the 44-hour workweek policy and urged all sectors to not let this beneficial economic policy be sacrificed due to political factors.
Meanwhile, the government spokesman, Su Cheng-ping, said Saturday that the Cabinet will continue soliciting support for the work plan, adding that it has no right to be pessimistic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JAN.-NOV. ENERGY CONSUMPTION UP 6.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's energy consumption for the first 10 months of 2000 was equivalent to 74.86 million kiloliters of petroleum, representing a 6.4 percent increase over consumption in the same period of the previous year, the Energy Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Saturday.

The Energy Commission said that the increase in energy consumption was mainly due to the increase in export orders in the first half of this year, especially export orders for the communications and information technology industries.

Statistics indicate that the amount of energy consumed by the industrial sector, which usually accounts for more than half of Taiwan's energy consumption, rose by 7.9 percent during the January-October period.
The increase was as high as 35.9 percent for the electronics and machinery industries (including the information-technology industry), and 9 percent for the chemical products manufacturing industry.
Energy consumption by manufacturers of paper pulp, steel, and cement however was down or remained unchanged for this period.

The Energy Commission said it foresees only a mild increase in energy consumption over the coming months as growth in the island's industrial production has been slowing down, with the rate for November up only 1.63 percent over that of November in the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCHOLAR URGES BUSH TO BRING TAIPEI, BEIJING TO BARGAINING TABLE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A noted American expert on China issues has clearly urged the new U.S. administration to actively seek to bring the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to bargaining table.
David Shambaugh, director of the China Policy Program at George Washington University, made the pitch in an article printed in the January/February 2001 issue of the "Foreign Affairs" magazine.

Shambaugh warned in his article, titled "Facing Reality in China Policy," that the current impasse between Taiwan and mainland China is fraught with danger, saying it threatens U.S. interests as well as broader peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
While not trying to mediate the intractable problem, Shambaugh said, the incoming George W. Bush administration should actively seek to bring Taipei and Beijing to the negotiating table.

"The need to jump-start a dialogue and build a sustainable framework of interaction between Taipei and Beijing is pressing," Shambaugh noted, adding that this is not a problem amenable to easy solutions and that any resolution must be agreed on by both sides rather than imposed by either one.
The pro-Beijing scholar further said any official cross-strait dialogue must take the "one China" principle as the starting point.

Moreover, Shambaugh said he thinks that the concept of confederation offers the best hope for an ultimate solution as "it would bring the island back into the sovereign fold of China while guaranteeing substantial autonomy to Taiwan."

Before this win-win solution can be reached ultimately, Shambaugh said, a variety of cross-strait interim agreements could be signed to preserve stability while progressively moving toward a new confederal system.
Shambaugh also pointed out that an essential component of any interim agreement would be a pledge by mainland China not to use force in return for a pledge by Taiwan not to declare independence.

The noted China hand further reminded U.S. President-elect Bush that his foreign policy and security team has to adjust itself to a number of pressing realities in crafting and implementing policies toward mainland China and Taiwan.
For one thing, Shambaugh said, the new U.S. administration will have to make the next round of decisions in April 2001 on conventional arms sales to Taiwan.

"The decision, deferred last year, on whether to sell Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with sophisticated Aegis battle-management systems and anti-missile defenses will be particularly sensitive and has the potential to precipitate a diplomatic crisis with Beijing," Shambaugh wrote, adding: "The administration needs to be prepared for the fallout if it decides to proceed." Beijing has on many occasions expressed strong opposition to U.S. sales of these advanced weapons to Taiwan.

In addition, Shambaugh said, U.S. policymakers will also face ongoing choices about helping Taiwan upgrade its military command-and-control infrastructure and potentially providing theater missile defenses (TMD) for the island.
In his article, Shambaugh also wrote that if Beijing truly wishes to solve the Taiwan problem, it must be prepared to undertake substantial political changes at home.

"It must shed its ossified positions and develop a truly innovative and flexible formula that actually attracts Taiwan back into the national fold. Forcing unification will never work, and the Hong Kong model will not satisfy the Taiwanese," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDUCATION MINISTRY WORKING ON RECOGNIZING MAINLAND CHINESE DEGREES

TEXT.P: Education Minister Ovid Tzeng said Saturday that the timetable for the implementation of a policy to officially recognize degrees conferred by mainland Chinese higher centers of learning will depend on other related government agencies.

However, he added that his ministry will continue to collect related information on those institutions so that the process can move forward quickly whenever the decision is made by other ministries and agencies such as the Mainland Affairs Council, which is in charge of planning the Republic of China's policies toward mainland China.

Responding to call-in questions on a Central Broadcasting System radio program, Tzeng said that the process may not be "as slow as everyone thinks" in light of the fact that the government appears to be working on one mainland China-related policy after another.

He pointed out such examples as the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal, and transportation links between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and designated ports in mainland China's Fujian province -- scheduled to kickoff Jan. 1, to be followed by the "three direct links" between Taiwan-proper and mainland China.

The most important task for the education ministry is to maintain control over the list of acceptable degrees and institutions and to ensure that the right to make such decisions stays in Taiwan, he added.

Tzeng went on to say that the preparations are necessary because if Taiwan lacks certain talent in such areas as high tech industries or Chinese medicine and plans to import them from mainland China in the future, then the ROC government must provide the means to recognize their education.

Regarding the information on 73 higher centers of learning in mainland China that the education ministry compiled two years ago, Vice Education Minister Lu Mu-lin said that the ministry is in the process of gathering more up-to-date data before planning a possible trip to visit those institutions for further evaluations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VP CALLS FOR END TO WAR IN NEW CENTURY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday she hopes that there will be no wars in the coming century and that there will be peaceful ties between the two sides of Taiwan Strait.
In an activity titled "reflection on war, pursuit of peace" celebrated in Taipei, Lu indicated that it is sad that two world wars broke out this century.

"Those who launched the wars thought they might resolve many problems, however, they were proved wrong. On the contrary, the wars produced more problems," Lu said, pointing out that World War II lasted six years and resulted in the loss of more than 40 millions of lives.
Lu, who has been dedicated to promoting Taiwan's democracy for many years, said people should learn from the two world wars, which brought tremendous suffering to humankind.

"All countries should give up the foolish notion of waging war and let peace exist forever among people," Lu said, asking if "Europeans can tear down barriers between themselves and establish a `European Union,' then why can't Asians?"

She said she has promoted the concept of a "Union of Asian States" with the hope that countries give up the notions of territory and sovereignty and instead cooperate as a common community for their collective future.

As the countdown to the end of the current century gets underway, Lu said she hopes everybody prays with her for peaceful relations between Taiwan and mainland China and world peace in the next century.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHT LEAVES FOR MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: John Chang, a member of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) decision-making Central Standing Committee, left for mainland China Saturday for a fact-finding visit.

Chang, a former KMT secretary-general and a former Republic of China foreign minister, said prior to his departure that he is visiting the mainland in his capacity as president of a newly formed association to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies in mainland China.

Chang said he will visit major mainland industrial zones which accommodate large crowds of Taiwan companies, including Shanghai, Suzhou, Xiamen, Shantou, Dongkuan and Zhuhai, to get first-hand information about working conditions and everyday lives of Taiwanese business people there.

"In view of increasing Taiwan investments on the mainland as well as growing commercial and civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, it is necessary for us to show more concern for the activities of Taiwanese investors as well as their living and working conditions," Chang said.
Chang was accompanied by his wife, legislators and several business executives with interests in mainland China.
Attracted by cheap labor and land costs and a common language and culture, Taiwanese enterprises have poured some US$40 billion into the mainland for various investment projects over the past decade.
Chang, a son of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo born out of the wedlock, also visited the mainland earlier this year to pay tribute to ancestors of the Chiang clan.
Chang resigned from the post of secretary-general to former President Lee Teng-hui about a year ago after local media accused him of having a six-month affair with former actress Sophie Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: STREET CARNIVAL PLANNED TO USHER IN NEW CENTURY

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) announced Saturday it will throw a carnival-style gala party on the Presidential Office plaza in downtown Taipei on Dec. 31 to bid farewell to the 20th century and usher in the new century.
GIO officials said the street carnival will begin at 7 p.m. Dec. 31, with the participation of representatives of all ethnic groups on this island.
This will mark the first time that the GIO has organized a cultural and entertainment extravaganza in front of the Presidential Office.
GIO officials said they are confident that the festive party will become a new landmark for domestic end-of-year activities.
According to the officials, the party is designed to demonstrate ethnic harmony and consolidate national unity in a carnival atmosphere.

Dazzling performances of dance, music and folk arts catering to the tastes of all ethnic and age groups will be presented along the spacious Kaitakelan Boulevard that links the Presidential Office to the Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) Memorial Hall complex, GIO officials said.

President Chen Shui-bian, who took office in the Republic of China's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, will attend the gala party to review a spectacular parade of marching bands from the CKS Memorial Hall complex to the Presidential Office square.
GIO officials said all local people are welcome to deck out to watch the spectacle and join the final countdown to the new year and the new century.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2001 CHINESE WORLD ALMANAC COMING OUT OF PRESS

TEXT.P: The 2001 Chinese World Almanac and the Who's Who in the Republic of China, published by CNA as a two-volume set of books, will come out of press at the end of this month.

The 2 million-word world almanac consists of 42 articles in five sections -- domestic affairs, international affairs, relations between Taiwan, mainland China and Hong Kong, reviews and outlook (containing about 100 articles by CNA reporters stationed abroad), and chronological events.

Major contents of the domestic affairs section include government organizations and personnel appointments, the 2000 presidential election, economic performance, the fourth nuclear power plant, new generation military buildup, Taiwan's top 500 exporters, and post-earthquake reconstruction work.
The Who's Who lists the names of 2,110 prominent figures from various areas.
CNA began publishing the Chinese World Almanac in 1990, and the Who's Who section has been published separately since 1999.
The two-volume set of books will be available at local major bookstores at the end of December. Each set is to sold for NT$750 (US$22.6).

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG MEMBERS ATTEND CANDLELIGHT MEMORIAL SERVICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Falun Gong Research Society held a candlelight memorial service for persecuted mainland Chinese Falun Gong members at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Saturday evening.
The event attracted over 1,000 participants from Taiwan and abroad.

Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu also visited the scene to deliver a short message to express her concern in her capacity as convenor of the human right consultation group of the Presidential Office.

Chang Ching-hsi, head of the Taiwan Falun Gong Research Society, stated that since the Beijing authorities began to suppress Falun Gong members in mainland China, 103 people had been persecuted to death, while some 50,000 others have been detained or sent to labor camps.
Earlier on the day, some 5,000 Falun Gong practitioners from over 20 countries gathered at National Taiwan Normal University to exchange their experiences of practicing Falun Gong.
Chang said that the series of activities were designed to urge mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to reinstate the clean image of Falun Gong and to stop persecuting Falun Gong members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
New U.S. administration urged to bring the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to negotiation table.
The China Times:
Falun Gong followers gather in Taipei to lend support for their members in mainland China.
The United Daily News:

The Liberty Times:

The China Post:
