The Taiwan News:
Cabinet presses for compromise on workweek.
The Taipei Times:
Asian trip upcoming for A-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: ATTENTION EDITORS:
VIETNAMESE PICKPOCKET RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police on Sunday morning announced the successful bust of a Vietnamese pickpocket ring and urged the public to beware of pickpockets in the run up to the Chinese New Year holidays in late January.
The two men and two women in the Vietnamese pickpocket ring were arrested Saturday afternoon while plying their illegal trade at a downtown flower market, the police said.

The police identified the two females as Nguyen Thi Huong and Nguyen Thi Thu, aged 30 and 33 respectively, and the two males as Nguyen Van Quang and Nguyen Pham Ngoc Dung, aged 21 and 20 respectively.
The police department's preliminary investigation found that the pickpocket ring had committed more than 50 offenses worth over NT$1 million during a short period of time.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS INDIRECTLY DENY PRESIDENTIAL VISIT TO S.E. ASIA NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has no plans to visit in the next month any Southeast Asian states that don't recognize Taiwan, reported the China Times on Sunday.

The China Times quoted officials from the Presidential Office as saying that President Chen will spend his first Chinese Lunar New Year, which falls on Jan. 24, as the Republic of China president in Taiwan, indirectly denying media reports Friday that he will visit some unnamed Southeast Asian states during that time.
Vice Foreign Minister David Lee confirmed the officials' statements, saying that his ministry has not made any such plans, which he added would certainly be blocked by Beijing if made public.

The plan to have Chen stop in Singapore and Malaysia, both states that do not have formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, on his way back from a visit to allies in Central America and Africa in August was scrapped after it was revealed by local media, said Lee.
A visit to Central America in May for a summit with leaders of that region is the top event of Chen's diplomatic agenda for next year, according to diplomatic officials.

On his way back from next year's Central America summit, Chen may stop over in Macedonia, the only state in Europe besides the Vatican with which the ROC has formal diplomatic ties, for an long-awaited visit.

Diplomatic officials said President Chen is eager to make Macedonia his diplomatic foothold in Europe, adding that Vice President Annette Lu is also interested in visiting Macedonia and is considering a visit to the Balkan state in June next year.

Taipei's ties with Macedonia have been shadowed by the internal power struggle between pro-Taiwan Macedonian Premier Ljubco Georgievski and President Boris Trajkovski, who has blocked Taipei's ambassador Peter Cheng from presenting his diplomatic credentials.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS PREDICT REBOUND IN ECONOMY IN SECOND QUARTER NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth will slow down next year but will rebound in the second quarter, two economic experts predicted Sunday.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Wu Rong-i, president of the think tank Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the remarks during a TV program on Taiwan Television Enterprise.

Wu said Taiwan's economic growth this year will be 6.47 percent and will be lower next year, although not as low as 1999's level of 5.7 percent. He added that economic growth in the United States is expected to fall to between three and 3.5 percent next year.

Wu said that next year's expected lower economic growth is not unusual and that there is no need to make a fuss about it. He pointed out that slower U.S. economic growth next year and a rebound in Japan's economy after a decade of sluggishness will affect Taiwan's economy.

But he also mentioned some unpredictable factors that may affect forecasts about Taiwan's economic growth, including a depreciation in the U.S. dollar, fluctuating oil prices, and the cross-strait situation.
Wu predicted that Taiwan's economy will hit bottom in the first quarter next year and will then rebound in the second quarter.

Wu also predicted that the U.S. dollar will weaken next year, while the Euro and the Japanese yen will get stronger. He added that the U.S. dollar could depreciate by as much as three percent and, in contrast, the new Taiwan dollar will likely appreciate.
He noted however that as Taiwan's stock market is expected to continue to slump and as people may want to buy U.S. dollars, Taiwan's currency may be driven down.
On whether the government will try to expand domestic demand, Lee said the CEPD has planned to do so for some time and is now waiting for a decision.
On the opening of direct trade, postal, and transport links with mainland China, Wu said the establishment of the "three direct links" will not be a panacea for Taiwan's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD BRUSHES ASIDE QUESTIONS RELATED TO FORMER HEAD'S CONFIDANTS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan brushed aside questions about why some of former Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui's cronies have not yet re-registered their party membership when there are only five days to go before the end of the re-registration period.
Emerging from a Christmas Party organized by the Kuomintang for children, Lien refused to comment on questions shouted by reporters as to why Lee's cronies have not registered their party membership.

With the Dec. 31 deadline for Kuomintang members to reconfirm their allegiance to the party by re-registering drawing near, the China Times revealed Sunday that former party secretary-general Huang Kuen-huei, former party spokesman Huang Hwei-chen, former chief of party business management committee Liu Tai-ying, and former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen have still not done so.
The news fueled speculation that supporters of Lee are considering forming a new political movement, as suggested by Liu Tai-ying.

Although the speculation turned out to have been based on Liu's personal suggestion, the fact that four of Lee's cronies have still not re-registered suggests that there is a division between the followers of Lee and Lien.

Huang Kuen-huei is said to bear a grievance against the new party authorities because he was blamed by Lien's supporters for not doing his best to help Lien's presidential campaign and was not rewarded with any job within the party after he quit as the party secretary-general to take responsibility for Lien's defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

Huang Huei-chen has been at odds with the new party authorities ever since he voiced his opposition to the party legislators' crusade for a possible recall of President Chen Shui-bian over Chen's decision in October to scrap the island's fourth nuclear plant.

Although Lien's staff said that there are still five days left to register and that the party will invite the former party heavyweights to reclaim their party membership, analysts said Lien's shift away from Lee's strong pro-Taiwan stance has alienated Lee's followers.
They said Lien's attempts to win over the support of the party's traditional members by watering down Lee's pro-Taiwan line might prompt the exodus of Lee's supporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPZ EXPORT BOOM EXPECTED IN FIRST QUARTER OF NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Despite declining domestic economic prospects, the Export Processing Administration under the control of the Ministry of Economic Affairs has predicted that the export processing zone (EPZ) will experience an export boom in the first quarter of next year.
A spokesman for the EPA said that since efforts were made to promote sales to investors, more and more investors have been casting their capital investment into the EPZ.

Investors had thrown in a total of NT$50 billion in new investments into the EPZ as of the end of November. Furthermore, several famous factories and companies have also expressed their interest in investing in the EPZ.

According to a survey conducted by the EPA concerning the economic and export prospects for next year, a great majority of investors were optimistic about exports, especially those producers of electronics, machinery, chemical products, and electrical appliances.
Meanwhile, those producers of metal machinery, ready-made garments, and textiles said they believe their exports will worsen next year, the EPA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DUE TO HOLD TEA PARTY WITH PRESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will hold a year-end tea party with the press before Chinese New Year, which falls on Jan. 24.
The tea party will be held after a three-month hiatus of his monthly press conference.

President Chen, in a tacit agreement with the press, had held a press conference every month since his inauguration May 20 to report directly to the nation. At these gatherings, he has usually spoken for an hour and then has held a one-hour question-and-answer session.

The president had maintained a popularity rating of more than 60 percent between June and September, during which he held four of these press conferences. Then, his popularity began to slip as he was faced with a number of domestic problems. No press conferences have been held since.
After the resignation of KMT stalwart Tang Fei as a premier, President Chen's minority government faced even more difficulties with the opposition parties.

Chen faced a major political storm after the opposition alliance moved to recall him in the wake of the premier's abrupt announcement to scrap the construction of the fourth nuclear plant shortly after the president's meeting with Lien Chan, chairman of the Kuomintang, during which he promised to give more thought to the KMT's pet project.

The president later apologized to Lien and the public in a video taped broadcast and said that he would adjust his style. Chen has since reacted in a low-key manner to various political issues and has let the Executive Yuan speak on them instead.

It is expected the topics of the slumping Taiwan currency and stock market, the recall motion by the opposition alliance, criticism of the government by business tycoons, and the controversy over the workweek scheme will all be raised at the year-end tea party.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI RANGSIT UNIVERSITY HONORS VINCENT SIEW
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Kuo Feng-chih & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Thai Rangsit University on Sunday conferred an honorary doctoral degree on former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew in recognition of his contributions to promoting political democratization and economic liberalization in Taiwan.

Making an address at the university's graduation ceremony, Siew said he hopes that children in Taiwan and in the Asian-Pacific region will jointly strive for a better tomorrow in this part of the world.

Siew, who is also vice chairman of Taiwan's major opposition Kuomintang, told the more than 4,000 graduates of Rangsit University that Taiwan has successfully achieved both an economic and a political miracle, resulting from the carrying out pragmatic policies, economic liberalization, democratization, and social reform, and also from an emphasis on education and talent cultivation.
Siew also exhorted those at the gathering that they must prepare to face the challenges posed by the inevitable trend toward globalization in the 21st century.

He pointed out that relations between Taiwan and Thailand are cordial and that Taiwan has emerged as Thailand's sixth largest trade partner, noting that Taiwan businessmen have made more than US$10 billion in capital investments in Thailand, making Taiwan the fourth largest source of investment in the country.
Siew is the third person to receive an honorary doctoral degree from Rangsit University.
Siew, accompanied by his wife and a nine-member entourage, arrived in Bangkok Saturday and will return to Taipei Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PREMIER URGES CHEN ADM'N TO RESTORE INVESTOR CONFIDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Kuo Feng-chih & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Saturday called on the Chen administration to restore investor confidence.
Siew said that Taiwan's economy is still strong but has been declining since Chen Shui-bian assumed the presidency on May 20.
He made the remarks when addressing a welcome party given in his honor by Rangsit University founder Arthit Ourairat, who is also the Thai minister of high-tech and environmental protection.
Siew also attended a ceremony Sunday where Rangsit University conferred an honorary doctoral degree on him.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI TURNS EIGHTY

TEXT.P: Former Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui turned 80 today, according to the Lunar calender.

Speaking at the Presbyterian Church in Taoyuan on Sunday morning, Lee told those attending the church service that he has not read the newspaper nor watched television since he left office on May 20. Instead, he said, he has spent all of his time reading the Bible.
The Church presented the former president with a three layer cake, and a children's choir sang Happy Birthday in his honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 70% APPROVE OF NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: More than 70 percent of the public approves of the current National Health Insurance program, according to the results of a survey released on Sunday.

The survey by Kuomintang think tank, the National Policy Foundation, also showed that nearly 70 percent of those interviewed said the current premium under the program is acceptable and that it should not be wiped out for suffering a loss which they said should be covered by the government instead of by raising the premium or cutting down the insurance payment.
The poll carried out among 1,265 adults found that most of those interviewed disapprove of the idea of offering better health care to those willing to pay more under the system.

More than 70 percent of the respondents said they do not oppose the opening of clinics for the exclusive use by patients who pay for the service or the bringing under the program's coverage rare disorders which are costly in treatment and difficult to cure.

Hsueh Cheng-tai, a professor at National Taiwan University, said the survey showed that a majority of the people think the program is relative fair and appropriately takes care of disadvantaged groups, but it also revealed that most are unwilling to pay more to improve the system.

Yang Chih-liang, the former vice minister of the Department of Health and now a professor at National Taiwan University, said that although 38.3 percent of those surveyed blamed the excessive amount of medicine administered to patients under the system as the main source of losses, 76 percent said they opposed abolishing the program simply because of the losses.
Instead, 24.6 percent of them said the government should cover the loss, and less than 20 percent said the insured should pay more to save the program from bankruptcy.
This attitude is similar to that which is found in most Western countries, Yang said.

In general, Yang said, the people believe health care is a part of social welfare and should be run by the government but also understand health coverage for high-medical risk groups is a heavy burden on the society.
The National Health Insurance program, initiated by the Kuomintang in 1995, is touted by the party as one of its major achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAN.-SEPT. REVENUE IN TAIWAN'S CELLULAR PHONE BUSINESS UP 45%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's portable telephone business continued to enjoy rosy business in the first nine months of this year despite the poor performance in most other sectors of the economy, said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Saturday.
MOTC statistics indicated that revenue from domestic cellular phone business during the January-September period totaled NT$108.9 billion, up 45.5 percent from that of the same period last year.

The revenue of the government-owned Chunghwa Telecom. Co. during this period amounted to NT$33.5 billion, up 45.5 percent over that of the same period the previous year, to account for 30.8 percent of the total figure.
The revenue of the private operators amounted to NT$75.4 billion for the period, up 59.7 percent over that of the same period a year earlier, to account for 69.2 percent of the total.
Chunghwa Telecom. has announced a reduction in the cellular phone rate by 15.2 percent, effective from Jan. 1. Private operators are expected to follow suit.
An official with the MOTC said that next year's cellular telephone business revenue will continue to grow because the rate reduction will lead to an increase in the number of subscribers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR CONFIRMS HE WILL SEEK REELECTION

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh reaffirmed Sunday that he will seek reelection and will not take any position in the Cabinet.
Hsieh, who is also the chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, made the remarks after he addressed a rally in a public square on the second anniversary of his inauguration.

Asked whether he would take a post in the Legislative Yuan or the Executive Yuan, he said he will definitely seek reelection as mayor, adding that he would even turn down an invitation by President Chen Shui-bian to serve as the premier.

In his speech, Hsieh promised that the development of Kaohsiung in the next century will begin soon, noting that Kaohsiung Harbor, which is now under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Communication, will be turned over to Kaohsiung city next May. Also, construction on the rapid transit project will begin in January, he added.

In addition, he said that the software technology industrial park now under construction and the proposed multi-function trade and economic industrial park will be valuable assets helping turn Kaohsiung into a global planning and management center.
He said with some pride that of all the cities in Taiwan, Kaohsiung, with its advantages of having both a harbor and an airport, will be the best city for cross-strait transport.

He also spoke of his performance over the past two years, but touched little on the questions concerning clear water, river cleaning as well social order, which have long been criticized by Kaohsiung citizens.

On recent polls which revealed his low popularity, Hsien defended himself by saying that even if his performance were tops among all city mayors, he still might not receive a high support rating from the public.

It is known that political figures, eyeing the vital city and county head and legislative elections scheduled for the end of next year, have been carefully observing whether Hsien will seek reelection before deciding their next move.
Although Hsieh has only fared modestly in public polls on his administrative performance, reports that he may be promoted to the post of premier have not ceased.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG FOLLOWERS TAKE PART IN PEACEFUL STREET MARCH IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: About 5,000 Falun Gong followers from Taiwan and 18 other countries and areas took part in a peaceful street march Sunday to call world attention to mainland China's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
The procession started from the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall and ended at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.

The march was part of a two-day event organized by Taiwan's Falun Gong Research Society to protest against mainland China's suppression on Falun Gong, a meditation sect founded by Li Hongzhi years ago.
Organizers said that more than 100 mainland Chinese Falun Gong followers have been persecuted to death, with some 50,000 others having been detained or sent to the countryside for labor.
On Saturday, the followers gathered at National Normal University to exchange their experiences of practicing Falun Gong and also attended a candlelight rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu was invited to deliver a brief message at the rally to show her concern about the persecution of Falun Gong followers in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN SINGAPORE TO REACH CLIMAX NEXT YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 24 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based United Microelectronics Corp.'s (UMC) huge investment in Singapore to build a wafer plant will result in a climax next year in Taiwan business' investment in Singapore, Chuang Cheng-yuan, director of the economic affairs division of Taiwan's representative office in Singapore said Sunday.

UMC and German Siemens group announced recently a US$3.6 billion joint venture to build a 12-inch wafer plant in Singapore. The UMC will hold at least half of the wafer plant's stake, meaning the capital it injects into the project will total at least US$1.8 billion.

With UMC's huge investment in Singapore, Taiwan businessmen's investment in the Southeast Asian nation is expected to reach at least US$1.89 billion next year, for the highest level ever recorded, he said.

UMC signed an agreement with the Siemens group in December this year, and construction on the wafer plant is scheduled to start next year. As a result, the investment value will not be listed in the Singaporean government's statistics as an investment from abroad for this year.
It is expected that the capital earmarked for the plant by the joint venture will be cast into Singapore on a step-by-step basis, with the first batch of capital going there early next year.

As of the end of August of this year, Taiwan businessmen's realized direct investment in Singapore had topped US$125 million, according to Singaporean government statistics. It is expected that the figure will reach US$190 million to US$200 million for the entire year.
At present, Taiwan businessmen's investment in Singapore is focused on the electronics and banking industries.

As of the end of last year, Taiwan businessmen's total direct investment in Singapore had reached US$900 million to US$1 billion, with the figure expected to rise to US$1.1 billion to US$1.2 billion after this year's total is factored in, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 26, or the first day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Tse-tung (Zedong), chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder, totaling $11 million, of a large sum of indemnities China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye's statement clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion of the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1983: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year ago, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing's regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Tuesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved down 169 points to close at 4,688, with 7,223 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February 2001 decreased 158 points to finish at 4,672, with 44 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 72 points to close at 4,798, with three contract transactions.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 89.86 points to close at 4,721.36.

Encouraged by a surge in the NASDAQ index over the weekend, the bourse opened at 4,871.86, but due to a lack of willingness to purchase on the part of investors, stock prices began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 4,880.41 and 4,711.38 during trading.

A total of 1.05 billion stocks worth NT$28.8 billion (US$0.87 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.66 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$46.22 billion (US$1.4 billion).

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 2.3 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 2.1 percent, electrical stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues and foodstuff shares, both at 1.3 percent, and construction stocks at 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 382 to 113, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHT CONTINUES FACT-FINDING TRIP TO MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Xiamen, Dec. 26 (CNA) (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) heavyweight John Chang said here Tuesday that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.

Chang, who is a member of the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee but making the visit in his capacity as the president of a newly formed association to promote the development of Taiwan business interests in mainland China, said that he hopes his new organization will be able to consolidate the influence of the 54 Taiwan business associations in the mainland area.

The former KMT secretary-general and former Republic of China foreign minister went on to say that bilateral trade is a "very important link" in the "intricate" cross-Taiwan Strait relations. Trade can often help forge bilateral contacts in other areas as well, he added.

Chang said that his Monday meeting with Wang Daohan, the top mainland negotiator with Taiwan, gave them an opportunity to exchange views on the cross-strait situation. According to Chang, both of them agreed that a breakthrough in bilateral relations will require a "positive response" from Taiwan on the issue of the "one China" principle.

During the meeting, which took place in Shanghai, Wang stressed that the two sides can "talk about anything" as long as dialogue takes place under the principle of "one China." However, Chang responded that the two sides should return to the "one China, respective interpretations" foundation established in 1992.
As to the actual significance of the "mini three links" to cross-strait relations, Wang said that mainland China will continue to "listen and observe."

Meanwhile, Chang said that the "mini three links" -- referring to the direct trade, postal, and transportation links to kickoff between Taiwan's frontline Kinmen and Matsu islands and designated ports in mainland China on Jan. 1 -- are "of course" important, but added that he is personally taking on a more conservative attitude as to whether the links will actually bring about any breakthroughs.

Only direct links between Taiwan-proper and mainland China will be able to resolve concrete issues, Chang said, adding that the two sides of the strait will then necessarily involve themselves in direct contact and negotiations.

Chang said that he is not particularly surprised that mainland China is not in a hurry to respond to Taiwan's latest olive branch offering in the form of the mini three links. Likewise, if the mini links don't lead to the more direct links between Taiwan-proper and the mainland, this should not be considered unexpected as the two issues are basically on separate levels, he added.

Chang is scheduled to visit major industrial zones with a large Taiwan business presence, including Shanghai, Suzhou, Xiamen, Shantou, Dongguan, and Zhuhai during his weeklong fact-finding mission, which began Saturday.

Attracted by cheap labor and low land costs as well as a common language and culture, Taiwanese enterprises have poured some US$40 billion into the mainland for various investment projects over the past decade.
Chang, a son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo born out of the wedlock, also visited the mainland earlier this year to pay tribute to ancestors of the Chiang clan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COORDINATION CENTER FOR 'MINI THREE LINKS' INAUGURATED IN KINMEN

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presided over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center for the "mini three links"-related affairs on the frontline island of Kinmen Tuesday.

Speaking on the ceremony, Chang said the inauguration symbolizes the start of the direct trade, mail and shipping links between the Republic of China's defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou, better known as the "mini three links."

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the government has decided to formally open the "mini three links" on a trial basis for one year from Jan. 1, 2001.
Chang said the opening of the "mini three links" marks a critical step in the establishment of a peaceful, stable relationship across the Taiwan Strait.

"It may be just a small step, but it is very important, in the development of cross-strait relations," Chang stressed, adding: "This is a historical test, and we cannot afford any flop in implementing the new opening measures."
Since its inauguration in May, Chang said, the ROC's new Democratic Progressive Party-led government has looked forward to forging friendly relations and dialogue with mainland China.

"The impending opening of the 'mini three links' will signify our sincerity and goodwill toward mainland China," Chang explained, adding the move indicates that the ROC has taken concrete steps, not just offered lip services, to improve cross-strait relations.

Noting that Kinmen and Matsu has been the ROC's front line with mainland China for more than half a century, Chang said the opening of the two defense outposts for direct trade and transport links with the mainland will mark a very important step toward forging a peaceful, constructive cross-strait relationship after more than 50 years of rivalry.

Chang further said as the newly opened coordination center holds the key to the success of the "mini three links," all staff members should work hand-in-hand to ensure its smooth operations. The coordination center is staffed by officials from the Kinmen County Government and all relevant central government agencies.

Chang was accompanied by Cabinet Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen, Interior Minister Chang Po-ya, Transportation and Communications Minister Yeh Chu-lan, Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Council of Agriculture Chairman Chen Hsi-huang and Government Information Office Director-General Su Cheng-ping on his Kinmen visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER JOBLESS RATE HIGHEST SINCE 1985

TEXT.P: Taiwan's jobless rate reached 3.22 percent in November, the highest level for November since 1985, statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting, and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.

DGBAS officials said the jobless rate over the first 11 months of 2000 averaged 2.97 percent. They estimated the average jobless rate for the whole year will be around 3 percent and will reach 4 percent after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization.

Other factors besides WTO entry that may increase Taiwan's unemployment rate include a slowdown in the U.S. economy, which is the largest market for Taiwan exports, along with the transformation of the local industrial structure and the exodus of Taiwan industries overseas, the officials said.
Statistics showed that Taiwan's total employment reached 9.54 million in November, up 24,000 from the previous month, while the number of jobless hit 319,000, up 6,000 from the previous month.

The 319,000 jobless in November and the 152,000 hidden jobless represent a serious situation in the local employment market. The number of hidden jobless, referring to those who are unemployed but are not seeking employment at the present, increased by 2,000 from the previous month, representing the sixth consecutive month increase in this figure.

DGBAS officials attributed the high jobless rate in November to the economic slowdown, saying that the closing and scaling down of businesses has resulted in 5,000 newly unemployed. They added that an additional 3,000 people became unemployed during the month due to their temporary jobs ending, and 1,000 people became jobless after quitting their employment due to job dissatisfaction.
The officials said that those who became jobless because businesses scaled back or closed reached 98,000 in November, increasing by 5,000 from the previous month and setting a record high.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOB SEEKERS SHOW CONFIDENCE IN WEB INDUSTRY DESPITE SLOWING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's online job seekers continue to look for employment in the Internet industry despite an overall reduction in job opportunities, according to a report released Tuesday by Taiwan's largest Internet-based manpower resource company.

The 104 Corporation, whose website allows businesses and job seekers to match up based on each other's needs, announced that the company saw a continued increase in the number of people looking for employment in the online industry.

According to the company's statistics, November saw a 6.29 percent increase over the previous month in the number of people who applied for WWW-based jobs on the 104 website, making jobs in the online industry the most sought-after by employment seekers at the site.

At the same time, jobs in the education sector also exhibited considerable growth in demand, suggesting that job seekers are either focusing on securing employment in fields that show characteristics for potential growth or that have long stood for long-term stability, the report added.

However, the report also indicated that the ratio of the number of jobs offered to the number of job seekers on the 104 website decreased from 1.02 in October to 0.9 opportunities per applicant in November.
Meanwhile, the government announced Tuesday that Taiwan's unemployment rate for November hit 3.22 percent, the highest level for that month since 1985.

Political turmoil, along with a lackluster year in the global economy and for local businesses, has pushed investor and market confidence to all-time low levels. Local economic growth has been widely predicted to remain slow at least until the second quarter of 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHING INDUSTRY CRITICIZES STUDY ON TOXIC LEVELS IN FISH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top fisheries administrator and fishing industry representatives on Tuesday criticized a study on the toxic levels of various types of fish sold on the market, citing excessively high standards used during the research.

Hu Hsing-hua, director of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said that the Australian standard adopted by the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) in lieu of an established domestic standard was 1,600 times stricter than the world standard used by the United States and the United Nations.

The EQPF, which funded the research, announced Saturday that 14 out of 30 types of fish purchased in September from supermarkets and traditional markets in the greater Hsingchu area in northern Taiwan contained "excessive" amounts of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) despite the fact that numerous types of POPs have long been banned in the country.
The foundation also announced that four of the 14 types of fish showed traces of organochlorine pesticides exceeding "international standards."

POPs are synthetic chemicals such as DDT, endrin, mirex, and aldrin, which are linked to cancer, birth defects, and developmental problems. They break down in the environment extremely slowly, travel thousands of miles in the air and water, and are extremely toxic to wildlife and humans.

Due to the persistency of these compounds and the quantity used years ago -- ironically, for the purpose of controlling disease, increasing food production, and improving the standard of living -- they are still prevalent in different environmental matrices such as soil, sediment, and biota.

According to Taipei Fish Products Marketing Corp. President Huang Yung-hsin, consumer spending on fish products has plummeted approximately 30 percent from the usual figures since the EQPF announcement.
The daily total tonnage of fish products sold over the past few days has decreased by 20 to 30 metric tons, drawing anxious complaints from fishermen in all affected areas, Huang said.

He added that consumers have obviously become afraid of the types of fish marked by the foundation as being contaminated -- including such local dinner table favorites as milkfish, hairtail, salmon, golden threads, and threestripe tigerfish.

National Tsinghua University chemistry professor Ling Yung-chien, who conducted the research, admitted that the results of his study may adversely affect the livelihood of the country's fishermen in the short term.

However, he went on to say that in the long run, if Taiwan can take the opportunity to establish a set of standards, thereby making Taiwan fish stocks more trustworthy on the market, then this could turn out instead to be a boon for fishermen. This is particularly important considering the predicted influx of imported fish products competing for local market share after Taiwan's impending World Trade Organization entry, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE TO CONSOLIDATE NEW WARPLANE COMBAT CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Air Force will step up consolidation of beyond-the-vision combat capabilities of its second-generation warplanes starting next year, Ministry of National Defense spokesman Huang Suey-sheng said Tuesday.

Huang said the Air Force has commissioned many second-generation warplanes into service this year, including a second wing of the locally developed Ching-kuo Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDFs), five squadrons of the U.S.-made F-16 jet fighters and two squadrons of the French-built Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters.

In the coming year, Huang said, the Air Force will focus on integration and consolidation of beyond-the-vision or hit-and-run combat capabilities of all these three types of new-generation warplanes to ensure its air supremacy over the Taiwan Strait in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat.

Huang said the Air Force also plans to purchase even more advanced stealth warplanes that can conduct short-range or vertical takeoffs and long-range precision targeting at several different targets simultaneously.

In view of Beijing's intensified military modernization plan, Huang said, the ROC Air Force will develop a multi-dimensional, multi-sorties air defense strategy characterized by the use of multi-types of warplanes.

Against this backdrop, Huang went on, all Air Force pilots must also undergo mixed warplanes tactical training in order to effectively integrate all new-generation weaponry systems and beef up their overall combat capabilities.

Over the past year, Huang said, Air Force pilots have received training in firing of air-to-air and air-to-surface missiles. "and in the new year, they will receive intensive training in integrating different weaponry systems and upgrading performance," Huang said, adding that all these training programs are designed to help realize the ROC's ultimate military goal of deterring its enemy from launching any attack on Taiwan.

As part of its efforts to resolve pilot shortage problems, Huang said, the Air Force has opened "professional pilots" classes to cultivate new pilots. In addition, he said, the Air Force has also offered special financial incentives to encourage active-duty pilots to postpone their retirement plans.

The ROC Air Force has taken delivery of 130 IDFs, 60 Mirage 2000-5s and more than 100 F-16s in the past few years. As a result, it must accelerate training of more qualified pilots to operate so many second-generation warplanes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO DISCUSS RE-REGISTRATION TOO EARLY: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that it is still too early to discuss who has yet to re-register with the Kuomintang (KMT).

Ma, who is also a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee, made the remarks when asked his views about several close aides of former President Lee Teng-hui who have yet to re-register with the party.

Local reports said the close aides, namely former party secretary-general, Huang Kuen-huei; former party spokesman, Huang Hwei-chen; former chief of the party business management committee, Liu Tai-ying; and former Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, were considering forming a new political party and even cooperating with the Democratic Progressive Party.

Ma said that the deadline for the re-registration, which the KMT launched to solidify its support base after finishing a distant third in the March presidential election despite boasting a membership of over two million, has been postponed until January 31, adding that it is still too early to discuss who has not re-registered.

He said reports about Lee's cronies possibly forming a new political party could only be "rumors," pointing out that the KMT could not afford to splinter even when it was a ruling party and now that it has become an opposition party and its support and popularity have slipped dramatically, members of the KMT will have no room to thrive after leaving the party.

Ma also said that if some KMT members want to cooperate with other political parties, they are free to do so, but he added that they would not be successful if they wanted to unite with the ruling Democratic Progressive Party since the DPP administration has shown the poorest performance of any of Taiwan's past governments.

Ma reiterated that the KMT should not cooperate with the DPP because the latter has different ideals, adding that it is better that a big and a small party cooperate so as not to squeeze the maneuvering space for an opposition party to monitor the government.

Ma, who has completed two years as Taipei mayor and who has vowed to run for reelection, said that he welcomes outstanding people from other parties to come forward to run in the mayoral race, saying that it would be good news for Taipei citizens.
Reports have said that Shen Fu-hsiung of the ruling DPP, Lee Ching-an of the People First Party, and former KMT spokesman Huang Hwei-chen may take part in the race.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER GROUP REORGANIZES FOR TRANSFORMATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group announced Tuesday a reorganization of its group operations as part of efforts to carry out a more ambitious business transformation plan.

According to Acer Chairman and CEO Stan Shih, the group will now be divided into three clear-cut businesses -- the development and manufacturing service (DMS) business; the operation of the group's own brand-name products; and the operations and investment management business.

The DMS, under the leadership of Lin Hsien-ming as general manager, will be exclusively responsible for specialized designing and development of products for customers and for carrying out OEM production, said Shih.

The brand-name product business, under the leadership of Wang Chen-tang as general manager, will be responsible for marketing and global sales of Acer's own brand-name products, and also for developing e-commerce.

The Acer business operations and investment management sector, of which Shih himself will take the helm, will help bolster the management of the entire group so as to seek the greatest possible levels of profit.

Shih said it is hoped that the reorganization will show positive results in six months as the group's organization is further streamlined and simplified and its operation performance and efficiency are upgraded.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT BANK MOST PROFITABLE OVER FIRST 10 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Finance Ministry statistics released Tuesday indicate that the China Industrial Development Bank was the most profitable domestic bank in Taiwan during the first 10 months of this year.

The pre-tax profit of the bank was tallied at NT$12.366 billion, followed by the Bank of Taiwan's NT$11.613 billion, the Chinatrust Commercial Bank's NT$8.399 billion, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank's NT$8.191 billion, and the Land Bank of Taiwan's NT$6.298 billion.
Five domestic banks suffered deficits during the January-October period.

The deficit was NT$2.052 billion for the Bank of Overseas Chinese, NT$1.135 billion for the Medium Business Bank of Kaohsiung District, NT$955 million for the Chung Shing Bank, NT$787 million for the Taitung Business Bank, and NT$441 million for the Cathay United Bank.

Regarding foreign banks operating in Taiwan, the most profitable bank during the period was Citibank, N.A. with a pre-tax profit of NT$6.602 billion, followed by the Chase Manhattan Bank Taipei Branch with NT$1.566 billion in profits, and the Hongkong Bank with profits of NT$1.212 billion. Eleven foreign banks suffered deficits.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC LIKELY TO CUT OIL PRICES BEFORE CHINESE NEW YEAR DAY

TEXT.P: It is highly possible that the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will lower its oil products prices between Jan. 1 and Chinese New Year day on Jan. 24, a CPC source said Tuesday.
It is the decline in international oil prices that have led the CPC to consider lowering its oil products prices, the source said.

If international oil prices remain stable and the NT dollar does not drop in value against the US dollar after Jan. 1, then the CPC most likely will lower its oil products prices before Chinese New Year day.

International oil price rises climaxed in mid-November when crude oil reached a cost of US$35.45 per barrel. The price then declined for over a month before stabilizing at US$25 per barrel before Christmas.
The CPC last adjusted oil prices on Nov. 3, with an average reduction of 2.32 percent for the different kinds of oil products.

The new wholesale price for the CPC's 98 octane unleaded gasoline will be NT$18.617 per liter, and the new wholesale price for its premium diesel will be NT$13.2227 per liter, according to the CPC source.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROSPECTS INDICES DECLINE FOR 4TH STRAIGHT MONTH

TEXT.P: The general syndicate indices of Taiwan's economic prospects in November registered at 91.56 points, a decline of 3.56 points from October's level, representing the fourth consecutive month of decline, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research announced Tuesday.

Wu Rong-I, president of TIER, said that, due to the fact that a great majority of manufacturers and traders have an optimistic view of the future of Taiwan's economy, he believes the island's economy may have a chance of turning for the better in the second quarter of 2001.
Mentioning Taiwan's escalating unemployment rate, Wu explained that a rate of around 3 percent is still acceptable as the island is facing an era of industrial restructuring.

In order to deal with the coming of a new economic era, the government agencies concerned should amend the 1984 Labor Basic Law as soon as possible, Wu said, adding that flexibility in the number of working hours will help both laborers and investors improve relations and working efficiency.

The results of surveys conducted by the TIER showed that the ratio of respondents who said they believe Taiwan's economic prospects will turn for the better in the second quarter of 2001 increased from 18 percent last month to 21.7 percent this month.

At the same time, the percentage of respondents who said they believe Taiwan's economic prospects will remain the same in the next month decreased to 40.7 percent from 48.8 percent last month. The percentage of respondents who said they feel economic prospects will turn for the worse increased to 37.6 percent this month from 33.2 percent last month.
Wu suggested that the government adopt an economic policy of moderate expansion and expand domestic demand in order to cope with projected declines in economic growth for next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LEADS HONG KONG, BEIJING IN CYBER POPULATION RATE

TEXT.P: Taipei enjoyed the highest cyber population among all major cities in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China in the fourth quarter of 2000, a local newspaper has reported.

Citing an investigation by an Hong Kong-based Internet survey company -- iamasia -- the Commercial Times said Taipei takes first place with 46.4 percent of its residents wired, leading all other cities in the three Chinese societies. But it pointed out that Beijing and Shenzhen are quickly coming from behind with a percentage of 32 percent each.
In terms of overall Internet connection rate, Hong Kong takes the first spot with a rate of 37 percent, ahead of Taiwan's 33 percent and mainland China's 7 percent, it added.

However, mainland China's cyber population has grown fast -- from 12 million in July to the current level of 15 million -- an indication that the mainland is a potential market for Internet businesses, according to the report.

At present, Beijing, Shenzhen and Guangzhou have the highest percentages of Internet connection in mainland China, while Shanghai, Shenyang and Wuhan register the largest growth in the number of Internet users.

Judging from the average number of pages viewed by Internet users in those cities, mainland Chinese users read an average 46 web pages each month, a level much higher than the 24 pages visited by Taiwan and Hong Kong users, it noted, adding that this is a reflection of the "in-depth reading habits" of mainland Chinese users.

According to the report, nearly 86 percent of the people surveyed contend that Taiwan has the upper hand over mainland China in the Internet Industry at the current stage, while only 40 percent of them think that Taiwan will maintain its edge over the next three years.
At the same time, about 83 percent of the respondents are of the opinion that Taiwan and the mainland are complementary to one another in terms of high technology, it reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IT HARDWARE PRODUCTION RANKS FOURTH IN WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's domestic information technology (IT) hardware production this year is estimated at US$23.081 billion, the Market Information Center of the Information Industry Institute (III) announced Tuesday.

The figure represents a 9.8 percent increase over last year's figure but means that Taiwan slips to fourth in the world behind the United States' US$88.4 billion, Japan's US$45.4 billion and mainland China's US$25.335 billion.

Last year, Taiwan ranked third in IT hardware production, but local firms contributed greatly to the increase in mainland China's production this year because in many cases, these firms received their orders in Taiwan but actually exported the products from mainland China.
If production by local companies with factories outside Taiwan were included, Taiwan's total IT hardware for 2000 would amount to US$47.019 billion, up 17.9 percent from the preceding year.

An III official estimated that Taiwan's domestic and overseas IT hardware production will go up 14.9 percent to US$54.031 billion in 2001, up 9 percent to US$58.886 billion in 2002 and up 7.3 percent to US$63.167 billion in 2003.

Taiwan's global share of the notebook computers market this year is estimated to stand at 52.5 percent, short of the expected 60 percent share target, although the III official said that the 60 percent share target might be attained in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO CONTINUE DISCUSSION ON WORKWEEK HOURS

TEXT.P: Lawmakers will continue to discuss the controversial workweek issue Thursday after a long day of debating the subject ended Tuesday in stalemate, according to He Chi-huei, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) whip.
If there is still no consensus reached, then the KMT, which is the dominant party in the 220-seat legislature, will force a vote on the scheme, he said.

The opposition alliance in the legislature held intensive consultations with labor and management representatives Tuesday and although it was agreed that the 84-hour bi-weekly workweek will be the basis of any consensus, there were differences over matching measures to be used to implement the scheme.

To cushion the possible impact of the shortened workweek, there will be a one-year grace period during which management and labor will have to agree on a flexible workweek so long as it has the consent of the labor unions or two-thirds of the laborers, according to an agreement reached between the opposition alliance and the labor representatives.
After the grace period, the 84-hour bi-weekly workweek will be implemented all across the board.

However, the agreement met with opposition from management representatives, who said that the threshold of an agreement between management and labor should not be as high as two-thirds, adding that all agreements between labor and management should have a 50 percent threshold.
The management representatives also opposed the one-year grace period and sought to have it extended to 18 months, an idea the opposition alliance said is unacceptable.

Hsu Tien-tsai, party whip of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said earlier that the DPP agreed in principle with the workweek scheme, but added that as some businesses have no labor unions and the establishment of such unions will take about three months, he and Chen Chu, chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, have suggested that the consent of the labor unions be replaced by the consent of more than half of the laborers.
The shortened workweek, due to be implemented Jan. 1, has been the focus of national debate as it comes at a time when unemployment continues to rise on the island due to the economic slowdown.

The controversy over the issue results from the retaliation of the opposition alliance, which resented the minority DPP for not consulting with them first and taking sole credit for taking care of the island's laborers, when it proposed the 44-hour workweek as one of President Chen Shui-bian's campaign promises.

The opposition alliance then proposed the even more generous idea of an 84-hour bi-weekly scheme, which is due to be implemented Jan. 1, but the scheme also puts the alliance in a dilemma, as it wants to offend neither the island's laborers nor its managers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN VOWS TO NORMALIZE CROSS-STRAIT TRADE TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he will do his utmost to push for normalization of trade and economic relations across the Taiwan Strait with a view to sustaining Taiwan's industrial and overall economic development.
Chen made the pledge during a visit to UNI-President Enterprises Corp. in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan.
Noting that economy is Taiwan's lifeline, President Chen said his administration has consistently attached great importance to problems faced by local industries.
"We'll squarely face problems and adjust our policies in the direction that will benefit local enterprises and help cultivate a better business and investment climate," Chen stressed.

As many industry heavyweights have been urging the government to forge direct trade, mail and transport links with mainland China, also known as "big three links," and eased restrictions on mainland China-bound investments, Chen said his administration will take positive steps to facilitate normalization of cross-strait trade and economic ties.

"Since normalization of trade ties is the first step toward normalization of full-fledged cross-strait relations, the government will tackle cross-strait issues from the angle that will benefit our economic development and business expansion," the president explained.

He lauded UNI-President Enterprises for its continued efforts to upgrade product quality and management system. "The company's experience tells us that there is no sunset industry. There is just 'sunset management' and 'sunset products,'" he remarked.

UNI-President Enterprises is one of Taiwan's leading food processor and manufacturer of many other consumer goods. In recent years, it has managed to diversify into many other new fields, including high-tech industries, by forming strategic alliances with foreign partners or through merger and acquisition. Under its diversification and globalization strategies, the group has successfully expanded its business empire into mainland China, North America and Southeast Asia.

President Chen said the UNI-President Enterprises group has provided a good example for local traditional industries to transform themselves to meet new challenges and stay competitive in the global market.

Meanwhile, Chen said his administration, while pushing for the development of knowledge-based economy, will also not let traditional industries feel lonely and will instead actively help them overcome difficulties and survive ever-increasing foreign competition.

"The government will provide support and service for local industries and improve the general investment climate by removing non-economic barriers so that they can pursue innovation and transformation," Chen pledged.

Later in the day, Chen visited Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp.'s (TSMC's) new 12" wafer plant in the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, which is also Taiwan's first 12" wafer production facility.

Chen witnessed the production of the first batch of 12" (300mm) wafer products ever churned out in Taiwan. "It marks a new milestone in Taiwan's memory chip foundry service. I'm glad to witness this great moment," he said emotionally.

TSMC Chairman Morris Chang presented a piece of the newly produced 12" wafer to Chen as a gift. Chang also reaffirmed TSMC's commitment to make continued investments in Taiwan. TSMC is the world's largest microchip foundry service.

President Chen also assured Chang that the government will place its top priority on improving the island's investment climate to attract more blue-chip companies to continue expanding their business in Taiwan to help upgrade the country's overall competitiveness and develop Taiwan into a "green silicon island."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION APOLOGIZES FOR TOXIC FISH REPORT

TEXT.P: The private Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) apologized Tuesday to Taiwan's fishing industry for publicizing a study on the toxin levels of various types of fish sold in local markets.

EQPF Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung apologized to the country's fishermen for making public the report, which has caused fish markets islandwide to nosedive over the last three days -- a result completely unexpected when the study was first ordered to be conducted.

The EQPF, which funded the study, announced Saturday that 14 out of 30 types of fish marketed in supermarkets and traditional markets in the greater Hsinchu area in northern Taiwan in September were found to contain "excessive" amounts of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) despite the fact that numerous types of POPs have long been banned in Taiwan.
The foundation also announced that four of the 14 types of fish showed traces of organochlorine pesticides exceeding "international standards."
POPs are synthetic chemicals such as DDT, endrin, mirex and aldrin, which are linked to cancer, birth defects and developmental problems.

The chemicals break down in the environment extremely slowly, travel thousands of miles in the air and water, and are extremely toxic to wildlife and humans, said National Tsinghua University chemistry professor Ling Yung-chien, who conducted the study.
According to the Taipei Fish Products Marketing Corp., sales of fish products have plummeted approximately 30 percent from the usual figures since the EQPF announcement.

The company added that consumers have obviously been frightened by the report, which notes that certain kinds of fish tested, including salmon, milkfish, hairtail and three-stripe tigerfish, were chemically contaminated.
Liu stressed that the announcement of the study results were not meant to batter the fishing industry but to remind Taiwan people that organic pollution of the environment is a global concern.
Consumers' rights are equally important to those of the fishermen, he noted.

Discounting Liu and Ling's opinions, representatives of the fishing industry claimed that the EQPF announcement of the study was "too coarse and reckless and the sampling and standards applied in the study were questionable."

According to Hu Hsing-hua, director of the Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, the Australian standard adopted by the EQPF in lieu of an established domestic standard was 1,600 times stricter than the world standard used by the United States and the United Nations.
The foundation and the professor should compensate for the losses that the study has incurred to the island's fishermen, the representatives said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTORS TO CONCLUDE PROBE INTO LAFAYETTE FRIGATE SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The Special Investigation Task Force of the State Public Prosecutor General's Office said Tuesday that a five-month investigation into a scandal surrounding the purchase of Lafayette-class frigates from France will be concluded soon.
Several retired ranking naval officers are suspected of having received bribes in the deals through which the Republic of China Navy procured the frigates several years ago.

After his May 20 inauguration, President Chen Shui-bian instructed the prosecutor general's office to form a task force to probe the scandal, saying that "the investigation must be conducted to the bottom, even if it might shake the country's foundation."

Top prosecutors from the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court and the Taipei District Prosecutors' Office put their heads together Tuesday to exchange views on the indictment to be submitted to the Taipei District Court.

The prosecutors declined to respond to a media question as to whether incumbent Presidential Strategy Advisor Liu Ho-chien (former chief of the general staff) and incumbent National Security Council Secretary-General Chuang Ming-yao (a former navy commander-in-chief) will be among the accused.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REMOVE CAPS ON FOREIGN STOCK INVESTMENT FROM JANUARY

TEXT.P: From January, Taiwan will completely remove a cap on foreign investment in companies listed on Taiwan's stock market, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw announced Tuesday.

At present, each foreign financial institution is allowed to hold a maximum 75 percent of a listed Taiwan company, while the amount of total ownership of a local listed company by foreign institutions also cannot exceed 75 percent, according to Vice Finance Minister Lin Tsung-yung.
Lin said both caps will be removed completely from the beginning of next year as part of a government effort to help revitalize Taiwan's financial sector.

The liberalization plan will be applicable to all industries, excluding companies involved in post, telecommunications, public utilities, inland transportation or national defense-related businesses, Lin noted.

At present, no foreign financial institutions hold a stake of more than 10 percent in any locally listed company, while the total amount of investment by foreign companies in a single company has not exceeded 50 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ALLOWS MORE MAINLAND CHINESE GOODS TO ENTER OFFSHORE ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Tuesday allowed an additional 1,291 items of mainland Chinese products to enter Kinmen and Matsu to cope with the start of the "mini three links" between the offshore islands and mainland China.
However, BOFT officials said the items, which include fish, marine products, plant products, and steel materials and products, will be banned from being shipped to Taiwan.
This brings the number of mainland goods allowed to enter Taiwan's offshore islands to 7,077.

The BOFT decided to ease the control on imports of more mainland products into the offshore islands partly because it is very difficult to crack down on cross-strait smuggling in the areas, which are much closer to the mainland than they are to Taiwan proper.
Taiwan will implement the so-called "mini direct links" on a trial basis for one year from Jan. 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TOILETS, SIDEWALKS FOR TAIPEI: MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that city construction plans will place emphasis on the improvement of public restroom and sidewalk facilities across the city.

Ma said that he has instructed the Bureau of Public Works to accomplish a renewal project of 700,000 square meters of sidewalk across the city next year. However, he admitted that this ambitious project cannot be completely achieved.

He also instructed the Bureau of Environmental Protection to modernize all public restrooms across the city to an international standard, or to the equivalent of the facilities of five star hotels, by next year.
Ma issued the instructions after inspecting sidewalk renewal work at various locations in Taiwan's largest city.

He expressed dissatisfaction over the work, which has lagged seriously behind schedule. "The bureau should have refurbished at least 600,000 square meters of sidewalk by the end of this year. "Actually, it has only managed to complete a total of 460,000 square meters during the past two years," Ma fumed.
He said that the weather will no longer be accepted as an excuse for the slow pace of the city's work crews.
He also said that the city government will form a special group to specifically design all underground pipelines under the city streets, to accompany the implementation of refurbishment work.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 TAIWAN FIRMS LISTED IN ASIA'S TOP 100 ENTERPRISES
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 25 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwan companies have been included in a list drawn up by the Japanese economic daily Keizai Shimbun of the top 100 enterprises in the Asian and Oceanic regions in terms of transaction volume.
The paper compiled the list after evaluating the transaction volume of 355 companies in the Asian and Oceanic regions (excluding Japan) made between April 1999 and March 2000.
Taiwan's computer giant Acer Inc, which led the Taiwan companies, was number 33 on the list, with turnover reaching US$4.205 billion.

Other Taiwan companies were: Nan Ya Plastics Corp., with US$3.103 billion (53rd); China Steel Corp., with US$2.947 billion (58th); Quanta Computer Inc., with US$2.469 billion (67th); Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., with US$2.398 billion (68th); Inventic Corp., with US$2.091 billion (81st); Tatung Co., with US$2.016 billion (91st) and China Airlines, with US$1.996 billion (93rd).
China Petrochemical Corp. (Hong Kong) topped the list, with turnover reaching US$27.416 billion, followed by Korea's Samsung Electronics, with US$23.615 billion.
Korea had 34 companies included on the list, followed by Australia, with 21 firms, Hong Kong, with 14 companies and India, with nine companies.

In terms of business sectors, electric and electronic companies topped the list, with 12 companies named, followed by transport and real estate industries, with 11 each, the information industry, with 10 and the petrochemical industry, with nine.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE POSTS 13 CONSECUTIVE MONTHS OF DOUBLE-DIGIT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade with mainland China registered the 13th consecutive month of double-digit growth as of October, according to statistics published Tuesday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

The statistics show that Taiwan exported products worth US$2.35 billion to the mainland in October, up 15.6 percent over the same month of last year and accounting for 17.2 percent of Taiwan's total exports for the month.

Taiwan's imports from the mainland in October totaled US$566 million, an increase of 29.9 percent over the same month of last year and accounting for 4 percent of Taiwan's total imports in this period.

Cumulatively, Taiwan's trade with the mainland reached US$26.99 billion during the period from January to October, an increase of 29.6 percent over the same period of last year and accounting for 11.2 percent of Taiwan's total trade.

BOFT officials attributed the continued prospering trade between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to the economic recovery of Asian countries after the 1997 financial crisis and to global economic growth.

However, they warned that as America's economic growth has recently slowed and mainland China's foreign trade department has forecast that its trade growth will decrease significantly next year compared with this year, it is still uncertain whether Taiwan's trade with the mainland will be affected next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND TO REORGANIZE POLITICAL WARFARE DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) will streamline its General Political Warfare Department (GPWD) and rename it the General Political Warfare Bureau (GPWB), Vice Minister of National Defense Chen Pi-chao said Tuesday.
Chen made the announcement while attending a public hearing held by Legislator Chang Shih-liang on the review of the armed forces' general political warfare system.

Chen said the streamlining of the GPWD is in accordance with the newly passed Organization Law of the MND and added that the MND also plans to further streamline the GPWB and rename it again, this time as the Political Warfare Bureau (PWB), within three years in accordance with the nation's Ten-Year Troop Reduction Plan.

The Republic of China Armed Forces' political warfare system has its origins in the commissar system of the former Soviet Union's armed forces. Its functions are to maintain the armed forces' security, crack down on irregularities, engage in psychological warfare and provide military personnel with psychological guidance.
Chen said that the GPWD will be headed by a three-star general, squashing earlier speculation that the top-ranking department official would be a lieutenant-general.
