DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 27, or the second day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: Johannes Kepler, German astronomer and mathematician, is born. Considered the founder of modern astronomy, he formulated three laws to clarify the theory that the planets revolve around the sun.
1822: Louis Pasteur, French chemist and bacteriologist who founded modern microbiology, is born. He invented the process of pasteurization and developed vaccines for anthrax, rabies, and chicken cholera.
1831: Under the command of Capt. Robert Fitzroy, the Royal Navy's HMS Beagle sets sail from Devonport, England on a five-year voyage of scientific exploration around the world.
1927: Leon Trotsky, Russian revolutionary theoretician, is expelled form the Soviet Communist Party for his opposition to the authoritarianism of Stalin and his emphasis on world revolution.
1945: The International Monetary Fund is set up in Washington.
1949: ROC government troops evacuate Chengtu, the capital of Szechwan Province.
1949: Ahmed Sukarno, leader of the Indonesian Nationalist Party, returns to Batavia (Jakarta) after A.H.J. Lovink, representative of the Netherlands government, signed a protocol transferring sovereignty to an Indonesian delegation.
1958: More than 10,000 Tibetans die in armed resistance against Communist Chinese atrocities.
1959: Japanese Prime Minister Shegeru Yoshida visits Taipei.
1969: Egypt, Sudan, and Libya agree to formation of a political, economic, and military alliance.
1972: Lester Pearson, the former Canadian prime minister who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1957 for his part in settling the Suez crisis in 1956, dies at the age of 75.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Chad.
1975: Ten people are honored by the Young Entrepreneurs Association in Taipei for their inventions.
1975: The First International Children's Camp opens for two days of activities sponsored by the Camping Association of the Republic of China.
1975: The ROC's Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen announces it had given aid to 251,563 former servicemen as of the end of November.
1976: Jacques Baumel, member of the National Assembly of France, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Twenty-seven college deans from South Korea arrive in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1976: Dr. Charles E. Bishop, president of the University of Arkansas, and Rev. Malcolm Carron, president of the University of Detroit, arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1978: Some 10,000 people demonstrate at the airport when a delegation led by U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrives in Taipei for talks after the United States severed diplomatic relations with Taipei in favor of Beijing.
1979: Afghan President Hafizullah Amin is executed by the Soviet Union. Babrak Karmal, a former deputy prime minister in exile in Czechoslovakia, is installed in his place.
1980: Twenty-two supplementary members are elected to Taiwan's Control Yuan from among 54 candidates by members of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly, the Taipei City Council, and the Kaohsiung City Council.
1986: Chinese Petroleum Corporation lowers prices on petroleum solvents by 10 percent to 30 percent.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government issues its last lottery tickets.
1995: France stages the fifth in a series of nuclear weapon tests in the South Pacific.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan expresses his appreciation to Chinese-Japanese baseball star Sadaharu Oh for his active efforts after the devastating earthquake hit Taiwan Sept. 21.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Gentlemen, why should you be concerned at your present want of official position! The world has long been without the order and justice of good government; now God is going to make use of your teacher as a tocsin to awaken the world."

DOC.HEADLINE: 11 MAINLANDERS NABBED TRYING TO ENTER TAIWAN ILLEGALLY

TEXT.P: Eleven mainland Chinese citizens attempting to enter Taiwan illegally were nabbed by police soon after landing on the shores of Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.
Police had found out beforehand about the mainlanders' scheduled rendezvous with a blue van that was supposed to pick them up and take them to safety after they had landed ashore in Pingtung.
Pingtung maritime police therefore arranged to have an identical van arrive at the previously arranged spot on the coast a little earlier than the scheduled meeting time.

Unfortunately for the 11 mainlanders from Pingtan, Fujian Province, they were unaware of the police foreknowledge of their scheduled landing and were nabbed when they came out of hiding and approached the van which they thought was their ride.

The 11 mainlanders, most of them young men, said they had each paid an unnamed "snake head" between 30,000-35,000 renminbi in order to be transported to the island and picked up upon arrival before being "dispersed" into Taiwan society "like instant milk powder into water."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 106.73 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 106.73 points to close at 4,614.63.
Market turnover amounted to NT$21.31 billion (US$0.64 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES BEIJING TO PAY MORE HEED TO PEOPLE'S NEEDS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Wednesday urged authorities from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to give more thought and attention to people's needs when cross-strait relations are concerned.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Tsai said both the leadership in Taiwan and mainland China should bear the responsibility of meeting the needs of their people and "should also have the wisdom" to do so.

Tsai made the remarks when asked by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wang Tuo what her opinion was concerning the fact that mainland Chinese authorities have been taking an uncooperative attitude toward Taiwan's approach via the "mini three links," set to kick off Jan. 1.

The "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou, both in Fujian Province, is designed as a goodwill gesture toward mainland China, as well as a project to help revitalize economic development on the two offshore islands.
Wang criticized the "mini three links" as not being significant and as only being a program that legalizes cross-strait activities that had previously been carried out illicitly.
Tsai argued that the program is primarily aimed at helping create new business opportunities on Kinmen and Matsu and consequently bettering the economies of the two offshore counties.

During the interpellation session, Legislator Chen Ken-teh from the major opposition Kuomintang blasted the government for its inability to do anything even about Beijing turning a deaf ear to the "mini three links" initiative and also rejecting an application for entry by Legislative Yuan Transportation Committee members, who had planned to take a trial sailing from Kinmen to Xiamen on Dec. 28 before the mini links go into effect at the start of the new year.

Chen said he is very concerned about what the government will be able to do if anything goes wrong after the "mini three links" are unilaterally implemented under circumstances where there has been no consultations nor agreement between the two sides on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 106.73 points to close at 4,614.63.
The bourse opened at 4,663.65 and fluctuated between 4,663.65 and 4,602.95 during trading.

A total of 0.81 billion stocks worth NT$21.31 billion (US$0.64 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.05 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$28.8 billion (US$0.87 billion).

All of the eight major categories lost ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving down the most at 3.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.4 percent, cement stocks and electrical shares, both at 2.3 percent, construction stocks and bank and insurance shares, both at 2.2 percent, textile issues at 2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 447 to 52, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Wednesday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved down 123 points to close at 4,565, with 6,420 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February 2001 decreased 82 points to finish at 4,590, with 58 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 163 points to close at 4,635, with three contract transactions.
June 2001 futures gained 42 points to finish at 4,680, with only one contract traded. No transactions were recorded for September 2001 futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 4,688 for next January, 4,672 for next February, 4,798 for next March, 4,638 for next June, and 4,784 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
January 2001 TE futures moved down 7.1 points to close at 214, with 2,271 contracts changing hands, while February 2001 TE futures fell 6.95 points to finish at 214.55, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January 2001 TF futures decreased 16.6 points to close at 612, with 1,186 contract transactions, while February 2001 TF futures lost 18 points to finish at 613, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD SENDS MORE PATROL SHIPS TO MATSU ON EVE OF MINI LINKS

TEXT.P: The National Coast Guard Administration (NCGA) said Wednesday it has sent three additional patrol ships to assist in patrol missions in the Matsu area in preparation for the impending opening of the direct "mini three links."

NCGA officials said the administration has taken the measure after three NCGA patrol vessels spotted a mainland fishing boat intruding into waters near the Republic of China's frontline island Tuesday evening in a suspected attempt to sell fishery and agricultural products.

The mainland ship first defied the NCGA officers' order to stop for inspection and instead used its stern to hit one of the ROC patrol vessels. In the stand-off, ROC coast guard officers fired 16 warning shots and the mainland boat finally halted its fight.

Later on, the mainland boat, identified as the Minlianyu F-1008, sank into waters due to cracks in its hull and all of its six crew members were taken to the ROC's coast guard patrol vessels. The crew members have been taken into custody for further questioning and prosecution in Matsu, which lies closer to mainland China's Fujian province than to Taiwan.

Chung Tung-sheng, director of the NCGA's maritime patrol bureau, said he feels regret over the incident. He urged people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait not to break any law at this critical moment as the NCGA has completed preparations, including tightening security measures, for the Jan. 1 opening of direct trade, mail and shipping links between the ROC's defense outposts of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Fuzhou, commonly known as the "mini three links."
Chung said the NCGA will intensify patrols in the Kinmen and Matsu areas to ensure safe voyages and thwart cross-strait criminal activities after the opening of the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR CALLS FOR BEIJING'S COOPERATION IN FAMILY EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Chien Hsi-chieh on Wednesday urged Beijing to cooperate in helping bring about reunion between family members separated for over five decades because of civil war across the Taiwan Strait.

On the eve of the Republic of China's landmark "mini three links" initiative, Chien called on Beijing authorities to consider things from a humanitarian standpoint and be cooperative in helping mainland Chinese citizens be reunited with family members living on Kinmen.

He said it is hoped that long-separated family members, most of them older citizens aged above 65, will be allowed to return to their Kinmen homes aboard the first vessel sailing across the strait to mainland China's Xiamen when it makes the return voyage to Kinmen the same day on Jan. 1 when the "mini three links" kick off.

Chien blasted Beijing's cold shoulder to Taiwan's initiative of the "mini three links," referring to direct postal, transportation, and trade links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Matsu and Kinmen and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou, set to kick off at the start of the new year.

Meanwhile, Chien, executive director of the civil group Taiwan Peace Promotion Foundation, announced that the group will sponsor a "Fireworks of Peace" to be set off simultaneously on Kinmen and Xiamen next Aug. 23 in remembrance of the artillery bombardment of Kinmen in 1958 and to celebrate the peaceful reconciliation between Kinmen and mainland China in 2001.

Kinmen was the only place where actual cross-strait military confrontation broke out during the last five decades. For many years after gaining control of the Chinese mainland in 1949, the Chinese communists sought to "liberate" Taiwan by force. Beginning in the early 1950s, the Chinese communists launched a series of military attacks against areas controlled by the ROC government in an effort to achieve reunification by force.

The artillery bombardment and attempted invasion of Kinmen in 1958 is one of the most well-known of these incidents. After days of artillery and aerial bombardment and attempted landings by its amphibious forces, communist China failed to take the island. Since then, it has not attempted to carry out a military attack on Kinmen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MINI LINKS' UNLIKELY TO TRIGGER MILITARY CONFLICT: MAC

TEXT.P: A senior mainland affairs official said Wednesday he foresees a very low probability that a military conflict breaks out in the Kinmen-Matsu area after the opening of the direct "mini three links."

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, made the remarks in response to an interpellation by opposition legislators at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that military conflicts might erupt in the KInmen-Matsu area following the opening of the direct "mini three links" on Jan. 1, 2001.

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the Republic of China government has decided to formally open direct trade, mail and shipping links between its defense outposts of Kinmen/Matsu and mainland China's Xiamen/Fuzhou, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis from the beginning of the new year.
Lin said mainland China has consistently adopted a "cold treatment" strategy to cope with the ROC's "mini three links" plan.

In fact, Lin said, mainland China has taken a double-edged tactic toward Taiwan since the new ROC government was inaugurated in May. "On the one hand, mainland China has softened its bellicose rhetoric in an effort to win Taiwan people's hearts, and on the other, it has persistently pressured us to embrace its 'one China' as a precondition for resuming bilateral dialogue," Lin explained.

He further said although Beijing has refused to discuss with Taiwan any issues regarding the "mini three links," it is unlikely to take an provocative action to spark a military conflict in waters surrounding the ROC-held frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, both of which lie closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.
Quoting Premier Chang Chun-hsiung, Lin said the impending opening of the "mini three links" marks a goodwill gesture to mainland China.

"We hope to express our sincerity and goodwill toward the mainland by opening the 'mini three link,'" Lin said, adding that the ROC looks forward to seeing the "mini three links" proceed smoothly and thus help pave the way for constructive interaction and resumption of dialogue of between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS GROUP SET TO MAKE INROADS INTO CAR INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: After years of planning, Taiwan's plastic giant, the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), is ready to make inroads into the automobile manufacturing industry, hoping to gain a slice of the lucrative car market.
The founder and chairman of the FPG, Wang Yung-ching, is scheduled to officiate at a ceremony Thursday marking the debut of the group's brainchild car -- the Formosa No. 1 Magnus 2.0 DOHC.

A product of a joint-venture between Formosa Automobile and South Korea's Daewoo Motor, the 2000cc Magnus 2.0 is being hailed as of top quality among all automobiles of the same level currently on the market in Taiwan.

Although Formosa Automobile officials have remained tight lipped about the signature car's price, it has been learned that the Magnus 2.0 DOHC may carry a price tag of between NT$650,000 and NT$700,000.
The introduction of the Formosa Magnus 2.0 DOHC is expected by many to add fuel to the already highly competitive local car market.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CONFERENCE TO BE HELD JANUARY

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung told the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Wednesday that more opposition party representatives will be invited to the National Economic Development Conference scheduled to be held in January.
Chang said that the meeting will be held in response to one of a six-point set of appeals made by the opposition alliance in early November.

The opposition New Party (NP) has already nominated its delegates to the meeting, Chang said, adding that the CEPD should try to invite other opposition parties to send delegates to the meeting so as to canvass their opinions.
The premier also said the escalating unemployment issue will be included on the meeting agenda.

According to statistics published by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics a day earlier, Taiwan registered 3.23 percent unemployment in November, the highest single-month record for the past 15 years.
Chang also called on relevant government agencies to thoroughly implement all the consensus to be reached at the upcoming meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT NAMED `TRENDIEST COMMODITY CONCEPT'

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian was the "trendiest commodity concept" of 2000, according to a report on Taiwan's top 10 products of the year.

The other nine concepts, published in the most recent issue Business Weekly, a local magazine, are trips to Shanghai, personal digital assistants (PDAs), a local television drama series, health spas and clubs, Internet cafes, king penguins, DVD players, digital cameras and South Park paraphernalia.
The items are evaluated and selected annually by a board of 10 local experts and scholars in consumer behavior and advertising.

According to the panel, trends reflect the nation's social psychology, and this year's list reflects the months of political upheavals and the subsequent need for the public to relieve themselves of the stress that came from coping with the changes.

Chen's likeness has been heavily marketed by local businesses in the form of print and television commercials, stuffed dolls and other spin-offs, due to the "political star" status he received in being the first opposition leader to become president, the report says.
The magazine also notes that Shanghai became the most popular city to visit, with over 300,000 locals making the trip in 2000.

In terms of information technology (IT) products, the magazine indicates that this year saw an increase in the number of IT-related items making the list, with PDAs taking the lead, suggesting that the Taiwan public has become more accustomed to high-tech commodities.

Stress-relief was another hot-selling concept this year, with spas and health clubs springing up all over the country and parents taking their children to the zoo to see the new king penguins. A local television drama and its product spin-offs also reveals the importance the public places on entertainment, the report adds.

As for predictions on the possible top 10 products for 2001, a panelist who studies consumer behavior said that if the country's economic situation continues to worsen, then the bestsellers may turn out to be tissue paper, toothpaste, and other essential household commodities.
However, another panelist quipped: "At the very least, stress relief products will become even trendier."

DOC.HEADLINE: `MINI LINKS' MARK ONSET OF NORMAL CROSS-STRAIT TRADE TIES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday that the imminent opening of the "mini three links" will mark the onset of normalization of trade and economic relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of the Taiwan-Japanese Relations Research Association, a forum founded 10 years ago by a group of heavyweights in Japan's cultural and academic communities.
It was also the first time that Chen had publicly addressed the "mini three links" issue.

Chen told his guests that the Republic of China government has taken the initiative by opening direct trade, mail and shipping links between its frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis for one year from Jan. 1.

"The `mini three links' will not only legalize the long-existing small-time trade between fishermen on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait but will also mark an initial step toward normalizing cross-strait trade and economic ties," Chen explained, adding: "It may be only a small step in the pursuit of cross-strait peace, but it is critical to the future development of bilateral commercial exchanges."
Chen further said the ROC government will review its policy toward cross-strait trade based on the principles of reciprocity, respecting market forces and ensuring Taiwan's security.

"I think that after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are admitted to the World Trade Organization in the near future, they should further open their markets in line with WTO requirements," the president observed.

Chen, who took office in the ROC's first democratic transfer of power between different political parties in May, pointed out that the people of Taiwan cherish the historical, ethnic and cultural backgrounds they share with the people of mainland China.
Nevertheless, Chen said that as a popularly elected ROC president, he must safeguard the country's sovereignty, security and dignity.

"Since taking office, I have on many occasions called on the top leaders on both sides of the strait to exercise wisdom and creativity to jointly deal with the issue of a `future one China' on the existing foundations and under the principles of democracy and parity," Chen stressed.
Noting that Taiwan is now a pluralistic democratic society, Chen said the people of Taiwan remain divided over the definition of "one China."
"I believe it will take much time for the people of Taiwan to forge a consensus on this extremely sensitive and complicated sovereignty issue," Chen told the Japanese visitors.

He reaffirmed his support for the recommendations presented recently by an advisory group on cross-strait relations, including the proviso that any change to Taiwan's present status quo must be approved by the people of Taiwan through democratic procedures and that his administration should respond to Beijing's "one China" claim in accordance with the ROC Constitution.

Chen further noted that the ROC's first democratic transition of power ranks 17th in the 2000 "Top 20" news events list compiled by the Associated Press. "We treasure this democratic achievement, and we'll certainly be better off because we have full confidence in this land and its people, history and future."
Touching on relations with Japan, Chen said the ROC and Japan should cooperate more closely to cope with the mounting military threat from mainland China.

"In the face of Beijing's intensified military build-up, its ever-increasing military budget and deployment of guided missiles in its coastal regions, our two countries must share information and cooperate more closely in the defense field in order to maintain peace, security and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific area," Chen urged.
He also said the new defense cooperation guidelines signed between Japan and the United States have deliberately maintained "strategic ambiguity" as regards the scope of its enforcement.
"We believe that this arrangement will contribute to safeguarding the Taiwan Strait's security and stability," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN JOB MARKET TO CONTINUE WORSENING

TEXT.P: Demand and supply in Taiwan's job market is likely to continue to worsen in the years ahead, as the country strives to develop a knowledge-based new economy, according to a recent government assessment.

The report by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) forecasts that gaps in manpower supply in the local job market will become even wider in the coming six years, with high-level white collar and grassroots-level blue collar sectors being the most affected.

During the 2001-2006 period, there will be an average 20,000 positions for top-level executives, while the labor sector will need nearly 400,000 grassroots workers, the report says, noting however that around 9,000 mid-level entrants to the workforce from university and college each year will be unable to find jobs.

High-level experts and business managers will be very popular, with an estimated 21,300 vacancies for such professionals annually in the coming years, while the largest gap will appear in the market for grassroots laborers such as fishermen, farmers and vendors, with only around 71,300 people available to meet an estimated demand for 507,500 such positions each year.

A local consulting firm described the popularity of those executives in the 35-45 age group with at least a masters degree as a stark contrast to those elderly jobless workers aged between 45 and 65 whose unemployment rate, according to the CEPD report, has increased by an average 16.5 percent each year over the past decade.

At the same time, the supply of mid-level manpower with university or college degrees, such as technicians and travel industry-related workers, will far exceed demand for such positions in the coming six years, as some 185,200 job seekers will join the market for such positions, vying for only 176,400 vacancies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LEADING ECONOMIC INDICATORS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND

TEXT.P: The stock market plunge has begun to bite into Taiwan's economy, with November's index of economic indicators, released Wednesday by the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), continuing to drop.
According to government statistics, November's economy flashed a yellow-blue light, the second-worst on a five-point color-coded scale.
CEPD Vice Chairman Lee Kao-chao said the yellow-blue light indicates that the island's economy is heading for recession, and will continue its downward trend into next year.

Liang Kuo-yuan, an economics professor at National Tsinghua University, said the leading indicator has dipped for nine months out of the last ten, owing to the sharp plummet of the local stock market.
The nine areas of economic activity on which the leading indicators are based post a composite score between 20 and 21, which is two or three points less than the previous month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD TO BE PRESIDENT'S ENVOY TO U.S. PRAYER BREAKFAST

TEXT.P: Frank Hsieh, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and mayor of Kaohsiung City, will lead a Taiwan delegation to a national prayer breakfast in Washington Feb. 1, DPP sources said Wednesday.

Hsieh has been named by President Chen Shui-bian as his envoy to the gathering, which will bring together dignities from around the world as well as across the United States, said Hsu Yang-ming, DPP deputy secretary-general.
The event will provide Taiwan leaders with a welcome chance to rub shoulder with world leaders.
However, Hsieh will not participate in the inaugural ceremony of U.S. President-elect George W. Bush, which is scheduled for Jan. 20. Chen will appoint another envoy to that event, said Hsu.
The Taiwan delegates will also include Deputy Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Eugene Chien, and DPP legislators Trong Chai and Chen Chi-mai.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHAOS RESULTS FROM DISRESPECT FOR CONSTITUTION: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the current domestic political instability mainly results from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) failure to respect the Republic of China Constitution and its "one China" spirit.

In an interview with a local radio station, Ma said that he could imagine President Chen Shui-bian's frustrations and feelings when he complained Tuesday about the opposition's incessant boycotts of his administration's policy initiatives and work plans.

"This is a logical result, since President Chen himself won just 39.3 percent of the vote in the presidential election and his party controls barely one-third of seats in the Legislative Yuan," Ma observed.

In his view, Ma went on, Chen should face up to this cold reality and keep his door open for consultations with opposition parties. "A minority administration should not come up with policy proposals that are way off the mainstream public opinion," he pointed out.

"The DPP's overbearing manner in denying the `one China' principle and the `dual-head' government system is the primary reason behind the lingering stand-off between Chen's minority administration and the opposition-dominated legislature," Ma explained.

Ma, the brightest political star in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), which ruled Taiwan for 55 years until May 20 and now still controls more than half of seats in the legislature, said the KMT should cooperate with the two other main opposition parties -- the People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP) -- to guide policy formulation and relevant legislation.

"As both the PFP and the NP are KMT splinter groups, they share similar concepts and ideals regarding the development of relations with mainland China and have common views on many other critical issues, Ma said, adding that the KMT should strengthen cooperation with the PFP and the NP instead of forging any alliances with the DPP.

Ma further said since the three opposition parties jointly control an absolute majority in the legislature, they should take the lead in broaching legislative programs and various policy initiatives to win the trust of the public.

At the moment, Ma said, the DPP minority government has been unable to win majority support for its policy proposals, while the opposition parties have also failed to play a leading role in policy formulation. "This is the worst scenario. We must end this sad phenomenon in the coming year," he urged.

The Harvard-trained mayor further said the scheduled Jan. 1 opening of direct trade, mail and shipping links between the ROC's frontline islands of Kinman and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, also known as the "mini three links," has little strategic significance in view of its small scale.

Nevertheless, he admitted that the "mini three links" mark a goodwill gesture toward the mainland. As for the opening of full-fledged cross-strait trade, mail and transport links, or the "three direct links," Ma said much more time is needed to clear the way. "For one thing, the `one China' issue must be resolved first," he noted, referring to the differing views on either side of the Taiwan Strait as to the actual meaning of "one China."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER EXPLAINS ECONOMIC, FINANCIAL POLICIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung explained Taiwan's economic and financial policies in an article published Wednesday in the Asian Wall Street Journal.

Chang wrote that Taiwan is undergoing a series of industrial upgrades and financial sector adjustments, and that a financial crisis brought on by a high ratio of non-performing bank loans and predicted by international news media is unlikely to occur.

Chang went on to say that although there are problems with impaired assets in some financial institutions, the ROC government is "closely monitoring the situation" and has taken "appropriate measures" to establish a sounder financial system and strengthen the management of financial institutions.

These measures include encouraging mergers and acquisitions among financial institutions, promoting the establishment of asset management companies and lifting a ban on mergers of foreign and domestic financial institutions.

Chang also addressed the issue of the upcoming Jan. 1 establishment of the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal, and transportation links connecting Kinmen and Matsu islands with the Chinese mainland. He said that the eventual establishment of the "three links" connecting the mainland with Taiwan-proper is a "clear expression of Taiwan's sincerity."

Chang added that Taiwan will adopt a progressive, step-by-step policy in dealing with cross-Taiwan Strait trade. However, he said that Taiwan is willing to make flexible adjustments and prepare for future cross-strait economic policies as long as the policies enhance mutual benefits, safeguard national security, ensure Taiwan's economic advantage, and fulfill World Trade Organization regulations.

With Taiwan listed as the third-largest foreign investor in mainland China, Chang said that "a change in comparative advantages and the relocation of businesses are both natural consequences of the processes of restructuring and industrial upgrading."

Because many of Taiwan's businesses are investing in mainland China to take advantage of low wages and large overseas markets instead of opting for complete relocation, Chang said that Taiwan is not facing an "industrial hollowing-out," as some critics have charged, but rather a "normal adjustment" in the industrial structure.

The administration has made the development of a knowledge-based economy for Taiwan its goal, he said, adding that the government has already implemented a plan to reach this goal by establishing a mechanism for stimulating innovation and venture capital.

The plan also helps lay the foundation for a high-bandwidth Internet environment and strengthens the application of information technology, thereby raising Taiwan's overall industrial competitiveness, he added.
In recent years, he went on, the people of Taiwan have demonstrated their creativity by becoming the fourth-largest U.S. patent holder in the world.
Taiwan is determined to establish itself as a "green silicon island that is respected for environmental friendliness, a high quality of life, and advanced industrial development," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING BOAT BUMPS ROC CUTTER

TEXT.P: A smuggling boat from mainland China's Fujian Province tried to ram a Coast Guard Administration patrol boat in waters off Matsu Island Tuesday night, Coast Guard Administration officials said Wednesday.
The officials said the six crewmen aboard the vessel were rescued after the boat sank and were taken to the Kinmen District Court Prosecutor's Office for questioning.

They said that three patrol boats belonging to the Tenth District Bureau of the Coast Guard Administration in Matsu pinpointed the fishing boat "Minlien Yu F-1008" 2.4 kilometers south of Kaoteng Isle as it made for the mainland without running lights.

The patrol boats called on the boat to stop for inspection and drew closer, whereupon the fishing boat tried to ram the patrol boat before eventually stopping after the patrol boats fired warning shots.
According to a preliminary investigation, the boat had allegedly been carrying mainland agricultural products to Matsu for illegal sale.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WILL NOT REJECT `MINI LINKS': NSB

TEXT.P: Mainland China has held a series of closed-door meetings to discuss the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links," a senior National Security Bureau (NSB) official said Wednesday.

Fielding questions at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee, NSB Deputy Director Han Kun said that although the Beijing authorities have ostensibly cold-shouldered the initiative, it has decided not to close the door on the new opening measure as it thinks the "mini three links" will facilitate its "united front" tactics against the residents of the Republic of China's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the legislature earlier this year, the ROC government is scheduled Jan. 1 to formally open direct trade, mail and shipping links between its defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis.
Han said mainland China has worked hard to win the hearts and minds of residents of the two islands, both of which lie far closer to the mainland than to Taiwan.

"The opening of the `mini three links' will make it even easier for mainland China to court Kinmen and Matsu residents," Han said, adding that the NSB is worried that the opening of the links will have a strong impact on the "psychological defenses" of Kinmen and Matsu residents.

In view of the geographical proximity between the islands and the mainland, Han said relevant security agencies have completed preparations to maintain security, stability and market order in the two islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: MURDER SUSPECT DEPORTED, RETURNS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Huang Wen-chung, the prime suspect in the 1995 murder of Taiwan's Kaohsiung County Council Speaker Wu Heh-sung, was deported from Thailand Wednesday and brought back to Taiwan in police custody.

According to Bangkok police, Huang was arrested Dec. 20 upon landing at the resort island of Phuket. He had been on the run, hopping from country to country using fake passports. Taiwan police failed to apprehend him in Vietnam, Singapore, and Sri Lanka but finally nabbed him in Thailand with the help of local police.
Huang was the owner of an illegal gambling house in Kaohsiung and allegedly talked another suspect into shooting Wu for interfering in his gambling operations.

Meanwhile, Chen Ming-cheng, a suspect who was involved in an alleged fraud case in Taiwan was arrested immediately after he finished serving a four-year sentence in Bangkok for forgery. He was also brought back to Taiwan to face a local court.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU DEFENSE COMMAND HOLDS LIVE-FIRE ARTILLERY DRILL
DOC.DATELINE: Penghu County, Taiwan, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Penghu Defense Command (PDC) Wednesday wrapped up a two-day live-fire artillery exercise aimed at displaying the defense capabilities of Taiwan's outlying Penghu islands.

According to a PDC staff officer, the drills were conducted to counter a hypothetical blockade and attack on the Republic of China Navy's supply ship flotilla. The mock attack simulated an attempt to cut off the ROC supply line to the area.

At 6 a.m., the defense command ordered 21 individual artillery command subposts in the area to lay down a barrage of fire to protect the ROC vessels under hypothetical attack. Coordinating among the tri-services, the PDC carried out air defense, sea superiority, and electronic warfare operations against the mock targets.
Penghu's strategic location halfway between Taiwan-proper and mainland China makes it necessary for frequent military exercises to be held there to ensure the island can defend itself against attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN COUNTY TOPS FOR OVERALL SERVICE QUALITY IN NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ilan County Government tops the list of best overall service quality among the seven counties and cities under the jurisdiction of the Taiwan Provincial government in northern Taiwan, according to the results of an official survey released Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission from Dec. 4 through Dec. 15, shows that 61 percent of those polled in Ilan County said they are satisfied with the overall services provided by Ilan County Government, followed by 57 in Hsinchu County, 53 percent in Hsinchu City, 49 percent in Taipei County, 48 percent in Miaoli County and Keelung City and 45 percent in Taoyuan County.

Sixty percent of the respondents in Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties said they are satisfied with the state of their respective counties' traffic, followed by 51 percent in Taipei County and Hsinchu City, 49 percent in Miaoli County, 43 percent in Keelung City and 34 percent in Ilan County.

Eighty-two percent of those polled in Ilan County said the unemployment issue in their county is serious, followed by 72 percent in Miaoli County, 71 percent in Taipei County, 69 percent in Keelung City, 66 percent in Taoyuan County and 52 percent in Hsinchu County.

Thirty-eight percent of the respondents in Hsinchu City said the government attaches importance to administrative affairs in their city, followed by 33 percent in Ilan County, 27 percent in Keelung City, 26 percent in Taipei County, 25 percent in Hsinchu County, 22 percent in Miaoli County and less than 20 percent in Taoyuan County.

Sixty-five percent the respondents in Taoyuan County said the medical service provided by Taoyuan County Government is good, followed by 57 percent in Keelung City, 49 percent in Hsinchu County, 45 percent in Miaoli County, 44 percent in Taipei County, and 41 percent each in Hsinchu City and Ilan County.

More than 66 percent of those polled in Taoyuan County said public security in their county is good, followed by 59 percent in Keelung City, 54 percent in Hsinchu County, 51 percent in Miaoli County, 46 percent in Hsinchu City and 29 percent in Taipei County.

Nearly 60 percent of the respondents in Taipei and Taoyuan counties said the environments in their respective counties are seriously polluted, followed by 45 percent in Keelung City, 41 percent in Hsinchu City, 40 percent in Hsinchu County, 33 percent in Miaoli County and 13 percent in Ilan County.

Seventy-five percent of the respondents in Ilan County said the quality of tap water in their county is good, followed by 61 percent in Keelung City, 56 percent in Taipei County, 51 percent in Taoyuan County, 49 percent in Hsinchu City, 43 percent in Miaoli County and 33 percent in Hsinchu County.

More than 50 percent of the respondents in Taipei County, Hsinchu City and Keelung City said the traffic issue is the most urgent problem, while more than 38 percent of those polled in Ilan County said unemployment is the biggest problem.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ADDS SWITZERLAND TO LIST OF 14-DAY VISA-FREE COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials said Wednesday that the ROC has added Switzerland to the list of countries that enjoy 14-day visa-free privileges, effective Jan. 1.
The official said that Switzerland has already granted 48-hour landing visa privileges for ROC citizens visiting for business or tourism.
The official said the move was made in accordance with the country's Foreign Passport Visa Regulations.

The official said that holders of Swiss passports with more than six months validity and a reconfirmed flight and air ticket, as well as Swiss passport holders who have not over-stayed their visas in Taiwan within a year, can enjoy a 14-day visa exemption.

Twenty countries around the world have been granted 14-day visa-free privileges since the policy was announced in 1993. They are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, France, German, Japan, Luxembourg, Macedonia, New Zealand, Holland, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Great Britain, the United States, Costa Rica, Italy, Greece and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA MAY BE WILLING TO STORE ROC NUCLEAR WASTE

TEXT.P: With the Russian parliament approving the first reading of a revised environmental protection law, Taiwan is a step closer to having some of its nuclear waste shipped to that country for final disposal, a Taiwan official said Wednesday.

The revised version of the Russian environmental protection law will allow its nuclear facilities to permanently store nuclear waste from foreign countries, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Under the brokerage of a private Russian firm, the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) has contracted the Russian National Science Institute to dispose of 5,000 barrels of low-level radioactive waste.
If the pilot contract had been carried out successfully, the official said, more Taiwan nuclear waste would have gone to Russia.
However, the contract was blocked by existing Russian laws forbidding the import of nuclear waste.

If the Russian National Science Institute is given a thumbs up for the disposal of radioactive waste from Taiwan, the some 30,000 barrels of nuclear waste now kept at the island's three nuclear plants will take precedence over the 90,000 barrels dumped at the island's only nuclear waste dump on Orchid Island.
Taiwan has been seeking a permanent overseas dump site for its 130,000 barrels of nuclear waste due to strong advocacy of domestic anti-nuclear groups to rid Taiwan of radioactive waste.

The difficulty in finding a site to keep the waste generated by the island's three nuclear plants was one of the reasons that prompted the administration of President Chen Shui-bian to halt the construction of the island's fourth nuclear plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY `TURNING THE CORNER:' GOVERNMENT ECONOMIST

TEXT.P: A government economist said Wednesday that the local economy will "soon turn the corner" and improve.
Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that what he described as "the 10th cycle" could be the shortest one in the island's economic history.

Saying that the stock market, which plummeted that day to a five-year low, is an indicator of what the economy will be like in six months or a year, Lee noted that the economy cannot turn around before the stock market recovers.

However, he went on, there is a sliver lining, citing falling international oil prices, no threat of inflation, a possible rate cut by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board and prospects for a soft landing for the U.S. economy.

Although there is little hope for a booming economy in the United States, which is the island's major export market, Japan, where the economy is expected to maintain a 2001 growth rate similar to this year, could absorb some of Taiwan's exports intended for the United States, he said.

Given that the information and electronic industries have become the backbone of the island's economy, the short life cycle of their products means an acceleration of the economic cycle, which means a reversal of the economic downturn might not be far away, said Lee.
