DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 28, or the third day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang Army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter-high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1942: Japanese planes bomb Calcutta, India during World War II.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non-binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Chinese Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama, and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1973: The third Asian regional meeting of the International Society for Education Through Art is opened in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: The Hai Kung, a scientific survey ship of the Republic of China, reaches Cape Town after a 26-day voyage.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan renames its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 182.51 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving up 182.51 points to close at 4,797.14.
Market turnover amounted to NT$58.1 billion (US$1.76 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKERS TO VISIT BEIJING NEXT MONTH

TEXT.P: A group of legislators from Taiwan's major opposition Kuomintang (KMT) is scheduled to visit mainland China Jan. 4-11 to exchange views with mainland leaders on the issue of "three direct links" across the Taiwan Strait.

The group will be comprised of some 40 KMT lawmakers and specialists from several of the party's think-tanks, including Kao Kung-lian, former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said Ho Chih-hui, party whip of the KMT caucus in the Legislative Yuan.

The KMT legislators and specialists, at the invitation of mainland China's intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), are expected to visit Beijing first to meet mainland Chinese leaders on matters pertaining to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China, better known as the "big three links" initiative, according to Ho.

The group members are also expected to meet with officials from mainland China's ministries of transportation, foreign trade, postal affairs and civil aviation, for talks on technical issues related to the "big three links."
Following their Beijing visit, the KMT legislators and specialists will visit mainland China's leading port cities of Shanghai, Tianjin, Qingdao, and Fuzhou on fact-finding tours, Ho said.

According to Ho, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said he fully supports the forthcoming visit to mainland China by KMT lawmakers and experts, noting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume negotiations as early as possible. He added that as the major opposition party, the KMT should do what it can in this respect as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been unable to.

Beijing has invited the KMT group to the mainland for talks on the "big three links" while evidently giving the cold shoulder to the DPP-initiated "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the Republic of China's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Fujian port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 182.51 points to close at 4,797.14.
The bourse opened at 4,581.06, and due to a strong rebound in financial shares, the index began to go up. The bourse fluctuated between 4,797.14 and 4,555.91 during trading.

A total of 1.98 billion stocks worth NT$58.1 billion (US$1.76 billion) changed hands, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 0.81 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$21.31 billion (US$0.64 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories lost ground, with construction stocks edging down 0.1 percent.

The other major categories posted gains, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 6.1 percent, followed by electrical shares at 4.1 percent, cement stocks at 3.4 percent, textile issues at 3.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2 percent, and foodstuff shares at 1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 366 to 125, with 83 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Thursday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January surged 302 points to close at 4,867, with 11,954 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February 2001 increased 288 points to finish at 4,878, with 99 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures gained 209 points to close at 4,888, with two contract transactions.
June 2001 futures gained 48 points to finish at 4,728, with four contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for September 2001 futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 4,565 for next January, 4,590 for next February, 4,679 for next March, 4,680 for next June, and 4,661 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also higher.
January 2001 TE futures moved up 14.95 points to close at 228.95, with 3,750 contracts changing hands, while February 2001 TE futures rose 15 points to finish at 230.7, with 22 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January 2001 TF futures increased 42.8 points to close at 654.8, with 1,675 contract transactions, while February 2001 TF futures surged 43 points to finish at 657.4, with 20 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL RUN DATE OF PRIVATE POWER PLANT DELAYED

TEXT.P: The start of operations at the privately owned Changsheng Power Plant in northern Taiwan, originally scheduled for this Thursday, has been delayed until early next year because preparations are behind schedule.
A planned opening ceremony for the thermal plant with Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presiding has now been delayed until Jan. 5, 2001, Changsheng sources said.

The Changsheng thermal power plant, located in the coastal township of Haihu in Taoyuan County, is equipped with two generator systems, each with an installed capacity of 480,000 kilowatts. The electricity to be generated by the plant will all be sold to state-run Taiwan Power Co., Taiwan's sole power supplier and distributor.

Changsheng Power Plant is currently one of two private power plants in Taiwan enjoying government subsidies under a government-initiated power-bolster plan designed to redress power shortage problems in the country.

Construction on the other privately operated power plant, the Chiahui Power Plant, which is located in Minhsiung township in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, resumed Thursday under the protection of a 400-strong police force aimed at deterring obstruction by neighborhood residents.
Construction on the Chiahui Power Plant was suspended soon after kicking off in July of this year because of residents' opposition.

The plant, to be powered by liquefied natural gas, will have an installed capacity of 670,000 kilowatts of electricity. It is scheduled to begin operating in January 2003 if all goes smoothly, company sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE UNIONS CONFEDERATION TOPS YEAR 2000 TAIWAN JOB MARKET NEWS

TEXT.P: The establishment of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) on May 1 was voted the top job market news story in the country for the year 2000 by Taiwan's 9-to-5 working men and women in an on-line survey.

Topping the list of 10 most reported and influential job market news stories over the past year, the establishment of the TCTU marked a milestone in the progress of general employees' decision-making rights, said the Taipei Office Workers Association, which conducted the survey in collaboration with the China Times Website.
Second on the top 10 list was the story of a part-time student-worker at the Tienmu branch of the Carrefour discount store franchise who was forced by the store management to eat burned cakes.

The third top story was the passage of an amendment to the state-run enterprise management statute allowing labor members of public enterprises to be elected to the enterprise's board of supervisors and directors.

Fourth was the Pahchang Creek Incident, in which four unlucky river-bed cleaners trapped together in rising Pahchang Creek flood waters in the southern county of Chiayi waited for over two hours for a rescue that never came before finally losing their footing and being swept away to their deaths.
The controversial shortened workweek plan ranked as the fifth top story, while labor union activist Tseng Mao-hsiung's arrest came in sixth.

Chosen as the seventh most important job market news story was the Department of Health's decision to assist enterprises in establishing nursing rooms at work to help working women take care of their infants or young children.
Ranking eighth on the list was the prevalence of layoffs of employees by Internet-related companies as a result of low business.
The story of members of several labor unions in a number of private-run companies being suppressed or fired in the wake of labor union activities ranked ninth on the list.
And rounding out the top ten was the continuing increase in Taiwan's unemployment rate, which topped 3.23 percent in November, marking a 15-year high for that month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PITCHES FOR CLOSER CROSS-STRAIT JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should strengthen mutual judicial assistance after the opening of direct "mini three links," a senior mainland affairs official said Thursday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, made the appeal as part of his efforts to allay public misgivings about a possible rise in the crime rate following the onset of the "mini three links."

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the legislature earlier this year, the Republic of China government is scheduled Jan. 1 to formally open direct trade, mail and shipping links between its defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis for one year.

Some people are worried that the opening of direct exchanges of people and goods between the two frontline islands and the mainland may cause sabotages to legal order on both sides and a rise in the crime rate.

Responding to such worries, Lin said judicial organizations on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should reinforce mutual assistance and join forces to crack down on crime so as to ensure smooth opening of the "mini three links."

Noting that the success of the "mini three links" hinges on security management and safeguarding of law and order, Lin said the ROC government looks forward to forging systematic consultative channels with the mainland to facilitate orderly cross-strait exchanges and better protect the legitimate rights and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin said the ROC's Ministry of National Defense, the Ministry of the Interior, the Ministry of Justice, the National Coast Guard Administration and other relevant government agencies have completed various security measures to curb possible illegal entry and exit as well as smuggling and illegal transshipment of goods between the Taiwan proper and the mainland following the opening of the "mini three links."

Meanwhile, Lin said he feels regret over Legislator Chen Ching-pao's decision to suspend a planned trial voyage between Kinmen and Xiamen before the formal opening of the "mini three links" with a view to testing the safety of the new route. Chen was forced to cancel the plan mainly because of Beijing's pressure.
Lin called on mainland China to adopt a pragmatic, positive manner to deal with such kind of cross-strait engagement to help foster mutual trust and rapprochement.

He further stressed that the government has no intention of promoting full-fledged direct cross-strait trade, mail and transport links, also known as the "big three links," by opening the "mini three links."
Nevertheless, Lin said he is convinced that the experience from implementing the "mini three links" will be helpful to planning an orderly opening of the "big three links."
In related news, MAC Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the ROC government will do its utmost to protect personal safety of Taiwan visitors to the mainland.

"We also hope that mainland authorities will offer all necessary assistance and protection for ROC nationals during their stay on the mainland," Tsai said, adding that the ROC government will also provide all needed assistance and protection for mainland visitors to Kinmen and Matsu following the opening of the "mini three links."

Tsai further said as mainland China still declines to resume dialogue with Taiwan, local shipping companies intending to operate scheduled or chartered shipping services to mainland ports after the opening of the "mini three links" should obtain prior mainland approval to avoid unnecessary risks and losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF INFO HARDWARE SEEN GROWING BY 20.5% THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The production value of information hardware is expected to grow by 20.5 percent this year, the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Thursday.

III officials noted that the world economy started to rebound last year and continued to turn for the better over the first half of 2000. For the second half of this year, with slumping world stock markets and a weak Euro, global economic performance was not as good as estimated.
But the officials noted that Taiwan's major information products' global market share has remained high, adding that notebook computers produced in Taiwan have the largest market share in the world.

With respect to computer monitors, with the price of LCD panels slipping, the price of LCD monitors has also dropped, they said, noting that Taiwan's world market share still continues to grow steadily in this area.

In addition, Taiwan's telecommunications industry has demonstrated good performance because of the steady production of cellular phones. It is expected that the growth in cellular phone production will help stimulate growth in the overall telecommunications industry over the next few years, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS TO HOLD BREAKFAST MEETING ON CURRENT ECONOMIC WOES

TEXT.P: Business leaders this Saturday will hold their first breakfast meeting since the new administration came to power this May to discuss Taiwan's current economic and industrial problems.
The breakfast meeting was initiated by Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce Chairman Jeffrey Koo and will be held at the headquarters of the Chinatrust Commercial Bank in Taipei.

Participants to the breakfast meeting will include the heads of Chinese National Federation of Industries, the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, and the National Association of Small & Medium Enterprises, along with Taiwan Semiconductor Management Corp. Chairman Morris Chang and Shin Kong Group Chairman Wu Tung-chin.
It is understood that President Chen Shui-bian, Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, and other financial and economic officials will also take part in the meeting.

Business leaders said they are worried about the exodus of local businesses overseas, the slump in the share and currency markets, the surge in the unemployment rate, and the sluggish overall economic performance over the past six months, adding that they hope to establish a communication channel with the government on these problems.
They also expressed the hope that the government will take forceful measures to revive the economic vitality of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET MINISTERS DISCUSS WAYS OF HELPING TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang and Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi Thursday presided over a meeting to discuss the government's measures for helping financially-troubled traditional industries.
The meeting was attended by several other senior officials from the two ministries.

Lin told reporters that the meeting was designed to divide the work load between the Economics Ministry and the Finance Ministry for the implementation of measures to help the industries tide over their difficulties.
The problem of a shortage of funds that government-run enterprises face was also among the topics discussed at the meeting, he added.
At the same time, Chinfon Group Chairman Shih H. Huang called on Yen to report on the results after six months of the Finance Ministry's extension of aid to help the group undergo structural reforms.
Shih also explained Chinfon's long-term remodeling plan and asked the Finance Ministry to continue its support for the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar appreciated NT$0.006 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at NT$33.159.
The local currency opened at NT$33.159 and was traded between NT$33.158 and NT$33.191.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$298 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER VISITS MATSU AHEAD OF 'MINI LINKS'

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen made an inspection tour of the frontline island of Matsu Thursday to review security measures adopted by the Matsu defense command ahead of the imminent opening of the "mini three links."

Wu said after his return from Matsu that he was satisfied with the circumspect preparations done by the Matsu defense command to ensure the offshore island's security following the opening of the "mini three links."

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the Republic of China government is scheduled Jan. 1 to formally open direct trade, mail and shipping links between its defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis for one year.

Wu said he is convinced that the limited opening of direct exchanges of people and goods with the mainland will not have any adverse impact on Matsu's security and defense operations since the ROC military has reinforced its security measures and adjusted some defense deployment and tactics.

As for the possibility of military reconciliation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said the time is still not yet ripe to consider such an issue. "It will depend on whether the 'mini three links' plan can be implemented smoothly," the minister noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL-WINNING CHINESE-FRENCH WRITER TO MAKE 14-DAY VISIT TO ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Dec. 27 (CNA) (By M.J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chinese-French novelist and playwright Gao Xingjian, who won this year's Nobel Prize in literature, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan Feb. 1 for a two-week visit, Republic of China Representative to France Kuo Wei-fan said Wednesday.
Kuo made the announcement at a dinner he hosted in honor of Gao and Chu Teh-chun, a celebrated artist who was just elected an academician of the prestigious Institute de France.

According to Kuo, Gao will receive an honorary doctorate in literature from the ROC's National Sun Yat-sen University during his stay, in recognition of his outstanding achievements in creative writing.

For his part, Gao said he appreciates all the care and assistance Kuo has given him over the years. Gao, a survivor of mainland China's Cultural Revolution who fled the mainland for France after his works were banned, recalled that Kuo helped organize his first trip to Taiwan in 1993 when Kuo was chairman of the ROC's Council of Cultural Affairs.

Gao said he has since made many other trips to Taiwan and has made friends with many of its literary, theatrical, artistic and religious elite. "I have found warmth and comfort in Taiwan and have come to feel that the island is my homeland," he added.

As the first Chinese writer to win the Nobel Prize, Gao said the honor should be shared by all Chinese people because he does not think his personal achievements deserve the laurel. "The prize also marks a recognition of Chinese culture," he noted.

Despite Beijing's repressive and unpopular rule, Gao said, the rich Chinese culture still enjoys a strong following in the world judging from the enthusiastic global response to his winning of the Nobel Prize.

Gao's upcoming Taiwan visit is organized by the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of Taipei City Hall. He will be a keynote speaker at a number of seminars to be sponsored by two major Taiwan press groups -- the China Times and the United Daily News.
During his visit, Gao will also meet with ROC President Chen Shui-bian and Tchen Yu-chiou, chairwoman of the council of Cultural Affairs.

The Swedish Academy cited the "bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity" in Gao's works such as the play "Fugitives," set against the background of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, and "Soul Mountain," a narrative about Gao's travels in southwestern China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PC FIRMS SHIFT MORE ASSEMBLY WORK TO M'LAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The trend of Taiwan personal computer companies shifting more and more of their assembly work to mainland China because of lower costs will become more obvious in the near future, according to a report by the Institute for Information Industry.
III statistics show that last year, 15 percent of Taiwan PC firms' assembly work was carried out domestically, while 29 percent was performed in North America, and 30 percent in mainland China.

However, the same statistics showed that the percentage of Taiwan PC companies' assembly work that took place in mainland China surged significantly to 45 percent this year, while local assemblage accounted for 16 percent, almost the same as the previous year.

Meanwhile, III officials said Thursday that with the continued orders from abroad, Taiwan's personal computers are expected to account for 31.1 percent of the global market in 2003, compared with the 24.5 percent registered this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAX BREAKS INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's lawmakers gave the nation's wage earners a holiday gift Thursday in the form of bigger tax breaks, only days before the end of this century's last legislative session.

After numerous negotiations among the ruling and opposition party caucuses, the Legislative Yuan passed the amendments to articles 17 and 126 of the Income Tax Law, raising the ceiling for a special tax-free income deductible from the current NT$62,000 (US$1,870) to NT$75,000 (US$2,262) per year per taxpayer.

This pre-tax deductible works out to approximately NT$780 (US$24) to NT$5,200 (US$157) in tax breaks per person, depending on each individual's income and taxation level, which can vary from 6 percent to 40 percent of one's total income.
When husband and wife are both wage earners, each receives his or her own NT$75,000 pre-tax deductible whether they file their tax returns together or not.

Meanwhile, each taxpayer can strike off an additional NT$120,000 (US$3,619) per year from his or her taxable income for apartment and house rentals for residential purposes. This translates into anywhere from NT$7,200 (US$217) to NT$48,000 (US$1,448) in final tax breaks, again depending on one's income level.

Another amendment passed Thursday allows taxpayers over the age of 70 who file their own returns to receive 1.5 times the amount of all tax-free deductibles they are eligible to claim. Prior to the amendment, only those 70-years-or-older taxpayers who filed their taxes as dependents on the return forms of their families or relatives were eligible for the same break.
Because the amendments include a clause that allows them to be retroactively applied to all income earned this year, the new tax deductible scheme can be used when filing tax returns in March 2001.

According to the Ministry of Finance, the government treasury stands to lose approximately NT$8.2 billion (US$247 million) in taxation income due to the new changes. This additional loss comes on the heels of a recent move to reduce and finally eliminate the gross revenue tax for the financial sector, which will lead to an estimated loss of over NT$30 billion (US$905 million) in revenues for the national coffer.
To cover the revenue losses, ministry sources indicated that the government will attempt to raise NT$70 billion (US$2.1 billion) in treasury bonds next year as a transitional measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE MEASURING 5.3 ON RICHTER SCALE STRIKES NEAR HUALIEN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.3 on the Richter Scale struck near Hualien in eastern Taiwan Thursday afternoon, with no human casualties or property damage reported, police said.
According to the Central Weather Bureau, the quake occured at 5:01 p.m. Thursday, with its epicenter being located at 68.9 kilometers southeast of Hualien.
The earthquake was also felt in areas across northern and central Taiwan and as far away as Tainan city in the southwest of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT BID TO EXTEND WORKWEEK FAILS IN LEGISLATIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: With three days to go before the 84-hour bi-weekly workweek takes effect, the government's attempts to extend it to cushion the effects on local industries failed again in the Legislative Yuan Thursday.

The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) motioned in the Legislative Yuan for the third time to change Thursday's agenda to discuss the government's proposal to revise Article 30 of the Labor Standards Law, which limits the maximum workweek to 84 hours in every two-week period, but was defeated by a 64-84 margin, with five abstentions.

President Chen Shui-bian called Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, to urge him to put national interest beyond partisan haggling and rally behind the government's proposal, but Chen's concerns only irritated the opposition, which denounced the president for trying to interfere with legislative business.
Chen called Wang again after the vote, to explore the possibility of revisiting the issue the following day, which would be the deadline for any possible revision.
A 44-hour workweek was the government's original initiative, but was cut down to the 84-hour bi-weekly version and approved by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan on June 16.
Then-Premier Tang Fei chose to take it lying down and did not ask the legislature to reconsider.

The shorter workweek version caused a backlash among the island's industries, especially when the economy expansion began to slow down in the latter half of this year. Bosses complained that the new workweek will force more firms out of business and lead to higher unemployment.
However, labor groups, which were in favor of the shorter hours, refused to budge and called on the opposition lawmakers to stick to their original stance to protect workers' rights.

In the last two weeks, the opposition alliance put forward a compromise which would provide that the workweek could be extended to 88-hours in every two-week period, as long as it was agreed by both employers and the majority of employees and registered with the authorities.
However, the total number of work hours could not exceed 48 per week and the compromise would lapse after one year, or Dec. 31, 2001.
The compromise, although similar to the government' plan in principle, failed to win over the DPP, which insists on giving firms 18 months to accommodate the 84-hour version.
The argument scuttled any efforts to bridge the gap between the two groups and sealed the fate of the DPP's attempts to reopen the issue Thursday.

Predicting that the shorter workweek will wreak havoc on the island's economy, DPP Secretary-General Wu Nei-jen said a day earlier that the Kuomintang, People's First Party and the New Party -- the three main opposition parties -- will bear the full blame for this.

While the legislators were working on the issue Thursday, separate lobby groups representing the management and workers demonstrated in front of the Legislative Yuan, each group vying to make more noise than other to make their respective voices heard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS URGED TO EXPLORE INDIAN MARKET

TEXT.P: A trade promotion agency Thursday urged local firms to explore the Indian market, as many international companies are attempting to gain a better foothold in the subcontinent.

Chang Shih-chang, director of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) office in Bombay, said Thursday in Taipei that his office has collected data on more than 40,000 Indian importers during the last three years for the reference of local firms, and has cooperated with Taiwan's Chinatrust Commercial Bank to help prepare Taiwan firms for making the move there.
Chang said that India has a gigantic market potential and a highly developed Internet industry, which facilitates the rapid circulation of merchandise information.

Although purchasing power in India is relatively low, the country enjoys first-class merchandise information and has attracted many international companies to invest there, Chang said, adding that some Taiwan companies such as the computer giant Acer Inc., China Motor Corp. and Chinatrust Commercial Bank have already followed suit.
He said his office has also focused its efforts on pushing India's top 200 trade groups to purchase from Taiwan.
He continued that India has developed actively its information software industry, which has attracted many Taiwan information companies to search for cooperation opportunities there.
According to statistics of CETRA's Bombay office, India boasts a merchandise and service market worth US$150 billion and a potential consumer population of 130 million.
CETRA officials stressed that India is a big market worth exploring by Taiwan enterprises while striving to reduce market risks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAW ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITIES SEIZE 133 KILOGRAMS OF HEROIN

TEXT.P: The Investigation Bureau (IB) of the Justice Ministry announced Thursday the year's biggest drugs haul, arresting a suspect and confiscating 133 kilograms of heroin from mainland China worth about NT$6 billion.

An IB official said that a special task force was set up to investigate the case several months ago after law enforcement authorities received a tip through international cooperation that a Taiwan resident was attempting to smuggle drugs into Taiwan from mainland China.
The suspect, identified as Tung Shu-sheng, recently returned to Taiwan from the mainland, where he was being sought by public security officials on charges stemming from an arms smuggling case.

A group of investigators led by a prosecutor of the Kaohsiung Prosecutors' Office raided Tung's houses in Luchow, Taipei County, and in Taipei City Thursday. Tung was arrested, but two other suspects staying with Tung escaped.
Investigators seized the 133.34 kilograms of heroin, along with 652 grams of amphetamine.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN EMERGES AS FAVORITE DESTINATION FOR TAIWAN TOURISTS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Japan was the favorite destination for Taiwan vacationers this year, according to the results of a survey released Thursday.

The results also show that Eva Airways (EVA) was selected by the survey respondents as the best airline in 2000, followed by Singapore Airlines, Japan's Asia Airways, Cathay Pacific and China Airlines.
To Go Travel and Information Magazine conducted the survey on overseas trips made by local people in millennium year.
The most popular destination for 2001, according to the survey respondents, is a resort island villa, with Bali, Hawaii, the Maldives, Guam and Palau as the most favored destinations.

According to the same survey, Hong Kong and Thailand were the places offering the warmest welcomes, but were also the worst places to visit, although Hong Kong was voted the best shopping destination.
Japan, France, New Zealand, Switzerland and Italy were the top five most favored destinations, while Vienna, Tokyo, Paris, Venice and New York were the top five cities.
Honeymooners tended to favor the Maldives, Hawaii, Paris, Switzerland and Italy.

According to statistics compiled by the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transport and Communications, local people made 6 million overseas visits in 1999 and tourism officials estimated that the figure might break the 7 million mark at the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC ANNOUNCES 0.125-PERCENTAGE-POINT CUT OF REDISCOUNT RATE

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) announced Thursday a cut of 0.125 percentage points in rediscount rate from Friday in a bid to stimulate the recovery of the economy.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan made the announcement at a press conference after a CBC board of directors and supervisors meeting.
The CBC also announced a 0.125 percent cut in the accommodation rate and a five percent raise in the foreign-currency deposit reserve requirement, also effective Friday.
The new rediscount rate and accommodation rate will be 4.625 percent and 5 percent, respectively, while the new rate for the foreign-currency deposit reserve requirement will be 10 percent.
Meanwhile, the CBC said it will reduce the M2 money supply target range for next year to between 5 and 10 percent from the current 6 percent-11 percent.
The moves are part of a CBC five-point monetary policy announced after the board meeting.
The other two key points of the policy include:
-- strengthening discipline in the financial sector in order to accomplish the government's existing policy of liberalizing and internationalizing the nation's finances; and
-- supplying mounting liquidity demand before the Chinese New Year holidays in late January for financial institutions, through open-market operations, discount windows and accommodation measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC ENVOY PRESENTS CREDENTIALS TO ROC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Dominican Republic Ambassador to the Republic of China Miguel Angel Hernandez Nunez presented his credentials to Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian Thursday.
Secretary-General to the Presidential Office You Shi-kun and Vice Foreign Minister David Lee were among the dignitaries who witnessed the ceremony at the Presidential Office.

After the ceremony, Chen extended a warm welcome to Hernandez, lauding him as an outstanding journalist and noting that he is a good friend of President Hipolito Mejia. Chen said he believes bilateral relations will be further strengthened as a result of Hernandez' appointment.

Chen went on to point out that relations between the ROC and the Dominican Republic have been established for more than half a century. He noted that the Dominican Republic was not only the first foreign country he visited after assuming power May 20, but also that he was the first ROC president to visit the Caribbean country.

Chen also said that Dominican President Mejia likes Taiwan very much. In addition to having made 22 visits to Taiwan, Mejia will visit the ROC again next March. "We will extend our most warm welcome to him," Chen noted.
In return, Hernandez conveyed Mejia's personal regards to Chen and said he hopes that the economic and investment cooperation between the two countries will be further cemented.
Chen also reiterated that the ROC will honor all the treaties that have been signed between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX CUSTOMS CHECKPOINTS TO BE ESTABLISHED ON KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance announced Thursday that customs checkpoints will be established in six locations on the frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu in order to prevent illegal transshipments from the islands to Taiwan-proper.

With only three days to go before the imminent opening of the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal, and transport links between Taiwan's two frontline outposts and designated ports in mainland China -- the ministry invited related government agencies to work out the specifics involved in preventing mainland goods from being smuggled into Taiwan via Kinmen and Matsu.

According to the measures, which were finalized by the Ministry of the Interior, the Mainland Affairs Council, the Ministry of Justice, the Council of Agriculture, the Coast Guard Administration, the Directorate General of Posts, the Department of Customs Administration and the Kinmen county government, the checkpoints will be located at each island's main airport, seaport, and post office.

Meanwhile, the Coast Guard Administration will be responsible for checking smaller seaports, the islands' coastlines and nearby waters for any illegal activities, while the Directorate General of Posts will be in charge of examining parcels for contraband.

According to the Department of Customs Administration under the Ministry of Finance, only a limited range of carry-on personal articles will be allowed to enter Taiwan or the Penghu islands from Kinmen or Matsu.

Regarding the maximum dollar amount per transaction that may be transferred from Kinmen and Matsu to mainland China and vice versa, the Central Bank of China in Taiwan announced Thursday that a cap of US$100,000 will be in effect other than for those instances when the items being imported or exported are accompanied by certification documents issued by the government-appointed currency exchange banks.

In addition, the total amount of transactions cannot exceed US$5 million per person per year, or US$50 million per company per year. Only residents of Kinmen and Matsu are allowed to carry out such transactions.

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the Legislative Yuan earlier this year, the Republic of China government is scheduled Jan. 1 to formally open the "mini three links" on a trial basis for one year.

Although mainland China's response to the mini links is only lukewarm, ROC Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Thursday that his administration will wait patiently for a friendlier response to the "first step toward cross-Taiwan Strait peace."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO STAGE YEAREND PRESS BRIEFING

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung will hold his first yearend press briefing Friday to answer questions from the media, the Government Information Office announced Thursday.
About 92 local journalists and 13 foreign reporters have registered to attend the briefing.

Chang, who took the helm of the Cabinet after Tang Fei quit on Oct. 3, is expected to explain his efforts to head the administration and develop the economy, the two principal focuses of his administration.

Plagued by the stock market nose-dive, the scrapping of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, rising unemployment, the launching of direct trade links between Kinmen, Matzu and mainland China and the battle with the Legislative Yuan over the work hours, Chang is expected to be bombarded with questions from the media during the briefing.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUDDHIST GROUP CONVENES YOUTH CONFERENCE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Nearly 400 young people from Buddhist groups in 15 countries gathered Thursday in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, to try to figure out "a direction for the next generation."

The young people participating in the youth conference, organized by the Buddha's Light International Association (BLIA), visited Nantou County, central Taiwan, on Wednesday, to see the area that bore the brunt of last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
They visited the temporary housing units where many quake victims are still living. They also visited an elementary school in the affected area.
It was the first time the group, which has collected money for the victims of the quake, had had the chance to see for themselves the results of the natural disaster.
One of the youths, a university student from Australia, said he wanted to share his experience with young people from other countries in order to influence other young people to care about the world.
During the five-day conference, the young people will listen to reports from scholars and to preaching by Buddhist Master Hsing Yun, the founder of the BLIA and the Fo Kuang Shan Temple.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LICENSES 1ST ABORTION PILL

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Thursday it has approved the marketing of the abortion pill Mifegyne in Taiwan as a grade-four controlled drug.

DOH Director-General Lee Ming-liang said the drug must be prescribed by gynecologists and only used under close medical supervision at approved clinics or hospitals. The drug will be covered under the National Health Insurance Program, he added.

According to Lee, two brands of abortion pills, both of which have Mifepristone -- commonly known as RU 486 -- as their active ingredient, have undergone clinical tests in Taiwan, but only the Mifegyne brand has been licensed by the DOH.
Mifegyne is produced by the French pharmaceutical company Roussel-Uclaf, which developed RU 486.
RU 486 is a steroid hormone similar in structure to the natural hormone progesterone, which is essential for establishing and maintaining a pregnancy.

Invented in 1980 by Dr. Etienne-Emile Baulieu, RU 486 is the first of a new generation of birth control drugs called "antiprogestins." As Baulieu later gave up his patent rights, pharmaceutical manufacturers around the world can produce RU 486 based on his recipe.

Lee said that as RU 486 has serious side effects, including bleeding, menustrual-style pain and cramping and some nausea and vomiting, the DOH must impose stringent controls on supplies and distribution. Statistics show that about 1,000 local women who have used various brands of RU 486 available on the "black market" have developed side effects that were fatal in two cases.

Before the DOH approved the use of Mifegyne, the drug underwent clinical testing on 43 pregnant women at National Taiwan University Hospital, Cathay General Hospital and Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital. The abortion success rate reached 95 percent, compared to 92 percent in the United States and 80 percent in many other countries.

Noting that RU 486 is basically made of anti-progesterone, Lee explained that the drug in combination with a prostaglandin can curb the growth of the embryo and bring about abortion in very early pregnancy.

Lee stressed that the RU 486 regime works only during the first nine weeks of pregnancy, or up to 63 days from the start of the women's last menstrual period. "After this time, the women's own protesterone level is apparently too great to be affected by the drug," he added.

Lee said a pregnant woman must swallows RU 486 in tablet form in the presence of a doctor before leaving the climinc and must return to the clinic after 36 to 49 hours to receive the prostaglandin which will complete the abortion. "And she must return again several days later for an examination to make sure the abortion is complete and to determine if she has experienced any side effects," he cautioned.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRY EXPERT URGES TAIWAN INDUSTRIES TO FOCUS ON GLOBALIZATION

TEXT.P: The head of an association that promotes the interests of Taiwan businessmen with investments in mainland China said Thursday that local businesses should focus on globalization instead of simply on the mainland market.

Chen Ming-chang, chairman of the association, said at a seminar on the political and economic situations of Taiwan and the mainland in 2001 that next year will be an important watershed for Taiwan businesses.

If the companies only focus their attention on securing their places in the mainland market but fail to explore the international market, then Taiwan's economic might will be drained by the mainland within a few years, he cautioned.

However, he added, if Taiwan firms can establish their head offices, design, research and development centers in Taiwan, relocate their manufacturing centers to the mainland and Eastern European countries, and develop their own brand identities in the mainland and other Asia-Pacific countries, then the future for these companies will be "limitless."

Chen went on to say that mainland China's strategy in luring Taiwan businesses has gradually changed from accepting every investment to the current method of providing incentives to attract certain selective sectors such as the high tech industry.

He added that the Taiwan businesses entering mainland China have failed to cooperate with each other and have even brought their competition into the new market, a situation he said might have adverse effects on their development in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG'S FIRST CAR ROLLS OUT OF FACTORY

TEXT.P: The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Thursday presented its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured through technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo group.
At a ceremony to mark the car's debut, FPG Chairman Wang Yung-ching explained its functions to Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi.

FPG, Taiwan's leading petroleum chemical producer, went into automobile manufacturing in October 1998, with the ultimate aim of developing an energy-conserving, low emission electrical car in the 21st century.
So far, the group has invested US$200 million in the project.
The Formosa Magnus comes in three models which will be sold in Taiwan at NT$759,000, NT$699,000 and NT$639,000, respectively. They will also be available on the world market from 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVICE TO REPLACE VETERAN AS ROC ENVOY TO CANADA

TEXT.P: An academic teaching at a Taiwan university will replace Fang Chin-yen as representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada as Fang is retiring.
Chen Tung-Pi, who lived in Canada for 30 years, taught law at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario and practiced as a lawyer in Toronto before taking his current teaching job in Taiwan.

Fang said Tuesday he is thankful for the support and assistance he has received from the overseas Chinese community over the past four and a half years in Canada. With their help, he said, he has enjoyed smooth sailing in promoting economic and cultural exchanges between Taiwan and Canada.

One of his proud achievements during his term of office in Ottawa was the settlement of the knotty "Maersk Dubai" shipping liner case, in which the Taiwanese captain and officers were accused by the Filipino crew of throwing three Romanian stowaways overboard into the Atlantic in mid-1996.

The controversy dragged several concerned countries into a diplomatic row that was complicated by legal battles and political fights over Taiwan's sovereignty. In March 1997, Fang convinced the Canadian government to hand over the six accused to face justice in Taiwan.

Following the "Maersk Dubai" case, Taiwan's relations with Canada have steadily grown into increased trade and investment as well as student and tourist exchanges. Two-way trade now tops C$5 billion a year and people-to-people relations are booming.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILATERAL ISSUES `TAKE TWO TO SOLVE:' MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Bilateral issues "take two to solve" and bilateral ties "take two to improve," Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said Thursday.

He made the comment after a Beijing spokeswoman described the forthcoming direct trade and shipping links between Taiwan's two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China -- the so-called "mini three-links" -- as "internal affairs."
Taiwan is set to open Kinmen and Matsu to direct shipping and trade with mainland China from Jan. 1.

Beijing, which has ignored Taiwan's proffered olive branches until Taipei acknowledges that there is only one China of which Taiwan is a part -- the so-called "one China" principle -- greeted Taiwan's latest gesture coldly.

Lin said the direct trade and shipping links between mainland China and the Taiwan-controlled islands indicate Taipei's goodwill toward Beijing and noted that they have been implemented solely by Taiwan in the hope that they will spark a positive and constructive response from Beijing and lead to more opening by both sides.

Taiwan has no intention of making the "mini three-links" a stepping stone to formal direct trade links between Taiwan and mainland China, said Lin, but he admitted that the experience gained from the "mini three-links" will help prepare Taiwan for direct links between the mainland and Taiwan proper.

DOC.HEADLINE: 14,000 AGED KINMEN MILITIAMEN BECOME ROC HONORARY VETERANS

TEXT.P: Two hundred and fifty representatives of aged Kinmen civil defense corpsmen who took part in the artillery duel across the Taiwan Strait in 1958 were granted honorary Republic of China veteran status Thursday.
The honorary veteran certificates were presented at a ceremony presided over by Yang Te-chih, chairman of the Cabinet-level Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen (VACRS).

Speaking at the ceremony, Yang thanked the recipients for their courage in the defense of the frontline islands against the communists and welcomed them as ROC honorary veterans. He also explained their rights to the various services provided by VACRS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Chen Shui-bian's complaint backfires; Workweek debate remains deadlocked.
The China Times:
84-hour every-two week work plan expected to be implemented at the start of the new year.
The United Daily News:
Central bank announces 0.125 percent cut in rediscount rate.
The Liberty Times:
A just-passed amendment to income tax law increases the tax exemption threshold for salaries and wages from NT$62,000 to NT$75,000.
The China Post:
Amendment to income tax law finally passed.
The Taiwan News:
Central bank surprises with key rate cut.
The Taipei Times:
China gives nod to 'small three links.'

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 29, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy, and Japan sign the Washington treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1973: Costa Rica's Labor Minister Francisco Morales Hernandez arrives in Taipei for a 12-day visit.
1973: Fernando Ricardo, new Colombian charge d'affaires in Taipei, arrives.
1973: An 18-member Chinese ski team leaves for Innsbruck, Austria for a month of training.
1974: Jose Leido, the Philippines minister for natural resources, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives visiting Greek Congressman Georgios Vasilio Mangakis.
1976: A two-week telecommunications exhibition opens at the Taiwan Communications Administration Building.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general election.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese boat people battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC air force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."
