DOC.HEADLINE: PM CHANG TOUTS `TRANSFORMATIVE CABINET'

TEXT.P: Calling the emergence of the Democratic Progressive Party as the ruling party the beginning of government by all the people, and noting that the people want to see the triumph of reform, Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the Executive Yuan will change itself from a "progressive Cabinet" to a "transformative Cabinet."

Chang, who touted a "progressive Cabinet" when he was first appointed by President Chen Shui-bian as premier nearly three months ago, said that "we are not afraid of failure. Success will be on our side in the long run as long as the direction is right."

In his first yearend press briefing held at the Government Information Office, Chang stressed the importance of "transformation," saying not only does the organization of the Executive Yuan need to be transformed, but also the relationship between the administration and the legislature.

Calling the idea of a "legislative alliance" an important concept, Chang said he hopes that the opposition Kuomintang, People First Party, and New Party, and the other independent legislators will cease boycotting the minority DPP which is the ruling party and form an alliance with it for the sake of national peace and progress.
Chang, meanwhile, ducked journalists' suggestions that the government form a coalition Cabinet, saying only that it is up to President Chen to decide such a move.

Chang, who took the helm of the Cabinet after Premier Tang Fei resigned on Oct. 3, explained to the media his efforts to head the administration and develop the economy, the two principal focuses of the present administration.

He met the press at a trying time when Taiwan is being plagued by a slumping stock market, political controversy over the scrapping of the fourth nuclear power plant, rising unemployment, and a battle over the issue of workweek hours. Adding to the general buzz at the same time is the fact that direct trade links between the offshore ROC islands of Kinmen and Matsu and selected ports in mainland China are set to kick off at the start of the new year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 53.2 points to close at 4,743.94.
The bourse opened at 4,797.08, and due to profit-taking selling pressure, the index began to go down. The bourse fluctuated between 4,813.64 and 4,728.43 during trading.

A total of 1.47 billion stocks worth NT$43.08 billion (US$1.3 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.98 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$58.1 billion (US$1.76 billion).
Only two of the eight major categories posted gains, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent.

The other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.8 percent, electrical shares at 1.7 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, and textile issues and construction stocks, both at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 309 to 160, with 111 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were lower Friday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved down 160 points to close at 4,707, with 9,409 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February 2001 decreased 170 points to finish at 4,708, with 46 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures lost 121 points to close at 4,748, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 4,867 for next January, 4,878 for next February, 4,869 for next March, 4,728 for next June, and 4,963 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were also lower.
January 2001 TE futures moved down 8 points to close at 220.95, with 2,263 contracts changing hands, while February 2001 TE futures lost 8 points to finish at 222.7, with nine contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January 2001 TF futures decreased 7.8 points to close at 647, with 2,010 contract transactions, while February 2001 TF futures fell 15.4 points to finish at 642, with 17 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO BAN USE OF PERFORMING ANIMALS

TEXT.P: Traveling circuses will not be allowed to bring animals such as tigers, lions, and elephants into Singapore to perform in their shows as of Jan. 1, 2002.
The Agri-food and Veterinary Authority of Singapore said it has imposed the restriction in the interests of public safety and animal welfare.

The AVA said it has been monitoring such traveling circuses in recent years and has noticed an increase in the number of cases of mishaps or abuse associated with performing wild animals in these shows.

In some cases, the accidents have resulted in serious injuries or death to both trainers and the public. Concern over the welfare of the performing wild animals in traveling circuses is also on the rise, it added.
The use of performing animals by non-circus acts will not be banned completely after the start of 2002 but will require approval on a case by case basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS SHOULD ALSO BE TRANSFORMED: PM CHANG

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said cross Taiwan Strait relations should also be transformed while the Republic of China government is undergoing a process of transformation for a better tomorrow.

Quoting former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, Chang said in his first yearend press briefing since taking office on May 20 that cross-strait relations should be transformed in a process from "reconciliation" to "peace" and to "closeness," adding that this will also be the direction the administration follows in terms of the development of cross-strait relations.

Chang said that although the implementation of the "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the ROC's offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Fujian port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou, is only a small step, it is an important one.
The "mini three links" is a crucial point in the transformation of cross-strait relations, he added.

Noting that the "mini three links" are a prelude to Taiwan and mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization and the "big three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between Taiwan proper and mainland China, Chang called for Beijing authorities to respond with goodwill and resume the cross-strait dialogue.

He said that in the past, cross-strait relations were based on the notions of "either you die or I do" and "fighting to the bitter end." Nowadays, relations have been transformed into a situation of "competition between two rivals," he said, adding that it is hoped that these relations will improve to the status of "co-existence and co-prosperity."

Describing the current cross-strait stalemate as a political deadlock, Chang said it takes two to unlock the knot and called for Beijing authorities to return to the negotiating table to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue.

Facing mainland China's cold-shoulder reaction to Taiwan's "mini three links" initiative, Chang said Taiwan will continue in its efforts with patience and determination, all for the purpose of redressing the cross-strait stalemate.
Chang stressed that only by meeting problems in a pragmatic manner can an opening be found to end the cross-strait deadlock.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA HELPS MEN IN QUAKE-HIT AREAS FIND WORK ON FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) is offering assistance to help adult men from earthquake-affected areas who are now jobless find employment aboard fishing boats.

Officials from the COA's Fisheries Administration said that more than one year after the major earthquake rattled central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, there are still many people from the worst hit areas who remain unemployed because of difficulty finding work.

To help this special group of people, the COA officials said the Fisheries Administration has so far sponsored nearly 40 men, including aboriginal people, to receive intensive training so as to give them the skills to be able to work on fishing boats.
In addition, they noted, the COA is offering a monthly subsidy of NT$15,000 to each of the new recruits who commit to work on ocean-going fishing boats.

The officials said adult men aged over 16 with a basic education background and whose homes are located in the 921 earthquake-affected areas are welcome to contact the Fisheries Administration's Ocean-Going Fishery Development Center for free training, paving the way for a future career on the seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN TO VISIT TAIWAN IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: The United States' top liaison officer in charge of dealing with the Republic of China is expected to be in Taiwan next month for a routine visit, sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported Friday.

Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), is scheduled to pay a ten-day visit from Jan. 6-16, said Liu Chih-kung, director of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.

According to Liu, Bush will exchange views with ROC political and legislative leaders on issues of mutual concern and familiarize himself with the latest situation and affairs in Taiwan and in the Taiwan Strait.
The AIT was founded by the U.S. authorities in 1979 to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
Bush last visited Taipei in March this year to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's presidential election and in May to attend the inauguration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian.
Meanwhile, according to Liu, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is expected to visit the United States, mainly to deliver a speech, next month.

Tsai, the top ROC official in charge of the country's mainland China policy, is scheduled to arrive in San Francisco Jan. 20, where she will deliver a public speech and take part in overseas Chinese community activities to celebrate the Lunar Chinese New Year.
Liu declined to say whether Tsai will visit other U.S. cities or meet other people during her visit.

Reviewing the development of U.S.-Taiwan ties over the past year, Liu noted that a total of 26 congress people from the United States visited Taiwan in 2000, eight of whom were senators and 18 of whom were House representatives.
Liu added that a transport secretary, six governors, six deputy governors and 15 congressional groups from the U.S. administration paid visits to Taiwan during the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF HIGHER EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Friday at an annual meeting of domestic university presidents that higher education should embrace reforms that will help prepare the nation for the coming of the "knowledge economy" era.

Chen said that the success or failure of university education is a key factor that determines a nation's competitiveness. With a rapid increase in the number of domestic universities within the past decade, university education has evolved from the old notion of "education for the elite" to a more public-oriented system, he added.

Facing a highly open and competitive education market, universities should refrain from excessive expansion and malicious competition, Chen said, warning that the resulting waste in precious education resources, the drop in the quality of education, and the imbalance in manpower supply and demand could lead to negative impacts on society.

Chen went on to urge domestic universities to upgrade their adult education programs and promote courses that will allow working professionals to conveniently sharpen their collective competitive edge so as to be able to adapt to the needs of a rapidly changing economic environment.
Universities are also charged with the mission of promoting the stable development of the economy and a democratic political landscape, thereby guiding the society toward cultural progress, he added.

At the meeting, the heads of the state-funded universities issued an emergency statement urging the nation's lawmakers to refrain from cutting education items from the government budget for fiscal year 2001.

Meanwhile, Education Minister Ovid Tzeng announced that Chen has allowed the ministry to propose the addition of a special NT$10 billion (US$302 million) item to the fiscal budget for 2002 for the purpose of raising the international competitiveness of the nation's higher education system.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL HOSPITAL TO BUILD WORLD'S BIGGEST MEDICAL CENTER IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, brainchild of Taiwan business magnate Wang Yung-ching, is poised to develop three medical institutions in mainland China, with one in Beijing expected to be the largest medical center in the world.

After receiving approval from the Beijing authorities, who approved the Chang Gung project on a special-case basis, the Chang Gung administration recently decided to branch out its operations to Xiamen, Fuzhou and Beijing in an effort to bring Taiwan's medical resources and expertise to the mainland.

The Chang Gung Medical Center in Beijing will be equipped with 5,000 beds, a medical center and an affiliated nursing institute, said Chuang Yi-chou, director of the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital Management Center.

The facility, which will occupy a 148-hectare site donated by the Beijing government, will be located near the mass rapid transport system and Beijing's Olympic village and is envisaged to be the largest of its kind in the world, said Chuang.

Each of the Chang Gung Memorial hospitals in Fuzhou and Xiamen will be equipped with 3,000 beds and will cover 100 hectares. Both facilities will also have affiliated nursing institutes, according to Chuang.
Construction is expected to begin next year and to be completed in three years if all goes smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM CHANG'S `TRANSFORMATIVE CABINET' TO REFORM FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the Executive Yuan is recasting itself as a "transformative Cabinet" at the same time that industries and financial institutions are undergoing a process of transformation.

Chang, who defined his team of Cabinet ministers as a "progressive Cabinet" when he was first appointed premier in October, admitted at an end-of-the-year press conference that the so-called progressive Cabinet's efficiency has so far not been up to par.

He went on to say that the Cabinet's lackluster performance is partly due to the global economic situation and the fact that Taiwan is currently facing a key moment at the crossroads of political and economic transitions, when "old and new forces are undergoing a violent tug-of-war."

A gradual pile-up of long-standing problems and an insufficiently quick transition may also be contributing factors to the nation's current economic predicament, Chang said. However, he added that his Cabinet, being the ruling administration, will hold itself ultimately accountable for the largest share of the blame and will not evade any of its responsibilities.

In the political arena, Chang continued, Taiwan just earlier this year underwent its first peaceful transfer of power from one party to another, while the nation's industries and financial sector are also facing radical changes under the lead of a global high tech revolution.

Chang said that if Taiwan can overcome the "old" and bravely face the changes, then the future will be "full of hope," and Taiwan will be able to survive and emerge from the transitions to take the lead. However, he cautioned, if Taiwan is unable to change, then it will face the fate of being left behind.

Therefore, he added, his administration not only has to be a "progressive Cabinet," but also has to change into a team that is able to bring about successful transformations. The team must not be afraid of failure or of making mistakes during the transformative process because staying on the "right course" is the "only way to go" in the long run, Chang said.

Facing the nation's economic problems of a rising unemployment rate and a downward-spiraling stock market, Chang said that his transformative Cabinet will reform the financial system and usher in a "knowledge economy."

Chang said that his team is prepared to tackle the numerous problems facing the nation's economy today, having even worked out the possible responses in the event that a financial storm strikes Taiwan next year as some foreign financial experts have predicted.

To strengthen Taiwan's financial system, he added, the finance ministry will present a concrete proposal within two months to create a framework for the necessary consolidation of the nation's financial institutions.

The first merger will take place Jan. 1, Chang continued, beginning with the provincial government-owned Taiwan Cooperative Bank and the private ChinFon Commercial Bank. The second merger is on its way as well, he added. Taiwan currently has 53 commercial banks and some 360 credit cooperatives serving a population of 23 million.

Meanwhile, the government will also promote mergers for the nation's small- and medium-sized enterprises so that they will be better able to withstand the pressures that come with globalization, Chang said.
A law on the establishment of financial holding companies and a financial institution merger law are both in the works, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.08 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 33.079.
The local currency opened Friday at 33.136 and was traded between 33.156 and 33.078.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$429 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADMINISTRATION, LEGISLATURE SHOULD FORM ALLIANCE: PM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the relationship between the administration and the legislature should be like an alliance and that a coalition government "is also a way to express a spirit of alliance."

However, Chang added that it is up to ROC President Chen Shui-bian, who is a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) stalwart like Chang, to decide whether to attempt to form a coalition government between the DPP and the opposition alliance made up of the Kuomintang (KMT), People First Party and New Party.
Speaking at a yearend press conference, Chang said that the nation is facing an unprecedented political dilemma and added that he is grateful for the ideas put forward by many political figures.

Fundamentally, Chang continued, a coalition government would require its members to share a lot of common ground and mutual trust, otherwise, they would differ in their views on many important issues.

Chang stressed that he is not concerned with how much longer he can stay on as premier and that all he cares about is what his Cabinet does for the DPP, for history, for the people and for the nation while it is still in power at this "key turning point."

Meanwhile, he said that convening a national conference to discuss whether the Constitution should be amended is probably a more viable way to resolve the current constitutional impasse, where the minority government is headed by the DPP while the opposition alliance has the majority in the legislature.

As to how the new constitutional system should be designed and whether the current dual-headed government system should be abolished, Chang said that the solution can be discussed at the national conference.
He urged the nation's bureaucrats to maintain administrative neutrality in the meantime to help bring political stability to the country.

Regarding his administration's decision to scrap the fourth nuclear power plant project, which began under the previous KMT administration, Chang said that he will respect the interpretation of the Council of Grand Justices on whether the Cabinet's move was constitutional.

He also urged the legislature to support his Cabinet's proposed 44-hour workweek, claiming that if the previously proposed 84-hour biweekly provision goes into effect Jan. 1 as scheduled, 70 percent of the nation's industries will be adversely affected. If the industries have trouble sustaining their operations, labor will be affected as well, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR ZHONG GONG LEADERS OF CHINA SENTENCED TO PRISON TERMS

TEXT.P: Four leaders of the Zhong Gong meditation sect in eastern Jiangsu province were sentenced last month to prison terms ranging from two to four years on charges of "inciting the overthrow of state power."

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Friday that the four -- Wang Wanping, Qin Zhaoyang, Zhai Xuehai, and Long Jialan-- were among the 600 Zhong Gong leaders arrested in and after October 1999, when China began to crack down on the meditation sect as an "evil cult" and close down its 3,000 training bases and affiliated businesses.

The information center said that the four were accused by law courts of spreading two letters condemning mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin for giving orders to crack down on Zhong Gong and other spiritual sects. The letters were written under the pseudonyms of two senior police officers, it added.

Like Falun Gong, Zhong Gong has millions of followers in China. The Chinese government is worried that the spiritual movement may transform into a huge opposition party in China, the information center said. Currently, the formation of any opposition party is banned in that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR SUGGESTS ESTABLISHMENT OF SPECIAL OFFSHORE ECONOMIC ZONE

TEXT.P: A prominent Taiwan scholar suggested Friday the government establish a special offshore economic zone in order to deal with global competition.
Liu Tai-ying, president of the Taiwan Research Institute, made the suggestion during a meeting with President Chen Shui-bian earlier on Friday.

Liu said that considering the fierce global competition and the necessity for domestic economic development, Taiwan should prepare to set up a special offshore economic zone where the introduction of man power from mainland China and other countries as well as the flow of capital and merchandise will have no limitations, adding that the sooner it does the better.

He suggested that the government transform the already existent Changpin Industrial District in Changhua, southern Taiwan, into such an offshore economic zone, a move that he said would also help balance the development among the areas of Taiwan.
He continued that this special offshore economic zone could accommodate centers for research and development, manufacturing, offshore finance, telecommunications, retail shopping, and entertainment.

Liu said he thinks economic growth at home and abroad will slow down next year, adding that improving the local investment environment and the opening of the domestic market to promote foreign investment will be the government's most important task.
The scholar also suggested the government increase public investment and domestic demand to stimulate the economy and thereby reduce the escalating unemployment rate.
Liu is one of the leaders of Taiwan's four eminent economic research institutes that President Chen has met recently in order to listen to their suggestions about the domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ 65.5 BILLION TO CREATE 290,000 JOB OPPORTUNITIES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung said Friday that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.

Chang said that under the project, the government will create 62,000 additional job opportunities, set up training facilities for 100,000 workers, provide a brokerage service to help fill 100,000 job vacancies and provide employers with incentives to hire a further 23,000 job seekers.
Chang made the remarks at a yearend Cabinet press conference held at the Government Information Office.
He said that the government is greatly concerned about the escalating unemployment problem caused by the nation's industrial structural transformation.
The premier also admitted that the domestic economy has continued to decline and that daily factory closures have boosted the unemployment rate.

Chang also stressed the importance of environmental and ecological protection, saying that the government's economic construction cannot address only the short-term interests at the expense of long-term development. If Taiwan develops nuclear power plants because it needs the electricity, he went on, it will create potential danger and environmental damage.

He said Taiwan should develop alternative energy sources to large nuclear power plants and noted that industrialized developed countries have always diversified and regionalized their power supplies, which avoids the problems of power cuts caused, for example, by the toppling of an electricity pylon.
Chang said that the government plans to invest NT$455 billion in the coming four years to carry out construction of the island's sixth electricity transmission project.

Speaking on the halting of construction of the controversial fourth nuclear power plant, Chang said that the decision to halt construction was correct and that he wanted to leave the issue to be judged by history. His principal concern, he said, is "whether we can give our younger generations a clean environment."

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATORS GIVE COLD SHOULDER TO PM'S `ALLIANCE' PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Opposition lawmakers Friday gave the cold shoulder to Premier Chang Chun-hsiung's proposal for an "alliance" between the administration and the legislature and even to the idea of a coalition government.

Premier Chang at his yearend press conference earlier in the day called for the establishment of such a relationship, saying that a coalition government could also be regarded as a way of "expressing the spirit of the alliance relationship" and that he and President Chen Shui-bian were willing to join hands with the opposition parties to create a "constitutional precedent."

Legislator Liu Kuang-hua of the Kuomintang, which controls 115 of 220 seats in the Legislative Yuan, said that no such administration-legislature alliance exists in any of the world's democratic countries.
The responsibility of the Legislative Yuan is to supervise the administration, and such a relationship would be tantamount to "selling out" the public's trust in the legislature, Liu said.
He added that what the nation needs now is not a "constitutional precedent," but rather a government that follows and respects the Constitution.

Chung Shao-ho, the head of the legislative caucus of the New Party, said that Premier Chang needs not bother trying to figure out how to form such an alliance because the opposition parties will throw their weight behind him as long as his polices are in the interests of the nation and people.

Falling short of directly objecting to Chang's call, James Soong, chairman of another opposition party, the People First Party, said that the administration and legislature each have their respective roles to play.

Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who is also the Kuomintang vice chairman and who has been tipped by the news media as President Chen's top choice in heading a coalition Cabinet, said that it's too early to talk about a coalition government now and that the Kuomintang has not discussed such an idea.
Meanwhile, Wu Nai-jen, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), denied that his party has pondered the possibility of forming a coalition Cabinet.

Wu said that the nine-member policy-making panel, of which Wu himself is a member, has never mentioned the idea in any of its regular meetings. With President Chen as its head, members of the group also include Premier Chang and DPP Chairman Frank Hsieh.

DPP Legislator Lin Chuao-shui said that it will be very difficult for the Kuomintang and the DPP to form a cooperative relationship simply because they hold quite different views on many important issues.

Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, who is also executive director of the DPP's Policy Committee, said that the resignation of the present Cabinet and ensuing legislative elections are necessary before a coalition government can be formed.

Another DPP legislator, Chou Po-lun, said there will be no need for Cabinet members to resign en masse and for legislative elections as long as the Kuomintang is willing to join hands with the DPP to form the coalition government.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON C. AMERICAN TECHNICAL EDUCATION TO BE HELD IN COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: A seminar aiming at improving technical education and vocational training programs in Central American countries will be held in Heredia, Costa Rica from Jan. 29-31, 2001, it was announced in Taipei Friday.

A spokesman for the International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) said that the Republic of China would like to share its successful experiences resulting from cooperation with Costa Rica on a technical and vocational education project since January 1998.
A second stage of the project is being considered for the establishment of a technical teacher development center and a student learning achievement evaluation center, the spokesman said.

Subjects to be discussed at the seminar will include the review of different systems and approaches to vocational education and technical training in six Central American countries; Costa Rica's development experiences in vocational education and technical training; the sharing of the experience of strength and areas of different countries in these fields; and the development of future programs for cooperation.
The seminar is being jointly sponsored by the ICDF and the ROC-Central American Economic Development Fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES MACAU TO SYSTEMATIZE TAIWAN-MACAU COMMUNICATIONS CHANNEL

TEXT.P: Vice Chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chen Ming-tung on Friday called on Macau authorities to systematize a Taiwan-Macau communications channel.

Chen pointed out that although relations between Taiwan and Macau are steadily developing, Macau authorities have still not designated an official to act as a liaison with the Taiwan representative office in Macau.

He added that under the restrictions of the so-called "six-pointed instruction" by mainland Chinese Vice Premier Qian Qichen, the Macau authorities are not able to freely handle relations with Taiwan representatives, so he said it is therefore important that a communications channel be systemized.
Chen made the remarks after presiding over a meeting on Macau affairs.

Chen, who has recently visited Macau, also said that the Chen administration will deal with relations between Taiwan and Macau on in the principles of "good faith compromise, positive cooperation, and an everlasting peace" as proclaimed by President Chen in his May 20 inaugural speech.

He said he hopes that both Beijing and Macau authorities will use a broad and farsighted approach when dealing with Taiwan-Macau relations and eventually set up a direct communication channel in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MADE CELLULAR PHONE OUTPUT GROWS 500 PERCENT IN 2000

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made cellular phone production grew by 500 percent in 2000, statistics compiled by the Institute for Information Industry (III) released Friday showed.
The statistics revealed that Taiwan produced 11.4 million cellular phones with a total value of US$861 million for the year 2000, representing a 5-fold increase over the previous year's figure.
The popularity of cellular phones in Taiwan reached a level similar to Finland, Norway, and Sweden, with 70 percent of the island's population using the devices.

Western Europe and mainland China were the chief purchasers of Taiwan-made cellular phones, importing US$387 million and US$286 million worth respectively. The next largest market was the local one, with cell phone purchases totaling US$79.2 million in value, followed by Southeast Asia at US$77.5 million, and South America at US$28.8 million.
An III official estimated that the number of cellular phones users in mainland China will reach 73 million at the end of this year and top 118 million the following year.

The official also predicted that Taiwan will produce 34 million cellular phones in the year 2001, 88 million in 2002, and 150 million 2003, accounting for 6 percent, 12.3 percent, and 17.4 percent of total global production for each of those years respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOODY'S REVISES UPWARD ITS OUTLOOK FOR BANK OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Moody's Investors Service announced recently that it has revised upward its outlook for the Bank of Taiwan from the rating of "negative" to "stable".
In Moody's assessment report, the Bank of Taiwan's long-term credit rating is A1, its short-term credit rating is Prime 1, and its financial structure rating is C.
The credit rating agency in February of this year rated the Bank of Taiwan's outlook as "negative."
Officials of the Bank of Taiwan all welcomed the announcement by Moody's and said they consider it an affirmation of the bank's performance.

Teng Chen-wei, vice president of the Bank of Taiwan, stressed that despite Taiwan's declining economic prospects and slumping stock market, the Bank of Taiwan has still managed to promote its operations well, with its earnings from the second half of last year to this year expected to slightly surpass its own projections.

Teng added that although the ratio of the bank's over-due loans has been climbing slightly, it is relatively low compared to other financial institutions in Taiwan. He also estimated the ratio will begin declining from the second quarter of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUE OF TAIPEI BOURSE DOWN OVER 45 PERCENT SINCE MAY 20

TEXT.P: The value of the Taipei stock market has decreased by a significant 45.61 percent since May 20, according to statistics released Friday by the Ministry of Finance's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC).

The SFC's statistics show that the value of the Taipei stock market as of Thursday amounted to NT$9.34 trillion (US$283 billion), a decrease of NT$4.93 trillion (US$149 billion) as compared with NT$14.27 trillion (US$431.8 billion) registered on May 20.

The NT$9.34 trillion figure includes the NT$8.29 trillion in total value of all listed companies and the NT$1.05 trillion in total value of those companies whose stocks are traded on the over-the-counter market. The bourse's weighted price index closed at 4,797.14 on Thursday.

The NT$14.27 trillion value of the Taipei stock market on May 20 broke down as NT$12.14 trillion for all listed companies and NT$2.13 trillion for those companies whose stocks are traded on the over-the-counter market. The weighted price index of the bourse ended at 8,820.35 on May 20.

The SFC's figures also show that as of Dec. 29, 182 of the 531 listed companies recorded a price/earning ratio of less than 10, accounting for 34.27 percent of the total; 76 companies registered a P/E ratio of between 10 and 15, accounting for 14.31 percent; 54 companies had a P/E ratio of between 15 and 20, accounting for 10.17 percent; 67 companies had a P/E ratio of more than 20, accounting for 12.62 percent; and 152 companies had no P/E ratio, accounting for 28.63 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM PROMISES TO WORK FOR `SUNSHINE' POLITICS

TEXT.P: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung on Friday pledged that his Cabinet will try its best to create what he dubbed as "sunshine", or clean politics for the nation.

Chang, who assumed the premiership in October, said at a yearend press conference that the government will spare no efforts in continuing the ongoing drive to sweep away the so-called "black gold" -- referring to corruption and the connection between politics and organized crime.
"What we want is not only democracy, but also clean politics," he said.
To this end, Chen said that the Cabinet approved an action plan in June and inaugurated a special task force in July to vigorously crack down on black gold.
He added that the task force has so far investigated 2,200 cases involving corruption and indicted 600 suspects.

Turning to human rights protection, Chang said that the U.S.-based human rights organization, the Freedom House, in its latest report lists Taiwan as one of the Asian countries whose people enjoy the most freedom, saying this is a fair and reasonable remark and a confirmation of the government's efforts to better human rights protection.
Chang also assured the people that judicial reform will be carried out, which he said will largely increase the people's confidence in the nation's judicial system.

Responding to criticism that the Chen administration has ruled the nation based on ideology, Chang said that his Cabinet will prevent ideology from influencing policymaking and that he will ask public servants to remain neutral when performing their duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OUTLINES NEXT YEAR'S WORKING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A senior official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Friday outlined the ministry's working program for next year.

Feng Tai, executive secretary of the MOFA's Research and Planning Board, said that priorities will be given to the establishment of a diplomatic academy, completion of the legalization of the proposed foreign aid bill, the implementation of a public opinion survey on the ministry's work, the establishment of an evaluation system for missions stationed in foreign countries, and on the regional meeting of diplomatic missions abroad.
As to the designation of the ambassador-at-large, the MOFA has already submitted the list of candidates to President Chen Shui-bian for final decision.
Concerning the establishment of a diplomatic academy, Feng said that the Cabinet has already granted consent to the project and that the next step is to seek support from the Legislative Yuan.
Those who will be able to receive training at the proposed diplomatic academy will include diplomats, congressional aides, public functionaries, civic leaders, and non-governmental organizations.
The MOFA also plans to send them to observe the diplomatic training organizations in Japan, the United States, and Europe, Feng said.
As to the foreign aid bill, the MOFA will consult with legislators from various political parties to seek their support for the bill, Feng said.

Speaking on the evaluation system for diplomatic missions abroad, he said the ministry will send officials to make field inspections of diplomatic missions stationed in foreign countries so as to set up a fair and objective evaluation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 67% OF TAIWAN FIRMS THINK LOCAL FINANCIAL CRISIS IS POSSIBLE

TEXT.P: About 67 percent of Taiwan enterprises think it is possible that Taiwan will face a domestic financial crisis, according to a survey conducted by the monthly magazine Global Views.

The survey shows that 57 percent of the enterprises that see a domestic financial crisis as possible even think that the crisis will break out in the first half of next year, while 38 percent of them said they think early next year is too soon for a crisis to occur.
Certain enterprises surveyed even said they think that the domestic financial crisis has already unfolded.

Of all the entrepreneurs interviewed, 41.6 percent said they think their most important task is to become more international, 33.2 percent said they see reconstruction of their enterprises as the top necessity, and 32.6 percent said they think they have to diversify their operations.

Of those surveyed who said they need to become more international, 72.8 percent said they have already invested or are planning to invest in mainland China, with most of these respondents being in the electronics or information industries.
Global Views conducted the survey between Dec. 5-8, randomly selecting 526 domestic companies. A total of 190 valid copies were received.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 30, or the fifth day of the 12th month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1884: Hideki Tojo, Japanese army official and politician, is born as Tojo Eiki. He governed Japan's progress through World War II and was later executed as a war criminal.
1887: Britain's Queen Victoria receives a unique celebration of her Jubilee year from the women of England -- a petition signed by 1,132,608 women in favor of the Sunday closing of English public houses and the banning of sales of intoxicating liquor on the Lord's Day.
1903: A raging fire breaks out in the Iroquois Theater in Chicago during a performance, killing 578 people.
1918: Dr. Sun Yat-sen finishes his book titled "The Tenets of Sun Yat-sen" and writes a preface to explain the philosophical principle that "it is easier to do something than to understand why."
1922: Russia is renamed the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, or the USSR.
1925: Hsu Soo-cheng, special envoy of the Peiyang government, is arrested and killed by troops loyal to Feng Yu-siang at the Langfang railway station in mainland China's Hopei Province.
1927: The first section of the Tokyo subway between the districts of Ueno and Asakusa is opened to traffic.
1929: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs proclaims the nullification of consular jurisdiction in China to rid China of foreign privileges.
1939: Wang Ching-wei, who on Dec. 29, 1938 called for a suspension of China's war of resistance against Japan and for peace negotiations with the country, signs a secret agreement with Japan.
1940: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt indicates during a "fireside" address to the American people that the United States will provide military aid to China.
1944: Romain Rolland, the French writer who won the 1915 Nobel Prize for literature, dies at the age of 78.
1946: The Chinese communists use the "Shen Chung incident" to incite students in Beijing to launch an anti-U.S. campaign.
1947: Romanian communists under the protection of Soviet troops force King Michael to give up his throne and declare Romania an "independent people's democracy."
1949: The Republic of China announces severance of diplomatic relations with India.
1965: Ferdinand E. Marcos becomes president of the Philippines.
1966: The ROC and Botswana establish diplomatic relations.
1968: Trygve Lie, Norwegian politician and the first secretary-general of the United Nations, dies at the age of 72.
1975: The United States Little League Baseball allows teams from foreign countries to take part in its world series competition.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan receives Ahmad Mohammed Mahmoud, editor of the Arab News in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia.
1979: Richard Rodgers, the American composer known for his musical comedies, especially his collaborations with Oscar Hammerstein II, including "Oklahoma," "South Pacific," and "The Sound of Music," dies in New York City at the age of 77.
1988: Colonel Oliver North subpoenas President Ronald Reagan and President-elect George Bush to testify in the Iran-Contra trial.
1993: Israel signs a mutual recognition treaty with the Vatican, ending nearly 2,000 years of antagonism between the Orthodox Jews and the Roman Catholics.
1997: South Africa establishes diplomatic ties with mainland China. The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs would formally severe diplomatic relations with South Africa the next day.
1999: The Republic of China and the Republic of Palau forge full diplomatic relations.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man without moral character cannot long put up with adversity, nor can he long enjoy prosperity. Men of moral character find themselves at home in being moral; men of intelligence find it advantageous to be moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 4.85 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Saturday, with the benchmark weighted price index moving down 4.85 points to close at 4,739.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$33.09 billion (US$1 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 4.85 points to close at 4,739.09.
The bourse opened at 4,687.95 and fluctuated between 4,793.24 and 4,670.39 during trading.

A total of 1.41 billion stocks worth NT$33.09 billion (US$1 billion) changed hands, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 1.47 billion shares traded on a market turnover of NT$43.08 billion (US$1.3 billion).
Only one of the eight major categories posted losses, with electrical stocks moving down 1.5 percent.

The other major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile issues and cement stocks, both at 1.9 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.7 percent, and foodstuff shares and construction stocks, both at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 309 to 192, with 86 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were higher Saturday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index futures for next January moved up 63 points to close at 4,770, with 10,126 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for February 2001 increased 27 points to finish at 4,735, with 72 contract transactions, while March 2001 futures gained 90 points to close at 4,838, with three contract transactions.
June 2001 futures rose 180 points to finish at 4,748, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Saturday at 4,707 for next January, 4,708 for next February, 4,748 for next March, 4,568 for next June, and 4,803 for next September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.
January 2001 TE futures moved down 0.95 points to close at 220, with 2,640 contracts changing hands, while February 2001 TE futures lost 5.7 points to finish at 217, with 11 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
January 2001 TF futures increased 22.8 points to close at 669.8, with 2,431 contract transactions, while February 2001 TF futures rose 30 points to finish at 672, with 18 contracts traded.
March 2001 TF futures moved up 20.6 points to close at 669, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT STRESSES ECONOMIC REVIVAL IS GOVERNMENT'S FOCUS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday at a breakfast meeting with the nation's industry leaders that the government's current focus is on economic revival through both short- and long-term means.

As the nation faces an exodus of local industries, a rising unemployment rate, and a dismal stock market whose total capitalization is down by over 45 percent since May, Chen told the 16 industry heavyweights attending the meeting that now is not a time for political bickering between the ruling and opposition parties, nor a time for "artificially provoked" management-labor confrontations.

"The country belongs to everyone, and the economy is even more nonpartisan," he said, adding that he will place the elimination of obstacles stemming from "non-economic factors" as his personal top priority.

He went on to urge the industry leaders to use their influence and take on the role of serving as "bridges of communication" to assist him in resolving the differences between his Democratic Progressive Party minority government and the opposition alliance of the Kuomintang, People First Party, and New Party.

From the government's point of view, Chen continued, to revitalize the economy for the sake of responding to the impact brought about by globalization and by the trend toward a "knowledge economy" requires a two-pronged course of action that includes short-term market-stimulating measures and long-term market-bolstering policies.

He added that although long-term measures will be beneficial to the economy as a whole, they might have certain adverse effects on particular individual companies or industries. Moreover, it will take time for the effects of the policies to become evident, he said.

Whether a corporation itself has sufficient capability to adjust and adapt is the key factor to resolving operational difficulties, Chen said, encouraging the business leaders to embrace new concepts, new attitudes, and new methods to enhance their companies' adaptability based on existing fundamentals.

Government officials attending the meeting included Vice Premier Lai In-jaw, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang, Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi, Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chen Po-chih, and Central Bank of China Governor Perng Fai-nan.

Industry participants included Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce Chairman Jeffrey Koo, who initiated the meeting; the heads of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, and the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. Chairman Morris Chang; and Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih.

DOC.HEADLINE: `92 CONSENSUS' SHOULD BE BASIS FOR `DIRECT LINKS' TALKS: KMT LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's party whip on Saturday called for authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to discuss direct trade, mail, and shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China based on the "1992 consensus."

Legislator Ho Chih-hui, who is scheduled to lead a KMT legislative delegation to visit mainland China Jan. 4-11 to exchange views with mainland leaders on the issue of "three direct links" across the Taiwan Strait, said negotiators from the two sides should use the "one China, disparate definition" consensus reached in 1992 to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue on technical affairs, with political issues being temporarily shelved.

Ho said the KMT delegation's top goals on this trip are to sound out how mainland China has prepared itself for the much-talked about "three direct links" and also to offer the Beijing authorities some substantive suggestions on that concern.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen visited the KMT party caucus in the Legislative Yuan Saturday to brief the KMT lawmakers on the latest government policies concerning the "three direct links" and to offer tips on related affairs.

Ho, meanwhile, said he and his group will propose to Beijing authorities that mainland China open more important ports to Taiwan shipping and related services so as to meet Taiwan business people's expectations and the long-term interests of both sides of the strait.
The KMT group will be comprised of some 40 legislators and specialists from several of the party's think-tanks, including Kao Kung-lian, former vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC.

The KMT legislators and specialists, at the invitation of mainland China's intermediary body with Taiwan, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, are expected to visit Beijing first to meet mainland Chinese leaders on matters pertaining to the "direct three links" initiative.

Group members are also expected to meet with officials from mainland China's ministries of transportation, foreign trade, postal affairs, and civil aviation for talks on technical issues related to the direct links.
Following their Beijing visit, the KMT group will visit mainland China's leading port cities of Shanghai, Tianjin, Qingdao, and Fuzhou on fact-finding tours.

According to Ho, KMT Chairman Lien Chan said he fully supports the forthcoming visit to mainland China by KMT lawmakers and experts, noting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume negotiations as early as possible. He added that as the major opposition party, the KMT should do what it can in this respect as the ruling Democratic Progressive Party has been unable to.

Beijing has invited the KMT group to the mainland for talks on the "big three links" while evidently giving the cold shoulder to the DPP-initiated "mini three links," referring to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the Republic of China's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Fujian port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MUSEUMS POST SUSPECTED STOLEN ART WORKS ON WEB

TEXT.P: Two of Canada's most prominent art galleries have posted more than 120 of their collections' works of art that are suspected of having been stolen from their original owners by Nazis during World War II on the Internet.

The National Gallery in Ottawa and the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto put images of the art online so that people from around the world, especially European Jews and their descendants, can examine and possibly claim the works.

Pierre Theberge, director of the National Gallery, said that not all the art on the list was necessarily stolen, adding that part of the reason for displaying the works on the Internet is that the museum needs more information on the ownership history of the pieces.
There are gaps in each of the posted paintings and sculptures' history between 1933 and 1945 when the Nazis were in power in Germany.

Works listed on the Internet by the two galleries include the French painter Edgar Degas' "Woman at Her Bath," Edouard Vuillard's painting "Madame Aron," Spanish painter Jusepe Leonardo's "St. John the Baptist," and "Bouquet of Flowers" by Jan Breughel the Elder.

The move by the galleries is part of a growing trend among institutions around the world to re-examine their collections and attempt to return stolen art to their original owners or their descendants.

Last year, the Montreal Museum of Fine Art returned the oil painting "Marriage Feast at Cana" by Italian master Giorgio Vasari to the government of Hungary. The painting was said to have been stolen by Canadian soldiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.087 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at 32.992.
The local currency opened at 33.055 and was traded between 32.992 and 33.075.
Interbank U.S. dollar trading totaled US$296 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN-XIAMEN ICE-BREAKING VISIT WILL BE SMOOTH: KINMEN COUNTY CHIEF

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai said Saturday he will head a large delegation, composed of Kinmen social elite, to make a direct voyage to mainland China's Xiamen port Jan. 2.

"It will be an ice-breaking visit after more than 50 years of separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chen told a group of journalists from Taiwan to cover the Jan. 1 opening of the direct "mini three links."
Chen said the delegation was originally scheduled to make direct sail to Xiamen Jan. 1, but changed its departure date to Jan. 2 at the request of its mainland host.

As Beijing still refuses to resume dialogue with Taiwan and gives a lukewarm response to the Taiwan-initiated "mini three links," Chen said, the Kinmen County Government is under heavy pressure in preparing for the new opening measure.

Chen said he has sent special envoys to consult with Xiamen officials on the mini three links-related issues. "My observation is that our planned Kinmen-Xiamen visit would proceed smoothly and no further changes to the itinerary are expected," he said optimistically.

In line with the Offshore Islands Development Act passed by the legislature earlier this year, the Republic of China government is scheduled Jan. 1 to formally open direct trade, mail and shipping links between its defense outposts of Kinmen and Matsu, and mainland China's Xiamen and Fuzhou ports, commonly known as the "mini three links," on a trial basis for one year.

Noting that the opening of the "mini three links" offers a new opportunity for Taipei and Beijing governments to deal with bilateral relations, Chen said the Kinmen delegation will show its greatest sincerity and goodwill toward the mainland during its historic visit.

"We looks forward to starting constructive interaction with the mainland," Chen said, adding that if necessary, he will ask the Xiamen officials to convey to Beijing authorities Taiwan's goodwill and friendship toward the mainland.

Chen said the upcoming Kinmen-Xiamen direct voyage is of great significance. Both Kinmen and Xiamen were under the jurisdiction of the Fujian government before the split of China into two parts in the 1940s civil war. Kinmen, which lies far closer to the mainland than to Taiwan, is now the ROC's frontline with mainland China.
In view of their geographical proximity and close blood ties, Chen said he hopes Kinmen and Xiamen will develop an even closer relationship following the opening of the "min three links."
Chen further said he hopes that the "mini three links" will help usher in a new chapter in cross-strait rapprochement in the new year.
