DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SUPPORT `MINI THREE LINKS'

TEXT.P: Two New Party heavyweights in an open letter urged Beijing Saturday to support Taiwan's "mini three links" initiative so as to help bolster trade and civil exchanges between mainland China and Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

On the eve of the kickoff of the "mini three links" on Jan. 1, 2001, Tsai Yuan-chang and Wu Cheng-tian, both former New Party deputies to the National Assembly, quoted ancient Chinese strategists by writing that "united, we prosper; divided, we suffer."
"Both sides of the Taiwan Strait should endeavor to allow Kinmen and Matsu to become a bridge of peace connecting the two rivals of mainland China and Taiwan," the letter said.

The soon to be implemented "mini three links" refer to direct trade, mail, and shipping links between the Republic of China's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China's Fujian port cities of Xiamen and Fuzhou.

Tsai and Wu called for the mainland Chinese authorities to allow for at least 700 mainlanders to visit Kinmen each day and 100 to visit Matsu so as to help revitalize economic development in the two ROC-control offshore counties and bolster civilian exchanges as well.

Meanwhile, in another open letter to President Chen Shui-bian's government, Tsai and Wu urged that the content of the "mini three links" be extended to be applicable to other related groups of people based on humanitarian principles.

The groups of people they were referring to include Taiwan relatives of Kinmen and Matsu residents, the some 6,000 Taiwanese families currently living in mainland China's Fujian Province, mainland Chinese brides who are married to Taiwan citizens, and elderly military veterans who came to Taiwan with the ROC armed forces after 1949 when the ROC government moved its seat from the mainland to Taiwan.

They said they will soon launch signature campaigns in Kinmen and Matsu to promote the ideas mentioned above so as to let the voices of the residents of Kinmen and Matsu be heard by authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELIGIOUS GROUPS CRY OUT AGAINST CASINOS ON KINMEN, MATSU

TEXT.P: Religious activist groups voiced strong opposition Saturday against the government's plan to consider establishing casinos on Kinmen and Matsu as one way of propping up the economies of the frontline islands.

In a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan, representatives from the Buddhist Care Life Association, the Presbyterian Church in Taipei, and the Bethlehem Mission Society in Taitung rallied against the idea of government-sponsored gambling.

The press conference was called with the assistance of Kuomintang Legislator Chen Hung-chi after the religious groups learned that Lin Chia-cheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development, and Evaluation Commission, suggested that the government consider and assess the possibility of establishing casinos on Kinmen and Matsu to help boost tourism and economic development in the offshore counties.

Kinmen and Matsu have been designated as the first two areas of Taiwan to begin direct trade, mail, and shipping exchanges with mainland China's Fujian Province in the so-called "mini three links" initiative.
Describing Lin's suggestion as irresponsible, Master Chao Hui from the Care Life Association said gambling can only bring about destruction and cause people to be reduced to ruin.
A responsible government should never be so financially shortsighted as to adopt policies that have the affect of pushing people into the abyss of suffering, she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES PLANE TO KENYA FOR WILDLIFE PROTECTION

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Saturday it has donated an additional plane to Kenya to help facilitate the East African country's wildlife conservation drive.
The anti-wildlife poaching airplane, dubbed Piper Super Cub, was presented to Kenya in a ceremony held at Israel's Herzliya Airport in suburban Tel Aviv Saturday, COA officials said.

Dr. Bill Clark, head of the Israel's Wildlife Conservation Bureau's Law Enforcement Division, presided over an inaugural ceremony for the plane. Republic of China Representative to Israel Yang Jung-tsao and a senior official from the Kenya Embassy in Israel also attended the ceremony.

According to COA officials, the single-engine, seven-meter-long plane can fly up to eight hours on a full tank and is suitable for low-altitude flights. "We believe that the plane will be very helpful to thwart poaching of endangered animal species," said a COA official.

The COA has donated anti-wildlife poaching planes to several African countries, including Ghana, Chad and Kenya, in the past few years to signify the ROC's determination to assist African countries in protecting endangered wild beasts. "Our efforts have received recognition from major international wildlife conservation organizations," the official said.
In order to further assist Kenya's 26 safari parks in their wild animals protection work, the COA recently decided to donate an additional anti-poaching plane to the East African country.

Speaking at the donation ceremony, Dr. Clark lauded the ROC for its generous donation for wildlife conservation purposes. He also recognized the ROC's conservation efforts, saying that the ROC is one of the few countries in the world that have strictly enforced its conservation law.

For his part, ROC Representative Yang Jung-tsao said the ROC is more than willing to cooperate with other countries in protecting wildlife and natural ecology based on its conviction: "We have only one planet."

Yang expressed regret over the ROC's exclusion from many international organizations simply because of Beijing's opposition. "It is unfair to both the ROC and those international organizations that need the ROC's participation and contribution," he decried.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS TAINAN COUNTY CHIEF WITH HIGHEST MARKS FOR PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: The results of a new public opinion poll announced Saturday gave Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tan-sun the highest score for administrative performance among the 23 county and city chiefs in the nation.

At a time when the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung have recently begun the third year of their four-year terms and the county magistrates and city mayors elsewhere in the nation are approaching the fourth and final year of their current terms, the public's rating of these local government leaders has been receiving much attention, particularly as the next set of legislative, county, and municipal elections are only a year away.

Chen, a member of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), received an average score of 74 out of 100 for his performance, while Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart, ranked second among city and county leaders around the nation with a score of 69.

Penghu County Magistrate Lai Feng-wei, a KMT member who administers the Penghu islands located strategically midway between Taiwan-proper and mainland China, received a score of 68 from the survey respondents in his constituency.
Pingtung county chief Su Jia-quan of the DPP received a score of 67, while Yunlin county chief Chang Jong-wei, an independent, received 66, placing him fifth overall.

Tainan City Mayor George T.H. Chang, a DPP member, received the lowest score of 47 out of 100, followed by Nantou county chief Pang Pai-hsien, an independent, with the second lowest score at 54, and Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank C.T. Hsieh, who serves concurrently as the DPP chairman, at 56 out of 100.
Kaohsiung county chief Yu Cheng-hsien of the DPP and Chiayi county chief Lee Ya-ching both received a just-passing grade of 60 out of 100.

Chen Wen-chun, director of National Sun Yat-sen University's Institute of Political Science, said that the Tainan mayor and the Nantou county chief received low marks mainly because they are both in the middle of lawsuits that have had a negative effect on their images.

As for the Kaohsiung mayor, Chen continued, not only has Hsieh been unable to effectively carry out his administrative policies, he has also given his constituents the feeling that he is only a sort of absentee mayor because he is also serving as a party chairman.

Wu Tung-yeh, director of the European/American Department of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University, said that the poll numbers will become increasingly complicated as the next election approaches.

He went on to say that although the DPP now controls the central administration, it is still a minority government. With the lackluster performance of several DPP county chiefs and mayors, he predicted that the DPP will place its emphasis on the legislative elections next December.

However, Wu said that the poor performance ratings of the DPP local government officials will also adversely affect the DPP's chances in the legislative elections because when a nation's overall economy is doing poorly, it is usually the ruling administration that is at a disadvantage.

The cooperation mechanism between the opposition alliance of the KMT, People First Party, and New Party will also influence the interaction among the county, mayoral, and legislative aspects of next year's election, he added.

The opinion poll was based on 16,549 effective samples collected from adult men and women over the age of 20 from around the country between Nov. 8 and Dec. 9. The margin of error is calculated at plus or minus 2.8 percent for Taipei City, plus or minus 2.9 percent for Kaohsiung City, plus or minus 2.3 percent for Taipei County, and plus or minus 4.0 for the other counties and cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR FURTHER MILITARY UPGRADING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the military Saturday to further upgrade its information warfare capability and develop an integrated combined services command and control system.
Chen made the call in a speech delivered at a senior military officers promotion ceremony.

Chen said the Republic of China armed forces have made remarkable progress in mobility, combat operations and command/communication capabilities over the past year as a result of internal restructuring and commissioning of a new generation of weaponry systems.

Noting that the military is now moving closer to the ROC's ultimate goal of establishing an elite deterrent force, Chen said the military should continue beefing up its information warfare capability and develop a comprehensive combined services command and control system based on its current achievements.

Chen also encouraged the military to devote even more efforts to manpower training and cultivation, pool resources with the private sector to upgrade defense technology and consolidate combat capabilities of the three branches.
"We must continue our efforts to build up a modernized elite deterrent force in the face of mainland China's persistent military threat," Chen added.

During Saturday's ceremony, a total of 10 military officers were promoted to the ranks of lieutenant general or vice admiral, and 39 others to the ranks of major general or rear admiral. The ceremony was presided over by Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNING OFFICE FOR FIRST TAIWAN ASSET MANAGEMENT COMPANY ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang on Saturday announced the establishment of a preparatory office for the nation's first asset management company (AMC).

Yen made the announcement after calling together a group of domestic banking industry leaders, including International Commercial Bank of China Chairman Lee Yung-san, who serves concurrently as chairman of the Bankers Association of the Republic of China.

Also present for the meeting were First Commercial Bank Chairman Chen Chien-lung, Hua Nan Commercial Bank Chairman Edward H.T. Chien, Chang Hwa Bank Chairman Chang Po-hsin, and International Bills Finance Corp. Chairman Lin Hua-teh.

Since the recent passage of a financial institution merger law creating a framework for a much-needed consolidation of the country's 53 banks, the Finance Ministry has been actively pushing for the establishment of an AMC to further reform the financial system through the buying and selling of problem loans.

Lee said at a press conference held in the Finance Ministry that a total of 33 domestic banks have already expressed interest in investing in the AMC, adding that he hopes foreign companies and non-financial organizations will participate in the venture as well.

According to Lee, the AMC, temporarily named Taiwan Asset Management Company, will aim for a capitalization of NT$15 billion (US$455 million) and will raise additional funds from the capital market in order to tackle the formidable amount of problematic loans in the financial market, to assist poorly managed banks to operate normally, and to allow the financial industry to continue developing steadily.

Lee went on to say that a total of 13 to 14 domestic banks have expressed interest in forming a financial asset service company to serve as an alternative channel for banks to dispose of non-performing loans (NPLs) other than through court auctions. A percentage of the stocks will be reserved for foreign investors, he added.

According to official government figures, Taiwan's NPLs are currently at about 5.6 percent of the gross domestic product. Foreign analysts have estimated that the NPL ratio may be as high as 15 percent.

Lee urged the government to establish an asset management agency similar to the U.S. Resolution Trust Corporation (RTC), which from 1989 to 1996 administered federal savings and loan institutions that went insolvent between 1989 and 1992 by either bailing them out or merging them.
Yen responded by saying that his ministry will carefully consider all its options.

Meanwhile, at another press conference, Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Chairman Lee Chung-ying announced that the 54.4 percent drop in the value of the bourse over the course of the year can only be described as "painful."
The TAIEX weighted index closed at 4,739.09 Saturday, down from 10,393 at the beginning of the year.

Lee attributed the tremendous losses -- amounting to NT$3.6 trillion (US$109 billion) in market capitalization -- to a variety of factors, including the Asian financial crisis three years ago, last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake that caused an imbalance in the supply and demand of traditional industries, higher international crude oil prices, and a lackluster year for high tech products around the globe.
He went on to say that although 80 companies entered the market with initial public offerings (IPOs) last year, the total value of the bourse still shrunk dramatically.

Giving his predictions on how the stock market will fare in the coming year, Lee said that the TAIEX is in for even more upheavals, particularly because it will become even more liberalized after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization.

However, with sound economic fundamentals, including continued two-digit growth in import and export trading and an estimated 5 percent economic growth rate, he expressed confidence that foreign investors will continue to invest in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER SPELLS OUT STRATEGY FOR FUTURE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi said Saturday that expanding cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations will be among the priority tasks of the government's economic policy next year.
Speaking at a yearend press conference, Lin said that economic and trade relations between Taiwan and mainland China in the future will become a competitive and complementary situation.
He said that the government's plan to relax its "go slow, be patient" policy in dealing with mainland China will be announced next week instead of at the end of this month as originally scheduled.

Lin said that the basic principle for relaxing the policy is to open more items for cross-strait exchange while keeping strategic technology in Taiwan and enforcing the monitoring of the risk of capital flows.
At present, Taiwan enjoys a trade surplus with mainland China, while the volume of the island's bilateral trade with the mainland accounts for 18 percent of its total foreign trade.

Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruey-long said on the same occasion that after Taiwan and mainland China enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) next year, Taiwan businessmen will be in a more advantageous position to enter the mainland market.
In order to encourage Taiwan businessmen to expand their sales in mainland China, Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Wu Wen-ya said that the board may consider implementing incentives.

At the press conference, Lin also pointed out that the priority tasks for his ministry next year will also include working out a set of new-century industrial policies, pushing forward important construction projects, improving the local investment environment, and acting to cope with the possible impacts caused by Taiwan's entry into the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN TO OFFER NEW CROSS-STRAIT POLICY INITIATIVES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is expected to offer new initiatives concerning the government policy on mainland China-bound investments in his New Year message, Vice Premier Lai Ing-jaw said Saturday.
Lai made the remarks in response to an appeal by UNI-President Enterprises Corp. Chairman Kao Ching-yuan that the government should ease its "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland investments.
Speaking at a breakfast meeting between government officials and senior business executives, Kao said mainland China-bound investment is an irresistible trend.
Against this background, Kao said, the government should assist local companies in securing business opportunities and resolving problems arising from their mainland investment activities.
"We hope the government can ease restrictions on mainland investments and take effective measures to help local industries stay competitive and expand their global market shares," Kao urged.

In reply, Lai said relevant government agencies have completed an overall review of the "no haste, be patient" policy and that President Chen will announce major adjustments to the policy in his New Year message.

The breakfast meeting was organized by Jeffrey Koo, president of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, and attended by senior financial and economic officials as well as 16 business and industry heavyweights. President Chen delivered a keynote speech at the meeting, reaffirming his determination to improve the domestic investment climate and revitalize the sluggish local economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RELEASE DISSIDENT JIANG QISHENG FROM PRISON

TEXT.P: More than 40 veteran Chinese dissidents living overseas in exile jointly made a statement Saturday, urging the mainland Chinese government to release Jiang Qisheng and other political prisoners, a human rights group in Hong Kong said.

The Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said Saturday that Wang Dan, Wu'er Kaixi, Chai Ling, and more than 30 other leaders of the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement also urged the international community to press Beijing to respect human rights and release the political prisoners as soon as possible.

The information center said Jiang, also a student leader of the 1989 movement, was arrested in June, 1999 soon after he released an article calling for an vindication of the student-led movement, and was sentenced on Dec. 27 to four years in prison on "subversion" charges. The statement said Jiang's sentence was too harsh.
The movement led to a bloody military crackdown on the pro-democracy protests on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in June 1989, killing hundreds, if not thousands, of the protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
TAIWAN BRINGS IN NEW YEAR WITH SEVERAL IMPORTANT NEW MEASURES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is bringing in the new year with several new measures that will have a relatively large impact on the citizens of the island.

Notable among them are the five-day work week for government employees, the 84-hour bi-weekly work week for the island's laborers, and the launch of direct shipping, trade, and postal links between Taiwan's two frontline islands and selected ports in mainland China, all measures which take affect on the first day of the new year.

Gearing up for the shorter work week for government employees, the administration has instructed its agencies to reorganize their staff to work in shifts in order to ensure that vital government services are not disrupted.

Members of the armed forces, coast guard, police forces, along with transportation crews, firefighters, medical workers, customs workers, garbage collectors, morgue workers, quarantine workers, and social workers, are among those who have to provide service year-round without interruption.

Local governments that oversee motor vehicle inspection, residency registration, and real estate registration were ordered to extend their business hours to 8:00 p.m. between Monday and Friday and to eliminate their usual lunch break.
Meanwhile, the shortening of the work week for government employees prompted a reduction in the maximum number of work hours per week for the island's laborers.

Although the 84-hour per two week work plan was finally settled upon after the government's last-ditch effort to extend it by two hours per week was scuttled in the Legislative Yuan on Dec. 29, most firms remain uncertain about how to cope with the new shortened workweek.
Many firms which face fierce competition from abroad are seeking agreement with their workers to extend the maximum number of work hours per week in order to maintain their competitiveness.

Meanwhile, the implementation of direct shipping, trade, and postal links between Kinmen and Matzu and selected mainland Chinese ports in Fujian, commonly referred to as the "mini three links," represents a possible advancement in the stalled relationship between Taipei and Beijing.
Taipei authorities have expressed the hope that the goodwill gesture to legalize the already thriving illicit small trade will prompt Beijing to respond in kind and resume cross-strait dialogue.

Although Beijing has tried to play down the first legal direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in five decades, Taipei is set to open them with the full glare of publicity in order to let it be known that it is doing its best to warm cross-strait relations.
Beijing has suspended all contacts with Taipei since 1999 when then Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui characterized the island's ties with Beijing as a special state-to-state relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 50% BELIEVE `MINI THREE LINKS' WILL HELP CROSS-STRAIT TIES: POLL

TEXT.P: On the eve of the implementation of the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait, the result of a public poll released Sunday showed that over 50 percent of the public believes it will help the positive development of cross-strait relations.

The poll, a year-end assessment and overview of mainland policy and cross-strait relations conducted by the Central Policy Coordination Committee of the Kuomintang, also showed that 31 percent of those interviewed feel the links will not be helpful in improving cross-strait ties.

The term "mini three links" refers to the direct trade, shipping, and postal links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matzu and selected ports in mainland China's Fujian province set to go into effect Jan. 1.
On the current pace of the development of cross-strait relations, 46 percent of those surveyed said the pace has tended to be "slow," in contrast with 28 percent who said the pace is "fast."
On the comparison of the overall development of cross-strait relations between this year and last, 39 percent said this year was worse, while 29 percent said it was the same as last year.

On the question of who should take the most blame for the currently stalled cross-strait relations, 56 percent said both Taiwan and mainland China should take the blame, 22 percent said the mainland should take the most blame, and 14 percent said Taiwan should take the most blame.

One noteworthy finding of the poll was that 45 percent of the respondents said they favor maintaining the status quo and moving toward unification in the future, 27 percent favor maintaining the status quo while saying any decision on the future hinges on the development of cross-strait relations, and nearly 13 percent favor maintaining the status quo and moving toward independence in the future.
Some 58 percent also said that the government should return to the "1992 consensus" on "one China, separate interpretations," while 14 percent said the government should not.

Meanwhile, 34 percent of respondents said they are pessimistic about the overall development of cross-strait relations next year, while 28 percent said they are optimistic. Also, 49 percent said they have no confidence in the government's ability to handle a cross-strait crisis next year, while 41 percent said they have confidence.

Just over 55 percent of the respondents said they favor the government's plan to open Taiwan to investments by mainland capital, and 63 percent of those polled said they favor opening the island to mainland tourists.
Some 46 percent of the people said that it is necessary to ease the "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in the mainland, while 25 percent said that it is "not necessary."
The poll of Taiwan citizens was conducted by telephone between Dec. 24-25, with 1,096 people islandwide being surveyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS CONDUCIVE TO SMOOTH RUNNING OF `MINI 3 LINKS': MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will be conducive to the smooth operation of the "mini three links," Taiwan's top planner of policies toward mainland China said Sunday.

Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks on the eve of the debut of Taiwan's so-called "mini three links" -- direct trade, transport, and postal links between its frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Fuzhou and Xiamen in Fujian province.
Tsai arrived in Kinmen on Saturday to inspect the preparations for the implementation of the "mini three links."

In addition to the smooth operation of the "mini three links," cross-strait negotiations on the issue will also be conducive to expanding the scope of discussions to include the subject of direct cross-strait links between the mainland and Taiwan proper, Tsai said.

Accompanied by MAC Vice Chairmen Chen Ming-tung and Teng Chen-chung, Tsai met at breakfast with Lt. Gen. Hsueh Shih-min, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, for discussions on the maintenance of security in the Kinmen area after the implementation of the "mini three links."
Meanwhile, Tsai welcomed Beijing's consenting to allow members of Taiwan's press in Beijing to proceed to Xiamen to cover stories concerning the implementation of the "mini three links."
She added that she hopes Beijing will adopt a more open-minded attitude to talk with Taipei on the issue of the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF PRO-REUNIFICATION PEOPLE INCREASING: KMT POLL

TEXT.P: The number of people who favor reunification with mainland China immediately or in the future is increasing, the results of a poll released by the opposition Kuomintang Sunday showed.

The year-end review of the government's policy toward Beijing and the ties between the two sides of Taiwan Straits, authored by the Kuomintang's Central Policy Coordination Committee, suggested that the hope by many Taiwan citizens that mainland China's booming economy will rub off on the island may be one of the reasons behind the surge in the pro-reunion camp.

Chen Yi-chuan, a professor at the Chinese Culture University, said at a press conference called to release the survey that Taiwan's closer exchanges with mainland China in recent years might also have contributed to the shift in public opinion by providing Taiwan citizens with a closer view of mainland China's development and thereby helping them shed their stereotypical views of the Chinese Communist regime.

Chen also pointed out that the Kuomintang's survey also found that the number of people in Taiwan who favor easing restrictions on trade with and investment in mainland China outnumber by more than 20 percent those who are opposed to it.
And an overwhelming number of respondents said the government's policy toward Beijing should be reviewed, indicating their strong disapproval of the current policy, said Chen.

Cheng An-kuo, who was the island's former representative to Hong Kong between 1995-1999, said at the press conference that most of the people surveyed said they favor the Kuomintang's call for the government to pick up again the 1992 consensus of "one China, separate interpretations" reached between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The Kuomintang's stance is nothing else than that of the predecessor government and represents mainstream public opinion on the island, Cheng said.
It is an approach acceptable to Beijing and thereby the only way to restart the stalled cross-strait dialogue, he added.

Wang Tan-ping, executive secretary of the Central Policy Coordination Committee, said that the survey revealed the existence of a prevailing sense of disappointment among the public with the development of ties with Beijing, the government's handling of mainland Chinese affairs, and the performance of the Straits Exchange Foundation, an organization charged with contacts with Beijing.

Tang Kuo-hsian, an official with the committee, criticized the government's policy toward mainland China, saying it "has gotten nowhere" because the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is deeply divided on its approach toward Beijing.
Tang's criticism was made one day after several DPP legislators pleaded with President Chen Shui-bian to commit himself to the 1992 consensus.
President Chen has denied that there is any such consensus and has branded reunion with mainland China as "one of the island's options".

DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung prodded Chen to convert the National Unification Council (NUC), which was set up by the predecessor government in 1990 to highlight the island's dedication to national unification, into an advisory council on national unification and also to assume its chairmanship.
DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung echoed Shen's calls by urging President Chen to reshuffle the council to better mirror the island's political spectrum.

Citing Chen's predecessor as an example, Lee Wen-chung said former President Lee Teng-hui has never been shy about his "pro-independence stance" despite the fact that he was the chairman of the NUC, pointing out that Chen could do the same.

Another DPP legislator, Yu Cheng-tao, said that on the eve of the new year, Chen should grab the opportunity by reconfirming in his new year message the 1992 consensus in order to get talks with Beijing back on track.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEASURES ADOPTED TO DEAL WITH MINI THREE LINKS AND WTO ENTRY: BOFT

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade has adopted several measures to cope with the mini three links, which are scheduled to kick off Jan. 1, 2001, and also Taiwan's World Trade Organization entry, expected later in the year, a BOFT official said Sunday.

The official noted that the BOFT has lifted the import ban in Kinmen and Matsu on some 7,077 items of agricultural, industrial, and fishery products produced in mainland China. These include 2,492 seafood and fishery products, 117 kinds of plants, and 560 items of iron and steel products, he added.

In order to help smooth Taiwan's WTO entry, the BOFT will also issue permission for the importing of 4,791 metric tons of chicken, 1,540 metric tons of pork, and 2,500 metric tons each of cattle and pork offals from the start of January to the start of March, the official said.

As to the quota for car imports on the global basis, the BOFT will issue import permission from Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 2001 for 4,832 sedans, and it will also lift the import ban on second-hand cars beginning Jan. 1, 2001.

The BOFT will also issue import permission for a total of 50,000 metric tons of fruit beginning Jan. 1, 2001. The types of fruit to be permitted entry will include coconuts, apples, oranges, Asian pears, plums, and peaches.
Areas to be permitted to export fruit to Taiwan will include Australia, New Zealand, Chile, Argentina, Japan, the Philippines, the European Union, Malaysia, and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT STATUS QUO CANNOT BE MAINTAINED: FORMER JAPANESE PM
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Ed Chen)

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said Sunday that Beijing must carry out drastic reforms otherwise communism in that country will be unable to continue to exist or be developed further.
Nakasone also predicted that the status quo in the cross-strait situation will be able to be maintained in the future.
He made the remarks while chatting on air on Tokyo television with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara on specific Japanese domestic issues and international issues in general.

Nakasone pointed out that Japan only noted Beijing's claim over Taiwan when it signed a treaty normalizing relations with mainland China, saying that it is very important to stress that Japan did not recognize Beijing's claim.
The prime minister of Japan from November 1982 to November 1987 said that Japan is against Beijing taking Taiwan by force and also wants Taiwan to restrain itself from proclaiming its independence.

The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume their dialogue, and Taiwan should agree to Beijing's request that the issue of the "three direct links" be discussed and decided by both sides, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN HEAD HOPES DIRECT SAILING TO XIAMEN WILL HELP CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Chen Tsui-tsai said Sunday he hopes his own small step will be a big leap toward opening the gates to cross-strait peace.
Chen was referring to his planned direct sailing to Xiamen at the head of a large delegation Jan. 2, representing the first such direct visit in more than five decades.

Chen's trip will come on the heels of the implementation of the "mini three links," referring to the direct trade, postal, and shipping links between Taiwan's frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the mainland Chinese ports of Xiamen and Fuzhou set to go into effect Jan. 1.
He said the 192-member delegation was originally scheduled to make a direct sailing to Xiamen Jan.1, but changed its departure date to Jan. 2 at the request of the mainland host.

On remarks by Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), that the central government will not rule out the possibility of including the local governments of Kinmen and Matsu in a cross-strait consultation team, he said that he would be most willing to join such a team.
Chen also said that the implementation of the "mini three links" will bring short-term business opportunities, including the upgrading of industry and a service sector boom.
Meanwhile, a private shipping operator said Sunday that he will carry around 50 local residents to begin direct sailings to Xiamen Monday morning.
He Chin-liang, the owner of a 20-ton ship, said that he is familiar with the route, adding that the ship will depart for Xiamen at 9:30 a.m. and is expected to arrive on shore by noon.

It is understood that the ship has not applied to the Xiamen port authority for permission to enter, but He said that as both sides have not discussed the issue of direct shipping, there are no standard procedures and he has to obtain the consent from the Xiamen port authority through its counterpart in Xiamen.
He continued that the passengers are tourists who will stay in Xiaman for three days at a cost of NT$5,000 per person before returning Jan. 3.

He also said that he hopes to learn more about the practical problems related to direct shipping after the inaugural sailing and then provide the information as reference for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Both Xiamen and Kinmen were under the jurisdiction of Fujian government before the split of China into two parts in the 1940s civil war. Kinmen, which lies far closer to the mainland than to Taiwan, is now the ROC's frontline of defense against mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC URGED TO PRESS BEIJING TO RELEASE POLITICAL PRISONERS

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has been requested by 28 mainland Chinese dissidents to push Beijing to release political prisoners, a human rights group said here Sunday.

In an open letter released through the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy, the 28 Chinese dissidents asked the IOC to help secure an early release of political prisoners in China, including Wang Youcai, a leader of the outlawed China Democracy Party (CDP).

The Chinese government outlawed the CDP in 1998, and sentenced its leaders to long prison terms. The Chinese persecution of political dissidents is inconsistent with the spirit of Olympic Games, the open letter said.

Beijing is competing with Paris, Istanbul, Osaka, and Toronto for the privilege to host the 2008 Olympic Games. China should be asked to improve its human rights and environmental conditions before the IOC selects in July, 2001 one of the cities to host the games, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER REITERATES GOVT'S DETERMINATION TO STAMP OUT CORRUPTION
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 30 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan on Saturday made it publicly known to overseas Chinese in London the ROC government's determination to crack down on organized crime.

Chen told overseas Chinese during a speech in London that Chen Shui-bian's victory in the March 18 presidential election reflected the fact that the people of Taiwan have spurned organized crime's connection to politics.
The new ROC government has listed the crackdown on organized crime and bribery as well as corruption in politics as its major goals.

Chen, accompanied by his two sons, arrived in London early Saturday morning for the start of a private visit to Europe. Although Chen is making a low-key trip, he was invited by overseas Chinese in London to give a speech on the ROC government's crackdown on corruption in politics. He also answered many questions raised by the audience after his speech.

Chen originally planned to stay in the Untied Kingdom for three days before proceeding to France. However, he canceled the trip to France because his application for a visa was rejected by the French government.
Chen and his sons will now stay in the United Kingdom until Jan. 5. While there, they plan to visit the Greenwich Observatory to welcome the coming of the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES BEING HELD ACROSS TAIPEI TO BRING IN 21ST CENTURY

TEXT.P: A series of parties will be held across Taipei City on Sunday night to celebrate the arrival of the 21st century.

A garden party and a music concert sponsored by President Enterprises Corp. will be held at the Chungshan Football Stadium, with popular singers Chow Hui, Liu Jou-ying, Su Hui-lun, and others performing.
The Voice of Taipei radio station will sponsor a party in Tamshui to bid farewell to the year 2000 and to welcome the new year.

A party being jointly sponsored by the Broadcasting Corporation of China, China Television Co., and China Times Group will be held at the Taipei City Stadium, while a party sponsored by Power989 will be held at Hsimenting in downtown Taipei.
A gala party jointly sponsored by TVBS TV station, Taipei City Government, and the United Daily News Group will be held at the plaza in front of the Taipei City Government.

Meanwhile, a party jointly sponsored by the Government Information Office, Taiwan Television Enterprises, and Public Television will be held at the plaza in front of the presidential office. President Chen Shui-bian is scheduled to deliver a speech at 10 p.m. to those attending the gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH ON GUARD AGAINST COMMUNICABLE DISEASE WITH START OF MINI 3 LINKS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) is on high alert against contagious diseases from the mainland in view of the opening Monday of the "mini three links" across the Taiwan Strait.

The DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control noted that Taiwan citizens traveling to Hong Kong or mainland China over the past three years have mainly contracted dysentery, typhoid fever, or cholera. The main communicable diseases present on the mainland now also include hepatitis A and amebic dysentery, with dengue fever, malaria, and the plague being present in coastal areas.

To prevent any possible inroads into Taiwan by any of these communicable diseases, the inspections operations in Liaolo Harbor on Kinmen and Fuao Harbor on Matsu will be in line with those of international harbors, DOH officials said.

They said that international harbors usually check for the presence of the plague, cholera, and yellow fever, adding that as there have been no cases of yellow fever reported on either side of the Taiwan Strait, the focus of attention will be on the plague and cholera.
The officials said that both Liaolo and Fuao harbors have set up mouse traps and that edible sea products must also have certificates to prove that they have passed cholera tests.

Meanwhile, in view of the fact that Kinmen and Matsu are closer in proximity to the mainland than to Taiwan, residents of these two frontline islands will be able to travel to the mainland in serious or emergency cases, while helicopter services for transporting patients back to Taiwan proper will be cut but not canceled abruptly, DOH officials said.
Kinmen or Matsu residents receiving treatment on the mainland will be able to use their receipts to be reimbursed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance, they said.

More people might travel to the mainland to see Chinese medicine doctors and to take Chinese medicines in the wake of the "mini three links," noted the DOH officials, adding that these medical costs will not be covered by Taiwan's health insurance plan.

An official of the DOH's Committee of Chinese Medicine & Pharmacy also said that Taiwan citizens will be allowed to take back up to 12 different kinds of Chinese medicine, and up to one kilogram of each type, from the mainland for their personal use.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY COUNCIL OKAYS CITY GOV'T BUDGET FOR 2001 FISCAL YEAR

TEXT.P: Taipei City Council early Sunday morning passed the city government budget for the fiscal year 2001 after a 45-hour marathon deliberations..

The council approved expenditures totaling NT$155.8 billion (US$4.72 billion) against revenue totaling NT$142.9 billion, representing a NT$3.9 billion cut over the city government's original proposal.
The city government will issue NT$20 billion in public bonds to meet the NT$21.5 billion deficit.
The council also passed the NT$750 million second preparatory fund after cutting NT$250 million from the original NT$1 billion proposal.

During the marathon deliberations, members of the Democratic Progressive Party and those of the New Party had a physical confrontation, during which NP Legislator Chung Hsiao-ping received a nose injury and DPP Legislator Lo Tsung-sheng hurt his head.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed regret that the incident occurred.
Ma also expressed his gratitude for the support given by the Taipei City Council for the city government's major construction projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT INTEGRATION
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 31 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian Sunday called on Beijing leaders to try to break through the existing cross-strait stalemate with open-mindedness and forward-looking vision so as to jointly establish a mechanism for permanent peace and political integration of Taiwan and the mainland.
Chen made the call in his New Year's message which was broadcast to the nation in the afternoon.
President said that both Taiwan and the mainland are originally members of a single family, adding that they should try to help rather than hurt or even destroy each other.

"We would like to call on the mainland government and leaders to move past the existing cross-strait disputes and stalemate by respecting the Republic of China's intentional living space and dignity and by renouncing the use of military force against Taiwan," Chen said.

"We should, beginning by seeking cross-strait trade, economic and cultural integration, build cross-strait mutual-trust on a gradual basis so as to seek permanent peace and build a new mechanism for political integration between the two sides," the president added.

Chen hailed the conclusions reached by the cross-party task force on policy toward mainland China and pledged to set up a new mechanism to take into account the views of various political groups in working out policies toward Beijing.

Turning to the economic situation, Chen said that although Taiwan successfully weathered the energy crisis of the 1980's and the East Asian financial storm of 1997, it now faces an even graver challenge as a result of the economic downward movement in the United States and Japan, the two largest markets for Taiwan's products.
Urging both the public and private sectors to be well-prepared for the challenge, Chen said that the government will work out a sound plan for Taiwan's economic development for the new century.
Chen also called on various political parties to stop wasting their energy on partisan bickering and join forces to brace for competition from abroad.
Political instability will inevitably disrupt the island's economic development, which is the lifeline of Taiwan, said the president.

Calling reconciliation the order of the new century, Chen promised to keep his mind open and conduct wide-ranging consultations in an effort to reconcile with domestic political parties and the other side of the Taiwan Straits.

On the eve of the 21st century, Chen also briefly recounted the hardships the island has suffered and the marvelous development it has experienced over the last five decades, attributing the latter to what he called the "Taiwan Spirit".
